title: Experts Confer on Rights to Seabed
description: Scientists and legal experts from Europe, Asia, Latin Amer ica and the United States, meeting this weekend at the University of Rhode Island, heard pleas yesterday for a new approach to the idea of national rights over the sea bed and ocean floor.

title: Were Great Composers Paupers? Was J. P. Morgan?
description: How much has musical genius been worth through the ages? Not esthetically, but in dollars and cents, in income per annum? Victori ans liked to believe that the great composers, neglected in their own days, lived in garrets, content to tussle with the muse. They were much too noble, much too greathearted, much too vi sionary to bother themselves about such mundane things as money.

title: Carl Mays and Klein Hall of Fame Eligibles
description: Carl Mays and Chuck Klein are among the leading candidates for admission to the Baseball Hall of Fame to day as the oldtimers' com mittee holds its annual selec tion meeting.

title: Death Penalty Threat Called Possible Incitement to Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) The American Psychiatric As sociation says the threat of the death penalty may incite crime rather than deter it among some persons.

title: Heated Plastic Blind Makes Life Just Ducky for Huntsmen
description: Henry A. Smith, a Richmond businessman and duck hunter, has rebelled against the duck hunting establishment.

title: John Lussen to Wed Miss Sheppard
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Shep pard of the Bronx and Sag Harbor, L. I., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kath leen Sheppard, to John F. Lussen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Lussen of the Bronx and Hampton Bays, L. I.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Senator George S. McGov ern's proposal to give all Amer ican parents allowances of $50 to $65 a month for each child in this country at a cost of $10 to $35 billion a year in or der to eliminate poverty may be good politics but very poor arithmetic. There are over seventy million children in the U.S. below the age of eighteen, so that even taking the lowest McGovern figure, the scheme would cost over $40 billion a year.

title: Inadmissible Witness
description: The refusal of Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman to let Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney Gen eral, testify before the jury in the trial of the Chicago Seven constitutes the ultimate outrage in a trial that has become the shame of American justice. Mr. Clark was kept out of the witness stand after an Assistant United States Attorney held that nothing he could say would possibly be admissible.

title: Gonzales Does It Again; Beats Newcombe Easily
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31 (UPI) Poncho Gonzales, so nearly perfect that he never had to display his famous temper, beat back time for the sec ond week in a row tonight by trouncing John New combe, 64, 64, 62, for the $10,000 winnertakeall prize in the $200,000 Champions Classic series.

title: Budd Unit Formed
description: The Budd Company has announced that the Budd Financial Corporation has been created a whollyowned subsidiary. J. J. Colliigan has been named president of the new subsidiary to be based in Wilmington, Del. Budd Financial initially will service the installment financing originated by the Gindy Manufacturing Corporation, the Budd subsidiary produc ing highway truck trailers and cargo containers.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to Oxford 53511 unill 11 P.M. in suburban offices, 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newerk (201) Market 33900; White Plains (914) White Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) Ivanhos 36660; Commack (516) 5435000; Stamford (203) 3187767.

title: It's Players' Serve Next
description: THE South African question seems certain to be among the topics for discussion at the meetings of the Interna tional Tennis Players Associa tion this week, John New combe said yesterday.

title: Award Slated for Rozelle
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 31 (AP) The Wsconsin chapter of the Professional Football Writers of America announced today that its meritorious service award would go to the pro football commissioner, Pete Rozelle.

title: Looking Ahead to Spring
description: THE spring flower show dates for the East Coast are as follows: National Capital Flower and Gar den Show, D.C. Armory March 615; International Flower Show, New York Coli seum, March 715; Philadel phia Flower Show, Civic Cen ter, March 1522; New Eng land Spring Garden and Flow er Show, Suffolk Dowps, East Boston, March 1422 and New Jersey Flower and Garden Show, Morristown National Guard Armory, April 39.

title: Illicit Traffic in Cocaine Growing by Leaps and Bounds in Miami
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31More and more cocaine, worth millions of dollars, is being smuggled Into the United States from Latin America, much of it through this area, according to Federal law enforcement offi cials and narcotics agents.

title: Blood, Blasphemy And Laughs
description: IT'S easy to understand why an increasing number of drama critics seem to look longingly at the world of film when, as in the rather ordinary week just past, without an inordinate amount of preopening publicity, and certainly without the sense of desperation that surrounds the Broadway premiere of something like Coco, there appear in movie theaters two films on the order of Luis Bunuel's The Milky Way and Robert Altman's M*A*S*H.

title: Television
description: THE average television viewer whose only concern is what he sees on the screen can relax for a few years in light of all the legalistic and technical arguments about the future of satellite TV. The latest of House memorandum on the use of space essentially promises only one thing  more delay  after which it would take at least two years to get satellite TV system operating.

title: Art Mailbag
description: Time for MOMA to Have Children?

title: Almost All Cubans Cut Cane In a Drive for a Sugar Record
description: HAVANA (AP)  Premier F1 del Castro has staked the pres tige of his revolution on a drive to harvest a record 10million ton sugar crop this year. Prac tically every Cuban, including Mr. Castro, is taking a turn in the fields.

title: RADIOTODAY'S LEADING EVENTS
description: Talk, Sports, Special Events

title: February
description: There is a tendency in some quarters to approach February with what must be called groundhog psy chology. To believe that the worse it looks, the better it will be; to consider sunshine a bad omen and a forecast of trouble and lots of it. Which, of course, nonsense. Tomorrow is Groundhog Day, but even it is shrouded in clouds five miles thick it won't be the last day of winter. If we stand by legend and fable it is far more credible to say that you have to earn spring by enduring January and February.

title: Boom War May Break More Than Mideast Windows
description: JERUSALEM  The Middle East reverberated last week to the relatively routine thunder of a sonic boom. This one was made by a Syrian MIG21 over Haifa, however. It was the first such Arab aerial incursion since the 1967 war.

title: Italy Gets '71 Title Sledding
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 31 (AP)Cervinia, Italy, was formally awarded the 1971 world bobsled championships after Italy advised the Interna tional Bobsled Federation that funds were assured, federation officials said today.

title: 11Race CanadianAmerican Cup Series Will Carry $1Million in warths
description: 11Race CanadianAmerican Cup Series Will Carry $1Million in warths

title: U.S. Business
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31A 20 to 35 per cent rise In prbduce prices, is pre dicted for Northern consum ers, according to growers and distributors at the Pom pano State Farmers Market.

title: Counseling on Marijuana Is Urged
description: The chairman of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission suggested yester day that the police use counsel ing procedures instead of ar rests in cases involving youths under 18 who are caught ex perimenting with marijuana.

title: DEMOCRATS INVITE ALABAMA BLACKS
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 31 Liberal Democrats opened the state's party leadership to blacks today for the first time this century and in passing handed former Gov. George C. Wallace an unusual political de feat inside Alabama.

title: Carter On the Record
description: WHAT is a repertory piece? Elliott Carter says he isn't sure. He thinks too many people dismiss contemporary works out of hand because they do not find a place in the repertory. Yet his own Double Concerto for Harpsi chord, Piano and Two Cham ber Ensembles has had five performances recently. Does not that make it a repertory piece? His Piano Concerto has been played by Jacob La teiner in Boston, Minneapolis, Chicago, Buffalo, Berlin and Cleveland and is scheduled shortly for Amsterdam, Paris and London.

title: TopSeeded Pair Advances In Open Squash Racquets
description: Mohibullah Khan, last year's professional champion, and Colin Adair, the 1963 amateur champion, advanced to the semifinals of the David C. John son Jr. Memorial open squash racquets doubles tournament at Heights Casino yesterday.

title: Label War: Inflation Hot Issue
description: Will consumer protection inflate consumer prices?

title: The Week in Finance:
description: THERE was a pervasive spirit of gloombut no panic in Wall Street last week as the stock market con tinued its winter plunge to the lowest levels in more than six years. Despondency was rampant as the leading stock averages sustained their worst weekly losses in six months and the bond market suffered another period turmoil, with interest rates soaring and prices slipping.

title: Plan for Black Museum Starts Dispute
description: A proposed museum devoted to black history and culture has started a controversy over whether the institution should be established in a black, white or integrated community.

title: I Was Fed Up With Hollywood Fantasies
description: IF you think you have troubles, turn on Chan nel 13 at 10:30 tomorrow flight and see Hospital, Frederick Wiseman's new 90 minute documentary. It may make you feel lucky just to be alive. It isn't easy to Watch a freakedout kid on a bad mescaline trip vomit his guts all over the floor and hear him scream, I dawanna die.

title: Dog Show Calendar
MISS PAGE AND BENT TAKE SLALOM RACES
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Jan. 31Paula Page, a diminu tive 19yearold blueeyed blonde from Mammoth Lakes, Calif., won the first leg of the fourth annual Corcoran Cup to day by outclassing a field of 42 top Class A girl competitors including seve nmembers of the United States national B team.

title: Costa Ricans Go to Polls Today, Proud of Democratic Traditions
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 31A young Costa Rican tour ist official, recently graduated from college in the United States, today recalled the typi cal American question about his country that caused him the most chagrin.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE problem of safely and securely hanging a large mirror  or very large picture frameon a wall (or door) is one that often seems a particularly knotty one to the homeowner or apartment dweller who is faced with a proiect of this kind.

title: Can SALT stop MIRV?
A Very Fine Young Actor, But . . .
description: I DON'T know whether Conrad Bromberg's bill of three oneacters called Transfers is likely to make a run of it at the Off Broadway Village South or not. If it does, I don't think Ron Leibman should be al lowed to play in it more than once a week. He'll kill him self.

title: Ross, Van Nostrand Gain Metropolitan Tennis Final
description: Steve Ross of Brooklyn and King Van Nostrand of Bright waters, L. I., reached the final of the Metropolitan men's in door tennis championship last night at the Hiway Club in Brooklyn.

title: Article 2  No Title
Steinbeck's Of Mice and Men Goes Operatic
description: SEATTLE.

title: Parochial School to Close
description: MILTON, Mass., Jan. 31 (AP) Another parochial school, Jeanne D'Arc Academy, in the Boston Roman Catholic Arch diocese will close its doors. The academy, which had class es for grades one through 12, will be shut down in June, 1971, after 40 years. The an nouncement said the closing is forced by a shortage of new members entering the order of nuns that teach at the school.

title: News of the Rialto
description: IN the cast of Israel Horovitz's new play, the leading character is called Hero. That's a lot simpler than Horovitz's title which, you should pardon his chutzpah, is The World's Greatest Play. It will be in town in March, sponsored by Hillard Elkins, whose assets are currently being bolstered by Oh! Calcutta! and the film, Alice's Restaurant.

title: Flight of Dissident In Taiwan Spurs Inquiry by Police
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 31In the week since the Government discovered that Prof. Peng Mingmin, a leading advocate of Taiwanese independence from Chinese Nationalist rule, had escaped from Taiwan, the security police have been con ducting an intensive investiga tion to learn how he man aged it.

title: Movies
description: THOSE of us who spent our most formative years during that decade which we already refer to with nostalgia as the sixties celebrated the New Year by jettisoning all kinds of paraphernalia. We unloaded all the great childhood gadgets and emotional trinkets which couldn't make it into the seventies without showing signs of appalling age.

title: Writers Honor 3 Mets Tonight
description: The Mets will take starring roleson the dais and on the stage  tonight when New York's baseball writers hold their 47th annual dinner and follies at the Americana.

title: McQuade of St. John's Takes Run in Jersey City Again
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 31Auto mobiles were kept out of Jour nal Square for 45 minutes today as 60 runners competed in the second annual 5.2mile run for the Hudson County Heart As sociation.

title: Police Flag Pins Approved
description: BOSTON Jan. 31 (AP)Pol ice Commissioner Edmund L. McNamara has issued an order allowing Boston policemen to wear, on a voluntary basis, a small pin depicting the Ameri can Flag as part of the uni form. Under Mr. McNamara's order of Thursday, the flag pin may not be larger than a square inch. It may be worn on the left lapel of the outer uniform or on the tab of the uniform shirt.

title: T.V.A. Is Seeking to Give Lead in Pollution Control
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 31Int he sevenstate Ten nasee Valley region, the Tennessee Valley Authority is trying to set an exanple and do something about air and water pollution.

title: Skiers Flock to Slopes In the Metropolitan Area
description: McAFEE, N. J.Operators or many metropolitan New YorkNew Jer sey ski centers, encouraged by heavy turnouts so far this winter, are already making plans to expand their facilities in time for the 197071 season. Attendance at the Great Gorge area here and at adjoining Vernon Valley has hit a combined oneday total of 6,000 on more than one occasion.

title: WAY'S LEAP OF 157 WINS SKI JUMPING
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan 31  Fred Way, who coats aluminum products all week for an anodizer firm in Beacon, N.Y., just across the Hudson, and who seldom has time to practice jumping, scored his most notable success as a cont. petitive skier today.

title: Pop
description: HE padded to the door of his manager's Cen tral Park West apart ment, a tall, slim young man of 26 looking like an African Eskimo in knee high fox fur boots, cut vel vet knickers and a red satin shirt with 20inch fringe on the sleeves. He inclined his head of exploded kinky hair, grinned shyly until the tips of his smile touched his Muttonchop whiskers and reached out a long, bony hand and said. I'm Sly.

title: Did Blyth End or Start Something?
description: Paul Devlin once said: If I have one asset, it's a sense of markets. Mr. Devlin as the chairman of Blyth & Co., Inc., which quit the New York Stock Exchange last week.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collectors from more than 100 coun tries who flooded Unit ed States post office facilities with orders for firstday cancellations of the Apollo 11 Moon Landing stamp, created a record 8, 743,070 firstday covers. The stamp was issued September 9, 1969, at Washington, to commemorate the first moon landing on July 20, 1969. Neil Armstrong and Col. Ed win E. Aldrin Jr., were in the landing module Eagle, while Col. Michael Collins circled the moon in the par ent craft, Apollo 11.

title: Marjorie P. Cummings Is Married
description: NEWTON, N. J., Jan. 31 Miss Marjorie Priscilla Cum mings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benton Pierce Cum mings, was married here to day to Thor Fredrik Wilcox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Wilcox of Cambridge, Mass., where his father is dean of general education at Harvard.

title: Imokalee, Bought Day Before, Captures Stakes at Bowie and Returns $12
description: Imokalee, Bought Day Before, Captures Stakes at Bowie and Returns $12

title: Castor Oil Thief Charged
description: VANCOUVER, Wash., Jan. 31 (AP)  A 17yearold boy was arrested Monday for shop lifting at a local supermarket. The police said he took two bottles of castor oil.

title: MASS EVACUATION PLANNED IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 31 The United States is planning an evacuation of thousands of civilians in the Plaine des Jarres next week in the expectation of a counteroffensive by Commu nist forces.

title: Roberta Craig Wed To Craig Jameson
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 31 Miss Roberta Elizabeth Craig, on assistant costume jewelry buyer for B. Altman & Co. in New York, was mar ried here today to Craig Eugene Jameson, a lawyer with Dewey, Ballantine, Bush by, Palmer & Wood there.

title: Marine Club Elects Chief
description: The Marine Square Club has announced the election of Ed ward A. Engebretson, national sales manager of I.T.T. Mackay Marine, as president. The club is an organization of 4,400 men in the Masonic fraternity who are affiliated with the marine industry.

title: Art
description: A NEW exhibition called The Neglected 19th Century at the Shick man Gallery is the latest symptom of current Interest in a group of paint ers who, of all discredited schools, have seemed the least likely to make a come back. With the masters of the French Salon it has been not merely a case of big reputa tions fading away. These men have been actively detested for half a century. Anyone who took his art survey course more than five or ten years ago, unless he took it under a most exceptional instructor, must remember that when men like the superacademician Jean Leon Gerome were mentioned at all, they were made the butt of jokes (to which they are often wide open) or were cast as villains who from en trenched positions of official patronage, persecuted the ad venturous young impression igts whose posthumous re venge it is to have succeeded the stars of the Salon as popular idols.

title: Sports of The Times
description: TOM GORMAN, a local boy from the Fordham Road section of the Bronx, made good in the big leaguesas an umpire. The New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association will rule him safe at home tonight at the Hotel Ameri cana during their annual eatinganddrink ing talkathon. He will be honored when he is presented the Bill Slocum Award for long and distinguished service to base ball.

title: The legacy of the Madureiras
description: Everybody knows about the stupendous resources of Brazil and their almost total neglect. It was a Brazilian in Brasilia, apologizing to me for the empti ness of the most modern parlia mentary buildings in the world, who asked whether I was fam iliar with the saying Brazil is the country with the great est futureand always will be. Nowhereexcept in the classic Brazilian writers, Machado de Assis, Euclides da Cunha, and Guimaraes Rosais this dis crepancy examined with more sensitivity than in Mrs. Geld's novel. One could only, in fact, charge Mrs. Geld with being too sympathetic to Brazil's weak nesses: more inclined than those three toughminded na tive novelists to glorify the sensual, tolerant lifestyle of the landed gentry, more lenient with political primitivism as an almost desirable alternative to our own dehumanizing effi ciency. But from an outlander this bias is commendable, and Mrs. Geld's love of everything Brazilian is contagious.

title: Stocks Decline Sharply On Amex and OTC List
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over  the  counter market took their worst beating in months last week, as many issues declined sharply in moderate trading.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: A number of trains were canceled and weekend visitors to the city were inconvenienced yesterday by the anticipated nationwide suspension of rail service before a Federal Court

title: Fire Bond Issue Voted
description: SOUTH. BURLINGTON, Vt., Jan. 31 (AP)A $180,000 bond issue to finance the establish ment of a town fire department has been favored overwhelm ingly by the South Burlington voters. The vote Friday was 1,018 to 123 for the proposal, which is intended to raisefunds to build a station, buy three fire trucks, and provide two fulltime paid employes who would be Assisted by volun teers.

title: Alien Fiance Rule Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A little early for Valentine's Day, the House Immigration Subcommittee paid its respects to love this week, voting to facilitate the entry of American citizen's alien fiancs. The bill, cleared Tuesday, would allow fiancs to come to the United States provided they married within 90 days.

title: $82,874 in Diamonds Stolen In a Holdup Near Kennedy
description: Two packages of diamonds valued at $82,874 were stolen yesterday by hijackers near Kennedy International Airport half an hour before the gems were to be placed aboard a Japan Airlines flight to Tokyo.

title: Condominiums Received Coolly By Manhattan
description: WHILE condominium apartments flourish around the country, their popularity has yet to take root in Manhattan, where the cooperative form of ownership has been entrenched for more than half a century.

title: Paris Peace Opening
description: A high Pentagon official of the Johnson and early Nixon Administrations, who worked on the secret Paris negotiations on Vietnam, believes the North Vietnamese may now be trying to tell the United States how to break the deadlock in the peace talks.

title: Whooping Cranes Total 56
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) A late arrival at the Arkan sas National Wildlife Refuge in Texas has increased the wild whooping crane population to new high of 56, according to the Interior Department.

title: CADET TRACKMEN ROUT PENN STATE
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31 Army's track team won 10 of 13 events today against Penn State and rolled to its fifth vic tory in six meets this season. The score was 8128.

title: Frazier Upset by Training Setup at the Felt Forum
description: A distressed Joe Frazier began the final two weeks of training in the Felt Forum yesterday for his heavyweight bout with Jimmy Ellis.

title: Speaking of Books: The Trick of Author as Character
description: I have always thought that one of the greatest problems a regular literary critic has to face is the effect on him of having to read more novels than could be expected of any normal man in his right senses. It seems to me that an almost in evitable consequence of this over dose would be to develop in him a greater need for innovation in the form and structure of the novel than would be felt by the lay reader. I am sure that if I had to read two or three novels a day, or even one, I would reach the position of Richard Gilman who is anxious to dispose of both plot and character as old fashioned devices. But the need for change is even felt in such a balanced and judicious critic as Christopher LehmannHaupt.

title: Student Loan Crisis May Block Return Of Many to College
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Anticipating increased Fed eral funds from the vetoed educational appropriations bill, college officials have overcom mitted themselves on, student loans with the result that tens of thousands of students may not be able to return to school next month.

title: PENN TURNS BACK CORNELL BY 6460
description: ITHACA, Jan. 31 Pennsyl vania won its first basketball game at Cornell's Farson Hall since 1959 today, 6460, but only after a late press cut down an inspired Big Red effort.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GERTZMANWllilam. The family of Wil liam Gertzman wishes to thank the many relatives and friends for their donations and kind expressions of condolences.

title: F.T.C. Tests Find Scarves From Japan Flammable
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion says it has found certain sheer rayon and silk scarves imported from Japan to be flammable.

title: Golf Writers to Honor Miss Caponi at Dinner
description: Donna Caponi, winner of the United States women's open golf tournament last year and the third leading money winner on the wom en's tour, will be honored at the annual awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writ ers' Association on Feb. 23.

title: Tugboat Men Will Meet Today to Weigh a Strike
description: Negotiations to avert a strike by tugboat crews in the city wire suspended yesterday. The crews' contract expires at mid night, and their union will meet today to discuss the next move.

title: Miss Tindale To Be a Bride
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 31Miss Deborah Frost Tin dale, daughter of Mrs. John Lingard Tindale 2d, of Harts dale and the late Mr. Tindale, and Ira Alan Bartfield, son of Mrs. Estelle Bartfield of Rego Park, Queens, plan to be married June 13.

title: Redmen Rally in 2d Half
description: St. John's University's bas ketball team bounced back from a midweek overtime loss to Providence to run away from Pittsburgh last night, 6758, in Alumni Hall before 3,730 fans.

title: RUTGERS TRACKMEN TOP COLUMBIA, 5752
description: The Rutgers track and field team beat Columbia, 5752, in a dual meet at the Baker Field Airdome yesterday. The Scarlet Knights now have a 11 won lost record for trie indoor track season, while Columbia is 111.

title: Music
description: NOT the Russians but an American orchestra gave the United States premiere of the Symphony No. 13  the socalled Babi Yar Symphony  by Dimitri Shostakovich. The Moscow Symphony Orchestra is in the process of an American tour  indeed, it is in New York City as these lines are being written  but its programs are made up largely of standard 19th and early 20thcentury works. Whatever it is giving us of 20thcentury Russian music is on the safe side  the Eighth Sym phony of Shostakovich, wellknown pieces by Prokofiev, and one or two minor tid bits by younger composers. If antibody wants to know what currently is going on in musical Russia, the Moscow Sym phony is a good place to stay away from. And so Eugene Ormandy and the Philadel phia Orchestra were responsible, last Jan. 20, for the Babi Yar Symphony.

title: APPEAL WEIGHED ON SCHOOL LINES
description: The Board of Education was expected to decide over the weekend whether or not to ap peal a State Supreme Court decision on Friday that voided the new decentralized school district lines for Manhattan.

title: Ruritania on the Potomac
description: Inspired, it was said, by President Nixon's observation of foreign police attire during his European tour last winter, the new whitetunicked, goldbraided, pillboxhatted ceremo nial uniform for the White House police was an instant flop with the nation's editorial writers when it was premiered during British Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Washington visit last week. To the Washington Star the men looked like West German traffic policemen: One's first inclination ... is to ask, Wo ist der Bahnhof? (Where is the railroad sta tion?) The Cleveland Plain Dealer thought they looked more like generals in the banana republics to the south of us. To the Chicago Daily. News they were like movie characters in a rerun of Graustark or The Student Prince, the Detroit News found them un usual but ghastly, while the Buffalo Evening News said even ushers at oldtime movie palaces were garbed with greater restraint and better taste. Ruritania, D.C., scoffed The New York Times. That Vice President Agnew would seek to mobilize the silent ma jority against all this effete snobbery was dismissed as an unfounded rumor.

title: Stephanie S. deSibour Plans Wedding to L. S. Stinchcomb
description: ST. MICHAEL'S, Md., Jan. 31Mr. and Mrs. Tom Rush Ragland Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rag land's daughter, Miss Step hanie Stirling deSibour, to Lawrence S. Stinchcomb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Stinchcomb of Bel Air.

title: New Baby Boom Is Reported in City
description: A new baby boom has be gun in New York City, the Health Department reported yesterday, with expectations that it may reach record levels despite expanded efforts to provide family planning.

title: Sob follows sigh, grin after groan after grunt
description: How can one describe it? That simplehearted, linsey woolsey Knickerbocker dame of 25 West 43rd St. has rounded up her small fry, her naked poems, and thrown them out on their own. Wellproduced on thin cream bond with spruce green endpapers, like a snowy day on Mount Fuji or an after noon on the Provincetown dunes, her book is as pleasant, solid and uninvidious an object as wit could devise, its more than 900 poems arranged al phabetically by title, with an index of authors and dates in backan elegantly democratic compromise if ever there was one.

title: PENN'S TRACKMEN BEAT YALE, BROWN
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31Penn sylvania defeated Yale in an indoor track meet for the first time today, with Brown finish ing third in a triangular com petition.

title: Still Young at 362
description: ALTHOUGH it is 362 years old, Montever di's Orfeo has not lost its power to stir the listener, at least when it is so faithfully and lov ingly recreated as it is in the newly recorded per formance prepared and led by Nikolaus Harnoncourt (three disks, Das Alte Werk, SKH 21).

title: Two Accept Giant Contracts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (UPI)Tito Fuentes and Alan Gallagher, infielders signed to day with the San Francisco Giants.

title: Marketing Deal Set
description: The Stauffer Chemical Company and Resource Con trol, Inc., have completed an agreement giving Stauffer exclusive marketing rights within the metal finishing industry in the United States for Resource Control's new water pollution control unit and system.

title: End of von Braun Era Feared By Spacemen of Huntsville
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Jan. 31 Dr. Wernher von Braun has lived for 12 years in a secluded foot of the area's highest hill and at the edge of an enclave of German rocket specialists.

title: FORMER RESISTER AWAITING DRAFT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan, 31 Erik Whitehorn, who once went to jail in a flurry of publicity because his mother told him not to register for the draft, now is out and registered.

title: Confrontation In The Everglades
description: MIAMIIt seemed the only logical, sensible course of action. Thirtynine square miles were pur chased in central South Florida, S13million was spent, a landing strip for training flights was constructed. Florida desperately, obviously, needed a new jetport; the site beside Everglades National Park was eminently reasonablewithin swift reach of the booming cities on both coasts, once expressways were constructed.

title: 7th Buffet and Fair Will Aid the Blind
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 31The Garden City League for Industrial Home for the Blind will hold its seventh annual antiques fair and sale preview and buffet supper on Feb. 8 in the Gar den City Hotel.

title: Huston's Young Man
description: JOHN HUSTON gets busier and busier. In recent months he has directed Sinful Davey, A Walk With Love and Death and The Kremlin Let ter, which opens here today. And he has acted in de Sitde and the upcoming war film The S.O.B.'s. Not to mention the already legendary Myra Breckinridge.

title: David Eisenhower Breaks Tradition and Joins Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  David Eisenhower, grand son of a fivestar general of the Army, broke with two generations of family tradition today and joined the Navy Reserve for six years. I've got a couple of old uniforms you can use, President Nixon, a former naval officer, told his sonin law at an informal White House induction ceremony. David, the husband of Mr. Nixon's daughter Julie, is to report to officer's candidate school at Newport, R.I., in late summer or early fall after his graduation from Amherst College. The Presi dent and his daughter at tended the swearing in by Capt. Phil Green, Deputy Di rector of Naval Recruiting. Later, Mr. Nixon, along with the young Eisenhowers, flew to Camp David, Md., in the Catoctin Mountains for an overnight stay.

title: POLICE WIN $10,525 IN PORTLAND, ORE.
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 31 The executive board of the Portland Police Association has accepted the city's offer to pay policemen $10,525 a year in wages and benefits.

title: HIGH COSTS RANK 2D IN ISSUES POLL
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31 In the year since President Nixon took office, the high cost of living has risen from fourth to second place among the most important problems facing the American people, accord ing to the Gallup Poll.

title: B'NAI B'RITH ACCUSES MOSCOW OVER JEWS
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith denounced the Soviet Union yesterday over the continuing agony of So viet Jews.The study said that world opinion forced the Kremlin to speak out (and against) Soviet Jewry's complaints of anti Semitism and there was noticeable voice of protest from Jews inside the Soviet Union in 1969.

title: Margaret Schmitt Prospective Bride
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J., Jan. 31Mr. and Mrs. Julius H. Schmitt have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Schmitt, to Leonard J. Sterba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Sterba of Rve. N. Y.

title: Federal Judge Resigns
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)  Chief Judge William J. Camp bell of United States District Court here has announced he is resigning effective March 19, when he will reach the age of 65. Judge Campbell, on the Fed eral bench in the Northern District of Illinois since 1940, said in a statement Tuesday that his resignation had been accented by President Nixon.

title: GOODELL CAUTIOUS ON HIS CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Jn. 31De spite the lingering threat that he may have to fight for his own party's nomination, Sena tor Charles E. Godell is mov ing cautiously in assembling his election campaign machinery.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: THE First National City Bank has come to the rescue of the stalled 225 acre Blue Hill office develop ment in Rockland County, N. Y., which had left the Uris Buildings Corporation abashed because of the lack of adequate initial construc tion financing.

title: Education
description: In folklore, the Ivy League colleges are the symbol of old schooltie tradition and rigidity. Their leadership is seen as the mirror image of the Establish ment  conservative, Protes tant, 1776 and all that.

title: Vanessa: Are People Right?
description: I BEGAN to realize, when taking part in demonstra tions and when people asked me questions, that I had to work out why I was doing what I was doing and what I thought. I was asked questions way be yond my capacity to answer except in an instinctual way, and I started reading up and I realized that every thing I'd been taught was just absolute rubbish.

title: New Port Head on Coast Calls for Modernization
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (AP)Miriam E. Wolff, the first woman to head the Port of San Francisco, has never sailed on a ship but she, says shipping will never be re placed by air transportation.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Announcements

title: Panel Proposes Widening of Foreign Policy Process
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31A panel of prominent citizens headed by former Justice Arthur J. Goldberg proposed a five point program today to improve the manner in which the Presi dent, Congress and concerned citizens take part in making foreign policy in the years after the Vietnam war.

title: But It Isn't A Nice Experience
description: EARLIER this season I devoted a column to inquiring where all the playwrights were, our theaters being so very uncrowded at the moment. Actually, I was asking where all the hit playwrights were, i.e., those who'd been markedly successful, weren't yet overage, but had disappeared nonetheless, Naturally, when the piece appeared quite a few letters came flying in, some from those very play wrights I was being nosy about. These good souls explained that (a) they were sitting it out in Switzerland until Jerzy Grotawski went away, or (b) sweating it out in Holly wood until nudity went away, or (c) sleeping it out in Menninger's until I went away.

title: Toomey, Left Off Original Nominee List, Is Chosen as Winner of Sullivan Award
description: Bill Toomey, whose name had been omitted from the original list of candidates, was announced yesterday as the winner of the 40th annual James E. Sullivan Memorial Award as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete of 1969.

title: Perfect pairing
description: Some foods have a natural affinity for other foods (and drinks): for instance, vodka and caviar, foie gras and a highly chilled, genuine Sauternes, garlic and snails, pasta and cheesethe list seems endless. And here is a new entry, a sauce that bears a rapport with pork chops unlike any other. Known as sauce charcuterie, it is a savory sauce made with vinegar and mustard and finely chopped pickles, ideal for winter.

title: Carswell Hearing Seeks Data On 1964 Florida Rights Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  A Senate Judiciary Committee subpoena has been served on a Justice Department lawyer who is expected to corroborate a Rutgers University law profes sor's testimony that G. Har rold Carswell was hostile to civil rights workers and their counsel in a 1964 case.

title: Record in Strikes Expected By Chamber of Commerce
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)  The United States Chamber of Commerce predicts an allout labormanagement slugfest in contract negotia tions this year that will prob ably result in a record number of strikes.

title: GA. TECH DEFEATS
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Jan. 31 (AP)In a bas ketball game stressing ball con trol and tight defenses, Geor gia Tech defeated Air Force today, 5148.

title: Los Angeles Times Official
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP) Robert J. Donovan, chief of The Los Angeles Times Wash ington bureau, was named an associate editor of the news paper today by the publisher, Otis Chandler. Mr. Donovan, born in Buffalo, in 1912, began his career as a copy boy for the Buffalo CourierExpress in 1933. In 1939 he joined the New York Herald Tribune. He be came the Los Angeles Times Washington bureau chief in 1963.

title: 50 Soccer Fans Injured After Barrier Gives Way
description: STOKE ON TRENT, England, Jan. 31 (AP)Nearly 50 soccer fans were taken to a hospital with injuries today after crowd barriers gave way at the Stoke CityLeeds United game.

title: What a complicated machine an Old School European is
description: At 70 plus, Artur Sammler is old enough to be metaphysical. Beyond desire, beyond competition, with nothing further to gain or prove, he lives in that twilight zone of the human condition where philosophy, poetry and parody shade into each other. Rescued by his nephew, Dr. Gruner, from a D.P. camp in Salzburg and supported by him, Sammler makes a fulltime job of trying to interpret life now in New York City.

title: Portrait of the mayor as benevolent superman
description: If the late 1950's and early 1960's were not a golden age in the gener ally gloomy history of American cities, they are at least beginning to appear, in retrospect, as a brief sunlit hour, a time when hope and energy and confidence flourished. In city after city, there was renewed belief that although the problems were formidable, they could be over come. Under the leadership of an astonishing variety of mayors, gen uine headway was being made.

title: Observer: The Longest Four Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31One man's appointment calendar for February:

title: Westmoreland Says Soviet All But Closes Missile Gap
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 31 (UPI)Gen. William C. West moreland, Army Chief of Staff, said today that the Soviet Union had all but closed the missile gap and was fast approaching parity with the United States in Polaristype submarines.

title: Morton Sees No Great Stir if Lindsay Became a Democrat
description: Rogers C. B. Morton, the Re publican national chairman, said yesterday that he did not think it would cause a great stir if Mayor Lindsay decided to become a Democrat.

title: Anticrime Bill Is Opposed By Texas Liberties Group
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 31 The Texas Civil Liberties Union is asking Texas Representatives to reject the organized crime control bill passed last week by the United States Senate.

title: Columbia Downs C.C.N.Y. In Wrestling Match, 345
description: The Columbia wrestling team won eight of 10 bouts, three by pins, to rout City College, 345, yesterday in the Lions' gymnasium.

title: Religion
description: It would have been unthink able a few years ago, but last week the Episcopal Church's Board for Theological Educa tion recommended that the church close at least six of its seminaries. Not that the Epis copal Church is having trouble attracting young men with vo cations; its seminary enroll ments have actually been con sistent over the past decade about 1,000. The problem was one of money. There were still too few seminarians in too many schools. The budget just won't it more.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS DELAY OF 10 DAYS IN RAIL SHUTDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The United States District Court here tonight headed off a national railroad shutdown for at least 10 days.

title: Stage: Puppet Theater
Top Skiers Strike Over Safety Issue At Kandahar Meet
description: GARMISCH, Germany, Jan. 31The world's leading men ski racers went on strike today and forced postponement of the Arlberg Kandahar downhill because of poor visibility.

title: Chargers List Bears Aug. 24
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 31 (UPI) The San Diego Chargers said today they would play the Chi cago Bears in preseason pro football at San Diego Stadium Aug. 24. The Bears will be the third preseason opponents in a sixexhibition slate planned by the Chargers. The Dallas Cow boys will play here Aug. 8 and the New York Giants Aug. 15.

title: Bruins Deadlock Canadiens, 33, on Esposito's Second Goal in Final Period
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 31 (UPI) Phil Esposito scored twice for his 27th and 28th goals of the season tonight and the Boston Bruins gained a 33 tie with the Montreal Canadiens. The result left the teams in a secondplace deadlock in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Millionaire to Oppose Kirk
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 31 Jack M. Eckerd, a Clearwater millionaire, will hold a news conference here Wednesday to announce that he will be a Re publican candidate for Gov ernor, opposing Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. in the September pri maries.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
INTERNS WAIVED FOR 2 SPECIALTIES
description: Medical students, beginning with this year's graduating class, no longer need to intern before gaining professional cer tification as psychiatrists or neurologists.

title: Indeed, it is difficult to understand why Stalin denounced Platonov
description: The Fierce and Beautiful World is a striking but somewhat mislead ing title for this collection of stories, the first publication in English of Andrei Platonov's work. There is not much fierceness in Platonov, and his beauty is likely to be a beauty of abstract strength, moral stability, celebration of virtues that are per haps now as oldfashioned in Russia as they are in the West  the equa tion of a man's soul with the larger, collective and holy soul of his na tion.

title: Gifts to Neediest Fund Survive Weather and MidTerm Delays
description: Friends of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are still sending contributions to the 58th Christmastime ap peal.

title: AMERICANA IS 2D IN FLORIDA EVENT
description: VENICE, Fla., Jan. 31Ted Turner's former America's Cup defense bidder, American Eagle, won today's 105mile, St. Pe tersburgtoVenice yacht race, the opening event, on the 1970 Southern Ocean Racing Con ference circuit.

title: Pastor Seeks School Post
description: STEVENS POINT, Wis., Jan. 31 (AP) Msgr. James P. Finu can, pastor of St. Joseph's Ro man Catholic church, is a candi date for a seat on the school board here. His nomination papers were circulated by the Rev. Vern Holtan, pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church.

title: FRENCH DOMINATE MODERN ART SALE
description: An assortment of modern paintings, drawings and sculp turemostly Frenchwill be auctioned on Wednesday at 2 P.M. in the first of three sales at the ParkBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: Renewed Guatemalan Violence Marks the Approach of Election
description: GUATEMALA, Jan. 31 (Reu ters)Guatemala, a traditional Central American battlefield for extremists of the left and right, is moving nervously to ward general elections on March 1 amid a terrorist cam paign of bombings and assas sinations.

title: Michigan G.O.P. Lists 2 Romneys Among 25 Potential Candidates
description: ST. CLAIR, Mich., Jan. 31 Michigan's Republican leaders chose 25 potential candidates today for the Senate race this fall, with George and Lenore Romney heading the list.

title: Marcos Says Attack on Palace, Fatal to 5, Was Subversive Act
description: MANILA, Jan. 31President Ferdinand E. Marcos today characterized the student attack on the presidential palace last night as an, act of rebellion and subversion aimed at the destruction and seizure of the seat of the central Govern ment.

title: Elizabeth Alsop Fiancee Of Walter B. Mahony 3d
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Miss Elizabeth Winthrop Alsop, a senior at Sarah Lawrence College, end Wal ter Butler Mahony, 3d, a Princeton graduate, plan to be married an June 13.

description: James Davis, president, Glencove (L. I.) Chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., and Stanley Hausen, lawyer for, the New Ridge Civic Association, Woodbury, L. I., Public Hear ing, Channel 2, 11:30 A.M.

title: Tapes of F.B.I. Show Two Mafiosi Gave Conflicting Versions of an Execution
description: When two selfdescribed par ticipants in a murder give sharply conflicting versions of how the deed was done, it is evident that at least one of them is lying.

title: Bomb on Saigon Plane
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (AP)A grenade devised as a time bomb was discovered in the washroom of an Air Viet nam jet today. There were 86 passengers and a crew of seven aboard the Boeing F2F, which had flown from Danang to Saigon. As the plane was taxiing toward the airport ter minal a stewardess noticed smoke, opened the door of a restroom and found a package.

title: Unbeaten N.Y.U. Wrestlers Rally to Beat Seton Hall
description: Trailing 1311, after the first six bouts, New York Univer sity's wrestling team swept the last four and defeated Seton Hall, 2513, yesterday at Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: List of Forthcoming Entertainment Benefit Parties
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: Article 4  No Title
Retired U.S. Aide to Head Fund for the Handicapped
description: The election of Miss Mary E. Switzer as vice president in charge of a newly opened office in Washhington of the World Rehabilitation Fund was an nounced here yesterday by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, the fund's President.

title: A Snug Harbor on Lexington Avenue
description: On a gray wintry afternoon when gale winds howl along the Eastern seaboard and even the frostbite fleets are in port, there is to be found a quiet reach of blue water, sunny skies and unlimited marine horizon. At least be tween the hours of 11:30 to 5:45, Monday through Friday (Saturday 10 to 5), when Francis Greenburger's Boatman's Bookstore is open.

title: Many Rail Runs Canceled Before Injunction by Court
description: acted to prevent the shut down.

title: Army Wins in 3 Sports, but Bows to Columbia Fencers and Brown Sextet
description: Army Wins in 3 Sports, but Bows to Columbia Fencers and Brown Sextet

title: VIOLENCE SUBSIDING IN NORTHERN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 31Vio lence subsided in Haryana State today as the presence of army units served to check riots pro testing the Government's award of the city of Chandigarh to Punjab State instead of Har yana.

title: The battles of The Happy Warrior
description: Al Smith was a giant in his time. Millions of city dwellers suffering the stigma of recent immigrant origins idolized him as the first of their number to become the Democratic candi date for President. Progres sive  minded Americans re spected him for his contribu tions to good government and social justice. Others hailed him for no loftier reason than his frank and conspicuous wet ness in the Prohibition era. Whatever their reasons, his admirers were legion. His de tractors, offended by that self same wetness, and his city background, fearing his Ca tholicism, were even more nu merous and piled up an overwhelming vote against him in 1928.

title: WELLS, 16, CAPTURES SKIJUMP HONORS
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 31 Bernie Wells, a 16yearold high school student with masterly style, won the Middlebury Col lege snowball jumping tourna ment today with leaps of 187 and 190 feet on the icy 50 meter hill here.

title: Recordings
description: FOR years, whenever the three B's were mentioned, music lov ers knew automatical ly that Bach, Beethoven and Brahms were what was meant. Now, on a new Angel release, those old masters are getting a little competition for their proprietorship of the initial.

title: Antagonists in the Railroad Dispute
Expo '70 Takes On A Futuristic Look As Opening Nears
description: OSAKA, Japan  The architects responsible for most of the pavil ions, towers and spires taking shape on the Expo '70 site have designed their cre ations to fit in with Expo's concept of the fair as a model city of the future. The results are often visionary, some times fancy camp.

title: Two Bus Lines in Jersey Are Facing Strikes Today
description: Two bus lines serving north ern New Jersey and about 25, 000 daily riders were threatened with strikes last night.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Beverly Jones, E. W. Laffey Jr. Married in Ohio
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 31 Miss Beverly Rey Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Macfarlane Jones of Shaker Heights, and Edwin Wellman Laffey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Laffey of Far Hills, N. J. and Har bour Island, the Bahamas, were married here today in the Fairmount Presbyterian Church. The Rev. John Ma gill, assisted by the Rev. W. Chave McCracken of St. Paul's Episcopal Church here, officiated.

title: The Agony and Ecstasy of Duberman
description: IT is afternoon of the day my play, The Memory Bank, is due to open. I am standing in front of the bathroom mirror, shav ing. In a triumph of the non traditional, I manage not to cut myself. Perhaps I lack the strength. My brain is deep into a fog bank. Even the sky, I note, has gone from the morning's brilliant blue to what is now, at mid day, a miasmic gray. Maybe the astrologers are rIght: tides do determine the affairs of men, telegraphing mes sages through nature.

title: FRANK G. SPENO JR.
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 31 Frank G. Speno Jr., who de veloped a method of grinding train rails in place and who was the president of the Speno Railroad Ballast Cleaning Com pany of Ithaca, N. Y., died at Overlook Hospital of a heart attack this morning. He was 68 years old and lived at 200 Hobart Avenue.

title: SENIOR CITIZENS GET OPERA TREAT
description: Don't ask our age, were all senior citizens, we're all over 65 and that's all you need to know, said Miss Hilda Gene11 after the Thursday afternoon opera performance at the City Center auditorium.

title: U.C.L.A. CRUSHES STANFORD, 10284
description: STANFORD, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI)University of California, Los Angeles, crushed Stanford, 10284, today in a Pacific Eight Conference basketball game, for its 16th straight victory of the season.

title: Coins
description: THE campaign by his toric groups, archi tects and numismatists to save the old San Francisco Mint  located at Fifth and Mission Streets in that city  continues. Hear ings to decide the fate of the landmark are expected to be resumed within the next few weeks. Senator. George Murphy, Republican of California, has informed Gordon B. Hunt, chairman of a project to preserve the structure as a western branch of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Mao Appears in a Film Shown in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 31 Reu ters)Foreign newsmen got a rare closeup look at Mao Tsetung in a film show here this week.

title: ENVIRONMENT PUT NO.1 ON CITY LIST IN CAPITAL BUDGET
description: Mayor Lindsay proposed a $1.4billion construction budg et yesterday that gave top pri ority to environmental protec tion.

title: Paperbacks
description: Current Best Sellers

title: U.S.C., Tide List 11th Game
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan, 31 (AP) Southern California and Ala bama jointly announced today a twogame football series be ginning next year as 11th games on their schedules.

title: Miss Poler Wed to Dr. John Ferguson
description: HUNTINGTON, L. L, Jan. 31Miss Margaretta Edson Poler and Dr. John Flint Fer guson were married here this afternoon in the Old First Presbyterian Church.

title: 1.500 acres for retarded adults
description: Some novelists, like Stendhal, use language in the plainest way possible, as if their greatest fear is to dis tract from the enormously important involvements of their characters. Others, like Flatibert, hope that the art with which they arrange words will be so striking as to elevate what they themselves may find rather de pressingly ordinary into timeless beauty. While it is true that the highly selfconscious writing in The Entrance To Porlock often strikingly heightens our sense of what is going on, it is sometimes an annoying dis traction.

title: F. A. Brown Jr. Weds Miss Fletcher
description: In the Chapel of St. James at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday Miss Grace Gilchrist Fletcher and Frank Abbott Brown Jr., alumni of the University of Michigan's Graduate School of Business Administration, class of '64, were, married by the Rev. Richard Rodney Kirk.

title: NICKLAUS FIRES 70 FOR 203 AND LEADS JACKLIN BY A SHOT
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 31A drive that fell into an unplayable spot in a canyon cost Tony Jacklin of England the lead today in the third round of the $150,000 Andy WilliamsSan Diego open tournament.

title: Mazzinghi Hurt in Crash
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 31 (AP)Sandro Mazzingh, the former world junior middle weight boxing champion, suf fered a broken bone in his right hand and cuts on his left leg today in an auto accident. He had been scheduled to meet Harry Scott of Erigland in Milan, Italy, next Friday night.

title: Cocktail Party for School
description: A cocktail party will be held at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison on Feb. 15 to raise money to maintain extracurricular ac tivities and enrichment pro grams at the Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains. General chair men of the event are Mrs. Edward C. McKeon and Wil liam J. Noonan.

title: Patricia Clerkin Becomes Bride Of D. W. Pollock
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 31 Miss Patricia Ann Clerkin and Don Wells Pollock were married here this afternoon in St. John's Roman Catholic Church by the pastor, the Rev. Michael F. Blanchard.

title: Katharine Lee Will Be Bride Of Fellow Curator at Museum
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio, Jan. 31The engage ment of Miss Katharine Cae cilia Lee to John Webster Keefe has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Emery Lee, parents of the prospec tive pride. Mr. Lee, is director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, Mr. Keefe is the on of Mr. and Mrs. Webster Wil liam Keefe of Ely, Vt. His father is retired superintend ent of schools in Somers, N. Y., and former director of Norway Camps, Inc., in Ely.

title: A Briton looks at Americans abroad
description: Ludovic Kennedy, a well known British television com mentator and author of several books, takes his title from Lyn don Johnson's greeting to a group of White House visitors in January, 1965. Mrs. John son and I are very happy to have you here and we think you are all very lovely people, said the President. Making allow ance for understandable and welldocumented cracks at some of his cast of charac ters, the author is obviously more friendly than sarcastic when he cites this phrase.

title: CANADA AND NORWAY IN ACCORD ON SEALS
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 31 (AP) Canada and Norway have agreed to extend the ban on the killing of whitecoat seals, or newborn pups, to the North Atlantic, the Canadian Fisheries Minister, Jack Davis, said at a news conference this week.

title: Full Satellite Service Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The newest communications satellitethe sixth in the Intel sat 3 serieswill be switched on for fulltime commercial service tomorrow, according to the Communications Satellite Corporation.

title: Djemaa El Fna Means Place of the Dead, But It's the Liveliest Spot in Marrakesh
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco  The wily snake charmer, backed by flutists and drummers, mesmerizes the crowd encircling him in Marra kesh's central square, Place Djemaa El Fna. Dressed in an orange turban and blue and yellow robes, he drapes the snakes around his neck, partly swallows one and tucks others into his clothing.

title: California Mission Gets a New Lease on Life
description: KING CITY, Calif.I first saw Mis sion San Antonio de Padua 37 years ago as a member of a touring party stuck in the mud for three days and nights. We managed to summon a tow car from King City, on U.S. 101 some 23 miles to the northeast, but it, too, mired down in the gumbo, of the flooded road, and a second truck had to be sent out to rescue itand us.

title: Marijuana: That Was the Week That Was
description: WASHINGTON  During a week in which the United States Senate voted to relax Federal penalties for marijuana smoking for the first time in a generation by the astounding margin of 80 to 0, it might logically have been expected that the furor over the use of pot would have sub sided. But as legislators, police men and scientists have come to learn over the years, logic and marijuana don't mix.

title: Justice Douglas Says Revolution May Be Only Honorable Reply to Oppression
description: Supreme Court Justice Wil liam O. Douglas warns in new book that revolution may prove the only honorable alter native to oppression by the American Establishment.

title: Brinks Has Fortress For Las Vegas Runs
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP) Brinks armored car service plans to assign The Boom eranga virtual fortress on wheelson the run from banks in the casino center of Las Vegas, Nev., to the Los Angeles Federal Reserve Bank.

title: Mama Mia! Rome Is No Place to Be a Movie Star
description: ROME.

title: Poodles, With 274,145 Listed, Head A.K.C. Breeds 10th Year
description: THE poodle maintained its position as America's No. 1 breed for the 10th straight year in 1969, ac cording to the registration figures issued by the Ameri can Kennel Club last week. The figures reflect how the 116 A.K.C. breeds stand in the popularity parade and thus hold interest for many owners. The poodle's po sition on top ap peared unassail able for a long time to come. While the sec ondplace German shepherd fell short of equaling 1968 by 2,046 dogs, the three varieties of poodlesstand ard, miniature and toy combined for a registration gain of almost 10,500 above 1968. The poodle left the shepherd behind by over 172,000 dogs, 274,145 to 102,081. Dachshunds and beagles were next. The poodle registrations had been double or more that of the next highest breed since 1962.

title: Slump in Housing Likely to Persist
description: THE family in search of a new home finds the chance of, achieving its objective today no more en couraging than at any time in the last year, and in all likelihood the situation won't change until after next sum mer.

title: NETS' FIVE CONQUERS CHAPARRALS, 113108
description: DALLAS, Jan. 31 (AP)New York's slow brand of play kept Dallas off balance as the Nets scored a 113108 American Bas ketball Association victory over the Chaparrals tonight.

title: To Tkaczuk, South Porcupine Was Never Like This
description: OAKLAND, Jan. 31In their struggle to firish first in the East Division of the National Hockey League, the New York Rangers have been provided with an explosive lustre by Walt Tkaczuk, befitting some one who once handled dyna mite in a gold mine.

title: Science
description: Strong interactions was the subject of one of the sessiors last week at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society in Chicago. That refers to the force that binds the atomic nu cleus. But the paper presented at the session dealt with strong interactions of quite a different sort, as it's title made abund antly clear. It read:

title: How the Ski Complex Grew Up and Became So Complex
description: IT is a story they tell in the Green Mountains when winter winds whine in the pine tops and six inches of fresh powder snow glisten on a fourfoot base: In the summer of 1763, the Rev. Sam uel Peters slowly bushwhacked his way to the top of Killington Mountain, 4,241 feet high in the clean New England air. In all directions was the solitude of forest and mountains. The Rev. Mr. Peters christened the wild and lonely region Verde Monte.

title: Jersey Athletes Dominate Cardinal Hayes Track Meet
description: New Jersey schoolboys ex perienced their finest day in New York yesterday as the Garden State athletes domi nated the 21st annual Cardinal Hayes track and field games at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Lawyer Weds Wendy Afton
description: QUOGUE, L. I., Jan. 31 Miss Wendy Margaret Afton was married in the Presby terian church here today to Richard Ernest Rieder, a lawyer with Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. R. Dewitt, Mallery of All Saints Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Unbeaten Princeton Defeats Dartmouth in Track, 7633
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 31 Capturing first place in nine of 3 events, Princeton's Un beatlen track team routed Dartmouth, 7633, today to record its fifth victory.

title: RICHARDS IS NAMED TOP TRAINING RIDER
description: M. Lockie Richards, a 33 yearold New Zealander who came to the United States by way of England six years ago, was the leading combined train ing rider in the nation last year.

title: NEW TRANSIT UNIT BEETS FIRST TIME
description: Surrounding a sketch of their symbola scowling gray bull dog on a red backgroundthe city's new transit watchdog committee met yesterday at City Hall and promised to speak for millions in protest ing bad service.

title: Canadian Site Favored
description: BERCHTESGADEN, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP)The World To bogganing Federation voted by 15.3 today in favor of holding the 1976 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, Canada. Three votes went to Denver.

title: 4 DIE AS U.S. COPTER IS DOWNED NEAR HUE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 1 (UPI)The United States command said to day that enemy forces shot down a United States Army helicopter and attacked two American military bases north of Saigon yesterday and early oday.

title: Dartmouth Will Seek More Indian Students
description: HANOVER, N. H. Jan. 31 (AP)  Dartmouth College which grew out of a school established in 1750 to educate American Indians, will re turn to its founding princi ples in seeking a signifi cantly greater enrollment of American Indians next year.

title: Personality:
description: In the present state of the American mind, to say that it is possible to exaggerate the air pollution problem is some thing like being antimother hood and pro the maneating shark.

title: Notes From the Field of Travel
description: IN both the Netherlands and England, commemorative programs marking the 350th anniversary of the Mayflower voyage will be the biggest travel promotions of 1970. In England, Plymouth, the Midlands and London will focus attention on events from May through October. In the Netherlands, the town elders of Leyden, heirs of the local council that in 1609 granted asylum to the Pil grims for 11 years, recently announced that their city will be the focal point of a sevenmonth, countrywide program in observance of the anniversary.

title: Alice M. Wang Sets Nuptials
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., Jan. 31  Miss Alice Mailien Wang and George TzuYung Chen plan to be married in the summer.

title: Rams Triumph by 6763
description: Although enjoying an early season diagnosis of tournament fever, Georgetown came into Fordham's gym after a two+ week intercession layoff last night only to suffer a severe chilla 6763 defeat by the Rams before 4.156.

title: Soybean Study Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The nation's soybean processors have contributed $20,000 to two university re search programs aimed at im proving production methods.

title: Christy Latham, Paul D. Fowler Wed in Jersey
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 31 Miss Christy Bogart La tham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lindsay Latham of Morristown, was married this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church to Paul Denman Fowler, son of Mrs. Willis Fowler of St. James, L. I., and Benjamin Prince Fowler of New York.

title: The People v. the Mob; Or, Who Rules New Jersey?
description: NEWARK. THE headlinemaking trial begins. U. S. Attorney Frederick B. Laceya commanding 6 feet 4 and 225 pounds, a man who walks at a trotrises and asks Judge Robert Shaw: Your Honor, may I use the lectern? I have so many notes. The judge nods and Lacey wheels the lectern to a spot front and center, before the jury box.

title: Marine Relics Here Show Insurers' Sentimentality
description: Marine underwriters are often regarded as sentimen talists in the world of mod ern, competitive business.

title: Joseph Rivera, Physicist, 37; A.E.C. Environmental Aide
description: Joseph Rivera, a physicist with the environmental studies division of the Atomic Energy Commission here, died yester day following a heart attack at his home in Old Bridge, N. J. He was 37 years old.

title: Rural English Cottages
description: COTTAGE architecture in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are the basis of designs by David Gentle man and Sheila Robinson for four stamps to be issued by Great Britain on Feb. 11.

title: Yale Captures 10 Events And Routs Navy Swimmers
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31What started out as a major confron tation turned into a typical Yale swimming victory today as the Elis trounced Navy, 6739.

title: What's New in the Theater
description: TRANSFERS, three oneact plays by Conrad Bromberg, got three favorable, four qualified, and two unfa vorable reviews. Clive Barnes: Mr. Bromberg's triple bill is a series of en counters, one comic, one pathetic and one tragic. They add up to an over heated, overhysterical yet finally rewarding evening. And probably the rewards derive as much from the acting of Ron Leibman and the direction of Herman Shumlin as from Mr. Brom berg's sensitive yet undis ciplined writing. By far the best part of the evening is a most remarkable mono logue  getting on to an hourby Mr. Leibman as a frayed, beaten psychia trist. Called Dr. Galley, this is an encounter be tween a psychiatrist and a university class. The char acter of the psychiatrist is wildly selfindulgent, and, fundamentally, quite unbe lievable. So for that matter is Mr. Bromberg's writing. Yet the power of Mr. Leib man's playing carries a be lief against all previous conviction. For Walter Kerr, see Page 7. CRISSCROSSING  WATER COLOR, the Playwrights Unit's production of two plays by Philip Magdalany got one favorable, two mixed and eight negative reviews. Clive Barnes: Over the years the Play wrights Unit has contrib uted much of value to our theater. It has given work shop performances to some of the very best newgen eration playwrights. Mr. Magdalany's duo is not en tirely successful, but it is just the kind of work that should be encouraged by such workshop perform ances. It closed after five performances.

title: Letters
description: No Swan Song

title: Blazing Ski Trails Near the Teton Peaks
description: DRIGGS, IdahoFor almost as long as Westerners have skied in the Jackson Hole country of Wyoming, they have looked longingly at the snowy, comparatively treeless slopes just west of the Grand Teton and her sister peaks. This Teton Valley spot, which was named Pierre's Hole by the early fur trap pers, has always had grat potential for winter sports. But it is only now that this potential is beginning to be tapped.

title: Headliners
description: Mailer's Nuance

title: Icefield Highway Goes on Overtime
description: BANFF, Alberta  For the first time in its 30year history, the Icefield Highway in Banff and Jasper Na tional Parks is being kept open this winter on an 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. daily sched ule. Two large hotels, the Banff Springs Hotel, below the southern end of the road, and the Jasper Park Lodge, at the northern end, are also being kept open for their first winter.

title: Soybean Supplies at Peak Levels, but Demand Up Even Faster
description: Despite record supplies, soybeans and their by products, meal and oil, are attracting the attention of commoditiesmarkets traders and prices are rising or hold ing steady.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Anniversaries

title: Jeanne StrumpenDarrie Wed To Richard Swift, Travel Agent
description: Miss Jeanne Strumpen Darrie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert StrumpenDarrie of Larchmont, N. Y., was married here yesterday to Richard Giencross Swift, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Swift of Sydney, Australia. The ceremony was performed in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Vincent J. P. Fox.

title: ANGOLA IS TAKING REBELS IN STRIDE
description: LUANDA, Angola, Jan. 24 According to the latest joke making the rounds of this bustling capital of Portugal's vast West African province, there is a plan afoot to lure tourists with safaris for lion, elephant and terrorists.

title: NigeriaSentences 35 Priests In Immigration Law Violations
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 31 (Reu ters)  The Government an nounced tonight that 35 priests had been sentenced to six months' imprisonment for breaking Nigeria's immigration laws but said the sentences would be reviewed in a few days.

title: Fire in Jersey City Destroys Old Arena and Dance Hall
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 31A fire ruined the Jersey City. Gar den, a former boxing arena and dance hall at Ogden Avenue and Franklin Street, early today.

title: Slow Growth Pony Clubs' Aim, Its New President Declares
description: The name or the game for sports organizations these days is numbersastronomi cal gates, fantastic attend ances and, for participation sports, uncounted thousands of competitors.

title: A Convert to Suburbanism Explains Himself
description: THE trail that led from a three  and  a  halfroom apartment in Schwab House on 73d Street and West End Avenue to a five bedroom, fivebathroom home in Montclair, N. J., began the day last year when the land lord raised the rent from $200 to $250 a month.

title: Assembly Line for That Dream House
description: In the striking modern build ing of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington last week, top staff members and a jury from nine Federal agencies were closeted with the 37 finalists of Operation Breakthrough, the Government's highly publicized, concentrated attack on the American housing shortage. They were working their way down, or up, to the top 20 entries in a national compe tition for a kind of industrialized housing that is meant to make it possible to massproduce and massmarket, for the first time, one of the country's most needed products.

title: JEWS ASKED TO AID HEBREW SCHOOLS
description: The head of the country's largest Jewish Orthodox rab binical group called on Ameri can Jews to declare a year's moratorium on capital expendi tures for new projects and in stead channel their funds for Jewish education and Israel's needs.

title: CRACK RULER WINS AT LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 Aided by pleasant, sunny weather, the only other game in East Magalopolis today broke virtually all records for parimutuel activity in Penn sylvania.

title: 2 OTHER EVENTS ALSO ARE LISTED
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31 Guaranteed prizes in the 1970 CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup series for sportsracing cars will total $875,000, up from last season's $740,000. At least $200,000 in manufactur ers' awards will bring the overall awards to more than $1million.

title: Some Vietnam Slayings by Korean Troops Cited, but Accounts Are Clouded
description: HOLAN, South Vietnam, Jan. 29  Enraged after two mine explosions killed six South Ko rean marines and wounded a Korean and three Americans, South Korean troops stormed into a village near Danang last spring, allied officials say, and killed three South Vietnamese civilians, including two women in their beds.

title: RANGERS TO MEET PENGUINS TONIGHT
description: The New York Rangers, led by the highestscoring line in the National Hockey League, will open a threegame home stand tonight when they take on the Pittsburgh Penguins at Madison Square Garden. Game time is 7:05.

title: YABLONSKI WEAPON IS REPORTED STOLEN
description: LA FOLLETTE, Tenn., Jan. 31 (AP)The .38caliber revol ver believed used to kill Joseph A. Yablonski, a 59yearold United Mine Workers official, his wife and daughter at their Clarksville, Pa., home may have been stolen from a physi cian here, it was reported yes terday.

title: Man Ray: Last of The Red Hot Dadas'
description: AT 80, Man Ray is one of the last of the red hot Dadas. He has survived his principal companion in the American confrater nity of Dadaists, Marcel Du champ, as well as most of the members of the interna tional brotherhood of that anarchic, estheticallyminded, antiart movement which sprang into being simultaneously  around 1916  in Zurich, Paris, Berlin and New York. Born in Philadelphia and raised in Brooklyn, the artist engineeredat an early age and in the latter city the first of his Dada esca pades: he organized a gang his boyhood friends for the purpose of pilfering col ored objects only from neigh borhood stores, meanwhile garnering in for himselfby. the same means a handy supply of oil paints, all in tended for the furtherance of his already precocious artis tic ambitions. Recalling the incident, Several years later, in his racy memoirs, Self Portrait; the successful art ist and former petty larienist remarked with satisfaction: Fagin would have been of me.

title: M'MILLIAN EXCELS WITH 25 POINTS
description: Columbia nab an unexpected ly easy time beating Princeton, 7652, last night to remain even with Pennsylvania at the top of the Ivy League basketball standing. The victory set the stage for tomorrow night's meeting between the Quakers and the Lions at University Hall, where the Lions ran away from the Tigers before 1,924 persons.

title: Junior Welterweight Title Won by Arcari on Decision
description: ROME, Jan. 31 (AP)Bruno Arcari, the Italian challenger, won the World Boxing Coun cil's junior welterweight crown from Pedro Adique of the Phil ippines with a 15round deci sion tonight.

title: Trade Held No CureAll In Germany
description: West German trade spec ialists do not believe that po litical overtures made by their Government to East Germany, even if successful, will automatically lead to vastly improved economic re lations.

title: Dystrophy Group Reelects Stockbroker as President
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31  The Muscular Dystrophy Asso ciations of America today, elected Henry M. Watts Jr., New York stockbroker, to third term as nresident.

title: Private Schools Thrive in South, But Finances Restrict Quality
description: CANTON, Miss., Jan. 30 The pretty young wife with champagne hair waved goodby to the children from her 1970 hardtop sedan, pushed a chrome button on the dash board and watched the tinted glass windows slide quietly shut.

title: Openings of the Week
description: LA TROUPE DU ROI and AMPHITRYONTuesday, City Center, 7. First offering in a threeweek Moliere Festival by the Comedie Frangaise.

title: Siena Beats St. Francis
description: Despite John Conforti's 31 points, St. Francis College lost to Siena; 8374, last night at the 69th Regiment Armory in Manhattan. The Terriers held a 2928 halftime lead. Bob Her mann led Siena with 27 points.

title: Adina Goes Abroad At 2: Europe On One Bottle a Day
description: IT was our last night in Florence, and our 2yearold was settling into her bed in the pensione. Every night of our trip, Adina talked to herself, idly reeling off in unconnected sentences her day's discoveries, and this night what we overheard was something she had apparently been too polite to say to us: No more statues. Please!

title: JUDGE IS CRITICAL IN THE MOTEL CASE
description: FLINT, Mich., Jan. 31 The judge trying the Algiers Motel case has criticized the prosecu tion and said that after two days of testimony it had not offered proof of the charges against the four defendants.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1970

title: Montreal's Crime Rate Continues to Increase
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 31 (AP) After a decade of battling its reputation as Canada's crime capital, Montreal is worse off than ever.

title: CAMPUS MILITANTS GIVEN 125 YEARS
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 Three student militants were sentenced this week to from one to 25 years in state prison con charges stemming from the takeover of two campus buildings at San Fernando Val ley State College in November, 1968.

title: Decals Are Big Business: In Printing of Textiles
description: An old artdecalcomania has been given a new ap plication in the textile trade. It is rapidly growing into a big industry and will prove an invaluable aid to apparel manufacturers and other who are using printed fabrics.

title: Major Contributors to U.N. Aid System Urge Drastic Reforms
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31The United States and other big contributors to the United Nations economic aid program for developing states have decided that drastic re forms are needed.

title: Barnard Girl Dies After Heroin Party
description: A 17yearold Barnard College student was found dead yester day Morning in a Bronx apart ment in which students had been sniffing heroin at a party the night before, according to the police.

title: French Grant Nelson His Coup at Trafalgar
description: PARIS, Jan. 31 (Reuters) The French Academy has ensured that the French will remember the defeat of their navy by the British under Lord Horatio Nelson in Oc tober, 1805.

title: Photography
