description: MORE than 6,000 his torically significant photographic items in 570 lots dating back to photography's early dec ades will be publicly pre viewed from 9 to 5 Thurs day and Friday at PB84, a division of ParkeBernet, Inc. galleries at 171 East 84th Street, prior to being offered at public auction Saturday. Because of the collection's hugeness, the auction will be held in two sessions, at 10 A.M. and, following a lunch eon break, at 1 P.M.

title: Spotlight:
description: One of the ruleofthumb approaches in stockmarket forecasting involves the ac tion of prices during the opening month of the year.

title: TOY POODLE WINS IN OBEDIENCE TEST
description: A 3yearold toy poodlel with one previous success in the event became the principal winner in the 18th annual obedience competition of the Poodle Obedience Training Club of Greater New York yesterday. The trials were at the Statler Hilton Hotel and drew 82 dogs for 110 entries.

title: Opera: Punch and Judy
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 31 Harrison Birtwistle is one of England's more talked about younger composers, and his long oneact opera Punch and Judy created a great deal of comment at its premiere in England last year. The Center Opera Com pany, ever on the lookout for new material, grabbed the work, and last night it had its American premiere at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater:

title: Louise Vance Plans Nuptials
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 31Mr. and Mrs. J. Nelson Vance 2d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Edger ton Vance, to Pvt. David Em ery Beardsley, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bidwell Beardsley of New Canaan.

title: King Clancy in Hospital
description: TORONTO, Jan. 31 (AP) Frank (King) Clancy, vice presi dent of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League, was in a hospital to day recovering from what hos pital officials described as a rundown condition.

title: Oliver in Pirates' Fold
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 (UPI) Al Oliver, Pittsburgh Pirate infielder, signed today.

title: Ohio Trend: Stores Had Small Gain
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31  Indications from prelimi nary figures are that retail ers in Ohio had a higher vol ume in 1969 than in 1968 but the margin may be a slight one.

title: Czechoslovak Aide Says Party Does Not Consider Dubcek Case Closed
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 31  A Com munist party official said today that the case against Alexander Dubcek, the fallen leader of the 1968 Czechoslovak liberal movement, was not yet closed.

title: Princeton 54 Hockey Victor
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 31 Jon Wright's two goals and two assists led the Princeton hockey team to a 54 triumph over Northeastern today.

title: Advertising:
description: NEW YORK television watchers have become accustomed these days to see ing Helen O'Connell, that wonderful blonde singing star of the dear dead nine teenforties, making a pitch for a record album called Those Memory Years.

title: In Memoriam
description: ASCHRussell, February 1Gone 2 years, but not forgotten.

title: Clerks at Coast Tracks Expected to Approve Pact
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP)  Parimutuel clerks are ex pected to approve a contract tomorrow that will signal the start Tuesday of the longde layed California winter racing season.

title: LEHIGH BOY WINS PACE AT WESTBURY
The World
description: LAGOS  The University of Ibadan, 70 miles north of here, addressed a newspaper adver tisement last week to students from waraffected areas. In the mood of reconciliation that the Nigerian Government is encour aging, the university welcomed back the former rebels, and told them when and where to reg ister for the resumption of their studies. But then it added: stu dents are warned not to expect ideal conditions. The university is merely responding to an emer gency which the sudden end of the rebellion and hostility has brought.

title: Foreign Affairs: Mediterranean Arms and Oil
description: ROME  The last modern statesman to try and make a mare nostrum of the Mediter reanean was Mussolini and he came a cropper. Since then the world's most famous sea has been a shared domain even if after World War II it was mili tarily dominated by the United States Sixth Fleet.

title: LONG ISLAND A.C. TO HONOR ROONEY
description: Art Rooney, the owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers will receive the second Pioneer Award at the fourth annual MostValuable Player Awards Dinner Wednesday at the Gar den City Hotel.

title: The house that time built
description: This rambling, oldfashioned house beside the Hudson in the Bronx has had three lives. It was built in 1900 as the library wing of a mansion. In 1950, it was moved down the street and given two wings of its own. Later, architect Hobart Betts turned the rather heavy and dark interior into light, modern spaces. A big fireplace designed by him is the focus of the living room, where old plaster ceiling was whitened and retained as a decorative element. The white and gray background permits frequent color changes in art, pillows, flowers and other accessories.

title: Aussie Yacht About to Be Launched
description: Australia's hope to become its America's Cup challenger next September has been named Gretel II. She is ex pected to be launched this week and shipped to the United States in May or early June.

title: Defiant Oklahoma Parents Place Son in Private School
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Rather than comply with a judge's desegregation order, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. York have put their son Ray mond, 14 years old, in a private school.

title: Pope Tells NATO Officials Of Hones for World Peace
description: ROME, Jan. 31 (UPI)Pope Paul VI said today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation was protecting the free dom and security of Europe.

title: For Autos Troubles Piling Up From Showroom to Union Hall
description: DETROIT, Jan. 31If this were an oldtime movie script, the Indians would be circling closer, whooping it up, and the handsome cowpoke would be handing Nell that revolverthe one with just one bullet left.But if you didn't crunch the popcom too loudly and really listened, you could hear, faintly, a bugle. And in another moment or two, they would cut to the good old Seventh Cavalry riding hard to the rescue.

title: Reds Sign Five Pitchers
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds signed five pitchers todayTony Clon inger, Wayne Simpson, Pedro Borbone, Tim Grant and Milt Wilson.

title: MARTIN SELTZER
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Jan. 31 Martin Seltzer of 181 Hartley Terrace, head of Seltzer, Malk & Co., certified public account ants with offices here and in Elizabeth, died yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hos pital in Philadelphia. His age was 58.

title: Bank Is Established For the. Caribbean Under U.N. Aegis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31The latest United Na tions project to help countries finance their own development began its existence formally this week with ratification by 13 Caribbean territories, Brit ain and Canada of an agree ment establishing a $50million Caribbean Development Bank.

title: BRECHU IS VICTOR IN SPECIAL SLALOM
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 31Henri Brechu of France, a husky and broad smiling 22yearold, rallied to day to win the special slalom ski race, breaking a string of victories by Gustavo Thoeni of Italy.

title: WEST BERLIN BESET BY FUNERAL CRISIS
description: BERLIN, Jan. 31West Ber lin is undergoing a funeral crisis as a result of an excep tionally cold and hard winter season that has sent the death rate soaring. According to offi cial estimates it now takes up to three weeks before a funeral or a cremation can take place.

title: Mary Tobey Married To Lieut. Rodney Cook
description: WINNETKA, Ill., Jan. 31 Miss Mary Harrison Tobey, a descendant of Presidents William Henry Harrison and Benjamin Harrison, was mar ried here today to Lieut. Rodney Wendell Cook, U.S.A., who is serving with Military Intelligence at Fort Bragg, N.C. The ceremony was per formed at the Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Dr. Edgar G. Prasse.

title: Reader's Report
description: All on a Summer's Night

title: Mansfield Decries Price Of Expanded ABM Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31President Nixon's proposed ex pansion of the Safeguard antiballistic missile system was challenged today by Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, who forecast a cost exceeding $50billion.

title: Job Changes:
description: Francis X. Whelan has been elected to the board of American Brands, Inc., and president of American Cigars, a division of American Brands, effective March 31. He will succeed Alfred F. Bowden, who is retiring from tenth posts.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: CEMETERIES

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I Am an aging kid (oh, God, 21 years old and hair receding!), once dropping out of college, twice dropped out, and cur rently copping out by work ing 42 hours a week for $80 (post taxes). Though I regret the everincreasing commer cialism of Arlo Guthrie as an Establishment product to be sold to alienated kids and concerned adults, I am hope ful that Arlo himself can escape unharmed.

title: Article 3  No Title
Their Mirrored Hallway Splendid Setting for a Secluded Waltz
description: THE image of the whirling couple, waltzing the length of their 40foot long corridor was blurred in the an tiqued, mirrored ceiling. Even the white stone urns spilling palm fronds, the tie back curtains framing a mirrored wall and the French Provincial settee seemed softened in the overhead reflection, as if in an impressionist painting.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE GOODELL'S RECORD
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31  Sharp criticism of Senator Charles E. Goodell's voting record and his late conversion to the anti war movement were empha sized by a panel of Democratic senatorial aspirants today as the key to defeating him in November.

title: Goodman Will Officiate At Dog Writers' Dinner
description: Walter F. Goodman of Oy ster Bay, L. I., whose Skye terrier, Ch. Glamoor Good News, was best in show al Westminster last year, will he master of ceramonies at the ?? dinner of the Dog Writ ers' Association of America next Sunday night at the Stat ler Hilton Hotel.

title: Cairo Reports Crossing
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31  Cairo's military spokesman said to night that an Egyptian infan try company crossed the Suez Canal early today and am bushed an Israeli armored pa trol, destroying the vehicles and killing all the occupants.

title: Negroes in Chicago Battling Evictions
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31  The furniture of the John Moss family was piled on the lawn in front of the family's neat brick home, surrounded by skirmish line of 150 helmeted sheriffs deputies armed with riot clubs.

title: New Restaurants Are Franchised
description: A contract calling for the construction of 40 franchised Frank N' Stein fast food restaurants in Maryland and Virginia has been announced by Eugene M. Broome, presi dent and chairman of the board of Frank N' Stein Sys tems, Inc. Estimated cost for the franchise to complete the 40 units, including land, Construction and equipment, is estimated at $7.5million.

title: The Difference Between Marat/Sade an Trotsky
description: I CAME to Dsseldorf to attend the critics' pre miere of Peter Weiss's new play, Trotsky in Exile. I saw only half of Weiss's play, but I partici pated in a happening that, in effect, made Weiss's Trot sky a play within a play something like Peter Weiss's Trotsky in Exile, Interrupted, Terminated, and Reinterpret ed by Leftist Students from the University and Art Acad emy of Dsseldorf, Apparent ly Not Directed by Anyone.

title: Points for Both Sides in G.E. Pact
description: In symbolic terms the tenta tive settlement last week of the 14week strike of nearly 150,000 General Electric workers repre sents the greatest union vic tory since labor overcame Tom Girdler, Harry Bennett and other champions of the open shop in the New Deal era. The chief goal of the 14union coalition was to slay Boulwarism, the papa knowsbest bargaining philoso phy on which G.E. relied to dom inate contract negotiations for two decades.

title: The man who made not eating a grape a holy act
description: Sal si puedes, Spanish for escape if you can, is the self mocking name that MexicanAmeri cans call the barrio in San Jose where Cesar Chavez spent part of his childhood. The rest of those years were spent tramping the back roads and fields of California's verdant San Joaquin Valley, a member of the faceless, nomadic army who pick the fruits and vegetables most Americans seem to think appear by magic in their supermarkets. What made Cesar Chavez different was that he accepted the challenge of sal si puedes. He has tried to escape, and take his people with him.

title: Book Tells of America's Cup Defense
description: Anybody wishing to spend over $700,000 on the de sign, construction and equip ment of a 12meter yacht and the care and feeding of a crew is urged to read De fending the America's Cup, a new book written from in terviews with those who made Intrepid the successful 1967 defender against Aus tralia's Dame Pattie. There were 15 authors, and Rob ert W. Carrick, the editor, taped 250,000 words from them, then boiled what was said down to 60,000. Stanley Z. Rosenfeld supplied 114 photographs.

title: 2 Apollo 13 Astronauts To Sip Wafer on Moon
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31(AP) The Apollo 13 moonwalkers will be able to take drinks of water while exploring the lunar surface in April.

title: New York
description: They've stopped asking, What's John Lindsay really like? This year they're asking, Is there real a New Lindsay?

title: Does everybody lie? Yes, says George Washington
description: All is jive. Jive is hypocrisy, lies, putons, false names, phony be liefs and perhaps real beliefs too. Jive is also living, staying alive. Jive is especially living as a black man in white society. Jive is what Cecil Brown's first novel is all about. I was thinking, says George Washing ton, his black narrator, near the end of the novel, that I'd write a novel, a book about the race problem with a dynamite stick concealed inside it. I mean, a real stick of dynamite. The dynamite is real enough. Washington, a black from the rural South, drifts up to Harlem and be comes, variously, a jazz player, a hustler, an encyclopedia salesman, a selfstyled Princeton graduate. When he has had enough of smalltime jiving, he takes off for Copenhagen to find out if everyone in the world lies as much as he lies in his dedi cated search for invisibility. Copen hagen also becomes a lie for him, at last.

title: Mine's Ore Snapped Un By Japan
description: The great size anct grow ing potential of Japanese markets for metallic raw ma terials were underlined again last week at simultaneous ceremonies in New York and in six other centers on three continents.

title: KENTUCKY UPSET BY VANDERBILT
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 31 (AP) Kentucky ran into a Vanderbilt buzzsaw tonight and suffered its first defeat of the season, 8981.

title: A Correction
description: It was erroneously reported in yesterday's New York Times that 12yearold Mary Frain sits during the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag while most of her class stands at Junior High School 217 at 85th Avenue and 148th Street in Jamaica, Queens Most of the class remains seat ed with Mary during the flag ceremony.

title: Economy Will Feel G.E. Woe
description: In many ways the strike against the General Electric Company has had less effect on the public than any other major strike in years.

title: GREECE TRAINING 112 LIBYAN PILOTS
description: ATHENS, Jan. 31Greek of ficials said today that 112 Libyans were being trained at the Greek Air Force Academy and that about 120 Libyan pilots had graduated from the school over the last four years, with experience in piloting jets.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGONEvery day for the last 15 months, sleek American jet fighters specially rigged for highspeed reconnaissance have taken off from air bases in Thai land and aircraft carriers in the Gulf of Tonkin and have headed north towards Hanoi. Their mis sion is essentially the same as it was before the announcement of a bombing halt on Oct. 1, 1968: to track the movement of enemy troops and matriel inside North Vietnam and in the Communist dominated portions of Laos.

title: Court Calls Search of Baby Without Its Consent Illegal
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP)A municipal court judge has ruled that narcotics search in a baby's diaper by sheriff's deputies was unconstitutional because the baby dlid not consent.

title: Sullivan Award
description: Winners

title: A:
description: CARL NIEMEYER, Schenectady, N.Y. writes: The Latin quotation queried by J. P. M. on Jan. 4 is from Virgil's First Georgic, lines 1718. (The lines were mis quoted, they should have read. Pan, ovium custos, tua si tibi Maenala curse, adsis o Tegeaee, favens... ) A rough translation would be: O Pan, guardian of the sheep, if you love your own Mount Maenalus, favor me, O Tegaean, with your pres ence.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONIf ever proof were needed that law and poli tics are a volatile mix, it came last week when the Senate ap prove a noknock law for the seizure of narcotics.

title: Rise Reported In Fire Losses
description: Fires in the United States caused losses estimated at $1.95billion last year, 6.7 per cent higher than the $1.83billion the year before, the National Insurance Ac turial and Statistical Asso ciation reports.

title: QUARANTINED LINER TO SAIL TO HONOLULU
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) The liner Oronsay, which was quarantined because of typhoid aboard in Vancouver British Columbia, for more than two weeks, will sail for Honolulu Wednesday, the P.&O. Orient Line announced here to day.

title: Theater: Golding's Brass Butterfly
METS SIGN DYER AND TWO ROOKIES
description: The world champion New York Mets counted 18 players set for the 1970 season yes terday, with the announcement that three of their younger members had signed contracts. Bob Scheffing, the new general manager, listed Duffy Dyer, catcher; Jon Matlack, left handed pitcher, and Mike Jor gensen, first baseman, as hav ing come to terms.

title: U.S. TO GIVE TAIWAN 34 OLD JET PLANES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The United States is taking 34 old F100 jet fighterbombers out of storage and will give them to Nationalist China, it was disclosed today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Easy Does It
description: DURING the last month, eels, beheaded and skinned, appeared in the fresh fish departments of some seacoast New Eng land supermarkets, averaging about 70 cents a pound.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: PARIS BACKS BONN ON POLICY IN EAST
description: PARIS, Jan. 31  Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany returned to Bonn tonight with full French support for his efforts to ease tensions with the Soviet bloc.

title: Porsche Sets Pace at 24 Hours of Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31Race teams representing the Porsche factory of West Germany and the Italian fac tory of Italy, each plagued by vexing mechanical problems, were engaged tonight in a strenuous fight for leadership in the 24 Hours of Daytona.

title: Johnson to Seek Presidency, His Brother Says in Article
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson will run again for the Presidency, according to his brother, Sam Houston Johnson, quoted in an article published today in Parade magazine.

title: A Museum For Children Of All Ages
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.A new $750,000 Children's Museum has been opened here and, despite its name, it is as interesting to parents as it is to their youngsters.

title: GROUND IS BROKEN FOR BRONX CAMPUS
description: A grounaoreaxing ceremony was held last week for a new $61million campus for Bronx Community College to be con structed over the subway stor age yards at Bedford Park Boulevard and Paul Avenue.

title: BULLETS CONQUER CELTICS BY 120117
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP) Wes Unseld sank 12 of 14 shots from the floor tonight, includ ing the tiebreaking shot with three seconds left, as the Balti more Bullets defeated the Bos ton Celtics, 120117.

title: The Basic Economic Issue
description: The Economic Report of the President is a remark ably explicit and useful document. It discloses the strategy of the Nixon Administration for checking inflation and avoiding a serious recession in the coming year. It describes a rather shallow valley of unemployment that the economy must cross in the next two years. It looks across to the other side of hat valley where it sees a promised land of 4.3 per Dent growth, 3.8 per cent unemployment, and negligible reflation.

title: Saigon Curbs on U.S. Press Disturb Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 The Pentagon has acknowl edged that it faces problems in getting United States news men full access to areas con trolled by South Vietnamese forces as the Vietnamization of the war moves ahead.

title: Grab the Money and Run?
description: DISAFFECTION with counter culture  the mishmash of myths, music and mishigas ani mating our youth  is beginning to manifest itself in the writings of the most observant and thoughtful of the younger rock critics. While the mass media go right on endorsing every fad and foible of a decadent pop cul ture, while soul is coopted by CocaCola and revolution becomes a phrase in a pants commercial, the kids who have grown up on the rock scene are starting to register their disgust with its perversions and their despair of its ever attaining its ostentatiously proclaimed millennium.

title: Diminutive Orchids Are Well Suited for Window Sills
description: THE names of vanda orchids used in Hawaiian leis carry some of the magic spell of the islandsAloa, Honolulu, Laukapu and Kilohama. For hobby orchid growers, vandas are among the most adaptable. They are easy to grow on a sunporch or at a sunny window.

title: Mary Haglund, David Pabst Jr. Wed in Midwest
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 31 Miss Mary Lynn Haglund, a senior at Butler University, was married here this after noon to David Pabst Jr., who operates the nearby Wauke. sha County Airport.

title: It's Called Earth Art And Boulderdash
description: MODERN art has escaped into the wilderness, and a search party may have to be sent out to find it. The new Earth Art is hoping to skip out on the insiders who have made the avantgarde into a kind of currency, an admission ticket to a rarified international so cial scene, a badge of inness, far outness, somewhere  elseness and toomuchness. Succeeding waves of action painting, abstract expression ism, pop and op and minimal arts have been captured and sequestered by hip art patrons vying to sponsor the most scandalous artists in town. In this procedure, certain of the art ists turned into prima donnas who could autograph a shoe and sell it for a fortune, while the patrons be came famed far and wide for crank ing up the momentum of art history to a breakneck speed.

title: The milieu of the generally welloff, often idle
description: Elizabeth Jane Howard's publisher compares her with Jane Austen. Something in Disguise lacks the Austen richness of texture and gentle touch and investigates private thoughts as a structural concession to modernitybut the comparison is not entirely unjustified. Like a substantial handful of contemporary English writersamong them Elizabeth Tay lor and, more eccentrically, Henry Green and the late Ivy Compton BurnettMiss Howard is a novelist of manners. (Amusingly and quite improbably, one of the characters in this her fifth novel enjoys the very writers I've mentioned.) And like Jane Austen, these novelists of man ners tend to rely on the milieu of the generally welloff, often idle, upper middle class.

title: A Correction
description: In some editions of Section 2 of today's New York Times, the Who Makes Music and Where schedule includes un der Concerts Today the listing of a concert by Olegna Fuschi, piano, with symphony orches tra. That listing is incorrect. The concert will not be given at this time.

title: Variety in Mexico's San Blas: Sea in Front and Jungle Behind
description: SAN BLAS, MexicoThis somnolescent Pacific Coast fishing village in the state of Nayarit is a lowkeyed vacation spot and also a place with poetic and historic associations. One of Longfellow's last poems was about the Bells of San Blas, although he had never seen them or the town, They were cast in foundry here and taken to California by Father Junipero Serra.

title: Walkout by 3,500 Cancels All Flights Of National Airlines
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Na tional Airlines canceled 450 flights serving 43 United States cities today as more than 3,500 members of the Airline Em ployes Association went on strike.

title: Harness Tracks of America ReElects Jenuine as Head
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. Jan. 29  Thd Harness Tracks of America concluded four days of meet ings today by reelecting Pres ton R. Jenuine of Los Angeles, as president, and Donald D. MacFarlane of Detroit as chair man of the board.

title: Arsonist Sentenced to Hang
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 31 (UPI)Delaware Superior Court Judge Andrew Christie yester day sentenced Herbert Steigler, murderer, to hang April 6 for 38 years old, a convicted arson his crime. If the sentence is carried out, it will be the state's first hanging in 35 years.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodaySecor Farms, Hillair Circle, White Plains, N. Y. Ama teurowner and regular working hunters, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR: Your article on Red Guard terrorism (The Making of a Red Guard, as compiled by Dr. and Mrs. Ivan London and Dr. Taling Lee, Jan. 4) is a needed antidote to the ef fort of some American radi cals to see Red Guards only as the sweet personification of idealism and democracy.

title: Rock Kills Woman in Car
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (AP) Mrs. Anna Perilli, 60 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y., was killed today when a rock smashed through the windshield of the car she was in and hit her on the head. The police were un certain how the accident hap pened.

title: CURBS ON TRAVEL DEBATED IN TAIPEI
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 31  The forthcoming Expo '70 ex position in Japan has set off debate here about the rigid travel restrictions to which Chi nese Nationalist citizens are subject in what the Government says is the interest of national security and currency stability.

title: SENATOR MURPHY PRONOUNCED FIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31Sen ator George Murhpy has had no recurrence of throat cancer, ac cording to the results of a phys ical examination released today.

title: Rech Gives Thanks on Anniversary of Heart Surgery
description: Fred Rech (as in Veeck) ob serves an anniversary today. Two years ago, the harness horseman from Tonawanda, N.Y., Was undergoing open heart surgery at Manhattan's Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Robert S. Litwak and Dr. Salvador B. Lubkan were replacing the damaged aortic valve in Rech's heart with a prosthesis, a plas tic replica of the valve. The layman commonly refers to such an operation as a valve job.

title: Leader of Lesotho Says Vote Is Null, Seizes All Power
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 31 Chief Leabua Jonathan, the Prime Minister of this tiny country in southern Africa, to day declared invalid last Tues day's general election, in which he was apparently defeated. The winner, Ntsu Mokhehle, was arrested on Chief Jona than's orders, and a state of emergency was imposed here.

title: Nerud Has Retired as a Trainer of Race Horses But It's on a DaytoDay Basis
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31Johnny Nerud snickers when anyone asks him how he is enjoying his retirement. Technically, Nerud did re tire as trainer for Tartan Farms after Sara toga closed last September because he was worn out. But retirement is not precisely the right word.

title: Soviet Starts a Research journal Devoted Entirely to the U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31The So viet Union's specialists on the United States, the American ists, as they call themselves, published the first issue of new magazine today devoted entirely to their subject.

title: 16 Black Panthers Go on Trial Tomorrow in State Court Here
description: Sixteen Black Panthers are scheduled to go on trial tomor row on charges of conspiring to bomb Manhattan department stores, the Bronx Botanical Gardens, police stations, sub way switchingrooms and rail road tracks.

title: Plastic Aortic Piece Inserted in 1968 Saved His Life
description: Right now, at 200. I'm about 30 pounds overweight.

title: ROLLICKING, 910, FINISHES SECOND
Barbara Fiore Becomes Bride Of Philip Green
description: The marriage of Miss Bar bara Ann Fiore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent R. Fiore, to Philip Wyatt Green took place yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Pat tick's Cathedral. The Rev. Francis Boyle of St. Jo seph's Seminary in Yonkers performed the ceremony.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Thee is a note of optimism that runs through the cau tiousness in wholesale mar kets as retailers and manu facturers look to spring busi ness and beyond. In manu facturers' showrooms and resident buying offices, order takers paused as they made an assessment of business placed by retailers in the last four weeks.

title: Australians Set Inquiry On Offshore Oil Drilling
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 31 The Federal Government and Queensland State Government have agreed to establish an in quiry into dangers to the Great Barrier Reef from offshore oil exploration.

title: The Football Market
description: FIVE TEAMSAtlanta, Buf falo, Cincinnati, Cleveland and Dallas  did especially well in the pro football draft by fulfilling prestated needs and strengthening their teams on the first three rounds. A sixth would be Pittsburgh, but the Steelers were select ing first among the 26 teams and the No. 1 club is expected such do well with such an advan tage. This anal ysis of the draft was confined to the first three of the 17 rounds and the top 78 players out of the 442 selected. Circumstances be yond anyone's forecast are responsible when a player drafted on the fourth round or beyond becomes a first year regular for a winning team because the talent thins out so quickly with 26 clubs choosing.

title: Free Mail to Congress Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Letters addressed to a mem ber of Congress could be mail ed postagefree under a bill in troduced this week by Rep. Charles. H. Wilson, Democrat, California. If Congressmen can use the mails free for official business, Mr. Wilson asked Tuesday, why should not a citizen be accorded the same privilege when writing offici ally to his elected Representa tive?

title: Talk Is Dear
description: BEGINNING in the latter part of December, 1968, three Federal grand juries sitting in Newark cast out a blizzard of more than 70 indictments. One flurry alleged the operation of a $20millionayear Newark bookmaking ring master minded by Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCaval cante, alleged by the F.B.I. to be the ruler of the sixth Mafia family in the New YorkNew Jersey metropoli tan area.

title: PURDUE DEFEATS MICHIGAN, 116103
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 31 (UPI) Rick Mount, an all America, registered 53 points today and led Purdue to a 116 103 Big Ten basketball conquest of Michigan.

title: Nancy A. Hardin Becomes Bride of Douglas Rogers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 When the newly married Douglas Langston Rogers un pack their wedding gifts in their new apartment in New Haven they have a square clock with a round face that says White House where the maker's name should be.

title: Miss MacFarlane White Plains Bride
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31 Miss Kathleen Kellogg Mac Farlane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph MacFarlane, and Warren Grimes Hall, son of Mrs. W. Richard Eubank of Urbana. Ohio, and of Hugh Hall of Dayton, were mar ried here this afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by, the Rev. J. Nor man Hall.

title: MRS. J. H. RAMBIN JR.
description: Mrs. J. Howard Rambin Jr., the wife of the chairman and chief executive officer of Texaco, Inc., died at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital yester day afternoon. She was 52 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn. Mrs. Rambin, the former Mary Virginia Grif fin, and graduated from Lou isiana State University.

title: Prime Leads Field of 78 In Mad River Glen Slalom
description: MAD RIVER GLEN, Vt., Jan. 31Bill Prime of the Amateur Ski Club of New York led a field of 78 competitors repre senting 12 clubs of the Metro politan New York Ski Council in the 36th running of the an nual twoday championships.

title: LONG BATTLE SEEN TO END POLLUTION
description: A leading biologist expressed fear yesterday that a planned nationwide campus teachin on pollution of the environment could turn into a glamorous event and a stupendous failure unless it was backed up with longrange philosophy.

title: Message To Marcos
description: Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos was elected to a sec ond term last November by a sizable majority, but opposition groups have charged that the victory was achieved by vote buying, intimidation and fraud. The President's opponents also fear that Mr. Marcos may try to manipulate a constitutional convention scheduled for next year so as to remove a consti tutional barrier to seeking a third term.

title: RIVERSIDE CHURCH HAS MONEY WOES
description: Riverside Church, which dis closed its financial assets in en dowments and its physical plant for the first time this year and said it was more than $100million, is having trouble meeting its budget for activities carried on inside its building.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: In Brief: Sex
description: The Sex Researchers

title: Canadians Seek to Extend Their Foreign Air Routes
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 31Dis cussions between Canadian and foreign airlines, designed to extend overseas routes of Air Canada and Canadian Pacific, with correspondingly deeper penetration this side of the Atlantic by European carriers, may significantly affect traffic at New York's Kennedy International Air port.

title: Nuptials for Miss Barbara Hussennetter
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., Jan. 31 Miss Barbara Hussennetter and Lieut. Ivan G. Larsh of the Marine Corps were mar ried here today in Our Sa vior's Lutheran Church by the Rev. Maury Drum, the pastor.

title: Gerald Loughlin to Wed Barbara Lynch
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 31  The engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Lynch to Gerald Michael Loughlin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James W. Lynch, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Loughlin of New York.

title: 2,000 HONOR POWELL, WHO SAYS HE'LL RUN
description: More than 2,000 people at tended a testimonial luncheon for Adam Clayton Powell, Har lem's 62yearold Representa tive, at the Americana Hotel yesterday.

title: BLACK POLL SET ON VIETNAM WAR
description: Plans for a referendum to poll the attitude of American blacks on the Vietnam war were announced last week by a group of Negro churchmen and other leaders.

title: Point of View
description: SIIVIEON BLOODGOOD was the villain in an off Broadway musical melodrama called Riverwind take one guess what his occupation was. Al though landlords have traditionally been cast as vil lains, the reallife public image of the landlord is at record low today. Criticism of the real estate industry is strongest in the cities and especially in New York.

title: When friends and Presidents fall out
description: Jonathan P. Dolliver, United States Senator from Iowa, a huge man whose wry humor put a good many things into useful perspective, said that William Howard Taft was a large, amiable island surrounded en tirely by persons who know exactly what they want. In the year 1912 Taft was in the White House, which was precisely where Theodore Roose velt, who had put him there in 1909, wanted to be. And thereby hangs the tale William Manners has to tell in his new book, TR and Will. From such bare and simple bones develops a fullbodied story of Shakespearean dimension. One comes upon scheming men, calculating wom en, noble purpose, vulgar comedy, the shining moment, excited rabbles, heartbreak, corn, tears, and the hopes, needs and affections of human beings all jangled up and all work ing through an enterprise of great pith and public consequence. The year 1912 had about everything.

title: American Eagle Triumphs Over 87 Rivals in 105Mile Race in Gulf of Mexico
description: American Eagle Triumphs Over 87 Rivals in 105Mile Race in Gulf of Mexico

title: Medicine
description: In 1960 there were 15; in 1964 there were 38; in 1967 there were 79; and last year a record number of 224 teen agers in New York City shot heroin into their veins and died from it.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The series detective, espe cially in that peculiarly Amer ican expression which began in the late 1920's, is some times shown in terms of brood ing intimacy with death, ha tred, squalor, pettiness, pover ty; and as these things begin to weigh on him, his creator uses their weight to shape his character. We need to look no further than Ross Macdonald's Lew Archer to see how this approach may add depth to a portrayal.

title: In The Nation: Making Ideals a Fraud
description: WASHINGTONIn the few days since Congress, roasting from the heat of the anticrime wave, returned from its mid winter recess, it has raised the greatest threat in many years to American liberty. The legal establishment in America, which ought best to understand this menace, has a special respon sibility for exposing the lasting consequences of momentary po litical hysteria.

title: Harris's 5.9 Ties Mark For 60 Yards Indoors
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 31 (AP)Earl Harris of Okla homa State University tied the indoor record for the 60 yard dash tonight, streaking the distance in 5.9 seconds in the Oklahoma City Jaycee indoor track meet.

title: Nancy M. Warren Has Nuptials
description: McMURRAY, Pa., Jan. 31  Miss Nancy Montgomery Warren was married in Trin ity Methodist Church this afternoon to David Atwood Schroeder. The pastor, the Rev. Conway E. Keibler, per formed the ceremony.

title: Prosecutors Voice Skepticism On Rockefeller's Crime Plan
description: A spokesman for the state's 62 district attorneys said yes terday that his organization, had grave misgivings about Governor Rockefeller's proposal to create a statewide crime fighting chief.

title: Lieut. Ben Henneke Jr. Fiance Of Susan Calhoun Petersmeyer
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 31Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Char les Wrede Petersmeyer of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Cal houn Petersmeyer. to Second Lieut. Ben Graf Henneke Jr., U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Henneke of Tulsa, Okla.

title: Soviet Vaulter Does 171
description: LENINGRAD, Jan. 31 (AP) Uri Khanafin set a Soviet Union indoor polevaulting rec ord today by clearing 17 feet 1 inches.

title: Albert Henry Detweiler Dead; Archeologist and Architect, 63
description: Albert Henry Detweiler, arch eologist and associate dean of the College of Architecture, Art and Planning of Cornell Uni versity, died Friday night in the New York Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Ithaca, N. Y.

title: 4 BLACKS SENTENCED IN AIR STATION FIGHT
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 31 (AP)  Four black Marines convicted of assault in disturbances at the Memphis Naval Air Station that injured 23 persons have been sentenced to terms ranging from one to six months at hard labor.

title: Okker and Taylor Gain New Zealand Net Final
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 31 (AP)Tom Okker, of the Netherlands trounced Ray Ruffels, an Australian Davis Cup player, 61, 64, 63, to day in 70 minutes in a semi final of the Benson and Hedges open tennis tourna ment.

title: West German Team Takes Lead in World FourMan Bobsled Championship
description: West German Team Takes Lead in World FourMan Bobsled Championship

title: Gardens
description: PRESIDENT NIXON marked the new decade last month by signing the bill which established a threemem ber White House Council on Envi ronmental Quality. In doing so, he warned that the fight to clean our air and water was a now or never task for the seven ties.

title: VANDERBILT TENNIS OFFERS SIDELIGHTS
description: The Bulgarian gymnastics team and the world tableten nis champion, Shigeo Ito of Japan, will appear here as part of the Vanderbilt Club's sports week highlighted by a $5,000 international women's tennis tournament.

title: Houseboats Are Heading for the Thousand Islands
description: ALEXANDRIA BAY, N. Y. No form of summer vaca tioning, with the possible ex ception of camping, has had a more rapid rise in popu larity than houseboat cruis ing. And nowhere has this been more in evidence than in the Thousand Islands area of the St. Lawrence River.

title: L.S.U. Star Gets 53 For Total of 2,987 In 10986 Victory
description: BATON ROUGE, Jan. 31 Pistol Pete Maravich of Louisi ana State broke Oscar Robert son's collegiate scoring record tonight with a 15foot jump shot that gave him a career total of 2,974 points.

title: MANHATTAN BOWS TO RUTGERS, 7869
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 31  Rutgers University con verted its last eight free throws in less than 45 seconds tonight and snapped Manhattan Col lege's fourgame winning streak by defeating the Jaspers, 7869, before a capacity crowd of 2,800 at the winner's gym.

title: ALLNEGRO ANTIOCH FACILITY DISBANDS
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Jan 31The allNegro AfroAmeri can Unity House at Antioch College, which was criticized last year by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for violating the Federal Civil Rights Act in limiting itself to Negro students only, has been disbanded without much fan fare.

title: Letters: A Bridge to the Brooklyn Bridge
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Q:
description: Slipper

title: CIVIL SAFEGUARDS GAINING
description: Rules of procedure drafted by leaders in law and in the mass media, of communications to safeguard fair trials without infringing on the free press are winning wide acceptance, ac cording to the Chief Judge of the state.

title: ISRAELIS FARMING WESTBANK AREA
description: MEHOLA, IsraeliOccupied Jordan, Jan. 27The guard house at the entrance to this Israeli outpost stands empty these days. Mehola has become a civilian settlement.

title: Elizabeth Ives To Be a Bride
description: BETHESDA, Md., Jan. 31 The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Turner Ives to Peter Arthur Radice, son of Mrs. Julius John Radice of Chevy Chase and the late Dr. Radice, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Skinner Iveg.

title: MAGAZINES' FILES UNDER SUBPOENA
description: The Federal courts have sub poenaed the unedited files and unused pictures of Time, Life and Newsweek magazines deal ing with the Weatherman fac tion of Students for a Demo cratic Society. The small group of militant revolutionaries is being investigated by a Federal grand jury in connection with four days of disorders in Chi cago last October.

title: SEASON TO OPEN HERE MARCH 28
description: The National Association of Amateur Oarsmen has sanc tioned a record number of 20 regattas for the Orchard Beach Lagoon rowing course in Pelham Bay Park this year.

title: Collectors Reap the Fruits of Demolition
description: THE Anonymous Arts Re covery Society is still worried, though not so much as it used to be, about the fate of New York's grif fins, sibyls, oak leaves, grapes, blossoms, cornuco pias, cherubs, masks, waves, spirals and assorted night mare monsters.

title: OX RIDGE POLO TEAM TOPS TORONTO, 167
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 31The Ox Ridge Hunt Club polo team found the range for four goals in the first chukker and went on to defeat the Toronto Polo Club, 167, today at Ox Ridge.

title: BOAT SHOW SALES APPROACH RECORD
description: A tight ship turneth away a tightmoney market. This ap pears to be the new principle that dealers at the National Boat Show have found to be successful, with sales orders re ported at $54.8million, the sec ond highest in its history.

title: Copper Race Opens in Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 31 Foreign entrepreneurs and geologists, particularly Japa nese, are coming to Zambia in a race to get prospecting rights in vast tracts of min eralbearing country made suddenly available to them, a sequel to the nationalization of the republic's key copper industry and the mineral rights reverting to the state.

title: The Bentwoods of Brooklyn
description: Using a merciless camera's eye style, Paula Fox (whose books include Portrait of Ivan and How Many Miles to Babylon?) describes in this really good novel a loveless middleaged marriage, human beings' cruelty to animals and vice versa, the white liberal's guilt, and the generation gap. Employing the technique of ob servation rather than solution, she spreads these problems be fore the reader and makes no recommendations.

title: Lobbyists Play a Key Role in Albany Lawmaking
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31With a subtlety and sophistication that shatter the stereotype of the cigarsmoking, money wielding buyer of votes, the modern lobbyists here have become indispensable parts of the process of making law.

title: Mrs. Garbisch Rhodes Is Remarried
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Jan. 314Mrs. Gwynne Chrysler Garbisch Rhodes and Capt. David E. Severance, U.S.M.C., retired, were married here this afternoon in the Wash ington Memorial Chapel by the Rev. Sheldon M. Smith in an Episcopal ceremony.

title: 20 Rowing Regattas Listed for Orchard Beach
description: 20 Rowing Regattas Listed for Orchard Beach

title: Soviet Union Woman Leads In European Speed Skating
description: HERRENVEEN, the Nether lands, Jan. 31 (AP)Nina Stat kevich of the Soviet Union fin ished second in the 500meter sprint, won the 1,500 and took the halfway lead todayy in the European women's speed skat ing championships. Her time for the 1,500meter race was 2 min utes 24.92 seconds.

title: Draper Takes Seniors Golf
description: BELLEAIR, Fla., Jan. 31 (UPI)Tom Draper shot a finalround twoover par 74 to day for a 72hole score of 292 and won the second annual in ternational senior golf cham pionship. Draper, a 55yearold manufacturer's representative from Troy, Mich., posted rounds of 73, 68, 77, 74 to beat the runnerup, Curtis Person Sr. of Memphis, Tenn., who finished with a 296.

title: Apartment Squeeze in the Suburbs Tightens
description: A CONSISTENT pattern of rejections of most applications for construc tion of apartments in New York's suburban areas over the last 10 years has led to a major shortage of apart ment units and predictions by planning experts of greater shortages to come.

title: New England Shoe Town Worried, Down at Heel
description: HAVERHILL, Mass.  In the heart of the area known as shoetown here, a billboard contains this nononsense mes sage: Support American Labor. Buy American Shoes. Help Your Neighbor And Yourself. whether consumers are buying do mesticmade shoes in Haverhill  and there are indications that even in this city where footwear accounts for 70 per cent of the industrial base, imports are being soldthey are buying the im ported variety in increasing numbers throughout the United States.

title: CAMPS EXPECTED TO OPEN CALMLY
description: Spring training will start for most major league baseball teams in a little more than two weeks, and there is no indi cation that any progress is being made in negotiating a new basic agreement between the players and the owners.

title: 2 Utah Executions Stayed
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 31 (UPI)  The execution of two convicted murderers  Walter B. Kelbach and Myron D. Lance  by hanging and firing squad was stayed today by District Judge Bryant H. Croft. They had been scheduled to die next Thursday at the Utah State Prison. They would have been the first persons executed in the United States since 1967.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAn interesting political phenomenon is occurring here. It is happening in the open and its architects make no ef fort to hide it; but for all that, few people have sat down and tried to figure out what is going on.

title: Paris Shrugs Off Lindsay Plan To Forgo a Pompidou Welcome
description: PARIS, Jan. 31President Pompidou's staff professed in difference today to Mayor Lind say's refusal to give him an official welcome on his arrival in New York on March 2.

title: Great Lakes Research Center Culls Northwest Ohio History
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Jan. 31 (UPI)Bowling Green State University has established Northwest OhioGreat Lakes re search center, which will serve as a repository of Great Lakes maritime materials and histori cal records of the area.

title: Woman, 20, Dead in Car, Friend Tells of Kidnapping,
description: A 20yearold woman was found dead yesterday in a car at the bottom of a cliff near Grandview, N. Y., in Rockland County, and the police here were questioning a man who said he was her fianc and that they had been kidnapped by two armed men.

title: TWO KEY STAKES SHIFTED TO TURF
description: The New York Racing Asso ciation's stakes schedule will consist of 111 races, 94 on the flat and 17 over the jumps. The organization's season will run from Tuesday March 10 through Monday, Dec. 7, with competi tion at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: Morris Brooke Becomes Fiance Of Miss Wilson
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 31 Mr. and Mrs. Sturgis S. Wil son have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Margaret Bowes Wilson of Brookline, Mass., to Morris Randall Brooke. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Clymer Brooke of Key Lareo. Fla.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Patterson Signed to Fight Tessman April 1 in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Floyd Patterson, the former world heavyweight champion, has signed to fight Mark Tess man, the No. 2ranked light heavyweight in a 10round fight in Sam Houston Coliseum on April 1, Lee Coleman the pro moter announced today.

title: Miss Jane Hill, 1962 Debutante, Engaged to Wed
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., Jan. 31 John A. Hill, president of Aetna Life and Casualty, and Mrs. Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Margaret Hill, to John Georgiades, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Georgiades of Salon ika. Greece.

title: For Young Readers
description: God made the world, Descartes observed, but the Dutch made Hol land. And they're still at it, salvaging fertile new provinces from the Zuider Zee while continuing, with undimin ished vigilance, to protect their low lying farms and cities from the vo racious Waterwolfagainst length ening odds, since Holland (hollow land) is sinking, while the sea is rising. In their long and often dra matic struggle to survive they have mainly relied on dikes (introduced by Roman occupiers) and, for pump ing, on windmills (originally inspired by windpowered devices for raising riverwater to fields which Crusaders saw in the Near East). Hence the title of this remarkable book, hand somely produced on highgrade heavy stock and worth every penny of its price.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Feb. 8Brooklyn Polytechnic Sports Car Club 80mile T.S. D rally; start at Poly Tech Grad uate Center, Route 110, north of Southern State Parkway, Farm ingdale, L. I. Registration: 9:30 A.M. Information: Paul Sass phone (516)5527880.

title: Iceland to Join Trade Bloc
description: GENEVA, Jan. 31The Euro pean Free Trade Association has announced that Iceland will officially become a member on March 1. The association comprises Britain, Sweden, Nor way, Denmark, Switzerland, Austria and Portugal, with Fin land enjoying a special as sociate status.

title: A grim, gleaming farce
description: Bad Debts has scenes in it that make one wince in de lighted discomfort. These scenes are in the same league with the best bitterly comic writing of recent yearspas sages of A Fine Madness, Catch22, Orpheus on Top, Portnoy's Complaint. Even though it ends up failing for lack of emotional thrust, Bad Debts is a novel with honest toGod touchstones in it, a nov el to be recommended for vir tues rare enough that one is grateful for even their quali fied appearance.

title: Polish Girl Toboggan Victor
description: KOENIGSSEE, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP)Barbara Piecha of Po land virtually clinched the women's world tobagganing championships today by win ning three of four runs down a 900meter course in this Alpine resort. Kathy Homstad of the United States was 10th.

title: BADILLO CONFERS WITH YOUNG LORDS
description: Herman Badillo, former Borough President of the Bronx, began an effort yester day to mediate between the Young Lords, a Puerto. Rican militant organization, and the First Spanish Methodist Church in East Harlem, which the Young Lords occupied fo 11 days. until Jan. 7.

title: Wall St. Group Backs a Degree
description: Harold A. Rousselot, chair man of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, has announced that the associa tion will sponsor the develop ment of a professional degree for securities salesmen.

title: ISRAELIS BATTLE U.A.R. COMMANDOS
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31Offi cials here reported tonight that an Israeli patrol clashed with an Egyptian commando unit on the Israeliheld eastern shore of the Suez Canal today, finally throwing the Egyptians back with heavy losses.

title: 111 Races 94 on the Flat and 17 over the Jumps, Listed for New York Tracks
description: 111 Races, 94 on the Flat and 17 over the Jumps, Listed for New York Tracks

title: Writing About Trade Unions
description: A few months ago, I attended a meeting of the editorial committee of a quarterly journal devoted to the study of America's social prob lems. The editors had it in mind to bring out a special issue on Trade Unionism Today. The 15 learned men in attendance thought this an excellent idea  the subject, every one agreed, had been sorely neglect ed of late. For a couple of hours we talked about the idea, with stead ily diminishing animationand, when we adjourned, the project was pi geonholed. It turned out that we simply could not come up with the names of 10 or so interesting writers who might contribute to such a spe cial issue. As a matter of fact, we couldn't even come up with five.

title: HIALEAH FEATURE TO VENT DU NORD
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31Leroy Jolley saddled Mr. Brogann for today's $32,150 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah, slightly confident and somewhat wary. In his last start Mr. Brogann won the $50, 000 added Tropical Park Handi cap but that race was on the dirt. The Palm Beach was a mile and a sixteenth on the grass.

title: City Opera to Open A 9  Week Season With Lucia Feb. 19
description: The spring season of the New York City Opera's 27th year will open on Feb. 19 with Donizetti's Lucia di Lammer moor. During its nine weeks at the New York State Theater the company will give 69 per formances of 16 works.

title: NIXON AIDE SEES PRICE RISE RELIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  President Nixon's chief economic adviser said today that the pace of price increases should fall to 3.5 per cent a year by the end of 1970 and that the rise in unemployment resulting from the Administration's anti inflationary policies should not be large.

title: Law
description: CLEVELAND  There was strong irony last week that Joseph A. Yablonski's death was accomplishing the very thing for which the United States Attor ney here Robert B. Krupansky, hinted the ebelunion leader had been killed to stop: A fullscale investigation of the ingrown, violenceprone United Mine Workers of America.

title: Knicks Crush Bulls Here, 123104; Maravich Shatters Scoring Record
description: The 17th sellout crowd of 19,500 for this National Basket ball Association season at Madison Square Garden, wan dered away, slightly dazzled and a bit dazed, last night, after watching Walt Frazier whip the New York Knicker bockers to a 123104 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Snead Cards 72 for 218 To Lead by Four Strokes
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP)Sam Snead of Boca Raton, Fla., lengthened his lead to four strokes at the end of 54 holes in the Profes sional Golfers' Association seniors championships at the National Gold Club today.

title: Claudia Whitney Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Hills Whitney of Brooklyn Heights have announced tiffe engage ment of their daughter, Miss Claudia Whitney, to Gunter. Frankenberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Frankenberg of Hoxter, West Germany. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Stewart, Andretti Get Top Spots In Auto Racing Buff's Rankings
description: CALLING Jackie Stewart or Mario Andretti the world's greatest or best driver will get you an argument, but you'll be on safer ground characterizing them as the leading drivers of 1969. Just be sure to cite Ralph J. Money's annual driver stand ings as your authority. Money is a race buff, but he overrides personal emotions and opinions (his and anyone else's) in grading race drivers. Money is a mathema ticianprofessor of mathe matics at Fairfield (Conn.) University and mathematics coordinator in the grade schools of Trumbull, Conn. and his approach is purely mathematical.

title: LAIRD MOVES TO BAR BIAS IN CONTRACTING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has issued a memoran dum ordering his subordinates to tighten up compliance with nondiscrimination requirements in defense contracting.

title: Columbia Crushes Princeton, 7652, as Titers Play Without Injured Petrie
description: Columbia Crushes Princeton, 7652, as Titers Play Without Injured Petrie

title: Harry Dent, the President's political coordinator, says:
description: RICHARD NIXON was still lost in a political wilderness in the spring of 1966 when he re ceived a visit from a young South Carolina Republican named Harry Dent. Dent, a brash, redhaired Bap tist deacon who had once been Sena tor J. Strom Thurmond's top aide and was now South Carolina's Repub lican chairman, had come to New York to invite Nixon to an unlikely happening: a Republican dinner in a state so stubbornly Democratic that

title: Truth on the Rails
description: A Federal judge's nostrike, nolockout order has brought a last chance for sanity in the dispute that brought the nation to the brink of a total stoppage of railroad service yesterday.

title: Lum's Chief: From Law to Hot Dogs
description: MIAMI, Fla.  In the up per echelon of the financial gambling fraternity in Las Vegas, the betting is even money that Clifford S. Perl man will fill the No. 3 niche in the not too distant future. Spots one and two are filled by Howard Hughes and Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Chromalloy in Pact
description: The Chromalloy American Corporation has concluded an agreement with Joseph Lucas Industries, Ltd., Birm ingham, England, under which Chromalloy will li cense Lucas's worldwide rights outside North America to use Chromalloy's smog burner exhaust control sys tem and turbine blower patents in its automotive smogcontrol systems.

title: Dalong's 4:01.1 Sets Boston Meet Mark
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31  Proving that a runforfun philosophy can produce dramatic results, Art Dulong of Holy Cross won the Hunter Mile in the meet record time of 4 minutes 1.1 seconds tonight at the 81st an nual Boston Athletic Associa tion Indoor Games.

title: Carolina Plan to Build a Plant on Unspoiled Coast Arouses Protest
description: BEAUFORT, S. C., Jan. 27 A storm of organized opposi tion has been aroused by statesponsored plan to per mit construction of a huge $200million chemical process ing plant in the heart of one of South Carolina's last remaining unspoiled coastal areas.

title: The Showoff Shrubs
description: AMONG the most popular ornamental shrubs are viburnums. They are valuable for landscape effects, beautiful flowers, at tractive summer foliage and brilliantly colored fruits. They are hardy as far north as New England, indifferent to soil and with one or two exceptions, free from insects and diseases.

title: Dramatic Rise in Drug Abuse Is Reported in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 31 Drug abuse, especially among the young, has increased dra matically in Australia in the last year, according to testimony be fore a Senate committee irrvesti gating the problem.

title: Tricia Nixon Is Ill With the Measles At Key Biscayne
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Tricia Nixon has the regular measles and not German measles, the White House said this afternoon. Miss Nixon is at the family's Key Biscayne, Florida home.

title: Mrs. Tracy and Lloyd Nelson Jr. Wed
description: DEAL, N. J., Jan. 31 Mrs. Carmen Pietre Tracy, widow of Donald S. Tracy and daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raul Pietre of Allenhurst and San Juan, Puerto Rico, was married here this afternoon to Lloyd A. Nelson Jr., a widower of White Plains.

title: Bad News Of the Psyche
description: WHAT is it about the paintings of the German Expressionists that so offends the sensibili ties of so many connoisseurs of modern painting? The distaste of an earlier generation, so pleasurably in thrall to the luxe, calme et volupt of French painting, so admiring of its ex quisite analytic powers and the grace with which the masters of the School of Paris seemed able to transmute ev ery perception of the world around them into a pictorial conception of the greatest decorative delicacythis, cer tainly, was understandable. Compared to the intellectual detachment and the sheer hedonistic display of French art, its German counterpart seemed over charged with emotion, undisciplined in form, perhaps even a little raucous in its adamant attachment to the raw ma terials of experience.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Photographs by Bernard P. Wolff from Photo Researchers, Inc., and Marc and Evelyne Bernheim from Raph?? Guillumette

title: Snow Speed Gets Fresh Start Today
description: PARIS, Jan. 31Recall, gentlemen, this race is a recall.

title: Indians Are Hopeful Nixon Administration Will Match Words With Deeds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  Leaders of America's impov erished Indians hope to find out by the end of February whether the Nixon Administration will come to their aid with more than rhetoric.

title: Chess
description: AMERICAN players are at their re sourceful best when the scene is Europe and the action is selective and hard. The tradition goes back to the 1850's. Then, the New Orleans genius, Paul Morphy, sailed for England to seek a match with Howard Staunton.

title: Nigeria's Oil Industry Makes Quick Recovery From the War
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 31 Nigeria's oil industry is fast effacing the ravages of the civil war. Production has al ready overtaken the highest prewar level and is expected to rise in February when most of the damage by raiding planes will have been re paired.

title: Iris Sorensen Wed
description: The marriage of Miss Iris Baek Sorensen to Aaron Jacob Richman, both of New York, took place here yester day in Temple Israel. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sorensen of Copen hagen, Denmark. Her hus band, a director of the East Bronx Youth Council, is a son of Alex Richman of the Bronx, and the late Mrs. Richman.

title: L.I.U. Swimmers Win
description: Andres Tropea was victorious in two events as Long Island University's swimmers defeated C.C.N.Y., 5536, yesterday

title: A.A.U. Track Tickets On Sale at the Garden
description: Tickets for the Amateur Athletic Union's national in door track and field cham pionships are on sale at Mad ison Square Garden and the A.A.U. House, 231 West 58th Street.

title: Diane L. Fricke Will Be Bride Of David S. Ely
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 31  Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Fricke have announced the engagement of Mr. Fricke's daughter, Miss Diane L. Fricke, to David Stanley Ely, son of Mrs. Luther Ely of East St. Johnsbury, Vt. and the late Mr. Ely.

title: Mrs. Brander Wed To Jason Sumner
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Jan. 31Mrs. Joan Mirc Brander was married here today to Jason Sumner, vice president of Spinning Wheel Rugs in New York. The ceremony was performed at the United Methodist Church by the Rev. Donald Stacey.

title: Loreen Joy Goldenson Bride of Norman Fox
description: Miss Loreen Joy Golden son, daughter of Leonard H. Goldenson, president of the American Broadcasting Com panies, Inc., and Mrs. Gold enson of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and New York, was married here last evening to Norman Chandler Fox, who is an ac count executive with Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., New York advertising agency. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Fox of Denver, where his father is founder and board chairman of Fox Metal Industries.

title: OF SOLDIERS AND SPIES
Alouettes Sign Citadel Back
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 31 (AP) Tony Passander, a 5foot11 inch quarterback from The Cit adel, has signed with the Montreal Alouettes of the Ca nadian Football League, the club announced today.

title: INSPECTORS FLUNK 1 RESTAURANT IN 4
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs reported yes terday it had carried out an other inspection of city eating places and had found 23 per cent to be serving meat dishes that did not meet city or state standards.

title: Bridge
description: EXPERTS of the bridge table are well trained in intercepting and interpreting enemy messages. And, like all good intelligence men, they are also aware of the possibility of the doublecross: if you know that the enemy is reading your mes sages, you can feed him some signif icant misinformation.

title: Frills for Top Men Cut, But Many Goodies Remain
description: American corporations may be cutting back on some of their, executive frills because of the general profit squeeze, but if you make between $15,000 and $250,000, there still seem to be plenty of solid benefits left to keep you from getting itchy feet.

title: Dance
description: BY common consent this present dance season is the busiest and the biggest the United States has ever known. More people are going to dance than ever before. It is, as Alexander Ewing, administra tor of the City Center Jof frey Ballet, puts it, the gold en age of American dance. But that is about the only thing that is golden about American dance.

title: Flaming Servings Extinguished By the City's Fire Department
description: Flaming dishes and drinks may spark a gourmet's delight, but not that of the city's Fire Department, which has issued new regulations on the use of open flame in public areas of assembly.

title: Florida Debates the Future of a Controversial Canal
description: PALATKA, Fla., Jan. 31 Conservation Committee mem bers of the Florida Legislature, along with representatives of the United States Corps of En gineers, toured portions of the Cross Florida Barge Canal this week as a prelude to hear ing testimony by the corps.

title: PANEL BIDS NIXON CONTINUE EFFORTS IN URBAN RENEWAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The President's study group on urban renewal has recom mended that the controversial Federal program be continued and used as a major means of halting the balkanization and polarization of American soci ety.

title: Bil Baird Show Appeals it to Whole Family
A Crash Food Plan for Poor Mothers is Discounted
description: A Government expert in child development predicts that crash programs to feed mal nourished pregnant women will not result in the desired decline in the rates of mental defi ciency, infant mortality and prematurity among the poor.

title: ITALIANS ARE NEXT AFTER TWO HEATS
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 31 (AP)West Germany, after finishing onetwo in the twoman world bobsled cham pionships last week, took the lead over Italy in the four man bobs after two heats today.

title: Rice Inventories
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)Sticks of unmilled rough rice on Jan. 1 totaled 62.7 million hundred pounds, down 6 per cent from the record large supply of a year earlier, according to the Agri culture Department. Milled rice holdings totaled slightly more than three million hun dred pounds, down 36 per cent from a year ago, the de partment said.

title: Players and Owners Report No Progress in Talks on Key Baseball Issues
description: Players and Owners Report No Progress in Talks on Key Baseball Issues

title: SEIXAS, UFFORD GAIN IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31 Vic Seixas, a former Wimbledon and United States tennis title holder, gained the semifinal round of the 29th Atlantic Coast squashracquets cham pionship today by winning, 516, 1613, 1816, from third seeded Diehl Mateer Jr. at the ChalfonteHaddon Hall Racquet Club.

title: ANTIAMBUSH PLAN APPROVED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay promised full cooperation yesterday in a planned campaign to warn people that ambushes against the police endangered both civilians and policemen.

title: Charles Rentschler Is Fiance Of Suzanne Stewart Snowden
description: Miss Suzanne Stewart Snowden, who is Mrs. John V. Lindsay's personal secre tary, and Charles Edwin Mitchell Rentschler, an asso ciate with McKinsey & Co., Inc., management consultants, plan to be married in April.

title: Bridge:
description: THE small number of New York enthusiasts who traveled to Bermuda last week for the regional cham pionships in Hamilton were well rewarded in terms of weather and hospitality, but fared less well in the tourna ment. Only Dr. Robert Tator of New York and Dr. John Manos of East Norwich, L. I., figured among the winners. They captured the Swiss team championship with Frank Westcott of North Attleboro, Mass., Robert Fox and Robert McVay, both of Providence.

title: GLOOM PERSISTS IN BOND MARKET
description: The bond market has just come through a dismal week with prices falling and new is sues failing to attract inves tors. Investment bankers see little reason for conditions to change this week.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The following is a list of loans and other aid expended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Dr. Ernst Waldinger, Poet And Skidmore Professor
description: Dr. Ernst Waldinger, an Aus trian poet and retired Skidmore College professor, died of pneu monia yesterday at Beth Abra ham Hospital in the Bronx. He was 73 years old and lived at 372 Central Park West.

title: Boy, 13, Drowns in Bronx
description: A 13yearold boy drowned yesterday when he fell through the ice at a pond in the Bronx Zoological Gardens. The police identified the victim as Philip Samms of 835 Jennings Street, the Bronx. Two companions were rescued by a passerby.

title: The Scourge of Youth
description: In the nineteenforties, teen agers sneaked a beer now and then if they wanted to be dar ing. By the nineteenfifties, beer had given way to gin, and campuses were filled with students who went on binges before assaults on telephone booths and girls' dormitories.

title: Cleveland Safety Chief
description: I'M ambitiousI like a challenge, I like to fig ure out one set of problems and then go on to the next. This was how Lieut. Gen. Benjamin Oliver Davis Jr. of the Air Force explained a bit of his personal philosophy to a visitor to Clark Air Force Base in the Philippines sev eral months ago when the general was in command of the 13th Air Force. He said, The military throws more on a man than he can easily handle. Either you grow with your job or you fall out of the system.

title: BENT, CARYN WEST TAKE SKI CROWNS
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Feb. 1Chuck Bent, 20 years old and cocaptain of the Dart mouth College ski team, won the Corcoran Cup today with a thirdplace finish in the 42 gate giant slalom. The course was 3,000 feet in length and had a drop of 916 feet. Bent's firstplace finish in yesterday's slalom helped take the top award.

title: 70 ENEMY ATTACKS IN SOUTH VIETNAM REPORTED BY U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 2The United States command said today that Vietcong and North Vietnamese forces staged more than 70, Irocket, mortar and ground at tacks in South Vietnam during the weekend, inflicting the heaviest casualties on Ameri can forces in a month.

title: Milwaukee's Poor Prod Stores in Clothing Fight
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1In the middle of one of Milwau kee's coldest winters, down town store owners are under pressure to urge county of ficials to provide proper winter clothing for children of parents on welfare.

title: Marchi Shuns Race for House, but Ponders a Bid for U.S. Senate
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1State Sen ator Joint J. Marchi has ruled out a race for the House of Representatives this fall, but says he still wakes up each morning with my Hamlet thing about the United States Senate.

title: Miss Antolini Bride Of Richard Scherer
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 1 Miss Carole Antolini and Richard Sheldon Scherer were married here this after noon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Fagan.

title: Navy Man Shot Near Manila
description: MANILA, Feb. 1 (AP)  A United States Navy enlisted man attending a village fiesta with his wife and children was shot and killed, military offi cials confirmed today. Gary E. Watkins of Chillicothe, Ill., was said to have been slain while walking in the town of Barn ban, 55 miles north of Manila.

title: Wisniewski Captures Run; Robinson Finishes Second
description: George Wisniewski, a 21 yearold history teacher at George Washington High School, won the seventh annual Henry E. Isola Memorial 4 mile run yesterday. The race, which drew 60 entries, was held over a fourlap course in the Bronx Market adjacent to the Yankee Stadium.

title: Truancy Overwhelms the Truant Officers Here
description: For tens of thousands of the city's teenagers, going to school has become a some time thing.

title: BOAT SHOW ENDS RUN AT COLISEUM
description: The nineday run of the 60th National Boat Show ended at the Coliseum yesterday without setting any records, which in itself was a record.

title: Macy Union Meets Today To Set a Walkout Date
description: The executive board of a union involving 9,000 Macy's department store employes is scheduled to meet today to de cide when to strike the huge store and four other branches if no suitable wage offer is received.

title: Renew Your Driver License
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1 (UPI)Mon day is the last day for re newing New York State regis tration and driver's licenses that expired yesterday. The Motor Vehicles Department extended the deadline to Monday be cause the expiration date fell on a weekend.

title: Rosie Dolly Netcher of the Dancing Sisters Dies
description: Roszika Dolly Netcher, the last of the famed dancing Dolly Sisters, died yesterday of heart attack at LeRoy Hospital. She was 77 years old.

title: Jewish Congress Organizes Urban Affairs Commission
description: The American Jewish Con gress announced yesterday the establishment of a commission on urban affairs to mobilize a new attack on the problem of the cities.

title: Court Order Forbids Lincoln Hospital TakeOver
description: Joseph V. Terenzio, the city's Commissioner of Hospitals, said last night that a court order had been obtained against a Puerto Rican group that had threatened an unlawful take over of Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx today.

title: Nasser Meets Karami As Policy Talks Begin
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1 (AP) President Gamal Abdel Nas ser of the United Arab Re public began a series of high level meetings today, appar ently aimed at restating Egyptian policy in the Middle East conflict.

title: Ethiopia Adds a Dash of Pepper to New AgriIndustry
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Even in this age of farranging international enterprise, trade ties between Kalamazoo, Mich., and the Ethiopian highlands may seem improbable. But not in the modern spice trade.

title: TALISMAN SCORES FOR ROBIN BACON
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 1 Every Friday, good weather and bad, Robin Bacon leaves Barnstable High School in Hyannis Port, Mass., and makes the long journey to Nimrod Farm in Weston, Conn., where she spends the weekend riding under the supervision of Ronnie Mutch.

title: Governor's Panel Urges City U. To Consider Charging Tuition
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1Governor Rockefeller's Council of Eco nomic Advisers has recommend ed that serious consideration be given to charging tuition at the City University of New York because of a gap between the university's plans for ex pansion and its limited sources of revenue.

title: Hint of Spring in Botanical Garden Routs Winter Woe
description: Smells of indoor orange blos soms, absinthe and myrtle, and the sound of rushing water through acres of sunlit woods helped dispel the rigors of Jan uary for 2,500 visitors to the New York Botanical Garden yesterday.

title: Transit Fares in Paris Also RiseAbout 16%
description: PARIS, Feb. 1 (Reuters) Bus, subway and suburban train fares here went up by an average of 16 per cent to day.

title: Telephone 6863061 For Advice, Aid, Job Or Just Cheering Up
description: Beginning at 9 A.M. today, New Yorkers can dial 6863061 and reach someone who will give them advice on finding an apartment, getting a job, set tling an argument, preventing a suicide, or handling a drug addict.

title: ERNEST WOLTON
description: Ernest Wolton, production manager for the Consolidated Cigar Corporation here from 1943 to his retirement in 1961, died of a heart attack in a San Juan hospital yesterday while on a visit. He was 80 years old and lived at 411 East 57th Street.

title: OPPOSITION LEADS COSTA RICAN VOTE
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Mon day, Feb. 2Jos Figures Ferrer, presidential candidate of the opposition National Libera tion party, took a commanding lead early today in returns from Costa Rica's national elec tions.

title: Madeleine S. Arons Is Wed to D.J. Leone
description: Miss Madeleine Susan Arons and Donald John Leone were married here at noon yesterday in the Hamp shire House. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Ghana Acts on Earnings
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  Gha na's Government has set up a foreign  exchange committee within its Cabinet to assure proper use of the country's for eignexchange earnings, the Finance and Economic Planning Minister, J. H. Mensah, said this weekend.

title: Bar Asks for Right Of Bilked Buyers To Sue Financers
description: A committee of the Associa tion of the Bar of the City of New York recommended yes terday that consumers who have bought defective merchan dise on installment plans be permitted to sue companies that financed the purchase.

title: Prey Sings Works Rarely Heard Here
description: Hermann Prey, the German baritone, gave New York art song enthusiasts something they seldom hear in his recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday nighthalf a program devoted to songs by Hans Pfitzner, a Mcscowborn German com poser, who lived from 1869 to 1949.

title: Fugitive Falls Ill in Greece After Asking Return to U.S.
description: ATHENS, Feb. 1Richard C. Scott, an American on the run since jumping bail in 1968 on California drug charges, col lapsed and was sent to a hos pital today before United States consular officials could act on his request to be sent back home.

title: Bronx Man, 21, Is Accused Of Murdering His Fiancee
