description: ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Feb. 1 A 21yearold Bronx man was arrested here today, charged with the murder of his fiance, who was found dead yesterday in a car at the bot tom of an embankment off Route 9W about a mile south of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Cefalu Retains His Title In Senior Speed Skating
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 1 (AP)Pete Cefalu of West Allis., Wis., fell in the 440yard race, but came back for the fivemile title and won his third straight senior men's title today in the 71st national outdoor speedskating championships at Lake Como.

title: CHARLES A. PEARCE, BOOK PUBLISHER, 63
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 1 Charles A. Pearce, a book edi tor and publisher, died today after a heart attack in his home at 145 Neperan Road here. He was 63 years old.

title: Pittsburgh Rabbi Named Religious Zionists' Head
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 1 The election of Rabbi Bern ard A. Poupko as president of the Religious Zionists of America was announced here today at the closing session of the group's 60th annual convention.

title: Company Sells Fashion Designers' Talents
description: Many fashion designers have marketable ideas that might be profitably trans lated into other fields of design and art. But unless the designers have reached top rank so that corporations approach them with propos als, they rarely get a chance to put these ideas into action.

title: Lost in Leap From Ferry
description: An unidentified man about 40 years old jumped yesterday from the stern of a Staten Is landbound ferryboat and dis appeared into the Upper Bay. Another passenger aboard the boat, the American Legion, saw the man jump at 12:15 P.M. about 1,000 feet off South Ferry. Capt. Walter Smith or dered a rowboat over the side, and three crewmen searched in vain for the man for 20 minutes. Two police launches then began search.

title: ITALY CAPTURES BOBSLED CROWN
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland. Feb. 1 (UPI)Nevio de Zordo, piloting Italy's No. 1 bobsled, broke the track record today to snatch victory from Wolfgang Zimmerer of West Germany in the 1970 world fourman bob sled championship.

title: Peace Forces, Lacking a Leader and Money, Gird for Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1At 1 o'clock in the morning one day last week, four professional mena doctor, two lawyers and an accountantgathered in a Capitol Hill office whose walls were covered with pictures of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Norman Thomas, Wendell L. Willkie and Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Baker Hartel Is Off and Running
description: The only mistake that Stephen Baker has made far with his new ad agency, Baker Hartel, Inc., was an nouncing it last Thursday, the same day as Marion Harper Jr. announced his. Mr. Baker got the space squeeze.

title: ORRIN DUNLAP JR., RADIO AUTHORITY
description: Orrin E. Dunlap Jr., who re tired in 1960 as vice president in charge of advertising and publicity of the Radio Corpo ration of America, died yester day of pneumonia in New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 11 Amherst Road, Great Neck, L. I.

title: Bar Association Century
description: Tammany Hall and the Tweed Ring controlled New York a century ago. The archives reveal that an editorial on this page called upon the lawyers of the city to stop being supine, break their silence, behave like true officers of the people's courtsand get organized.

title: Robertson's Price Tag May Jeopardize Trade
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) Coach Bob Cousy of the Cin cinnati Royals said after a 115108 loss to the Chicago Bulls today that he'd rather trade Oscar Robertson now than wait until the end of the season. Robertson, how ever, might have priced him self out of going to the Baltimore Bullets, a club that has expressed strong in terest in him.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1970

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: IN Prisoners of Culture, George A. Pettit of the Berkeley anthropology de partment modestly steps from behind the academic curtain, clears his pedagogi cal voice (somewhat), and performs to a slowslow beat his own muted versions of the desmond Morris dance and the Lionel Tiger rag. Half the act is extremely impres sive. What is man? asks Mr. Pettit. Why, the sum of his evolutionary past. Where did that past begin? In the Oldivai Gorge, in Tanzania, East Africa, some 1, 750,000 years ago, where Australo pithecus first reared up on his two hind legs. Who cares? We all had better, be cause just as am nesiacs need their identities, society, too, needs a back ground for its self pride. That background had best coincide with the realities of human nature, which can only be discovered in the human past. If it doesn't, we may very well crack up. In fact, our plight today, and the plight of our children especially (children being the guinea pigs of civilization) suggests that America is already well on the way to the mental asylum.

title: PURCELL CAPTURES NORDIC SKIING TITLE
description: RIPTON, Vt., Feb. 1Bill Pur cell, a 32yearold member of the National Nordic Combined B Team, finished a close second today in the 15kilometer cross country race that concluded the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association Nordic com bined championships and won the overall title.

title: After Long Career, Beverly Sills Makes Her Local Recital Debut
description: Beverly Sills has had an extraordinarily long and varied career, but until yesterday aft ernoon, she had never sung recital in New York. Thus, it was a kind of debut that she made in the Great Per formers series at Philharmonic Halla debut attracting an overflow audience that filled the stage behind her.

title: Tokle Scores SkiJump Double At Bear Mountain Competition
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 1On the same hill that had provided the backdrop for many victories by his Norwegianborn father, a former American champion, Arthur Tokle Jr. en joyed the most successful day of his skijumping career this afternoon.

title: 'I Cut My Way Through the Crocodiles . . .
description: LONDONTwo of the great British popular papers had their ace foreign correspondents cov ering the Congo rebellion. With a nod to Evelyn Waugh, we may call them Banger of The Daily Beast and Oldwife of The Daily Brute.

title: Old Tokens Won't Do On City Buses March 1
description: The use of the old 20cent tokens as part of the exact fare payment on city buses will be discontinued March 1, the Transit Authority an nounced yesterday.

title: Court Deadline Today
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1At least 43 school districts in seven Deep South states are facing court orders to desegregate to morrow in a major test of the white Southerner's capacity to accept social reform.

title: TENNIS TOURNEY FACING BOYCOTT
description: OMAHA, Feb. 1 (AP)Stan Smith won the $10,000 Mid lands international tennis tour nament today. Then, as a spokesman for the registered players in this country, he threatened a boycott of the Philadelphia indoor open, scheduled to start tomorrow.

title: PHILIPPINE SCHOOLS CLOSED FOR A WEEK
description: MANILA, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  The Government of the Phil ippines tonight suspended for a week all classes in Manila and nearby cities as student leaders planned a demonstra tion to mark the deaths of four students killed in clashes with security forces Friday night.

title: Biafrans Wait and Watch From Exile in Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Feb. 1  The Ibos inside Nigeria have no choice now, but none of us outside want to be Nige rians, said Peter Ochigbo, who still uses the title deputy per manent representative of Biafra in the Ivory Coast.

title: A CatchingUp Budget
description: Mayor Lindsay's proposed $1.4billion construction budget for the City of New York is less what it claims to be than what it has to be. It is less a budget for a city with growing needs than it is a budget for catching up with longneglected and shuntedaside problems. It provides less for building the new than for repairing and replacing the old.

title: Split on Defining Jew Grows in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1The question of who is a Jew appears far from settled here despite the Government's de cision last week to seek to ap ply a strict religious definition to immigration and registration procedures.

title: Miss Sue Jacobson Is Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Miss Sue Ellen Jacobson to Paul Alan Meyers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Meyers of Long Beach, L. I., took place here yester day afternoon. Rabbi Bernard Klegfeld performed the cere mony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Jacobson.

title: VietnamStudy Conclusion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Following is the text of the conclusions in a Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff study on Vietnam, made public today:

title: YEAR'S EARNINGS UP AT HOSPITAL SUPPLY
description: The American Hospital Sup ply Corporation announced over the weekend record sales and earnings for 1969. Net in come spurted 19 per cent to $25million from $20.92million a year earlier. On a pershare basis, earnings amounted to 77 cents, up from 67 cents.

title: Kheel Becomes Publisher Of a Journal of Politics
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, has become publisher of Interplay, a journal of inter national politics, succeeding Gerard C. Smith.

title: TV: Front Page, Harbinger of Entente With Stage
description: IN a day when the perform ing arts are feeling the economic pinch and so much theater is addicted to unde cipherable hangups, it is en couraging news that stage people and the Xerox Corpo ration have joined forces in presenting on television ac cepted American classics. The potential of the entente was the major significance of Saturday evening's pres entation of The Front Page, starring Robert Ryan and George Grizzard, on a network of independent sta tions, including Channel 5 in New York.

title: LEADER OF LESOTHO JAILS 30 OPPONENTS
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Under orders from Chief Leabua Jonathan, the Prime Minister, policemen to day jailed at least 30 members of the opposition Congress party, including 16 members of the party's executive com mittee.

title: Cucumbers, Cows and Variety of Color Decorate New China
description: FOOD aside, the nation's dining tables will soon be groaning with a weighty bounty of some of the most colorful, freshly patterned and practical wares to be shown in recent seasons. Cookandserve pots and pans have come a long way, judging by the new collec tions of Dansk Designs, Ltd., and Copco.

title: 300 TUGBOATS IDLE AS MEN WALK OUT FOR DOUBLED WAGE
description: Tugboat workers seeking threeyear contract that would double their wages struck the Port of New York yesterday, idling 300 tugs that move pas senger liners, freighters, gar bage scows and oil tankers across the harbor.

title: Mets Steal the Show at Baseball Frolic
description: The dawning of the age of the amazing Mets was heralded in song and dance last night when New York's baseball writers staged their 47th annual dinner at the Americana.

title: $30MILLION TO HELP CITIES FIGHT CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)  The Government's crime fighting agency will award $30million in grants during the next five months to help the nation's cities solve pressing crime problems, Attorney Gen eral John N. Mitchell an nounced today.

title: Advertising: Agencies Feel Money Pinch
description: The tight money situation is having its repercussions on the advertising scene and some of the small suppliers who work for agencies are hurting.

title: Savings Officer Named
description: The Equitable Federal Sav ings and Loan Association an nounced yesterday that John B. King, former executive deputy superintendent of New York City schools and one of the nation's leading Negro educa tors, had been elected chair man of the $116million Brook lynbased institution. Dr. King, 62 years old, succeeds Andrew S. Roscoe, who is retiring.

title: PONTIFF ADAMANT ON CELIBACY RULE
description: ROME, Feb. 1Pope Paul VI said today that celibacy of priests was so fundamental a principle of the Roman Catho lic Church that it could not be questioned, much less dropped.

title: Party Bids Czechs Work Harder
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 1The official Czechoslovak television report ed the other day that some of the World Cup soccer matches in Mexico might not be seen here this year. Because of the time difference, too many work ers would stay up late to watch and this might affect work di scipline.

title: Who Cares About Drug Abuse?
description: The seriousness of New York City's drug abuse problem and the utter inadequacy of the governmental response to it have been demonstrated by a series of developments within the past several days.

title: Bonn and Moscow Sign Pact Trading Pipes for Gas
description: BONN, Feb. 1Soviet and West German officials signed agreements in Essen today that call for a longterm ex change of German steel pipes for Soviet natural gas in what promises to be one of the biggest business deals between the two countries.

title: 3 Legislative Experts on Conservation List 10 Ways for Citizens to Win Environmental Battles
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1  Everybody's talking about en vironmental problems, but howl do you get something done about them?

title: The New Budget: TopSecret Printer's Headache
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  The final pages of the Fed eral bureaucracy's bible for the next year  the 1971 budget which will be made public tomorrow  cascaded off the presses of the Gov ernment Printing Office four days ago and were rushed under guard to its bindery.

title: The Proceedings In the U.T. Today
City Expense Budget Estimated To Be Increasing $600Million
description: New York City's expense budget will go up by $600mil lion to $700million on the basis of revenues likely to reach a total of $7.2billion to $7.3 billion for the year starting July 1, the Citizens Budget Commission predicted yester day.

title: Brooklyn Prep Swim Squad Dethrones Seton Hall Prep
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. Brooklyn Prep snapped Seton Hall Prep's twoyear reign in the 19th annual metropolitan) Catholic interscholastic swim ming championships tonight. Seton Hall, the host school, finished behind Brooklyn, 42 37, in the 15school field.

title: Film of Kremlin Letter Weaves Espionage Tale
Chemical Company's Gift Opens Whitney to Staff
description: About 2,000 employes of the Geigy Chemical Corporation may now enjoy the art exhibi tions and other facilities of the Whitney Museum of American Art at no charge. The museum, at Madison Avenue and 75th Street, has a $1 admission fee.

title: K. N. Sherman And Mrs. Rubin Wed in Suburbs
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 1  Mrs. Merry Mar golish Rubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerson T. Mar golish, was married at her parents' home here today to Kenneth N. Sherman, a foun der and general partner of the Cambridge Research and Development Group in West port, Conn.

title: Barnard Mourns a Heroin Victim
description: Two weeks ago, a bright, pretty Barnard freshman named Antoinette Dishman joined other black militants in a de monstration to force St. Luke'S Hospital to open a progra n for teenaged heroin addicts.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA WAGE NEW BATTLE, HEAVIEST SINCE '67
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 1Israeli and Syrian tank and artillery units today fought their heaviest battle since the six day war of 1967. It was the third successive day of ground fighting in the Golan heights.

title: ARTHUR L. STERN
description: Arthur L. Stern, president and founder of the Arthur Stern Meat Company in the Bronx, died at New York Hospital yesterday. He was 66 years old and lived at 799 Park Avenue.

title: 100 Reported Dead As 2 Trains Crash Near Buenos Aires
description: BUENOS AIRES, Monday, Feb. 2A passenger express train smashed into the rear of a parked commuter train filled with people returning from a weekend holiday last night, crushing two of the five com muter cars and knocking the others off the track.

title: Tricia Nixon Feeling Better
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Tricia Nixon, suffering from the measles at the Nixon villa at Key Biscayne, Fla., is feeling much better, the White House said today. The President's 23 yearold daughter was running a 104degree temperature three days ago.

title: BUILDING ORDERS SET 1969 RECORD
description: A late surge of contracts for future construction work at the end of 1969 brought the total volume of building con tracts placed in the conti nental United States during the year to a record level of $67.4billion, indicating that in at least one sector of the economy the Nixon Adminis tration's cooling  off measures have yet to take hold.

title: Demand Is Strong For Steel Exports
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1Steel officials report booming export demand with continued uncer tainty at home.

title: Plans for a Luxury Ship Terminal Are Abandoned
description: An ambitious plan of the city and Port of New York Author ity for a consolidated sixberth passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River in luxury liner row has been abandoned, and a lessambitious project is under study.

title: 2 Die in Tel Aviv Blast
description: TEL AVIV, Monday, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Two persons were killed and several others in jured when an explosion rocked a factory north of Tel Aviv shortly before midnight, the po ke said early today. They de clined to give any further details.

title: Newark Teacher Strike Is Voted For Today Despite Court Order
description: NEWARK, Feb. 1Teachers in the public schools voted to day to strike tomorrow and shut down the city's 84 schools in defiance of a court order obtained by the school board barring such a move.

title: Nassau Aide and Wife Die In Lindenhurst Auto Crash
description: LINDENHURST, L. I., Feb. 1 Samuel A. Roberts, who was sworn in last Wednesday as an assistant Nassau County dis trict attorney, and his wife, Sade, were killed today when their automobile went out of control on the Southern State Parkway near here and crashed into a bridge abutment.

title: Panel to Guide Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Vice President Agnew said today that the President would soon establish a Cabinetlevel com mittee to guide Southern school districts into courtordered in tegration in the least disrup tive way.

title: Porsches Take First Two Places in 24 Hours of Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1A German sports car driven by a Mexican and a Finn and prepared by an Englishman won the Twentyfour Hours of Day tona today with a lead of 172 miles over a companion Porsche 917 driven by a Swiss and an other Englishman. The winning car covered 2,758 miles for record average speed of 114.866 miles an hour.

title: SCHRANZ VICTOR IN ARLBERG SKIING
description: GARMISCH, Germany, Feb. 1 (UPI)Karl Schranz of Austria, wearing a 10yearold helmet for good luck, won the Arlberg Kandahar Classic for the sev enth time today by capturing his sixth downhill event in the 1970 ski games. The race had been postponed yesterday when contestants refused to ski in a dense fog and heavy snow.

title: PRINCIPALS ALTER STAND ON PLEDGE
description: The High School Principals Association reversed its stand yesterday and urged that the city's 64 academic high schools continue the daily recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance for the time being.

title: Salvation Army Jousts With Hair in Paris
description: PARIS, Feb. 1The Salva tion Army and the hippie musical Hair have been helping each other at the box office.

title: Savings Group Grows
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1 (UPI) The Wisconsin Savings and Loan League said this weekend that member savings and loan associations posted a 4.8 per cent gain in assets in 1969. The assets of the state's 142 asso ciations on Dec. 31 totaled more than $3.6million, up from the yearearlier $3.4million.

title: Sonics Five Downs Bucks, 118 to 116, On Clemens's Shot
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 1 (AP)  Barry Clemens's jump shot with 21 seconds to go gave the Seattle Sonics a hardearned 118116 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: Dance: Diverse Program
description: Definitions of dance have become elastic enough by now so that it should come as no surprise that the most successful of three choreog raphers a the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse Satur day night happened to be one whose amount of movement was relatively limited.

title: Brown Wins at San Diego on First Playoff Hole
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 1Pete Brown, a Mississippiborn Negro professional, beat Tony Jacklin, the British Open champion, at the first hole of a suddendeath playoff to win the Andy Wil liams San Diego open today after a remarkable comeback.

title: Some Israeli Wages to Be Paid In Bonds to Prevent Inflation
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 1In a move to prevent devaluation of the nation's currency, representa tives of Israeli Government, industry and labor signed a package deal this morning to restrain wages, prices and taxes for two years.

title: O'DWYER ASKS DRUGS BE GIVEN TO ADDICTS
description: Paul O'Dwyer, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, yester day urged the testing of a plan by which a narcotics addict would he given needed drugs each morning under Health Department supervision.

title: Windows Smashed in Protest
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 1 (UPI)A teachin against re pression at the University of Michigan ended in a rock throwing incident today when approximately 25 persons broke off from the main body of about 400 marchers and smashed about 40 windows and five trophy cases in a building where the Reserve Army Train ing Corps program is housed. University officials said that nobody was arrested.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Partisans Here Hold Strong Opinions in Impending Battle Over Lengths
description: WE are about to enter upon The Great Midi Crisis of 1970. In certain quar ters, it is sure to rival pollution as the No. 1 issue of the year. Not to mention Vietnam.

title: LONGRANGE SHOTS WIN 8TH STRAIGHT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1  A loose, floating defense that harassed the Detroit Pistons through the final 16 minutes of play brought the New York Knicker bockers back from a 14point deficit to a 117111 National Basketball Association victory today in a nationally televised game at Cobo Arena.

title: Output of Paper Rose to Record in 1969
description: This country's manufacturers of paper and paperboard set a record high in 1969, turning out 53.8 million tons, a rise of 5.6 per cent over the 1968 figure.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Films

title: QUALITY SCHOOLS ASKED BY 4 IN SUIT
description: Four Harlem mothers who last week won their suit to void the Board of Education's new decentralized Manhattan school districts described their action yesterday as a fight to maintain integration and qual ity education for our children.

title: WARPOLICY BASIS IS CALLED DUBIOUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee made public a report to day suggesting that the Nixon Administration's policy of Viet namization rests on dubious as sumptions about the abilities of the Saigon Government and the military intentions of North Vietnam.

title: PRIME PLACES FIRST IN SPECIAL SLALOM
description: WAKEFIELD, Vt., Feb. 1  Bill Prime of the Amateur Ski Club of New York repeated yesterday's winning perform ance today by taking the spe cial slalom, the second event of the twoday New York City Championships.

title: Opera: A New Egk Work
description: MIINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 1  Everybody can make a mistake, and even officials of the Center Opera Company admit that they came up with a lulu in Werner Egk's 17 Days & 4 Minutes. The idea behind the selection was to choose a contemporary work that would offset the literary and musical difficulties of Harrison Birtwistle's Punch and Judy, which received its American premiere Friday night.

title: Miss Lolly Shattuck Is Bride in Jersey
description: Miss Lolly Shattuck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Shattuck of South Orange, N. J., was married at the Warwick yesterday to Barry L. Werner, a physicist with Motorola, Inc., in Arizona, where he is study ing for a master's degree at Arizona State University.

title: MERGER DROPPED AT U.S. PLYWOOD
description: United States PlywoodCham pion Papers, Inc., and Essex International, Inc., said yester day that they had broken off negotiations, disclosed only 11 days ago, for the merger of Essex into U.S. Plywood.

title: Premier Resigns in Yemen
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  Premier Abdullah alKurshumi of Yemen resigned tonight, the Middle East News Agency re ported here. The agency quoted the Sana radio as saying Pres ident Abdul Rahman alIryani accepted the resignation and asked Deputy Premier Abdul Salem Sabra to become acting premier.

title: Births
description: ENGLANDERMr. & Mrs. Herbert Englander of 87 Grantland Ave., W. Hempstead, L.I., announce the birth of a boy, February 1, 1970, at Hempstead General Hospital.

title: The South at Deadline
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1 (UPI)A statebystate look at the South as it faces Supreme Court desegregation deadlines follows:

title: EARLY G.E. BALLOTS FAVOR AGREEMENT
description: The contract proposed to set tle the threemonthold General Electric strike met a mixed re action yesterday, but early re sults indicated most union members were accepting the new package, The Associated Press reported.

title: Bruins Down Maple Leafs, 76, In Game Marked by Brawling
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)John McKenzie's goal midway in the third period today gave the Boston Bruins a 76 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, in a nationally televised National Hockey League game marked by fights among the players.

title: Miss June Hirsch Is Married To Edward Kean, Stockbroker
description: Miss June Hirsch, daughter of Mrs. I. Henry Hirsch and the late Mr. Hirsch, was mar ried at the Regency yester day to Edward George Kean, a writercomposer who is now a stockbroker.

title: President Is Elected By Bridgeport Brass
description: The election of C. Frank Cowley as president of Bridgeport Brass Company the metals division of Nation al Distillers and Chemical Corporation, was announced over the weekend. Mr. Cowley, 52, succeeds Richard L. Allen, 59, who requested early re tirement.

title: Geniel Gwin Fiancee
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 1Mr. and Mrs. James Martin Gwin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geniel Gwin, an alumna of Lake Erie College, to Marcus H. Strock, a Harvard graduate who is studying law at New York University. The future bride groom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Moses S. Strock of New ton Centre and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: BASIC ECONOMY SETS OFFERING OF STOCK
description: The International Basic Econ omy Corporation has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Com mission for the proposed offer ing of 700,000 shares of com mon stock at a maximum price of $16.875 a share, Donald E. Meads, chairman, announced over the weekend.

title: L.I.R.R. AND UNION AVERT STOPPAGE
description: A unioncompany agree ment was worked out yester day that is expected to keep service on the Long Island Rail Road at, or near, normal today.

title: Heart Drive Gets Director
description: The appointment of Ernest M. Frost as director of fund raising for the American Heart Association was announced yesterday. Mr. Frost has been in charge of fund raising for the National FoundationMarch of Dimes since 1964.

title: Paris: A Study in StateControlled Art
description: PARISQuestion: What do a porcelain ostrich, a foam rubber chair and an abstract tapestry have in common? Answer: All three were not only made in France but also made by France.

title: Poll Finds 18% Dip in Use of Birth Control Pills
description: Nearly onefifth of the esti mated total of eightandahalf million American women who have been using birthcontrol pills have recently stopped, ac cording to a special Gallup Poll commissioned by News week magazine, which appears in its Feb. 9 issue onefourth of these women re ported that they had been using the pill within the last three months, and these were ques tioned further.

title: Janet Alice White Plans Nuptials
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., Feb. 1 The engagement of Miss Janet Alice White to Michael Ed ward Foster has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. White, who practice law in Patchogue.

title: Soviet Rejects Notes on Berlin Access
description: BERLIN, Feb. 1  The So viet Union today rejected Western allied notes of protest over recent Commpnist slow downs on roads linking Berlin with the West.

title: Poor Wins 3d Title in Row In Atlantic Coast Squash
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1 Tom Poor of the New York A.C. became the first player today to win the Atlantic Coast squash racquet championship three years in a row since the inception of the tournament in 1930 at ChalfonteHaddon Hall.

title: Rare Hieronymus Bosch Work Missing From Chrysler Museum
description: A small, rare painting by Hieronymus Bosch, the Dutch Renaissance master of the gro tesque and fantastic is missing from the Chrysler Art Museum in Provincetown, Mass., accord ing to the police there yester day.

title: M. Khan and Adair Win
description: Mohihullah Khan of the Har vard Club in Boston and Colin Adair of the Montreal Badmin ton and Squash Racquets Club won the David C. John Memo rial open squash racquets dou bles tournament yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn. They defeated Kenneth Binns and Ian McAvity of the Mon treal Badminton and Squash Racquets Club, 1714, 156, 1115, 159.

title: Executive Appointments Made by Bonwit Teller
description: The appointments of a new executive vice president and a senior vice president were announced yesterday by Bon wit Teller, a subsidiary of Genesco, Inc. The appoint ments are effective today.

title: LATIN AMERICANS DEMAND MORE AID
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 1 The Executive Committee of the InterAmerican Economic and Social Council began gath ering here today for one of the most crucial hemisphere con ferences ever held by the group.

title: Bronx Interchange Started After 2 Decades of Red Tape
description: Nearly two decades after it was conceived, the $67.85 million Cross BronxBruckner interchange  part of the $137million Bruckner Ex pressway  is finally under construction.

title: Tidalium Pelo Scores Victory By HallLength in French Trot
description: PARIS Feb. 1Tidalium Plo may not race this year in the Roosevelt International and may not win the world cham pionship of trotting.

title: Pistons Send Bellamy to Hawks And Miles to Bullets in Trades
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1Less than eight hours before the National Basketball Association trading deadline, the Detroit Pistons traded Walt Bellamy, their 6 foot10inch center, and Eddie Miles, an experienced forward guard.

title: Menuhin Excels as Conductor In American Symphony Concert
description: Yehudi Menuhin, the rising conductor, led the American Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in an outstanding program that proved he pos sesses the same unlearned and unlearnable qualities that made Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, one of the great names in music. Audiences come predis posed to like  adore, really  what Mr. Menuhin, in which ever his role, sets before them. When that sort of ambiance can be created in a concert hall, musical matters have a way of going right.

title: Political Paradox in Chile's Election
description: SANTIAGO, ChileIf Chile were to elect a new president today the winner by a wide margin would be 73yearold Jorge Allesandri. The polls and most coliticians concur on that.

title: COAST TRACKMEN SEEK A.A.U. HELP
description: In an effort to dramatize the financial plight of track and. field clubs throughout the coun try, prominent West Coast teams may boycott the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor championships scheduled here Feb. 27.

title: Liberal to Be Lindsay's Liaison With City's Board of Estimate
description: Mayor Lindsay's legislative liaison is to be reorganized, with additional power going to an aide who was the Liberal party's top representative at Mr. Lind say's campaign headquarters last fall.

title: Nutmeg Club Rink Captures Darien Curling Final, 168
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 1The Nutmeg Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Ralph Mester, won the club's international bonspiel for the Nutmeg Stone today by defeating the Albany C.C. rink, skipped by Richard DeGraff, 168, in the 12end final at The Country Club of Darien.

title: SNEAD'S 290 TAKES GOLF BY 2 STROKES
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 1 (UPI)Sam Snead, despite some problems on the greens, won his fourth Profes sional Golfers' Association sen iors championship today at the P.G.A. National Golf Club with a 72hole total of 290. The win ning score was the highest in the 32year history of the event.

title: Hambro Bank Board Elects
description: Jack I. Straus, a director and chairman of the executive com mittee of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., has been elected a director of the Hambro American Bank & Trust Company. An indepen dent bank chartered under New York State law, Hambro Ameri can is affiliated with Hambros Bank Limited, England's largest merchant bank.

title: COUGARS TURN BACK COLONELS BY 109104
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 1 (AP) The Carolina Cougars, helped by steady freethrow shooting, led all the way today in de feating the Kentucky Colonels, 109104, in an American Bas ketball Association game.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THREE issues may have to be faced this month: the refusal of South Africa to let Arthur Ashe go there to play tennis, the latest proposal for legalized offtrack gambling in New York, and the plight of the Seattle fran chise in baseball's American League. Each of these issues may truly be as mechanically complex as the lawyers claim, but none is as simple as the moralists seem to think. The response to the rejection of Ashe's visa application, for ex ample, tends to fall into three clear categories: one, that the United States should immediately break off all sports connections with South African athletes; two, that the ac tion should be regarded as a justified individual rejection of Ashe, and ignored; three, that a token, compromising retaliation be made to soothe Ashe and other black citizens.

title: ADVISER TO NIXON EXPELLED BY LAGOS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 1 (AP) A man identified as a United States Army colonel, in Lagos reportedly to advise President Nixon on Nigerian relief, was roused from his hotel bed to day by police and expelled from the country. No explanation was given.

title: Concern Voiced by Muskie Over President's Use of TV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie expressed concern today over President Nixon's increasing use of television and possible effects of Vice President Ag new's criticism last fall of network television news.

title: Tories Select Law and Order As Issue for General Election
description: LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  A swing to the right in Conservative party thinking was foreshadowed today as the Conservatives, the main British Opposition party, completed a threeday meeting for electoral planning.

title: Fittipaldi's Lotus Wins
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1 (AP)  Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, driving a Lotus, won the first International FormulaFour Race in this country today.

title: 50 Hurt in Hotel Fire; Most Treated at Scene
description: A fire in the basement of the Manhattan Towers Hotel at 2166 Broadway at 76th Street injured about 50 per sons early this morning.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: FREYDA N. ADLER, INTEGRATION AIDE
description: Mrs. Freyda Nacque Adler, an educator who had been active in the integration of schools here, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a long ill ness. She was 61 years old and lived at 333 Central Park West.

title: LAKERS TOP 76ERS FOR 8TH IN A ROW
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI) Jerry West's pair of foul shots with two seconds remain ing today gave Los Angeles a 113112 victory over the Phil adelphia 76ers and stretched the Lakers' National Basketball Association winning streak to eight.

title: The WilsonNixon Talks
description: The paradox in Prime Minister Wilson's participation in a National Security Council meeting at the White House last week was that the socalled special rela tionship it symbolized between the United States and Britain has virtually come to an end. The roles both countries in the world have changed drastically since Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill fused policies, commands and forces for victory World War II and even merged their highest military councilors into a combined Chiefs of Staff.

title: BRITISH WILL STUDY ALLEGED MASSACRE
description: LONDON, Feb. 1 (UPI)The Defense Ministry said today that it was looking into news paper reports that British troops, with orders to wipe out a jungle village, massacred 25 men during the antiCommunist war in Malaya 22 years ago.

title: America Israel Unit Pays Music Tribute To Juilliard School
description: Between cocktails at the Juilliard School and the annual dinner dance of the America Israel Cultural Foundation, an audience glittering with celeb rities filled Alice Tully Hall early last evening for a glow ingly affectionate hour of chamber music. The concert was presented as a tribute to Juilliard, which has trained more than 125 young Israeli musicians since 1948, most of them under foundation scholar ships.

title: CANADIENS' RALLY BEATS FLYERS, 52
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI) Ralph Backstrom registered three goals to help the Mont real Canadiens gain a 52 vic tory over the Philadelphia Fly ers tonight in a National Hock ey League game.

title: Personal Finance: TaxHelp Guides
description: Every year at tax time mil lions of people need guidance in making out their income tax. Those who can afford it, go to accountants or other tax consultants.

title: BULLETS SET BACK HAWKS BY 133124
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1 (AP) Kevin Loughery and Jack Marin sparked a secondhalf spurt that carried the Balti more Bullets to a 132124 Na tional Basketball Association victory over Atlanta tonight, knocking the Hawks from the Western Division lead for the first time since Nov. 2.

title: SitIn City Marks Decade of Change
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Jan. 31It was the eve of an anniversary that regularly passes with little remem brance and, from the window of his midtown law office, Walter T. Johnson Jr. watched the Saturday shoppers mean dering down Elm Street eight floors below. That dime store down there was the birthplace of a whirlwind, he said, recalling that 1st of Febru ary, 10 years ago, when four young Negroes walked down the same street into Woolworth's, sat on lunch counter stools and asked for coffee.

title: Utility Profits Up For Southern Co
description: The Southern Company re ported over the weekend gains in operating revenues and net income for 1969.

title: Rangers Rout Penguins, 60, for Sawchuk's 103d Shutout
description: Brad Park planted a kiss on the scar tissue that serves as Terry Sawchuk's forehead and the pair danced off the Madison Square Garden ice last night to a standing ovation.

title: GOVERNOR RESIGNS IN WEST PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1 The resignation of Air Mar shal Nur Khan as Governor of West Pakistan was announced last night by the Federal Gov ernment headed by President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, the General who last March de clared martial law throughout the country. It was the first highlevel resignation from President Yahva's regime.

title: Maravich's Next Goal Is Bid to N.I.T.
description: With the career individual scoring record tucked away, Pete Maravich can now turn his sights to rolling up enough points to keep a mediocre Lou isiana State basketball team winning.

title: Frick, Combs and Haines Selected for Baseball Hall of Fame by OldTimers
description: Ford C. Frick. former Com missioner of Baseball; Earle Combs, a center fielder for the New York Yankees in the nine teentwenties, and Jesse Haines, oldtime knuckleball pitcher, were elected yesterday to Baseball's Hall of Fame by the oldtimers' selection com mittee.

title: Stratford Music Fete Off
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, Feb. 1 (AP)Lack of money has forced cancellation of the 1970 Stratford Summer Music Festi val, Dr. Ian Lindsay, festival president, said yesterday. The usual program of opera, ballet and symphony orchestra per formances will be replaced by seven Saturday morning cham ber concerts and nine Sunday matinee musical events.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: JULIUS H. COHN

title: Miss Havecker Becomes Bride
description: Miss Eileen Janet Havec ker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Havecker of Los Angeles, was married yester day afternoon to James Michael Rosenthal, who is a men's sportswear buyer for the Abraham & Straus chain. Supreme Court Justice Sam uel M. Gold performed the ceremony at the home here of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Rosen thal.

title: Title to Magallanes Nine
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 1 (UPI)Magallanes won the Ve nezuela professional baseball championship today, defeating La Guaira, 21, for a sweep of the threegame playoff. The vic tory, Magallanes's first since 1954, earned the Valenciabased team the right to face cham pions from Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic in the Caribbean series starting Thurs day.

title: Railroad Talks to Be Resumed Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Negotiators for the railroads and four shoperaft unions agreed today to return to the bargaining table in hopes of coming to terms on a new contract before the expiration of two court orders forbidding any shutdown or strike for 10 days.

title: Chess:
description: THE Pirc Defense is a flex debut for the second player against 1 PK4 or 1 PQ4. Black's early key moves include ... PKN3 and ... PQ3, consigning slashing diagonals to his bishops.

title: PROTESTERS UPSET RUSSIANS' RECITAL
description: Young demonstrators pro testing alleged persecution of Jews in the Soviet Union dis rupted last night's duo recital at carnegie Hail by David Oistrakh and Sviatoslav Richter, the Soviet violinist and pianist. Twice during the per formance of Brahms's Sonata No. 3 in D minor young men raced down aisles to the stage, screaming as they went, with Carnegie Hall security men and the police in pursuit.

title: Laotian Premier Ready to Talk With Hanoi on Pullout of Troops
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1 Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotion Premier said here yes terday that he was prepared to close his eyes to the exist ence of the Ho Chi Minh Trail in eastern Laos if North Viet nam withdrew its 50,000 troops from the rest of the country. The Premier said further that in that event he would call for a halt in the air attacks against Communistheld regions else where in Laos.

title: Saint Laurent Hemlines Go From Knee to Ankle
description: PARIS, Feb. 1Poor Yves Saint Laurent: He is cor nered now by his own suc cess. A flop might bring him to his senses. It has been rumored here for a long time that the 33yearold designer wanted to bolt and, for a lit tle while, lead a different kind of life. But nowadays his name sells too many clothes and he only has to show a new belt, or whip out another scarf, to go on generating for yet another season.

title: 2 VETERAN STARS AT U. OF MICHIGAN
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 1 The premiere of the Phoenix Theater's revival here tomor row night of Harvey, star ring James Stewart and Helen Hayes, will mark the 100th pro duction sponsored by the Uni versity of Michigan's Profes sional Theater Program.

title: RESERVE OFFICIAL SEES A RECESSION
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis thinks it is unlikely that the United States can avoid a re cession this year, and he be lieves inflation will continue to accelerate for some time.

title: Influence of Reagan's Landlords Questioned in California Governorship Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 The election for Governor of Califoznia is still nine months away and the Major issue be tween the two probable con tenders so far is the ownership of a residence.

title: F.B.I. Sifts Finances of Rosebud Sioux
description: ROSEBUD, S. D.Agents of the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation and the Internal Reve nue Service have been looking into the tangled financial af fairs of the Rosebud Sioux.

title: Liechtenstein's Voters End 32Year Coalition
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein, Feb. 1 (UPI)  The electorate of 3,986 adult males in this European principality voted the traditionally minority Pa triotic Union party into power today, ending the co alition Government that had stood for 32 years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Francis C. Smithers, formerly vice presidentbanking and se curity services has been elected executive vice president in charge of operations at the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York.

title: Rep. Glenard P. Lipscomb Dies; Republican of California Was 54
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) Representative Glenard P. Lipscomb, Republican of Cali fornia, died of cancer today in Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: Child Dies in Harlem Fire As Mother Saves 4 Others
description: A 20monthold boy was killed yesterday by a fire in his Harlem apartment when his mother was unable to reach him after she led her other four children to safety.

title: Theater: Art Buchwald's Sheep on the Runway
description: ART BUCHWALD's Sheep on the Runway is an always endearing, often very funny play. At the Helen Hayes Theater on Saturday night I seemed to be sur rounded by more political figures than you would find at a Nixon Cabinet meeting, and these politicos laughed and laughed at this gentle but subcutaneously corrosive satire on gunboat politics and the American Way.

title: Mr. Nixon's ABM Decision
description: Expansion of the Safeguard antiballistic missile (ABM) system, as sought by President Nixon, is likely to spur the missile race with Russia without signifi cantly improving security against Communist China for the United States and its allies.

title: Brisker Excels as Pipers Defeat Floridians, 122107
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 (UPI) John Brisker scored three key baskets with less than seven minutes to play today as the Pittsburgh Pipers defeated the Miami Floridians, 122107, in an American Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: Anne G. Lapidus Bride of Rabbi, Stephen Lerner
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 1  Miss Anne Geraldine Lapidus, a doctoral candidate in literature at Harvard, was married at Temple Kehillath Israel here today to Rabbi Stephen C. Lerner of the Tif erethIsraelTown and Vil lage Synagogue in New York.

title: 100,000 to Get Smallpox Vaccine in Rhine Epidemic
description: BONN, Feb. 1An epidemic of smallpox that has caused two deaths has prompted health authorities in the populous state of North RhineWestphalia to plan the vaccination of 100,000 people, starting today.

title: 'Fando and Lis,' a Film Calculated to Shock
description: "EVERY cinematographic trick was avoided. The actors, enduring a veritable 'Via Crucis,' were stripped naked, tortured and beaten. Artificial blood was never used." So conclude the clues for critics attractively printed and furnished by Panic Productions to accompany Alexandro Jodorowsky's film version of Fernando Arrabal's play, "Fando and Lis," which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.It's a good thing movies are for one time only, because "Fando and Lis" subjects its heroes to vampirism at several levels of refinement. It also has Fando murder Lis (no retakes on that one), and at her funeral it exposes her body to be devoured in bite-sized portions by her mourners.But such is the anesthetic effect of Jodorowsky's direction (and perhaps of Arrabal's dramaturgy) that each new outrage invites a yawn; each torture, beating and nonartificial blood letting, an acknowledgment of shocking intention  and little more.He is impotent and she is paralytic, and together, through trash heap and desert, they search for an unattainable city called Tar. Along the way (which, of course, leads back to where they started) they have many meaningful experiences and encounter numerous exemplary grotesque characters.Repeatedly Fando is misled into strange adventures, and repeatedly he returns to serve and humiliate Lis. Occasionally they remember their childhoods in flashback, and near the end Fando's dying mother reappears and his dead father jumps out of the grave to claim him.Such figures of the imaginationparticularly the imaginations of Hieronymus Bosch, Gustave Dor, and above all, Federico Fellinigive a comfortable familiarity, a strong sense of having seen it all before, to the innovative excesses of "Fando and Lis." And Jodorowsky, in everything from his selection of freaks to his choice of camera angles, admits his indebtedness.It is as if the grotesque of the later Fellini, mostly drained of their (nonartificial) blood, has wandered zombie-like onto a landscape created by a marriage of low budget with literary sources, to take part yet again in the most approved rituals of academic absurdist tradition.Deprived of responsibility to objective reality, "Fando and Lis" tends to exploit accounts of subjective realitymost obviously, a simplistic Freudian system of guilt and repression. In spite of its fantastic premises, it seems almost wholly conventional in the interpretation it asks for its images. And like most overt film fantasy, the end product is flat, literal, unimaginative.Neither Sergio Klainer as Fando nor Diana Mariscal as Lis are acceptable actors (whether they could be if they had the chance is another question), and Miss Mariscal's Giulietta Masina make-up (another tribute to Fellini) works to reduce her part from performance to mere representation. For all its invocations of theater of cruelty, "Fando and Lis" hardly ever scares up anything stronger than unpleasant whimsey.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Welfare vs. Wages

title: V.A. Appoints Psychiatrist
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 2 (AP)Dr. Joseph J. Baker of Providence has been named director of the psychiatry, neu rology and psychology service of the Veterans Administration. Dr. Baker is superintendent and physicianinchief of Butler Hospital here. He will assume his new position in Washington next spring.

title: Informer Put on Probation
description: Alan I. Segal, who pleaded guilty to four counts of con spiring to sell some of $488,000 in stolen securities, and later turned Government witness, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court here to seven years' provation.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2President Nix on's pledge to take a new and searching look at American education is not spelled out but it is hinted in his budget for the fiscal year 1971.

title: DR. GIAN RASTELLI, HEART RESEARCHER
description: ROSHESTER, Minn., Feb. 2 (AP) Dr. Gian C. Rastelli, head of open heart surgical research at the Mayo Clinic and twice a winner of Ameri can Medical Association gold medals, died in a Rochester hospital today of Hodgkin's disease, a progressive deterio ration of the kidneys and spleen.He was 36 years old.

title: AIRLINES TO RESUME FIGHT ON FARE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The nation's longhaul airlines were preparing today for the second round in a battle over a Civil Aeronautics Board air fare plan.

title: Deny Hearing on Loss in Exclusion From House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The United States Supreme Court rejected today an at tempt by Representative Adam Clayton Powell to recover the $55,000 in Congressional pay he lost when he was excluded from the 90th Congress.

title: U.S. Report Cites Negro Gains Despite Housing and Income Lag
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Negroes have made substantial gains in education, income and housing in recent years but still lag behind whites, two Federal agencies reported to day.

title: 21 Reported Injured In Racial Fighting At Plainfield School
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J. Feb. 2 Racial fighting broke out in Plainfield High School today and the school was closed after 20 students and one teacher were reported injured.

title: Opening by Gimbels Completes a Project
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 2Gimbels opened a depart ment store here today that virtually completed the State Street Urban Renewal Proj ect, a 50acre Federally aided downtown redevelopment program begun almost 10 year ago.

title: Piper Guard to Get Surgery
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 (AP) Charlie Williams, a guard with the Pittsburgh Pipers of the American Basketball Associa tion, will undergo an operation for the removal of cartilage from his right knee on Wednes day. Williams, who has aver aged 21 points a game, is ex pected to be out for the rest of the season.

title: G.E. CONTRACT VOTED BY 2 UNIONS' BOARDS
description: The conference boards of the two major electrical unions on strike against the General Elec tric Company since Oct. 27 vot ed approval yesterday on the terms of new 40month con tracts.

title: Merrick Again Asks Fox Film For a List of Its Stockholders
description: David Merrick, the theatrical producer, apparently is step ping up his warat least his war of nerves  against the management of Twentieth Cen turyFox Film Corporation.

title: Lincoln Hospital Occupied for Two Hours in Protest
description: South Bronx civic leasers who serve on Lincoln Hospital's community advisory board held the administrator's office for more than two hours yesterday, protesting the city's refusal to appoint a Puerto Rican phy sician as administrator.

title: COAST NUNS PLAN A SECULAR ORDER
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 About 315 of the 400 sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, who have been in conflict with the Roman Catholic hierarchy over reforms in their rules and customs, will abandon formal religious life and become a secular community, the head of the order announced today.

title: Tomeo Will Pass K. of C. HalfMile To Run Casey 600
description: Five days a week, people try to get Frank Tomeo to buy com mercial time on television. Yes terday, Tomeo sold instead of bought. The product he sold was himself, talking his way into the Casey 600 Friday night in the 51st annual Knights of Columbus indoor track meet at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lesotho's Leader Tightens Rule and Seizes More Foes
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Prime Minister Lea bua Jonathan rounded up more political opponents today while tightening his grip on this country, an enclave in South Africa, where he has ruled by decree since last week.

title: Yeshiva Is Desecrated
description: Vandals using a spray can of red paint have desecrated the walls of Joel Braverman High School of the Flatbush Yeshiva at 1605 Avenue J, between East 16th Street and East 17th Street. The vandalism, dis covered Saturday, included the writing of a Black Panther slogan on a wall of the four story building reading, Free Panther 21 or face White Riots, and the name of the Arab guerrilla organization, Al Fatah, written across valuable mosaic mural depict ing the 12 tribes of Israel.

title: I.R.S. AGENT ACCUSED OF TAKING A BRIBE
description: A special agent in the Man hattan office of the internal Revenue Service's intelligence division was arrested yester day on charges of receiving a $1,000 bribe from a reputed member of the Mafia in West chester.

title: Aged Gelding Finds New Home Through U.S. Mail
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 2 Sonny, the regal 25yearold marshal's horse at Roosevelt Raceway, has a new home. The white gelding, who was retired in a simple track ceremony on Jan. 20, was vanned to the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Francis G. Allchin in Old Westbury today.

title: Ohio's Miller Seeks 3d Term
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Representative Clarence Mill er, Republican of Ohio, said today he would be a candidate for reelection to a third term.

title: Output of Workers Up in 4th Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Labor Department said today that workers' output per manhour in the private econ omy rose moderately in the, last quarter of 1969, but the year's gain of ninetenths of 1 per cent was the smallest since 1956.

title: GOLD SOLD I. M. F. BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reu ters)  The International Mon etary fund said today that South Africa sold it $98.3mil lion worth of gold in January.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES MANAGE TO RALLY
2 Accounting Firms Merge As Clarence Rainess & Co.
description: Two accounting concerns, Wright, Long & Co. and Clar ence Rainess & Co., merged yesterday. The name of the merged company will be Clar ence Rainess & Co. with offices in New York, Boston, Phila delphia, Los Angeles, Buffalo, Elizabeth, N.J., and Washing ton, D.C.

title: Senators Are Told Carswell Was Insulting to Negro Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Judge G. Harrold Carswell was said by a Senate witness today to have been so insulting and hostile to Negro lawyers that young civil rights attorneys who were to appear before him were previously drilled in making their arguments while being harassed.

title: Massive Chandelier Stolen From Museum in Norwalk
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 2 A ??assive chandelier has been stolen from the second floor of the LockwoodMatthews Man sion museum at 295 West Ave nue, next door to the police station.

title: Opera Orchestra Presents Concert Rigoletto
description: With a Korean tenor, Jae Woo Lee, as the Duke of Mantua and a fetching young woman, Eve Queler, on the podium, last night's concert version of Rig oletto at Alice Tully Hall pos sessed a great deal of curiosity value. And the performance, by the Opera Orchestra of New York, did present a recogniz able, economysized picture of Verdi's familycircle tale of malediction, rape and murder.

title: Chase Bank Appoints 4
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the ap pointment of four vice presi dents in its United States de partment, its national territorial unit. They are Bruce A. Crocco, Byron S. Pardee, Frank L. Tenu sak and Robert D. Weeks Jr.

title: GEOGER SCHIRER, 84, OF S & H STAMPS DIES
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 2 George Schirer, retired chair man and former president of the Sperry and Hutchinson Company, died today in St. Francis Hospital here. He was 84 years old and lived in Sands Point.

title: Advertising: Nixon Aide on Consumerism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 A Presidential adviser called on the advertising commun nity today to do something about upgrading the Better Business Bureaus and edu cating the public to the cost of consumer legislation.

title: N.F.L. STANDOUTS PLAYED IN 1950'S
description: CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 2 (AP) Hugh McElhenny, Tom Fears, Pete Pihos and Jack Christian sen, four stars of the nineteen fifties, have been elected to the Professional Football Hall of Fame.

title: Grace Hill Seastone, ExEditor And Fashion Executive, Is Dead
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 2Mrs. Grace Hill Seastone, a former president of I. Miller Retail Salons, a division of Genesco, Inc., shoe and apparel maker, died Wednesday in YaleNew Haven Hospital after an illness of several months. She was 52 year old and lived on Curiosity Lane in Essex, Conn.

title: Miss Linda Hurd Leslie Is Betrothed
description: MILL NECK, L.I., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. James Leslie Jr. have announced the en gagement of their daughter. Miss Linda Hurd Leslie, to Specialist 4 Hutchinson Du Bosque Jr. of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. DuBosque of Laurel Hollow, Syosset.

title: For Japanese, the Abacus Still Counts
description: TOKYO, Feb. 2In the lobby of a Tokyo building oc cupied by one of Japan's big gest computer manufacturers the girl at the cigarette stand handed a customer a 70yen pack of HiLite cigarettes and, when handed a 100yen coin, whipped out an abacus to figure out the change.

title: Leader Quits Party in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 2 Former President Posun Yun quit the New Democratic party, the major opposition group, to day because of his dissatisfac tion with the outcome of the party convention held last week. His action led to specu lation that he might form new party. Mr. Yun, who lost the Presidential election con tests to Chung Hee Park in 1963 and 1967, is known to have been unhappy with the election of Yoo Chin San as the New Democratic party President.

title: DR. RUSSELL APSEY
description: Dr. Russell Apsey, adminis trative medical officer at St. Luke's Hospital Center from 1952 to his retirement in 1965, died of cancer at the hospital Sunday. He was 69 years old and had been living in Malta since 1967.

title: Episcopal Women Prepare a Party
description: Hawaiian Holiday will be the theme of a luncheon, fashion show and bridge party to be held tomorrow at the Parish House of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, East 90th Street off Fifth Avenue. Miss Janet E. Roda and Miss Aly son J. Thomas, daughter of the Rev. Dr. J. Burton Thomas, the rector, are cochair men for the event, sponsored by the Women of the Church. Proceeds will go to the Rec tor's Discretionary Fund.

title: Property Taxes Expected to Rise Here
description: The city reported yesterday that the assessed value of tax able real estate here had spurted to a record of nearly $36billion; at the same time, a 30cent increase in the property tax rate was foreseen.

title: Maravich Scores 49 Points
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 2 (AP)  Pete Maravich soared past the 3,000point mark to night with a 49point perform ance in leading Louisiana State to a 10991 victory over Mis sissippi State.

title: Chemical Makers Report a Mixed Scene for Year
description: Birny Mason Jr., cnairman of the Union Carbide Corpo ration, said in a preliminary report yesterday that the company's net income in 1969 increased 19 per cent to $186.2million, or $3.08 a share, from a net of $157.0 million, or $2.60 a share, the year before.

title: 2 Boys Are Thwarted In Queens Bank Holdup
description: Two boys, 16 and 15 years old, brandished harmonicas as simulated guns in a Queens bank yesterday and were given $8,000 by a frightened teller moments before two passing patrolmen entered and captured the boys.

title: Comment by Schlesinger
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr., the historian, who has written extensively about President Roosevelt, said that, in the first place, Mr. Roosevelt drank old fashioneds, not gin and grape fruit juice, and didn't drink very much, anyway.

title: Deposit Ratio Is Eased For Savings Institutions
description: The New York State Banking Board has raised the percentage of time deposits that savings banks and savings and loan associations may hold relative to total deposits to 40 per cent, from 15.

title: POLLUTION ROLE OF LEAD DISPUTED
description: Claims that the presence of lead antiknock compounds in gasoline adds to air pollution were disputed yesterday by the Ethyl Corporation, a leading manufacturer of the compounds.

title: RETAIL SALES UP 3% FOR JANUARY
description: Sales in New York's big stores during January showed the adverse effects of con sumerprice resistance and an oldfashioned winter.

title: Seaver Wins the Hickok Award in a Virtual Shutout
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 2 (AP) Tom Seaver, the New York Mets' righthander, continued to add to his string of post season awards tonight when he became the biggest vote getter in the 20year history of the S. Rae Hickok profes sional athleteoftheyear bal loting.

title: 2 BOSTON SEXTETS GAIN BEANPOT FINAL
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Boston University withstood a Harvard rally and defeated the Crimson, 53, and Boston Col lege swept past Northeastern, 50, tonight in the first round of the 18th annual Beanpot hockey tournament. A crowd of 14,702 saw the games at Boston Garden, where the final round will be played next Monday night.

title: Brandt Due April 10 in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany has accepted an invitation from President Nixon to visit Washington April 10 and 11, the White House an nounced today.

title: Observer: After the Crime Bill, Buffaloes?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Bleeding hearts, liberals, in tellectuals and hippies, with their usual bleating about con stitutional rights, may have dis tracted President Nixon's atten tion from the genuine flaw in his program for ending crime in the streets.

title: ResidentTuition Appeal Lost
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected today an appeal that tried to upset the $327 quarterly fee that the University of Califor nia charges students who have lived in the state less than a year. Last May a court in Cali fornia ruled the residence re quirement reasonable. The Su preme Court dismissed the case for want of a substantial federal question.

title: Orange Concentrate Prices Active on Cold in Florida
description: Future prices of frozen or ange juice concentrate which had been dropping for some time, rose yesterday on no par ticularly bullish news.

title: YOUNG LORDS GET DELAY IN HEARING
description: Negotiations between officials of an East Harlem church and the Young Lords, a militant Puerto Rican group that took over the church for 11 days, led yesterday to a delay in a con temptofcourt hearing.

title: Chicken Cancer Vaccine Is Reported
description: Agricultural scientists report ed yesterday the development of a vaccine to prevent Ma rek's disease, a common form of cancer in chickens that costs the American poultry industry $150million a year.

title: Hanoi Warns That War May Last Many Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  The North Vietnamese leadership has warned the nation to be prepared to fight the United States for many years more to force the full withdrawal of American forces from South Vietnam.

title: Everglades Explorers File Suit To Stop NearbyMarsh Airfield
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Two friends who met while touring Everglades National Park a few years ago and who now explore the park together each Febru ary filed suit today to stop use of a training airstrip in South Florida, which they contend will destroy the Everglades.

title: U.S. WILL DESTROY $140,000 IN DRUGS
description: Federal Judge Orrin G. Judd signed an order yesterday for the destruction of $140,000 worth of a tranquilizing drug Reserpine Alkaloidseized last Jan. 9 by agents of the Food and Drug Administration and the United States Attor ney's office in Brooklyn.

description: The Memory Bank, a play by Martin Duberman, gave its last performance Sunday, Jan. 20, at Tambellini's Gate. It was produced by D. Weinstock, M. Pantaleoni and L. E. Lehr man.

title: JoAnn Giffuni Wed in Paris
description: Miss JoAnn Veronica Gif funi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Giffuni of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married in Paris yesterday to Michael Sher, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sher of New York.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Teaching Parents to beach Child
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Before his second birthday, Ivan Lucius James Mitchell Jr., nicknamed Peco by his father because the little boy was so pink at birth, was withdrawn and very shy.

title: 5 Swiss Banks Set Up Fund To Invest in Tokyo Stock
description: GENEVA, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Bank Hentsch et Cie. said today five Swiss banks had set up the Samurai Fund to invest in Japa nese stocks.

title: Bertrand Russell Is Dead; British Philosopher, 97
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 3 Earl Russell, the philosopher and mathematician, died at his home in Wales last night. He was 97 years old.

title: GOVERNORS LOSE BID TO SUE ON SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Supreme Court turned down attempts by Govs. Albert P. Brewer of Alabama and John Bell Williams of Mississippi today to sue two Federal Cabinet officers over school de searegation.

title: Jersey Assembly Backs Raising Sales Tax to 5%
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2The over whelming Republican majority In the Assembly tonight ap proved Gov. William T. Cahill's request to increase New Jer sey's 3 per cent sales tax to per cent.

title: Tax on Japan's Bonds Is Reimposed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) President Nixon ordered an interestequalization tax re stored today on purchases by Americans of private or Jap anese Government bonds.

title: Kubrick to Adapt A Clockwork Orange for Screen
description: Stanley Kubrick, who has not made a film since the release nearly two years ago of his highly successful futur istic adventure, 2001: A Space Odyssey, has been signed to write, direct and produce A Clockwork Or ange for Warner Brothers release. The film will be an adaptation of Anthony Bur gess's novel published here in 1963 by W. W. Norton.

title: Penguins Grow Into a Contender After MetsLike Error in Draft
description: AFTER a Metslike mistake in the expansion draft that threatened to bury the Pittsburgh Penguins for years, the club with one of the sor riest nicknames in sports has made it as a playoff contend er in the National Hockey League.

title: John J. Carty, Deputy Controller For Eight Years, Is Dead at 61
description: John J. Carty, first deputy controller, who was widely re garded as a consummate pro fessional in the field of munici pal finances, died of a heart at tack yesterday. He was 61 year old and and lived in the Bay Ridge Section of Brooklyn at 216 90th Street.

description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: OCCHIPINTI HEARD IN JERSEY INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2  After giving more than 10 hours of secret testimony to the State Commission of investigation, Robert (Bobby Basile) Occhipin ti, of Long Branch, was re leased from jail here this after noon, at least temporarily.

title: BOXER HELD IN DEATH OF BABY DAUGHTER
description: A Brooklyn man identified by the police as a welterweight professional boxer was charged with murder yesterday in the death of his 6monthold daugh ter.

title: Practical Outlook on Spring
description: IT USED to be a flowered hat or a navy blue suit that a woman would rush out to buy when the snow was on the ground and she hoped to hasten spring. But these are more prosaic times. To day she's more likely to rush the season with a raincoat, according to Abbe Rabiner.

title: Farmers Demonstrate in London for Increased Government Subsidies
description: LONDON, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Thousands of farmers con verged on the Ministry of Agriculture today to support their leaders, who were ar riving for price negotiations with the Government.

title: NIXON AIDE DEFENDS VIETNAM WAR POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reu ters)The White House today responded to questions about critical Congressional report on the Vietnam war by stating that the program to turn all aspects of United States in volvement in South Vietnam over to the Vietnamese was progressing well.

title: Screen: Elusive Reality:'A Married Couple,' by Allan King, Opens
description: BILLY EDWARDS is a 42-year-old advertising executive with a receding hairline, walrus mustache and a comparatively well-preserved, tubular-shaped physique of which he is proud. His wife, Antoinette, 30, is a former secretary to Shelley Winters. She has the kind of trim, well-packed figure that tends to look too plump in clothes, a face that becomes suddenly beautiful when she smiles, and, apparently, she doesn't shave under her arms.Billy and Antoinette live in a casually decorated (inflatable furniture, highly polished floors, multicolored kitchen, hi-fi, Pop posters), two-story frame house in Toronto with their 3-year-old son, Bogart, and a dog named Merton.They are real people, and they are the stars of a new cinma vrit film by Allan King ("Warrendale," "Will the Real Norman Mailer Please Stand Up?") that King calls "A Married Couple," although an equally fitting title might be: "Where Should We Put the Harpsichord?"For 10 weeks King and his crew (Richard Leiterman, the cameraman, and Christian Wangler, the soundman) more or less lived with the Edwardses from early morning until late at night, becoming silent participants in their lives, a constant audience, while photographing and recording them as they laughed, argued, were tender and exhibitionistic.In the course of the production, Billy and Antoinette came close to separating, which gives structure to the 97-minute film that King and his editor, Arla Saare, have put together from some 70 hours of original footage.The 40-year-old King is one of the most talented of the filmmakers now exploring the possibilities of documentary cinema, but it seems to me that in "A Married Couple" (which he calls "actuality drama" or "living drama") he has pushed filmed sociology into the murky outer reaches of psychodrama. In terms of straight, cinematic art, "A Married Couple" ranks somewhere above "King, Murray" but somewhere below such real movies as "Birth of a Nation" or even "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice."On film, anyway, Billy and Antoinette are not very interesting people (nor, I suspect, would most of the rest of us be, if photographed under similar circumstances). They are the sort of aware, upper middle income types who talk a lot about "relatiohships" and argue mostly about possessions  shoes, stereos, harpsichords, records, vacuum cleaners, the car.After six years of marriage, the point of all the arguments really is: Who is going to dominate whom? "I'm completely bewildered," Billy says toward the end of the film. "It seems that everytime we get on some plateau of understanding, the next minute we are kicking and screaming."Throughout "A Married Couple," which opened yesterday at the Kips Bay, it's perfectly apparent that Billy and Antoinette are playing to the camera, in moments of anger, intimacy and even boredom. It may be no accident that both of them were, at earlier stages in their lives, aspiring actors who never made it. The unreality prompted by the camera's presence is acknowledged in the film, which then proceeds to pass off this conscious performance as some kind of meta-truth that is neither fact nor fiction.What King ultimately proves, I think, is that something that is neither fact nor fiction is less meta-truth than sophisticated sideshow. As I've never believed there is a novel in everybody, nor even a tape-recorded book, I now am convinced there are probably very few people worthy of being the subjects of an actuality drama. Better than any other instrument, perhaps, the documentary camera can capture the sense and feeling of events, of social climates, and even of people in public crisis, but meaningful private drama must always elude it since the camera is stopped by what Arthur Miller once called "the wall of the skin."Anyone who saw King's "Warrendale," a laconic, deeply moving study of the treament of emotionally disturbed children, will not be surprised by the great technical skill of "A Married Couple," only by its built-in superficiality.Anyone, that is, except Billy and Antoinette Edwards. According to word from Toronto, the Edwardses, after watching all 70 hours of rough footage, patched up their differences, had a second child, and now are living happily ever after as celebrities of a sort. If you have a friend who is a filmmaker, a 16-mm. feature film might turn out to be less expensive than analysis.

title: Schoonmaker Takes Opener In Bacardi Sailing Series
description: MIAMI. Feb. 2 (AP)  Jim (Ding) Schoonmaker conquered 20knot winds today and won the first race in the. Bacardi Cup sailing series.

title: Negro Women Plan Ball
description: The annual charity ball sponsored by the New York Club of the National Associa tion of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs will be held on Feb. 13 at the Americana. Mrs. Beula Nichols is chairman of the event and Mrs. Verlie Wyche is vice chairman. Miss Wil helmina F. Adams is presi dent of the organization. Tickets at $10 each and in formation are availabe from Miss Venetta Berry, 15 Mount Morris Park West. The benefit will aid the Minisink Townhouse and Community Center, 143 Lenox Avenue, and Camp Minisink in Port Jervis, N. Y.

title: Princeton Trustee Named
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 2 (AP)Princeton University an nounced today that Robert B. Stuart Jr., president and chief executive of the Quaker Oats Company, has been elected a trustee.

title: Faculty Votes to End Boycott At Essex Community College
description: NEWARK, Feb. 2  They faculty of Essex County Com munity College voted today to end its boycott of classes and return to work.

title: TRANSIT RETURN TO CITY IS SOUGHT
description: Controller Abraham D. Beams announced yesterday that legislation was being in troduced in Albany, at his re rquest to return the city's trap sit system to city control.

title: New York City Area Projects
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  President Nixon's proposed budget seeks funds to start the construction of a Federal cor rections center in New York City and to expand customs facilities at Kennedy Interna tional Airport to service the new jumbo jets.

title: The Nixon Budget and the Future
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The political implications of the first Republican budget in a decade spring from a few fairly evident propositions: First, the irreversible or uncon trollable growth of a generation of Democratic so cial programs is consuming dol lars even faster, than President Nixon is saving them on Viet nam. The President clearly does not intend to wreck the major New Deal or Great Society projects, from Social Security to Medicare; in fact, he wants to build on them by spending more for welfare and food pro grams, at least in the short run.

title: Japan and U.S. Face Clash Over Textile Imports
description: TOYKO, Feb. 2  The first real test of the new relation ship between Japan and the United States proclaimed by President Nixon in his State of the Union Message may result from a battle neither side wants over a relatively minor issue.

title: Sonics ReSign Clemens
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Barry Clemens, a forward, signed a oneyear contract to day with the Seattle Sonics, after spending half the season playing out his option. The Sonics also reactivated Al Hairston, a guard.

title: CLERKS APPROVE A 2YEAR PACT
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)  Horse racing will resume in California tomorrow following the settlement of a strike that lasted more than a month, with total losses estimated at more than $10million.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS STATES' CATV RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP  The Supreme Court upheld today the power of states to regulate rates and operations of community antenna televi sion companies.

title: Andrew Wallace Heck to Marry Miss Marnie Isabelle Stanley
description: OSSINING, N. Y., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Archi bald Stanley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mamie Isa belle Stanley, to Andrew Wallace Heck, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Cameron Heck of Cliffside Park. N.J.

title: Jacksonville Tops Ion
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP)The nation's leading re bounder, 7foot2 Artis Gilmore dominated the boards and bas kets tonight in leading sixth ranked Jacksonville University to a 11075 victory over Iona of New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: KOREANS CONCEDE 4 VIETNAM DEATHS
