title: Mansfield Opens Attack on Proposal to Expand ABM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Mike Mansfield, the Senate ma jority leader, denounced today the Administration's proposed expansion of the Safeguard missile defense system, calling it a step that could escalate the atomic arms race and divert resources from domestic needs.

title: Screen: Kastle's 'Honeymoon Killers':Theme Recalls Lonely Hearts Murders
description: LEONARD KASTLE'S "The Honeymoon Killers," which opened yesterday at the Cine Malibu and neighborhood theaters, recounts the criminal partnership of Martha Beck and Raymond Fernandez, who were executed for murder at Sing Sing Prison, in March, 1951.Fernandez and the 29-year-old, 200-pound Mrs. Beck, known as the "Lonely Hearts Killers" at the time of their trial, made a career of stealing from lonely women whom Fernandez met through correspondence clubs, with Mrs. Beck, a trained nurse, posing as his sister. Two of their more recalcitrant victims were murdered, and a third died as a result of an overdose of sleeping pills administered by Mrs. Beck.The movie follows the killers from just before their meeting (through a lonely hearts club correspondence) until just before their trial. Although it takes only the slightest (and most essential) liberties with the facts of the Beck-Fernandez case, "The Honeymoon Killers" is basically a fiction filmof a type virtually unknown in recent years, except as transmuted in the myth-making romanticism of, say, a "Bonnie and Clyde." Within the limits of its type it is one of the best and, curiously, most beautiful American movies in recent years.Photographed in black and white, with fairly rudimentary sound recording and with lighting that seems always to come from natural sources or from whatever electric light bulbs might be at hand, "The Honeymoon Killers" virtually epitomizes the low-budget murder melodrama of everyone's fondest imaginations.In fact, it is concerned with murder less as crime than as unambiguous event. There is no conflict between law and disorder, no trail of clues, no hot pursuit, not even much suspense. When Martha decides that Raymond has taken more than monetary interest in one too many of their victims, she calls the police and turns him, and herself, in. And that, without climax, is the end of that.But "The Honeymoon Killers" has something else  a more concentrated, less cluttered, clearer vision than you are likely to have found in even the best conventional crime movies. Unusually seedy in all its particulars, utterly unflattering to all its characters, sufficiently horrible (but never gratuitously shocking) in the details of its murders, Kastle's film succeeds as a kind of chamber drama of desperate attraction and violent death.Although it is profoundly involved with the quality of individual middle-class American lives, it completely subordinates anecdote to action and pathos, even the pathos of its central characters, to passion.The secondary performances range from acceptable to excellent, with special praise for Mary Jane Higby as a 66-year-old Albany widow who proves especially difficult to kill. Shirley Stoler certainly looks the part of Martha Beck, but she brings to the role an air of grand disdain that seems reasonable as interpretation but sometimes awkward in performance. But Tony LoBianco, with slightly too much profile and a characterization that suggests an immensely humanized early Bela Lugosi, is brilliant.The real star of the movie is its writer-director. Leonard Kastle is a 40-year-old composer who has not previously made films. Oddly, the musical backgroundselections from Mahler symphonies, which oversell every climaxis the only serious failure in "The Honeymoon Killers." But direction, the sum of those decisions that the filmmaker must feel as moral imperatives and that constitute the authorship of a movie, places Kastle among the important deliberate artists of his medium.

title: CENTERS TO ADVISE ON GENETIC ILLS
description: The formation of a fivecen ter network to counsel families and treat patients with genetic disorders was announced yes terday by the National Founda tion for Genetics and Neuro muscular Diseases.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RUN OUT OF STEAM

title: JERSEY DETECTIVE BRANDED A THIEF

He indicated that Chief Gawler had taken nearly $58,000 from a revolving fund earmarked for underworld in formants.

title: Advertising: Doubts Over SelfRegulation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  The same group of advertis ing industry people that has been hearing the call for self regulation heard today from a panel of experts that it can't be done.

title: DAVID W. MARSHALL SR.
description: LITTLE SILVER, N. J., Feb. 4David W. Marshall Sr., a senior management consultant for the Metropolitan Life Insur ance Company in New York, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, after a long illness. He was 49 years old.

When the magistrate asked him to pledge his future good behavior, he replied, No, I won't, and went to jail for a week.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, defended the Administration's Vietnam policy today before the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee, asserting that President Nixon's program of troop with drawal was irreversible.

description: ON the verge of 40, few blueeyed blondes wear such an air of eager expectancy. Unless, like Midge Turk and Dada Van Antwerp, they spent most of their adult years in a convent.

title: Patricia Amy Johnson Betrothed
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 4Mrs. G. Leonard Johnson has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Patricia Amy Johnson, to Dr. John Archibald Wood, also of Englewood. The prospec tive bride is a daughter also of the late Dr. G. Leonard Johnson and her fianc is the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Archibald O. M. Wood of Far Rockaway, Queens, New York.

title: WESTBURY TRACK CLEARED QUICKLY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 4  Cesare Gennari, the track su perintendent at Roosevelt Race way, does not carry a thermom eter, or an anemometer. There fore, he could only guess upon his arrival at the raceway at 6:20 A.M. that the temperature was 6 degfees and the wind velocity 45 miles an hour.

title: Albany Asked to Consider Legal Numbers Gambling
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The Legis ??ature was urged by the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime today to consider the legaliza tion of numbers gambling as a method of undercutting organ ized crime.

title: Clarkson Sextet Wins, 65
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP)Clarkson's hockey team defeated the University of New Hampshire, 65, in overtime tonight. Wayne LaChance, the Clarkson captain, scored the winninv goal.

title: His Newest Work, a Tribute to the City, Is Unveiled
description: YOU have to be extraordi narily confident either in yourself or in your critics to call a ballet Who Cares? for the answer could come back all too slickly and dan gerously. But last night at our New York State Theater our New York State Balan chine did just that.

title: Dockers in British Columbia Spurn Pact, Strike Again
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Feb. 5 (UPI)  Long shoremen, after narrowly re jecting jecting a third contract offer that would have given them the highest hourly wage rate for dockers in North America, went on strike again today and tied up British Columbia's six norts.

title: Arrest of 3 Halts Talks In Newark School Strike
description: NEWARK, Feb. 5Negotia tions in the fourdayold New ark teachers' strike were sus pended tonight following the arrest of three officers of the Newark Teachers Union on charges of violating an anti strike court order.

title: ... but a Letdown in the Senate
description: Riders of the subway, city buses and commuter rail lines should find a little excessive the enthusiasm members of the United States Senate expressed in passing the mass transit bill.

title: Morgan Names Director
description: Emilio G. Collado has been elected a director of J. P. Mor gan & Co., Inc., and of its sub sidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. He is executive vice president and a director of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

title: 12 Dogs Develop Lung Cancer 1 In Group of 86 Taught to Smoke
description: Twelve of 86 beagles that were trained to smoke developed lung cancer, two scientists reported yesterday. They said it was the first time malignant tumors had been produced in large animals by exposing the animals to cigarette smoke.

title: U.S. STUDIES WAYS TO STOP STRIKES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Pres ident Nixon is studying a new, farreaching proposal for set tling labor disputes that threat en the nation's welfare, Gov ernment sources said tonight.

title: Bertrand Russell Cremated
description: COLWYN BAY, Wales, Feb. 5 (UPI)The body of Bertrand Russell was cremated today fol lowing a nonreligious service attended by five mourners. The 97yearold mathematician phil osopher and pacifist had re quested simple, private rites. He asked that his ashes be scat tered. Those attending the service in the tiny chapel at Colwyn Bay Crematorium were Lady Russell; a son by a pre vious marriage; a daughterin law; Russell's private secretary, Christopher Farley, and Ken neth Coates, a director of the Russell Foundation.

title: DEVLIN POSTS A 68 TO GAIN 2D PLACE
Soviet Satellite Destroyer Is Believed to Be in Orbit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  American and British space ex perts believe that the Soviet Union has built and success fully tested a satellite capable of intercepting and destroying other orbiting spacecraft.

title: Richey, Graebner and Laver Gain in Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5  With 16 of the world's top ranked professionals battling head to head today for major shares in the $60,000 Interna tiopal Tennis Players' Associa tion indoor open, it was no sur prise that the losers' list read like a who's who: Arthur Ashe, Manuel Santana, Tom Okker, Fred Stolle, Stan Smith, Roy Emerson, Roger Taylor and Jim Osborne.

title: Stony Brook Unit Gets Grant
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Feb. 5  The department of chemistry at the State University Center here has received a $15,000 grant from the National Science Foundation that will enable 10 top undergraduates from Stony Brook and other East Coast col leges to conduct independent, study projects during the sum mer.

title: SENATORS RESIST NAMING OF DIBONA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, is leading a drive to block the nomina tion of the White House choice for Director of Selective Serv ice, Charles J. DiBona.

title: Garbage Accord Reached in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 5  The Cincinnati City Council and negotiators for 1,485 striking members of the union of non uniformed municipal employes agreed today on the terms of a settlement to end a 31day strike.

title: How Shifts Occurred In State Bond Yields
description: Interest rates on topgrade state bonds climbed sharply last year. Since midDecem ber they have come back down part way. Here is a table of state bond sales il lustrating how yields have shifted.

title: 511 Manufacturers' Profits Decline 4%
description: Bewitched, bothered and be wildered probably best describes management's attitude today as it strives to maintain profits while inflation climbs and the economy declines.

title: Judge Carswell's Failure
description: The spotlight on Judge G. Harrold Carswell's white supremacy speech of 22 years ago has had the unfortunate effect of overshadowing the need for an examination of his professional qualifications for the Supreme Court. A man may perhaps be forgiven for the extravagance of youthful campaign oratory, although Judge Carswell's claim that he has long shed all traces of racial bias would be more convincing had he shown a more hospitable attitude toward civil rights during his years on the bench.

title: F. I. duPont Fined By the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced last night that it had fined Francis I. duPont & Co. and three of its presept or former partners a total of $110,000 for having failed to handle customers' complaints properly. The action of the exchange's board of governors established a prece dent, in that it marked the first known instance that dis ciplinary moves had been made against a member firm or any of its partners for failing to handle complaints properly.

title: Writer in Yugoslavia Wins Anneal in Supreme Court
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 5 (UPI)Zoran Gluscevic, a writer sentenced last year to six months in jail for writing an article that insulted the Soviet Union, will not be im prisoned, a court ruled today.

title: Roseboro Settles for $7,500 In Suit Against Marichal
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP) A 4yearold, $110,000 bat tery suit filed by the former Los Angeles Dodgers' catcher, John Roseboro, against the San Francisco Giants' pitcher, Juan Marichal, was settled today for a reported $7,500.

title: Italian Socialists Endorse Move for Coalition Cabinet
description: ROME, Feb. 5The Italian Socialist party gave lukewarm and ambiguous endorsement tonight to efforts to reestablish a centerleft coalition govern ment after six months of minor ity rule.

title: 2 Bronx Children Killed In Small Apartment Fire
description: Two small children were killed and a third critically in jured early this morning after a small fire broke out in the bedroom of their secondstory apartment at 633 Tinton Ave nue in the southeast Bronx.

title: Miss Rubenstein And J. M. Green Planning Bridal
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Feb. 5Miss Judith A. Rubinstein and Jeffrey Martin Green will be married March 29.

title: '69 EARNINGS ROSE AT L.I. LIGHTING CO.
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that its earnings in 1969 increased for the 17th consecutive year.

title: At Gimbels, an Ode to California Sun
description: GIMBELS has discovered California and, starting Monday, it will celebrate that fact throughout the store for two weeks. Besides the numerous exhibits and ac tivities, there are fashions and furniture from the Golden State. The lash ions, not surpris ingly, tend to he for sunning and relaxing: bikinis with float, coverups; simple slithers of jersey dressesmostly solid lavender or pale green; T shirt tops over tiny pleated skirts or pants, and a variety of Levis (including some in stripes) from a new Levi Strauss boutique the store has opened.

Turner, who was head of the Justice Depart iment's antitrust division dur ing the Johnson Administra tion, said today that he saw no justification for filing anti trust suits against conglomer ate mergers on the ground that the mergers would increase the prospects for illegal reciprocal dealings. This is one of the main bases for several of the suits that have been filed by the Nixon Administration.

It would be difficult to think of a more apt descrip tion as Ollie, the magnificent dragon with the center mo lar, gentle Kukla and Fran Allison returned last night to Channel 13 for a fivepart series.

The game will benefit the South ern Christian Leadership Con ference Foundation and the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Memo rial Center under construction in Atlanta.

title: Actor Acquitted of Assault
description: SANTA. MONICA, Calif., Feb. 5 (UPI)Jim Brown, the athlete and actor, was acquitted today on charges that he drove his automobile at a motorist after a minor traffic accident and then threw the motorist to the ground. A jury of seven women and five men deliber ated 30, minutes before finding Mr. Brown, 33 years old, not guilty of felony assault and misdemeanor battery.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Following is the text of a statement today by Attorney General John N. Mitchell about subpoenas issued to members of the press:

title: Sun Oil Cuts Spending
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (UPI) The Sun Oil Company will spend $55.7million less in 1970 because of anticipated higher taxes and other costs, it was reported today. The board chairman Robert G. Dunlap, said the cutback would reduce total expenditures this year to $264.5million. The bulk of the cut, $35million, will be in capi tal expenditures and develop ment costs related to explora tion and production activities.

title: Israel's 'Flying Matchmaker' Lands
description: THE nicest thing about "The Flying Matchmaker," a folk-comedy musical from Israel, is the excellent English-language adaptation, as thorough and spic and span as you please, from the dubbed dialogue to the intricate business of supplying and lip-matching new lyrics in English. Furthermoreand for once on the screentranscribers is spelled out in the whole team of the closing credits, from Paulette Rubinstein, the adapter, down a list of "ghost" singers. Bully for National Showmanship, the distributors, who opened this film yesterday at the Trans-Lux 85th Street.But the picture itself is less impressive than the surface renovation for American audiences.Based on a vintage folk-comedy by Abraham Goldfaden, the "father" of Yiddish theater, energetically played by a host of Israeli players and rooted in traditional lore and humor, the picture is less winning for format and content than for its pretty color, festive spirit and thread of music. This friendly, perfectly harmless enterprise was understandably a big hit in the homeland. But some spectators, mindful of the exotic source and setting, may see the movie as a broad, old-fashioned village diversion of thwarted young love and mistaken identity.The film is as wholesome as it is transparent, with simple, broad, predictable jokes. The tunes by Shaul Barzoweski have a nice "Fiddler on the Roof" flavor, but the extremely conventional lyrics are something else (at least in translation). And they are well sung ("ghosted"), to exceptionally ripe, tasteful arrangements. But there simply are not enough tunes to overcome the tedious stretches and drawn-out gags.Front and center, in a demanding double role, is young Mike Burstein, as a personable youth determined to win his girl by a camouflage as the village idiot. Now it is quite probable that the untranslated Israeli original dealt more benignly with this character, who is the main plot device and the chief joke. But the plight of this limping, stuttering, one-eyed dimwit  actually a sweet-spirited little chap  grows increasingly less funny. And one musical dream montage, when he stumbles through a woods, seems downright Freudian, amid all the jollity.As the three main elders, Shmuel Rodensky, Elisheva Michaeli and Raphel Klatschkin, are fine. Rina Ganor is a pretty heroine and Jermaine Unikowsky makes a darling minx of a matchmaker's daughter. Call it tame, cheerful andexcluding the main joke and jokesterpretty to watch.

description: CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP)The San Francisco Warriors, paced by Joe Ellis and Jerry Lucas, took over fourth place in the National Basketball Associa tion's Western Division tonight with a 127105 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 America's museums are drown ing in their own success, over whelmed by the millions stream ing to see their exhibitions, the Congress was told today.

description: The International Utilities Corporation announced yester day that, subject to the com pletion of formal agreements, it proposed to sell all of its holdings in Brascan, Ltd., for about $37million in cash in Canadian funds.

description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 5 (UPI)The Honduran Defense Ministry said that Gov ernment forces fought Salva doran troops tonight about 10 miles inside Honduras, it said four Salvadoran soldiers had been killed.

title: Foreign Affairs:

title: Screen: 'Virgin Soldiers':Tragicomedy of Empire Opens at Rendezvous
description: YOU can still see them on television, those World War II service dramas, at least 20 years old. They are a special sort, comitragedies, I guess, in which a group of raw recruits stumble through trainingbrawling, drinking, wenchinga laugh a minute, and then all of a sudden they go to battle and get themselves shot to pieces. And always somebody will remain to tell the story, win the medals, get the girl back home.In John Dexter's "The Virgin Soldiers," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvous, yet another group ofnot quite rawrecruits trains together and plays together, a laugh maybe every three minutes, and then they go to battle and get themselves shot to pieces. Only now the time is the early 1950's, the place is southeast Asia, the troops are British, and they are not saving Western civilization; they are overseeing the dissolution of the empire. And Brigg (Hywel Bennett), the most important of those who come back from battle, doesn't win the girl or the medals; he merely gets to leave.The virgin soldiers are all occupational misfits. One leans to the right, another leans to the left, most wear thick glasses, and two sleep together. Clerk-typists by assignment, they play battle games across their desks until somebody's blood-soaked records come through, and then they blanch. By night they make timid stabs at sex with the local (Singapore) talent, but by day they mock themselves as they "stick it in, twist it, pull it out right," and learn how to be fierce on the bayonet range. They don't have much fun, and generally, they reflect their world's frustrated dis-ease.All goes fairly badly until a train taking them to a new assignment is ambushed by guerrillas, and then things go very badly indeed. Many die, a few are brave, the braggart sergeant of the bayonet range (Jack Shepherd; a fine broad preformance) panics and locks himself in the toilet, and young Brigg makes an ambiguous escape-rescue.The ambiguity rather than the boldness of the gesture is the point at issue here. Although the movie is never clear about its heroics (there are, for example, moments of unexcused, unexcusable battle sentimentality), its general drift is toward disillusion, bitter bitter-sweetness, and welcome defeat.Performances among the officers and men run a fairly conventional range of British satiric and nonsatiric soldier types. Almost everybody is as good as his role allowswhich is "good" within a rather narrow range of character potential. Hywel Bennett's young Brigg appeals by grace of his close-set eyes, puddled brow, and general air of queasiness.Lynn Redgrave plays the sergeant major's daughter, an army brat bored and aggressive. This is the first time I have seen her in a role that is not a caricature of one sort or another, and she is tough, believable, honestly pathetic and winning.At its worst "The Virgin Soldiers" indulges in a lot of unfunny, I think unreal, sexual initiation fantasy. That any of this works and even seems to matter says a good deal for Hywel Bennett and Miss Redgrave as performers. But at its best, the movie really does become involved, in small and private ways, with the question of imperialism. The "enemy," the movie knows, and the British troops more or less know, is rightor at least has history on his side. Between the two orders, Eastern and Western, moments of confused confrontation, even one shocking intimate killing, which evokes an awareness a little deeper and sharper and more moving than the films's tired genre requires.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOME superficial gripes first. History and Human Survival is a collection of pieces. Its contents come from a bewildering variety of sources: Daedalus, The New Republic, The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease, The Atlantic Monthly, Partisan Review, Psychiatry, The New York Review of Books, The New York Times Book Re view, TransAc tion, among oth ers. Testimony to Mr. Lif ton diver sity, but such a diverse gathering would have to be superbly organized to justify itself as an organic whole, and, in the case of History and Hu man Survival, it is not, as the catch all subtitle sug gests (Essays on the Young and Old, Survivors and the Dead, Peace and War, and on Con temporary Psychohistory). The book be gins with what is most conclusive and fa miliar in Mr. Lifton's work and proceeds slowly to underlying principles. There are unsuccessful attempts to disguise some of the pieces' original purposes, as in cases where the titles of books under review are never given, or in the inclusion of only one side of a debate. Much of the book is difficult to read, both because the author's prose can be grindingly academic and be cause his focus is often on death and apoc alypse, and the psyche plain fights it. Whatever the reason, the mind wanders.

He is, as one of them put it, the complete ly unapproachable man in whose blue eyes the twinkle turns to frost the instant anyone tries to edge a friendly toe over the line of propriety.

title: AN ISRAELI VESSEL IS SUNK AT ELATH
description: TEL AVIV, Friday, Feb. 6 An Israeli Navy vessel de scribed as an auxiliary craft was sunk early this morning in the harbor of Elath, apparently by enemy sabotage. Another was damaged.

title: WOOD GAINS LEAD IN FIGURE SKATING
description: TULSA, Okla., Feb. 5Tim Wood, the world and national men's champion, gained first place today during the com pulsory figures of the senior men's event of the United States figure skating champion ships.

title: Choreographer Is Awarded City's Handel Medallion
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE gently coaxed a tired ballerina out of the wings onto centerstage during a re hearsal for the premiere of his ballet Who Cares? of fered last night as he marked nearly half a century as a choreographer.

title: Edward J. Eder Plans to Wed Miss Nancy Duncombe on May 2
description: PLANDOME, L. I., Feb. 5 Henry L. Duncombe Jr., di rector of economic studies for the General Motors Corpora tion, has announced the en gagement of his daughter, Miss Nancy Duncombe, to Edward J. Eder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Eder of Old Brookville. The wedding is planned for May 2 in the Congregational Church of Manhasset.

title: Miss Allyson Young to Be a Bride
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 5Dr. and Mrs. Everett Young have made known the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Allyson Young, to David S. Schwartz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanford Schwartz of Greenvale. A wedding in June is planned.

title: Dempsey Plays ThirdMan Role at FrazierEllis Camp
description: Joe Frazier was putting on the long rubber trunks he wears under his green tights when Jack Dempsey entered the room.

title: Davis Cup Isn't Open Yet, but It's Ajar
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 5 Any discussions of an open Davis Cup must include all parties, including the profes sional promoters, Edward A. Turville, the new United States Cup captain, said to day.

title: Article 3  No Title
Reply From Boston
description: Cornelius Vermeule, curator of classical arts at the Boston Museum, said yesterday:

title: Music: Bernstein Leads Carter Work
description: ELLIOTT CARTER was sup posed to have a new work ready for the 125th Anniversary Year of the New York Philharmonic, two seasons back. But he never did get it in on time, and it was not until last night that Leonard Bernstein conduct ed the world premiere of Mr. Carter's Concerto for Or chestra.

title: Great Lakes Pollution Poses 2 Problems for Nixon
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 5  When President Nixon sits down to morrow with four Republican Governors to discuss water pol lution in the Great Lakes states he will find that the machinery for cleaning up Lake Michigan is already turning.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE SHOWS 6.8% RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 31 was above the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same pe riod was down.

title: Hanoi Hints It May End Private Talks
description: PARIS, Feb. 5  North Viet nam hinted today that it might not be willing to meet with the United States privately so long as the American delegation was headed by Philip C. Habib as acting chief.

title: Lawyer Is Named Chairman Of Columbia Advisory Unit
description: The election of Clarence S. Barasch, a New York lawyer, as chairman of the advisory board to the counselor of Jew ish students at Columbia Uni versity was announced yester day.

title: Capitol TB Tests Planned After Deaths of 2 Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Arrangements were made to day to test members of Con gress and about 14,000 Capitol employes for tuberculosis.

title: Vannes School Gives Premiere Of Henze's Miracle Theater
description: Hans Werner Henze, one of today's most successful opera composers, wrote his first stage piece in 1948 when he was only 22. It was Das Wundertheater, or The Mir acle Theater, and was devised as an opera for actors.

title: SERVICE FAMILIES ON WELFARE LISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The families of more than 12,000 servicemen are on the nation's welfare rolls and re ceive monthly welfare checks, food stamps, surplus food or other forms of assistance, the Defense Department reported today.

title: Denver Blasts Destroy 24 School Buses
description: DENVER, Feb. 6Multiple explosions destroyed 24 empty school buses and damaged 15 more last night when at least 12 dynamite bombs went off under their as tanks.

title: Del Papa Outpoints Preberg And Regains European Title
description: MILAN, Italy, Feb. 6 (UPI) Piero del Papa of Italy recap tured the European lightheavy weight boxing title tonight by beating Yvan Preberg of Yugo slavia on points in 15 rounds:

title: Negroes Profit From Beef Cattle in Experiment in Mississippi
description: LEXINGTON, Miss.There was a certain pride in Willie Palmer's voice, in the broad smile on his face and in his step as he led a stranger up a grassy hillock studded with pine trees to show off his herd.

title: CHARLES F. FRYLING, RESEARCH SCIENTIST
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6Dr. Charles F. Fryling, who retired in 1962 as a research scientist for the Koppers Company after 11 years, died yesterday in West Penn Hospital. He was 72 ment and production of syn thetic rubber.

title: Bridge:
description: THE lead of a singleton against a slam contract in a suit is a doubleedged venture. The slight chance that the lead may produce an immediate ruff for the de fense must be offset against the possibility that a queen or a Jack in the hand of the other defender will be trapped.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
OTHER RAILWAY REPORTS
description: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN

title: Columbia Tops Brown, 4326, Despite Bruins' FirstHalf Stalling Tactics
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 6 Columbia ran into just what it expected from Brown tonight a firsthalf stall that kept the score down. But the Lions sur mounted that problem and went on to beat the Bruins, 4326, before 2,008 persons at Marvel Gymnasium.

title: Palmer Outpolls Russell As Athlete of Decade
description: Arnold Palmer, whose boy ish charm and faculty for miraculous comebacks sent professional golf into a multi million  dollar spiral, was chosen athlete of the decade yesterday.

title: TV: A Storm in Summer
description: THE incredible virtuosity of Peter Ustinov lent heart break, humor and hope to Rod Serling's inspired original drama entitled A Storm in Summer, seen last night on the Hallmark Hall of Fame over the National Broadcast ing Company network.

title: Gabriele Seyfert Captures 3d European Skating Title
description: LENINGRAD, Feb. 6 (AP) Gabriele Seyfert, the skating star from East Germany, won her third European figureskat ing championship tonight.

title: N.B.A. Adds Cleveland, Houston, Buffalo, Portland, Ore.
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb 6 The National Basketball Associ ation voted today to expand to 18 teams for next season with the addition of four new fran chises.

title: J. A. Wilkinson to Marry Miss Sarah T. Young
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 6Mrs. Tyler Young has announced the engagement of her daugh ter, Miss Sarah Tyler Young, to Flying Officer Joseph Alan Wilkinson of the Royal Air Force.

title: Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Bonn's Bill for Experts Put at $1Million a Year
description: BONN, Feb. 6A consci entious civil servant has dis covered that the federal Government's belief in and affection for expertise is costing West German tax payers well over a million dollars a year.

title: SIHANOUK APPROVES AMERICAN PRESENCE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 6  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodian Head of State who is often thought to favor his, Communist neighbors over the United States, has declared publicly that he knows it is American imperialism that presently assures Cambodia's independence and territorial in tegrity.

title: Three Bus Lines Still Out; A Fourth Strike Is Averted
description: A strike against two north ern New Jersey bus lines and a third serving upstate New York communities ended its sixth day yesterday with no signs of a quick settlement. Forty thousand commuters have had to find other means of transportation.

title: Japanese Satellite Delayed
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6 (UPI)Japa nese space scientists postponed today an attempt to launch a small satellite into earth orbit. The Tokyo University space de partment announced that un favorable weather conditions forecast for southern Japan forced them to cancel Sunday's scheduled launching. Japan has made four unsuccessful at tempts since 1966 to launch a small satellite packed with equipment to record and trans mit scientific information.

title: ABE ATTELL DIES; BOXING CHAMPION
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Feb. 6 (AP)Abe Attell, the world featherweight champion for 12 years in the early years of the century and who was elected to boxing's Hall of Fame in 1955, died today in Liberty Loomis Hospital in the nearby community of Libertyville. He was 85 years old.

title: Northeast Oil Crisis Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Federal officials are prepar ing to provide emergency sup plies of home heating oil for the Northeast. The Oil Import Appeals Board, to meet what its chairman calls the emer gency situation up there, is allocating terminal operators a quota of 9,475 barrels a day. The Defense Department re ports it is willing to contribute an additional 1,756 barrels a day from its quota.

title: Essex County College Head Quits Post for Harmony
description: NEWARK, Feb. 6 (AP) Ellis F. White, the president of Essex County Community Col lege, announced his resignation from that post today.

title: NATION'S JOBLESS INCREASE SHARPLY TO 3.9% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  The slowdown of the national economy pushed unemployment significantly higher in January to 3.9 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Department re ported today.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE'VE suffered nearly a decade of activist fiddle and at least two decades of being brainwashed by the doctrine that whatever is young right, writes John W. Aldridge in this snobbish, contradictory, wilful and obses sive broadside. The young, by virtue of their sheer numbers, vociferousness, and evident unanimity of vision have become the most powerful new establishment. In fact that must be the first generation in history to see itself from the outset as a herd rather than as an aggregate of private persons who happen to be the same age.

title: Susan Dana Fiancee Of David I. Kertzer
description: GARDINER, Me., Feb. 6 Miss Susan Dana and David I. Kertzer will be married May 30 in Augusta.

title: Prices Guaranteed By National Steel
description: The National Steel Corpora tion announced yesterday it was following the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in introduc ing a guaranteedprice policy.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Police and Protesters Clash in Londonderry
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Feb. 6 (AP)Armed police clashed with Roman Catholic civil rights demon strators tonight after a mob hurled rocks at British sol diers.

title: Couple Held in Bronx Fire Fatal to Two Children
description: A Bronx man and his com monlaw wife were charged with criminal negligence yes terday in connection with fire in which two of their children were killed and a third was injured.

title: Belgium Reports Economic Growth of 6% for 1969
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 6Belgium ended 1969 with an estimated 6 per cent increase of her gross national product, her industrial potential nearly engaged to capacity and price increases below those of her partners in the European Common Market.

title: Vorster Backs Lesotho Coup
description: CAPETOWN, Feb. 6Prime Minister John Vorster pledged South Africa's full political backing today for Chief Leabu Jonathan, the Prime Minister who retained power in Lesotho by arresting all opposition last week to avert possible defeat in a general election.

title: PENN FIVE DOWNS HARVARD, 8677
description: Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP)John Koller came oil the bench in the second half to night, hit on six straight field goal attempts and led Penn to an 8677 basketball victory over Harvard. It was the Quakers' seventh triumph in Ivy League play in which they are un beaten.

title: 2d Pan Am Terminal Is Opened at Kennedy
description: I don't know what New York is going to do, but they've got to do something. This looks like progress.

title: Tate Suspect Is in Solitary For Violation of Jail Rule
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP) A judge refused today to set aside a murder indictment against Charles M. Manson, who disclosed in court that he was being held in solitary confine ment.

title: HOWARD S. BOWNS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 6 Howard S. Bowns, president of the Gray Rapids Lumber Company of New Brunswick, Canada, died here today. He was 64 years old and lived here and in Lyme.

title: G.M. Reports a Rise in Hiring Of Workers in Minority Groups
description: DETROIT, Feb. 6  The Gen eral Motors Corporation today reported gains in its minority group hiring, even among the salaried ranks, although the number of salaried black work ers was still low.

title: TEAMSTERS SEEK TO HELP BROKERS
description: The International Brother hood of Teamsters is attempting to organize some 5,000 stock brokers in the Chicago area.

title: AID TO ARTS PLAINT IS AIRED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A House subcommittee heard again today that Federal grants to symphony orchestras and dance companies in everdeeper financial trouble were not enough. A recital of achieve ments in film provided the only cheerful note.

title: Market Place:
description: YOU call it churning, but your broker says he is merely taking advantage of shifting investment opportu nities. You haven't proved your case when you show that you have lost money as a result of rapidfire trading. Nobody's perfect, your bro ker will say.

title: MANCE PERFORMS IN JAZZ CONCERT
description: For a jazz pianist, the gulf between a style that is melodic and theatrical enough to at tract a mass audience and one that is creative enough to ap peal to a jazz audience is diffi cult to close. Erroll Garner wrapped the two tightly to gether 25 years ago. Since then Junior Mance has become one of the very few pianists who have coped with the problem successfully.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Liquori Captures 1,000Yard Run in 2:07.6 for K. of C. Meet Mark
description: Marty Liguori is rapidly be coming the darling of the Madi son Square Garden track gal lery because (1) he wins and (2) he makes his races exciting. Last night, switching from the familiar mile to the relatively unfamiliar 1,000yard run, he won an exciting race.

title: Sophistry on Genocide
description: After two decades of inaction, based on sophistry and outright hypocrisy, there are signs that the United States may at last be moving to ratify the International Convention on the Prevention and Pun ishment of the Crime of Genocide.

title: Gillian Feeley, Alan M. Harnik Are Wed Here
description: Miss Gillian Feeley and Alan Martin Harnik, gradu ate students in anthropology at New York University, were married yesterday in the of fice of Rabbi A. Bruce Gold man, a chaplain at Columbia University.

title: Harris Quits Post As Democrats' Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma resigned unex pectedly today as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserting that he wanted to free himself from the restraints of the job.

title: A ThreeDimensional Mirror Invented
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The inventor of a vi brating, three  dimensional mirror believes it should help air traffic controllers to visualize the actual position of aircraft. Alan C. Traub, a re searcher for the Mitre Corpora tion, Bedford, Mass., was grant ed Patent 3,493,290 for his variable focus mirror this week. In experiments simulat ing traffic control he obtained a display that was some thing like observing fish in a tank.

title: SENATE BARS CUT IN SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Federal aid to school districts serving children living in public housing units came one step closer today when the Senate voted 43 to 32 to retain this new program in the $35billion, fouryear aidtoeducation bill now being debated.

title: WOOD KEEPS TITLE IN FIGURE SKATING
description: TULSA, Feb. 6Skating with the confidence of a world Cham pion, Tim Wood of Colorado Springs, Colo., successfully de fended his National men's fig tire skating championship to night at the Tulsa Assembly Center.

title: FITZGIBBON GAINS AT HACKENSACK NET
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 6 Seeded players swept their firstround matches today in the Eastern indoor tennis cham pionships sponsored by the Mecca Tennis Club of New York City. Play was conducted at the Eastern Clay Indoor Tennis Club.

title: Roberts Co. Plans to Seek Chapter X Reorganization
description: The Roberts Company, a tex tilemachinery producer in San ford, N. C., announced yester day that its directors have voted to apply for a reorganiza tion of its financial affairs un der the Chapter X provisions of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: CITY ETHICS CASE IS GIVEN TO HOGAN
description: A possible conflictofinterest case involving a former deputy commissioner of the old Depart ment of Licenses as referred by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to District Attorney Frank S. Ho gan.

title: Mrs. Walter Winchell Dies; Former Vaudeville Actress
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP)  Mrs. Walter Winchell, wife of Walter Winchell, the retired columnist, died yester day in a Phoenix hospital. She wag 64 years old.

title: Test for Sickle Cell Trait Urged for Negro Recruits
description: The sudden deaths of four Ne gro Army recruits during basic training at Fort Bliss, in El Paso, has prompted an Army doctor to urge that all Negro military recruits be screened for an inherited blood condition known as sickle cell trait.

title: Article 1  No Title
E.L. HOLTERMANN SR., BANK EXECUTIVE, 73
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 6 E. Louis Holtermann Sr., who retired eight years ago as a vice president of Grace National Bank, now part of Marine Mid land Grace Trust Company, died here yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 61 Rock ledge Road South.

title: 50c Buys Lunch for the Elderly in an Affluent Suburb of Boston
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 6Harry Bernstein contem plated a forkful of turkey chow mein, paused a moment before putting it in his mouth, and said, You couldn't du plicate this meal anywhere outside for less than $2.

title: Parents With $300 and an Idea: Free School Is Born
description: MOST families faced with the conditions that pre vail in New York City schools have done one of three things: moved to the suburbs, turned to private or parochial re sources or tried to cope as best they could with exist ing conditions.

title: Federal Judge Authorizes Panther Chief's Exhumation
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)A Federal judge authorized today the exhumation of the body of Fred Hampton, a Black Panther party chief, for examination in connection with a grand jury inquiry into his slaying.

title: Leningraders Confident Their City Is No. 1
description: LENINGRAD, Feb. 7The second largest city in the Soviet Unionborn in 1703 of a Czar's whim and aban doned as the national capital by Communism in 1918has shaken off its secondcity complex.

title: REPORT ON CARSWELL CALLED MISLEADING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Senator Roman L. Hruska of Nebraska said today that a civil rights lobbyist had given a misleading impression that Judge G. Harrold Carswell showed racial bias in his Fed eral District Court decisions.

title: Poetic Sensibility of Joseph Glasco
description: THE American painter Jo seph Glasco is an artist of rare gifts. He has a high ly complex, idiosyncratic con ception of the figure as a pictorial device. He is an ex quisite and dramatic drafts man, who, even when he chooses to Work in black and white, has the ability to en dow his (usually elaborate) images with an aura of sen suality. He is also a power ful designer, who confers on every area of the picture sur face a very personal and em phatic visual quality.

title: TEXAS MAN FIRES INTO A TELESCOPE
description: FORT DAVIS, Tex., Feb. 6 (AP)  An employe of the Mc Donald Observatory, described as drunk by the sheriff and as mentally depressed by his superiors, fired seven shots last midnight at a delicate $1mil lion telescope mirror.

title: Lindsay and Garelik Hail Year of the Dog
description: Mayor John V. Lindsay yesterday helped welcome the Chinese Lunar New Year 4668, the Year of the Dog as firecrackers crackled and lion dancers pranced in Chinatown.

title: TRIO OF AUSSIES, RALSTON ADVANCE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6  They started separating the superpros from the ordinary pros today at the International Tennis Players Association in door open, and the four super players emerging as semifinal ists included the three top seeded Australians and one American.

title: PATTEE CANYON WINS AT HIALEAH
description: MIAMI, Feb. 6 (AP)Barbara Hunter's Pattee Canyon, mak ing her first start since Octo ber, closed with a rush to win the sixth race at Hialeah Park today. She raced the 5 fur longs on the grass in 1:03, only twofifths of a second slower than the track record.

title: ECOLOGISTS WARN ON HEATING RIVER
description: Witnesses at a hearing warned Congressmen yesterday of the dangers of hotwater dis charges into Long Island Sound and the Hudson River from prospective atomic powergen erating plants.

title: MRS. STEWART ATKINSON
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 6 Mrs. Stewart B. Atkinson, who was active in civic affairs here, died yesterday in her home at 13 Beach Drive. The wife of the former principal of Darien High School, she was a member of the Darien Board of Public Welfare.

title: Antiques: Authentic Tudor Furniture
description: THE search for fine Tudor furniture is on for astute collectors just learning to ap preciate its quality.

title: 39 PLAYERS FINED $4,300 FOR FIGHTS
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (UPI)  The National Hockey League cracked down on teams whose players leave their benches to join in fights, slapping three separate teams with $1,000 fines each and levying a total of $4,300 in fines to 39 play ers from four clubs.

title: Store Sales Revised Down
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (Reu ters)The Commerce Depart ment said today that total re tail sales for December were revised slightly downward to $29.42billion from the origi nally reported $29.58billion. This was nearly unchanged from November's retail sales of $29.47billion, but was three per cent above the December, 1968, total of $28.46billion.

title: MAYOR CITES NEED TO TRAIN JOBLESS
description: Mayor Lindsay cautioned business executives here yester day that their federally sup ported program of hiring the hardcore unemployed needed to emphasize keeping the men employed and upgrading their skills.

title: Allies Resume Vietnam Action After a CeaseFire of 24 Hours
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 7 (AP)  The allies resumed offensive opera tions throughout South Vietnam last night at the end of their 24hour ceasefire, which, they said, had been marked by num erous enemy violations.

title: Washington: For the Record
2 Texas Gulf Insiders Ordered To Give Up Profits in Trading
description: A group or men who were insiders of the Texas Gulfl Sulphur Company almost six years ago were ordered yester day by Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsai to repay to the com pany their profits made in trad ing in its stock at that time.

title: Candidate Petitions For School Boards Will Be Accepted
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that nominating peti tions of candidates seeking election to local school boards in Manhattan, as well as in other boroughs, would be ac cepted starting Monday despite present uncertainty over the eventual school district bound aries in Manhattan.

title: Doctors Strike in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 6 (UPI)  Six hundred resident doctors in 14 state hospitals in six Colombian cities went on strike today for higher wages and improved working condi tions. The doctors, who earn $70 a month, are asking for a $160 basic wage.

title: 3 FRENCH CONSCRIPTS GIVEN PRISON TERMS
description: PARIS, Feb. 6Three young revolutionaries in army uni form were sentenced to prison today for distributing leaflets that allegedly incited other con scripts to insubordination.

title: Zoe Ann Kritzler Prospective Bride
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey F. Kritzler of Ridgewood and High Falls, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Zoe Ann Kritzler, to Stephen Jordan Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Jordan Potter of White Plains.

title: Sabotage of 2 Israeli Vessels Is Followed by Sinking of U.A.R. Ship
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6  Israeli jets attacked and sank a 700ton Egyptian minelayer with a crew of 80 in the Gulf of Suez this evening, the Israelis reported. The attack apparently was in retaliation for the sinking of an Israeli coastal vessel in Elath harbor before dawn.

title: Reporters Are Allowed To Watch Theodorakis
description: ATHENS, Feb. 6Several foreign correspondents were taken to a detention camp today to he shown that Mikis Theodorakis, the Greek com poser, was alive and well.

title: 3 More Ships Are Docked Without Tugs' Assistance
description: The masters of the liners Raf faello, Bremen and Queen Anna Maria put on a dazzling dis play of seamanship here yester day morning.

title: Burger Asks States to Develop Reform on Prisoner Grievances
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)  The Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Bur ger urged the states today to develop some simple method for hearing promptly, fully and fairly the grievances of pris orers.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ONCE, when he was 20, James J. Beattie was taken to the top of the Empire State Building and a man put one hand on Beattie's arm as he waved the other toward the city that lay below. Some day, kid, the man said, all these is gonna be yours, kid. It's gonna be your town. Even then Beattie had his curious ability to be both participant and observer in the dramas of his life and years later he remembered thinking on two tracks: One, the man was right, when he was heavyweight cham pion of the world, New York would lay supine be tween his size 15 shoes and gaze 6 feet 8 inches up at his crisp black hair; and two, that if this wasn't a banal scene in a cheap second feature, why was the man always calling him kid?

title: MANTLE MANAGES AN UNCANNY SHOT
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6  Mickey Mantle's runaway vic tory in yesterday's proam didn't carry over into the open ing round of the $30,000 Amer ican Airlines Astrojet Classic today, but he treated fans to one of the tournament's most snectacular shots.

title: CHARLES F. NUGENT, BROOKLYN RECTOR
description: GREAT MEADOWS, N. J., Feb. 6  The Rev. Charles Francis Nugent, who retired last year after 16 years, as rector of the Episcopal Church of the Nativity, at Ocean Ave nue and Farragut Road in Brooklyn, died yesterday in Warren Hospital, Philipsburg. He was 66 years old and lived here.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON LACK FIRM TREND
Miss Macmanus Will Be Wed To Marc Desautels in March
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Feb. 6Mr. and Mrs. Armand F. MacManus have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Mac manus of Larchmont, N. Y., to Marc Pierre Desautels of Geneva. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Georges Desautels of Woodside, Calif.

title: Ziegler Shoots a 68 for 200 and Keeps 3Stroke Lead in Hope Golf Classic.
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 6Larry Ziegler, who jumped from the ranks of the rabbits last year when he won the Michigan Golf Classic, remained the pacesetter in the $125,000 Bob Hope Golf Classic today. No longer forced to seek a qualifying spot each week as he is now a tournament winner, the 30yearold St. Louis pro fessional completed his three best rounds on the tour with a 54hole aggregate of 200.

title: A Calley Charge Is Dropped
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. (AP)The Army dropped today a charge of murder against First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., now facing courtmartial for the alleged massacre of 102 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai in March, 1968. The charge filed Nov. 29, 1969, alleged that Lieutenant Calley killed an adult male in Quang Ngai prov ince approximately one and half months before the My Lai incident.

title: YOUNG LORDS GET NEWARK WARNING
description: NEWARK, Feb. 6Anthony Imperiale, a City Councilman who is running for Mayor, today warned a Puerto Rican group known as the Young Lords that there would not be any old lords if they violated a police order to leave a school they had helped keep open during a teachers' strike.

title: Activity on a Wide Front
description: CAIRO, Feb. 6Warfare be tween the United Arab Repub lic and Israel flared over a wide front today, with reports of ships being sunk, aircraft shot down and targets under heavy fire on both sides. down and targets under heavy fire on both sides.

title: U.S. REPORTS AIDING LAOTIAN REFUGEES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A spokesman for the State De partment said today that the first 3,000 of 18,000 Laotian refugees on the Plaine des Jarres were evacuated by Amer ican aircraft yesterday.

title: HAWKS SET BACK BULLS BY 10493
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 6 (AP) Walt Bellamy teamed with Lou Hudson tonight to pace the Atlanta Hawks to a 10493 vic tory over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Associa tion contest.

title: State Plans Big Project In Suburbs
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6  The State Urban Develop ment Corporation plans to re develop an 11acre downtown residential neighborhood here in a project that will include 1,000 apartments for people of low and middle income.

title: CORALLO IS GIVEN A 4YEAR TERM
description: Antonio (Tony Ducks) Co rallo, convicted last December of conspiracy to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus, was sentenced to fourandahalfyear prison term yesterday.

title: A Designer Lowers His Aim
description: YOU have to take a good look at yourself in the mirror and see what looks best on you.

title: Suspect With Immunity Gets 90 Days for Standing Mute
description: For refusing to answer ques tions when granted immunity from prosecution for the an swers, an alleged member of a gambling ring was jailed for 90 days yesterday.

title: WALTER M. SHOHL, FORMER OHIO JUDGE
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 6Walter M. Shohl, a former judge of the Ohio Court of Appeals, died here last night at his home at the Queen City Club. His age was 84.

title: NIXON URGES END TO 2PARTY FIGHT OVER POLLUTION
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6President Nixon called today for an end to sterile discussions between Republicans and Democrats as to who really deserves the credit for discovering the issue of dealing with pollution.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
A U.S.SAIGON SPLIT DETECTED BY JAVITS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that the Saigon Govern ment's timetable for withdrawal of United States combat forces appeared to be a year and possibly two years longer than the Nixon Administration.

title: Supreme Court Stands Firm On Indiana Districting Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to withdraw its order permitting elections this year for the Indiana legislature to he conducted without redis tricting.

title: GARMENT FIGURE TERMED MAFIOSO
description: Natale Evola, a former con vict with financial interests in several garment and trucking companies, was described at a public hearing yesterday as a Mafia strong man in the gar ment center.

title: Newark School Conflict
description: NEWARK, Feb. 6Two years ago, a Governor's commission studying the 1967 riots in New Jersey concluded that the New ark public school system was in an advanced state of de cay and recommended that the state operate the system durine the educational crisis.

title: Bowery Project: Warm Bed and Another Chance
description: It was a sunny day, but the temperature was a raw 10 degrees, and the man named George who was sit ting on the steps of the Bouwerie Lane Theatre had no coat.

title: Art: The Humanism of Jacob Landau
description: JACOB LANDAU, a dedi cated American humanist and if you think that's easy, just try itis having an extensive exhibition at the Associated American Artists galleries, 663 Fifth Avenue, just below 53d Street. Identi cal exhibitions of these litho graphs and woodcuts are be ing held simultaneously at the Print Club of Philadelphia, Britton Fine Arts in San Francisco, the Giraffe Gal lery in Los Angeles, the Van Straaten Gallery in Chicago, and the Lunn Gallery in Washington. Here in New York, A.A.A. also has a group of Mr. Landau's watercolor studies for his series of 20 illustrations for E.T.A. Hoff man's The Kingdom of Dreams, which are the heart of the show.

title: SEALS' EARLY SURGE SETS BACK BLUES. 21
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6 (UPI) Nonn Ferguson's two goals within one minute in the first period gave the Oakland Seals a 21 triumph over the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: Pollution by Government
description: Hardly a week goes by that someone high in the Administration fails to pay his respects to the environ ment, which for political purposes is beginning to take on the combined attributes of flag and mother hood. The trouble with this admission of pure air and water into the pantheon of national symbols is that it becomes harder and harder for the public to tell whether the environment is being saved or only revered.

title: Julius Bendheim, 85, Headed Several Realty Concerns
description: Julius Bendheim, former head of several real estate com panies here, died of a stroke in his home at 911 Park Avenue on Thursday after a long ill ness. He was 85 years old.

title: INTERSTATE STORES REPORTS SALES GAIN
description: The Interstate Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday that fiveweek sales ended Feb. 1 rose 18.8 per cent to $42,415,500 from the year earlier $35,708,600. The figures do not include supermarket sales.

title: M.T.A. Will Run Field At Stewart Air Base
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Approval was granted today to the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority to oper ate the airfield at Stewart Air Force Base in Newburgh, N. Y.

title: Susan Gray Flynn Is Fiancee Of Capt. Stephen L. Gordon
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Flynn of Sands Point, L. I., and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Gray Flynn, to Capt. Stephen Law rence Gordon, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Gordon of Tenafly, N. T.

title: Hijacker Killed in Fight Aboard Chilean Airliner
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 6 (AP)Two students wanted to go to Cuba and hijacked a jet plane today to take them there. A few hours later one of them was killed by police bullets, and four persons who had taken part in a police plan to stop them were wounded.

title: Financier Buys 80Room Swiss Castle From the U.S.
description: Bernard Cornfeld, a former Philadelphia social worker who now heads the Genevabased Investors Overseas Services Corporation, has purchased for $500,000 an 18th century, 80 room Swiss castle that the United States had owned for seven years.

title: Illegal Political Contributions Get Ship Lines $50,000 Fine
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 (Reuters)Two large American shipping companies were fined $50,000 each in Federal Court today for making illegal politi cal contributions. The fines were the maximum under the law.

title: KENNAN SAYS ABM COULD PERIL TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 George F. Kennan, former Am bassador to Moscow, warned today that the United States could be jeopardizing talks with the Soviet Union on stra tegic arms control by plunging ahead with large new weap ons, such as a missile defense system.

title: Reprimand Given In Saigon Incident Of False Newsmen
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 (AP)The United States command announced today that the person who placed four agents in the Saigon press corps had been reprimanded and transferred to a new assign ment.

title: Market Summary
description: Friday, Feb. 6. 1970

title: CONTINENTAL BIDS FOR DINERS CLUB
description: The Continental Corporation, which owns 34 per cent of the outstanding shares of Diners Club, Inc., announced yesterday it planned to ac quire the rest through a tender offer at $15 a share.

title: JUDGE FAVORS SALE OF R. HOE UNIT NOW
description: Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan has concluded that the printing press division of R. Hoe & Co. should be sold or leased im mediately without awaiting a plan of reorganization for the company.

title: I.R.S. Asks Taxpayers To File Early Returns
description: Taxpayers were urged by the Internal Revenue Service yesterday to file their tax returns as soon as possible to avoid delays of refunds.

title: Psychoanalyst Doubts Schools Can Aid Addicts
description: Dr. Bruno Bettelheim assert ed yesterday that teachers could not do much about the spread of narcotics addiction in schools.

title: Gillette Executive's Will
description: DEDHAM, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) The will of Joseph P. Stang, former president and chairman of the board of Gillette Com pany, leaves almost $1million to his family. Mr. Stang, who died last December, left $500, 000 to his sister, Miss Marie F. Stang; $250,000 to his sons, Jo seph P. Stang 3d of Milton, Mass., and Thomas J. C. Stang of Manchester, Mass., and other amounts to other family mem bers.

title: Ardsley No. 2 Rink Advances In Cuthbertson Bonspiel
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 6 The Ardsley (N. Y.) Curling Club No. 2 rink, skipped by William Nolan, defeated the New York Caledonian Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Vernon Hambly, the 1968 winner, 136, tonight in the second round of the 15th annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: HAROLD L. NEUMAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6Har old L. Neuman, president for more than 25 years Of Robert Bruce, Inc., manufacturer of men's clothing, died here last night. He was 62 years old.

title: 8 YOUTHS IN BRONX SEIZED ON HEROIN
description: Seven high school students and another teenager were arrested yesterday outside Bronx high school on charges of possessing heroin.

title: Dartmouth Beats Princeton
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 6A pair of free throws by Gary Dicovitsky gave Dartmouth a 7065 lead with 1:16 to play to night and the Indians survived a Princeton press for a 7069 victory over the Tigers.

title: Veeck Races to the Rescue of Patriots
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)City and state officials, in an 11th hour effort to keep the Boston Patriots football team here, out lined a plan today to build a $16million football stadium with funds guaranteed by horse racing revenue.

title: Stage: Comedie Francaise's Dom Juan
Opera House in Derby Is Spared for 120 Days
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  A Cabinetlevel advisory board has recommended that the opera house at Derby, Conn., he spared from urban renewal bulldozers for 120 days while a crusading wo man develops a viable plan to restore the 19th century building.

title: NETS ARE VICTORS OVER CAPS, 114110
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 6 (UPI)Les Hunter and Ed. Johnson scored 27 points each in leading the New York Nets to a 114110 victory over the Washington Capitols to night in an American Basket ball Association game.

title: West Germans and Poles End First Round of Talks
description: Warsaw, Feb. 6 (AP)Polish and West German representa tives ended two days of talks today and agreed to meet again next month.

title: Japanese Rescue Greeks
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 7 (AP)A Japanese freighter res cued 18 Greek crew members of a Liberian freighter today after the Liberian vessel had sunk about 1,300 miles east of Japan, a United States military spokesman said. The survivors were in a life raft.

title: A.C.L.U. Asks Army to Free Men Under Invalid Induction
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has proposed to the Fed eral Government the release from the Army of all men in ducted under Selective Service delinquency regulations that were subseqently held Invalid by the Supreme Court.

title: GLAMOUR SHARES LEAD MARKET RISE
description: The stock market's favorite recurring hope  an easing of credit conditions in the nottoo distant future  provided a better tone to prices yesterday.

title: BILL WOULD LET CITY RENT VACANT UNITS
description: Assemblyman Stanley Stein gut, the minority leader, an nounced his sponsorship yester day of a bill to enable the city to take over apartments that are being held vacant by land lords who hope to convert them to offices.

title: GASTONA M. ROSSILLI, FASHION CONSULTANT
description: Gastona Marie Rossilli, who was a fashionbehavioral con sultant to department stores and the Fashion Institute, died Thursday in her home at 45 Christopher Street after an ill ness of several months.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1970

title: British Bill Discount Rises
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (Reuter) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury 91 day bills rose to 7.565 per cent from 7.510 per cent last week. This week's 100million offer met applications of 214,065, 000. Next week $80million bills will be offered replacing 100million of maturities. The offer is believed to be the smallest amount offered for a considerable time and re flects the Government's current money supply policy.

title: Suez, OnceBusy City, Now Wasteland
description: SUEZ, United Arab Repub lic, Feb. 6The voice of the imam appealing from the mosque to the survivors of Suez for fortitude and sacri fice echoed figuratively through the empty streets of the city.

title: Topics: The Middle East Still Time for Peace
description: It is conventional wisdom about the Middle East that (1) the super  powers share an interest in peace, but cannot control the states with which they are closely associated; (2) the absence of peace is the equal responsibility of Israel and its Arab neighbors; and (3) the United States has been proIsraeli, at the expense of broader national interests.

title: BANK AND BROKER ACCUSED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that the First National City Bank and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., had vio lated Federal securities laws by operating an unregistered in vestment company.

title: The Program
description: CHAMBER MUSIC SUCIFTY OF LINCOLN CENTER, with Isaac Stern and Pinchas Zukerman, violins; Walter Trampler, viola; Leonard A?? oboc; and Charles Wadsworth, piano. At Alice Tully Halt.

title: Dissidents Rally in Capital to. Protest Mine Union's Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Both the United Mine Workers of America and the Federal Government came under re newed, angry criticism today for what was described as pro longed, joint toleration of cor ruption, fear and violence among the nation's 200,000 coal miners.

title: Phyllis Teicher, Alvin J. Goldman Planning Bridal
description: Dean Morton I. Teicher of the Wurzweiler School of So cial Work at Yeshiva Uni versity and Mrs. Teicher of New York, formerly of New Rochelle, N. Y., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Margaret Teicher, to Alvin James Goldman. Mr. Gold man is the son of Mrs. Ber nard E. Rand of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and the late Mattis Y. Goldman, who was a builder and real estate man in Cleveland.

title: M.T.A. IS ASSAILED ON SUBWAY ROLE
description: Some critics of the city sub way system, testifying yester day at a legislative hearing on its efficiency, called for the dismissal of all of the members of the Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority, which runs the system. Others were will ing to settle for the resignation of its chairman, Dr. William J. Ronan.

title: Tough Dock Leader
description: ON Pier 8 at the foot of Congress Street in Brook lyn yesterday, the chill air hummed with the activity of heavy unloading. Against the stark backdrop of ships and the shadowy Manhattan sky line, longshoremen labored to shift big steel containers full of cargo. In a bar across the slushy street, a Mario Lanza rec ord was playing in the jukebox. Teamsters with American flags on their caps and longshoremen with baling hooks hanging from their back pockets drank and joked.

title: U.S. IS REPORTED READY TO PROVIDE ARMS FOR ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Nixon Administration has de cided to sell Israel new jet air craft and other war material she requested in the fall, high official quarters said today.

title: Of Morals and the Law
description: LONDON, Feb. 6  When twenty London policemen broke up a showing of Andy Warhol's Flesh, and seized the film, it was only the latest in a series of repressive incidents in this supposedly permissive society. The police have confiscated John Lennon's erotic litho graphs from an art gallery, har ried respectable printers and ar rested underground newspaper editors, all in the name of pub lic decency.

title: UTILITY CONCERN REPORTS DECLINE
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries re ported yesterday significant gains in sales of electricity and revenues for 1969 but a modest decline in earnings.

title: Suns Sink Warriors, 122117
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 6 (UPI)The Phoenix Suns hit on 42 of 55 shots from the freethrow line tonight to defeat the San Fran cisco Warriors, 122117. Paul Silas led the Suns' balanced at tack with 23 points.

title: Blockbusting Suit By Justice Agency Cites 14 Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  The Government today charged 14 real estate com panies in Memphis and Atlanta with practicing blockbusting in previously allwhite neighbor hoods.

title: Music: Strings Have It
description: THE emphasis was very much on strings last night in Tully Hall and, more specifically, on the violin. Or violins. An unusual program featuring mostly violin duets, and spiced with other string music, was brought together by the Chamber Music So ciety of Lincoln Center. Isaac Stern and Pinchas Zukerman were the heroes of the eve nine, but Charles Wadsworth, Leonard Arner and Walter Trampler lent notable as sistance.

title: Trip Planned To Waldemar
description: In preparation for its 1970 gala, the Million Dollar Ex travaganza, to be held at the WaldorfAstoria on May 4, the benefit committee for the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation will participate in a Million Dollar, Viaggetto (a little voyage) to foundation headquarters in Woodbury, L. I., on Tuesday. There, com mittee members will tour the laboratories to see the scien tific research made possible by their fundraising efforts.

title: BAN ON 8 PESTICIDES PROPOSED BY NELSON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Senator Gaylord Nelson, Demo crat of Wisconsin, introduced today a bill to outlaw eight longlived insecticides, includ ing one pest killer that has been called deadlier than DDT.

title: Cruises Help the Atlantic Lines To Reverse YearsLong Slump
description: Atlantic passenger lines, with a powerful assist from cruises, appears to have arrested their yearslong slump.

title: Bank Americards Increase
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 (AP)  Worldwide sales on BankAmericards exceeded the $2billion level last year, a 146 per cent increase from the pre ceding year, the Bank of Amer ica said today billings more than doubled the $814million posted in 1968, while the num ber of cardholders rose to 29.5 million.

title: Halliburton Sales and Earnings Set Records in '69 and Quarter
description: Revenues and earnings of the Halliburton Company set rec ords in the fourth quarter and all 1969, L. B. Meaders, presi dent, reported yesterday from Dallas. Revenues exceeded $1 billion for the first time.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: PROSECUTORS PLAN JOINT EFFORT HERE
description: The three United States At torneys for the Eastern and Southern Districts of New York and for New Jersey met yester day and discussed how to co ordinate their fight against or ganized crime in the metropoli tan area.

title: Lindsay Acts to Divest H. R. A. Of Its Power to Make Payments
description: Mayor Lindsay moved yester day to take away some of the payment powers of the Human Resources Administration, the target of Federal criticism of fiscal mismanagement. Several indictments and convictions for mishandling of funds have been obtained against employe of the superagency.

title: Masseur Keeps Ellis's Corner From Getting Uptight
description: He seldom speaks, and then only in Spanish, but Luis Sarria doesn't have to. He communicates in other ways.

title: Mrs. Nixon Flies to Florida
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon flew to Key Biscayne, Fla., tonight to he with her daughter Tricia, who is recovering from the measles. Mrs. Nixon flew to the Florida White House aboard a military plane less than an hour after arriving in Washing ton with the President from their twoday trip to the Middle West.

title: The McGoverns' House Isn't Too Old, but It's Set in Its Ways
description: WASHINGTONSenator George S. Mc Govern, the South Dakota Democrat and his wife, Eleanor, bought their $115,000 home fully furnished last June, and, since then, Mrs. McGovern has been rearranging the furniture. But no matter how she does it, the pieces always seem to end up just as they were in June.

title: High Court Asked To Upset an Edict Easing Abortions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI)  The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today) to overturn a Federal judge's ruling that a District of Colum8 bia law was unconstitutional because it permits abortions only when the mother's life or health is in danger.

title: Syracuse Tuition to Rise
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 6 (AP) Syracuse University announced today a $200 increase in under graduate tuition fees to take effect at the end of the current semester. The present tuition is $2,100 a year.

title: Norwalk Mayor Named
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 6 (UPI) Mayor Frank N. Zullo of Nor walk has been appointed by Goy. John N. Dempsey as a member of the TriState Trans portation Commission. The commission operates under a compact among Connecticut, New York and New Jersey for continuing study of transpor tation and related land use.

title: POSTAL COMPLEX RULED OUT HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 6 A major post office project originally planned for New York City was shifted today to Jersey City.

title: WrongCar Caper, Or a Lesson in How To Botch a Holdup
description: An unemployed cook with a coasttocoast record of arrests jumped in the wrong car the other night after allegedly rob bing a cab driver.

title: L.I.R.R. DISRUPTED BY UNION PROTEST
description: Homebound service out of Brooklyn on the Long Island Rail Road was briefly disrupted last night when the line defied a union threat and used super visors to man a train whose crewmen had been abused by riders Thursday.

title: MISSISSIPPI CAPITAL INTEGRATES SCHOOLS
description: Mississippi's largest school district, in Jackson, the state capital, peacefully integrated its 55 schools yesterday while Gov. John Bell Williams and three other Southern Gover nors laid plans for a strategy session aimed to stem federally ordered desegregation.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION DECLINES IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) Shutdowns at 14 of the Big Three auto makers' assembly plants across the country idled more than 50,000 workers and slowed auto production this week.

title: Brimmer Advocates States End Bond Rate Ceilings
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6An drew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, warned state and local govern ments today not to put off the necessary step of removing legal ceilings on bond interest rates in the hope that market interest rates would decline.

title: $615,000 Settlement Made In Death of Jack Flynn
description: The widow of Jack F. A Flynn, national sales manager of television station WPIX, re ceived a $615,000 settlement yesterday for the death of her husband in the crash of an American Airlines jet at Cin cinnati on Nov. 8, 1965.

title: Abe Attell Is Dead at 85
description: Abe Attell, who held the world featherweight title from 1901 to 1912 and was elected to Boxing's Hall of Fame in 1955, died yesterday at the age of 85. Obituary is on Page 29.

title: Friedman and Okun Differ on Length of Downturn
description: Two of the nation's leading economists agreed yesterday that business activity is defi nitely slowing down, but they differed about the shape of things to come.

title: Knights of the Road?
description: Caught, they say, in a cost squeeze, American truck ers are gearing up for another attempt to push, through Congress legislation that would permit wider, longer and heavier trucks on the nation's interstate high ways. No motorist who has been caught in another kind of squeezebetween a pair of the currentsize behemothscan view that prospect with equanimity.

title: JOHN L. HARKINS
description: John L. Harkins, a paper handier for The New York Times for 15 years, died Thurs day of pneumonia and a heart attack at Freeport (L.I.) Hos pital. He was 47 years old and lived at 114.58 114th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: TWO OF CHICAGO 7 DON BLACK ROBES
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6Two de fendants showed up at the Chi cago conspiracy trial this morn ing wearing black judicial robes, but soon afterward Judge Julius J. Hoffman ruled that they and the five other men at the defense table were just defendants.

title: PLAY BY SHAFFER OPENS IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Feb. 6  Peter Shaffer is one of the small band of British playwrights who be lieve that the entertainment play is a form robust enough to carry weightier issues. This certainly brought him popular success with The Royal Hunt of the Sun. And perhaps it will do so again with his new play, The Battle of Shrivings, at the Lyric Theater.

title: 2 Convicted of Destroying Dow Chemical Property
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)  Two of nine defendants were found guilty today of willfully destroying Dow Chemical Corn pany property in an antiwar demonstration. They were con victed after they pleaded no contest to one charge against them.

title: ROBERTSON IS OUT OF ROYAL LINEUP
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 6A vivid example of how much Oscar Robertson means to the Cin cinnati Royals was presented tonight at Cincinnati Gardens, where the New York Knicker bockers took advantage of the Big O's absence to run up 13592 victory over the Royals.

title: TV Licensing Picture
description: In the last few years a glimmer of hope has flashed across the television screen.
