That hope has taken the form of challenges by citizen, church and business groups to replace the franchises held by federally licensed stations that have failed in their obligation to present public service programs.

title: BANKERS OPPOSE HOUSE MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The American Bankers Associa tion announced its opposition today not only, to the version of the onebank holding com pany bill that passed the House of Representatives, but also to any further action on such legislation until a basic study is made of the nation's entire financial system.

title: British Soccer Player Is Sold for $264,000
description: DERBY, England, Feb. 6 (AP)Terry Hennessey was sold by the Nottingham Forest team to Derby County today for a reported $264, 000, the highest transfer fee for a defensive player in British soccer history.

title: Lindsay Appoints A Puerto Rican To Housing Panel
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced the appointment of Aramis Gomez as a member of the New York Housing Authority. Mr. Gomez will re place Roger W. Flood, who will retire from the threemember authority on March 16.

title: James Going Through Motions Until Races Turn Him On Again
description: It is the low ebb of winter, the low ebb between Olym pics, and Larry James has lost the feeling.

title: House of Leather to Open
description: The House of Leather, a rock musical set in New Or leans during the Civil War, will open March 16 at the Ellen Stewart Theater, 240 East Third Street, instead of the Brooklyn Academy of Music as originally announced.

title: PRICES SHOW GAIN FOR SOYBEAN MEAL
description: Because of renewed demand for soybean meal by poultry and livestock producers, fu tures prices of that commodity closed strong yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Army to Replace Marines In Northern South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 (AP)  In a move pos sibly foreshadowing the with drawal of all remaining United States Marine forces in South Vietnam, the United States command announced today that the United States Army would assume overall com mand from the Marines on March 9 in the five northern provinces.

title: Common Market and Yugoslavia Agree On 3Year Trade Treaty
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 6  Yugo slavia and the European Eco nomic Community today con cluded a threeyear nonprefer ential, nondiscriminatory trade agreement, the Common Mar ket's first commercial treaty with an Eastern European country.

title: Acadia Tops Brandeis Five
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP)Acadia's basketball team defeated Brandeis, 6659, to day. Steve Pound was high scorer for Acadia with 25 points. Tom August led the Judges with 19.

title: Yale Subdues Cornell
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 6John Whiston, a 6foot9inch center, scored 26 points, his high for the season, tonight lifting Yale to victory over Cornell, 8264, in an Ivy League battle.

title: Johnson Says Tet Victory Led to His '68 Peace Move
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6In a rambling but at times fer vent conversational memoir, former President Lyndon Johnson offered today his version of the events two years ago that led to an end of the American troop buildup in Vietnam, a partial halt in the bombing of North Viet nam and his decision not to run for reelection.

title: U.S.Latin Panel Formed To Negotiate Trade Issues
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 6  A new interAmerican ne gotiating unit was created here today in which the United States can be called to account for restricting the entry of Latin American goods into its market.

title: LIST EDGES AHEAD IN AMEX TRADING
description: Advances narrowly topped declines on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the list moved ahead in quiet trading.

title: Standing Pat on Education
description: President Nixon has promised to take a new and searching look at American education, but his 1971 budget offers only slender clues to the meaning of that pledge. The one certainty is that whatever new action is to be proposed will have to be carried out without additional funds. Education is confronted with a standpat budget.

title: NEW ISSUES SLIP IN LIGHT TRADING
description: The newissue market slipped into the doldrums this week. Fewer companies made initial public offerings of their stock, prices declined and trading ac tivity remained light.

title: WELFARE COOPS ASKED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  New York City welfare officials, complaining that relief recipients are forced to pay high rents for the dregs of the city's shrinking housing sup ply, clan to ask the Legislature for permission to finance co operative housing.

title: Charles L. Terry Jr. Is Dead; ExDelaware Governor Was 69
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 6Charles L. Terry Jr., Governor of Dela ware from 1965 to 1969, and former Chief Justice of the Delaware Supreme Court, died here today, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 69.

title: GOLDBERG PRESSED TO RUN FOR OFFICE
description: Democratic supporters of Ar thur J. Goldberg for the party's nomination for Governor have intensified their efforts to per suade him to run.

title: President Resigns From PhilcoFord
description: The third president of the PhilcoFord Corporation in the eight years since the Ford Motor Company took over Philco resigned yesterday. He is Robert E. Hunter and he served as both chairman and president of PhilcoFord and vice president of the parent Ford Motor Company. He severed all ties with the two concerns in a terse letter of resignation.

title: Phone Operator Host to Critics
description: The chief operator at an uptown branch of the New York Telephone Company, troubled by recent complaints and jokes about telephone service, on her own initiative invited unhappy customers to visit her operators yesterday for a firsthand report.

title: Reputed Mobster Is Shot To Death in Rhode Island
description: CRANSTON, R.I., Feb. 6 (AP) Louis J. Taglianetti, said by the police to be an underworld figure, and a woman com panion were found shot to death tonight at the bottom of a flight of steps leading to Broad Street apartment house.

title: CHARLES A. RACHT
description: Charles A. Racht, regional manager of the six Florida offices of Shearson, Hammill & Co., Inc., brokers and invest ment bankers, died Thursday after a short illness in Sara sota, Fla., where he lived. He was 41 years old.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Rockefeller Family Divorce
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 6 (AP)Mrs. Anne Bartley Papa, the stepdaughter of Gov. Win throp Rockefeller, Republican of Arkansas, was granted a di vorce yesterday from Salvatore Papa of New York.

title: Conviction of Queens Man On Draft Evasion Set Aside
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ordered a new trial yesterday for a Queens man who was convicted of draft evasion two years ago.

title: ANN CONVERSE BACKUS
description: Ann Converse Backus, a Uni Wersity of Wisconsin junior and graduate of Brearley School here, died Wednesday in Madi son, Wis., as a result of an au tomobile accident. She was 20 years old and lived at 1158 Fifth Avenue and Sands Point, L. I.

title: LAGOS RELIEF SEEN AT TURNING POINT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb.6 In formed sources in the State Department said today that the Nigerian effort to relieve mal nutrition in the former enclave of Biafra had reached a crit ical turning point.

title: PALMER SCOTT
description: SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 6Palmer Scott, founder of the Palmer Scott Com pany, Inc., boat builders, died Wednesday in Grenada, the West Lndies, where he was va cationing. He was 72 years old and lived on Jordan Road here.

title: Miss Susanne Rheault Betrothed
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. Miss Susanne Rheault, whose father, Col. Robert B. Rheault, retired in October as the commander of Special Forces (Green Berets) in Viet nam, plans to be married in June to John Anderson Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Brown of Wayne, Pa., and Bay Head. N. J. The future bride is the daughter also of Mrs. Rheault of Brookline and Martha's Vine yard, Mass.

title: Tennis Dispute Flares Anew Over Structure for Opens
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 6An other war seemed imminent in American tennis today when the United States Lawn Tennis Association and the two pro fessional organizations rejected contracts for the 1970 season.

title: HIGH RATES SPUR REFUNDING BY U.S.
description: The Federal Government by offering the highest interest rates in more than a century persuaded public holders of 85 per cent of $5.57billion of maturing bonds to exchange them for new notes yielding 8 per cent or more.

title: Moscow Calls for Urgent Moves to Curb Israelis
description: MOSCOW. Feb. 6  The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia called on all peace ioving countries today to take the most urgent measures to end what it called Israel's military escalation against the United Arab Republic and other Arab states.

title: MRS. E. R. M'CARTHY, EXY.W.C.A. OFFICIAL
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6Mrs. Eu gene R. McCarthy, a former national and international offi cial of the Young Women's Christian Association, died in her sleep at her home here last night. She was 81 years old.

title: Expatriate Composers in Rome Using Audiences as Instrument
description: ROME, Feb. 6The audience is the instrument of a group of young American composers who have been honing their collective,, electronic techniques here for three threadbare years and are now headed, somewhat nervously, for a New York de but and an American tour.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To End Job Bias

title: Stage: Play It Again, Sam Revisited
description: YOU might have imagined which is a critic's sly way of saying I myself imagined that Woody Allen's Play It. Again, Sam was a vehicle with only a single trip ticket. Mr. Allen wrote about Mr. Allen for Mr. Allen. So how can the nonreal Woody Allen stand up?

title: Pacers Top Colonels, 102100
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 6 (AP)  Bob Netolicky's four free throws in the final 30 seconds of play gave Indiana a 102100 American Basketball Associa tion victory over the Kentucky Colonels tonight and broke the Pacers' twogame losing streak.

title: Liberian Ship Is Reported Sinking in Western Pacific
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 (AP)The Liberian flag freight er Antonios Demades was re ported sinking today 780 miles east of Japan as a Coast Guard cutter sped to the rescue.

title: Bucks Beat Lakers, 118105
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. (UPI)The Milwaukee Bucks, with Jon McGlocklin leading the way, broke open a close contest by outscoring Los An geles, 165, in the last four minutes of the third quarter to night and scored a 118105 tri umph over the Lakers. Mc Glocklin scored 27 points while Lew Alcindor was high with 29.

title: Celtics' Spree Tops Sonics
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP)John Havlicek scored 8 of his 39 points within a threeminute span in the final period tonight to help the Boston Celtics post a 127117 victory over the Seattle Supersonics.

title: 2 Charged in Death Of 3 Boys in Fire
description: A Bronx landlord and a for mer tenant in his building were indicted yesterday for the mur der of three boys, two of whom they were said to have hired to start a fire in the structure.

title: Russian Orthodox Church Gives Independence to Branch in U.S.
description: The Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church of America, the largest of three Russian Orthodox groups in the United States, announced yesterday that Russian church officials in Moscow had agreed to acknowl edge its independence.

title: Thieu Opponent in Saigon Feels Betrayed by U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 7Tran Ngoc Chau, an Opposition deputy ac cused by President Nguyen Van Thieu of Communist affilia tions, says he feels he has been betrayed by the America mis sion here despite a long and close working relationship.

title: AIDE BACKS NIX ON SERVICE ROLE
description: Richard N. Hughes, vice president of WPIXTV, Channel 11, defended the public and community service records of his station in a speech to the City Club of New York yes terday. WPIX broadcast license is currently being challenged.

title: Clarke Laps Field in Taking 3Mile Race at Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP)Ron Clarke lapped the field in winning the threemile run last night, but failed in his attempt to regain the world indoor record at the Athens invitation trackandfield meet.

title: FEATS AS MANAGER WILL BE SALUTED
description: The New York Yankees an nounced yesterday that they would revive some matchless echoes of their past this sum mer when Casey Stengel re turns as the guest of honor at the annual oldtimers' reunion.

title: New Products
description: FEATURING a swiveltype rotating mount that en ables it to rotate through 360 degrees and tilt in any direction up to 90 degrees, the versatile vise pictured at left (in two styles) is actually part of a whole system that includes various types of mountings, as well as a wide assortment of different holding acces sories. The newest addition is the vacuum base illus trated at the top. With this base, the vise can be locked onto any smooth, nonporous surface by simply flipping a lever.

title: COAST UNIT WARNS ON URBANIZATION
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 7 A special study council cre ated by the California Legisla ture has submitted a pessimistic deport on the status of the California environment and has proposed steps to correct the problems.

title: The unsung little war that was fought in the Aleutians
description: Along the thousandmile stretch from Dutch Harbor on Unalaska Island to forlorn Attu, the United States fought its most unpublicized campaign of World War II. The air, sea and ground battles that took place in the Aleutians over a period of 15 months in 194243 were the only engagements waged on North American soil; yet how many of us have heard of the Battle of the Komondorskis, the airraids on Paramushiro or Operation Landcrab?

title: FARM PLAN REACHED BY COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 (AP)The Common Market countries gave their approval today to a pack age plan to aid farmers that the French Government had insist ed on before it would discuss British entry. Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann of France emerged after 21 hours of nearly continuous meetings and said:

title: Keller Leads 3 Japanese In Speed Skating Meet
description: INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 7 AP)Erhard Keller of West Germany led the field in an in ternational speedskating meet today. Japanese skaters occu pied the next three places.

title: CHARTER OAK BRIDGE PAYS $30 IN VICTORY
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Feb. 7 (AP)Charter Oak Bridge, a 141 shot in a field of seven, raced to an easy victory in the $7,500 Roger Williams Handicap today.

title: Tickets on Sale Here For Feb. 20 Track Meet
description: Reserved scats for the sec ond edition of the Olympic invitation track meet at Mad ison Square Garden Feb. 20 are now on sale at the Gar den box office and at the of fice of the New York Olym pic Committee, Suite 1818, Hotel Warwick, 65 West 54th Street.

title: Cuba Buys Spanish Cider
description: MADRID, Feb. 7 (Reuters) The Cohan Government., which last October announced an austerity campaign to last until July of this year, has signed a contract to buy 85,000 case, of Spanish champagne cider.

title: Headliners
description: No Soap

title: 53 JUDGES HEADED BY MISS NICHOLAS
After Nothing Less Than Emotional Profundity
description: THEODOROS STAMOS, 18 of whose new paint ings are now at the Emmerich Gallery, ar rived on the New York scene earlier and made a bigger splash than did most of the SecondGeneration Abstract Expressionists in whose ranks he is perhaps incor rectly numbered. He first showed with Betty Par sons in 1943 at the then incredibly tender age of 22 and soon earned a reputation as a prodigy, the whizkid of the new American painting. It was a reputation that did not stand him in good stead later with serious critics, who were compelled to observe that the Master's smock for which he had been fitted con tinued to be several sizes too large. Not that his talent Dame to be neglected ex actlyin a decade, the 60's, that brought lean times to a number of gifted Second Gen eration artists, Stamos showed regularly at the ritzy Emmerich  but the sort of critical ennui that followed his overly sanguine early notices has persisted to the present, leaving the true character of his work mostly.

title: RHODESIA LIMITS REPORTS ON RAID
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7  The Government reported this week that 12 of the na tionalist guerrillas who invaded Rhodesia from Zambia early last month had been killed, one of them while trying to escape.

title: Henry Disston Jr. Plans To Wed Miss Ellen Lea
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Lippin cott O'Neil of Chestnut Hill have announced the engage ment of Mrs. O'Neil's daugh ter, Miss Ellen Elizabeth Lea, to Henry Disston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Disston 2d, also of Chestnut Hill.

title: FITZ GIBBON GAINS IN EASTERN TENNIS
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 7 Herb Fitz Gibbon, the top seeded player, met unexpected opposition tonight before ad vancing to the third round of the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship.

title: Alabama Negroes Score Changes in State's Democratic Party,
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 7 The predominantly Negro Na tional Democratic party of Ala bama denounced today the re organization of the state's reg ular Democratic party to allow Negro participation.

title: Gardens
description: SOME plants have the language of love in their name. While thumbing through seed and plant catalogues, gardeners will find many. Seed packets or plants might be used for a special Valentine remembrance this weekend.

title: Chess
description: THE Rev. William James Lombardy of St. Mary's Church, the Bronx, a chess grandmaster, captured the world junior championship some 13 years ago at Toronto. Ever since, he is justly feared when he finds time to compete in national and interna tional arenas. His triumphs, too numerous to detail, include the grand master accolade granted by the Inter national Chess Federation (F.I.D.E.) in 1960. At about the same time, he attained a 92% score on first board of the victorious American world students team in Leningrad.

title: COAST'S CHURCHES FACE FISCAL WOES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 The Episcopal Diocese covering California's northern coastal area is facing serious financial problems that threaten to cur tail some of its activities.

title: Croats Venerate Cardinal Steninac Without Official Interference as YugoslavVatican Relations Ease
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia  Tall candles flicker day and night around the tomb of Aloysiusl Cardinal Stepinac behind thei main altar of the ancient fort resscathedral here, the strong hold and spiritual center of Croatia's powerful Roman Ca tholicism.

title: Mrs. Meir Says Air Raids Show Nasser Is a Failure
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 6Premier Golda Meir said today that Israeli air raids deep inside the United Arab Republic had brought the war home to President Gamal Abdel Nasser and had exposed him to his people as a failure.

title: Victoria Arend, Carl Johnson 3d To Be Married
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7The en gagement of Miss Victoria Anne Arend to M. Carl John son 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson. Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by Mrs. Peter Gerald Arend, mother of the future bride.

title: Madrid's El Rastro Steals the Show As Bargain Center
description: MADRIDThey call it El Rastro, the junk or flea market. Its six teeming blocks are littered with some of the world's most expendable ob jects: old shoes and antiques, statuary and used eyeglasses, illuminated manuscripts and wornout tires. What lures the shopper  native and tourist alikeis the chance of a special bargain.

title: '69 Cargoes Down 14.5% On St. Lawrence Seaway
description: CLEVELAND, Feb., 7 (AP) Cargo tonnage moved on the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1969 dropped 14.5 per cent to 41 million net tons, compared with 47,953,850 tons the previous year.

title: Coins
description: WITH St. Valentine's Day coming up next Saturday, it is only fitting that collect ors this week pay respects to some of the many numismat ic sweethearts that have been portrayed on the world's coinage.

title: Police Surprise Vandals In Philadelphia Draft Office
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) Eight vandals were surprised early today as they were de stroying records in a draft board office here, the police said, but only two were appre hended.

title: Roscoe Karns, Actor, Dies at 77; TV Navy Doctor in Hennesey
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (AP) Roscoe Karns, the stage, movie and television actor, died at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. He was 77 years old, and had been hospitalized for over a month.

title: Too much and not enough
description: This is a disappointing book. It is, to begin with, much too big. It takes Voltaire from his birth in 1694 through his early training, his English visit in the late 1720's, his life with his mistress, Madame du Chtelet, in the 1730's and 1740's, and ends rather diffusely with Vol taire the philosopher, with his final positions settled in the 1750's. In its stately prog ress, Ira O. Wade's book takes up many matters on the way Voltaire's literary training, his relation to 17thcentury think ers, his techniques of clandes tine publishingand seeks to exhaust them all. Searching for the true Voltaire, it traverses many beaten paths, summarizes much available literature, and spares itself, and its readers, no detail.

title: STANLEY R. GREENE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 7Stanley R. Greene, former executive vice president of Bel lows & Co., died at the New Rochelle Hospital today of heart ailment. He was 79 years old and lived at 50 Kane Avenue, Larchmont.

title: Sees Corporate Mergers As Causing More Crime
description: The Harvard Business Re view concluded not too long ago that mergers and acqui sitionswhen they are well conceived and well executed remain one of the most expeditious means of corpo rate growth and equity en hancement.

title: Israelis Jail a Barber For Shaving Guerrillas
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 (Reu ters)An Arab barber has been sentenced to one year's imprisonment on a charge of aiding and abetting Al Fatah guerrillas by shaving them and cutting their hair.

title: LANDRUMGRIFFIN IS AGAIN AT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 7A Federal law that organized labor denounced as antiunion when it was passed 10 years ago is becoming the focus of what may be another strenuous pe riod of labor reform efforts in Congress and the courts.

title: Moffo Recital Canceled
description: The recital to have been given by Anna Moffo at Car negie Hall next Saturday night, Feb. 14, has been canceled. Miss Moffo is ill with influenza in Italy. The advertisement for the program that appears today on Page 16 of Section 2 of The New York Times and the listing of the event in Who Makes Music and Where on Page 18 of the same section were print ed before the cancellation was announced.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: How Pointless It All Seems Now
description: COMING down the road from Okigwi, we were stopped at an army roadblock a few miles from Owerri. As always, there were refugees hoping for a lift. But this time there seemed to be some thing special about one family, not just pathetic but urgent. The soldiers asked us to take them. The mother, very pregnant, fell to her knees at the side of the car and prayed for ride. She and her husband and the two tiny children got in.

title: To shake educational reality loose from its fictions
description: To a very great degree, school is a place where children learn to be stupidJohn Holt.

title: City's Schools Plan Fight on Drug Use
description: Mayor Lindsay, deciaring that the schools were the training ground for the next generation of addicts, said yes terday that the city would in stitute drugeducation programs in every affected school.

title: The Theater: Dom Juan
Mary E. Lashley Is Engaged
description: ALBANY, Ga., Feb. 7 Miss Mary Elizabeth Lashley and E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barcella of Bethesda, Md., will be married here March 21. The future bridegroom's father is manager of public relations for General Motors in Wash ington.

title: From the Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: The Ashe Case

title: They Volunteered and Found Their Unpaid Job Pointing to a Paying Career
description: IT doesn't happen often. But working as a volunteer can lead to a paying job, and there are a number of people around, ranging from a graduate of Mount Holyoke to former relief recipient, to prove it. They started volunteer work with no other goal, than to give their services, but later, social service agencies asked to to assume respon sibilities and a schedule that rated a paycheck.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Speaking of Books: Creative Dissertating
description: The revolting Japanese author Ken zaburo O says it is his favorite book; James Joyce drew extensively on it for the fluvial imagery of Fin negans Wake; Ernest Hemingway saidand there are few Americans who would disagree with himthat all American literature is derived from it. The book of course is Huck leberry Finn.

title: Freight Gains For Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)The nation's scheduled airlines carried 10.6 per cent more air cargo on domestic routes in 1969 than in 1968 for a new record, the Air Transport Association re ports.

title: BOWIE STAKE WON BY WEEKEND FUN
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 7 (UPI) Weekend Fun, ridden by George Cusimano, rallied from off the pace today at Bowie to score an upset in the fourth running of the $29,450 Patricia A. Stakes before 19.215 fans.

title: U.S.O. Office Is Moved
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Feb. 7 (AP)The New England region al office of the U.S.O. has moved from Boston to Man chester.

title: YUEN AND WEVURSKI WIN K. OF C. EVENTS
description: Andy Yuen of the Southern California Striders upset Al Hall, the National champion and Olympic team member, in the 35pound weight throw yes terday as the 51st annual Knights of Columbus meet was completed with two field events.

title: Governor Asks New DayCare Center Funds
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7Governor Rockefeller announced today a series of legislative proposals designed to more than double the amount of mortgage money for daycare centers and to help neighborhood groups open them so that welfare mothers can be freed for work.

title: UNIONS ARE URGED TO UPGRADE JOBS
description: A study of worker opportun ities in 11 major industries has warned of danger signs requiring a call for more effort in upgrading jobs. It suggests skills advancement as a new goal for labor unions needing to eliminate worker discontent.

title: KELLY PAIR LEADS IN ASTROJET GOLF
description: PHOENIX, Feb. 7Mickey Mantle and Joe Namath are such an attraction in the fourth annual $30,000 American Air lines Astrojet Golf Classic, the miniskirted darlings don't even care what they are shooting on the golf course.

title: Fund Manager Worries Successfully
description: The 230lb, 24year old fi nancial tycoon shifts his bulk in the chair as the mar ket ends its daylong gyra tions with a whimper.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: MIAMI BEACH  There is a new era opening up in the women's and children's coat and suit industry, ac cording to Samuel Sandhaus, newly elected chairman of the National Board of the Coat and Suit Industry.

title: IRELAND REVISING UNIFICATION VIEWS
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 6  The con tinuing political and religious strife in Northern Ireland and the British intervention there have forced the Republic of Ireland to redefine its attitudes toward ending the partition of the country.

title: Weslevare's President Resigns to Run for Senate
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 7 Edwin D. Etherington, a for mer president of the American Stock Exchange, resigned to day as president of Wesleyan University to become a Repub lican candidate for the United States Senate from Connecti cut.

title: Miss Victoria Cobb Is Married In Mt. Kisco to Ian Mackintosh
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y. Feb. 7 Miss Victoria Cobb, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ives Cobb Jr., was married here today to Ian Mackintosh who is with the Paris office of White, Weld & Co., the in vestment bankers.

title: Soviet Photo Exhibit Opens In Washington on Feb. 17
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Soviet Union will send 1,400 photographs on a sevenmonth, sixcity tour of the United States beginning Feb. 17, the Novosti press agency announc ed today.

title: JASPERS' TRIUMPH 14TH OF CAMPAIGN
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 Manhattan, led by Henry Sea wright's 23 points, defeated Navy in basketball, 7757, at the loser's field house today before a crowd of 2,412 fans.

title: More Unemployed
description: Signs that the Nixon Adminis tration's effort to slow the econ omy was meeting with some success turned up last week in the form of the biggest monthly increase in unemployment figures in nearly a decade.

title: HOG CHOLERA COSTS UP $4MILLION IN '69
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Federal and state indemnities paid to farmers under coopera tive hog cholera control pro grams last year nearly tripled from that of 1968 because of the most outbreaks of the dis ease since the eradication cam pain began eight years ago.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: PRO BASKETBALL TO RESUME TALKS
U.S. Sues for Suspension Of Coast Charter Flight
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (AP) Hundreds of Californians who have signed up for char ter flights to beat the high cost of getting from the West Coast to Europe now find their travel plans shaky.

title: Urban Rat Race Affects Rats, Too, A Scientist Finds
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7 (AP) A scientist at the University of Pittsburgh has been putting rats through the simulated rigors of city life for the last 11 years in an effort to determine if noise and bright lights affect the health of people.

title: ABM: Weapon in Search of A Mission
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps through an accidental political launch by the President, the Ad ministration has provoked an other bruising, divisive ABM de bate in the Senate with a deci sion to expand the controversial Safeguard antiballistic missile de fense system.

title: Karen A. Shoemaker Is Bride Of Richard Fitzgerald, Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Miss Karen Ann Shoemaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry M. Shoemaker of Tam pa, Fla., formerly of Summit, N. J., was married at the Navy Chapel here today to Richard Victor Fitzgerald, a lawyer with the Controller of the Currency here.

title: Bill Asks Doctors' Earnings
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)  A bill to require public re lease of the names of physi cians and others earning more than $10,000 a year from Medi care and Medicaid programs was introduced in the Senate this week by Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Demncrat of New Maxico.

title: 9 Flee Jail Here
description: An accused bank robber, in jured in a fall and abandoned by eight otherprisoners in an escape from the Federal House of Detention here, was seized in a parked truck yesterday a half block from the prison on the western edge of Greenwich Village.

title: PREMIER IN ITALY AND CABINET QUIT
description: ROME, Sept. 7  Premier Mariano Rumor and his Chris tian Democratic minority cabi net resigned today in an at tempt to force former center left coalition allies to rejoin the Government or face new elec tions.

title: RAWBURN PRESHET NAMED BEST BITCH
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Freed man's Ch. Bayside Doubloon from Boxford, Mass., reasserted his right to rank with the coun try's top members of the breed yesterday by becoming best of breed in the annual preWest minster specialty of the Bulldog Club of America.

title: Robert C. Weiss Becomes Fiance Of Miss Phelps
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7Mr. and Mrs. William Walter Phelps Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosamond Lea Phelps, to Robert Charles Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Weiss of Sewickley.

title: Halt in Tooth Decay In 70's Is Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  A study group of the National In stitute of Dental Research is working toward the goal of vir tually eliminating tooth decay in the United States.

title: The Purification
description: February was named for Februarius, a midmonth feast of purification among the ancient Romans. There are those who say that the whole month now is not too long a time for cleansing and clarifying a man's thinking, if not about man's estate at least about the world around him and his own predicament here.

title: Art
description: EVERYTHING considered, I think that we would be happier thinking of the Siqueiros semisretro spective at the Center for InterAmerican Relations as a friendly, even placatory, gesture than we are going to be by giving it the works as an art exhibition. At the age of seventyfour, Mr. Siqueiros is an artist considerable stature, flamboyant stance, and spectacular though disturbingly mixed record. But in this group of thirtythree paintings from two collections (those of Dr. Alvar Carrillo Gil of Mexico City and Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Mitchell of New York) the stature is much reduced, the flamboyance a bit lumpy, and the record invisible.

title: Sludge Emergency Declared by Cahill; U.S. to Send Tugs
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7 (AP)Gov. William T. Cahill signed a dec laration of a state of emer gency in New Jersey tonight SO huge sludge accumulations at the state's sewage treatmen plants might be disposed at sea.

title: Ana Silva a Bride
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 7 Miss Ana Silva and Lieut. Dudley Lawrence Bauerlein Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bauerlein of Brookline, Mass., were married here this afternoon in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Cath olic Church by the Rev. John W. Finn. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felipe Silva of Paramus, is an alumna of Newton Mass. College of the Sacred Heart. Hetfather is export manager for the American Tobacco Company of New York. Lieu tenant Bauerlein was gradu ated from Boston College. He is stationed at Fort George G. Meade, Md.

title: Shortage of Manpower Slows Investigation of Crime in New Jersey
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7The three Federal grand juries that have indicted about 75 municipal officials, gamblers and under world figures here recently are continuing their investigation of organized crime, but at a slower pace.

title: BURNS PROMISES TO DO ALL HE CAN TO BAR RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Arthur F. Burns, the new chair man of the Federal Reserve Board, declined today to give any clue as to when and by how much the Federal Reserve would relax its extremely, re strictive monetary policy. But he pledged to do everything in my power to help this coun try, prevent a recession.

title: DEAD SEA RISING AT HARBOR MOUTH
description: Dumping millions of tons of sewage sludge and dredging spoils just south of the Am brose Light has created a dead sea that is spreading toward New York and New Jersey beaches, according to a report by the United States Marine Laboratory at Sandy Hook.

title: Spain Seeks Belgian Fascist
description: MADRID, Feb. 7 (AP)A na tionwide search for Leon De grelle, a Belgian who collabo rated with the Nazis in World War II, has been unsuccessful so far, informed sources re ported today. According to the sources, an arrest order for the 63yearold former Fascist lead er was issued yesterday be cause he had violated his status as a political refugee in Spain by making unauthorized politi cal statements to a Madrid newspaper.

title: Yale Wrestlers Win, 2213, And Break Columbia Streak
description: The Yale wrestling team won six of 10 bouts in defeating Columbia, 2213, yesterday at university gym. The Bulldog triumph ended a threemeet winning streak for the Lions and lifted the Yale wonlost record to 53. Columbia is now 341.

title: Alexandra Jones Is Married Here
description: Miss Alexandra Jones and Colin Neblett, both of New York, were married here yes terday evening in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episco pal Church by the Rev. Bruce Forbes, director of Christian education.

title: Zambia Doubts Big StepUp
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 7 Recently reported engagements in the Zambezi River Valley are not viewed here as a sign of a major stepup of fighting in the longsimmering situation.

title: Disorder on the Court
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 7 Like a baby trying to run be fore he has learned to walk, tennis has stumbled to new chaotic depths.

title: U.S. Agency Weighs A Riverfront Park On the Mississippi
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Feb. 7 The National Parks Service will begin this week a study of the feasibility of develop ing a Mississippi river front park here opposite St. Louis's Gateway Arch.

title: 32,172 FANS SEE $19.20 SHOT WIN
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 7 Cardinal Garrison, one of two Class AA pacers going against three junior freeforallers, won the onemile United States Harness Writers' Association handicap pace that topped to night's card before 32,172 fans. The largest turnout of 1970 6yearold New Zealand ex saw John Chapman drive the patriate in front at the outset and lead all the way to a $19.20 for $2 ??.

title: Karen Weiss Plans Wedding
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Albert Weiss of Great Neck and Remsen berg, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Dale Weiss, to Neil Harrison Ban der, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sid ney Bander of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The wedding is planned for July. the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Dale Weiss, to Neil Harrison Ban der, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sid ney Bander of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Sam Huff Seeks House Seat
description: FARMINGTON, W. Va., Feb. 7(UPI)Sam Huff, player coach of the Washington Red skins and former AllAmerica lineman at West Virginia Uni versity, announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the House from West Virginia's First Congres sional District. Mr. Huff, 35 years old, would oppose Repre sentative Robert H. Mollohan, in the May primary.

title: Duffer Agnew Shanks Ball And Hits Sanders in Head
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 7Vice President Spiro T. Agnew played golf that endeared him to duffers today. A duffer occasionally whiffs when he swings and at times hits bystanaers. The vice Presi dent, playing in the Bob Hope Classic paired with Senator George Murphy of California, the host, Bob Hope, and professional, Doug Sanders, hit Sanders in the head with his second shot of the day.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Year of G.O.P.

title: Hurricane Rios Greenland
description: GODTHAAB, Greenland, Feb. 7 (AP)A hurricane left at least 100 persons homeless in the town of Angmagssalik in South east Greenland, according to radio reports from there today. There were no reports of deaths or injuries as the town of 800 was ripped by winds said to have reached 100 miles an hour.

title: Richard Webbe Fiance Of Miss Nancy Lodge
description: BEVERLY, Mass., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. George Cabot Lodge have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Nancy Kunhardt Lodge, to Richard White Webbe, a registered repre sentative of the investment banking firm of Glore, For gan. Staats. Inc., in Boston.

title: Article 4  No Title
Graebner, Lutz and Scott Victors in Buffalo Tennis
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 7 (AP)  Clark Grabbner, Bobby Lutz and Gene Scott advanced today in the Buffalo invitation Indoor tennis tournament.

title: China's Note to Nasser Is Seen As Bid to Widen Mideast Role
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 7Com munist China's unexpected ex pression of support for Gamal Abdel Nasser in a message to the United Arab Republic's President this week is regarded here as an effort to increase Peking's influence in the Middle East.

title: Who Receives Top Billing When 2 Champions Meet?
description: On the yellowandblack showcard, Joe Frazier's name is on ton in red Ietters.

title: Maine Legislature Closes
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 7 (AP) The 104th Maine Legislature, which has been required to spend more time at its lawmak ing tasks than any other in Maine history, adjourned its first special session today.

title: North Koreans Accuse U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, Feb. 8 (Reuters)North Korea accused the United States today of ma chinegunning one of its military posts in the demilitarized zone a the border between North and South Korea. The North Korean Central News Agency, in a dispatch from Pyongyang, said the grave provocation took place yesterday afternoon In the central sector of the zone.

title: Police Strike Ends in Toledo
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 7 (UPI) A sick call strike by To ledo's 700man police depart ment ended today after the actting chief, Robert Duck, threatened to dismiss any of ficer who was not actually sick. About 100 men of an overnight shift of 120 failed to show up for work at 11 P.M. yesterday. But 118 of 120 men on the 7 A.M. shift reported for duty today.

title: 3 GAMES THIS WEEK FOR LAFAYETTE FIVE
Group Off to Watch Eclipse
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 (UPI)Ten astronomers, stu dents and technicians from the Harvard College Observatory and the Smithsonian Astro physical Observatory left today to establish a base in Mexico for the study of the eclipse of the sun March 7. The group was led by Prof. Donald H. Menzel, Paine Professor of Practical Astronomy at Har vard, and Jay M. Pasachoff, re search fellow in astronomy at Harvard.

title: Tenants' Complaint: No Heat, Water or Sympathy
description: A Bronx apartment house has been without water for two weeks and without heat since Christmas. Tenants in the 39 apartments get their water by going to fire hy drants with buckets, pots, kettles and bottles.

title: Bailey Signs With Expos
description: Montreal, Feb. 7 (AP)Bob Bailey and Junior Lopez, in fielders, signed today with the Montreal Expos of the National League.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Phaedra Judged Best at Afghan Show
description: A blackandsilver Afghan from Tulsa, Okla., Ch. Shang rila's Pharahna Phaedra, bred, owned and handled by Dr. Gerda Maria Kennedy, was named best of breed in a field of 205 yesterday, at the 31st National Specialty Show of the Afghan Hound Club of America at the StatlerHilton. It was the largest gathering of Afghans to compete in the United States.

title: SO. CAROLINA BEATS CLEMSON BY 9952
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 7 (AP)Scoring as many points in the first half as their oppo nents did in the entire game today, South Carolina routed Clemson 9952. It was the Gamecocks' 16th consecutive basketball victory.

title: A Place Where Children Can Go for Nothing
description: CARROLLTON, Ala.  Nine miles northeast of here along State Route 17, in the middle of just about nowhere, is Ma Cille's Museum of Miscellania  a rambling, helterskelter, doityourself collection of fascinating oddments that is the fruition of a family dream.

title: Letters
description: KNITTING: ITS ROLE IN THE LIFE OF DR. BRUNO BETTELHEIM

title: M. G. Connors Fiance Of Nancy M. Gallant
description: WILTON, Conn., Feb. 7 The engagement of Miss Nancy Marie Gallant, a jun ior at Marymount. College in Tarrytown, N. Y., to Michael Gerald Connors, a junior at Fairfield University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Gallant, par ents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Connors.

title: Soling Class Leans to One  Design
description: I am now convinced that when a man buys a Soling, he will get a Soling, said Gordon Lindemann of Milwaukee, chair man of the technical committee for the United States Soling As sociation, at the first major meeting of the relatively new sailing group at the New York Yacht Club during National Boat Show week.

title: Capital Bridal For Mrs. Noyes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Mrs. Lelia Gordon Noyes, widow of Newbold Noyes, an associate editor of The Wash ington Star, was married here today to the Rev. Dr. Albert Hawley Lucas, retired dean of the Episcopal Divin ity School in Philadelphia. The noon ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church, George town, was performed by the bridegroom's son, the Rev. Albert Lucas.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Anniversaries

title: DEMOCRATS WEIGH SHIFT ON VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Democratic Policy Council will be asked at a meeting on Mon day to advocate the withdrawal from Vietnam of all American troops, combat and noncombat, within 18 months.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: MARSH & McLENNAN, an international cas ualty insurance bro kerage concern that has had its New York offices at 70 Pine Street for many years, will move uptown early in 1971 when the 51story McGrawHill Building is com pleted on the Avenue of the Americas between 43th and 49th Streets.

title: Mrs. Duke Has Daughter
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Feb. 7A daughter was born Jan. 17 to Mr. and Mrs. Alan Duke at the Washington Hospital Center. Mrs. Duke is the for mer Miss Judith Silverman, whose husband is assistant to the president of Children's Supermarts, Inc., of Belts ville, a chain of toy discount stores.

title: This Fledgling Robyn Yearns to Be Among the First at Aqueduct This Spring
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7Trainer Frank I. Wright was standing by the clubhouse rail at Hialeah the other morning, shading his eyes from the sun and worriedly observing the antics of a filly named Embecias who was galloping into the clubhouse turn.

title: Rosina Berry, Physician, Sets Bridal in July
description: The engagement of Dr. Rosina Otis Berry to Richard Wayne Dixon has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Loren C. Berry of New York. The future bridegroom's par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Harlow C. Dixon of Woodburn. Ore.

title: Antiwar Groups Are Planning New, Peaceful Demonstrations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Antiwar protesters will an nounce plans early next week for a winterspring offensive that will include mailing Bibles to draft boards in March and parading against war taxes in April.

title: NADER TO PRESS FOR G.M. REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Ralph Nader, the advocate of con sumer interests and critic of the automobile industry, announced today the opening of a national Campaign to Make General Motors Responsible.

title: Kennedy's Draft Reforms
description: A subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, headed by Senator Edward Ken nedy, last week issued a report urging substantial reform of the Selective Service System, particularly with regard to deferments. Below are the present deferments (the figures in clude all those from age 19 to 35 affected by the current deferments) and the Kennedy subcommittee's proposals:

title: Deborah A. Hamilton Engaged To Navy Lieut. James Brengle
description: ARDMORE, Pa., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Perrin Calvert Hamilton of Ardmore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deb orah Anne Hamilton to Lieut. (jg.) James Kenneth Brengle, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolland M. Brengle Jr. of South Lyon. Mich.

title: Frederick Douglass On Screen
description: THE Theater Guild has been bitten by the movie bug again. Last year, its Theater Guild Films made it big with Slaves somewhat bigger at the box office than with the critics. Now they've decided to take a second cinematic stepthis time joining producer Sam Jaffe to film a biography of the black abolitionist Frederick Douglass. And they are cur rently having discussions with a group headed by Budd Schulberg, who has also been planning a movie about Doug lass. The hope, of course, is that they can all become one happy family, pro fessionally speaking.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Space
description: WASHINGTON  While the attention of the world's space buffs was focused on three astronauts and their Apollo 7 flight 16 months ago, the Soviet Union rocketed one of its many unmanned space probes into the heavens. As the Russians had correctly predicted, the launch ing of Cosmos 248 created not a ripple In public attention.

title: CRUFT'S PRIZE WON BY GREAT PYRENEES
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP)A Great Pyrenees mountain dog named Bergerie Knur, his nose marred by a fight, won first prize tonight at Cruft's, the world's biggest dog show.

title: Uranium Hunt Sets New Mark
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The government has reported that exploration for uranium the key element of the atomic energy program  once more reached new record high lev els during 1969, resulting in the largest annual increase in uranium ore reserves since 1957.

title: Jean E. Smith, A College Aide, To Be Married
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 7 Miss Jean Elizabeth Smith, a learningresources special ist for the Harvard Graduate Lesley College, will be mar ried this spring to Stanley Shepard, who is enrolled in a doctoral program at the Harvard School of Education.

title: Janet Holmes Bride Of G. A. Heckscher 3d
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 7 Miss Janet Holmes and Gus tave Adolph Heckscher 3d were married here this after noon in the chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Cathedral by Canon Thomas Smith.

title: Savings Stamp Hit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Treasury Department plans to end the sale of Unit ed States savings stamps June 30. The cost of handling the program has gone up while participation has not increased, the Treasury said.

title: Soldier Dies in Copter Crash
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 7 (Reuters)One American sol dier was killed and three were Injured last night when their helicopter crashed and burned about 20 miles north of Seoul, a spokesman said today.

title: Notes From the Field of Travel
description: FOR 18 of the last 19 years, Americans have spent more on travel abroad than foreign visitors have paid for travel and services in this country, thus creating what has be come known as a. travel gap. In 1969, according to unofficial figures, about 2 million overseas visitors toured the United States and spent approximately $720 million, but more than 5.3 million Americans went abroad and spent almost $2 billion.

title: Quotes
description: GEN. SIR GEOFFREY BAKER, Chief of the British General Staff, warning against com placency about Western defense: We tend not to see the writing on the wall until our backs are against it.

title: Linda Liu to Be Bride
description: ORINDA, Calif., Feb. 7 Dr. and Mrs. David C. T. Liu have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Liu of Boston, to Kenneth Alan Behar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Behar of New York.

title: In The Nation: Alive and Well in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7  After Gov. Ronald Reagan con centrated his 1970 State of the State message on rescuing California's environment, one skeptical Democrat remarked sarcastically: Once a left wing er, always a left winger.

title: Kallen, at New School Since Its Founding, Gives Last Lecture
description: The government of the city of Boston decided at one point in the nineteentwen ties that Prof. Horace Meyer Kallen must be arrested. It was then that Dr. Kallen knew his theory was work ing.

title: Tokyo Airport's Troubles Are Mainly on the Ground
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7Travelers passing through Tokyo's In ternational Airport at Ha neda often experience the emotions common to passen gers at most other busy air ports: boredom, exaspera tion, rage and hysteria.

title: Computers: Gain Seen To Top Spot
description: The Computer industry was born in the 1950's and enjoyed a healthy and amaz ing childhood during the dec ade just ended.

title: Israel's Early Warning System In the Arab World
description: THE comparison to a James Bond exploit was inevitable, although airlifting a stolen 7ton radar station would have been rejected by Ian Fleming, Bond's crea tor, as too fanciful, too improbable even for his implausible hero. Yet to the world's astonishment, Zahal, the Israeli Defense Forces, in December stole and then airlifted to Israel 7ton Russianbuilt radar station, to gether with its crew.

title: ST. JOHN'S HANDS ARMY 5444 LOSS
description: Jack Gimmler, the trainer of St. John's University's ath letic teams, said, That wasn't basketball, it was war.

title: The Openings of the Week
description: EXCHANGE Tonight, MercerO'Casey Theater, 7:30. A musical, with music and lyrics by Mike Brandt, Michael Knight, Robert J. Lowery.

title: Stalin's Interpreter Recalls Roosevelt Was Conciliator
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7Vladimin N. Pavlov, Stalin's interpreter, remembers an ailing Franklin D. Roosevelt doing his best as arbiter and conciliator to ease the tension at the Yalta con ference.

title: Movies
description: I BECOME hysterical, Fellini is saying, not hysterically. He has just flown from Italy to New York via Hollywood, to promote the first major film he has made in nearly five years, Fellini Satyricon, loosely based on Petronius Arbiter's Latin classic about the New Morality of Nero's Rome, and he dislikes flying, New York and Hollywood, not neces sarily in that order. Moreover, United Artists, the picture's distributor, has put him in a suite in the Plaza, which has not turned out to be his favorite hotel. The pearl and peach velvet living room is inexplicably cold, and Fellini glares around with displeasure, as if to spot some icy phantom who has not yet checked out. He loathes cold. He also loathes noise, and the phones ring per petuallyYoung ladies, wishing to be in his movies, explains Mario, his gentle, smiling secretary, bounding into the bedroom to grab another receiver. Below, drills gouge the pavement. The door buzzer sounds, a startling rasp. Is this possible? Fellini asks. Such a bell, just to announce somebody? become hysterical!

title: BILL SHIFT SOUGHT BY CHIROPRACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The nation's chiropractors are gain ing increasing support in Congress to, include payment for their professional services under Medicare, despite the determined opposition of the Administration and organized medicine.

title: LEEDS MOBERLEY, NEWSMAN, IS DEAD
description: Leeds Moberley, a newspaper man for more than 40 years and a former president of the New York Newspaper Guild, died yesterday in Flushing Gen eral Hospital of emphysema and cardiac arrest. He was 64 years old and lived at 14411 75th Avenue, Flushing. Oueens.

title: Villacampo Wins Close One
description: MANILA, Feb. 7 (AP)Ber nabe Villacampo of the Philip pines, World Boxing Association Flyweight champion, won a close, but unanimous, 10round decision over Raton Mojica of Nicaragua in a nontitle bout tonight.

title: Junior Hockey Twin Bill Slated Today at Garden
description: The Metropolitan Junior Hock ey Association allstar team will take on the league champion New York Green Leafs in the second game of a junior hockey doubleheader this afternoon at Madison Square Garden.In the first game starting at 12:30 P.M., the New York Ban tam Presidents of the Greater New York City Hockey League will take on the Royal York Rangers of the Metropolitan Toronto Hockey League. Ref ereeing the first game will be Scotty Morrison, the National Hockey League's refereein chief.

title: Letters: The Fisheye on Foreigners
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: N.Y.U. Fencers Sweep Foils And Down Harvard, 23 to 4
description: Paced by a 90 sweep by its foil squad, New York Univer sity's undefeated fencing team easily beat Harvard. 234, yes terday at the Washington Square Gymnasium.

title: Do's and Don'ts for Trees
description: SOME tree owners with a doityour self attitude, perform various proj ects which they believe will aid their trees. Some of the things they do are indeed beneficial. Other projects are either of no value or are actually harmful. Here are some nono's for tree owners:

title: Temple Routs Syracuse Five
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 7 (UPI) Tom Weiczerak scored 34 points 24 in the second halfto lead Temple to a 9069 victory over Syracuse tonight. The Owls led, 3929, at halftime and hit on 52 per cent of their shots in the game. Lee Tress scored 15. points, John Richardson 15 and 011ie Johnson 14 for Temple Sill Smith paced Syracuse with 23.

title: A touch of scarlet in a prudish and hypocritical age
description: The simultaneous publication of Per Seyersted's critical biography of Kate Chopin and his edition of her complete works is a literary event that ought to make more of a noise than it probably Will. Who, after all, was Kate Chopin? Seyersted's sensi tive and sensible interpretation of this extraordinarily talented author, together with two volumes of her writing (some of it hitherto unpub lished) should allow readers with or without his intelligent assistance to evaluate the results of his literary excavation.

title: LINDSAY PLEDGES OPEN ENROLLMENT
description: Open enrollment will be in stituted at the City University next fall, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday, no matter what other city services may have to be reduced to get the $8 million to $9million needed to pay for it.

title: College, School Results
The Nuns Fashion A New and Different Order
description: After years of being obedient daughters of the church and laboring in pious anonymity, nuns have become frontrunners of church reform. They have made sharp changes in rules and dress and they have made head lines as well, as their reforms sometimes met with resistance from their bishops. They have, in fact, become one of the most vis ible exponents of the changes taking place in the Catholic Church since Vatican II.

description: Alexander and The Magic Mouse

title: Briton Cites the Parley's Reality: Russian Armies
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  Lord Gladwyn came in wearing long woolen coat, dark blue, heavy, with big lapels.

title: GROUP'S USE OF NAME DISOWNED BY BISHOP
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Episcopal Bishop of California has complained that be is tired of being used by advocates of controversial causes.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUE
Chicago: A Trial Not by Rules but Invective
description: CHICAGOYou're a disgrace to the Jews, runt.

title: NAVY REQUESTING A NEW SUB FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Navy has asked Congress for $44million to pay for research on a nucleararmed submarine fleet that Democratic liberals think is unnecessary and could lead to another upward spiral in the arms race.

title: TERRIER FIXTURE TOPS TODAY'S LIST
description: This, in the year of the dog in China, is the week of the dog in the metropolitan area. Three specialty shows were held in New York yesterday, 22 are on today's calendar and Westmin ster takes place tomorrow and Tuesday. There are 2,226 dogs at the specialties and 2,611 for the Garden fixture.

title: Moscow Has a Nagging Pain in the Economy
description: In Moscow last week Sovi et scientists were publicly chided for retarding the country's economic growth by their slow development of computer technology. In New Zealand, almost simultane ously, Soviet representatives learned they could buy there only a small proportion of the meat they wanted, meat needed to end shortages in Soviet cities.

title: Lucinda Braddock Watson Married
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 7Miss Lucinda Braddock Watson, third of the five daughters of Thomas J. Wat son Jr., chairman of the In ternational Business Machines Corporation, and Mrs. Wat son, was married here this afternoon to Sherman Alan Kew. The bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Kew of Buffalo, is serving as a quartermaster seaman in the Navy. His father is presi dent of Ellicott Associates, a real estate holding company.

title: Article 2  No Title
CHAD TAX EVADERS RISK DEATH PENALTY
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, Feb. 7 (Agence FrancePresse)Presi dent Francois Tombalbaye of Chad has warned that income tax evaders in this Central Af rican country now risk the death penalty.

title: Sergei Denham
description: SERGEI DENHAM, who died Jan. 30, at 73, pro vided a small but none theless significant foot note to the history of Ameri can dance. Born in Moscow, he settled in the United States after the revolution, and worked both here and in Europe.

title: Italy Will Study Reports Liner Struck a Submarine
description: ROME, Feb. 7 (Reuters)The Italian Government has or dered an inquiry to determine if damage to an Italian liner could have been caused by a collision with a Soviet subma rine it was announced today.

title: Illinois Seeking a Curb On Damaging Hailstorms
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 26 The Illinois State Water Survey is undertaking a re search program aimed at re ducing damaging hailstorms.

title: Voting at 19 to Be on Ballot In the State of Washington
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 7 (UPI) A proposed state constitu tional amendment to allow 19 yearolds to vote has received final legislative approval and will be submitted to the voters in the November election.

title: Patton: He Loved War
description: PATTO A Salute to a Rebel looks and sounds like the epic American war mov ie that the Hollywood estab lishment has always wanted to make but never had the guts to do before. The film, which is now in its premiere roadshuw engagement at the Criterion Theater, is 20th CenturyFox's $12million tribute to the late General George S. Patton Jr., the bril liant, unstable World War II tactician who saw himself as nothing less than the divine instrument for making the world safe for future wars.

title: Jean Aldrich Smith to Be Wed To Rev. H.H. Weicker in March
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Feb. 7  Mrs. James Kenneth Tompkins and Brewster Weed Smith have announced that their daughter, Miss Jean Aldrich Smith of New York, and the Rev. Harold Hastings Weicker plan to be married on March 21.

title: Salvador Asks O.A.S. Check As Honduras Dispute Flares
description: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 7 (Reu ters)El Salvador asked the Organization of American States today to send a subcommittee immediately to establish the eality of Honduran aggression.

title: Do angels have the answer for the West?
description: Not long ago at a lecture on the roots of Christian renew al, a Dutch scholar observed that of course no one was los ing sleep these days over the existence or nonexistence of angels, those spiritual beings so often encountered in the Bible and the art and literature of the West. One wanted to say, Not so fast. Perhaps the Dutch are losing no sleep, but it is probably safe to say that a lot of Americans are just beginning to. Now Theodora Ward has addressed herself to the subject of angels in a schol arly and graceful way.

title: Menswear in Trouble, Looks to NonSuits
description: The men's apparel indus try, which in recent years has been riding the crest of a newly discovered fashion wave to spur its profitabili ty, is anticipating a difficult period in 1970.

title: Monty Denneau Becomes Fiance Of Miss Lucey
description: HAMDEN, Conn., Feb. 7  Mr. and Mrs. Donald Francis Lucey have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Lucey, to Monty M. Denneau, son of Mrs. Charles Montague Denneau of Lin coln Park, N. J., and the late Mr. Denneau.

title: NEW TOWNS PLAN FACES TAX HURDLE
description: A 1968 Federal tax law is preventing the State Urban De velopment Corporation, at least temporarily, from enjoying a taxexempt status on bonds it plans to issue to finance con struction of industrial facilities for its proposed new towns and other projects.

title: POST SQUADS BREAK 2 MARKS AT RELAYS
description: C. W. Post College broke pair of meet records yesterday in the Collegiate Track Confer ence's 14th annual relay car nival at Queens College.

title: 876 Named for Rich Race
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N. M., Feb. 7 (UPI)A record 876 nominations have been filed for the 13th running of the world's richest horse race, the 1971 $600,000 AllAmerican Futurity for quarter horses at Ruidoso Downs. The race, over 400 yards, will be held on Labor Day with the winner to receive about $159,840.

title: Schools and City U. Move to Coordinate Curriculums
description: A major effort to coordinate and upgrade the curriculums of the public schools and the City University has been undertaken as part of a broader and part nership between the Board of Education and the multicam pus university.

title: Unbeaten N.Y.U. Wrestlers Capture Triangular Meed
description: ANNVILLE, Pa., Feb. 7New York University's undefeated wrestling team trounced Dickin son and Lebanon Valley, the host school, in a triangular meet today.

title: Tripe twice
description: Patricians, to quote again that venerable and outofprint tome, The Wise Encyclopedia of Cookery, relished tripe in Baby lon's gardens; plebians have always welcomed it as good and cheap. The world's most famous dish of tripe is a la mode de Caen, flavored with Calvados and named for the Norman town, but there are also American tripe dishes that en joy considerable esteem. Count among them tripe creole with its flavorings of tomato, onion, green pepper and celery. For tripe fanciers, either the French or the American preparation is ideal for coldweather dining.

title: In Friendly Upstate Vermont Sans Skis
description: TROY, Vt.  One of the many good things about a winter stay here in upstate Vermont is that the local folk have time to pass and to mix with people from away, as they call outlanders. Modern heating, better insulation and machinery to help with the chores have eased what was once grueling labor for them at this time of year, traditional sports like ice fish ing have become more comfortable be cause of handy oil heaters and new excitements like snowmobiling have been added.

title: L.I.R.R. Union Again Demands Police Protection on All Trains
description: Long Island Rail Road trains will continue to run, including the embattled 7:07 P.M., Brook lyntoFar Rockaway local, if police protection is provided for railroad employes, the head of the trainmen's union an nounced yesterday.

title: INFIELDER GETS RAISE TO $25,000
description: The Mets continued to spread money around yesterday when they signed five more players to 1970 contracts. But the takers did not include Tom Seaver, Tug McGraw, Ron Swoboda, Ed Kranepool or several other varsity men who are haggling for more.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BEING an inquisitive young man with an unslakable thirst for knowledge, Tom Seaver has developed an under standable curiosity about Christy Mathew son. What awakened the interest of New York's latest folk hero in his inquiries regarding the background of New York's first folk hero has been the way some of the older baseball historians have begun comparing the two great pitchers.

title: MITCHELL TO MET MEDIA ON DISPUTE
description: Attorney General John N. Mitchell plans to meet with representatives of the nation's news media in an unusual per sonal effort to ease the bitter ness caused by a recent series of wideranging Government subpoenas to newsmen.

title: New Way to Enter Olympics: Show Your Gas Charge Card
description: THERE was a time, back when he was in high school in WilkesBarre, Pa., that Sam Savitt thought all artists wore beards and lived in attics.

title: MICHIGAN DOG WINS CHIHUAHUA HONORS
description: Ch. Dartan's Chocolate Chip, a longhaired Chihuahua owned by Darwin and Tanya Delaney of Essexville, Mich., was chosen best of breed in a field of 66 at The Chihuahua Club of Met ropolitan New York specialty yesterday at the PennGarden, Hotel.

title: Mrs. Charlotte Borg Erickson Married to Howard Hartman
description: Mrs. Charlotte Borg Erick son of Chicago and Honolulu, widow of L. Hyland Erickson, was married here yesterday to Howard Lowell Hartman of New York and Hartford. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony at the River Club.

title: Keen Johnson Is Dead at 74; Governor of Kentucky, 193943
description: RICMVIOND, Ky., Feb. 7 (AP)Keen Johnson, former Kentucky Governor and presi dent of The Richmond Daily Register, died today at the Pattie A. Clay Infirmary. He was 74 years old.

title: Middlebury Fills Posts
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 7 (AP)Dr. Paul M. Cubeta, dean of faculty, has been named academic vice president of Mid dlebury College, a 170yearold liberal arts institution. Dr. Cubeta will continue as profes sor of English and director of the Bread Loaf School of Eng lish, it was announced Wednes day. Dr. A. Richard Turner, professor of fine arts, succeeds Dr. Cubeta as dean of faculty. Both appointments are effective July 1.

title: ISRAELI JET SALE NOT SET, U.S. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The State Department denied today that the Nixon Administration had already decided to meet Israel's request to purchase more jet aircraft.

title: Jasmines, Gardenias and Hoyas
description: THE variety of scented flowers and foliage that can be grown indoors is somewhat limited. This is the challenge, but the added bonus of fragrance for having succeeded is worth the extra plant care re quired.

title: EAGLES USE ZONE TO OVERTAKE RAMS
description: When you can win, you don't need a lot of fans in the audi ence, and Boston College had few rooters among the father andson day crowd of 3,016 at Fordham yesterday, but they defeated the Rams. 7168.

title: Cutting Car Smog Now
description: The devastating pollution of the air from automo bile exhaustmain cause of the foul atmosphere so many American citiesrequires both immediate and longrange responses.

title: Profiteer, banker and very rich
description: When William Bingham died in 1804, he was reputedly the richest man and the largest landowner in America. One of that numerous tribe of inter national war profiteers, the Philadelphia merchant banker blended private concern and public interest to his own im mense gain. As agent of Con gress in the French West Indies during the American Revolu tion, he worked assiduously at procuring supplies for the Con tinental Army, at the same time speculating in trading and pri vateering ventures on his own.

title: Birds
description: VIETNAM has added four multicolored tri angular stamps to its postal issues illus trating its flora and fauna. The most recent issue from Saigon is of birds, from de signs by Nguyen Van Ri, Nguyen Minh Houng and Neuven Van Minh Chau.

title: 34 Cars in PileUp In Fog on Thruway; 16 Persons Injured
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., Feb. 7 Heavy fog caused a 34auto mobile pileup on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway this morning, resulting in injuries to 16 persons, none of them serious, and the closing of the superhighway for a time.

title: MAYOR AND AGNEW GAIN, GALLUP SAYS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 7 Vice President Agnew and Mayor Lindsay of New York have registered gains in per sonal appeal, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Girl Dies, Then Mother
description: WEST KEANSBURG, N.J., Feb. 7A 45yearold mother died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, after her daughter was asphyxiated accidentally in a parked car in Matawan Bor ough on Tuesday. The mother was Mrs. E. Georgette Anderson Murphy of 45 Eighth Street, wife of Larry Murphy, a route man in the circulation depart ment of The New York Times for 23 years. Their daughter, Georgette, was 17 years old.

title: ROBERTSON IS OUT OF ROYAL LINEUP
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 6A vivid example of how much Oscar Robertson means to the Cin cinnati Royals was presented tonight at Cincinnati Gardens, where the New York Knicker bockers took advantage of the Big O's absence to run up a 13592 victory over the Royals.

title: ROGERS, IN RABAT, OPENS 15DAY TRIP TO AFRICAN LANDS
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 7  Secretary of State William P. Rogers began a 15day tour of 10 African nations today, say ing that his purpose was to show a new interest in Africa on the part of the United States.

title: Grounded Tanker, Leaking Oil Cargo, Is Breaking Apart
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press)  The 11,379 ton Liberian tanker Arrow, agorund and leaking oil on shoal off Nova Scotia, is break ing up, a spokesman for Imper ial Oil, Ltd., said today.

title: Bronx Democratic Split Widens Over a Nomination for Assembly
description: Reform and organization Democrats in the Bronx have begun a new phase of their struggle for leadership. They split last week over the method of selecting a candidate for the Assembly from the 84th District.

title: Fenner's Team Triumphs In 4Man Bobsled Event
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP)  The fourman bobsled driven by Les Fener of Keys ville, N.Y., placed first today in Adirondack Amateur Athletic Union competition at nearby Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: Zionism as a moral and religious movement
description: Naturalism did not disappear in Chicago with Studs Lonigan. It is here today in Charles Angoff's Jewish novels of New York and its associated envi rons. This one is fullblown, allinclusive, with all events since Zionism began as a moral and religious movementshow ing up in all their naturalistic juices. It is an admirable lit erary exercise in historical nu ances  and the hero is, most unusually, the moral man. But, then, he has to be normal in his nature, his virtues, his lack of vices, his conceits about Ju daism in world he has made  and a time that was, not too long ago, filled with social and political actions that are still with us.

title: Tourists in the Laid of the Twilight War
description: JERUSALEMTen days ago, a Syrian MIG21 streaked low over Haifa, smashing some windows with its sonic boom and sending even stronger ripples through the defense establishment. In the Dan Carmel Hotel high atop the city, American tourists glanced at each other in the lobby and nodded knowingly. Get it all the time at home, one said.

title: Music
description: WHEN Sidney Foster, at his piano recital last month, played Leopold Godowsky's Alt Wien as an encore, there was a little intake of surprise from the audience. Everybody knew the tune, but not many realized that it had been written for solo piano. Godowsky is that forgotten these days. He composed a good deal of piano music, and there was a time when virtuoso pianists loved to play his Strauss paraphrases, especially Fledermaus and Artist's Life. Those pieces seem to be gone, too. The current Schwann Long Playing Record Catalogue does not list one composition under his name.

title: Chiefs of Northern Lines Sure Merger Will Work
description: Last Monday, the United States Supreme Court cleared the track for the merger of the Northern Linesthe Great Northern, the North ern Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy rail roadsinto a new company known as Burlington North ern, Inc.

title: Red Guards Urged to Renew Struggle
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 7  The militant Red Guards of Com munist China, quiescent for the last two years, have been sum moned to support what appears to be a new leftist drive for greater power.

title: Pop
description: THE question was sim ple enough. Had all the flowers gone from last summer's musical garden of peace, love and community? Or, to get down to the nittygritty, did the blight that marred the recent Rolling Stones concert in Al tamont take the bloom off the growing Woodstock Na tion?

title: Will Florida's Total Eclipse Be a Total Tourist Success?
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.Why do tens of thousands of visitors flock to Florida in the winter? To bask in the sun, of course. But come next monthMarch 7, to be exacta multitude of sun wor shippers will converge on this northern Florida area to watch the sun disappear.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Craig Johnston to Wed Miss Backhurst
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 7  Miss Deborah Hargreaves Back hurst, a graduate student in social work at the State Uni versity College of New York at Buffalo, and Craig Paul Johnston, a graduate student there in Spanish, plan to be married in April.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: OCHO RIOS, Jamaica  Leaning my flyrod against a coconut palmthe last time it had been out of its case was in LabradorI watched Austen J. Thomas striving to catch a mountain mullet before daylight failed.

title: Words on Carswell
description: President Nixon's nomination of Federal District Judge G. Har old Carswell of Florida to the Supreme Court was stalled in the Senate Judiciary Committee last week as opponents used parliamentary ploys to delay a committee vote. As a result, it now appears that the full Sen ate may have to wait until the beginning of March to vote on the Carswell appointment.

title: Santa Anita Mark Broken
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 7It was no contest once Nodouble started rolling on the turn for home and the 1969 handicap champion made his, year's debut a winning one today by capturing the $46,650 San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: Business Index Fell in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activ ity fell last week to 357.9 from 364.3 a week earlier. A year ago it was 343.9.

title: Article 1  No Title
Another Skirmish On Issue Of Press Freedom
description: WASHINGTON  Neither in law nor in philosophy have Americans ever defined the meaning of the freedom of the press. It implies a great many freedoms, including some con flicting freedoms, notably the freedom of some citizens to speak and publish without restraint and the freedom of other citizens to receive a diversity of fact and opinion. As the debates of recent years have shown, it also implies a great many duties, including some conflicting duties, notably the responsibility of the press to serve society with a dedication to truth and the duty of society to the tolerate error and even falsehood so as to preserve the freedom of the factfinders.

title: Trend Even On Counter And Amex
description: Mr. Kennedy's statement that interest rates may soon decline was not quite enough. The market is sick of promises and wishful thinking and wants de livery.

title: BRITISH ARE FIRM WITH PROTESTERS
description: LONDON, Feb. 7A group of Welsh students marched in to a London courtroom this week in a noisy but nonviolent protest. By the end of the day, 14 of them were in jail on threemonth sentences for con tempt of court.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 125 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: 43,000YearOld Mine Discovered in Swaziland
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 7South African archeologists have reported discovering the world's old est mine. The mine, in an ironore mountain in neigh boring Swaziland, is 43,000 years old, according to radio carbon dating.

title: Match Sets Lap Record In Rothman Qualifying Test
description: SURFERS PARADISE, Aus tralia, Feb. 7 (AP)  Frank Matich of Australia, driving a McLaren M10A Chevrolet, smashed lap record by nearly two seconds today as he set the fastest qualifying time for the Rothman's 100mile race.

title: Miss Nancy Dutcher Is Bride In Darien of Peter Strohmeier
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 7 Miss Nancy Odette Dutcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Dutcher, was mar ried here this afternoon to Peter Torrey Strohmeier, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Strohmeier, in a candlelight ceremony by the Rev. Dr. Lawrence McColl Horton, who was assisted by the Rev. Robert N. Balk, in the Nor ton Presbyterian Church.

title: College, School Results
Ordinary People of Laos Wish for Peace but Only Shrug as the War Continues
