description: VIENTIANE, Laos  Whilel their leaders make diplomatic attempts to stave off the pro Communists' dryseason offen sive and evacuate people from what will again become combat zones, the ordinary people of Laos shrug their shoulders and say that the question of war or peace is not theirs to answer.

title: Article 6  No Title
Television
description: DEMOCRACY's traditional basis of checks and balances between the administrative, legislative and judicial branches of Govern ment has been knocked askew by the television age. As matters stand, the White House has all the advantages or gaining access to the minds of the voting viewer while, for practical purposes, Congress and the Supreme Court are blacked out. The picture of Government on the home screen is badly distorted precisely at a moment when the country faces a multitude of grave issues.

title: Expo '70 from Canada
description: CANADA on March 18 will release a block of four 25cent stamps (the airmail rate to the orient and Pacific Ocean areas) to commemorate Expo '70, the international fair at Osaka, Japan, and Canada's participation in the event. The stamps will be printed by sixcolor lithography, an innovation for Canadian stamps.

title: GARBAGE STRIKERS FIRM IN CAROLINA
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 7 A garbage workers strike linked to the deaths of two workers who were trying to keep warm, found both sides standing firm here today.

title: Bank BuildUp Is Pausing
description: THE tide that seems to have left a bank branch office on every corner and in each new midtown Manhat tan building appears to be stemmedat least for awhile.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: News of the Rialto
description: ALEXANDER SOLZHENIT SYN'S voice has been stifled in the Soviet Unionthe publication of his works has been barred since 1966. But he continues to speak to the world.

title: Rebellion in Lausanne
description: This short novel, dramatiz ing the impact of the French Revolution on a Swiss canton, is Bryher at her best  and Bryher at her best is second to none. While neither as drama tic as The Coin of Carthage, nor as imaginative as Visa for Avalon, it is particularly effective because its sharp focus on a single locale makes the larger ramifications of the French turmoil intelligible and movine.

title: Purchasing Men Braced For a Hard Time in 1970
description: Seen through the eyes of purchasing executives, 1970 is going to be a tough year.

title: Cavarretta Named Manager
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI) Phil Cavarretta, former Chi cago Cub first baseman and manager, was named today to manage the Birmingham A's of the Southern League, farm club of the Oakland Athletics.

title: Ziegler Fires 71 for 271 and 2Shot Lead
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 7In relative obscurity, five miles from where most of the 13,000 fans were watching Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, Lar ry Ziegler shot a 71 to keep his lead today after the fourth round of the $125,000 Bob Hope Golf Classic.

title: Jean Luise Hallstein Is Bride Of Bruce F. Linck Jr. In Jersey
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 7 Miss Jean Luise Hallstein and Bruce Fulton Linck Jr. were married here this morn ing. The Rev. Dr. Frederick E. Christian performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church.

title: BURTON CAPTURES $45,000 BOWLING
description: DENVER, Feb. 7 (AP)Nel son Burton Jr. of St. Louis de feated three straight opponents today to take firstplace money of $6,000 in the $45,000 Denver open bowling tournament.

title: Spotlight:
description: The sell recommendation  an area of some sensitiv ity in the securities business  is making itself more evi dent these days. These same recommendations often trig ger price declines in big name stocks, particularly those glamour issues trading at high priceearnings ratios.

title: College Increases Tuition
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass, Feb. (AP)  American International College will raise tuition by $150 next year, its president, Harry J. Courniotes, has an nounced. The increase will bring the average tuition to $1,560 for a full academic schedule.

title: Bowdoin Aide Promoted
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 7 (UPI)A staff economist at Bowdoin College's public af fairs research center, Carl E. Veazie, has been appointed di rector of the center, the col lege announced today.

title: Slum Groups Get Offer of Free Stock
description: Substantial stock ownership in a pioneer factory at the abandoned Navy Yard in Brook lyn has been offered free to slum community groups by the company.

title: 40,000 Riders of InterCity Bus Line in Jersey Face 10% Increase in April
description: Forty thousand daily riders of InterCity Transportation Company buses, running be tween northern New Jersey and New York City, face fare increases generally of 10 per cent about April 1, a courtap pointed trustee said yesterday.

title: Stamps
description: THE 75th anniversary exhibition of the Col lectors Club of New York will be staged Nov. 17, 1971, at the Wal dorfAstoria Hotel It will be an invitationonly show, un der the chairmanship of John R. Boker Jr.

title: Japan Plans Advance Payment
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 (UPI) Ja pan has decided to make an advance repayment of $80 million to the United States ExportImport bank for loans given Japanese concerns for purchases in America.

title: Photography
description: JUDGING from the volume of show notices and course announcements streaming into this cor ner, the month of February promises to be one of the busiest for these activities in some time.

title: Army to Try Officer in Vietnam In Killing of a Vietcong Suspect
description: A 22yearold Army lieuten ant is to go on trial tomorrow in South Vietnam charged with the premeditated murder of a suspected Vietcong agent last September, according to his lawyer in New York.

title: The mill of their dreams
description: Many people dream of living and working in some romantic rural retreat, but Li las and Raymond Barger made their dream come true. They left suburban Mamaroneck for Carversville, Pa., where they bought an abandoned, eighteenthcentury, stone mill. It was riddled with holes in the roof and floors, but the stone shell was sturdy. They cleaned and repaired the interior, stripped plaster walls in the living room and kitchen down to the stone, laid a new tile floor and added a winding staircase. Mrs. Barger, the mother of three children, has become a piano teacher and antiques dealer; Mr. Barger continues as a sculptor.

title: Miss Bonica Banks Becomes a Bride List of Entertainment Benefit Parties
description: Miss Bonica Banks, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Davis Banks of Rowayton, Conn., was married here yes terday afternoon to Hubert (Mark) Potter Earle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. J. Burton Thomas in the Chapel of the Beloved Dis ciple of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. A re ception was given in the Col ony Club here.

title: Deaths of 2 Women In Rochester Tied To Use of Diet Pills
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 7Health officials have reported that two young mothers died during the last two weeks after taking a variety of diet pills.

title: Oh! Copenhagen!
description: COPENHAGEN. ON July 1, Denmark became the first Western nation to re move legal prohibitions against the production and sale of hardcore pornography to adultsthat is, any one at least 16 years old. In Octo ber, the leaders of the already flour ishing pornography industry, like their counterparts in pleasureboat ing, electronics or homefurnishings, hired a publicrelations man and put on a trade show to display their wares.

title: SKI JUMP TROPHY TAKEN BY WELLS
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 7Bernie Wells, 16yearold Brattleboro (Vt.) Union School athlete, won the Donald B. Stewart Trophy in ski jumping today with a 163foot jump on the 50meter hill.

title: Accusation In France: Merchants Of Death
description: PARISFew dealers in weap onry are fond of the appelation merchants of death. When it was pinned last week on Michel Debre, the hottempered French Defense Minister was deeply stung.Most painful was that the ac cusation came from within the majority bloc of deputies in the National Assembly. Michel Poni atowski, chairman of the Inde pendent Republicans and chief political aide to Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing, opened fire at a party meeting Monday night.

title: Jerusalem: Surrounded, Outnumbered and Defiant
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 7By all the normal laws of geography, history and military science, the State of Israel should be in a state of deep anxiety these days, but it is nothing of the sort. It is surrounded, threat ened, outnumbered and defiant.

title: Arabs Pin Hopes on Moscow
description: CAIROSoviet Premier Ko sygin's messages to the West last week warning that Israeli air strikes against Egypt had become dangerously provocative and implying that the Soviet Union might take steps to pro tect Egyptproduced in Cairo the joyous effect of bugles in a Wild West movie when the cav alry gallops in to rescue the be sieged fort.

title: Minor Leagues to Bend Foul Lines in Baseball Trial
description: A startling and original pro posal to increase hitting in baseball has been approved for experimental use in the low minors this season. It involves bending the foul lines outward, once they pass first and third bases, to make more fair terri tory, especially for extrabase hits.

title: Alice S. Kirby Fiancee Of George A. Horton 3d
description: MADISON, N. J., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Kirby 2d have made known the en gagement of their daugher, Miss Alice Sutherland Kirby, to George A. Horton 3d of Morristown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horton 2d of San Ma teo, Calif.

title: RUTH VINCENT
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 7 Miss Ruth V. Vincent of the Duncan Hill Apartments here, music supervisor of the West feld public schools and former secretary of the New Jersey Music Education Association, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York.

title: British Dismantle Land Mine
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP)An army bomb disposal squad working in a suburban reser voir dismantled a 1,500pound land mine today believed dropped by parachute during a German air raid in World War II Explosives were removed from the 6footlong mine, dis covered when workmen drained the reservoir.

title: Dance
description: UNQUESTIONABLY one of the most signifi cant events in Amer can dance over the last few years has been the return of Jerome Robbins. Robbins was born to be our leading choreographer one day. He shouted greatness almost with diffidence, and seemed unwilling at one time to play in dance's ball park. For a time it appeared that he was prepared to accept the secondary role of theater director  interpreting other men's workand desert the primary, creative role of choreographer.

title: MARINES SUSPECTED IN CLUB EXPLOSION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 (AP)An explosion that killed one Marine and wounded 62 others in an enlisted men's club near Danang Thursday may have been set off by an American rather than by Viet Cong terrorists, Marine Corps officials said today.

title: Medicine
description: Cigarette smoking seems to have been born in Spain and when Prosper Merime, after his sojourn in that country, wrote Carmen in the 1840's his heroine made her living rolling cigar ettes. Some Americans began smoking cigarettes before the Civil War but it was the inven tion of cigaretterolling machines in the 1880's that started their rise to wide popularity. By 1910 the American Tobacco Company, which controlled 86 per cent of the business, was massproduc ing cigarettes  a monopoly broken a year later under the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: GYPSY MOTH CONTROL
description: THE New York State Conserva tion Department's Bureau of Forest Insect and Disease Con trol has just completed its field survey to determine where this year's gypsy moth defoliation will occur. Some 145,000 acres are proposed for aerial treatment with the insecticide Sevin. This chemical is one of the degradeable insecticides which break down shortly after use, unlike the hard pesticides such as D.D.T. The affected woodlands surveyed indicate that if treatment is not applied, they will probably be heavy defoliated.

title: Joan S. Esselen Is Bride of Ensign
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 7 Miss Joan Sargent Esselen was married here this after noon to Ens. Silas Buck Foot 3d, U.S.N.R., by the Rev. Rob ert Nelson Back in St. Luke's Episcopal Church. A recep tion was given in the Country Club of Darien.

title: MANHATTAN TAKES TRIANGULAR MEET
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 Manhattan College won the onemile and twomile relays tonight, the last two events of the program, and defeated Navy and Penn State in a triangular track meet at the Naval Acad emy.

title: Vietnam 2: Doubts Where They Count the Most
description: SAIGONFor Vietnamese, the Tet Lunar New Year festival that began here last week is tradi tionally a time for introspection, a fourday pause in which to reassess the year gone by and consult fortune tellers about the future.

title: Mary Kearns Married in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Mary Jane Kearns, daugh ter of Mrs. John P. Kearns of Sarasota, Fla., formerly of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Kearns, was married here this morning to Edward Fran cis Carey of Washington, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Carey of West Roxbury, Mass. The ceremony was per formed in St. Matthew's Ro man Catholic Cathedral by the Rev. James Sweeney.

title: Soviet Finds the Mail Is Slower Than in 1900
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7On Jan. 25, 1900, Leo Tolstoy mailed a letter from Moscow to the director of the State Public Library in St Petersburg. Records of the time show that the novelist's message was received the next day.

title: Job Changes:
description: E. L. O'Neill, formerly sen ior vice president, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Emer son Electric Company, St. Louis. W. L. Davis, formerly president, has been elected vice chairman of the board and chief administrative of ficer, and W. R. Persons has been reelected chairman of the board and chief execu tive officer. All three are Emerson directors.

title: O. Pappa, $14.60, Capfures $15,000 Sprint at Oaklawr
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 7 (AP)O. Pappa took the lead at the start and defeated a field of eight other older handi cap horses in the $15,000 King Cotton Handicap at Oaklawn Park Saturday. The 5yearold O. Pappa cov ered the 5 furlongs in 1:06 25, the best time at this distance this season here.

title: Battered Nigerian Economy Poised for a Comeback
description: In Enugu, Port Harcourt, Umuahia and the other battered towns of the former Biafra, the slow healing of the physical scars of war has started.

title: MRS. DEAN C. OSBORNE
description: Mrs. Dean C. Osborne, for many years president of the auxiliary of the Brooklyn Chil dren's Museum, died Friday in her home at 50 Park Avenue. Her age was 91. The former Sade Fawcett, she was the widow of a dental supply man ufacturer.

title: Adelphi Swimmers Win
description: The Manhattan College swim mers were defeated by Adelphi 5540, yesterday in the Alumn Pool in Riverdale. Tom Liott led the Adelphi team by win ning three events.

title: Tanzania Takes Control Of EnglishLanguage Daily
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Feb. 7 (AP)The Tanzanian Govern ment has taken over The Standard, the only remain ing Englishlanguage, privately owned daily newspaper here.

title: Jets for Israel
description: The Nixon Administration is reported to have de cided to supply Israel with additional jet airplanes. If, despite the State Department denial yesterday, the report is correct, it represents a tragic, but necessary, decision. It is a forced reply to the threats contained in Soviet Premier Kosygin's recent note to Washing ton. The decision is also in part a response to the appearance of France as a major new supplier of war planes to the Arab Middle East, combat craft that are virtually certain to be used against Israel if the present dangerous trend continues.

title: The Text of Democrats' Draft Resolution on Vietnam
description: Despite the Administra tion's claims of progress, Vietnam remains our most urgent overseas problem and our most divisive and bitter domestic one. Our national interests require that the war in Vietnam be brought to a close at the earliest practical moment. The loss of life, the diversion of resources from critical domestic needs and the disunity of our country must be ended.

title: The Panorama From Diablo When There Is No Smog
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif.  Although it is only 3,849 feet high, a mere molehill when compared to the many 14,000foot peaks of the Sierra Nevada and Rocky Mountains, Mount Diablo, here in San Francisco's backyard, is one of the world's great view points. Some geographers and the local Chamber of Commerce say that it is possi ble to see more land area from Diablo's summit than from any other peak on earth; certainly, it has no equal in this country.

title: Dartmouth Fills Post
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 7 (AP)Dr. Jere R. Danniell, as sociate professor of history, has been named chairman of the Committee on Equal Opportu nity at Dartmouth College.

title: JULIE HOLMES GETS RUNNERUP HONORS
description: TUSLA, Okla., Feb. 7Janet Lynn, who still finds figure skating fun despite the pressure of being the national champion, successfully defended her senior women's title at the Tulsa Assembly Center today.

title: The Americas at Caracas
description: It was difficult in Caracas last week to find one LatinAmerican statesman convinced that the Nixon Administration had yet developed a coherent, consist ent policy for the Americas. All that even the more optimistic delegates to the InterAmerican Economic and Social Council were persuaded of was that such a policy might yet emerge in time if a united Latin America could maintain steady pressure for it.

title: Pakistan Won't Postpone Her Fourth 5Year Plan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 7Pakistan will begin her fourth fiveyear economic de velopment plan In July, the Government announced this week.

title: Obedience Trial Feb. 22
description: The first point obedience trial of the Bay Shore Com panion Dog Club in 10 years has been scheduled for Feb. 22 at the Bay Shore (L. I.) High School.

title: A Black Father on Sesame Street It's Into Cognition, Baby
description: TELEVISION runs a game, I mean runs it on us all . . . each and evvy, you know. And unless you're one of those cases who never sits slumped and lifeless before that chilled and chilling gray eye, the number is being run on you, too. Framing your life with which car, and what table napkin, the beer or the shampoo. Slipping into your head with a vengeance, with a purpose.

title: 2 CANADIAN TEAMS ADVANCE IN CURLING
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 7, Two Canadian teams and those representing Ardsley and Nutmeg won quarterfinal matches in the 15th Annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club today.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: Today  Associated Terrior Clubs specialties; Armory, 168th Street west of Broadway, New York; 645 entries, 9 A.M.

title: IRISH STAR SETS SCORING RECORD
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 7 (UPI)  Notre Dame, behind Austin Carr's recordbreaking performance, defeated Mar quette, 9695, today in a dou ble overtime game before a capacity crowd.

title: Contractor Sues City For Removing House
description: A Brooklyn contractor has sued the city and a Great Neck, L. I., wrecking concern for allegedly razing a fire damaged home that he had purchased and started to re pair.

title: Closeup of the Grunt
description: SAIGON.

title: Harvard Tuition Up $200
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP)The cost of a Harvard education now is $2,600 an nually. The university announc ed today it was raising its tui tion $200 for 19701971. The increase affects students at Harvard College, Radcliffe Col lege and the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. Last year Harvard raised its tuition to $2,400 from $2,000.

title: Colburn Sets 2Mile Mark As Harvard Trackmen Win
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 Keith Colburn, Harvard's track captain, set a twomile run meet record of 8 minutes 52.2 seconds today to highlight the Crimson's seventh consecutive victory in the Greater Boston collegiate indoor track and field championships.

title: Middlebury Six Wins
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 7 (AP)Chris Burr scored two Foals and assisted on one today as Mickllebury's hockey team edged Iirmilton 54.

title: Special Assistant
description: JAMES R. HOLLAND is the new Special Assistant to the Postmaster General for Public Information, succeed ing James M. Henderson.

title: Miss Friedman Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Judith Rae Friedman, daughter of Mrs. Elaine Friedman of Westport, Conn., and Rabbi Herbert A. Fried man of New York, plans to be married in September to Wayne Warren Unice.

title: Training Courses Listed
description: The Watchung Mountain Poo dle Club will begin new classes in obedience training and show handling next Friday at the Veterans' Memorial Home, Kirkman Place and High Street, Union, N. J. The courses are open to all breeds. Dorothy Anne Griffin (201) 3327270, will supply information.

title: Being Gorgeous Isn't Enough
description: GEORGE Hamilton (n.) Little Lord Faunt leroy; Romeo; playboy bachelor; dandy on the Best Dressed list; a Cary Grant of the seventies; Pyg malion to a President's daughter; glamourpuss.

title: Diane McClure to Be June Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 7Miss Diane McClure, an illustrator in archeology at Yale's Peabody Museum, plans to be married in June to Lieut. (jg.) G. Penn Hol senbeck, U.S.N.R.

title: Bookings Fat, Profits Lean In N.Y. Hotels
description: New York's hotel keepers may be turning down the covers on more beds these days but they aren't turning up with corresponding profits.

title: Saga of a Building Traced
description: A FEW strokes of the pen at a corporate confer ence table last Tuesday wrote the final chapter in a decadelong realty saga that in many ways is typical of scores of transactions each year that involve prime tracts of Manhattan real estate.

title: Value of Much Business Data Is Called in Question
description: WASHINGTON  Econo mists have done little to esti mate how serious a loss the American economy suffers from poor data, slow data, missing data or dishonest data. In a society in which knowledge and information are becoming the most criti cal factors in increasing pro ductivity and economic growth, improving the quali ty of data becomes a crucial economic objective.

title: Recordings
description: THE old argument that art does not have to be socially relevant to be Art  a point often made today in refuting the artistic claims of the new Black Theater movement  falls quietly to pieces at the mention of Beethoven. What composer was more in tune with his revolutionary times, was more the standard bear er of antiaristocraticism in his work, dress and deport ment than the illmannered genius who fook titled money all the while he bit the feed ing, silkgloved hand?

title: Duval Jennings Bride of Robert Bird 3d
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Feb. 7  In Trinity Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Duval Barlow Jennings and Robert Montgomery Bird 3d, who are with SSC & BLintus International, ad vertising agency in New York, were married by the Rev. Francis X. Cheney.

title: UPSALIN IS THREAT IN TWOMILE RACE
description: PARIS, Feb. 7  Two French champion trotters, Upsalin and Une de Mai, as well as Amer ica's Snow Speed will have their last chance tomorrow to win one of the winter harness classics in Paris.

title: Princeton Six Loses
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 7 Harvard's hockey team jumped to a threegoal lead in the first period today, then held on to down Princeton, 63.

title: Patrons Eat Frankfurters Sardi After Fire Shuts Down Kitchens
description: Theatergoers lunched on free hot dogs and sauerkraut in stead of $4.85 English sole saut amandine at Sardi's yes terday afternoon as the theat rical gathering place struggled to recover from an extensive fire in its kitchens.

title: GEN. JAMES DREYFUS
description: RED BANK, N. J., Feb. 7 Maj. Gen. James Dreyfus, who retired from the Army in 1961, died at the Riverview Hospital here yesterday. He was 65 years old, and lived at 85 Fish Hawk Drive, in Middletown Township, N. J.

title: Excerpts From the Replies by Premier Golda Meir During an Interview in Tel Aviv
description: The Moscow message? If we read it right, it really has nothing surprising in it. It proves to us that Nasser is not happy. The war has been brought home to him. Not only he knows what is hap pening, for example, on the Suez Canal, but he can't fool his people anymore. Maybe that's the most important thing that has happened.

title: Francis Finds Need for Angles Acute
description: The Rangers will play their 50th game of the National Hockey League campaign to night, against the Los An geles Kings, and as he has done for the 49 previous con tests, Coach Emile Francis will practice psychology with out a license.

title: Ullman Named President Of American Technion Group
description: The election of Jacob Walter Ullmann, chemical engineer and executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, as president of the, American Technion Society was announced by the society last night.

title: Brothers Are Expanding Family Food Business
description: We take a bite out of the food dollar at every level for services rendered: grow, can or process it, distribute it and use it.

title: MRS. SADIE R. SHIMM
description: Mrs. Sadie R. Shimm, active in Jewish organizational activi ties, died Thursday at the age of 70. She lived at 600 West 239th Street, Riverdale, The Bronx.

title: DRUG ABUSE HELD JEWISH PROBLEM
description: A Jewish communal leader and head of a prominent phil anthropic organization says that drug use has penetrated all levels of the Jewish com munity.

title: The Metropolitan Museum of Art / Lectures
description: Rembrandt: 16091669

title: U.S. Business:
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 7Severe winter weath er for the past two months has had one beneficial effect on a project undertaken here by the Research Center of the Bureau of Mines.

title: Quiz No. 82
description: In a simultaneous performance versus about 50 players, world champion Dr. Alexander Alekhine polishes off his opponent, A. Kussman, in jig time. His first move is crucial. Can you guess it?

title: Never Bow 2d at Hialeah
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7  With Arts and Letters resting comfort ably in the barn, out of the rain, the $65,700 Seminole Handicap at Hialeah today was a wide oven race.

title: Stony Brook Takes 12th, Beating Kings Point, 6355
description: STONY BROOK, L. L, Feb. 7 Superior rebounding and shooting led Stony Brook Uni versity to a 6355 victory to night over Kings Point.

title: Vietnam 1: Critics Say Nixon Policy Is A Hoax
description: WASHINGTONThe Congres sional doves were aflutter Iast week. Their long muted cries were heard again in the land as they challenged the Nixon policy in Vietnam.

title: Lane O'D. Sheble, '63 Debutante, Is Bride of William Reardon Jr.
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Feb. 7 Miss Lane O'Day Sheble was married to William Fran cis Reardon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Reardon of Rumson, this afternoon in the Cres cent Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Charles L. Mead performed the cere mony.

title: Hunter College Is Preparing Centennial Dinner for Saturday
description: Hunter College will wind up a week of centennial events next Saturday with a dinner at the Americana for the benefit of the college's centennial fund. Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, the City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs and a Hunter gradu ate, will he mistress of cere monies for the event that will include an address by Sena tor Jacob K. Javits.

title: Unbeaten Columbia Fencers Beat Yale for 5th Victory
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7Co lumbia's undefeated fencing team won its fifth match to day, turning back Yale, 189.

title: Did the Italians Invent Opera  Or Vice Versa?
description: THE traveler in Italy seems often to crack his head on knobby con tradictions. How can the seat of Catholicism, the breeding ground of saints, lead the rest of Western Eu rope in the size of its Communist party? How can an open, kindly people be so indifferent, so inconsiderate? How can menCatholics who wear conspicuous medals to prove itwho are so child loving snip their home ties with such ease? How can a courteous people tram ple one another for a seat in a bus?

title: Columbia Trounces Yale Quintet, 9669
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7Co umbia needed a good defense to handle a sometimes difficult Vale team and that was just what the Lions worked on as they trounced the Eli, 9669, before 2,200 persons in Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight.

title: Western Union Asks a Rise In Its Rates in the State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP)West ern Union has submitted a re quest for a rate increase in service beginning March 8, the Public Service Commission said yesterday.

title: Decade of Black Struggle Has Mixed Result in South
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7Blacks and whites may now eat together publicly in the South, and frequently do. But they are still not permitted to drink together in many places. They go to baseball games, political rallies and carnivals together, but it is still hazard ous to go to church together.

title: When Remodeling, Be Vigilant
description: ETERNAL vigilance, Wen dell Phillips remarked, is the price of liberty. It is also the price a man has to pay if he is having major changes or repairs done in his country place by local help.

title: Crazy Quilt in Southern Schools
description: ATLANTAThe deadline for desegregation of nearly 50 school districts across the face of the South came and went last week with the only noteworthy progress being made in the vol ume of political stridency.

title: COLUMBIA TO MEET NEW ENGLAND FOES
description: Columbia's basketball team, winner of 14 of its first 17 games, takes its second trip into New England next week end, playing at Dartmouth Fri day and at Harvard Saturday.

title: Threat to Condors Ends Coast Water Project
description: FILLMORE, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP)Plans for an $89mil lion water project have been suspended by the Department of the Interior to head off threat to the nearly extinct California condor.

title: New Life Ahead for 1912 Fishing Boat
description: Steve Mack is a young man on the way up. On his way however, he wants to take as many other young people up with him as he can.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE FINANCIAL EDITOR:

title: ST. PETER'S REFUSES AID TO ITS MAGAZINE
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 7 School funds are being with held from Pavan, the literary magazine at St. Peter's College here, following publication of two poems in the last issue that were held to be objectionable.

title: Architecture
description: IT is hard to believe that the first major retrospec tive of the work of Bruce Goff is only now being shown in this country, packed into the tight quarters of the Architectural League. (Monday through Friday. 10 to 5, until Feb. 11, ad mission free, at 41 East 65th Street.)

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: Feb. 13MG Car Club month ly meeting at Marcpierre Res taurant, Route 110, Huntington, L.I. (exit 49 South, Long Island Expressway). Film of Shell 4000 International Rally to be shown. 8 P.M. Information: Steven C. Wieczorek, phone (516) 4810034.

title: Israel Wages War of Risky Premises
description: JERUSALEMVisitors to the Middle East seem to have stopped asking if there will be war, and if so, when? The war Is already under way, but it is almost as much a war of nerves as the conventional military kind.

title: Sports Car Club and Promoters Fuel Chill in Their Relationship
description: AMONG those hornyhanded former race drivers in Westport there is a sen sitivity that career diplo mats would be proud to have. From the Vatican of the Sports Car Club of America emanates a news release about the recent Miami meet ing of promoters of the S.C.C.A.'S three professional series of road races. The release sounds more like a diplomatic com munique. Tiptoeing through a mine field, it speaks of the business aspects of racing, including rising costs of putting on races. The re lease adds: The involvement of the promoters... in the decisionmaking process was viewed by the participants as the most significant develop ment.... One promoter put it less euphemistically: I don't like the way this meeting is going.

title: Legislators Achieve An Accord on Roaches
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 7 (UPI)After more than a year of discord, the presi dents of Puerto Rico's two legislative houses have found something they can agree upon: cockroaches.

title: About MOMA, The AWC And Political Causes
description: ELSEWHERE on this page today readers will find a letter from representatives of the Art Workers Coalition com menting on my article of Jan. 18. Do You Believe in the Principle of Museums? This letter is important, I be lieve, in two respectsfor what it says about museum policy, and for what it fails to say. Because of its im portance, I want to deal with some of the issues raised in this letter today.

title: Personality:
description: After 53 years in the dim recesses of Manhattan's Woolworth Building, the Un ion Camp Corporation moved its headquarters a few months ago to the quiet coun tryside of Wayne, N. J., where it built a light and airy office building surround ed by woods, lawns, ponds and a scattering of the Southern pine trees that have helped to make the company what it is.

title: New York: A Trial Of the Panther Credo
description: A young man stood in the freezing rain in Foley Square last Monday morning and cried out, Black power to the people! He was heard by a handful of passersby, 300 fellow sympa thizers of the Black Panther par ty, and several dozen police. The same morning 13 Black Panthers rose from their seats in the musty 13thfloor courtroom in Manhattan's Criminal Courts Building and cried out, Black power to the people! They were heard by the judge, the specta tors, and the millions who read newspapers, watch television and listen to radio.

title: Italian Mayor and Aide Form Marital Alliance
description: SAN CIPIRELLO, Sicily, Feb. 7 (Reuters) The Com munist Mayor and the Re publican Deputy Mayor of this village near Palermo have formed a nonpolitical alliancethey were married, this week.

title: Montclair State Golf Team Lists 11Match Schedule
description: An 11match schedule and participation in the New Jersey State College individual con ference and metropolitan golf intercollegiate championships has been announced for Mont clair State College's 1970 var sity golf team by Bill Dioguardi, the director of athletics.

title: Thrusters Ease Ships Into Berths
description: In the modern, doit yourself world, the man with the better gardget will come out on top.

title: W. F. Bogle Jr. Weds Miss Layng
description: COCONUT GROVE, Fla., Feb. 7In St. Stephen's Epis copal Church here this after noon Miss Susan Kennard Layng was married to War ren Frederick Bogle Jr. by the Rev. Eric Potter. The par ents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. A. Gardiner Layng of Glen Ridge, N. J., and Chebeague Island, Me., and Mr. and Mrs. Bogle of Lynd hurst. N. J.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Banbury Cross, Kenil worth Road, Rye, N. Y. Green and open working hunters, ponies, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: Gradwell M. Girardi Weds Keavy Conley
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 7  Miss Keavy Conley, daughter of Mrs. John Con ley, was married at the Ro man Catholic Church of St. Augustine here today to Gradwell Mark Girardi.

title: Life on the Aryan side
description: This novel is an attempt to portray the life of Jews in Po land after Sept. 1, 1939  specifically those Jews, who, by various stratagems, man aged to stay out of concentra tion camps. It is the story of the destruction of a wealthy family presided over by patri archal Hermann Weil, and par ticularly it is the story of Elli, his teenage granddaughter, who survived.

title: Jordan Gets Loan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 7 (Reuters)The United States international Development Agency will lend Jordan more than $5million to improve internal telephone and cable communications, it was an nounced here this week.

title: MARTHA BRAUN
description: Miss Martha Braun, owner of Stella Braun, Inc., couture dress shop at 1134 Madison Avenue, died Friday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 60 years old and lived at 135 East 83d Street. A broth er and four sisters survive.

title: Foes of Channel Tunnel Hopeful
description: ROTTERDAM, The Nether lands, Feb. 7The plan for tunnel under the English Chan nel between Britain and France appears to be growing less likely in the view of some shipping and industrial inter ests.

title: MARAVICH SCORES 69 POINTS IN LOSS
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 7 A rough, wideopen basketball game ended in a brawl between players and fans as Alabama beat Louisiana State, 106104, today.

title: U.S. ASKED TO BAN BOOK IN ALABAMA
description: TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE, Ala., Feb. 7  An Alabama civil rights leader asked two Federal agencies today to take steps to ban use of a fourth grade text book on Alabama history that he contended dehumanizes Negroes and glorifies the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Mrs. Former Press Secretary spills the beans
description: When Napoleon Bonaparte was sent into exile and sailed for the Isle of Elba, Liz Carpenter recalls in an introductory note to this book, he asked aloud, Whatever shall we do in that remote spot? Well, we shall write our memoirs. Work is the scythe of time. I felt exactly like Napoleon on Jan. 20, 1969, when went into exile in the upstairs study of my home in Washington. After six months of exile, the work was finished. The former press secretary to Lady Bird Johnson had managed to write a kind of My 1,997 Days or 45,288 Hours in the White House in only 341 pages.

title: Leahy, Rockne's Pupil, Joins Football Hall
description: Frank Leahy, whose won lost record as a coach was exceeded only by his tutor, Knute Rockne, was named yesterday to the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

title: Housing Supply in City Eroding Amid Construction Standstill
description: ECONOMIC pressures are steadily eroding the quality of New York's housing supply and shrinking the quantity at such a pace that apartments with space for an estimated 81,000 people are being abandoned by their owners each year.

title: Measures to Help To Preserve Venice Are Delayed Again
description: ROME, Feb. 7A new post ponement of a longawaited measure to help the +crumbling city of Venice and its polluted lagoon is increasing the indig nation of its citizens, who only recently began to speak out publicly in defense of their his toric home.

title: Chicago 7 to Be Allowed to Reply to U.S. Rebuttal
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP)The Government concluded its re buttal to the defense today in the trial of seven men charged with conspiracy to incite riots at the time of the 1968 Demo cratic National Convention.

title: Kings Point Swimmers Post 6638 Triumph Over N.Y.U.
description: Jim Brennan, a freshman, won two individual events and an chored a victorious relay race today in leading the Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy to a 6638 swimming triumph over New York University at the loser's Quigley Pool in the Bronx.

title: ST. JOHN'S SUFFERS FIRST SWIM DEFEAT
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 7 St. John's University's swim ming team, undefeated in its first nine meets, suffered its first loss, 6053, today to West Chester State Teachers.

title: Hostel Hopping, FamilyStyle, in Norway
description: VOSS, NorwayThe hostel here, a singlestory, weatherfaded building, is not among the largest or most modern of the 165 in Norway. But it has a reputation among winter sports enthusiasts and summer tourists for cozy camaraderiethanks in large measure to Oswald, the warden, or man in charge.

title: Through the Iron Curtain Aboard the Korridorzug
description: LOIPERSBACHSCHATTENDORF, Austria  For little more than it costs to ride the subway in New York, one can take a train through Hungary's Iron Curtain and get closeup views of that Communist coun try's fences, watchtowers, border guards and collective villages.

title: Dawn G. Rudisill Engaged to Wed Dan M. Bonsanti
description: DUMONT, N. J., Feb. 7 The Rev. and Mrs. Glenn H. Rudisill of Dumont have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dawn Gayle Rudisill, to Dan M. Bonsanti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Bonsanti, also of Dumont.

title: Mann Follows Wife Into Opera
description: ONE of the New York City Opera's lead ing sopranos, Patricia Brooks, has been mar ried for 16 years to Theodore Mann, a wellknown theatri cal producer and director. It wasn't until last summer, how ever, that Mann was lured into staging an opera, when he tackled Puccini's Gianni Schicchi for the Lake George company in upstate New York. He liked the experience well enough to take on another work, this time for the City Opera. Tomorrow he begins rehearsing that company's re vival of Benjamin Britten's The Turn of the Screw, which will be given for the first time this season on March 1.

title: YALE ASKS E.C.A.C. TO ASSAIL N.C.A.A.
The Week in Finance:
description: FINANCIAL MARKETS soared early last week on the wings of some flimsy hopes rather than on concrete developments. Some sectors of the market remained in a more lofty orbit throughout the week, but others were quickly hauled back to earth by the hard realities of a stilldeclining inflationdominated economy.

title: A Village of Craftsmen Preserves the Japan of Old
description: TAKAYAMA, Japan  Old Japan, which in Tokyo and other indus trialized cities seems buried under clouds of smog, screeches of brakes and the glittering neon of gogo nightclubs, is alive and well here in this small town in the foothills of the Japanese Alps on Honshu Island. Some how, Takayama has retained the style and flavor of the past in its daily life and, most especially, in centuriesold festivals, which the townspeople re enact every spring and fall.

title: Program for the Cities
description: The tenpoint urban program sketched by White House spokesmen during President Nixon's visit to Indianapolis this week is not a new program, but an old program; and it consists more of gauzy rhetoric than firm commitment. Some of the proposed points revenue sharing, for examplemight actually be detrimental to the cities by siphoning away funds that otherwise would have gone to ease the plight of slumdwellers and diverting these funds to states and their suburban areas.

title: Kerr on Sheep on the Runway
description: ART BUCHWALD is one of the marvels of the age, a man who can be funny as many times a week as anybody will print him and still come up fresh each and every unbelievable time, and I suppose it's just as well that he can't write a play to top or even keep company with all those col umns. It would have made him too marvelous, and led to hubris, which all my friends tell me is a good thing to avoid.

title: I Don't Run Away From the Truth
description: EILEEN FARRELL is a study in pure energy at work burning out a limit less fuel supply. An interview is a kaleidoscope of feelings, thoughts, remembrances. The door to the hotel room opens to the knock and there she stands, about 5 feet 4 in heels and a big woman. Her graying hair is blond now, upswept and short, and the blackbrown eyes send little sparks out over the hilly cheeks. Maillol had her in mind when he sculpted his heroic motherfigures.

title: Ashe, Smith Favored In Schaefer Tourney
description: Arthur Ashe and Stan Smith have been installed as cofavorites to win the SchaeferJaycee tennis clas sic, which gets under way tomorrow.

title: Pacers' 4thQuarter Spurt Tops Floridians, 122115
description: ANDERSON, Ind., Feb. 7 (AP) Four Indiana players scored over 20 points each tonight as the Pacers defeated the Miami Floridans, 122115, in an Ameri can Basketball Association game.

title: Garden Dog Show Opens Tomorrow
description: The Westminster Kennel Club dog show that will run for two days in Madison Square Gar den, starting tomorrow, will have a new schedule for bench ing the dogs and judging them. The change is important to any Ine interested in seeing specific breeds because not all the 2,611 dogs entered will be in the building on any one day. Ex amination of the program in this issue is recommended to see what breeds will, be judged when.

title: Foreign Affairs: Blunder on the Left
description: ROMEDespite the rumors which occasionally spice Ro man conversation during still another Italian political crisis, it would be a profound mistake to think there will be any de parture here from legal, con stitutional forms. There isn't going to be a coup d'tat from the right and there isn't going to be a coup d'tat from the left.

title: Gypsy Moth Threat To Eastern Forests Linked to DDT Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)  The gypsy moth, once con fined to the Hudson River re gion, is now infiltrating public and privately owned forests as far south as Virginia and threat ening future supplies of wood products.

title: Roughing It by Otobus Across the Other Side of Turkey
description: IZMIR, Turkey  It was only 7 o'clock in the morning, but already the heat was moving in. My husband and I might have beaten it some by taking the regularly scheduled bus at 3 A.M., but we had no enthusiasm for such an early rising. Instead, arrangements had been made for us to take the postal bus at 8.

title: Laver and Roche Gain Tennis Final; Mrs. King Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7The men considered the two best tennis players in the world, seeded No. 1 and 2 in the tour nament, both Australian and lefthanded, will meet tomor row for the $10,000 first prize in the International Tennis Players Association indoor open.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY FEBRUARY 8, 1970

title: DUQUESNE DOWNS PROVIDENCE, 7066
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7 (AP) Jarrett Durham sparked Du quesne to a 7066 victory over the Providence Friars today, tossing in 21 points.

title: Rail Talks: A Study in Chaos and Confusion
description: The Railway Labor Act of 1926, most durable of the na tion's statutory safeguards against strikes, seems likely to join the Iron Horse on the junk pile this year. No industry com pares with the railroads in la bormanagement turbulence even in a year that Federal officials expect will be full of big strikes.

title: Point of View
description: THERE is clear evidence of urban disaster on this page today. The process of abandonment of sound housing in the midst of a housing short age is epidemic. At least 100,000 apartments have already been lost. Another halfmillion are now threat ened1,35b,000 people who will have to find new places to live in a city where there are no new places to live.

title: Iris Murdoch's thirteenth novel, about evil
description: At the climax of this, Iris Mur doch's 13th novel, Hilda Foster, alone in an isolated cottage, receives an important telephone call. If she can get through to her husband in Lon don and tell him what she has just learned, a major tragedy will be pre vented. With shaking hands she puts down the receiver and thendamn knocks the telephone off the table. Broken. The nearest working tele phone is in the village, miles away. Hilda runs outside, climbs into the car, turns the key. Nothing; an empty whirring sound. Oh no, she thinks. The car does not start; the message is not transmitted; the tragedy is averted.

title: Russo, Jersey Mafia Figure, Hospitalized in Long Branch
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 7 Anthony (Little Pussy) Russo, reputed rackets boss of Mon mouth County, was reported today to be in good condition at Monmouth Medical Center. The Mafia figure left Mercer County Jail in Trenton last night to seek medical treat ment for a variety of ailments.

title: Scott Trull Weds Pamela McCrory
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 7The marriage of Miss Pamela Syl via McCrory to Charles Scott Trull took place in Christ's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The Rev. James Lodwick performed the cere mony.

title: My Favorite Rock Musical Thus Far
description: THE Last Sweet Days of Isaac is my fa vorite rock musical thus far for three reasons: (a) The songs end when they are over; (b) While a boy and girl are doing all that talking about coming alive, they are alive; and (c) Language at last is beginning to rise to the beat.

title: POLICE CHIEF QUITS IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: MANILA, Feb. 7President Ferdinand E. Marcos today ac cepted the resignation of Brig. Gen. Vicente Raval, chief of the Philippine Constabulary, who had been accused of per mitting police brutality during a riot at the presidential palace here last week at which five students were killed.

title: 5 ARAB COUNTRIES BEGIN CAIRO TALKS ON WAR STRATEGY
description: CAIRO, Feb. 7  Five Arab countries engaged in the strug gle with Israel opened a strat egy conference here tonight in the wake of some of the sharp est fighting since the 1967 war, and amid warnings of worse fighting to come.

title: U.S. AND BOLIVIA MEND RELATIONS
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 7 With Bolivia in the throes of her spectacular annual carnival, even leftist Government offi cials and representatives of Bolivia Gulf Oil Company are drinking and laughing together.

title: Bridge
description: It is customary to sneer at players who lead out aces and kings when defending, for such a policy will usually help the declarer on the road to his contract by promoting his queens and jacks.

title: Octogenarian Honors Late Wife With a Gift to the Neediest Cases
description: Charles H. Grenberg of East 96th Street was born in 1890, the year that marked the begin ning of the last decade of the 19th century.

title: Premium Lists Distributed
description: Premium lists were distrib uted last week for the Saw Mill River Kennel Club allbreed show to be held at the West chester County Center, White Plains, N. Y., on March 8. As usual, the event provides no variety group nor bestinshow classes. The entry is limited to 1,000.

title: RUSSIAN U.N. AIDE ARRESTED AS SPY
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 7A Soviet employe of the United Nations was arrested today and charged with espionage in trying to ob tain secret information about the missile defense of the Pa cific Northwest.

title: CORNELL SIX GAINS 17TH VICTORY IN ROW
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 7Un defeated Cornell scored three times in the second period, to rout Brown, 51, tonight for its 17th victory, while Brown now has an 871 wonlosttied record. The triumph also was Cornell's 29th in a row in Ivy play, a league record:

title: FIGHT ON PRAYER IN SCHOOL PUSHED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7The protracted battle over constitu tionality of prayer and Bible readings in public school class rooms has been taken to the Federal Court of Appeals here by both sides.

title: FAMILY PLANNING IS GAINING IN INDIA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 7A team of United Na tions experts has reported gen eral progress by the Indian Government on a major family planning program that they hope will help restrain the enormous population growth.

title: Coalition Is Formed For Better Housing In Rural Sections
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Formation of a nationwide, nonpartisan coalition to wipe out rural shacks and replace them with decent homes was announced today.

title: Celibacy Issue Worries interAmerican Bishops
description: MIAMI, Feb. 7The contro versy surrounding celibacy of priests in the Roman Catholic Church weighed heavily on an interAmerican conference of bishops here this week.

title: Congo to Honor Lumumba
description: KINSHASA, The Congo Feb. 7 (UPI)The Congolese Govern ment announced today that it would bulid a 564foot monu mentslightly taller than the Washington Monument  to Patrice Lumumba, first Premier of the Congo after it gained its independence from Belgium. Mr. Lumumba was killed in Ka tanga Province in 1961.

title: Indiana School PhaseOut Plan Stirs Talk of Peaceful Protests
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 7  Parent groups and Negro or ganizations here planned to protest peacefully next week a decision of the Indianapolis, board of school commissioners to phase out two high schools in response to charges of racial segregation by the United States Department of Justice.

title: T.V.A. Getting New Equipment To Cut Pollution by Generators
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 7 The Tennessee Valley Authority is adding new air pollution con trol equipment at coalfired generating plants. The work is expected to bring the overall cost of air pollution control at new and existing installations to $100million.

title: Jumped, fell, pusheddifferent motions for different motives
description: At dawn of March 10, 1948, Czech oslovakia's immensely popular For eign Minister, Jan Masaryk, a demo cratic idealist, fell to his death from the bathroom window of his apart ment at the Czernin Palace in Prague.

title: Harris Captures 300 and 60 in Coaches Ft. Worth Event
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. (AP)Earl Harris of Oklahoma State, overshadowing several Olympians, streaked to a dou ble victory last night in the Coaches Indoor Games.

title: Legislators Cite Westchester Issues
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7  There was a time when a Westchester legislator could just about go to sleep for months, State Senator John E. Flynn said in his office here the other day.

title: Canada Will Limit Phosphate Content Of Detergents Soon
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 7 (AP)Re sources Minister J. J. Greene has announced that Federal regulations to control phos phate content of detergents will come into effect not later than this summer and phos phates probably will be banned within three years.

title: 51 Sunfish Class Boats to Race In St. Thomas Event on Friday
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 7Fiftyone tiny sailboats from 11 nations will compete next Friday through Sunday in the first Sunfish Class world championships.

title: Meningitis Death Closes School in Orange County
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Feb. 7 (AP)The death of a 107year old boy who had spinal menin gitis has prompted Orange County health officials to close the school the boy attended and urge parents of other chil dren to seek medical advice.

title: In Congress It's Not One Budget; It's a Half Dozen
description: WASHINGTONIn sending his precariously balanced $200.8billion budget to Congress last week, President Nixon dipped his toe into waters large ly avoided by his predecessors. He gently suggested that Con gress might want to think about improving its own way of han dling the budgetan issue that has reached such seriousness that some observers have con cluded that a rational fiscal pol icy is all but impossible in the United States.

title: Bermuda Currency Shift
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Banks reported to day all was going smoothly in Bermuda's conversion to deci mal currency.

title: Home Improvement
description: NOTHING can make a winter evening as pleasant as a cheer fully blazing fire in the home fireplace  but the pleasure will be shortlived if the fire smokes and sputters, or if the homeowner has to spend the entire evening try ing to get it started.

title: A Champion Tenor
description: JUST moments before the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera com menced the prelude to Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana, a few weeks ago, Franco Corelli, an Italian tenor, took his place backstage trembling with fear. His pulse, normally a lethargic 58, was throbbing at more than 130. His teeth chattered and his legs were quivering like mandolin strings.

title: Charlotte Busing Order Pits Parents vs. Students
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 7 While many parents are calling for defiance of a court order for desegregation during the cur rent school year, a group of students are asking their par ents to set an example by ob serving the law.

title: ARMY TEAMS WIN IN TRACK AND SWIM
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 7 Bruce Olson set a field house and academy high jump record and the Army track team turned in its finest performance of the season today in defeating Princeton University, 7336.

title: Dr, Daniel Ludwig Is Dead; Former Fordham Biologist
description: Dr. Daniel Ludwig, an insect physiologist and former profes sor of biology at Fordham Uni versity, died Friday in his home at 2557 Mickle Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Five Plays I'd Like to See Revived
description: By NORMAN MAILER

title: Laotian Refugee Airlift To End Early This Week
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 7 (Reuters)The giant airlift of 18,000 refugees whose homes are endangered by a threat ened North Vietnamese at tack on the strategic Plaine des Jarres should be com pleted by early next week, United States sources said to day.

title: Halaby Predicts Role For Airlines in Space
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP)Najeeb E. Halaby, president of Pan American World Airways, predicts that Pan AM and other carriers will be in the space trans portation business in the nineteeneighties.

title: Policeman Denies Panthers' Charge
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7A Black Panther charge that one of its leaders had pleaded guilty in the fatal shooting of another Panther because his brother, a policeman, had put extreme pressure on him was labeled an unmitigated lie by the policeman yesterday.

title: When mothers need mothering
description: WHEN a bottlenosed dolphin gives birth to a calf, other adult females in the group help out by keeping her off spring afloat until he can fend for himself or until the mother regains her strength. Similarly, adult fe male elephants, in response to some yet unknown signal, will separate from the rest of the herd with a pregnant female. They remain close during her labor and delivery, being protective and sup portive, until they all rejoin the group many weeks later.

title: Caviar and Suckling Pig A Memorable Breakfast
description: LONDON, Feb. 7For Lord Gladwyn, one personal remi niscence of Yalta is the food. He had come from wartime Britain, where the diet was Spartan.

title: Bell System Evolving Methods to Handle Business of Giant Phone Users
description: Ma Bell has turned the tables on eight of the na tions major companies: it's making them serve as guinea pigs for future system plan ning.

title: Reader's Report
description: The Broadbelters

title: The Development of Hovercraft Leaves Wake of Financial Problems in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 7The de velopment of hovercraft air cushion vehicles is leaving a wake of assorted prob lems in Britain, where the novel form of transportation is being promoted the hard est.

title: Education
description: Examining the impact of tech nology on American education in 1969 is like examining the im pact of the automobile on Ameri can life when the Model T Ford first came on the market.

title: COUNCIL STUDYING TEENAGE PARENTS
description: The people at the school used to attend will all know I've had the baby. I don't care where I go because I just want to learn, but I can't put up with their attitudes and their snide comments so I'm not going back to school.

title: Suit Over Draft in Utah Attacks Mormon Missionary Deferments
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 7  A system that allows the Mor mon church to nominate about 2,600 young men annually for twoyear draft deferments as missionaries is under attack in the Federal District Court here.

title: BODY OF HAMPTON EXHUMED IN SOUTH
description: HAYNESVILLE, La., Feb. 7 (UPI)  The Claiborne Parish Sheriff's office said today that the body of the Black Panther leader, Fred Hampton, was exhumed yesterday for a third autopsy.

title: Filipino Champion Beaten
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 7 (AP)Gilbert Biondi, 35year old Australian lightweight, out pointed Rudy Gonzales, the Flipino champion, in a 10round bout tonight.

title: Ailing Howe Has to Default In Squash Racquets Event
description: Ralph Howe, me topseeded player in the Harry Cowles squash racquets tournament at the Harvard Club, had the flu and lost his match by default yesterday. But three other top seeded players won and ad vanced to the semifinals.

title: Junior Handler World Series Takes Spotlight Here
description: The world series for junior handling takes place on Tues day night.

title: Advertising:
description: A few years back Paul Foley, news writer turned ad writer turned agency mogul, felt strongly about a rather effete type face proposed for a poster advertising the ex citing goingson at a race track. And rather than simply Saying Change it to the art director, he went back to the old Underwood in his office and pounded out a twopage memo that explained how type in ads can impart the tone of the message.

title: Mayor Stokes and Hays Are Received by Pope Paul
description: ROME, Feb. 7 (UPI)Repre sentative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio and Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleveland called on Pope Paul VI today in separate pri vate audiences.

title: Soviet Students Capture Figure Skating Dance Title
description: LENINGRAD, Feb. 7 (AP) Ludmila Pahhomova and Alek sandr Gorshkov, Moscow stu dents, became the first Rus sians ever to win the dancing title of the, European figure skating championships, Tass re ported today.

title: Yalta Conference 25 Years Ago Is a Memory, Not Myth, to Harriman and Bohlen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The two senior surviving American participants in the Yalta confer ence, reminiscing a quarter of a century after that historic effort to shape the postwar world, see it as a landmark in United States diplomacy despite the criticisms it later drew.

title: Stage: Congo's Upheaval
Gail Morrison Wed to Lieut. J. C. Shine
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y. Feb. 7  Miss Gail Embree Morrison and Lieut. Jonathan Cameron Shine were married this afternoon in the Briarcliff Congrega tional Church by the Rev. John McComb, chaplain of Syracuse University. The Rev. Stuart E. Rapp assisted.

title: Observer: Sooscoization
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Colonel Sulla is in Washington. To house his retainers, staff and wives, he has rented an entire hotel, the name of which may not be disclosed to the public because the colonel is traveling incognito.

title: Someone Else Might Be Even Worse Than Husak
description: PRAGUEWhen Gustav Husak succeeded Alexander Dubcek as the Communist party chief here nine months ago, a leading lib eral told a visitor: We know Husak is an oldline Communist, cunning and pragmatic. He'll dis mantle the reform movement. Just how far he will go remains to be seen. After all, he is an enigma to us.

title: Contaminant in Pesticide Linked to Defects in Mice
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 7 (UPI) The Agriculture Department has announced that a toxic contaminant in samples of a controversial weed killer might have caused birth defects in mice.

title: KNICKS TOP ROYALS AT GARDEN, 121114, BY CHECKING RALLY
description: As everyone west of Never Never Land expected, the New York Knickserbockers defeated the Cincinnati Royals last night in their National Basketball As sociation game before a capa city crowd of 19,500 at Madi son Square Garden. The score was 121114.

title: Congressmen Criticize the U.N. As a Passive Witness to Events
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Two Congressmen who were mem bers of the United States dele gation to the United Nations General Assembly last fall criticized the international or ganization today as a passive witness to events and recom mended steps that the United States should take to help make it more effective.

title: PISTONS TURN BACK SONICS FIVE, 113109
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) Dave Bing scored 32 points and Otto Moore had a career high of 27 to lead the Detroit Pis tons to a 113109 victory over the Seattle Sonics in the Na tional Basketball Association tonight.

title: Miss Cynthia Gail Hamilton Wed to John Richard Phillippe
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 7Miss Cynthia Gail Hamil ton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Hamilton Jr., was married here this afternoon to John Richard Phillippe, son of Mrs. Gerald L. Phillippe of Greenwich, Conn., and North Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Phillippe, who was chair man of the board of the Gen eral Electric Company.

title: MARAVICH SCORES 69 POINTS IN LOSS
Giants' Johnson Fears Phipps and Jones on Spot With Hostile Cleveland Fans
description: Ron Johnson doesn't feel sorry for him self, not even with his new furniture, his bank job and his fans all back in Cleve land. The man he feels sorry for is Mike Phipps.

title: Deformities and Hemorrhaging Laid to Forest Spray in Arizona
description: GLOBE, Ariz., Feb. 7  Robert McKusick is a potter who raises goats on a small farm tucked into the scrubby foothills of the Pinal Moun tains. Until 1965, more than 200 goats were born here; only one was born dead, and none was deformed.

title: Anne L. Conklin Plans Nuptials To John Ogden
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., Feb. 7Mr. and Mrs. William P. Conklin have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Anne Lawrence Conklin, to John Cabot Ogden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dayton Ogden of New Ca naan.

title: NEW BALLET TEAM MAKES U.S. DEBUT
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7  Boston came up with some notable firsts in culture last night, not the least of which was the burly helmeted policeman who, when asked which way to the Savoy Theater, responded eagerly, To the ballet? Two blocks to the right.

title: PROTESTERS DEFY NEW ULSTER LAM
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 7Civil rights demonstra tors in Belfast and nine provin cial towns defied the Northern Ireland Government's new Pub lic Order Act today by sitting down in the streets and dis rupting traffic and Saturday shopping for short periods.

title: French Feeling the Pinch of Rule Limiting Ski Teams
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 7Henri Duvillard is the 12th best slalom skier in the world, according to the Fed eration Internationale de Ski ratings.

title: McLain Is Working Out of Money Jam
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP)How could a baseball star who says he makes $200,000 a year from all sources have financial problems? Ask Denny McLain.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Inspection of the record would suggest that the pub lished works of R. T. M. Scott consist of only eight books. Further research would disclose that seven of these volumes published between 1923 and 1947feature the exploits of Aurelius SmithSecret Serv ice Smith  a detective and international adventurer whose career was born in the early pulps. However, even apart from the Smith saga, Scott was an active contributor to the pulps, and in 1933presumably to offer competition to the then wellestablished Shadow  he launched a series of magazine novels about the Spider. Now, as part of a revival of interest in pulp fiction, we are offered a package deal for the first two Spider novels, THE SPIDER STRIKES and THE WHEEL OF DEATH (Berkley, paper, 60 cents).

title: Diary of A Harlem Schoolteacher
description: This past Dec. 4, Nathan Brown, Acting Superintendent of Schools in New York City, told the State As sembly that Nobody knows why certain [poor] children are not prof iting from the educational program. He urged that New York State seize the national leadership in education by establishing a research program to find out.

title: BOOM IS BUSTED AT CAPE KENNEDY
description: COCOA, Fla.,A sadfaced blonde wearing pink stretch pants, the ashes from her ciga rette falling onto an afghan she was crocheting, summed up the failing Cape Kennedy space boom for a visitor at a coin laundry:

title: What not to do in the theater
description: Nobody knows better than Jerzy Grotowski how, in the theater even more than in the other arts, the likeliest fate of original ideas is a swift congealing into formula, and how what one proposes as spirit is almost unfailingly seized on for con version into property. Stanislayski, Grotowski recently remarked, was killed by his disciples, and I think I am going the same route. Dis ciples are of course idolaters; much more interested in usefulness than in truth, they kill by handling, by the manipulation of intellectual acts and the wielding of consciousness as though it were materiel. Stanislayski was brought down by the construc tion of a method out of his liberat ing ideas, Antonin Artaud by a hy postatized and selfconscious thea ter of cruelty and Grotowski, the third great original theater mind of the century, will be laid low by hav ing his poor theater turned into a blueprint.

title: Puerto Vallarta and the Growth of Gringo Gulch
description: PUERTO VALLARTA, MexicoSet at the curving base of Bahia de Banderas halfway down Mexico's Pacific coast, but sharing the latitude and climate of the Hawaiian Islands, Puerto Vallarta and its environs are rapidly developing into a yearround tourist mecca. With its whitesand beaches backed by jungled slopes, the area is becoming the playground for Guadalajara, which lies 125 miles to the east.

title: BERKELEY EYES TENANTS' STRIKE
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 6 Berkeley's landlords and ten ants eyed each other warily this week waiting for first indi cations of the effectiveness of a longthreatened rent strike.

title: Pangs of Prosperity
description: IN SPITE of new television contracts with guarantees of $167million through 1973, football teams continue to raise ticket prices because of increases in costs. Perhaps the club owners are anticipat ing the outcome of the con tract negotiations with the Players Association, scheduled to start tills spring. The latest club to raise prices was the Washington Red skins. The choice 1,724 mezzanine seats in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium went from $10 to $12, thus tying a record top set by the Eagles for certain seats in the new Philadelphia stadium.

title: Laurie A. Kammler Plans Wedding
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Feb. 7  The engagement of Miss Laurie Arlene Kammler to David Russell McShane has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward August Kam mler Jr. of Cranford and Wolfeboro, N. H., parents of the bridetobe. Mr. McShane is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Russell McShane of Mont clair.

title: Japan Termed A Trade Threat
description: LONDON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Board of Trade's Presi dent, Roy Mason, said re cently that Japan is attack ing Britain's Far Eastern markets everywhere with persistence and aggression.

title: PENN TURNS BACK DARTMOUTH, 9668
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 7 The University of Pennsylvania lived up to its national ranking as the Quakers romped to 9668 Ivy League basketball victory over Dartmouth before a crowd of 2,000 tonight in Alumni Gym.

title: Colby Five Wins, 8467
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt., Feb. 7 (AP)Doug Reinhardt scored 25 points today to pace Colby to an 8467 basketball victory over Norwich, Colby led, 3528, at halftime.

title: In Palm Beach Art Is One Of Life's Staples
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  There are five art galleries for every grocery store in this resort, and that is only the beginning of the area's finearts fixation. The town's two banks change their painting dis plays weekly, and many of the restaurants have rotating exhibits. Then, too, there are sidewalk picture sales, auc tions, the municipal auditorium and three major museums all catering to the art lover.

title: B52's Raid Despite Foe's Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 (AP)The United States command sent B52 bombers back over South Vietnam today, ignoring a Vietcong ceasefire for Tet, the Lunar New Year.

title: The New Plays
description: SHEEP ON THE RUNWAY, a comedy by Art Buchwald, amused the 12 critics who reviewed it, although four qualified their approval. Clive Barnes: An always endearing, often very funny play  a gentle but sub cutaneously corrosive sa tire on gunboat politics and the American way. The tone of the play resembles Woody Allen more than anyone elseit is a Don't Drink the Water style of writingand the individual lines are a lot funnier than the play itself. You may feel at the end of Sheep on the Runway that it is not as funny as you thought during the play. It is an eve ning that disappointingly leaves no aftertaste to lin ger in the mind. But al though the drift of the writing is obvious, it does always have a genuine un dertow of a ridiculously oriented wit. The staging by Gene Saks was a delight and the cast was splendid. I wholeheartedly recommend Sheep on the Runway, warts and all. It may not be perfect, but who is per fect? For Walter Kerr, see Page 5.

title: Home of President Pierce Is Periled
description: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 7 The modest home of America's 14th President may be spared from the wrecking ball if it can be removed from the path of urban renewal by April 1.

title: Academy Awards of Dogdorn Given in Variety Groups Here
description: The show dogs that won most variety groups during 1969 were honored last night at the annual KenLRation din ner at Delmonico's Hotel. The scores were figured on a na tional basis for what have been called the Academy Awards of the Dog Show World.

title: JERSEYAN TAKES JUNIOR SKI EVENT
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 8Sveinung Evensen, an 18 yearold Ramapo (N.J.) high school senior, won the New York State junior crosscountry ski championship today at the Anthony Wayne course.

title: London: Christy Brown's Triumph
description: LONDON Christy Brown is outwardly a helpless, speechless, lolling baby, in wardly an artist with a mind racing and creating . . .An Irishman of 37 who has typed a wonderful novel with the little toe of his left foot. So ran a headline on a two page profile in The London

title: Glibness in the Campaign Against Crime
description: LONDONOne of the attrac tions of Britain for Americans these days is the simple feel ing that it is safe. A person can walk through a park or down the street at night, with out giving a thought to the pos sibility of robbery or assault. By American standards the level of crime in general is low.

Rogers met today with the Mo roccan Foreign Minister, Abdel hadi Boutalch, for what he de scribed as a very friendly talk about the Moroccan economy, North African affairs and the forthcoming appointment of a new United States ambassador to Morocco.

A Traffic Department truck will patrol the length of the island from the Battery to the Henry Hudson Bridge on weekdays, 6 A.M. to 10 P.M., pushing those cars that can roll to the near est shoulder or exit.

title: FLYERS HALT WINGS AS GENDRON STARS

Twentyfour were hurt in a 16vehicle crash on Route 99 here; two were re ported in serious condition. Thirty others were injured in a 28car collision on Interstate Route 5 near Carlsbad, about 200 miles south of here. All the injuries were minor.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Widespread faults and abuses in Medicare and Medicaid, with costs mounting almost beyond control, are shown in the most extensive analysis of the two health programs yet under taken.

description: MONTREAL. Feb. 8To dis pel the present mood of uncer tainty that has been dampen ing investment in Quebec, a group of business leaders is drafting a provincial economic strategy and goals, for the period 197076.

description: CADILLAC, Mich., Feb. 8 Clarence Hill of Ishpeming, Mich., won the veterans' class competition easily today in the Briar Hill Ski Club 50meter skijumping contest.

description: George W. Rabinoff, a social work executive and educator, died Saturday at the New York Infirmary. He was 77 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that a less restrictive monetary policy at the Federal Reserve Board was needed reasonably soon to spur the economy in the second half of 1970.

In the month or two since these weekly performances were started by Jack Bradley, they, have featured such jazzmen as Julian Dash, Ray Nance, Roy Eldridge, Zoot Sims, Budd John son, Vic Dickenson and Jimmy Rushing.

description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (Reuters)  Western central bankers left an uneventful meeting of the Bank for Inter national Settlements here today conscious that Washington not Baselnow holds the key to world monetary and eco nomic developments.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Democratic leadership in Con gress responded to President Nixon's State of the Union Message today with a nation ally televised State of the Na Ition program that resembled Mr. Nixon's own 1968 campaign broadcasts.

title: Bridge:
description: SYDNEY Australia, Feb. 8 Australia defeated the unofficial United States team here today In the first of two test matches The Australians drew away in the closing stages of a well fought match to win by 36 international match points.

description: MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 8 Dr. Bernard T. Bertman, as sistant professor of physics at Wesleyan University, died last night after being stricken at his home here, apparently with a heart attack. He was 36 years old.

title: Screen: 'Molly Maguires':Ritt's Direction Sticks to Conventional Style
description: OF course they do still make movies the way they used to, and Martin Ritt, who in the recent past earned a reputation for a certain ambiguous modernism ("Hud" and "The Spy Who Came in from the Cold"), has now, with "The Molly Maguires," directed a film almost wholly involved with old conventional ways of seeing and old conventional ways of putting together a movie.Nothing about the old conventions, or in the elaborate rhetoric of cranes and tracks, precludes great movie-making. But in "The Molly Maguires," which opened yesterday at the New Forum and Paris theaters, Ritt has so accepted the conventions and succumbed to the rhetoric that he seems less to have seen his movie than to have assembled a plausable sequence of stock responses, stunning devices and generic touches."The Molly Maguires" is full of illustrations, but quite without insight. The camera pans not so much to reveal action as to show off the mood and detail of a setting. And on the immensely realistic (and admirably atmospheric) main street of the film's Pennsylvania mining town, one has the feeling that even the dogs run out and bark on cue.The Molly Maguires were a secret society of Irish-American coal miners who in the second half of the 19th century fought by sabotage and murder against their overseers and for better pay in the mines. The mine owners finally subdued them with the aid of a Pinkerton detective, James McParlan, who worked himself into the Molly Maguires, won their confidence, and then identified and testified against their leaders in a trial that cost them their lives.The film attempts to dramatize the situation of McParlan (Richard Harris), torn between his instincts and his interests. He is identified with the workers but assigned to the side of the ownersrepresented solely by one incredibly evil black-coated, black-browed police captain (Frank Finlay), who keeps materializing for rendezvous on hill sides, in mine shafts, and wherever you would not expect him to be.McParlan is intended therefore as a kind of modern hero, with the right reactions and the wrong credentials.
