Near the beginning, he announces one sort of motivation ("I'm tired of always looking up. I want to look down.") and at the end, when he admits in court that he is a detective, he essentially proclaims another. In between, he sides with the Maguires and gets off one-liners against police brutality while making his secret reports to the captain. This method of seeing both sides amounts to having it both ways, and the film never sustains enough tension within either character or situation to keep each gesture, confrontation or crises from seeming at least slightly gratuitous.The cast, an exceptionally attractive cast, does pretty well considering that only a few of its members have real characterizations they can settle into. Samantha Eggar as the strong-willed girl who loves and leaves McParlan, suffers least because she is allowed the expression of some definable emotions. Sean Connery, the leader of the Molly Maguires, suffers most because his role is the most arbitrarily closed. But when he and Richard Harris act together they create a superb and powerful sense of presence that almost hides the absence of anything very meaningful for them to say. Under the realistic coal dust that begrimes their faces, Harris and Connery wear realistic sun tans. Everybody else is appropriately pale, and the miners as they work cough a lot.Realism without much reality, enormous care for the wrong details, historical accuracy and spineless dramaturgy, "The Molly Maguires" vacillates among intentions and settles finally for ponderous spectacle and easy irony. There is a world of difference separating the opening camera movement from rising sun down a strong diagonal structure to the mine entrance itself, and the final shot that imposes McParlan against the gallows he has helped to build.But between the impulses controlling these scenes there is very little to choose. Personally I prefer the well-oiled mechanics of James Wong Howe's camera and the intricacies of Tambi Larson's Hollywood-sound-stage coal mine to the timid positions of Walter Bernstein's screenplay. In any case, both are subject to a directorial hand that mistakes effects for effectiveness and replaces complexity with confusion.

title: Tostao Ready to Go Home
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)  Brazil's No. 2 soccer player, Eduardo Goncalves (Tostao) Andrade, who underwent suc cessful eye surgery last Octo ber, will leave Tuesday for home. He's in perfectly good health, Mrs. Jorge de Oliviera Maia, wife of the Brazilian Con sul General, said today. Andrade has been staying with the Maia family during convalescence.

title: Australian Recalls A Second Grenade In Danang Incident
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 (UPI)Australian enter tainers who were performing for United States Marines when a grenade explosion in an en listed men's club killed marine and wounded 62 others said today that they had seen grenades lobbed from each side of the club.

title: U.S. Reports Third Autopsy On Body of Panther Leader
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Feb. 8 (UPI)United States Marshal Joseph W. Keene said today he had carried out the order for a third autopsy on the body of Fred Hampton, slain Black Panther leader, but refused to discuss circumstances surround ing the exhumation and au topsy.

title: National Trends Found
description: Racial polarization, disrup tions and growing racial ten sions that sometimes explode into violence are plaguing school administrators in vir tually every part of the country where schools have substantial Negro enrollments.

title: COLUMBIA SEEKING YOUNGER TRUSTEES
description: The trusteeumbia Uni versity announced yesterday that they have abolished the re quirement that alumni trustees must have graduated from the university at least 10 years be fore their appointment to the board, thus making possible the selection of younger trustees.

title: 2 Killed in Michigan Blaze
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Feb. 8 (AP)  Two persons were killed early today when fire swept through two floors of the fourstory Gilbert Hotel in down town Battle Creek, firemen re ported. The identities of the vic tims were not immediately known.

title: Humphrey Urges Timetable For Vietnam Withdrawal
description: MIAMI, Feb. 8 (AP)Former Vice President Hubert H. Hum phrey conceded today that President Nixon is making political points with his Viet nam policy, but the Minnesota Democrat said the Administra tion needed to establish a time table for troop withdrawal.

title: HOOPER'S 69 FOR 275 TAKES PANAMA GOLF
description: PANAMA CITY, Feb. 8 (UPI) Herb Hooper, a 30yearold pro from Richmond, who shot an eagle on the 12th hole, carded a threeunderpar 69 to day and won the 15th annual Panama open.

title: LISTON OAK DIES; LEFTIST EDITOR
description: Liston M. Oak, a leader in the politics of the American left and a former managing editor of The New Leader, died Fri day in Tel Aviv, while on a visit. He was 74 years old and lived in Long Valley, N. J.

title: School Board by a Vote of 3to2 Opposes Repeal of Blaine Law
description: The New York City Board of Education voted 3 to 2 yester day to oppose a controversial bill that would repeal the State Constitution's ban on financial I aid to schools with religious affiliation.

title: Plan for Licensing All Auto Repairmen Is Before Council
description: Prompted by increasing complaints about poor work manship, padded bills and de fective parts used in auto repair work, the City Council will consider legislation to re quire licenses for mechanics.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER BLUES, 7 TO 1
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)Don Marcotte, a rookie wing, scored three goals and John McKenzie two tonight in a 71 romp by the Boston Bruins over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Federalism Gains in the Common Market
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 8The six governments of the European Economic Community have just tied up the loose ends of what is regarded as one of their most significant agreements since the 1957 Treaty of Rome establish ing the Common Market.

title: In Memoriam
description: BADERDavid. We shall always remember you with love. Shirley A, Ronnie.

title: '69 Orders and Deliveries Of Railway Cars Increased
description: The American Railway Car Institute and the Association of American Railroads reported over the weekend that orders and deliveries of new and re built cars showed substantial increases last year.

title: A STATE UNIT URGED TO RUN OLD HOUSING
description: A Manhattan Assemblyman has proposed legislation to create a statewide public cor poration to acquire and operate deteriorating or abandoned apartment houses.

title: In an Exercise in Political Science, Hunter Students Bring Pop Art to a Subway Station
description: A group from Hunter Col lege, using paint and balloons costing $44.25 and bubbling enthusiasm, which costs noth ing, accomplished a lightning redecoration of the Lexing ton Avenue subway station at 68th Street yesterday morning.

title: Egyptian Leader at Arab Parley
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 8Israeli jets attacked what were de scribed as military targets around Cairo today and report edly downed two MIG21's that were part of the first Egyptian aerial challenge to the raids in the Nile Delta.

title: Middle East Airlines Lifts Traffic by 6.2% Over 1968
description: Traffic increases of 6.2 per cent over 1968 were recorded by Middle East Airlines, the Beirutbased carrier reported last week, despite the political situation that hurt the tourist trade in 1969.

title: The Good Life Eludes Most Rural Brazilians
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7 President Emilio G. Mdici has asked his Government to turn its attention to the Bra zilians who make up more than half the population and live in varying degrees of poverty well outside the cities.

title: Audrey Hepburn Has Son
description: GENEVA, Feb. 8  Audrey Hepburn gave birth last night by caesarian section, at Lau sanne hospital, to a boy weigh ing 7 pounds. The 40yearold actress and the child are doing well. Miss Hepburn was mar ried a year ago to Dr. Andrea Dotti, an Italian psychiatrist. She has a son by her first mar riage, to Mel Ferrer.

title: Gaytonglen Teddy Scores In Yorkshire Terrier Show
description: Ann Seranne and Barbara Wolferman of Newton, N.J., scored notably in the 123dog specialty of the Yorkshire Ter rier Club of America at the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday. Their Ch. Gaytonglen Teddy of Mayfair won the bestofbreed title. Their Ch. Mayfair's Upsa Daisy became best of opposite sex.

title: FiveDay Forecast
description: (February 10 thruogh February 14)

title: Clothes Collected for Needy Children
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Mrs. Robert Finch and Mrs. Gilbert Hahn think every child in the District of Co lumbia should have a pair of shoes, underwear, a dress or pants and a shirt and a warm coat.

title: Budget Surplus Called Thin
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) The Council of State Cham bers of Commerce said today the $1.3billion surplus shown in President Nixon's $200.8 billion budget for the next fis cal year was extremely thin and would not survive any Congressional additions to spending programs. Eugene F. Pinta, council research direc tor, said the surplus was needed to help combat infla tion.

title: Jersey City Schools To Be Struck Today
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 8 Unionized teachers voted over whelmingly today to strike Jer sey City's four public high schools and 32 elementary schools tomorow in a contract dispute over wages.

title: Pope Asks Penance in Lent
description: ROME, Feb. 8 (Reuters) Popp Paul VI said today that the worship of pleasure had made men insensitive to mat ers of the spirit. Addressing pilgrims in St. Peter's Square. the Pope called on Roman Catholics In practice penance during Lent which begins Wednesday.

title: Bomb Destroys Vietnamese Press Center in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 A bomb thought to be 20 pounds of plastic exploded this evening at the office of the South Vietnamese National Press Center, destroying the building's secondfloor offices and setting a fire.

title: AUSSIE SHOOTS 66 FOR A 339 TOTAL
Indonesians Defectin Soviet
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Three Indonesian Air Force cadets defected to the Soviet Union after attend ing their graduation ceremony in Odessa late last month, an air force spokesman said here today. He said that Soviet au thorities had been asked to find and return them. Seventy one cadets were sent to the Soviet Union in 1965 for train ing in guided missiles and radar.

title: JAVITS IS HESITANT ON CARSWELL VOTING
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he probably would not vote to confirm the nomination of Judge G. Har rold Carswell to the United States Supreme Court, The As sociated Press reported.

title: Stage: Exchange Opens
description: BY most rules of thumb at least of most thumbs Exchange, which opened last night at the brandnew MercerO'Casey Theater, is not theater. Indeed this di verting enough evening calls itself a musical entertain ment, and it is an entertain ment closer rather to cabaret than theater.

title: Protecting Union Democracy
description: The Democratic leadership in the Senate has wisely decided to authorize a broad inquiry into legislative questions raised by the murder of Joseph Yablonski. The mine union insurgent died believing that his chal lenge of abuses in the United Mine Workers had been frustrated by the Labor Department's highly legalistic interpretation of its obligations under the union democracy provisions of the LandrumGriffin Act.

title: French Communists Oust Dissenter from Party Posts
description: PARIS, Feb. 8  The French Communist party removed an ideological thorn in its side to day by dropping Roger Garau dy, one of its principal intel lectuals, from the Central Com mittee and the Politburo.

title: Pope Asks Penance in Lent
description: ROME, Feb. 8 (Reuters) Popp Paul VI said today that the worship of pleasure had made men insensitive to mat ers of the spirit. Addressing pilgrims in St. Peter's Square. the Pope called on Roman Catholics In practice penance during Lent which begins Wednesday.

title: PALMER CAPTURES STARR SKI TROPHY
description: STOWE, Vt., Feb. 8  The East and West shared major honors in the first C. V. Starr Trophy competition as Tyler Palmer, the frecklefaced cam paigner from Kearsarge, N.H., and tall Ann Black, national downhill champion from Seat tle, won today's slalom events.

title: Europe Warned on City Growth
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 8  The towns and cities of Europe will double in popula tion in the next 15 years, creat ing vast environmental prob lems, according to a report from the Council of Europe made available here today.

title: Sun and Moon
description: The sun rises at 6:58 A.M., sets at 5:25 P.M. and will rise tomorrow at 6:57 A.M.

title: HAMILBURGS' DOG WINS SHOW PRIZE
description: The Daniel M. Hamilburgs of Brookline, Mass., came out of the American Boxer Club's ring last night laden with silver. For the fifth time within the last 10 years these New Englanders won best of breed at this event in the 71st Regiment Armory.

title: 2 TENNIS TOURNEYS STARTING TONIGHT
description: Play begins tonight in two tennis tournaments featuring worldranked stars.

title: Bill Would End SeeAll Meat Package
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8Two offi cials of the Lindsay administra tion today criticized as back ward and anticonsumer bill reintroduced in the Assem bly that would supersede New York City's law requiring pre packaged meats to be sold in containers that are transparent on all sides.

title: Special Edition Named Best
description: Ch. Special Edition made the headlines again yesterday when the Lakeland terrier was named the best of breed at the specialty of the Urrited States Lakeland Terrier Club in the 102d Engineers Battalion Armory. The show was one of 13 specialties under the aegis of the Associated Terrier Clubs.

title: Rita Walis Is Wed To W. H. Blockton
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Feb. 8 Miss Rita Dawn Walis, daugh ter of Mrs. Izhak BenMeir, was married at the Harrison Temple today to William Herbert Blockton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Blockton of Larchmont. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Arnold Kaiman, who was as sisted by Rabbi Mayer Gruber.

title: BoatBorne Pollution
description: Governor Rockefeller justly chided President Nixon the other day on the disparity between the extrava gance of the President's rhetoric in support of pollu tion control and the limited dimensions of his program for cleaning up the nation's water.

title: Personal Finance
description: There used to be a time not too many years ago when some insurance companies avoided you like the plague if you had a history of heart disease, diabetes, tuberculo sis, cancer, epilepsy, hemo philia and a wide variety of other ailments.

title: 3 GROUP JUDGINGS SLATED AT NIGHT
description: Dogs that looked extra spe cial were being walked along the streets of New York in the midtown area yesterday, par ticularly where the leading hotels were and most particu larly near Madison Square Garden. The reason for this, as always at this time, was the Westminister Kennel Club Show. It will begin for the 94th consecutive year this morning in the Garden and will last through tomorrow evening.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Following is a weekly listing of the ne asset value of closedend investment fund shares as reported by the companies through the Association of ClosedEnd Investmen Companies at the close of business Friday.

title: Lesotho Opposition Accuses Prime Minister of Plot
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 8 (Reuters)The opposition Con gress party, which claimed vic tory in Lesotho's abortive gen eral election last month, ac cused Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan today of plotting to insure the victory of his party.

title: Zealous Advocate of Conservation
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 8The Bootes of Stokeon Trent had no family motto, and so years ago young Rob ert Edward Boote, a strong willed and original English man, simply adopted one that he liked. It happened to be a slogan from an adver tisement for British Ford cars: Our policy is one of continu one of con tinuous improve ment. Mr. Boote chose well. Im provement has been the watchword of his career as a conservationist. He began by craving to improve the landscape of his native Staff ordshire, which has long been scarred by pottery mak ers' claypits and heaps of smoldering waste. Before long he was trying to im prove the environment of the entire British Isles, as a con servation adviser to Prince Philip.

title: Antipollution Cost Climbs for Industry
description: The cost to American busi ness for control of pollution rose sharply last year and is expected to go on increasing, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.

title: Soviet Pressure on Rumania Said to Be Growing After Lull of a Few Months
description: VIENNA, Feb. 8Soviet pres sure on Rumania is mounting again after a few months' lull, in the view of analysts of East ern European affairs.

title: U.P.I. and Union Reach Pact
description: United Press International and the United Telegraph Workers reached a tentative contract agreement last night that pro vides a wage increase of $35 a week over three years. Wages would go up $15 the first year and $10 the second and third years, according to the union.

title: American Airman Shot
description: MANILA, Feb. 8 (UPI)A United States airman was in fair condition at Clark Air Force Base Hospital near here after he was shot twice in the stomach last night in nearby Angeles City, allegedly by an American, the Clark Informa tion Office announced today. The office identified the wound ed man as Sgt. Frederick G. Ainsworth, 22 years old, of Hackettstown, N.J. It said a suspect had been arrested, but his name was withheld.

title: Transit Train Is Derailed
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP)  A rapid transit train was derailed today, in the fourth mishap within nine days on a new line of the Chicago Transit Au thority. Officials said no pas sengers were on the train and no injuries were reported.

title: Defense Budget Debate
description: The Administration's $71.8billion defense budget, viewed as a percentage of total Federal spending, promises to be the lowest in twenty years. It is $5.2 billion lower than defense expenditures during the current fiscal year. Yet it is headed into heavy weather in a Congress that is increasingly critical of military programs.

title: JOHN F. HUGHES
description: John F. Hughes, a coffee im porter here from 1933 until his retirement in 1963, died Satur day at the Suffolk Infirmary, Yaphank, L.I. His age was 88.

title: P.S.C. CHIEF URGES PHONE CALL CURB
description: The new chairman of the state Public Service Commis sion suggested yesterday that telephone users could contrib ute to improved service by avoiding or shortening calls during peak hours  about noon and 6 P.M.

title: Goodman Scores Conditions in City Girls' Shelter
description: State Senator Roy M. Good man charged yesterday that heroin addicts pushers, mari juana smokers and prostitutes were among the girls now housed in a cityrun shelter in the East Village.

title: Chess:
description: WALTER GOLDWATER, the bibliographer and pro prietor of the University Place Bookshop, is the new president of the Marshall Chess Club. He is also the guiding spirit of the annual Goldwater  Marshall invita tion tournament. His canny ability in overtheboard com petition is well known among metropolitan chest buffs.

title: Nixon Sends Coast Guard Tugs To Avert Jersey Health Crisis
description: Acting on orders from Pres ident Nixon, Coast Guard tug boats began pushing sludge laden barges away from the New Jersey coast yesterday in an effort to avert a possible health crisis.

title: Agribusiness Plans Aid to Latin Farms
description: Formation of an investment company to promote profitable agricultural enterprises in Latin America and turn them over to local ownership was an nounced yesterday by 12 prom inent corporations.

title: Graebner Downs Lutz In Buffalo Net Final
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 8 (AP) Clark Graebner downed Bob Lutz, 64, 36, 97, in the final of the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club invitation indoor tournament today. Graebner has now won the tourney four years in a row.

title: Kentucky, Georgia and Maravich Roll On
description: If nothing else, Ken Rose mond, Georgia's basketball coach, is making life a little tougher for the 68yearold Adolph Rupp, the baron of Blue Grass country, now in his 40th coaching season at Kentucky.

title: Soviet Women Play Chamber Music
description: The Prokofiev Quartet made its local debut at Vanderbilt Hall of New York University yesterday afternoon, and in some ways, the event was not routine.

title: BenGurion Ties Peace To Removal of Nasser
description: SDE BOKER, Israel, Feb. 8 (UPI)  President Gainai Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic must be re placed if there is to be peace in the Middle East, David BenGurion said today. Is rael's first Premier added that Mr. Nasser's position is becoming more and more critical.

title: NETS DOWN COUGARS FOR 3D IN ROW, 9588
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 8 The New York Nets stormed back from an 11point halftime deficit to beat the Carolina Cougars, 9588, today in an American Basketball Association game at Island Garden.

title: 2 COAST SETTERS TAKE TOP AWARDS
description: A measure of the geograph ical range of the dogs here for Westminster was given yester day when an Irish setter, Ch. Webline Fame 'N Fortune, and an English setter, Ch. Guys 'N Dolls Shalimar Duke, gained the main honors of their breeds in specialties at the Statler Hil ton Hotel. Both were from California.

title: Zambia Honors Tito
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)Presi dent Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia today conferred his country's highest award on vis iting President Tito of Yugo slavia, who was made a Grand Companion of the Order of Freedom.

title: Oil Slick Killing Birds Off Martha's Vineyard
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 8 (AP)  Hundreds of birds have died in recent days on South Beach, where an un explained oil slick washed ashore on the ocean side of Martha's Vineyard Island off Cane Cod.

title: Wood and Janet Lynn Head American FigureSkating Team
description: TULSA, Okla., Feb. 8With the world champion, Tim Wood of Colorado Springs, heading it, a wellbalanced United States figure skating team will com pete in the world champion ships in Ljubljana, Yugoslavia, March 2 through 8.

title: French Novels to Appear In Modern Translations
description: A longrange project to publish modern English trans lations of neglected but im portant French novels for the general reader has been un dertaken by Prof. Henri Peyre, Sterling Professor of French at Yale.

title: ESCAPED PRISONER SURRENDERS AT JAIL
description: Alton Henry Bradby, one of nine inmates who escaped from the Federal House of De tention here Friday night, re turned to the prison and sur rendered yesterday, reportedly at the uring of his family.

title: EDWARD DAVISON, POET AND TEACHER
description: Edward Davison, poet, teach er and lecturer, who retired two years ago as dean of the School of General Studies of Hunter College, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 435 East 57th Street.

title: Carswell's Opponents Find a Steadily Growing Debt But No Conflicting Investments
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  Opponents of G. Harrold Cars well's Supreme Court nomina tion are using the current delay in his Senate confirmation pro ceedings to dig exhaustively into his background for any ammunition that might block his confirmation.

title: Paradox of Big Cities: Houses Are Abandoned Despite Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8In the District of Columbia, three miles southeast of the Capitol, there is a cluster of two and threestory apartment buildings set on rolling hills and sepa rated by treelined streets, lawns, sidewalks and play areas.

title: L.I.R.R. Police Protest Ban on Guns
description: The Long Island Rail Road's police force, to protest a ban on their carrying firearms, refused to report for duty yesterday. The policemen were promptly suspended by the railroad, and they returned to their jobs last night.

title: Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Reactions Vary Widely on Bill To Protect Consumers as Class
description: An aggressive local merchant advertises refrigerators with the lowest prices in town. But a customer who bought one returns soon afterward and irately demands a refund or an adjustment be cause she found other stores in town with the same brand and model at a lower price.

title: Peace Corps Volunteer Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)  A Peace Corps volunteer, John L. Wills, 67 years old, of West Seneca, N. Y., died yes terday in Jamaica of injuries suffered in a fall from a sea shore bluff.

title: Felicia Weathers Sings Lieder And Spirituals in Debut Recital
description: Four seasons after her Met ropolitan Opera debut, Felicia Weathers came forward yester Iday afternoon to proclaim that she is not only an opera star but also a singer. Her first recital here, at Alice Tully Hall, certified her credentials as a superior musician with a prom ising sense of what it means to address an audience in the special tone of the lieder artist.

title: Doctor, Citing Studies in Buffalo, Tells Pollution Meeting Here That Environment Determines Health
description: A California physician said yesterday that the concept of health care as the treatment of separate diseases was outdated and that the total environment was the most important deter minant of health.

title: RUSSEL FINISHES 2D AFTER 2 RUNS
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 8 (UPI)  JeanNoel Augert of France won the slalom title today at the world Alpine ski championships after withstand ing determined challenges from Patrick Russel, a teammate, and Billy Kidd of the United States.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: SATURDAY NIGHTS'S GAMES

title: Seattle Mayor Says He Refused to Raid Panthers
description: SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 8 (AP) Mayor Wesley C. Uhlman has said that he turned down a Federal proposal for a raid on Black Panther headquarters in Seattle because he did not want to popularize the Panthers' cause. He also said that such raids smacked of gestapotype tactics.

title: Bill Cosby, Right Foot in a Cast, Gives 2 Shows at the Felt Forum
description: Bill Cosby flew in from Cali fornia Saturday with a broken ankle but that did not prevent him from giving the two per formances he had scheduled Saturday night at Felt Forum. With his right foot in a cast, Mr. Cosby limped slightly but otherwise was surprisingly mo bile as he told of an encounter at handball with a 79yearold man (who beat him, 213) gave a vivid synopsis of a dog movie and discussed the travails of raising small children.

title: DANCE WORKSHOP OPENS 15TH SERIES
description: The Dance Theater Workshop is a quietly persistent cultural force that during its four years of existence in a loft studio on West 20th Street has consis tently presented new choreog raphy. This past weekend, it opened its 15th studio series with four new works.

title: Bonn Officials Complete Talks in Poland and Soviet
description: BONN, Feb. 8 (AP)The For eign Ministry's state secretary, Georg Ferdinand Duckwitz, re turned today from Warsaw where he held two days of talks with too officials of Poland.

title: VICTOR DISPLAYS WIDE SUPERIORITY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8The Rocket is back on top.

title: SAIJO RETAINS TITLE, DEFEATING CHILEAN
description: TOKYO, Feb. 8 (AP)Shozo Saijo of Japan retained his World Boxing Association featherweight boxing title to night by pounding out a 15 round unanimous decision over Godfrey Stevens of Chile.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEITHER Oscar Robertson, who is considered the game's most complete performer, nor Wilmer (Bill) Hosket, who has yet to explore the boundaries his talent, played basketball last Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. Robertson, for 10 years the star of the Cincinnati Royals, was home with an injury he might have played with in another time, while Hosket, in his second year with the Knicks, sat on the bench and watched his learning curve drop. Robertson is locked in a bitter, highly publicized controversy with his new coach, Bob Cousy, and the Royals' manage ment. The club, a perennial loser, is undergoing recon struction and Robertson, at the age of 31, is apparently considered more valuable as a barter item than as a building block. A deal was negotiated to trade him to Baltimore, without his ad vice. Robertson, who has the contractual power to veto a trade, refused to go. His emotional reactions seemed to include anger and militancy and a sense of betrayal. He also said ho would not play in Cincin nati next season.

title: BUDGET SURPLUS GAINING SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 68The National Planning Association has joined the ranks of those who believe the United States may need large Federal Govern ment budget surpluses in the new decadenot for the famil iar antiinflation economic rea sons, but to fill a gap in the nation's savings.

title: Nancy Merger, Student, Engaged
description: PORT ALLEGANY, Pa., Feb. 8Miss Nancy Patricia Herger and A. Wilbur Duryee Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Dur yee of New York and Pawl ing, N. Y., plan to be mar ried on July 11.

title: Montreal School Plan Feared By EnglishSpeaking Minority
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 5  The Englishspeaking inhabitants of Montreal, roughly onethird of the 2.2 million people in the metropolitan area, are disturbed and divided by Quebec's latest move to strengthen the role of French as the province's princi pal language.

title: What to Wear Is Special Problem for Women on Television
description: THE WOMAN in front of the tele vision camera is usually famous, often glamorousand almost always welldressed. She ought to be. Dress designers court her to wear their clothes on camera, hoping for a credit at the end of the show. They also bestow upon her that hallowed honor to which so many women aspirewholesale buy ing privileges.

title: Iran's Defense Budget To Rise by Almost 50%
description: TEHERAN, Iran. Feb. 8 (Reuters)Iran announced to day an increase of almost 50 per cent in her annual de fense budget.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: El Cordobes Recovers From Goring in Bogota
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 8 (Reuters) The Spanish bull fighter Manuel Benitez, known as El Cordobes, was gored in the throat here yes terday but was reported out of danger today.

title: StatePaid School Bills
description: The proposal by Governor Milliken of Michigan to have the state take over total responsibility for financ ing the local public schools, in return for a statewide property tax levy, puts the spotlight on the many seri ous deficiencies in present methods of paying for public education. The appeals by Mayor Lindsay and his fellow mayors of New York's big cities that the state begin to assume responsibility for more, and eventually most, of the expenditures for public educa tion underscore the national significance of the Michi gan plan.

title: Major Bills in Congress
KEY TO LATIN TIES SEEN IN CONGRESS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 8 President Nixon's negotiators have averted an unpleasant confrontation with LatinAmer ican officials over interAmeri can trade and aid cooperation but only by making promises that depend on future action by the United States Congress.

title: Arafat to Visit Moscow
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 8 (AP)A spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organize lion announced here today that a sevenman delegation led by Yassir Arafat, its president, would leave for Moscow Tues day for a oneweek visit at the invitation of the Soviet Union.

title: Errors by U.S. Taxpayers Delay Payment of Refunds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that many taxpay ers were confusing itemized de ductions or personal exemp tions with adjustments, thus delaying the payment of re funds.

title: JOHN KELLY, 69, DIES; REPORTER, EDITOR
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Feb. 8 John F. Kelly, a former re porter for The New York Herald Tribune and The Hartford Cour ant, died of cancer at the Cot tage Hospital here Thursday. His age was 69.

title: Miss Bonnie Bryant Is Fiancee Of Lieut. Neil Warren Hiller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emmons Bryant of New York and Foxboro, Mass., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Bryant, to Lieut. Neil Warren Hiller, U.S.M.C.R. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Charles Hiller of Milwaukee.

title: New Brunswick Aim Is to Restore Its Former Wealth
description: FREDERICTON, New Bruns wickThis province, which was prosperous and hustling 100 years ago hut now earns only 70 per cent of the Canadian average, is engaged in economic reconstruction.

title: Thomas K. Edwards Marries Ellen Theodora Silberblatt
description: HEWLETT NECK, L. I., Feb. 8Miss Ellen Theodora Silberblatt, daughter of Mrs. Jacob Goldberg and the late Theodore Silberblatt, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Kennedy Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Edwards of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Nuptials for Christina E. O'Dunne
description: Miss Christina Ekengren O'Dunne, daughter of Mrs. Eugene O'Dunne Jr. of Wash ington and the late Mr. O'Dunne, was married on Jan. 25 to George Garrett Byers Griffin at the United States Embassy residence of Ambassador Carol Laise Bunker in Katmandu, Nepal.

title: Alzerian Car Burned in Rome
description: ROME, Feb. 8 (Reuters) Demonstrators set ablaze a car belonging to the Algerian Em bassy after scrawling Long live Israel on the windshield, the police said today.

title: 2 ExMinisters to Be Tried In Libyan Court Tomorrow
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 8 (Reu ters)Thirty persons, including two former Government minis ters, will stand trial Tuesday before a special military court on charges of plotting to over throw the revolutionary Gov ernment, the Libyan press agency reported today.

title: SON OF FUN GAINS POMERANIAN PRIZE
description: The American Pomeranian Club's annual specialty, held in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel PennGarden, was captured by Ch. Model's Son of Fun. The 2 yearold male toy is owned by Robert L. Goodrich of Hamp ton, Va., and was handled by Marlene Scott.

title: Tom Krause Sings Sibelius Airs Best In Hunter Concert
description: If one who attended Tom Krause's recital at Hunter Col lege Assembly Hall on Satur day night had left at intermis sion, he would have gone away with an incomplete notion of the Finnish baritone's effective ness on the concert platform. Mr. Krause has sung with the Metropolitan Opera, but this was his first New York recital.

title: Une de Mai Rallies to Defeat Upsalin in $54,000 Paris Trot
description: PARIS, Feb. 8Une de Mai hates Vincennes. Today, she had to face the rollercoaster course again for the third time in three weeks. She got through her ordeal as painlessly as pos sible by trotting a wise waiting race and winning in smooth style.

title: Deborah Deixel And a Physicist Married Here
description: Miss Deborah Jane Deixel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vardon E. Deixel of Wood mere, L.I., was married at the St. RegisSheraton here yesterday afternoon to Wil liam Allan Mitchell Blum berg, a physicist at the Lawrence Radiation Labora tory in Livermore, Calif. The ceremony was performed by Cantor David Benedict.

title: THE CHIEF AWARDS
description: GORDON SETTERS

title: I.T.T. and Hartford Fire Alter Tactics on Merger
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 8 (UPI) The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Com pany said this weekend they had dropped their court appeals challenging Connecticut's rejec Ition of their merger plan.

title: OUTLOOK BULLISH IN BOND MARKET
description: The money and capital mar kets have just scored their most impressive advance since Oc tober, and they don't face a particularly burdensome volume of new securities for sale this week.

title: Dunk's Rittmeister Captures National Dachshund Specialty
description: Thomas R. Dunk Jr., a re tired cattle breeder from Jack sonville, Fla., won the Dachs hund Club of America's 75th annual specialty last night at the Royal Manhattan Hotel. It was the third time one of his dogs had taken the top prize.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: POWERBOATS CLIP TWO WORLD MARKS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP)Two world records were broken today and Ron Larsen of Long Beach, Calif., zoomed to victory in the feature race of the 32d annual Southland Sweepstakes Regatta for power boats

title: City High Schools Affected
description: Racial fears and resentment are steadily eroding relations between white teachers and administrators and black stu dents in many, possibly most, high schools here.

title: Guide Through the Jungle
description: Minor revisions have been made in the movie industry's rating system, which was begun just over a year ago because of public resentment against excessive violence and sex scenes. The classifications set up by the Motion Picture Association of America have served to guide parents and, in the case of some films, to categorically bar admission to minors.

title: MISS FORD IS VICTOR IN 3 RIDING CLASSES
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Feb. 8Fiddler's Blues, an aged brown mare owned by Jay Bol ton of Huntington and handled by Sue Ford, captured all three classes to pile up 15 points and win the regular working hunter championship today at the Middle Island horse show.

title: Georgia Troopers Halt Negroes Marching to Hear Maddox Talk
description: SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Feb. 8 (UPI)The state police, fear ing a violent confrontation, halted 500 marching Negroes today and refused to let them into a high school gymnasium to hear a speech by Gov. Lester G. Maddox, who chastised whites for not fighting integra tion earlier.

title: HOMER COCHRAN, 63, WITH MORGAN BANK
description: PLAINFIELD, N J., Feb. 8 Homer P. Cochran, who retired last year as a senior vice presi dent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York. died today of a heart attack at his home, 961 Oakwood Place. He was 63 years old.

title: 15 Are Overcome by Gas
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (UPI)Fif teen persons were overcome by gas today when fumes from a faulty furnace leaked into a West Side apartment building. Thirteen victims were admitted to Cook County Hospital and two were under observation. A hospital spokesman said 10 of those admitted were children and were doing quite well.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WRITING ON THE WALL. And Other Literary Essays. By Mary McCarthy. 213 pages. Harcourt, Brace & World. $6.75.E

title: ParkviewGern Chain Elects Former Gimbels Executive
description: Irving Wiggs, who resigned last May as vice president and general manager of Gimbels, New York, has been elected president and chief executive officer of ParkviewGem, Inc., a large discountstore chain based in Kansas City.

title: Israeli Paper Prints Letters From Jews in Soviet Union
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 8 (Reuters) A leading Israeli newspaper to day published letters from So viet Jews to their relatives here expressing what it called the fervent desire of many of the Soviet Union's three million Jews to emigrate to Israel.

title: Channel 13's Auction
description: Channel 13's plans for a weeklong, ontheair auction in June have been postponed for lack of a suitable site. John W. Kiermaier, president of the New York educational station, said the fundraising auction now becomes a possibility for next year. Plans are being made for an alternate fundraising event this June.

title: Machinist Locals Voting For General Electric Pact
description: Most members of the Inter national Association of Machin ists striking 34 General Electric Company plants since Oct. 26 have apparently accepted a new contract and are preparing to return to work, the Associated Press reported last night.

title: Joseph Brainin Is Dead at 74; Aide of Weizmann Institute
description: Joseph Brainin, journalist and writer, who retired three years ago as executive vice president of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Sci ence of Rehovot, Israel, died of a heart attack here Saturday night. He was 74 years old and lived at 172 West 79th Street.

title: 2 BOMBS EXPLODE AT G.E. BUILDINGS
description: Two bombs exploded at two General Electric service cen ters in the city last night, with in 45 minutes of each other. The damage was slight and no injuries were reported in either explosion.

title: Snowmobiles Mix Headaches With Thrills
description: EAGLE RIVER, Wis.Twi light shadows were darken ing around the Chanticleer Inn and the clean, feathery north woods snow thickened the heavy silence.

title: STRING IS 2 SHORT OF LEAGUE RECORD
description: The Los Angeles Kings didn't even come close at the final buzzer last night as the Rang ers closed in on one of the National Hockey League's old est records with a 51 victory.

title: CITY U. SEES RISE IN BUILDING COSTS
description: More than $1billiondouble the original estimateis ex pected to be needed by 1976 for a building program for the City University's senior col leges and graduate institutions.

title: It's Nadler & Larrimer For Glenfiddich Scotch
description: Only one in every 10,000 drinkers has ever drunk Glen fiddich Scotch, according to William Lyons, executive vice president of Nadler & Lari mer. That can mean prob lems for the ad agency plan ning a testimonial campaign.

title: Brazil's Military Government Tightens Control
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7 The military leaders of Brazil, soon to begin their seventh year in power, have slowly changed their role from that of temporary caretakers to stern tutors, with a vision of a dis ciplined Brazil on her way to becoming an industrial power on the world scene.

title: SAN JUAN CLERGY BACKS BIRTH CURB
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 8 The Most Rev. Luis Aponte Martinez, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Juan, said yesterday that his conditional approval of a Government sponsored birth control pro gram could and should have far reaching effects in con trolling the island's rapidly growing population.

title: Officials' Lapses Mar Baltimore and Seattle Meets
description: Many people, especially meet directors, had warned that the crowded track week end would be disastrous for the athletes, the public and the meets. They said that six major indoor meets in three nights would be too much.

title: ORDERS FOR STEEL UP AT SOME MILLS
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8The steel market is showing resis tance to a downturn.

title: Cautious optimism on Peking  Washington Relations
description: There must have been some quiet jubilation in the White House and the State Depart ment the other day when Peking sent word it wants this year's second formal Chinese American meeting held next Feb. 20, only one month after the initial gettogether. Having gambled last year that the Chi nese Communists might be fa vorably impressed by a uni lateral American easing of trade restrictions, the Nixon Admin istration can be pleased that its wager is producing some dividends.

title: PROFIT AND SALES SET KROGER HIGHS
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest food chain, realized a 10 per cent increase in earnings last year on sales gain of 10 per cent, both setting new levels, Jacob E. Davis, chairman and presi dent, reported over the week end.

title: WALLACE URGES A DEFIANT SOUTH
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb., 8  George C. Wallace urged Southern governors today to defy Federal Court integration orders and promised to seek the Presidency again in 1972 if Nixon doesn't do something about the mess our schools are in.

title: Selective Service Head's Son In Jersey Seized in Drug Raid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8William Avella, 18yearold son of Col. Joseph T. Avella, head of New Jersey's Selective Service Sys tem, was one of 18 young per sons arrested in a narcotics raid made over the weekend by the Trenton police.

title: AVANTGARDISTS PLAY NEW WORKS
description: The two new works on the LeagueISCM's Continuing AvantGarde series program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night were the kind that depend on the careful perception of very special areas of sound on the patt of their composers.

title: Margery E. Rosen Fiancee of Dentist
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 8Mr. and Mrs. Abram S. Rosen of Maplewood have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mar gery Ellen Rosen, to Dr. Stewart M. Chodosch, the son of Mrs. David Chodosch of the Bronx and the late Mr. Chodosch.

title: Nasser Concedes That Israelis Have Air Supremacy in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  Charging the Israelis with ar rogance of power, President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has con ceded that Israel now has air supremacy in the Middle East, primarily because of an abun dance of highly trained pilots.

title: 12 Wounded, Cairo Says
description: CAIRO, Feb. 8Israeli fight erbombers striking at targets near the industrial city of Helwan wounded 12 civilian employes of the el Nasr auto mobile works, Egypt's Ministry of the Interior reported today.

title: Grounded Tanker, Leaking Oil, Splits Off Nova Scotia
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 7The stranded Liberian oil tanker Arrow broke in two today off the coast of Nova Scotia as tugs hauled on her stern.

title: Woman Head of Clan Is a Sprightly 92
description: DAME FLORA MACLEOD carne to town this week end to celebrate her 92d birthday with 185 other Mac Leods who turned out in tar tan and evening clothes to pay tribute to their doughty chieftain at a dinner dance, Saturday night, in her honor. The first woman ever to be head of a Scottish clan, Dame Flora bears a great resem blance to Queen Victoria in her later years. And despite her age her wit is nimble.

title: S. AFRICA FACES BAN IN DAVIS CUP
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 8 (UPI) A special meeting of Davis Cup nations will be held in Lon don March 23 to consider South Africa's suspension for racial discrimination.

title: HUNTER LAURELS TO HAPPINESS IS
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 8  Eight months ago Dana Douglass, a blond, 17yearold senior at Ridgewood (N.J.) High School, lost three horses in a fire at Holiday Farms, River Vale, N. J. First In, her top show mount, was among the three and Miss Douglass thought a good replacement would be hard to find.

title: YARBOROUGH CAR SETS SPEED MARK
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (UPI)Cale Yarborough, whose right shoulder was broken in a racing wreck two months ago, raced along the Daytona Speed way at a record 194.015 miles an hour today to gain the pole position for the $198,500 Day tona 500 stock car race on Feb. 22.

title: Sierra Leone's Morgan Is No Banker
description: FREETOWN. Sierra Leone When anyone speaks of a House of Morgan here, they are refer ring not to a bank but to a chain of pharmacies founded by Er nest Dunstan Morgan.

title: CELTICS VANQUISH ROYALS, 130 TO 117
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)  Jo Jo White, a rookie, sparked a Boston outburst at the outset of the third period today and the Celtics fashioned their third straight National Basketball As sociation victory, beating the Cincinnati Royals, 130117.

title: Newton Paper Will Publish Daily Starting Next Month
description: NEWTON, N. J., Feb. 8 (AP)  The New Jersey Herald, which now is published on Thursday and Sunday, will become a daily in March.

title: V.D. CASE INCREASE ALARMING IN CITY
description: An alarming increase in venereal diseases in the city was reported yesterday by Health Commissioner Mary C. McLaughlin, who estimated that there were 200,000 new cases a yearmost of them undetected.

title: Southern Governors Seek Unity in Integration Fight
description: MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 8The governors of four Deep South states met here today in a show of unity on the desegre gation controversy but failed to devise a strategy to deal with it. In a statement issued at the close of the fourhour conference, however, they specifically rejected violence as a recourse. The governors were John Bell Williams of Mississippi, Lester G. Maddox of Georgia, Albert P. Brewer of Alabama and John J. Mc Keithen of Louisiana. An aide to Governor Williams, who had called the conference, said an invitation was also extended to Governor Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida and Governor Robert E. McNair of South Carolina, but they were unable to attend. Gov ernor Kirk, the only Republi can governor in the Deep South, has been one of the most vocal critics of court desegre gation plans that employ the crossbusing of children. Gov ernor McNair, on the other hand, has counseled his state to comply with the court orders.

title: Bomb Explodes at Home Of Liberal Ulster Legislator
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Monday, Feb. 9 (Reuters)A bomb attack was made early today on the home here of a Liberal woman member of Northern Ireland's Parliament.

title: PAUL AGNEW SYNNOTT
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 8 Paul Agnew Synnott, a former member of the advertising staff of Time magazine, died yester iday at Stamford Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 611 Westover Road.

title: 1 Killed, 20 Hurt in Blaze
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 8 (AP)One person was killed and 20 others were injured in a rooming house fire early today near the downtown section.

title: FISHBACH PULLS OUT 86, 2018 TRIUMPH
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 8  Pete Fishbach gained the semifinals of the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship to night, but it's fortunate he won't have to play again until next Saturday.

title: 4 Benefits Set at Opening of National Antiques Show
description: Four benefits have been scheduled for the opening of the 10day National Antiques Show at Madison Square Gar den on Feb. 20.

title: SANTOANDRIE FIRST ON LINKS BY 8 SHOTS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 8 (AP) Ron Santo of the Chicago Cubs and George Andrie of the Dallas Cowboys won the $30,000 American Airlines As trojet golf tournament today at the Goodyear Golf and Country Club course.

title: Bronx Tenants Get Water, but Briefly
description: The city sent a plumber and two helpers yesterday to restore heat and water to a Bronx apartment house while a Commissioner and four assistants watched.

title: Sesame Street Plan May Alter PublicTV Form
description: A proposal that could alter the basic form of public tele vision, and perhaps ultimately, its content, has been sent to the public and private spon sors of Sesame Street.

title: BAYVIEW'S CURLERS WIN AT MOUNT HOPE
description: MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 8 The Bayview Curling Club of Toronto, skipped by Kenneth Cooper, won the New York Cal edonia medal today by defeat ing the Montreal Caledonian Curling Club, skipped by Jack Hobbs, 109, in the finals of the 15th annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: GRANATELLI PLANS GRAND PRIX RACING
description: Andy Granatelli is going rac ing on the international grand prix circuit, a whole new world for the former mechanic who learned his trade as an urchin on the streets of Chicago.

title: Amex Governors' Board Chooses New Members
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that Frank C. Graham Jr. had been reelected to a second oneyear term as chairman of the exchange's board of gover nors. Mr. Graham is a partner of Purcell, Graham & Co.

title: Institutional Traders Raise Size of Holdings
description: Investment companies and other institutional traders in creased their aggregate share of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange to 24.1 per cent by the end of 1969 from 23.5 per cent a year earlier, the Big Board report ed yesterday.

title: Welfare Protest Begins Today For Guaranteed Family Income
description: Mrs. Beulah Sanders, chair man of the Citywide Coordi nating Committee of Welfare Groups, outlined plans yester day for Guaranteed Income Week that begins today in Buf falo and ends with a conver gence of several thousand welfare recipients next Tues day in Albany.

title: 5MAN U.S. CREW HELD IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (UPI)A United States Navy river patrol boat strayed into Cambodian waters last week and was seized by Cambodian forces, the United States head quarters reported today. The vessel and its fiveman crew are being held.

title: General Foods Executives Named Division Presidents
description: Changes that affect the managerial responsibilities and titles of the division executives of the General Foods Corpora tion were announced yesterday

title: Sandra Roberts Engaged to Wed Tobias V. Welo
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Feb. 9Mr. and Mrs. John Wood ard Roberts have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Rob erts, to Tobias Victor Welo, a senior associate of the con sulting concern of Cresap, McCormick & Paget, Inc., of New York.

title: JAPAN TOPS QUOTA ON STEEL EXPORTS
description: Japanese steel producers re ported here yesterday that their shipments to the United States last year had exceeded the voluntary quota negotiated with the State Department by only 2 per cent.

title: LESTER STOEFEN, 58, TENNIS CHAMPION
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 9 Lester Stoefen, former United States and Wimbledon tennis champion, died of a rare liver ailment in his home yesterday. He was 58 years old.

title: Dow Chemical Increases Profit; Cuts Prices on Some Products
Apple Festival Queen Named
description: WINCHESTER, Va., Feb. (AP)  Merie Ellyn Fong, 21 yearold daughter of Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, will reign as Queen Shenandoah 43d at this year's Apple Blossom Festival, festi val officials announced today.

title: L. I. U. CONQUERS ST. PETER'S, 6659
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 (AP) Long Island University handed St. Peter's College its third straight basketball loss tonight, 6659.

title: Does Bites Kill Boy
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (UPI)An 18monthold boy was killed to day when he was bitten by his mother's German shepherd dog. Anthony Cliff was bitten in his crib at his home in suburban Brentwood and was dead on ar rival at St. Louis County Hos pital. The police said he had been bitten about the face, head and neck.

title: Washington: For the Record
Susan Bates Fiancee Of Andrew Grainger
description: Miss Susan Jean Bates, whose father and grandfather were members of Congress, plans to be married this summer to Andrew Ronald Grainger, a law student at the University of Michigan.

title: National City Corp. Elects
description: Louis K. Eilers and John C. Hall have been named directors of the First National City Cor poration and its principal sub sidiary, the First National City Bank. Mr. Eilers is president and chief executive officer of the Eastman Kodak Company. Mr. Hall is president of the Anaconda Company.

title: Advertising: Consolidation Cuts Big Swath
description: Economyminded advertis ers are constantly eying tele vision commercial production costs and trying to figure out ways to cut them.

title: Waste Hinted in Services GracinateSchool Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The General Accounting Office has found that the Army, Navy and Air Force have been making many more of their officers eligible to go to graduate school at the taxpayers' expense than they ought to and that the serv ices are making relatively little use of the officers when they return from school.

title: BASEBALL SELECTS EASTWEST PLAYERS
description: Plans and rosters for the Major League EastWest All Star Classic, an exhibition game to be played in Los Angeles on Saturday afternoon, March 28, were announced yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, Commissioner of Baseball.

title: MRS. ANDREW TSU
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 9 (AP)Mrs. Andrew Y. Y. Tsu, wife of the retired bishop of the Anglican Church in China, died yesterday. She was 72 years old and lived at the, Methodist House here.

title: Copter Crashes at Danang; 12 Americans Are Killed
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 10 (Reuters) A United States Army helicop ter crashed here today, killing the 12 men aboard. All aboard were Americans, military sources said.

title: Anaconda Up in 1969
description: Reflecting increased prices, record production and sales to, meet the strong demand for copper and other nonferrous metals, the Anaconda Company lifted its earnings last year by 11.5 per cent from 1968, C. Jays Parkinson, chairman, reported yesterday. Fourthquarter earn ings, however, declined.

title: PANTHER RAID PLAN CONFIRMED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service confirmed today that its agents wanted to raid a Black Panther headquarters in Seattle last month but changed its plans at the request of the city's police.

title: G.M. Truck Plant Set
description: DETROIT, Feb. 9 (UPI)The G.M.C. truck and coach divi sion of the General Motors Corporation announced plans, today to build a mediumduty truckassembly plant in Pontiac, Mich. The cost of the 1.5million squarefoot facility was not disclosed.

title: London Board in Temporary Quarters
description: LONDON, Feb. 9  The Lon don Stock Exchange opened today in temporary quarters, an awkward trilevel trading floor that will accommodate the $72 billion business until late in 1972.

title: Music: The Clevelanders
BANKING EXPERTS SIGHT RECESSION
description: The United States economy has entered a recession, pos sibly one of some severity, a panel of bank investment spe cialists warned more than 2,000 of their colleagues here yesterday.

title: L.I. BANKER BACKS ROLE IN LAND DEAL
description: MINEOLA, L.I. Feb. 9  Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Franklin National Bank, denied any wrongdoing in the acquisition of land near the proposed site for a jetport and a transportation hub in Suf folk County and said he would not resign as a member of the NassauSuffolk Regional Plan ning Board.

title: Polyethylene Down 6%
description: The bow Chemical Company said yesterday it had reduced prices on some grades of high density polyethylene by about 6 per cent in recognition of current market conditions.

title: Newsweek Employe Faces Contempt Charge at Panther Hearing
description: A woman researcher for Newsweek magazine was sum moned to the bench yester day at the pretrial hearing here for 13 Black Panthers to face a contemptofcourt charge for having joined in spectator ap plause of defendants who de nounced the court.

title: BERKELEY POLICE SEEKING COPTERS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 9 Berkeley police officials are pushing for a helicopter patrol to fight rising crime. They are being derided by protesters as potential whirly pigs and choppercoppers.

title: Alberta Oil Output Rises
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press)Crude oil production in Alberta averaged 1,037,671 barrels a day during the week ended Feb. 2, the Al berta Oil and Gas Conservation Board reported today.

title: Orr Leads N.H.L. Scorers But Esposito Gains Ground
description: A switch in linemates didn't bother Phil Esposito one hit last week.

title: Labor Leader Displeased
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 9 Disappointment was ex pressed here today by C. J. Haggerty, president of the Build ing and Construction Trades De partment of the A.F.L: C.I.O., over Mr. Shultz's announce ment. pressed here today by C. J. Haggerty, president of the Build ing and Construction Trades De partment of the A.F.L: C.I.O., over Mr. Shultz's announce ment.

title: Georgia Loses to Alabama, 9486, Falls Game Back of Winning Kentucky
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 9 (UPI)Alabama fought off a late surge by Georgia tonight and knocked the Bulldogs out of a firstplace tie with Ken tucky in the Southeastern Con ference with a 9486 upset victory.

title: ARTS PLEA MADE BY MISS DE MILLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Agnes de Mille, the choreogra pher, pleaded with Congress today for more than a pit tance for the arts and said the nation could make no bet ter investment than in its gift ed citizens.

title: Themistocles Tsatsos, 63, Served in Greek Cabinets
description: ATHENS, Feb. 9  Prof. Themistocles Tsatsos, a former cabinet minister and an expert on constitutional law, died here today after a brief illness. He was 63 years old.

title: TRAVEL EXPENSES RAISED BY $10,000
description: Progress was made yester day as the Amateur Athletic Union sought to avert a boy cott of its national indoor track and field championships by the nation's two strongest clubs. The meet will be held Feb. 27 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Chicago Trial Testimony Ends; Four Last Defense Items Barred
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9Testimony was formally completed today in the Chicago conspiracy trial and the marathon case moved rapidly toward an end.

title: Nixon Asks for an Office on Communications Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  President Nixon moved today to equip the White House staff for the first time with its own experts on the multiplying is sues of communications policy.

title: Israelis Report Losing Jet in Dogfight at Canal
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9  An Egyptian pilot shot down an Israeli jet over the northern part of the Suez Canal area to day, an Israeli military spokes man here reported.

title: 2D DEMOCRAT RUNS FOR MURPHY SEAT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 Representative George E. Brown Jr. of Los Angeles, now hi his fourth term in the House of Representatives, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination to op pose Senator George Murphy's bid for a second term.

title: Bronx Apartment Woes Linked To Holdup Death of 2 Owners
description: Two of three owners of a Bronx apartment house that has been without water for two weeks and without heat since Christmas were killed in a holdup in November, 1967. The thirdtheir brotherwas de scribed yesterday by an aide to Mayor Lindsay as having gone completely to pieces since the holdup.

title: Lindsay, as Parent, Voices Concern on Marijuana
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that he did not know whether his three teenaged daughters had ever smoked marijuana, but added, I shouldn't be the least surprised if they have.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1970

title: RIVAL OF LINDSAY NAMED IN BRONX
description: Bronx Republicans nominated an opponent of Mayor Lindsay last night to run for an As sembly seat left vacant by the recent appointment of Benja min Altman to a city post, but the vote was promptly chal lenged as invalid and illegal by a leader of the proLindsay forces.

title: West Point Waits for Plant To Cut Its River Pollution
description: WEST POINT, N. Y.The United States Military Acad emy, which was pouring thou sands of gallons of raw sew age into the Hudson River each day only 14 years ago, is waiting for funds to build a treatment plant designed to meet Federal and state pol lution standards.

title: Students in Prague Now Know Their Beautiful Dream Is Over
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 9The record was Louis Armstrong singing Hello, Dolly as the students gathered after classes in a vinarna not far from Charles University. And the former stu dent leader, now only intent on finishing his studies, summed up the mood today:

title: Don Meade Jr. Registers Narragansett Park Triple
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Feb. 9 (AP)Don Meade Jr., son of the great jockey, rode three winners today at Narragansett Park.

title: PARVIN REALIGNS ITS MANAGEMENT
description: The ParvinDohrmann Com pany, owner of three Las Vegas gambling casinos, disclosed yes terday that it was reorganizing its management in a settlement with several regulatory bodies that had raised questions about the concern.

title: Yankees' Robinson Makes Assist For BasketballPlaying Brother
description: Walter Robinson plays in the backcourt for ElizabethFor ward High School, a town 15 miles south of Pittsburgh. It's not a very good basketball team. It has won only three of 17 games in Section IV of the Western Pennsylvania Inter scholastic Athletic League.

title: Loss at C. & N. W.
description: Last year was one of the worst ever experienced by the Chicago & North Western Rail way, the operating subsidiary of Northwest Industries, Inc., the holding company headed by Ben W. Heineman.

title: A. J. McGinley, Betsy Blaisdell Plan Nuptials
description: Miss Betsy Ann Blaisdell and Andrew John McGinley, coworkers at the Interna tional Business Machines Corporation in Kingston, N. Y., plan to be married in April.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Feb. 3:

title: Matson, St. John's Star, Signs Phillies Contract
description: Al Matson, captain of St. John's University's baseball team, has signed a contract with the Philadelphia Phillies and will leave for spring training on March 19.

title: RETAILERS URGED TO HIRE DROPOUTS
description: DALLAS, Feb. 9A strong call was issued here today for retailers of men's apparel to hire and promote noncollegc graduates for managerial and executive positions.

title: Article 1  No Title
ANTIWAR UNIT PLANS 3MONTH CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) A major antiwar group an nounced today a three months' Campaign of rallies, picketing and demonstrations against civ il rights repression, the draft and war spending.

title: CHARLES L. BATES
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 9 Charles Lane Bates of River side, who retired 10 years ago as a business consultant in New York, died today in nursing home here. He was 86 years old.

title: Drama League Prepares a Party
description: The Drama League of New York will sponsor a card party at the Gotham next Tuesday to raise money. The nonprofit organization sup ports the legitimate theater here by providing scholarships to the American Acad emy of Dramatic Arts.

title: Bombing Threat Routs 1,100 From G.E. Midtown Building
description: The General Electric Com pany's 48story headquarters here was evacuated yesterday because of a bomb threat. The threat came as Federal and lo cal authorities investigated two bombings at G.E. facilities in the city.

title: BLAINE AMENDMENT BACKED BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay came out yes terday in opposition to repeal of the socalled Blaine amend ment, which prohibits state aid to schools with religious affili ations.

title: Galanos Abandons Short HemsCompletely
description: HELEN of Troy wasn't im mediately discernible, but a whole mass of gods, god desses, centaurs and temples were. They were cavorting or standing stationary and adorn ing the multitudinous evening dresses James Galanos de signed for modern women to wear this spring and summer. The prints were credited to Tzaims Luksus.

title: Vice President Named By American Airlines
description: American Airlines has named Peter Radulovic Jr. to succeed Robert L. Frederick in Honolulu as vice president for the Pacific.

title: Nixon Plans Florida Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) President Nixon plans to fly to Florida Wednesday evening to join his wife and older daughter for a long Lincoln's Birthday holiday at his Key Biscayne home, a White House spokesman said today. Miss Tricia Nixon, 23 years old, has been there for two weeks re covering first from flu and then from measles.

title: Vatican Asking All Priests To Affirm Celibacy Yearly
description: ROME, Feb. 9The Vatican has asked Roman Catholic priests to reaffirm their vows of celibacy and obedience an nually and publicly.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: NAVY COACH POSTS 6LENGTH VICTORY
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 9 (AP) Before a crowd of 8,952, Navy Coach, ridden by Rudy Rincon, took command at the top of the stretch and registered a six length victory today in the Greenbelt Purse at Bowie Race Course.

title: Riot in Washington School Marks Demand for Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Hundreds of black students at racially mixed Western High School emphasized their de mand for a weeklong boycott today by ripping doors off hinges, setting a small fire, flooding a bathroom and taking over the school's public address system.

title: TV: Day Before Sunday
description: THE talents of Uta Hagen, who has taught her full share of young people the in tricacies of the acting craft, are the redeeming feature of The Day Before Sunday, which the Columbia Broad casting System Playhouse will present at 9:30 P.M. today. The original play by Robert Crean is soap opera after the sun has gone down, and it falls upon Miss Hagen to try to give a measure of sub stance and coherence to an inferior work.

title: Radar Parts Being Shipped To Israel Seized in Zurich
description: GENEVA, Feb. 9  A con signment of radar parts being sent to Israel by air freight was seized at the Zurich Air port Friday by customs offi cials, the Swiss Government announced today.

title: HOPING TO LEAVE BROADCAST POST
description: Thomas P. F. Hoving has told the board of directors of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting that he will resign as chairman in a month. He is expected, however, to re main a committee member.

title: U.S. Bars Immunity For Soviet U.N. Aide Seized in Spy Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The State Department rejected to day a Soviet claim of diplo matic immunity for a Soviet employe of the United Nations Secretariat arrested in Seattle on Saturday and charged with conspiracy to commit espio nage.

title: British National Theater Bow sin U.S.
Mediatory Role on Celibacy Seen for French Clergy
description: PARIS, Feb. 9  The Roman Catholic hierarchy of France proclaimed its fraternal com munion with Pope Paul VI last Thursday in his disagreement with the Dutch bishops over the celibacy of the priesthood. Yet discussions with church men here have turned up some remarkable Gallic nuances.

title: MARKET BUOYED BY BURNS VIEWS
description: Glamour and pollutioncon trol issues ranked among the better gainers yesterday as the stock market got a lift from statements made by Arthur F. Burns, new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: N.Y.U. Journalism School To Teach Minority Groups
description: The Department of Journal ism at New York University will offer an internship for minority journalism students this summer at the university's Washington Square campus.

title: A Correction
description: The caption with a picture published in yesterday's New York Times indicated incorrect ly that Mrs. Robert F. Kennet would be seen today in Sesa me Street on Channels 11 and 13. The picture showed Mrs Kennedy taking part in a Ses ame Street program that will be televised next Tuesday on Channel 13 and three weeks later, March 10, on Channel 11.

title: Bruins Wreak Rough Revenge On Maki for Green Incident
description: KNOWING what he was in for, Wayne Maki ac cepted an invitation to may hem in Boston Sunday night. Maki, of the St. Louis Blues, was making his first appear ance against the Bruins since that night last September when he gave Ted Green a fractured skull in an exhibi tion game. An employe of the Blues, who saw Sunday's game on television, said yesterday, It was brutal. They pounded poor Maki every chance they got. Even Phil Esposito took a run at him. The Blues were routed, 71. In another week, an Ottawa, Ontario, court will determine whether civil action should be taken against either Green or Maki. The Bruins already have made their determination, al though Green has admitted to teammates that the fault was not Maki's.

title: Interne to Wed Susan Rosenthal
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Rosenthal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Rosen thal, to Dr. Phillip Kummel Keats, a surgical interne at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N. C.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Al Hirt, Injured in Parade, Says Career Is Endangered
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 (UPI) Al Hirt, the jazz trumpeter, said today that a cut from a piece of concrete that struck him in the mouth during a Mardi Gras parade last night might endanger his career.

title: Caird Leslie, 70, Dancer And Ballet Teacher, Dead
description: Caird Leslie, a former ballet dancer and teacher, was found dead in his home at 129 West 56th Street on Sunday, appar ently after having taken an overdose of sleeping pills. He was 70 years old.

title: JAMES CHIRURG, 63, HEADED AD CONCERN
description: DANVERS, Mass., Feb. 9 James Thomas Chirurg, a for mer advertising agency execu tive, died at Hunt Memorial Hospital here today. He had suffered a heart attack in De cember. He was 63 years old and lived here.

title: Hawley Rides His 26th Winner After Getting 5Day Suspension
description: MIAMI, Feb. 9 (AP)Sandy Hawley, whose chances of win ning the Hialeah riding title were jolted earlier in the day when he received a fiveday suspension, rode the favorite, Red Beret, to victory in the sixth race today before a crowd of 17.729.

title: CHINESE REWRITE WARTIME SONGS
description: HONG KONG. Feb. 9In an effort to rekindle the patriotism and revolutionary fervor that existed among the Chinese in the war against Japan, Commu nist cultural authorities have revived popular songs of that period with new words more suited to present times.

title: Bridal Planned For Ann Brody
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Feb. 9Mr. and Mrs. David A. Brody have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Sheryl Brody, to Gary Jon Marker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor E. Marker of Pottstown, Pa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Yale School Cuts Enrollment
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9Yale's Graduate School of Arts and Sciences has announced it will reduce its enrollment by 20 to 30 per cent next year as part of a program to balance Its finances. According to Dean Donald W. Taylor, the school ran a deficit of $500,000 last year because of an unexpected increase in applicants who en rolled, combined with a decline in public and private funds.

title: The Path to Designing Fame Was a Bit Muddy
description: TAY STEFFY may well be the first interior designer who had to shovel himself out of a decorating mistake a dirt floor that turned unexpectedly to mud.

title: 2 Schools Closed in Protest By Poughkeepsie Teachers.
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. Feb. 9 (AP)  Classes at two schools here were canceled to day and teachers manned picket lines as a dispute over discipline and teacher and pupil safety continued.

title: Mrs. King Asserts Nixon Slows Rights Movement
description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (UPI)Mrs. Martin Luther King accused President Nixon today of slow ing the civil rights movement and said Black Panthers await ing trial were being unjustly treated.

title: 90Day Sill Rate Off to 7.312%; 181Day Discount Dipsto 7.387%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Treasury bill rates declined dramatically at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported today.

title: Gilpatric Stops Sale Of 4 Letters to Him From Mrs. Onassis
description: Roswell L. Gilpatric, a former Deputy Secretary of Defense, requested last night that four letters written to him by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis the widow of President Kennedy, he with drawn from sale at an auction here next month because they had been stolen from his New York law office.

title: E.C.A.C. Hockey Statistics
AMERICAN EXCHANGE
Japan's Gold at New High
description: TOKYO. Feb. 9 (UPI)Japan' gold reserves have risen past the $400million mark for the first time since the end of World War II. The announce ment by he Finance. Ministry and the Bank of Japan noted that so far this year the re. serves have benefited from rise of about. $50million.

title: Big Board Nears Vote On Firms' Ownership
description: The New York Stock Ex change is expected to vote Thursday on final approval of rules changes that would permit public ownership of member firms. The exchange also may disclose a new commissionrate structure.

title: Mrs. Court, Mrs. Jones Advance in Vanderbilt Indoor Tennis Here
description: About 15 minutes before the Vanderbilt women's invitation tennis tournament was to begin last night, a young woman ur gently approached a workman and said:

title: JOHNSON'S KETCH IS FIRST TO FINISH
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 9Windward Passage has accomplished what she was built to dofinish ahead of Ondine in an ocean race.

title: Mayor's Proposal for New Jail Criticized by Planning Agency
description: Mayor Lindsay's decision to go ahead with plans for a new House of Detention for men in Manhattan was criticized by the City Planning Commission yesterday as the wrong ap proach to solving overcrowding in city jails.

title: Harlem Bus Group Gains in I.C.C. Bid
description: The Cheetah Charter Bus Service Company, Inc., a fledg ling enterprise with headquar ters at 40 West 135th Street, in Harlem, annoupnced yester day that it had moved a step closer to the day it could start doing business.

title: Stage: The Jumping Fool
Shultz Warns 18 Cities to End Bias in Building Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI)  Labor Secretary George P. Shultz announced today that the Philadelphia Plan would be extended to 18 other cities un less they devised their own plans for ending job discrim ination in the construction in dustry.

title: City Rights Group Is Accused of Bias
description: The director of the Puerto RicanHispanic Affairs Divi sion of the City Commission on Human Rights resigned unex pectedly yesterday after charg ing that the commission discrim inated against Puerto Ricans in its hiring practices.

title: Lieut. Thomas Kenney to Wed Miss Erica M. Rizzo in June
description: Miss Erica Marie Rizzo, a senior at Manhattanville Col lege, plans to be married in June to Second Lieut. Thomas Kenney, who is serving with the Marines in Quantico, Va.

title: I.L.O. Chief Resigning, Not Retiring
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9David A. Morse, who announced his resigna tion as head of the Interna tional Labor Organization today, was born on Washing ton Avenue in the Bronx, but he is obviously not ready to retire to placid inactivity in any parochial neighborhood.

title: A. PAGE BROWNE, 77, EXHOTEL EXECUTIVE
description: CONCORD, Mass., Feb. 9 A. Page Browne, who retired in 1937 as senior vice president and director of Sheraton Hotels, died here yesterday. His age was 77.

title: BOSTON U.'S SIX TOPS BOSTON COLLEGE, 54
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Wayne Gowing scored three goals in the third period to night in sparking Boston Uni versity to a 54 victory over Boston College for the cham pionship of the 18th Boston Beanpot Hockey Tournament.

title: Schranz Captures First Heat In World Title Giant Slalom
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 9 (UPI)Karl Schranz won the first of two heats in the giant slalom at the world Alpine ski championships today. Billy Kidd of the United States, fa vored for the combined title, severely damaged his chances by finishing 30th.

title: Engine Overheats; 747 Jet With 145 Returns to London
description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) A Jumbo 747 jet engine overheat ed about 1,000 miles out over the Atlantic today, forcing the Pan American World Airways plane to return to London's Heathrow Airport.

title: 3 Officers Deny Nixon Had Role In Ordering a Trial for Calley
