At present he is serving a five year sentence for income tax evasion. Judge William J. Lynch of United States District Court directed that the punish ment imposed today be served consecutively to the income tax sentence.

title: Cutting Campaign Costs
description: George N. Spitz, a former consultant to the Joint Legislative Committee on the Election Law, has sound idea for cutting down the cost and confusion of electoral campaigns. Mr. Spitz, who has been active in numerous reform efforts, proposes that his fellow Democrats in Manhattan's 26th Senatorial District cooperate in underwriting the publication of a voters directory for the approaching primary.

title: Yarborough Keeps Racing Enthusiasm Despite Bad Spills
description: LAST season was the worst ever for Cale Yar borough. The hefty 195 pound stockcar driver from Timmonsville, S.C., had a series of accidents in which, with ghastly consistency, he led races and then lost them by hitting the wall. When it seemed impossible for Yar borough's luck to get any worse, his Mer cury Cyclone blew a tire dur ing the Texas 500 on Dec. 7 and again he slammed into the wall. He shattered his right shoulder. The surgeons considered it a miracle that he survived that violent crash. Certainly they thought it would be at least eight months before he could drive again.

title: Allen Spinner, 48, Professor At Stevens Tech and N.Y.U.
description: FORT LFE, N. J., Feb. 10 Allen H. Spinner, a professor in the department of economics of engineering and management science at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, died, apparently of a heart attack, at an Edison hospital Saturday. He was 48 years old and lived here at 2400 Hudson Terrace.

title: Pontiac Unveils Firebird With European Flare
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 10 A new Firebird auto model, aimed at the youth market or, more realistically, those with an urge for high styling and horsepower, was un veiled today by the Pontiac division of General Motors.

title: A.B.C.TV Explains Why It Censored Judy Collins
description: The American Broadcasting Company, after almost a week's delay, explained yesterday why it had censored the remarks of Judy Collins, the folk singer, about the Chicago conspiracy trial presided over by Judge Julius J. Hoffman.

title: Mount Sets Purdue Mark
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 10 (UPI)AllAmerica Rick Mount scored 41 points tonight to establish a Purdue career scoring mark and lead the Boilermakers to a 9880 Big Ten basketball victory over Indiana.

title: Prosecution Says Chicano 7 Planned a Revolution
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 10The seven defendants in the Chica go conspiracy trial came here in August, 1968, to develop a National Liberation Front and start the revolution, the Gov ernment contended today in its final arguments.

title: CITY SAYS 13 TOOK POLLUTION BRIBES
description: Thirteen city airpollution in spectorsabout 15 per cent of the 83man inspection force were suspended yesterday and six businessmen were arrested on charges of having bribed, inspectors to overlook viola tions. Warrants were issued for the arrest of two more busi nessmen.

title: 5 IN FAMILY FOUND DEAD IN BROOKLYN
description: A mother and four of her six children were found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in their apartment in downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by the woman's estranged hus band.

title: Statement by Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Following are excerpts from a statement today by the Democratic Policy Council:

title: A RALLY FALTERS IN BOND MARKETS
description: The rally in the bond market went into its seventh day yes terday and then faltered.

title: DR. JOHN B. HICKAM, MEDICAL LEADER, 55
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 10Dr. John Bamber Hickam of India napolis, chairman of the depart ment of medicine at the Indiana University School of Medicine, died yesterday at St. Luke's Presbyterian Hospital at Chi cago after a cerebral hemor rhage. He was 55 years old.

title: BROAD BILL ASKED IN TAKEOVER CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Legislation aimed at giving the public more information about attempted corporate takeovers was introduced today by Sena tor Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey. Sena tor Williams was the author of the original corporate take over Bill enacted In 1968. His new bill will broaden and ex tend it to additional situations.

title: STOCKS TUMBLE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: Continuing its 1970 pattern of not able to advance for more than two days in a row, the stock market took another tum ble yesterday.

title: H. Austin Peck, 48, State College Head, Suicide by Hanging
description: POTSDAM, N.Y., Feb. 10 (UPI)Dr H. Austin Peck, 48 years old, president of the State University College here, hanged :himself today from a basement beam in his home. He was found dead by his wife.

title: Brewer Will Run in Alabama For a Full Term as Governor
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 10  Gov. Albert P. Brewer for mally announced today that he would run for a full term as Governor and would stress that the job was fulltime.

title: MRS. WALTER KIDDE
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 9 Mrs. Louise Carter Kidde, widow of Walter Kidde, founder of engineering and contracting companies that bear his name, died in a hospital here yester day. She was 91 years old and lived at 57 Union Street.

title: Old Enemies Slowly Building New Lives in Nigeria
description: OWERRI, Nigeria, Feb. 10 (AP)  Markets are opening again and workmen are repair ing roads and buildings in the area that was Biafra. Life is trickling back to normal, but serious problems remain.

title: Bar Association Chief
description: OF course, my chief claim to fame is being the father of George, Fran cis Taylor Pearsons Plimp ton, the distinguished lawyer and diplomat, remarked yes terday in chatting about his 44 years at the bar. The president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, which is marking its cen tennial this year, was referring to his eldest son, who is the author of such bestsellers as Paper Lion, Out of My League and Bogey Man, and who cuts a figure in New York and Paris literary circles.

title: Qualifiers Increased to 60 For Sunfish Title Sailing
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 10 (AP)Eight boats qua lified today for the first Sun fish world championships, bringing the fleet to 60 repre senting 11 nations.

title: TELEX DENIES SHIFT IN ACCOUNTING SET
description: TULSA, Feb. 10 (UPI)The Telex Corporation denied today that it intends to change its accounting from the financing to operating method or that it has been under any pressure from any source to do so.

title: Royals Top Pistons
M.I.T. Student Indicted
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10 (AP)A junior in the Schoo of Architecture at Massachu setts Institute of Technology has been indicted on a charge of possessing a burglar's tool the steel battering ram used in an invasion of M.I.T. offices Jan. 15. He is Stephen F. Kras ner, 21 years old, of Engle wood, N.J.

title: Four Sentenced for Fraud Involving Federal Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)A Federal judge sen tenced four persons to prison today for defrauding the De fense Department of more than $4million in excess profits on contracts for missile launchers.

title: Outgoing Freighters
For Mainbocher, Elegance Still Counts
description: TWO things upset Main Rousseau Bocher, the last of the bigtime couturiers: when a woman asks the price of a dress or whether he makes it in, say, a size 12.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: News Source Law Backed
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 10 (AP) The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors strongly endorsed legislation to protect the confidentiality of report ers' sources at todays final session of its winter meeting.

title: Asian, Barred by Kenya, Wins British Haven After Week's Travail
description: LONDON, Feb. 10  A 22 yearold Asian woman from Kenya who has been flying back and forth between Nairobi and London for a week was finally allowed to enter Britain temporarily today.

title: Textile Task Force Is Urged by Javits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Senator Jacob K. Javits, just re turned from Japan, urged to day the appointment of a spe cial Presidential task force to make a finding on precisely what segment of the textile and apparel industries are being in jured by rising imports.

title: France to Sell 30 Mirage Jets to Spain
description: PARIS, Feb. 10An agree ment for the sale of 30 Mirage fighter planes to Spain was signed here today after several months of negotiation.

title: INCOME HIGHS SET BY GENERAL PHONE
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in revenues and sales and net income for the fourth quarter and for all 1969.

title: Article 2  No Title
STATES TO ATTEND NEW HAVEN TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP)Secretary of Transporta tion John A. Volpe has asked the Governors of New York and Connecticut and officials of the Penn Central and its unions to join in talks to speed the re lease of funds for improving the railroad's commuter serv ice.

title: Arab Terrorism in Munich
description: The despicable terrorist attack in Munich on pas sengers of the Israeli airline discredits the Arab cause, just as did earlier attacks in other European cities. This latest crime against innocent international air travelers deserves universal condemnation, espe cially by responsible Arab leaders.

title: U.S. Orthodox Bishops Meet To Avert RussianGreek Split
description: The bishops of the Eastern Orthodox faith in the Americas met in special session yesterday in an attempt to head off split between the Russian and Greek churches here over an effort to form an independent Orthodox church of America.

title: Councilmen Assail Landlords' Plan For Rent Increases
description: City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss assailed yesterday a landlord association's plan to raise rents in the city's rent controlled apartments by an average of 25 per cent.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS PLAN FOR CLEANUP OF AIR AND WATER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Nixon asked Congress today for a variety of tools some old, some new and some experimentalto help clean the air and purify the nation's pol luted waters.

title: Britain Says Entry Into Common Market Could Raise Food Prices 25 Per Cent
description: LONDON, Feb. 10  Enter ing the Common Market could raise Britain's food prices as much as 25 per cent and put a substantial new burden on the balance of payments, the Government said today.

title: ORANGE FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Future prices of frozen orange juice concentrate fell rather sharply yesterday on the! New York Cotton Exchange.

title: N.Y.U. WINS, 8972; SIGNORILE LOSES
description: The reason Jim Signorile of New York University was not smiling after last night's 8972 victory over Lehigh before 600 fans in Alumni Gymnasium had nothing to do with the fact that he was not the game's leading scorer nor the leading rehnunder.

title: Nixon Assailed for Ending Aid To a Bill on Swiss Tax Haven
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Robert M. Morgenthau, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, today attacked the Nixon Ad ministration's withdrawal of support for a bill designed to curb millions in tax evasion and wholesale violation of stock and bond trading laws through secret Swiss bank accounts.

title: MRS. EUGENIE BURR
description: NORWALK, Conn, Feb. 10 Mrs. Eugenie McMahon Burr, long a teacher, died this morn ing after a short illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 24 Olmstead Place.

title: Textile Makers Win Awards
description: Six textile manufacturers re ceived awards last night at the Plaza Hotel for outstanding de signs in the annual contest sponsored by Vogue magazine. Bore Fabrics, a division of the BunkerRamo Corporation, won the special fabrication award; E. F. Timme & Son, Inc., print ed fabric; the J.S.J. Embroidery Company, lace and embroidered fabric; Wemasco, Inc., solid woven fabric; Malden Hills, patterned knitted fabric, and Einiger Mills, Inc., patterned woven fabric.

title: Sends Protest Letter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10In vestors, Diversified Services, Inc., denounced todaysight unseen  the proposed new schedule of sales commissions and the proposed new rules for public ownership of broker age firms that the New York Stock Exchange is about to make public.

title: N.B.A., A.B.A. Committees Picked to Discuss MerGer
description: The commissioners of the two rival pro basketball leagues an nounced yesterday that three man committees from each league would meet soon to dis cuss possibilities of a merger.

title: Sedlack Hits 1,000 Mark
description: John Sedlack became the fourth player in Queens College history to exceed 1,000 points as he pumped in 22 last night to lead the Knights to a 9166 Knickerbocker Basketball Con ference victory over Lehman College at the loser's Bronx gym. Sedlack brought his three year total to 1,002 points.

title: Burch to Start Arts and Letters in Widener If Workouts Are Satisfactory
description: MIAMI, Feb. 10Trainer Elliott Burch said today that if Arts and Letters worked in satisfactory fashion this week end he would start the Ribot colt in the $100,000added Widener at Hialeah a week from Saturday.The 1969 horse of the year has not run since winning the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Aque duct last Oct. 25 and the Wide ner distance is a mile and a quarter. But Burch feels Arts and Letters is up to the assign ment.

title: Port Agency Picks Manager
description: Anthony Barber of Basking Ridge, N. J., has been appoint ed manager of the George Washington Bridge Bus Station by the Port of New York Au thority. He succeeds Lee C. Webb, who retired last month. Mr. Barber joined the bistate gency in 1961.

title: A U.S. Company Loses Suit, Longest in Australian History
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 10 A judge of the New South Wales Equity Court today ac cused principals of an Ameri can company of blatant perjury, misuse of legal process and de liberate misrepresentation of information it had obtained from the Australian Deputy Prime Minister, John McEwen.

title: Russian in Spy Affair Described as Scofflaw
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 10Alcksandr V. Tik homirov, The Russian trans lator arrested Saturday in Seattle on espionage charges, seems to have been attract ing the attention of the New York City police for years by ignoring traffic regula tions.

title: Men's Wear Retailers Play a Numbers Game
description: DALLAS, Feb. 10  Mer chants attending the annual convention here of the Mens wear Retailers of America are playing a numbers game.

title: Laird and Wheeler in Saigon For Study of Vietnamization
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird; the man who coined the term Vietnamiza tion, arrived here tonight to review the progress of that program during the last year.

title: TWO TIMES MEN WIN POLK AWARDS
description: Henry Kamm and Walter Rugaber, members of the news staff of The New York Times, were among the winners of George Polk Memorial Awards for outstanding achievement in journalism in 1969, it was announced yesterday by Long Island University, sponsor of the annual awards.

title: OTTO MAYER, SERVED OLYMPIC COMMITTEE
description: GENEVA, Feb. 10Otto R. Mayer, former chancellor of the International Olympic Commit tee, died today in Lausanne. He was 69 years old.

title: AGNEW DENOUNCES FULBRIGHT VIEWS
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP) Vice President Agnew told Missouri Republicans tonight that policies voiced by Senator J. W. Fulbright amounted to a blueprint for defeat in Viet nam and retreat from the world.

title: A DETERGENT CURB IN CANADA DOUBTED
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press)  Resources Minister John J. Greene conceded today that the federal Government was powerless to enforce any ban on phosphates in laundry detergents or a progressive re duction in their use.

title: Enterprise Fund Suspending Sales
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10No share sales have, been made by the Enterprise Fund or Harbor Fund in the last 10 days follow ing the filing of a suit by the Securities & Exchange Commis sion against the mutual funds' investment adviser and under writer, the Shareholders Man agement Company.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY, ??, 1970

title: Army Six Beats Yale, 32, In Overtime on Young's Goal
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 10  Army played its fourth overtime hockey game in five starts tonight and beat Yale, 32. Dave Young scored the winning goal in the sudden death period.

title: Blue Hill Troupe Dance to Help Disturbed Children
description: The 10th annual Blue Hill Troupe dance, to benefit the children of Friendly Homes, Inc., a residence in the Bronx for disturbed children, will be held Friday in the ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Captain Reports He Protested Possible Stalling in Calley Case
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 10 The man who signed murder charges against First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said to day that he had led a sort of rebellion among the young law officers of this post early last September when it appeared to them that the Nixon Ad ministration and Pentagon of ficials might be trying to cover up the alleged Sogmy mas sacre.

title: Ban on Autos in Center of Large Cities Weighed by Swedish Pollution Experts
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 11  Swedish officidls, having already taken strict measures against air pollution, are think ing of banning private cars from sizable downtown areas in Stockholm and other cities.

title: 10% in Costs Seen in Nonpolluting Car
description: 10% in Costs Seen in Nonpolluting Car

title: French Militants Fan New Student Unrest
description: NANTERRE, France, Feb. 3 Al Fatah will win! shouted leftist protesters who surged through the law school here. Their campus foes had already slathered its walls with the slo ean Israel Will Live.

title: City Will Build 1,000 SeeThrough Bus Stop Shelters
description: The City Highway Depart ment has begun a long range, $2million program to erect more than 1,000 side walk shelters at bus stops along heavily traveled routes. For the first time, some New Yorkers waiting in the snow and the rain for a bus will have the protection that rid ers in London, Paris, Cleve land, and other cities have enjoyed for years. Although the lack of shelters has al ways been a major cause of complaints from riders here, the requirements of such shelter in New York have heretofore defied solution by any city department. The shelters had to be construct ed in such a way that they would not conceal a mugger, but be resistant to the efforts of vandals, be easy to clean and be inexpensive to con struct. Last summer, however, after lengthy consultation: with the police, the Highway Department began a small pilot project with 50 structures, each costing about $2,000. Mayor Lindsay recently expanded it into a longrange program that will be paid for out of the capi tal budget.

title: Newsmen and Guards Clash As Accused Spy Returns
description: Airline and Soviet security guards scuffled with reporters and photographers last night at Kennedy International Airport when Aleksandr V. Tikhomirov, who has been charged by the United States with espionage returned here from Seattle.

title: A Role for Diana Lynn: Travel Agent
description: A Role for Diana Lynn: Travel Agent

title: Julia Long and James K. Tighe Will Marry in North Carolina
description: BURLINGTON, N. C., Feb. 11Mr. and Mrs. George At tonore Long of Burlington have announced the engage ment of their daughter Miss Julia Margaret Long, to James Kenneth Tighe, son of Mr. George Augustus Tighe of Bronxville, N. Y., and Mrs. Andrew Mitchell of Prince ton, N. J. The couple plan to be married here April 11 in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Comforter.

title: Sports of The Times
description: WEEB EWBANK put it all into perspective. Now don't sign anybody until our doctor examines him, the Jets' coach said. We've learned. We're still paying people who never played for us.

title: Business Records
description: EASTERN DISTRICT

title: Sonics Topple Bullets
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 11 (AP) Bob Boozer's free throw with two seconds remaining tonight enabled the Seattle Sonics to beat the Baltimore Bullets, 119117.

title: State Savings Banks Show Deposit Outflow in January
description: Savings banks in New York State suffered a heavy outflow of deposits during January as savers withdrew their funds to place them in higheryielding openmarket investments, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yes terday.

title: 5GOAL OUTBURST GAINS 5TH IN ROW
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11  The Rangers kept waiting for all of the Rolling Stones to swoop down on a powerplay tonight, or perhaps for the elec tricity to fail completely.

title: Gale Drives Oil From Broken Tanker Off Nova Scotia
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11A south easterly gale drove oil from the broken Liberian tanker Arrow toward the rocky Nova Scotia shore today. So far pollution has been light. Patches of shoreline have been contaminated.

title: Met Museum Opens Year 1200 Show
description: The Metropolitan Museum's second major exhibition of its centennial year opens to the public todaywith holi day hours of from 1 to 5 P.M.

title: Nixon and Senators at Odds on Laos Transcript
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  President Nixon was reported today to have refused to authorize the release of any thing more than a heavily cen sored version of a Senate subcommittee's transcript of Administration testimony on the extent of United States in volvement in Laos.

title: Colorado Health Unit Studies Charge of AtomPlant Hazard
description: DENVER, Feb. 11The Colo rado Department of Public Health is looking into the re port by a group of scientists that the Rocky Flats atom bomb manufacturing plant has been releasing highly poisonous plu tonium into the environment.

title: Shriver Reported Ready to Resign as Paris Envoy to Enter Political Arena
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 11 One of the small dramas of American politics in 1970 is being played out in a Paris office.

title: MORSE IS NAMED ARBITRATOR HERE
description: David A. Morse was ap pointed the new impartial chairman of the New York coat and suit industry yesterday.

title: ELECTRICITY OUTPUT ROSE 8.1% IN WEEK
description: The nation's electric power production rose 8.1 per cent last week from the yearearlier level, the Edison Electric Insti tute reported yesterday.

title: Market Place
description: THAT erstwhile stock market whiz bang, the Parvin  Dohrmann Company, will rejoin the American Stock Exchange trading list Monday amid excited conjec ture about its opening price.

title: Pan Am Air Loss Grows; Profit at American Rises
description: Intense competition from other carriers on its worldwide routes, a costly strike, inter mittent employes lowdowns and a $30million increase in its wage bill were cited yesterday as partial explanations for Pan American World Airways, Inc.'s reporting a 1969 deficit of $25,257,000, a record loss for the company.

title: U.S. JETS ATTACK FOE IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11United States fighter bombers attacked enemy gun positions inside Cambodia to day after an American light observation helicopter was struck by ground fire from Cambodia and exploded in the air, United States spokesmen said.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Today is Lincoln's Birth day. Following is a list of services that are affected:

title: CivilDefense Measures Are Tightened in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Feb. 11  In ex pectation of attacks on Cairo, the Ministry of the Interior has ordered tightening of de fense measures. The capital's car owners were given 24 hours to paint their head liphtc blue or face fines.

title: WILLIAM ABERNETHY
description: SPING LAKE, N.J. Feb. 11 William Abernethy, former pres ident of the Sanitary Supply Company and the Monmouth Plumbing Supply Company, dis tributors of building materials in this area, died Monday at his home, 401 Monmouth Ave nue, Spring Lake. He was 74 year old.

title: Cabby Dies From Beating During West Side Robbery
description: A 47yearold cab driver who was beaten and robbed early yesterday on the West Side, died of head injuries a few hours later in Roosevelt Hos pital.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1970

title: Article 3  No Title
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11The job of cleaning up the automobile engine by 1975 to meet Presi dent Nixon's proposed require ments could raise the price of a new car by 10 per cent, one of the auto industry's leading pollution experts said today.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The Pentagon today identi fied th, following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Men'sWear Leader Sets Goals
description: DALLAS, Feb. 11.  My problems are nearer those of the little guy than those of the big stores and my major goal this year is to help give small retailers some or the advan tages that big companies have had for a long time.

title: Nixon, in Letter, Praises Organizer of World Skiing
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 11 (AP)A personal letter from President Richard Nixon was presented tonight to Fabio Conci, the president of the Italian Winter Sport Federa tion, congratulating him for the organization of the Val Gardena World Alpine championships.

title: GRAY IDOL SCORES IN BOWIE SPRINT
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 11 (AP) Eldon Nelson a jockey, and John Tammaro, a trainer, joined forces today to capture three of the first seven races, in cluding a one, two finish in the featured Eddie Gallaher Purse at Bowie race course.

title: Two Hunter Students Destroy Murals in Subway
description: Some of the Hunter College students who helped redecorate a subway station last weekend contended last night that they had been unfairly used. Two of them destroyed the murals they had painted earlier.

title: Bridge:
description: THE Dallas Aces, the 1970 North American bridge team, arrived back on their home grounds last night to continue their touring rival ry with Omar Sharif's Bridge Circus. A private practice session was held last night and the Aces impressed their nonplaying captain, Oswald Jacoby.

title: Networks Will Discuss Satellite As Way to End A.T.&T. Costs
description: The three commercial tele vision networks have curbed their immediate interest in using a domestic satellite sys tem to relay their programs across the country. They have engaged Page Communications Engineers, Inc., of Washington, to study all possible methods of interconnecting their affili ated stations, whether by ground or microwave facilities.

title: Newsmen and Guards Clash As Accused Spy Returns
description: Airline and Soviet security guards scuffled with reporters and photographers last night at Kennedy International Airport when Aleksandr V. Tikhomirov, who has been charged by the United States with espionage returned here from Seattle.

title: REPORTED CRIMES DECLINE 1% IN CITY
description: For the first time since the Police Department modernized its crime analysis system four years ago, the annual number of major crimes reported in the city has dropped.

title: WIDE CURBS ASKED FOR SNOWMOBILES
description: DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 11 States across the nation's snow belt were urged today to regu late the design and use of snowmobiles before their bur geoning numbers and indiscri minate operation became a pub lic nuisance.

title: RISE IS EKED OUT IN AMEX TRADING
description: Rumors of an imminent cut in interest rates enabled the American Stock Exchange to post a gain yesterday as a late rally wiped out most of the ear lier losses.

title: Board of Rabbis Here Elects New President
description: The New York Board of Rabbis yesterday elected Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein, the spiritual leader of Tem ple EmanuEl in Lynbrook, L. I., as the board's presi dent.

title: Most Markets Open Today
description: Major securities exchanges will operate as usual today, Lincoln's Birthday. However, some commodity markets will he closed. Among those closing are the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the Com modity Exchange of New York and the New York Cocoa Ex change. Others will he open. Banks here will he closed.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT HAS PROFIT DROP
description: Substantial charges for fu ture losses on contracts reduced last year's earnings of the Unit ed Aircraft Corporation to $50, 909,496, or $4.21 a common share, from the record of $61, 393,951, or $5.10 a share, earned in 1968 after similar special charges, according to a report issued yesterday from the company's East Hartford, Conn., headquarters.

title: St. Patrick's Marshal Named
description: John Kerry O'Donnell, New York restaurateur and pro moter of Gaelic football and hurling, has been elected grand marshal of the 208th annual St. Patrick's Day Parade which will be held on Fifth Avenue beginning at noon on March 17. The installation ceremony will take place at the Com modore Hotel on Tuesday eve ning, March 3.

title: League to Loan Pilots $650,000 And Keep Franchise in Seattle
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (UPI) The American League club owners decided tonight to maintain the Pilots' franchise in Seattle under its present ownership.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Northern Liberals Counter Ribicoff School Criticisms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Sen ate liberals, shaken by the new alliance between Senator Abra ham A. Ribicoff and Southern opponents of school desegrega tion, moved today to counter the Connecticut Democrat's contention that the North was guilty of monumental hypoc risy.

title: Hired Killer in Westchester Gets a 25YeartoLife Term
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 11 (AP) Kenneth Wedra, hired killer of Dorothy DeTore, was sen tenced to a maximum of 25 years to life in Westchester County Court today.

title: Spitz Stars in Swim Meet
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 11 (AP)Mark Spitz swam the fastest 200yard butterfly in the nation this year with a time of 1 minute 52.6 seconds today as Indiana downed Pur due, 8340. The Hoosiers won 12 of the 13 events.

title: A Brokerage House Seeks Pension Role
description: A brokerage house is at tempting to invade a restricted area of pensionfund manage ment by requesting the internal Revenue Service to permit to sponsor prototype pension olans.

title: MOSCOW SENTENCES. 3 ALIEN PROTESTERS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11Three young activiststwo Italians and a Belglanwere sentenced today to a year in a Soviet la bor camp for staging public protests in support of political dissidents.

title: Uranium Ore Body Found
description: The United Nuclear Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had discovered a body of uranium ore in the LagunaRio Puerco region of New Mexico. The company estimated that the body contained 1 million tons of uraniumbearing ma terial, which included about 3 million pounds of uranium ox ides.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Quotas are the amounts the I.M.F.'s member nationsmost of the nonCommunist world plus Yugoslaviaagree to de posit. They determine the amount each nation may bor row to help it solve balanceof payments problems.

title: 3 Professors Feared Lost in L. I. Sound Air Crash
description: GROTON, Conn., Feb. 11 (UPI)Two professors and the dean of the College of Engi neering at Virginia Polytechnic, Institute were among five per sons aboard a plane believed to have crashed in Long Island Sound.

title: Opera: New Golden Girl
description: RENATA TEBALDI may have recorded the role of Minnie in Puccini's Fan ciulla del West, but she had never sung it in New York. Last night at the Metropoli tan Opera she took care of that omission. At the end of the first act she received a good hand. At the end of the second, the audience would not let her go. New York had found a new Girl of the Golden West to love.

title: UTILITIES EXPAND AT UNABATED RATE
description: Utilities continued to expand rat an unabated rate with a variety of new programs and projects announced yesterday.

title: ABM RADAR CALLED PERIL TO MINUTEMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  The Safeguard antiballistic missile radars emit such power ful radiation that they could cripple the longrange missiles they are supposed to protect. The radiation could also endan ger the health of the launching crews, according to the Army.

title: GROUPS TO FIGHT FOR 20CENT FARE
description: A coalition of groups opposed to the 30cent transit fare here announced yesterday that it would circulate petitions for a citywide referendum designed to roll the fare back to 20 cents.

title: Nixon Report Is Due Feb. 18
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The White House announced today that President Nixon would send his first annual state of the world report to Congress on Feb. 18.

title: Preparing for the New
description: The national observance today of Abraham Lincoln's birth one hundred and sixtyone years ago comes at time when the moral centerpiece of his Presidency the emancipation of the black manis being disputed in its most important meaning: education of youth as the way to achieve full equality of opportunity and citizenship in the United States, North and South.

title: DiBona Rejects Job As Draft Director
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Nixon Administration's most recent choice for Selec tive Service Director has with drawn himself from considera tion in the face of a threat from a senior member of the Senate Armed Services Com mittee to block the nomination.

title: President Pledges He Won't Jawbone Industry on Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 11 President Nixon promised about a hundred of the nation's top business executives tonight that he would not resume the dis carded Kennedy and Johnson Administration practices of trying to jawbone businesses into not raising prices.

title: Mexican Journey Leads to a Dish Called Food for the Gods
description: AMONG the most interesting cooking classes in Manhattan are the Mex ican ones of Diana Southwood Kennedy, and they have, within recent months, acquired an added dimension.

title: BANK SHIFT URGED ON FOREIGN LOANS.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  The member of the Federal Re serve Board who has been run ning the program of control over bank lending to foreigners proposed today a major change in the program.

title: Pontiff Warns Against Bill To Legalize Divorce in Italy
description: ROME, Feb. 11Pope Paul VI, noting the 41st anniversary today of the signing of the Lateran Treaty and the Con cordat between Italy and the Holy See, said the Vatican ac cepted the need for a jointly negotiated revision of some parts of the 1929 agreement.

title: Nixon Won't Fight Move
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11The Nixon Administration will not oppose two Stennis amend ments to the fouryear, $35 billion education bill, the chair man of the Georgia Republican party said tonight.

title: GOVERNOR SPURNS CITY S.I. ROAD PLAN
description: Governor Rockefeller re jected the city's plans for the Richmond Parkway yesterday and recommended that Mayor Lindsay accept an alternate route along the western edge of the Greenbelt in central Staten Island.

title: BILL ON ABORTIONS STUDIED IN HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 11 (AP) A bill repealing the state's abortion laws was referred to day to a SenateHouse confer ence committee.

title: Hofstra Beats C. W. Post In Final Seconds by 6259
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. 1., Feb. 11 Hofstra beat C.W. Post tonight, 6259. Hofstra's Gary Doyle led all scorers with 22 points, in cluding two free throws with six seconds remaining to clinch the game. Dave Bell had 21 points and 12 rebounds for Hofstra, which evened its won lost record at 1111.

title: Egyptians Report Assault on Israelis By Infantry Force
description: CAIRO, Feb. 11Cairo's mili tary spokesman reported that an Egyptian infantry company carried out another major as sault across the Suez Canal early today, occupying an Is raeli fortified position and later ambushing an armored column.

title: DAVIDSON CHECKS S. CAROLINA, 6862
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 11 (UPI)Eleventhranked David son staged a secondhalf rally against South Carolina tonight to hand the secondranked Gamecocks their first defeat in 18 games, 6862.

title: Garelik Votes No In Estimate Session On Morgenthau Job
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik, in a display of political independence, voted against one Lindsay administra tion proposal yesterday and sharply questioned another.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: OCHO RIOS, Jamaica  Jamaica's off shore sport fishing is excellent, and char ter boat rates are comparable to those along Florida's coast.

title: L. S. U. Takes No. 14
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 11 (AP)Louisiana State gained its 14th victory in 20 games by defeating the University of Florida, 9485, tonight in South eastern Conference action.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMJerome J. In memory of our beloved brother who passed away Feb. 12, 1968.

title: LOS ANGELES TOLD IT MUST INTEGRATE ALL SCHOOLS BY '71
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11  The Los Angeles school system was ordered today to present a plan by June 1 for the inte gration of the district's 555 schools.

title: ALEXANDER RALIWAIN, HISTORY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Alexander F. Balmain, a former assistant professor of history and sociology at Ford ham University, died Saturday at North Shore Hospital, Man hasset, L. I., after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at the Sands Point (L.I.) Nursing home.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: DIANA LYNN HALL opens today in her first ci vilian part, and she's letting her hair grow for the role. The former actress (she's not sure whether she gave up the theater or the theater gave her up) is director of Go, a travel agency, operated by Diners Fugazy Travel. Go is the newest inhabitant of Bon wit Teller's sixth floor.

title: FORDHAM TO MEET NIAGARA TONIGHT
description: Ed Conlin, Fordham's basket ball coach, believes the only way Calvin Murphy of Niagara can be stopped is with a fish net and a tranquilizer gun.

title: PAPERBOARD OUTPUT ROSE 2.6% IN WEEK
description: Paperboard production rose 2.6 per cent with 526,600 tons in the week ended Feb. 7 from 512,500 tons in the yearearlier week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday. New orders rose 2.0 percent from the pre ceding year's levels on the fourweek moving average.

title: Phone Workers Choose C.W.A. to Represent Them
description: The Communications Work ers of America has won a rep resentation election among 34,000 plant department em ployes of the New York Tele phone Company, the National Labor Relations Board reported yesterday.

title: GELBER JOINS SZELL IN CARNEGIE CONCERT
description: Bruno Leonardo Gelber is a young and extremely gifted pianist and George Szell is a seasoned and extremely gifted conductor. The Brahms Piano Concerto in D minor, on which the two musicians collaborated last night in the Cleveland Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall, reflected those facts precisely.

title: TV Review
description: THE age of youth? Balder dash! The over70 set walked off yesterday morning with a television program that combined the engaging qualities of lightly recalled nostalgia, the sophisticated sti letto, and a demonstration of genuine affection that had more substance than adoles cent wails on how love will save the world.

title: Television
Anne Stewart Plans June Wedding
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 11  Mr. and Mrs. Frederic M. Stewart have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Stewart, to Army Lieut. Chris Harlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas C. Harlow of Sunnyside, Queens. A June wedding is planned.

title: Social Content Mild in New Soviet Revue
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11Watch Your Faces a theatrical mix ture of poetry by Andrei Voznesensky, imaginative pantomime, topical humor and a relatively mild social message, opened here last night.

title: Miss Sheehan To Be a Bride
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Feb. 11Miss Evelyn T. Sheehan and Richard F. Edmonds plan to be married here in early June. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Sheehan of Miller Place and. Massapequa, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mrs. Field Edmonds of North ampton, Mass., and the late Stuart Coles Edmonds of Boston.

title: Bernstein's Last Concert Of Season Goes Smoothly

title: FORD IS WEIGHING DROPPING TEAMS

title: Friends Plan Salute to Duke Ellington

title: 'My Sweet Charlie,' Interracial Drama, Opens at the Regency
description: The speed with which "My Sweet Charlie" has leaped from television into commercial movie houses is justified. In the faces and eyes of the two principals in this new drama  a pregnant, unwed Southern girl and a young Northern Negro hiding in an abandoned house on the Gulf Coast  there is truth, power and beauty. Superbly played by Patty Duke and Al Freeman Jr., the emerging characters of these two young people in their initial racial friction, personal torment and eventual understanding make for an intelligent but flawed film, definitely worth seeing at the Regency, where it opened yesterday.Nicely photographed in color on a sparsely populated strip of the Gulf Coast, this Universal release is essentially a dialogue, encased in a melodramatic frame, a dutiful, obvious device that cues in some theatrical touches. The story, adapted from David Westheimer's novel and play by Richard Levinson and William Link, will be predictable to anybody who has seen a movie in the last 20 years.From the moment the frightened heroine screams "Nigger!" at the other intruder on the remote premises, we know that these two lonely young fugitives eventually will, learn from each other understanding and simple human values. And looking at their plight squarely, some viewers may wonder if the drama would have stronger, more meaningful or perhaps even more honest with the intellectual scales more balanced.The young Negro portrayed by Mr. Freeman, an articulate, activist lawyer from the North who has killed a Southerner in self-defense, is exceptional. The Dixie girl, an equally stubborn but inarticulate redneck, is not. What matters is the wonderfully true, moving and meshed performances of Mr. Freeman and Miss Duke under Lamont Johnson's searching direction.The picture slips from reality in contrived touches. A climactic scene, in which Mr. Freeman tangles with a stereotype of a tolerant white storekeeper, is as phony as it can be. And the fade-out, rather than being poignant, is flat."My Sweet Charlie" has some serious flaws as rounded drama, but its Charles Roberts and Marlene Chambers are real.

title: Clement S. Crystal Dead at 68; Founded City Building Concern
description: Clement S. Crystal, president of Clement S. Crystal, Inc., con struction contractors, died yes terday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 190 East 72d Street in New York.

title: World Bank to Get Loan From Japan For the First Time

He never walks the night streets without it. Once, he says, he took his nocturnal walk wearing a porkpie hat, but felt like an anachronism.

At stake is the future of public education as well as the protection of religious freedom. Efforts to eliminate the socalled Blaine Amendmentthe 75yearold ban on the direct or indirect expenditure of public funds in support of religious institutionsare clearly a response to pleas by churchrelated schools for a massive infusion of tax dollars.

Senator Abe Ribicoff of Connecticut is going to support this because of what he called the monumental hy pocrisy of the North, where communities have been as sys tematic and consistent as South ern communities in denying to the black man and his children the opportunity that exists for the white people.

The project, in which scientists from the Soviet Union and the United States are playing leading roles, would identify subtle but po tentially disastrous alterations caused by pollution, power plant radiation, chemicals and other factors. habit it. description: THAT venerable institution, This Was Burlesque, came back to New York last night at the Hudson West Cabaret Theater. Ann Corio's memory book of burlesque, originally opened off Broad way in 1962, moved to Broadway in 1965 and sev eral months later began what appears to be an endless road tour of America.

title: $10MILLION GIVEN TO BROOKLYN AREA
description: Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy sat quietly in an overcrowded room yesterday as Mayor Lind say, New York's two United States Senators and other speakers praised a $10.1mil lion Federal grant to develop the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn.

title: Chicago 7 Defense Charges U.S. Concocted Case to justify Police Violence
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11The de fense in the Chicago conspiracy trial contended today that the Government concocted its case against the seven defend ants to justify the police vio lence against demonstrators during the Democratic National convention here in 1968.

title: ERICH HECKEL DIES; EXPRESSIONIST, 86
description: BONN, Feb. 11  Erich Heckel, one of the first German exinessionists, died after a long illness Jan. 27 at a hospital in Radolfzell, Lake Constance. He was 86 years old.

title: CAIRO ADMONISHES BIG OIL CONCERNS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 11Arab pres sure on United States oil inter ests intensified today following a declaration by five Arab con frontation countries that the exploitation of Arab resources and wealth by benefactors of Israel must be liquidated.

title: Cabinet Said to Reject Eban's CeaseFire Plan
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 (Reu ters)Newspapers here re ported today that the Israeli Cabinet had overwhelmingly rejected proposals by Foreign Minister Abba Eban for a new political initiative by Israel to restore the ceasefire with the United Arab Republic.

title: Connecticut Aide Named
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 11. (AP) State Treasurer Gerald M. Lamb, the first Negro elected a state executive office in Con necticut, was appointed State Bank Commissioner today. Mr. Lamb had been State Treasurer for seven years, winning elec tion with the state Democratic ticket in 1962 and 1966.

title: CHARLES POWERS, 65, AUTO CLUB COUNSEL
description: Charles E. Powers, resident counsel and secretary of the Automobile Club of New York until his retirement Jan. 1, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: PAULINE KAEL is my favorite movie critic, which doesn't mean she is necessarily reliable or trust worthy. Absolute trustworthiness presup poses a static intelligence, a kind of analytical gearbox or dogma mill for grinding fine whatever cinematic grain drops into it. Reliable critics, automata with whom you know you will al ways agree or dis agree, are usually flacking for one of George Orwell's smelly little or thodoxies, either ideological or com mercial. Not Miss Kael. She doesn't thump you on the head with Cahiers du Cinma or Sieg fried Kracauer or the latest press release on the state of Darryl Zanuck's soul. She writes superbly; has been and remembers almost every rum ever made; she knows where all the bodies, artistic and financial, are buried; and she is rest less: I resent the assumption that we are so bored and corrupt that we will be pleased whenever we are not bored. Since I am not bored outside the theater, why should I go in to see a movie whose only purpose is to keep me from being bored?

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Management. President Nixon signed an Executive order establishing the Presi dent's Advisory Council on Management Improvement. The council will be chaired by Bernard A. Schriever, the former Air Force missile di rector.

title: Atom Test Under Mesa
description: MERCURY, Nev., Feb. 11 (UPI)  An underground nu clear test with a maximum power equivalent to 20,000 tons of TNT was triggered today 1,300 feet below the surface of a mesa. The Atomic Energy Commission said that the de vice had been fired at the end of a tunnel 5,000 feet long, near Ranier Mesa in the Nevada test site. No radiation leaked into the atmosphere, the commission said.

title: UNITPRICE STUDY ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Commerce Department was accused today of conduct ing an industrybiased study to determine whether unit pricing  the posting of the price per pound, ounce or other appropriate unit for food and other consumer items  was necessary and feasible.

title: HENRY F. WOOGE
description: SPRING LAKE HEIGHTS, N.J., Feb. 11Henry F. Wooge, former chief of detectives of the New Jersey State Police, died yesterday at Point Pleas ant Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: RUMORS TRIGGER BIG BOARD RALLY
description: Spurred by rumors of immi nent reductions in key interest rates, stock prices rallied sharp ly in heavy trading late yester day.

title: Business Returning to Normal in Lesotho After Coup
description: MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 8 To rent. says an advertise ment in The Rand Daily Mail of Johannesburg, mountain cot tage in Lesotho, Splendid sce nery and superb trout fishing.

title: YESHIVA BUILDING DAMAGED BY FIRE
description: A fire caused heavy damage early this morning to the two story building occupied by the Flatbush Yeshiva in Brooklyn.

title: ROBERT G. THOMPSON
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 11 Robert G. Thompson of 236 Oak Ridge Avenue, who retired in 1964 as president and chairman of the board of the Lufkin Rule Company, now a division of Cooper Industries, Saginaw, Mich.; since 1906, died today at a nursing home in Madison. He was 86 years old.

title: Stony Brook Library Grows
description: STONY BOOK, L. I., Feb. 11  The State University center here has been adding an aver age of 100,000 volumes a year to its Frank C. Melville Jr. Memorial Library, library offi cials announced today.

title: Royals Halt Pistons
description: OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 11 (AP) Connie Dierking and Tom Van Arsdale led a rally by the Cincinnati Royals in the last 91/2 minutes of National Bas ketball Association action to night as the Royals defeated the Detroit Pistons, 124113.

title: C.B.S. NET UP 24% ON PEAK REVENUES
Olympic Airways Appoints
description: Olympic Airways has ap pointed Walter G. Conrad as general manager with responsi bilities for the airline's entire Western Hemisphere opera tions. The line serves Europe, the Middle East and South Af rica by way of New York, Chi cago and Montreal.

title: New Grey Unit Will Do Broadcast Spot Baying
description: Spurred probably by the proliferating independent me diabuying services, Grey Ad vertising has created a spe cial unit that will do all its broadcast spot buying.

title: New Place to Shop If You're 25 to 35
description: AND NOW they are design ing clothes for The For gotten Woman. That's what B. Altman & Co. calls the woman whose age lies some where between 25 and 35. Or somewhere between kook and couture, as one store spokesman put it. At any rate, she's a woman who's not about to climb into those sleazy, furikycol ored duds that sell so well to the Aquarian Genera tion. And so Altman's has come to the resctie of The Forgotten Woman with a new third floor shop called The Young Collection. It sells only clothes that the buyer, Gail Gallagher, herself a For gotten Woman, considers right for the 2535 age group.

title: Virus Production to Rise in Hunt For Evidence of a Link to Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  American laboratories will be asked to make a big effort this year to grow large amounts of viruses in the hope of clinching the rapidly accumulating evi dence that some human cancers are caused by viruses.

title: Assembly Defers Action on Blaine Law
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11The As sembly postponed action today on, a controversial bill to re peal the state's constitutional ban on financial aid to paro chial schools as the bill's spon sor offered an amendment that would permit taxpayers' suits to restrain unconstitutional expenditures.

title: Ducks' Franchise Purchased
description: The Long Island Ducks of the Eastern Hockey League were acquired yesterday by Coliseum Properties Inc., in a stocktransfer transaction. Al Baron remains as president of the Ducks.

title: City to Update Its BombShelter Plan
description: The city is getting ready to feed into a comnuter its vast fund of Civil Defense infor mation, with the goal of matching every person who lives or works here with a shelter that could protect him from radioactive fallout for two weeks.

title: 3 Die in Mountain Clash
description: JOHANNESBURG; South Af rica, Feb. 11It was confirmed in Maseru today that the Lesotho police clashed with civilians at a mountain hideout yesterday. Three men alleged to be mem bers of a secret group seeking to overthrow the Government, were killed and several wound ed, the police said.

title: Foreign Trade of France Showed a January Decline
description: PARIS, Feb. 11 (Reuters)  January French foreign trade showed a deficit of 960million francs, the Finance Ministry said.

title: Religous Services
description: JEWISH

title: I.D.S. Seeks to Reach Goal Of Big Board Membership
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 11 (UPI) Investors Diversified Ser vices, a manager of six mutual funds with assets over $6 billion, said today it would not give up its plans to seek mem bership on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Personal Finance
description: Last year, Congress enacted the Tax Reform Act of 1969, the most massive overhaul of the tax law in the nation's history. The following article is the first of a series that peri odically will examine the implications for personal money management of the changes that were adopted.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Seven Judges for Criminal Court And One for Civil Court Named
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced the appointment of seven judges to the city's Criminal Court and an interim appointment to fill a vacancy on the Civil Court.

title: REYNOLDS METALS MEETS PRICE RISES
description: The Reynolds Metals Com pany said yesterday it would match price increases of 4 per cent to 8 per cent announced by other producers on various types of aluminum wire used in construction.

title: Beatle Haircut Upheld
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. of the United States District Court ruled today that the dress code at Abington High School violated the United States Constitution because it permitted a principal to sus pend a student who would not cut his hair. Judge Wyzanski ordered the school to reinstate David Hamilton White, 16 years old, who was suspended on Feb. 2 because his Beatle style hair clashed with the dress code.

title: HAWKS TROUNCE ROCKETS, 155131
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 11 (AP) Walt Hazzard led Atlanta through a National Basketball Association recordshattering 54point third quarter tonight and the Hawks overwhelmed the San Diego Rockets, 155131.

title: Spending by Ottawa In Next Fiscal Year Put at $12.9Billion
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11The Gov ernment submitted to Parlia ment today spending estimates for 197071 that showed a 7.4 per cent rise to a record level of $12.9billion. Much of the increase resulted from expendi tures required by law.

title: Seals Top North Stars
description: OAKLAND, Feb. 11 (UPI) Harry Howell scored on a pow er play in the second period to break a tie and give Oakland a 21 victory over the Minne sota North Stars tonight to solidify the Seals' hold on fourth place in the Western Division.

title: 300 Leave Boston to Help Cuba Harvest Sugar
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11  Eight busloads of young men and wo men, carrying sleeping bags, knapsacks and provisions, left Boston this afternoon on an ex pedition to harvest sugar in Cuba.

title: GOVERNOR SKEPTICAL ABOUT VEECK'S PLAN
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent expressed doubt today that the latest in a long line of stadium proposals to keep the Patriots in Boston would be acceptable to either the Legislature or the adminis tration.

title: BankAmericard's Billings Climbed 146% Last Year
description: BankAmericard, one of the nation's two principal credit card systems, reported yester day that total billings last year soared to slightly more than $2billion from $814million in 1968, an increase of 146 per cent. Master Charge is the other principal system.

title: Death of Five Laid To '69 Heat Defect
description: A defective chimney, known for nearly a year to city hous ing inspectors, was tentatively blamed yesterday for the death on Tuesday by asphyxiation of a 31yearold mother and four of her six children in their Brooklyn apartment.

title: HIJACKING SUSPECT RETURNED TO U.S.
description: An airliner hijacking suspect who had turned himself in to United States military authori ties in Spain on Monday re turned to this country yester day from Madrid in the cus tody of two United States marshals.

title: Rogers Confers With Tito in Ethiopia on the Middle East and Outlines a FourPoint U.S. Policy on Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 11  Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred with President Tito of Yugo slavia here today on the Mid dle East crisis. In a statement Mr. Rogers also outlined fourpoint policy on Africa that the Nixon Administration in tends to follow.

title: Maritime College Offers Sailing Lecture Series
description: New York Maritime Col lege will begin a 10week lec ture series on sailing tech niques on Tuesday, Rear Ad miral Edward J. O'Donell, the president, announced yes terday.

title: Screvane to Head U.S.O. Here
description: Paul R. Screvane, former City Council President, has been elected president of the United Service Organizations of New York City. Mr. Screvane re ceived the Silver Star Medal and rose to the rank of major in World War II. He is now colonel in the Army Reserve.

title: Mrs. Wexler Installed as 9th President of 100YearOld Hunter College
description: Mrs. Jacqueline Grennan Wexler, appealing for new patterns of government in the cities and on the cam puses, was invested yester day as the ninth president of Hunter College.

title: BOSTON SCORES 14 IN EXTRA SESSION
description: Some defeats over an 82 game National Basketball Asso ciation schedule hurt more than others and last night's 125118 setback by the Boston Celtics was in that category for the New York Knickerbock ers.

title: Police to Wear Flag Patches
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 11 Policemen here will begin wearing American flag patches on their uniforms as a result of approval granted last night by the Board of. Police Com missioners.

title: PROTESTERS DISRUPT HEARING ON COPTERS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 11 The Berkeley City Council's public hearing on a proposal to buy two Police Department helicopters broke up in shouts of anger, stenchbomb fumes and fluttering paper airplanes last night.

title: DR. HELEN KIM, 71, KOREAN FEMINIST
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 11 Dr. Helen Kim, the president emeritus of Ewha Women's University and a pioneer in Ko rean women's education, died last night of cerebral hemor rhage at her home here. She was 86 years old.

title: Park Worker Killed Upstate
description: BINGHAMTON, Feb. 11  Donald Burton, a 40yearold Park Department employe, was killed here today when part of the bridge pavement collapsed under his street sweeping ma chine, dropping him 35 feet into the Susquehanna River. He was married and the father of five children.

title: Frazier and Ellis Choose Their Weapons With Care
description: Throughout the physical examination four white card board cartons of boxing gloves had been on the green rubbing table. And after Dr. A. Harry Kleiman of the State Athletic Commission staff had pronounced Joe Fra zier and Jimmy Ellis to be in excellent condition, Ellis walked over to select his gloves.

title: 1970 RECESSION SEEN BY RESERVE OFFICER
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11  The economy is unlikely to avoid a recession in 1970, a vice president of the Federal. Re serve Bank of St. Louis said today.

title: Carswell Is Supported by a Negro Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Judge G. Harrold Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court won its first support to day from a nationally known Negro leader when it was dis closed that Dr. Thomas W. Mat thew, who was freed from Fed eral prison last month by Presi dent Nixon, had urged that the nomination he confirmed.

title: Dr. Irving LeBell, Headed Board of Health Division
description: Dr. Irving LeBell, former chief of communicable diseases at the Board of Health here, died Wednesday in 13is home, at 680 Longview Drive, Sara sota, Fla. He was 64 years old.

title: Pan Am Airways Elects
description: Otis Chandler, vice chairman of the board of The Times Mir ror Company and publisher of The Los Angeles Times, has been elected to the board of Pan American World Airways. He replaces his father, Norman Chandler, who is retiring after 13 years on the Pan Am board.

title: Channing To Appear In London
description: Carol Channing, the husky voiced, blond comedienne who has been a domestic enter tainment phenomenon for more than 20 years, is finally going to make her foreign stage debut.

title: Progress in Italy
description: As expected, President Saragat has asked Mariano Rumor to reconstruct a fourparty centerleft Govern ment in Italy to replace Mr. Rumor's minority Chris tian Democratic Cabinet. The hope must be that the two Socialist parties are now ready to halt their feuding and collaborate with Christian Democrats and Republicans to end months of dangerous drift.

title: Insko Joins 4 Other Harness Drivers With His 2,500th Winner
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 12  Del Insko, a 5foot2inch, 120pound bundle of energy, arrived tonight at a harness racing plateau previously reached by only four other modernday drivers.

title: Anthony J. West, Miss Thompson Wed in London
description: Miss Antonia, Tackaberry Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Daniel Thompson of New York and Lloyd Neck, L. I., was mar ried in a civil ceremony in London last Friday to An thony James West.

title: 2Day Carnival at Dartmouth Will Open With Giant Slalom
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 12 Just when it seemed that Frosty, the 36foothigh snowman in the middle of Dartmouth's campus, was in danger of shrinking out of sight, along came a deep freeze last night to stop his cold sweat.

title: Students in Milwaukee Form Their own School
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 Bill Ahlhauser, Belinda Behne, Jim Boulet and 32 other Milwaukee teen  agers  among them some of the brightest and most success ful students in the city's most highly regarded public and private schoolsbelieve that much of their high school experience has been a waste of time.

title: A.M.C. Unveils SubCompact Car
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 12Fifteen years ago the newly formed American Mo tors Corporation, a fragile consolidation of the Nash and Hudson Companies, led its giant competitors with the first compact car in the United States, the Rambler. It turned the company around. Today, American Motors unveiled the Gremlin, the first subcompact, de signed to meet the challenge of imported cars.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.S. URGES TALKS ON MIDEAST ARMS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 12The United States to day called for bigpower dis cussions on limiting arms ship ments to the Middle East and declared that the Big Four, should make a joint appeal for an immediate restoration of the ceasefire between Israel and Arab countries.

title: Woman, 58, Dies in Fire
description: Anna Barnes, 58 years old, died in a fire last night in her firstfloor apartment at 538 East 21st Street, Brooklyn. The Fire Department said her body had been found in a bedroom after a small fire undetermined origin was extinguished in her apart ment.

title: Raid Described by Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 12  Israeli jets raided deep in Egyp tian territory today, hitting what were described as a radar station, an army camp, an air force depot and other military installations.

title: Spiral Staircase Takes Hialeah Sprint and Pays $16.60
description: MIAMI, Feb. 12 (AP)The Mill River Stable's Spiral Stair case scored an upset victory in the $10,000 Roman Soldier Purse race at Hialeah today, winning by three lengths from Perfect Tan. Hunter's Dance, a 1131 shot, was only a nose behind Perfect Tan.

title: U.S.SOVIET STUDIES ON SATELLITES URGED
description: PARIS, Feb. 12A coordi nated United StatesSoviet study of satellite communica tions was proposed here today by Robert W. Sarnoff, chair man of the board of the RCA Corporation, as a step toward ending nationalism in commu nications.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Criticizes Negro Over Support of Carswell
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday criticized Negro neurosurgeon who en dorsed the nomination of G. Harrold Carswell to the Su preme Court.

title: WINGS HAND BLUES 6TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) Pete Stemkowski scored twice tonight as the Detroit Red Wings handed the St. Louis Blues their sixth straight loss, 52, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Screen: A Sheriff and a Helping Hand
Westchester Gains Semifinal In Women's National Curling
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)  Three teams rallied in the last end today and a fourth team Westchester of New York won handily in gaining the semifinals of the United States women's curling championships at The Country Club.

title: Sports of The Times
description: ON the opposite side of the Mississippi River from New Orleans is the at tractive Louisiana town of Gretna. For most visitors to the Super Bowl game last month it had no significance. But for any whose first boyhood heroes were the baseball Giants of John McGraw, a visit to Gretna was akin to a pilgrimage to a shrine. This was the birthplace of Mel Ott, the idol of a couple of generations of Gi ant fans.

title: M.T.A. TAKES OVER STEWART AIR BASE
description: The former Stewart Air Force Base, near Newburgh, N. Y., in Orange County, was formally turned over to the Metropoli tan Transportation Authority yesterday for use, starting March 1, as an airport for cor porate and other generalavia ton planes.

title: Conservation of Coasts Urged at European Talks
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 12Representatives of 24 Euro pean countries called today for the safeguarding of unspoiled coastal areas and a variety of other conservationist measures.

title: HERBERT L. WEIDERMAN
description: Herbert L. Weiderman, a re tired insurance executive, died yesterday at the Tuxedo Park (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Reports of Ski Conditions in East
HADASSAH ASKS U.S. TO BOLSTER ISRAEL
description: Hadassah, the Women's Zion ist Organization of America. appealed yesterday to the Nixon Administration to provide Israel with sufficient military and economic strength to deter Arab aggression.

title: U.S. CASE QUASHED BY 6YEAR DELAY
description: A Federal judge said yester day, that a sixyearold criminal tax case would be dismissed because the Government had failed to prosecute it expedi tiously.

title: EAST GERMAN BIDS BRANDT OPEN TALK
description: BONN, Feb. 12  Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany today invited Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany to confer this month in East Ber lin on a treaty between the two German states.

title: Amount of Aid Disputed
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 12 Pakistan is providing mili tarytraining assistance to Jor dan but the number of her per sonnel there, as reported in The New York Times, is highly ex aggerated, a Foreign Office spokesman said today in Is lamabad.

title: OIL TANKER STERN SINKS OFF CANADA
description: TORONTO, Feb. 12  The stern section of the broken Liberian tanker Arrow, holding a million gallons of heavy fuel oil, sank in 100 feet of water off Nova Scotia today.

title: Brother of Lesotho's King Arrested by Chief Jonathan
description: CAPETOWN, Feb. 12  The brother of King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho, himself under house arrest since Chief Leabua Jona than, the Prime Minister, sus pended the Constitution 13 days ago has been arrested.

title: PROTEST IN MANILA BY 20,000 IS ORDERLY
description: MANILA, Feb. 12An esti mated 20,000 students and workers held an orderly demon stration in downtown Plaza Miranda this evening and lis tened to speakers who denounced growing fascism and imperialism in the coun try.

title: PARIS PEACE SESSION ONE OF THE BRIEFEST
description: PARIS, Feb. 12The four delegations to the Paris peace talks found nothing new to say to one another today and made the 54th plenary session one of the shortest on record.

title: Year and Quarter Down
description: Northwest Industries, Inc., the holding company that owns the Chicago & North Western Railway and the Lone Star Steel Company as well as sev eral other major corporate en tities, reported yesterday its net income last year plunged to $16,818,000, from $36,803,000, in 1968. Last year's earnings ac tually fell $1,718,000 short of the $18,536,000 the company paid holders of its preferred stock. In 1968 earnings were equal to $2.64 a share on the common stock.

title: E.E.C. Stands by GATT
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12  The European Economic Community told its trading partners today it intended to abide by the letter and spirit of the Gen eral Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: 3 Time Bombs Defused
description: ABU ZABAL, United Arab Republic, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  Egyptian Army engineers to night defused three unexploded Israeli time bombs in the rub ble of a scrapmetal processing plant that was bombed today.

title: Galley's CourtMartial Is Tentatively Set for May
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 12 A tentative date in midMay for the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with the murder of 102 Vietnamese civilians, was set today by Lieut. Col. Reid W. Kennedy military judge.

title: Karl Spitzer Fiance Of Patricia A. Moser
description: Miss Patricia Ann Moser, a junior at Carnegie Mellon University, plans to be mar ried to Karl Geoffrey Spitzer, a student at Boston Univer sity School of Law.

title: TV: Red, White and Maddox on Air
description: A CUT version of Red, White and Maddox. the satire on the career of Gov. Lester Maddox of Georgia, which had a brief Broadway run after an original presen tation in Atlanta, was of fered last night by station WNEWTV, Channel 5. The show's compression to elec tronic proportions was not very helpful, and the best joke of the night had nothing do with the original.

title: FULLMER IS HELD TO DRAW BY BOGS
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 12 (AP)  Don Fullmer of West Jor dan, Utah, fought a 10round draw tonight with Tom Bogs, the European middleweight champion from Denmark, in an unpopular decision before 7,000 outraged spectators who thought the American had won.

title: Mrs. Court Defeats Virginia Wade, 63, 63, in Vanderbilt Club Tennis Final
description: Continuing her private blitz krieg through women's tennis, Mrs. Margaret Court of Aus tralia won the women's invita tion tournament at the Vander bilt Club last night by over coming Virginia Wade of England, 63. 63.

title: Upsets Mark Realignment Of Hutton's Top Officers
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest broker age houses, announced yester day a series of changes in its top management that included several surprises.

title: Trevino and Murphy Shoot 66's and Tie for Lead in Tucson Golf
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 12 (AP) Bob Murphy posted a six underpar 66 today and tied Lee Trevino for the firstround lead in the $100,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

title: 3 SKIERS INJURED IN PRACTICE RUNS
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 12 (AP)Billy Kidd, America's skiing ace, who has a sore back, moved into the favorite's role for the combined title at the world Alpine ski champion ships today when Dumeng Giovanoli of Switzerland and Franz Vogler of West Germany were injured during practice runs.

title: Shriver and Family to Pay Private Visit to Rumania
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The United States Ambassador to France, Sargent Shriver, is fly ing from Paris to Bucharest to morrow on a private visit, State Department officials said today.

title: Cairo: The Warring Capitals
description: CAIRO, Feb. 12The war has not changed Cairo much on the surface. Some but not all the vast windows at the airport are taped, just in case. Some but not all lights are dimmed at night; but the life of the city goes on about as before, slow and indifferent as the Nile.

title: Germans Say Arabs Planned to Hijack El Al Jet
description: BONN, Feb. 12The three Arabs who hurled grenades at the passengers of an Israeli air liner at the Munich airport Tuesdaykilling one of them and injuring 11 originally planned to hijack the jet, the Bavarian Interior Minister, Bruno Merk, disclosed today.

title: Cop on the Campus
description: THERE was a summer va cation when David Durk, now a sergeant on the New York City police force, was still at Amherst College, and turned down a chance to be an interne at the United Na tions and joined the team sters instead to take a job working in a freezer from midnight to 8 A.M. There were two of them, college in the boys, and Mr. Durk recalled that we were accept ed when we took all their money in a poker game. Then, in the early summer of 1963, he made another out wardly unexpected career choice and joined the police force.

title: Air Nauru: Newest and Smallest Airline
description: NAURU, Feb. 12  The world's smallest republic has started the world's smallest in ternational airline, Air Nauru, according to an announcement by the government of this Pa cific island.

title: 10 Students Indicted
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP)Ten students were indicted by a Suffolk County grand jury to day on charges arising from recent disturbances at North eastern University and Ken more Square. The disturbance at Northeastern took place Jan. 29 outside an auditorium where S. I. Hayakawa, president of San Francisco State College, was speaking.

title: SMITH RATED NO. 1 ON U.S. TENNIS LIST
description: Stan Smith, who capped brilliant 1969 showing with two singles victories and a share of the doubles triumph in Davis Cup challenge round play, was listed No. 1 nation ally yesterday In the United States Lawn Tennis Associa tion's final rankings.

title: 5 Overcome in Brooklyn Fire
description: Four patrolmen and a fire man were overcome yesterday while rescuing four persons from a fire in a rooming house at 7702 Fifth Avenue, in the. Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. The patrolmen were William O'Neill, 38 years old; Ronald Kiel, 29; George Gallagher, 28 and Victor Kramiz, 38, from the Fort Hamilton station. The Fireman was Fabian J. Eche varrieta of Ladder Company 109.

title: State Drug Doses For Addicts Urged By Assembly Bill
description: Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter, a West Side Demo crat, introduced a bill yesterday that would make it possible for registered addicts to receive doses of heroin and other hard drugs in state clinics.

title: Columbia Drama Students Raise Sights
description: Lope de Vega's rarely per formed historical drama, Fuente Ovejuna (The Sheep Well), seems a strange vehicle at first glance to introduce a university theatrical troupe to a larger public.

title: Col. Ashley C. McKinley, Byrd Flight Photographer
description: Col. Ashley C. McKinley, who was a photographer on Adm. Richard E. Byrd's flights over the South Pole in 1928 and 1929, died Wednesday at Mor ton F. Plant Hospital, Clear water, Fla. The retired Army officer was 73 years old and lived in Belleair, Fla.

title: Aussies Launch Gretel II, Potential Challenger for America's Cup
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12Gretel II, Australia's po tential challenger this year for the America's Cup, was launched by crane today into Sydney Harbor to the com ments of yachting experts such as not radical but in teresting, a weirdie but she should fly, and probably the most unusual 12Meter yacht ever built.

title: DR. HAROLD ROBERTS, LABOR AUTHORITY, 58
description: Dr. Harold S. Roberts, direc tor and founder of the Univer sity of Hawaii's Industrial Re lations Center in Honolulu, died there Feb. 5 of a heart attack. He was 58 years old. Dr. Rob erts had lived in Hawaii since 1947.

title: Title Figlit Is Such an In Thing That Even Izvestia Will Cover It
description: In the narrow beigetiled hallway of the Madison Square Garden boxing de partment, the old men in their black overcoats shuffle impatiently.

title: Subway Eyedropper
description: The anguished roars from the subway tunnels have finally become loud enough to be heard in Albany. With the statewide election coming on faster than the Sea Beach express, Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders have come up with a modest bundle of cash to make life a little less intoler able for subway riders as well as commuters.

title: Chilean Escudo Adjusted
description: SANTIAGO, Feb. 12 (Reuters) The Chilean Central Bank to day adjusted the escudo to 10.46 to the United States dol lar from 10.26 previously. The bank note rate was fixed at, 12.33/12.34 against 12.08/12.10 previously.

title: Liquidation Asked For Webb & Knapp
description: Mortimer M. Caplin, the bankruptcy trustee for Webb & Knapp. Inc., in a report filed with the Federal district court here, said he had found that after nearly five years of trus teeship there still remains a severe deficiency in stockhold ers' equity of that once far flung realty empire headed by William Zeckendorf Sr.

title: PRESIDENT HINTS HE BACKS STENNIS ON SCHOOLS ISSUE
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 12 President Nixon believes that the North and South should be treated equally on school de segregation, the White House said here today.

title: Bugle Call to Retreat
description: Senator Ribicoff's charge of monumental hypoc risy in the liberals' condemnation of Southern segre gation could serve a high purpose, if it resulted spurring Northern communities to faster school inte gration. The North is indeed vulnerable to charges of footdragging both in bringing about a more equitable racial balance and in improving the educational oppor tunities of Negro and Puerto Rican children. Discrimi nation and neglect cannot be condoned, whether they flow from racist policy, personal insensitivity or pro fessional incompetence.

title: Aide of F.C.C. Says News Media Have Right to Refuse Subpoenas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  Federal Communications com missioner Nicholas Johnson said tonight that the nation's news media had an absolute right to refuse the demands by Government prosecutors for reporters' notes and unused tel evision film.

title: Mary McKee To Be a Bride
description: Miss Mary Jane McKee, a senior at Sweet Briar College, plans to be married in June to Norman Spencer Car michael, a graduate of the University of Virginia.

title: Zambian Opposition Party Banned in Border District
description: LAUSKA, Zambia, Feb. 12 President Kenneth D. Kaunda today banned the oppositioin African National Congress in the Livingston district on Zam bia's border with Rhodesia.

title: City Seeks to Bar Con Ed Plant; Charges Water Supply Threat
description: Continuing its opposition to the proposed Storm King Moun tain storage hydroelectric plant, the city will ask the Federal Power Commission today to reverse a decision granting a construction license to Con solidated Edison Company.
