title: College Looks to Community
description: PRINCETON, N. T., Feb. 12 Princeton University announced today plans for a public meet ins to explore ways of improv ing relations between the uni versity and the Princeton com munity. The meeting, jointly sponsored by the Princeton Area Council of Community: Services and the university's committee on relations with the local community, will he held March 7 in the university's engineering quadrangle.

title: CARSWELL TRACT WAS RESTRICTED
description: CRAWFORDVILLE, Fla., Feb. 12Judge G. Harrold Carswell, nominated by President Nixon to the Supreme Court, owned and sold real estate in 1966 with a covenant restricting the use of the land to members of the Caucasian race.

title: Existing Projects Will Share Funds for Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  More than onefourth of the $800million appropriated by Congress this year for waste treatment plants will not go fort new projects. The money will be used to reimburse the states that have prefinanced the Fed eral share of projects that are already completed or started.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: STOCKS EDGE UP ON LONDON BOARD
description: Stocks advanced slightly in cautious trading on the London stock exchange as traders watched the action on ex changes in New York.

title: SCHEUER TO SHIFT ELECTION DISTRICT
description: Representative James H. Scheuer, whose district in the Bronx was virtually eliminated by this year's reapportionment, announced yesterday that he would seek election from a neighboring district to the north now represented by a fellow Democrat, Jacob H. Gilbert.

title: Columbia Gets Football Aide
description: Norm Gerber, 34 years old, has been appointed an assistant football coach at Columbia Uni versity. He will serve as de fensive coordinator under Coach Frank Navarro, Columbia announced yesterday. Gerber played tackle at the University of Connecticut.

title: Rockefeller's Transit Loan Plan Called Inadequate by Democrats
description: Democrats yesterday heaped criticism on details of Gover nor Rockefeller's proposed $30.7million masstransit loan. But many conceded that it was a step in the right direction and predicted that the proposal would easily pass the Legisla ture, probably next week.

title: Green Gets Housing Post
description: S. William Green has been named administrator of the New York regional office of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Devel opment. Mr. Green, a native New Yorker, was counsel for the Joint Legislative Commit tee on Housing and Urban De velopment from 1961 to 1964. In the following year he was elected to the State Assembly and served three years.

title: IRISH AIR QUESTIONS PAN AMERICAN STAND
description: The president of Irish Inter national Airlines was in New York yesterday and issued a statement in which he told of his disappointment that Pan American World Airways should belabor the old horse of its efforts to get into Dub lin, Ireland.

title: Harris Survey Finds Democratic Party Is Not a Majority
description: A poll by Louis Harris pub lished yesterday in the New York Post finds that, for the first time in the modern politi cal era, the Democratic party has lost its position as the majority political party.

title: Miss Parker Fiancee Of James Brooks Jr.
description: Miss Frances Lea Parker, a stewardess for Continental Airlines, plans to be married in Houston on Feb. 28 to James M. Brooks Jr., an art student at the Fine Arts Museum there.

title: RIGHTS OF NEWSMEN TO BE ESSAY SUBJECT
description: A move to encourage legal research on the constitutional implications of the Federal Gov ernment's policy of subpoena ing reporters and their notes was announced yesterday by Sidney Zion, president of Scan lan's Literary House, at a news conference at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West 44th Street.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DRIFT AIMLESSLY
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved aimless ly yesterday as measured by its index, which was unchanged at 25.63. Trading moved at a slower pace than the previous day, apparently due to the holi day, 3,555,785 shares compared with 4,242,005 on Wednesday.

title: Wrong Doors Opened, IND Rider Nearly Falls
description: A Transit Authority spokes man said yesterday that a conductor who accidentally opened the wrong doors of an elevated IND line F train to a 40foot drop had been warned and. told to be careful.

title: Agency Not Informed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12An official at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said tonight that the depart ment had not yet been informed of the Governor's action.

title: Manhattan Lands Top School Runners
description: Joe Savage is currently the country's top schoolboy in door miler. Ditto for the halfmile. Ditto for the 1,000. Many people believe he would be the fastest in the 600, too, but he hasn't run it as yet.

title: Dance: The Sumptuous Balanchine Don Quixote
description: BALLET is a hard task master. In drama you see a play, offer your opinion and fly away. In ballet a critic has to live with his earlier thoughts. Any man who has ever been in love will know the perils of such a course.

title: GEORGETOWN TOPS N.Y.U. FIVE, 9472
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Except for the opening mo ments of the game, George town University never trailed tonight and registered a 9472 basketball triumph over New York University at McDonough Gym.

title: Anniversaries
description: SARROWAl, Edith, Joyfully announce their fiftieth wedding anniversary, Feb. 15, 1970.

title: Armco Unit Leases 3 Jets
description: GATX Boothe Corporation, a subsidiary of the Armco Steel Corporation, reported yesterday it had leased three Boeing 737 200 jetliners to Frontier Air ways. GATX Boothe specializes in the leasing and financing of capital equipment.

title: Muskie to Use Maine Campaign As a National Platform for '72
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie, dissat isfied with the lack of political attention he has been attract ing, plans to use his reelec tion campaign in Maine this year as a national platform.

title: U.S.French Pact Amended
description: PARIS, Feb. 12A 60year old extradition agreement be tween France and the United States was brought up to date with the inclusion of plane hi jacking and drug trafficking among extraditable crimes. The new agreement was signed by the United States Ambassador, Sargent Shriver, and Herve Al phand, Secretary General of the Foreign Ministry.

title: Stage: On Dwelling in Bloomingdale's
Approval by Big Board
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the appli cation of Joseph L. Searles 3d to be a member of the ex change. He is the first Negro to obtain a seat on the ex change. He will be a partner in the brokerage firm of New burger, Loeb & Co.

title: Books of The Times
description: IRA LEVIN'S first novel, A Kiss Before Dying, was too rooted in its ingenious narrative (involving a tricky switch in its point of view) to be made into a satisfy ing movie. His second, Rosemary's Baby, got onto the screen, but also with prob lems. It, too, depended on its leading char acter's point of view (until the end one couldn't tell whether or not Rosemary was imagining it all), and its literalization on film made it silly, unless you happened to have a thing about witches.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: CHICAGO 7 LIKENED TO KEY AGITATORS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12  The defendants in the Chicago con spiracy trial were compared today to an illustrious line of outside agitators.

title: James J. Feron Is Dead at 66; Headed Tennis Racquet Shop
description: James J. Fermi, president of S. J. Feron, Inc., a tennis and squash racquet shop at 55 E. 44th Street, died yesterday at University Hospital after suf fering a brain hemorrhage Sunday. He was 66 years old.

title: Panel Told of Intrigue for Gambino Job
description: An account of alleged in trigue within the Mafia to de pose Carlo Gambino as boss of one of the most powerful organized crime families in the country unfolded yesterday at a public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

title: 1969 Sales Also at Peak
description: The Singer Company attained record sales and earnings for the 11th successive year in 1969, with the fourthquarter also contributing record re sults.

title: Promoter Making Another Run At Presenting Pro Track Meet
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 Professional track and field, which has had more false starts in the last 16 months than a nervous sprinter, is quietly moving into the blocks again for one last run to fame or financial doom.

title: Two Meat Plants Closed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that two meat plants in North Dakota has been told to halt operations be cause they were turning out products under conditions en dangering public health. The department acted under pro visions of the Federal Meat In spection Act.

title: NASA WINS BATTLE FOR SPACE MACHINE
description: The producer of an instru ment that can translate video signals from outer space into permanent pictures at the rate of six a second surrendered the equipment yesterday after the Federal Government went to court to win its release.

title: BOGGS DOUBTFUL ON TARIFF RELIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12A leading member of Congress on trade matters threw cold water today on a major program of both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations  the idea of special tariff preferences for nonfarm goods from the less developed countries.

title: Deep Yankee Triumphs As Liberty Bell Reopens
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 Deep Yankee and Smokey Rain bow, a pair of 4yearold horses, won a division apiece in the Independence pace series as the 1970 spring harness rac ing season opened tonight at Liberty Bell Park.

title: PUBLICATIONS GET BRAZIL MORALS LAW
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12 A new Brazilian morality law was decreed yesterday for periodicals and books.

title: 125 College Men Agree to Take Police Exam Here
description: More than 125 upperclass rnen from such colleges as Princeton, Yale, Harvard and Union Theological Seminary have signed up to take the examination to become New York City policemen.

title: Plane Crash Kills Pilot
description: STERLING, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP)A search plane crashed and exploded on a runway at Sterling Airport today, killing the pilot and injuring a passen ger. Stew Woodworth of New ton, was identified as the dead pilot. The passenger, Stephen Nottoson, of Newton Center, was taken to Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston.

title: G.O.P. Loss Likely In Governorships, Survey Discloses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania spent most of 1969 trying to persuade his state legislature to increase taxes.

title: Yale Track Team Triumphs Over Dartmouth by 6049
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12Yale's track team won eight of 13 events today to defeat Dart mouth in a dual meet, 6049.

title: PROF. G. M. FAIR OF HARVARD DIES
description: Gordon M. Fair, an expert in sanitary engineering and former dean of engineering at Harvard University, died Wednesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon was at his Key Biscayne, Fla., home where he worked with White House staff members on his foreign policy message, which will be delivered to Congress next Wednesday.

title: 13 AMERICANS DIE IN ENEMY AMBUSH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 13 (AP)North Vietnamese troops in concealed positions ambushed a United States Marine patrol in the Queson Valley south of Danang yesterday, and 13 of the Ameri cans were killed in the battle. Twelve other marines were wounded.

title: National Guard Drops Pilot for His Mustache
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 12 (AP)An Iowa Air Na tional Guard pilot has been dropped from the ranks be cause of his bushy mous tache. The Guard said today, Nonconformists just don't work in the military.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Assails Nixon Reply on Mideast
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12  The Government newspaper Izves tia made it clear today that the Soviet Union was dissatis fied with President Nixon's re ply to Premier Aleksei N. Kosy gin's proposals for reducing tension in the Middle East.

title: KEY LAOTIAN PLAIN IS UNDER ASSAULT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos. Feb. 12 In a series of attacks against more than a dozen Laotian Government positions yesterday and early today, North Viet namese troops launched what military observers here inter preted as their longexpected counteroffensive to retake the Plaine des Jarres.

title: Weekend Recipes
description: IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: U.S. Meteorologists Are Urged to Press Research
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The nation's top weather ad ministrator told a symposium of meteorologists and weather specialists this morning that the national weather forecast ing effort was not meeting the needs of the American people.

title: Common Market Plans Defense Against Trade Policy Criticism
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 12  The Executive Commission of the European Common Market has decided to defend itself against criticisms that its trade policies are harming trade in the nonCommunist world.

title: Bridge
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 12The Australian national team inflicted a sec ond defeat on the American touring team here last night. Tim Seres and Dick Cum mings, who played a key role in the earlier Australian vic tory in Sydney, teamed with an outstanding husbandand wife partnership, Jim and Norma Bonin of Melbourne, to win the 48deal match by 20 international points.

title: 13 Seized as Violators of Writ In Jersey City School Walkout
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12  Thirteen persons were arrested here today on charges of vio lating a court order barring a teachers' walkout.

title: Music: An Encore for Le Bal Masque
ACTIVITIES LIGHT IN BOND MARKET
description: With the commercial banks closed in New York City and, other money centers, the credit markets yesterday were almost at a standstill.

title: Sydney Stock Trading Usually Heavy and Frenzied
description: SYDNEY Australia, Feb. 12Richard Waters, a staff statistician working behind the scenes in the wildly booming Sydney Stock Ex change, gauges the day's trend of the world's busiest share market by a faster method than scanning the figures that flow into his de partment.

title: 6 Hurt on British Submarine
description: GIBRALTAR, Feb. 12 (AP) An explosion aboardthe Brit ish submarine Auriga while on exercises about 25 miles east of Gibraltar injured six sailors early today. A navy spokesman said the submarine was on the surface when the explosion oc curred in the battery room.

title: Susan Ann Bondy Is Engaged To D. G. Willoughby, an Ad Man
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., Feb. 12Miss Susan Ann Bondy and David Gordon Willough by, an account executive with the Young & Rubicam advertising agency in New York, plan to be married here in May.

title: New Music Enlists Help of Computers; Results Are Uneven
description: Could a combination of stochastic choice rules with heuristic, multivalent, decision taking procedures contribute an apparent musical coherence to a chain of changes of state in a structured system?

title: Death Penalty Is Urged For Plane Hijackers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)The president of El Al, the Israeli air line, suggested capital punishment today for persons hijacking or attack ing passenger planes.

title: Bach Concert Canceled
description: The Bach concert announced for presentation at the Mannes College of Music at 8:30 to night by Judith Anderson, flute, Hendrik Broekman, harp sichord, and others will not be given. One of the performers is ill.

title: Cabbies to Open a Drive to Restore Death Penalty
description: Thousands of cab drivers here will ask passengers to sign petitions calling upon the Legislature to reinstate the death penalty for murder in the state.

title: NoDecision Likely for Game
description: Dr. Edward S. Steitz, secre tary of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Rules Com mittee, said yesterday that the Dec. 18 JacksonvilleGeorge town basketball game, now listed as a 20 Jacksonville victory, probably would be ruled a nodecision game. The contest was ended with 1:26 remaining in the first half when players from both teams brawled, spectators joined in and the Georgetown coach Pulled his team off the court.

title: Michigan Economists Find A Slowdown as Predicted
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 12 (AP)Preliminary data for the fourth quarter of 1969 confirm their prediction of a further slowdown in the American economy, University of Michi gan economists said today.

title: Congress Panel Seeks End Of the Highway Trust Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) A Congressional joint panel on the economy proposed to day the abolishment of the Highway Trust Fund, which has been used to finance the vast interstate network of roads.

title: Suspect's Wife Is Charged With Murder of Yablonski
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 12 (AP)First degree murder charges were filed today against Mrs. Annette Gilly, 29 years old, in the slayings of Jo seph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter, Washington County officials said.

title: A Correction
description: A discussion by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird with high school and college stu dents was listed inadvertently in yesterday's New York Times for broadcast by WCBS radio yesterday. The program, Class room, U.S.A.: At Issue  the Draft, will be broadcast Feb. 26 from 10:10 to 11 P.M.

title: Mt. Vernon Board Is Sued Over School Contract
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12  A suit charging that the Mount Vernon Board of Education spent $200,000 unnecessarily on school renovation project was brought yesterday in State Su preme Court here.

title: DALLAS STUDENTS OUSTED BY POLICE
description: DALLAS, Feb. 12  More than 250 policemen arrested 351 Negro students at Bishop College during the night, end ing a sixday sitin by the stu dents, who were protesting con ditions at the predominantly Negro school.

title: Skiing Trainer Has a Big Hand In Keeping Billy Kidd on Slopes
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 12In Room 24 of the Hotel Laurin at Selva, one of the three little valley villages that are host to the world Alpine ski championships, lives an odd couple: Billy Kidd, the 26yearold medal winning United States skier, and Tage Pedersen, the 42 yearold director of the As pen Health Center in Col orado.

title: Agnew Denounces University Quotas To Help Minorities
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12Vice President Agnew criticized tonight colleges and univer sities that are now admitting minority groups on the basis of quotas rather than apti tude for learning.

title: AN AFRICAN CRITIC EXHORTS ROGERS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 12  An African leader told Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers today that the United States should show the same energy in opposing sup pression of blacks in southern Africa by minority white gov ernments as it had shown in fighting fascism in World War II.

title: Two Health Aides Sworn In
description: Mayor Lindsay swore in Dr. James A. Shannon and Dr. Walsh McDermott yesterday as members of the city's Board of Health. Dr. Shannon will serve until Dec. 31 as the successor to Dr. Lewis Thomas, who re signed to become a professor at Yale University Medical School. Dr. McDermott, a mem ber of the board since 1965, was named to a full eightyear term.

title: Plastic Booths Studied to End Outbursts in Court
description: A national committee of ar chitects, judges and lawyers is studying the possibility of rede signing courtrooms so that de fendants who might disrupt trials could be kept behind soundproof plastic shields ex cept when testifying.

title: NUSSEIN IN PACT WITH GUERRILLAS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 12 King Hussein and the Pales tinian commandos reached agreement here tonight on measures to end the crisis over new security steps taken by the Jordanian Government.

title: BIG BOARD VOTES A NEW FEE SCALE
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to authorize the presentation of a new com mission rate schedule to the Securities and Exchange Com mission.

title: Rep. Fountain to Run Again
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Representative L. H. Foun tain, Democrat of North Caro lina, announced today that he would seek reelection this year for a 10th term in the House.

title: 13 Die in Colombian Crash
description: BOGOTA, Colombia Feb. 12 (UPI)Thirteen persons died Thursday in the forced land ing of a Colombian Urraca Air line DC3 on a river bank near Puerto L6pez, 80 miles south east of Bogota. The plane ex ploded and burned.

title: Metcalf Injured in Crash
description: BUTTE, Mont., Feb. 12 (AP) Senator Lee Metcalf, Demo crat of Montana, was hospital ized early today at Silver Bow General Hospital with injuries suffered late yesterday in an automobile accident on Home stake Pass, eight miles east of here. The hospital authorities said Mr. Metcalf had suffered an arm fracture, cuts and bruises.

title: I.O.S. Expands in Canada
description: TORONTO, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press)  Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., anounced today it has agreed to purchase the assets and business of the Ca nadian Channing Corporation, Ltd., one of Canada's oldest mutual fund sales and manage ment organizations. I. O. S. is a Genevabased concern.

title: Two Candidates Endorsed
description: The Citizens Union, a private civic group, announced two preferences yesterday for special elections for the State Legislature to be held Tuesday. For the 25th Assembly. District seat in Queens, formerly held by Supreme Court Justice Mos es Weinstein, the Union en dorsed Emanuel R. Gold, a Democrat. In the 81st Assem bly District it endorsed Alan Elochberg, a Democrat for the seat formerly held by Bronx Borough President Rob art Abrams.

title: Mrs. Meyner's First Child Is Born Dead at Hospital
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 12 (AP)The first child born to Mrs. Robert B. Meyner, wife of the former Governor of New Je sey, was dead at birth, Prince ton Hospital reported today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: APPLIED OCEANICS, Ltd., of Bath, Me., has devel oped a wire lobster pot it believes may replace the traditional wooden unit.

title: Sensor Seal Around Vietnam Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The Pentagon is studying a pro posal to provide enough modern sensing devices so that South Vietnam could seal its entire 900mile border against sizable enemy infiltration.

title: Koch Says Commission Is Failing on Dock Control
description: Representative Edward I. Koch charged yestreday that the Waterfront Commission failed to use its licensing pow er to keep organized crime off the waterfront of New York Harbor.

title: Tufo Resigns as Director of City's Washington Office
description: Peter F. Tufo, at 31 an old timer in the Lindsay adminis tration, has resigned as head of the city's Washington office to resume private law practice.

title: Casals, at Benefit Here, To Conduct 100 Cellists
description: Pablo Casals, the 93year old cellist, will conduct 100 cellists in his own composi tion, La Sardana, in a special benefit concert, Salud Casals, to be given by the American Symphony Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall on April 15.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Decides To Renationalize Banks
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 12 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi decided tonight to re nationalize the nation's 14 leading banks, brushing aside leftwing advice that she take over all of India's foreign and domestic banks, informed sources said.

title: Some Gallic Designs for American Men
description: CALL it the Mao, call it the Nehru, or call it the Feruch, which is what Gilbert Feruch, the Paris tailor who made it fashionable, likes to Call it. Whatever its name, the highcollared tunic has been mortally wounded in the United States by its mass acceptance. But in Europe, says Mr. Feruch, it has be come a classic costume.

title: Inspector Garelik's New Beat
description: The Board of Estimate votes today on funds for setting up a third Deputy Mayor's office. This Office will be responsible for coordinating the presently diverse; slack and tangled ties that the city maintains with both Albany and Washington as well as with regional groups and other governmental agencies. There is, incredibly, no single point of contact within the city's sprawling bureaucracy for state and Federal officials interested in promoting programs that might be of benefit here or in determining emerging needs for new programs.

title: VIKINGS SPLIT UP FOOTBALL BOOTY
description: Although they lost the Super Bowl game to the Kansas City Chiefs, the Minnesota Vikings did well by their bank ac counts near the end of the last National Football League season.

title: PENTAGON DENIES ABM RADAR FLAW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) The Defense Department de nied today that the powerful radars needed for the Safeguard antiballistic missile system would interfere with the Min uteman missiles it is designed to protect.

title: SMOTHERS SHOW STRESSES RIGHTS
description: The Return of the Smothers Brothers on National Broad casting Company television at 10 P.M. Monday, will be dedi cated to Constitutional rights, on which the brothers stand and on which the network will not even cautiously tread.

title: SteelPricing Policy
description: A pricing policy on steel, gen erally described by producers as a guarantee of stability, was assured of acceptance through out the industry yesterday when the United States Steel Corporation said it would match what other big com panies had announced.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Feb. 13, 1970 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Treasury Aide Prods Business on ValueAdded Taxi
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 If the business community wants to see a valueadded tax enacted, it will have to help sell the idea to the American people, a high Treasury offi cial told an audience of cor poration chiefs today.

title: EILEEN FARRELL DISPLAYS POLISH
description: Eileen Farrell, soprano, gave her first New York recital in five years at Philharmonic Hall last night, and she was her usual superradiant self.

title: Mother Dies Rescuing Son
description: CLOSTER, N. J. Feb. 12 (AP) Mrs. Anthony Corso, 36 years old, was killed here yesterday while saving her 2yearold son from being run over by a truck. Mrs. Corso, the mother of five children, was struck by the truck after she pushed the boy to safety. He had wandered in to the street in front of their home at 199 High Street, the police said.

title: Siegfried of Celtics Hurt
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Larry Siegfried, Boston Celtics playmaker, will be out of ac tion for the next three games because of an injured Achilles tendon, leaving the Celtics with out three regular starters through the weekend. Siegfried aggravated the injury in his left leg in Wednesday night's over time victory over the Knicks in New York.

title: GILPATRIC LETTERS REPORTED FOUND
description: Four letters written by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis to Roswell L. Gilpatric were found in a wastepaper basket, according to information received by Charles Hamilton, the autograph dealer who accepted the cor respondence for auction.

title: Dining Out in a Turkish Pub
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicin ity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

title: Pound Circulation Increases 22.42Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: Refurbished Great Hall Opening at Metropolitan
description: Terraced steps replace the steep old entrance stairway. The wooden vestibule known as the doghouse has given way to polished brass doors and a curtain of air. The grimy limestone interior has been freshened back to whiteness. And the statues and shops that cluttered the vast floor have been super seded by flowerfilled plant ers.

title: Woman Dies in Harlem Fire
description: A 36yearold woman, iden tified as Carrie Booth, died yesterday in a fire in her fifth floor apartment at 418 St. Nich olas Avenue, near 133d Street, in Harlem. The onealarm fire, of unknown origin, was con fined to the Booth apartment.

title: Penn Central Runs Delayed
description: A section or nortnbouna track between the Mount Vernon and Crestwood Stations on the Penn Central's Harlem Division was closed for several hours during the evening rush hour yesterday when a 1000foot sec tion of third rail was knocked to the ground. Delays up to an hour and a half were reported. The railroad said the track was returned to service at 7:57 P.M.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS SHOWS SALES RISE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12The American Motors Corporation took the automobile industry spotlight today not only by showing its new small car to the news media but also by running up the largest gain in earlyFebruary car sales.

title: De Carlo Breaks Down and Sobs; Jersey Crime Hearing Is Delayed
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12  Angelo (Gyp) Da. Carlo, a reputed Mafi oso who was portrayed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last year as a methodical gang land executioner, burst into tears today under questioning by the State Commission of Investication.

title: National Union May Shed Part of Emerson Division
description: The National Union Electric Corporation is considering phasing out operations of its Emerson television and radio division in Jersey City, C. Rus sell Feldmann, chairman, said at a news confercence here yesterday.

title: EDUCATION
description: COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES

title: Screen: Mumsy and Friends Arrive
UNIONISTS CAUTION ON MERGER TREND
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 12 A labor group warned here today that mergers and the con tinuing increase in conglomer ates posed a serious threat for American consumers and work ers.

title: Lindsay Finds Capitol Lobby Success
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  When Peter F. Tufo went be fore the New York City Board of Estimate in the fall of 1968 to request a few hundred ex tra dollars to move the city's office in Washington to slight ly larger quarters, an aide to Mario A. Procacino, who was then Controller, grumbled that he wasn't aware that the city office had real ly accomplished anything.

title: No Rest for the HighFlying Rangers on Coast Trip
description: OAKLAND, Feb. 12 Practice? asked the pretty girl from United Air Lines. What do you guys need practice for?

title: Bitten by the Art Nouveau Bug
description: HARRISON, N. Y.Some people use art as decoration; they demand that it picture be a certain size to fill a cer tain spot or they shop for a painting whose colors will go with the living room walls. (Serious art lovers, natu rally take a dim view of this.)

title: Pilots Keep Their Seattle Home, But Foundation Remains Shaky
description: The Seattle Pilots, using $650,000 supplied by their 11 partners in the American League, will continue to play baseball in Seattle in 1970, but after that the future location of the franchise, may be Milwau kee or DallasFort Worth.

title: Kent L. Brittan Fiance Of Florence R. Meyer
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Feb. 12The engagement of Miss Florence Roome Meyer to Kent Landon Brittan has been announced by her par ents, Mr. and Mrs. John Van Nostrand Meyer of Locust Valley. Mr. Brittan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Goodhue Brittan of Vail, Colo.

title: Jack Tinker Selects 2d Creative Partner
description: Jack Tinker & Partners, eager to find its way up the comeback trail, has just named Ken Duskin, a creative partner. He joins Marcella Free, whose appointment was recently announced.

title: 30 Marines Hurt in Fracas
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)Thirty marines were injured in a fight involv ing three Negroes who stormed a barracks last night in a stag ing area for men headed for Vietnam, a marine spokesman said today. There were no seri ous injuries. As many Negroes as whites were reported in jured. No specific reasons for the disturbance were made public.

title: RENT CONTROL END AND CITY SUBSIDIES LINKED IN A STUDY
description: A confidential draft of the Rand Corporation's study do housing decay concludes that a relaxation of the city's rent control law must be linked to a $130millionayear city pro gram of rent subsidies to needy families.

title: U. S. Assails Israeli Raid; Presses for a New Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The United States strongly condemned Israel's bombing of an Egyptian scrapmetal plant today and pressed for Big Four efforts to reestablish a ceasefire and to limit arms deliveries to the Middle East.

title: Miss Pamela M. Hull Is Betrothed
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 12 Miss Pamela Marie Hull, a graduate of Catholic Univer sity of America and Gerard A. Dupuis, who received a degree from the Columbus School of Law of Catholic University, will be married April 4 in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: 500 Raid Building Site
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 12 (UPI)Five hundred union workers, contending that mem bers of another union were do ing their work, raided a con struction site here today and it took 40 policemen to quell the rampage. The raiding workers, members of an operating engi neers union, upended and smashed equipment, overturned and burned a car and a truck, and stoned and beat nearly a dozen electrical workers.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The New York Times on Sunday, reporting the 25th anniversary of the Yalta conference, incorrectly reported that the conference agree ments included a provision for a Soviet zone of occupation in Korea. In fact that provision was not made until seven months later, as part of the arrangements for the formal Japanese surrender in Septem ber, 1945.

title: Mississippi's Governor Vetoes Grants for Head Start Programs
description: JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 12 (UPI)Gov. John Bell Williams vetoed more than $5million in Federal grants for Head Start programs today on the grounds that they were primarily ope rated for black children and consequently discriminated against whites.

title: MARKET IS MIXED IN BRISK TRADING
description: Pollutioncontrol stocks, cur rently the favorite group in Wall Street, provided some support yesterday to a mixed market. Popular averages showed minor drops, while ad vances outpaced declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 653 to 612.

title: LEE W. STANLEY
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 12 (UPI) Lee W. Stanley, who created the comic panel The Old Home Town, died yesterday at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: GARELIK HOPEFUL OF A COMPROMISE
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik, who opposed two Lindsay administration pro posals earlier this week in display of political independ ence, was in a conciliatory mood yesterday.

title: Rumania Offers to Assist on the Mideast
description: VIENNA, Feb. 12Rumania stressed today her construc tive posture in the search for a settlement in the Middle East, offering increased cooper ation with all parties involved.

title: Nemesis, Sailed by Turner, Wins Scandinavian Cup Race
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Ted Turner, an American yachtsman, stepped off a jet from the United States today, raced to Sydney's Palm Beach by taxi and sailed his sloop Nemesis to victory in the third race of the Scandinavian Gold Cup 5.5Meter Class series. Nemesis was timed in 3 hours 20 minutes 32 seconds.

title: Net's Hollander Is Sung First Time By Thomas Stewart
description: Not much can be done to make the title character in Wagner's Der Fliegende Hol lander come to life. He is intended, of course, as a face less, mythic fellow, and even in his big chance to snap out of it and act like a human being, in the scene at Daland's house, he stands around strik ing lovelorn poses for half an hour and then leaves without so much as kissing the angelic unta.

title: Jane Foy Sets August Bridal
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 12 The engagement of Miss Jane Foy to Joseph W. Kara man, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Karaman, has been announced by the fu ture bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. Foy of Ken dridge Farm. Plans have been made for an August wedding.

title: 2 RUSSIANS OUSTED BY SWISS IN SPY CASE
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12  The Swiss Government announced today that it had requested recall of two diplomats from the Soviet embassy in Berne because they had been found to be spies.

title: Back From Cuba, U.S. CaneCutters Greet 500 Replacements
description: SAINT JOHN, New Bruns wick, Feb 12 (UPI)More than 200 enthusiastic young people from the United States, just returned from Cuban sugar fields, today met 500 recruits preparing to take their place. The returning group sang, slapped backs and described their trip as an incredible experience.

title: ADAMS CLIPS MARK IN N.Y.U. SHOTPUT
description: Steve Adams of St. Joseph's Regional High School of Ram sey, N.J., shattered Gary Gub ner's 10yearold meet record by nearly four feet yesterday in winning the open shotput event at the 21st annual New York University interscholastic track meet at Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: Giant Light Bulb Is Ornament, Too
description: THE tinselbright ball sit ting on top of the chromed cylinder looks like an outsize Christmas tree Ornament. The glittering bauble, a 5inch diameter sphere, may well be the first lamp bulb that is as decorative unlighted as when it is turned on.

title: POTATO FUTURES SHOW SHARP RISE
description: Potato futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in heavy volume.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE SHOWS A 2% RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 7, registered a rise in vol ume over the corresponding week of last year. Intercity Truck Tonnage in the same period was down.

title: New Slides in French Alps Kill an Infant
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Feb. 12 (Reuters)Four avalanches struck in the French Alps near here today, killing an infant and once again isolating Val d'Isere.

title: Norwalk Hat Plant Planning to Close; Union Scores Move
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 12 The Hat Corporation of Amer ica, one of the nation's largest hat producers, has notified its employes' union that its plant here will close down March 31, Paul Autuore, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, said today.

title: L.I.R.R. IS BLAMED FOR FAMILY WOES
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 12 Harried Long Island Rail Road commuters, according to a study, blame the rail line for fatigue, conscious anger, anx iety, headaches, palpitations, in digestion, abdominal cramps, muscle painand even sexual problems.

title: REV. RICHARD DOHERTY
description: The Rev. Richard F. Doherty, assistant pastor at St. Vincent de Paul Church at 123 West 23d Street, died Wednesday. He was 61 years old.

title: 3D COALITION SOUGHT BY ITALIAN PREMIER
description: ROME, Jan. 12  The care taker Premier, Mariano Rumor, who has headed Italy's last two Governments, agreed tonight to try to form a third and to re construct the fourparty cen terleft coalition that has domi nated Italian politics since 1963.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID PLANT NEAR CAIRO; 70 REPORTED DEAD
description: EL KHANKA, United Arab Republic, Feb. 12Israeli fight erbombers attacked a scrap metal processing plant in this Cairo suburb this morning, ?? ing dozens of civilian workers and wounding many more.

title: G.M.A.C.'S EARNINGS ROSE 4% LAST YEAR
description: The General Motors Accept ance Corporation announced yesterday that consolidated net income last year amounted to $47.16million, up 4 per cent from 1968's $45.33 million.

title: WEDNESDAY NIGHT FIGHTS
description: TokyoKim Kyun, 124 pounds, South Korea, outpoint ed Kenjiro Nakajima, 126, Ja pan, 10 rounds.

title: Advertising: The Grope Is Making Tracks
description: Out of the deep, dark, se cret (but creative) recesses that link American Telephone and Telegraph with Cunning ham & Walsh has come the Abominable Yellow Phone man.

title: Bernadette Lombardo Affianced
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Frank Thomas Lombardo have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Bernadette Lombardo to Alfred Pearce Bch, son of Mrs. Alfred P. Ilch and the late Mr. Itch of Ruirison, N. J. A spring wed ding is planned.

title: Protest at Wisconsin U.
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 12  Madison policemen used tear gas to disperse bands of anti war demonstrators on the Uni versity of Wisconsin campus this afternoon.

title: Japan Debates Policy as Satellite Orbits
description: TOKYO, Feb. 12As Japan's first space satellite, a 50pound er, circled the earth today, sci entists and policymakers, wrestled with problems of where and how to direct such ventures in the future.

title: 25 Picket M.T.A. Offices To Protest Transit Fare
description: A call by a group that iden tifies itself as the Transit Crisis Coalition, which urges restora tion of the 20cent transit fare, for a protest demonstration at the headquarters of the Metro politan Transportation Authori ty attracted five person yes terday.

title: Potholes Are Back in All Sizes and Shapes
description: A new crop of potholes is making driving often bumpy, sometimes hazardous and oc casionally even impossible on streets, roads and highways in the metropolitan area.

title: Market Place
description: NOT long ago Burnham & Co., a mediumsized brok erage house noted for the quality of its research, started a mutual fund for its custom ers.

title: Few Swiss Francs Now Stay at Home
description: GENEVA, Feb. 12  Swiss bankers have been sending so many francs abroad to earn a better return than can be gained at home that the Swiss currency is now in short sup ply.

title: Crisis on 42d Street
description: The New York Public Library again faces a financial crisis, with the prospect of a $4.3million deficit. Two issues vital to the city's cultural and educational environment are at stake.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1970

title: 90 Reported Top Number For March Draft Lottery
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The military draft will prob ably call lottery numbers no higher than 90 in March, an informed source said today.

title: Real G.N.P. Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Re vised figures today put the gross national product in the last quarter of last year slight ly lower than the earlier esti mates, thus confirming a slight dip in the nation's real out put.

title: NARCOTICS SEIZED WORTH $9MILLION
description: Federal and city narcotics agents arrested three men in Manhattan and Queens last night and confiscated quanti ties of pure heroin and cocaine, which the police said were worth more than $9million on the illegal market.

title: Borough Chief Favors Bronx Power
description: For Bronx Borough Presi dent Robert Abrams, his job has a twofold purpose: to build stable neighborhoods in slums and to insert himself as the conduit between all Bronx communities and City Hall.

title: Monopoly Issue Holds Up Cheyenne TV License
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12In a rare expression of concern about the dangers of monop oly in local media, the Federal Communications Commission today held up for hearings the license renewal of KFBCTV in Cheyenne, Wyo.

title: Store Sales Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $561million, up 12 per cent from the year earlier $502million. Total retail store sales, last week were about $5,971,000,000, down 2 per cent from $6,093,000,000.

title: HUNT FAILS TO FIND MISSING AIRCRAFT
description: GROTON, Conn., Feb. 12 (UPI)A search for a missing Pilgrim Airlines plane with five men aboard was called off at sunset today.

title: THOMAS H. GIBBONS
description: Thomas H. Gibbons, statis tical editor of The Morning Telegraph, died Wednesday at the Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens, after an illness of several months. He was 64 years old.

title: Boyle Says Press Lynches U.M.W
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The United Mine Workers of Amer ica accused the news media today of conducting a journal istic lynching bee of its top leaders.

title: Inexcusable Attack
description: The Israeli bombing of an industrial plant near Cairo, with heavy loss of civilian lives, was an inex cusable perversion of Israel's indisputable right to respond to President Nasser's war of attrition. Cer tainly the slaughter of scores of Egyptians was not justified by Tuesday's bloody attack on El Al airline passengers at Munich, despicable as was that guer rilla assault.

title: G.I. Publications Asked Not to Stress Fighting
description: LONGBINH, South Viet nam, Feb. 12 (UPI)  Army unit publications in South Vietnam have received an of ficial suggestion that they stop emphasizing hard com bat news and replace it with reports of the progress of our efforts in the fields of Vietnamization, pacification and civil action.

title: Beame Blames Policy of U.S. For Rise in City Interest Costs
description: The city's debt costs will in crease by more than $125mil lion to $850million during the coming fiscal year, according to a report issued yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame.

title: U.S. Jet Cleared After Report Of Toxic Leak From Rocket
description: MILDENHALL Air Force Base, England, Feb. 12 (Reu ters)An American Air Force jet transport reported to have been leaking poisonous fumes from a rocket on board was cleared as safe by United States authorities tonight.

title: Murphy Rallies Niagara to 7768 Victory Over Fordham
description: Calvin Murphy helped bring out the largest crowd (12,321) of the regular Madison Square Garden college basketball sea son last night andafter a major scaregave the Niagara rooters something to cheer about.

title: Fellini Satyricon to Open
description: Fellini Satyricon will have its American premiere at the Little Carnegie Theater on March 11. The Italianmade comedydrama, set in pre Christian Rome, was directed by Federico Fellini from a story and script on which he collaborated with Bernardino Zapponi based on the writings of Petronius.

title: Philadelphia Judge Acts to Speed Garbage Collection
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12  City officials obtained a court order today in an effort to end a health emergency caused by a 10day slowdown in garbage collections.

title: Laird Confers With Thieu and Affirms Nixon Policy
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (UPI)Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird con ferred today with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam and affirmed Pres dent Nixon's decision to con tinue the withdrawal of American troops.

title: Striking Tugboatmen to Haul Sludge
description: Striking tugboat workers agreed yesterday to provide tows to governmental agencies for disposal of sludge at sea.

title: 2D OFFICER FACES SONGMY CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The Army has charged Capt. Thomas K. Willingham, a 25 yearold infantry officer, with the unpremeditated murder of Vietnamese civilians in the vil lage of Songmy on March 16, 1968.

title: Foreign Affairs: The Strategy of Chaos
description: PARIS  With every battle field success of Israel's re doubtable little military forces, new political problems emerge among the Arabs. The big ques tion is whether these problems do not in fact make even more remote than ever Israel's hope for eventual settlement.

title: GEORGE O. CUTTER
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Feb. 12 George O. Cutter, recently retired director of the control ler's staff of the Fisher Body Division of the General Motors Corporation, died Monday night in a Detroit hospital. Mr. Cut ter, who was 65 years old, had been an overseer of Bowdoin College at Brunswick, Me.

title: PUERTO RICAN GROUP DESCRIBES BOMBINGS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R. Feb. 12 (UPI)An underground Puerto Rican revolutionary movement that favors independence and calls itself Mira said today that it had carried out 19 terrorist acts since last December, in cluding seven in New York City.

title: 2 Mississippi Informers Helped Foil Bomb Plot on Jewish Aide
description: MERIDIAN, Miss., Feb 12 A man convicted in the slaying of three civil rights workers in 1964 and his brother have been identified here by police sources as the paid informers who helped the police to spring a bizarre trap in the attempted bombing of a Jewish business man's home here in 1968.

title: HANOI EMPHASIZES NEW LABOR GOALS
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese Government has published a resolution con cerning the opening of a pro ductive labor movement, de signed to put into effect the economic plan for 1970.

title: Miss McBride, M. L. Lehrman Plan to Marry
description: MADRAS, Ore., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. J. P. McBride have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann McBride, to Michael L. Lehrman of Wash ington, president of Aircraft, Holdings, Inc. He is the son of Charles Lehrman of New York and the late Mrs. Edithe G. Lehrman.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Feb. 10.

title: Hirsch Jacobs Dies at 65
description: Hirsch Jacobs, who saddled 3,569 winners, more than any other trainer of thoroughbred race horses, died yesterday in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 65 years old. Obituary on page 27.

title: 2 POLICEMEN HURT IN BLAST ON COAST
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 13 A reserve policeman was seri ously injured early today when two bombs exploded in the Berkeley police narkine lot.

title: JOHN R. HARDIN
description: John R. Hardin, retired sen ior partner in the Newark law firm of Pitney Hardin & Kipp, died yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at Timberstone, Old Gladstone Road, Chester, N.J.

title: McLain Under Baseball Scrutiny
description: Some offfield activities in 1967 of Denny McLain, the American League's out standing pitcher for the last two seasons, are under in vestigation by the office of the commissioner of base ball, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

title: Laver Beaten by Gimeno
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP)Andres Gimeno of Spain upset topseeded Red Laver of Australia tonight, 46, 119. 75, to gain the final of the $25,000 Montgomery Ward cup against Ken Rosewell of Australia, who defeated Tony Roche, 97, 2G, 62.

title: 3 Bombs Set Off to Cover Bank Robbery in Danbury
description: DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 13 Two gunmen set off bombs in a police station, a bank and a parking lot here this morning and made off with about $40,000 as the three explosions, staggered with military preci sion over a period of less than 10 minutes rocked Main Street.

title: PROSECUTOR CALLS CHICAGO 7 EVIL
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 13A Gov ernment lawyer labeled the de fendants in the Chicago con spiracy trial today evil men who want to stand on the rub ble of our destroyed system of government.

title: World Church and Jewish Group Agree to Meet on Regular Basis
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13World Jewish leaders and officials of the World Council of Churches announced today plans to hold, for the first time, consultations on a regular basis.

title: U.S. PLANS SHIFTS IN BIENNALE ROLE
description: The United States is plan ning a drastic change in the type of exhibition it will pre sent at this June's Venice Bien nale, the oldest and most pres tigious of the international art fairs.

title: Concern Grows in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The official position of the Nixon Administration continues to be one of support for the Common Market as an instrument for eventual European unity. But, with variations among the major Government departments, there is growing skepticism about unity and rising concern about the economic impact of the Common Market, particu larly in agriculture.

title: In Brooklyn, Brownstones Within Their Budgets
description: A STARTLING expanse of sky  not just a patch work affair filling in the gaps between skyscraper tops viewed at the risk of a crick in the neckis one of the attractions that is draw ing brownstone buyers to Carroll Gardens in South Brooklyn. Many of the area's four and fivestory early Victorian brownstones are set back behind 25footdeep front yards, giving the sky MOM to make its presence felt.

title: OFFDUTY POLICEMAN KILLS BOY IN JERSEY
description: KEARNY, N. J., Feb. 13 (AP) Two boys were shot, one fatally, in Arlington Cemetery here today during what Deputy Police Chief Henry Bloomer said was an apparent attempt by them to take the car of an offduty Jersey City policeman.

title: GEN. BULL CALLED TO U.N. FOR TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 13  Secretary General Thant today ordered Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull, commander of the United Nations observation team in the Middle East, to return to New York this week end for, urgent consultation. The order followed the Israeli bombing attack that killed at least 70 civilians in a Cairo suburb yesterday.

title: Cellist to Give Recital
description: A concert featuring Michael Rudiakov, Israeli cellist, will be presented tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the Van Alstyne Auditorium of the Horace Mann School, 231 West 146th Street, the Bronx. Mr. Rudiakov will be accompanied by Alan Hersh, pianist.

title: STOCKS DECLINE, BUT A.T.&T. STARS
description: American Telephone turned in a star performance yester day as the stock market drifted down a bit in the absence of any teethrattling news.

title: AIRCARGO LOSSES TRIPLE IN 2 YEARS
description: International air cargo losses, of which 80 per cent were at tributed to theft, have almost tripled during the last two years, according to the Ameri can Institute of Marine Under writers.

title: Rep. Watson Enters Race For Carolina Governorship
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 13 Representative Albert W. Wat son announced his candidacy for Governor of South Carolina today to give some hope to our beleaguered students, teach ers and parents.

title: Regulatory Unit Says Railroads Attempt to Weaken Safety Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) An organization of state reg ulatory agencies accused the railroad industry today of try ing to thwart the nation's first comprehensive train safety leg islation.

title: SEALS VICTORS, 42, ON TWO LATE GOALS
description: OAKLAND, Feb. 13 The Rangers tied their own league record by scoring for the 117th consecurive game tonight, but they didn't feel like celebrating.

title: U.S. DROPS CHARGES IN BETTING INQUIRY
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Federal officials, who predicted several dozen more arrests when they began gambling raids Jan. 1 are instead drop ping charges against some men previously arrested.

title: Plane Lindbergh Flew Is Returning to Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)The tiny, single en gine airplane that Col. Charles A. Lindbergh flew to Japan in 1931 will leave Washington tomorrow for a second trip to Japan.

title: BONN AND SOVIET SET FOR TREATY TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13 (UPI)A high West German official con ferred with the Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, for an hour and a half today and indicated after the meeting that the two countries were ready to nego tiate a treaty to renounce the use of force.

title: Topics: The Notebook That Came In From the Cold
description: My colleagues eye me with increasing contempt, and my family views me with growing suspicion. How much selfre spect can I salvage if the Jus tice Department continues to ignore me and fails to sub poena my files and my note books?

title: 3 Liners Tie Up Safely Unaided by Tugs
description: Without the benefit of tug boats, the world's longest and largest passenger liner, the superliner France, eased into her West Side berth be fore dawn yesterday in a delicate, closely timed ma neuver, while most of her 1,152 passengers slept.

title: LONDON MARKET IN QUIET DECLINE
description: The London Stock Exchange closed easier in quiet trading yesterday. A mood of caution prevailed as traders awaited the release on Monday of Brit ain's January trade figures. The possibility of a strike at British Ford, coupled with the decline in Thursday's New York markets, was also con sidered a factor.

title: Hanoi Troops Push Into Plain in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 13 The Defense Ministry said that elements of two North Vietnamese divisions, over coming Laotian resistance on the ground and largely pro tected by clouds from United States air strikes, drove Gov ernment forces today from several important positions and advanced into the north east quadrant of the Plaine des Jarres.

title: Wisconsin Bans DDT
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 13 (AP)  A bill prohibiting the sale or use of DDT in Wiscon sin was signed into law today by Gov. Warren P. Knowles. He urged that persons with the pesticide on hand not throw it in trash cans or empty it down drains because this would only compound the problem and create au additional pollution hazard.

title: Sigma Delta Chi View
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 Frank Angelo, managing editor of The Detroit Free Press, who is presi dent of Sigma Delta Chi, said tonight that the criticism of the national journalism society was unwarranted because the or ganization has been fighting for freedom of information for several decades.

title: Remote Vietnam Village Barely Feels War
description: THOIBINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 9At the end of a wobbly board out over the canal bank, a wrinkled woman squatted and washed her family's breakfast dishes in the brown water as sampans loaded with baskets of green vegetables, rice and people in conical straw hats passed by.

title: DARTMOUTH LEADS IN CARNIVAL MEET
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 13  Outscored this morning by Middlebury in an actionfilled slalom event, Dartmouth stormed back in crosscountry this afternoon to gain the team lead as the Big Green's 60th annual Winter Carnival got under way.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Rough Grindstone Is Ahead for Ellis's Damaged Nose
description: Among the unknown fac tors in Monday night's heavy weight title showdown is how Jimmy Ellis's nose will react.

title: Resin Price Rise Set
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Feb. 13 (UPI)The Rexene Polymers Company, a division of Dart Industries, Inc., announced to day it is raising prices on resins for lowdensity polyethylene in jection moldings to 11 cents a pound from 10 cents on ship ments beginning March 1.

title: SANDRA HAYNIE'S 68 LEADS BY A STROKE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13 (UPI)San dra Haynie, who bounced:back from a severe knee injury and got rid of her crutches only few weeks ago, fired a four underpar 68 today to grab the firstround lead in the $40,000 Burdine's women's invitation golf tournament.

title: U.S. BARS DRUG USE BY RELIGIOUS SECT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The Government has refused to allow a small church in New Mexico to use a forbidden drug on grounds that it might open the door to establishment of drugoriented religious sects.

title: SOUTHERNERS ACT IN PASADENA CASE
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 13 The Attorneys General of Mis sissippi, Alabama and Louisi ana asked to intervene today in the historic Pasadena school integration case in an attempt to force the district to desegre gate its schools immediately.

title: 45 STATES REPORT THE HONG KONG FLU
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 13 (AP) The Hong Kong flu is back. National health officials say its occurrence has been reported in 45 states, but they predict that it will not be so severe as last year's epidemic that killed thousands.

title: Mrs. Romney on Senate List
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 13 (AP)Mrs. Lenore Romney, wife of the Secretary of Hous ing and Urban Development, George Romney, says she can be considered a possible Re publican candidate for the Senate this year in Michigan, according to Gov. William G. Milliken. The Governor had set today as the deadline for 26 Republicans to reply whether they wanted to remain on the list as possible consensus Can didates to oppose Senator Philip A. Hart, a Democrat.

title: LAIRD DECLARES PULLOUT GOES ON DESPITE THE FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird said today that the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam would continue despite the stalemate in the Paris negotiations and the persistence of a substantial enemy threat on the battlefield.

title: S.C.C.A. DELEGATES ATTEND SEMINARS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 More than 350 delegates of the Sports Car Club of America, representing a nationwide membership of 18,500, opened the club's 26th annual conven tion today with attention di vided between motor sports and club politics.

title: RICHARD W. HAYES
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 13 Richard W. Hayes, vice presi dent for marketing of Devro Ltd., a division of Johnson & Johnson, since 1964, died today at his home here at 414 Law rence Avenue, after a long ill ness. His age was 57.

title: LAWYER WAS DUPED ON GILPATRIC NOTES
description: A lawyer who had offered to auction off four Dear Ros letters that Mrs. Aristotle Onassis wrote to Roswell Gil patricfrom whom they were allegedly stolen  contended yesterday that he had been duped by someone who wanted them made public to embarrass the principals.

title: TRIAL OF PANTHER TO BE SEEN ON TV
description: Some of it is tedious. Some of it is repetitious. But so of course is a trial, Robert M. Fresco said yesterday about his sixhour documentary of the courtroom trial of a Black Panther, which will be broad cast on public television in 90 minute segments on four suc ??essive nights beginning March 23.

title: SOVIET MAY FREE 2 YOUNG ITALIANS
description: ROME, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Two young Italians sentenced this week to a year in a labor camp for a protest demonstra tion in a (Moscow department store will be released, diplo matic sources said here tonight.

title: Pakistani Regiment In Jordan Is Placed At 300 to 500 Men
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 13 Only 300 to 500 Pakistani sol diers, assigned to an antiair craft detail, are stationed in Jordan, according to highly placed Jordanian sources and Western diplomats.

title: 2 New Novels, With 7th Avenue Setting, That Focus on Fashion and Sex
description: TWO new novels with au thentic Seventh Avenue backgrounds will soon have the fashion industry in a state of gossipy ferment. By coincidence, both have heroes named Phil who wrestle with the problem, to be or not to be a homosexual.

title: Rock Island Line Reports Loss for Quarter and Year
description: The Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad, reported yes terday a fourthquarter loss of $977,196 in contrast to a year earlier profit of $1,954,126. In all 1969 the company had a loss of $9,830,712 compared with a 1968 loss of $4,805,163.

title: Washington: For the Record
Fire Kills 7 and Hurts 9 In Munich Jewish Center
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 13 (AP)  Fire swept through the top floor of a Mu nich Jewish community center tonight, killing seven and in juring nine of the 30 elderly people who lived there.

title: OISTRAKH CHOOSES 2 VIOLIN NOVELTIES
description: David Oistrakh, the Soviet violinist, has covered quite bit of musical ground in the various concert appearances he has made here within the past few weeks, and he came up with two works that qualify as novelties for inclusion in the recital he gave at Philhar monic Hall last night.

title: Princeton Beats Brown
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 13 Princeton combined a tight de fense with a methodical offense tonight to crush Brown, 7340, in an Ivy League game.

title: Luigi Quintiliano Is Dead; I.L.G.W.U. Unit Head Was 77
description: Luigi Quintiliano, who re tired as manager of Local 38 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died Thursday here after a short ill ness. He was 77 years old and lived at 341 West 24th Street.

title: NEW NORMA TO STAR SUTHERLAND AT MET
description: The Metropolitan Opera will introduce a new production of Bellini's Norma on March 3, during the 10th week of its sea son, in a performance spon sored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild for the benefit of the company's production fund. Joan Sutherland will sing the title role, and Marilyn Horne will make her Metropolitan debut in the part of Adalgisa.

title: Royals Defeat Warriors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (AP)The Cincinnati Royals broke loose with torrid third period shooting and defeated the San Francisco Warriors, 128110, tonight.

title: ENTHUSIASM LOW FOR NEW ISSUES
description: Investor enthusiasm for new stock issues remained at a low ebb this week as 10 com panies, according to one com pilation, offered shares to the public for the first time.

title: Israel Reports Her Ground Fire Downed U.A.R. Jet Near Suez
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13Is rael reported today that her antiaircraft fire brought down an Egyptian fighterbomber in the Suez Canal sector. The downed craft was described by an army spokesman as a Suk hoi7, a Sovietbuilt jet that has proved particularly suitable for the lowflying hitandrun mis sions that the Egyptians ap pear to have adopted.

title: Swenson Stars as Kansas State Sets 2 Astrodome Relay Marks
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) Ken Swenson, a halfmiler, an chored Kansas State relay teams to two world best rec ords tonight, Kansas took the lead in the team standing after the first half of the United States track and Field Federa tion national indoor champion ships at the Astrodome.

title: ARRESTS INCREASED 21% HERE IN 1969
description: A total of 228,175 arrests were recorded here during 1969, an increase of 21.6 per cent over the 187,613 arrests in 1968, the Police Department reported yesterday.

title: 3 Are Held in Drug Raid
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 13 Three Colgate University stu dents were arrested yesterday in a cottage near here on charges of possessing $10,000 worth of hashish, marijuana and LSD. The students, Geof fery A. Hoare, 20 years old, of Largo, Fla.; John S. Cramer, 16, of Elizabeth, N. J., and Mar tin Henderson, 20, of Bound Brook, N. J., were released on $2,500 bail pending a hearing Feb. 27. and LSD. The students, Geof fery A. Hoare, 20 years old, of Largo, Fla.; John S. Cramer, 16, of Elizabeth, N. J., and Mar tin Henderson, 20, of Bound Brook, N. J., were released on $2,500 bail pending a hearing Feb. 27.

title: Bettye Carter, '66 Debutante, To Be a Bride
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 13Mayor and Mrs. Matthew G. Carter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bettye Fran ces Carter, to Robert Turner Freeman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs.Freeman Jr. of Washing ton.

title: 2 DECLINE TO TALK AT CRIME HEARINGS
description: Cosmo Frasca, described as a Mafia captain in Brooklyn, resorted to the Fifth Amend ment 25 times yesterday as he refused to answer questions at a hearing of the state's Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

title: Black Experience and Modernist Art
description: THE collage paintings of Romare Bearden, with their fragmented images of Negro life locked into an elegant cubist design, are fairly well known on the New York art scene. The sculptures of Barbara Chase Riboud, including her four abstract Monuments to Mal colm X, are new to New York. Yet the works of both of these black American art iststhe one a well estab lished figure, the other a young expatriate living in Franceraise some interest ing questions about the re lation of black experience to modernist forms of painting and sculpture.

title: Brandt Confers With Danes
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 13The West German Chancellor. Willy Brandt, arrived in Copenhagen today on an official twoday visit and held talks with Pre mier Hilmar Baunsgaard and other members of the Danish Government He also visited King Frederik I.

title: Bowdoin 62 Hockey Victor
description: BRUNSWICK, Me.; Feb. 13 Two goals each by Steve Hardy and Ed Good paced Bowdoin College to a 62 hockey victory over Middlebury College today. The triumph was Bowdoin's ninth straight. Jim Glenn scored both Middlebury's goals.

title: PAUL SIEBEL SINGING HIS FOLK SONGS HERE
description: Paul Siebel, a folk singer with a country and Western bias, is playing through tomor row at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: Taxi Procession Honors Cabby Slain by Robber
description: With lights and offduty signs blazing, a milelong pro cession of 300 cabs rolled from Times Square to a Brooklyn funeral home yes terday in tribute to a cab driver slain in a holdup.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION DECLINES IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP)  The nation's auto makers scheduled production of only 95,078 new cars this week, compared to 133,371 last week and 171,069 In the 1969 week.

title: Antiques: Lusterware Finds Friends
description: ENGLISH lusterware is attracting a new genera tion of collectors who ap preciate the qualities of 19th century pottery. When it was first popular in the 1920's, common English luster was considered an 18thcentury product. It was admired as rural ware and used with country furniture.

title: John Lotz Shoots a 64 for 133 and Takes OneStroke Lead in Tucson Golf
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 13 (UPI)John Lotz, a pro from Hayward, Calif., shot an eight underpar 64 in the second round of the $100,000,Tucson, open today and took a one stroke lead at the halfway mark.

title: The Philippines on the Brink
description: A Jesuit priest warned the Filipino Ccingress in an opening day invocation last month that dying hopes and perished longings were driving the nation to the trembling edge of revolution. A few days later the Philippines almost slipped over that brink as six demonstrators died in bloody student rioting before the Presidential Palace.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Lagos Issues Arms Ban
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 13 (AP) The Government issued an order today barring the pos session of arms in the three eastern states that once formed Biafra.

title: Citizens Group Seeks Support For Legal OffTrack Betting
description: A 10Member citizens com mittee to mobilize public sup port for legal offtrack betting was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay, Controller Abraham D. Beame and City Council President Sanford D. Garelik.

title: A Correction
description: A review of the New York Philharmonic concert in The New York Times on Thursday stated that it had been Leon ard Bernstein's last appearance with the orchestra here this season. Mr. Bernstein will con duct the Philharmonic again on Monday night in a repetition of that program of works by Wil liam Schuman, Mozart and Tchaikovsky. It is a nonsub scription concert, and tickets are still available at the Phil harmonic Hall box office.

title: 10 Die in French Plane Crash
description: MORTAGNEauPERCHE, France, Feb. 13 (UPI)A char ter plane crashed near here to night in a snowstorm, killing all 10 persons aboard.

title: Miss Lafforgue Gains Slalom Crown
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 13 (UPI)Ingrid Lafforgue of France withstood a strong fin ishing run by Barbara Cochran of Richmond, Vt., and captured the women's slalom title at the world Alpine ski championships today.

title: Yablonski Suspect Moved
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 13 (UPI) Paul Gilly, 36 years old, one of the men charged with con spiring to murder Joseph A. Yablonski, United Mine Work ers official, was transferred to Canton, Ohio, today for his personal safety. A Federal grand jury was impaneled here Jan. 20 to investigate the slay ings of Mr. Yablonski, 59, his wife, Margaret, 57, and daugh ter, Charlotte, 25, whose bodies were found in their Clarksville, Pa., home on Jan. 5.

title: Judith Fitzpatrick Prospective Bride
description: Justice Daniel E. Fitzpatrick of the State Supreme Court, and Mrs. Fitzpatrick of Ja maica Estates, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Fitzpatrick, to Joseph John Asselta of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Asselta of Garden City, L. I. The wedding will be in June.

title: Net Protects Passengers in Auto Accidents
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 In a severe collision, a car safety device will release the windshield and catch the frontseat passengers in netting. The equipment was patented this Patents week by Paul V. Malloy of Cleveland, a re tired vice presi dent of Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Foes of Smoking Gaining by Attack on Its Social Acceptability
description: With per capita cigarette consumption at the lowest point in a decade, the battle against cigarette smoking seems to be gaining momentum and taking off in a new direction.

title: August Nuptials Are Scheduled By Miss Moore
description: GLEN ROCK, N. J., Feb. 13 The engagement of Miss Stephanie Marie Moore, a junior at Syracuse University, to Charles Thorndike Ladd, a doctoral candidate at Syra cuse, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William A. Moore, parents of the pros pective bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Blaney Ladd of North Scituate, Mass.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill to Allow Arming of L.I.R.R. Policemen
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today permitting railroad policemen to carry guns.

title: U.S. Shaping Goals In Institution Study
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Administration has not yet de cided precisely what its new commission on financial insti tutions should study, but offi cials are beginning to pinpoint what should be within and what outside the scope of the inquiry.

title: PISTONS CONQUER SUNS, 132 TO 120
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14 (UPI) Terry Dischinger, Jimmy Walk er and Dave Bing combined for 73 points tonight in leading the Detroit Pistons to a 132120 victory over the Phoenix Suns in a National Basketball Asso ciation game.

title: St. Valentine's Day Survives His Fall
description: ALTHOUGH Saint Valen tine's prestige fell sharp ly last spring when the Roman Catholic Church dropped him from its official liturgical calendar, his good name is being proclaimed throughout the country today in ribbons and laces and candycoated sentiment. Commercial love's labors have not been lost.

title: Santa Claus, Irish Racer, Dies
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Santa Claus, the winner of the 1964 Epsom Derby and Irish Sweepstakes Derby, died at farm at Lucan, it was reported today. He was at stud several years. Owned by John Ismay and trained in Ireland by Mick Rogers, Santa Claus was the first horse this century to achieve the English and Irish Derby double.

title: ISRAEL AND MARKET REACH TARIFF PACT
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 13  The European Common Market and Israel reached agreement today on a fiveyear preferential trade treaty that pledges sub stantial tariff reductions on ex changes of industrial and farm products.

title: Triborough Surplus Is Put At $26,226,769 by M.T.A.
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the op erating surplus of the Tribor ough Bridge and Tunnel Au thority for the the fiscal year ended last Dec. 31 amounted to $26.226,769.98.

title: Guild Reaffirms Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The American Newspaper Guild re affirmed today its position that newsmen's notes and other confidential material should not be subject to subpoena.

title: White House Defends Sale
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 13 The weekend White House shrugged off today reports of the Carswell land sale.

title: British Gain From Revolutionary War 200 Years Later
description: LONDON, Feb. 13Davison, Newman & Co., tea merchants of Creechurch Lane, are pra paring packets of Ceylon, India and Darjeeling for export to the United States in the ex pectation of better acceptance than was received in Boston in 1773.

title: Al Fatah Claims Victory
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 13  Al Fatah, the major Palestin ian guerrilla group, said tonight over the Cairo radio that the commando movement had emerged victorious in its con frontation with the Jordanian Government.

title: How Maternity Shop Is Born
description: AMOTHER image doesn't necessarily mean Mrs. Whistler or Sophie Portnoy. She can be Joanne Tiefer, 22 years old, who has long dark hair, wears a size five in a mini or a maxi and who an swers when 11monthold Melissa calls, Mama. Nor is Lady Madonna, the bou tique on the cor ner of Madison Avenue and 67th Street, the usual idea of a mater nity shop. For one thing, Zelda, one of the preg nant mannequins in the win dow, is a swinging young doll in an Afro hairdo and a pur ple velvet jumpsuit. (She wasn't pregnant when we bought her, I stuffed her she's about five months along, says Mrs. Tiefer.) is Lady Madonna, the bou tique on the cor ner of Madison Avenue and 67th Street, the usual idea of a mater nity shop. For one thing, Zelda, one of the preg nant mannequins in the win dow, is a swinging young doll in an Afro hairdo and a pur ple velvet jumpsuit. (She wasn't pregnant when we bought her, I stuffed her she's about five months along, says Mrs. Tiefer.)

title: Cornell Tops Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 13 Cornell's Bill Schwarzkopf scored 12 points in the first 8 minutes of the second half to help lift the Big Red from a 3333 intermission deadlock to a 7365 Ivy League victory over Harvard tonight.

title: CARSWELL'S SALE OF LOT EXPLAINED
description: PANACEA, Fla., Feb. 13 The land that Judge G. Harrold Carswell sold in 1966 with a whites only restriction in the deed is in a sparkling resort area being developed on the milewide Ochlocknee River near here.

title: MRS. WALTER POSTLEY
description: Mrs. Dena Eckstein Cadden Postley of 69 Dogwood Lane, Stamford, Conn., widow of Wal ter Postley, a typographer, died here yesterday. She was 82 years old.

title: Rand Housing Report Criticized As Incomplete by City Officials
description: The controversial Rand re port on rent control and hous ing decay came under criticism yesterday from two of the city's top housing officials.

title: Opera: Filledu Regiment
description: GIVEN a soprano who can sing the role of Marie and, even more, convince the audience that she is hav ing a good time singing it Donizetti's La Fille du Regi ment can be a lot of fun. And so it was last night in Carnegie Hall, when Beverly Sills took over the stage as star of the American Opera Society concert version.

title: GOLD MARKETED BY SOUTH AFRICA
description: CAPETOWN, Feb. 13 (AP) South Africa has been selling twothirds of her newly mined gold abroad on the free market in recent months. Finance Min ister Nicolaas Diederiche told the Parliament today.

title: NINA LEWITON, 65, AUTHOR OF NOVELS
description: Mina Lewiton, an author and the wife of Howard Simon, died Wednesday in her home at Lilac Hill, Stanfordville, N. Y. She was 65 years old.

title: Dinner to Benefit U.J.A.
description: An inaugural dinner, spon sored by the Young Leader ship Division of the United Jewish Appeal to initiate its 1970 campaign, will be held on Wednesday at the Plaza. Cochairmen are Miss Bar bara Sue Feldman and Rich ard N. Runes. Proceeds will aid Jews in Israel and throughout the world.

title: COURT CURBS NADDEO AND NAMES RECEIVER
