description: V. F. Naddeo & Co., Inc., a securities concern that makes markets in several hundred overthecounter issues, was enjoined yesterday from doing further business with other securities concerns.

title: CATHOLICS WIDEN SATURDAY MASSES
description: Roman Catholics in the Dio cese of Brooklyn will be able beginning today, to attend masses on Saturday that will free them of their obligation to go to church on Sunday.

title: Hirsch Jacobs, Leading Trainer, Is Dead
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 13  Hirsch Jacobs, the trainer who saddled more winners than any one else in thoroughbred rac ing, died of a cerebral hemor rhage today at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 65 years old.

title: Dresden, Rebuilding, Is Still Seared by Memory of '45 Firebombing
description: DRESDEN, East Germany, Feb. 13  That terrible night just 25 years ago, when Dresden was devastated in one of the most controversial chapters of World War II, still sears the memories of those who survive.

title: RESERVE STANDS ON MONEY CURBS
description: The Federal Reserve System held close to its policy of firm monetary restraint during the last two weeks, banking figures published yesterday showed.

title: Millican Gains Early Lead In World Sunfish Regatta
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 13 (AP)Chuck Millican of Plymouth, Mass., took the lead today in the first world championship sunfish regatta by winning the opening six mile race and finishing fourth in the second.

title: Catena Is Subpoenaed
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13The State Commission of Investiga tion disclosed today that it had subpoenaed Gerardo (Jerry) Ca tena, the reputed successor to the late Vito Genovese, who was New Jersey's most import ant Mafia boss of bosses.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Arson in Church Fire
description: A 24yearold Brooklyn man was charged with arson last night in connection with a fire at the Mary Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Friday evening.

title: Court Gets Maddox Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) Private attorneys for Gov. Les ter G. Maddox appealed to the Supreme Court today seek ing to strike down the Geor gia constitution's prohibition against a second consecutive term for a Governor. They contended that the prohibition constituted invidious discrimi nation and an unreasonable and arbitrary restriction on the right to run for a second term.

title: Europeans call for Degrees in Ecology
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 13The science of ecology the study of the natural en vironment  received encou ragement in Europe yesterday.

title: Birgit Nilsson Sings Title Role In Met Season's First Turandot
description: To the most cruel of his so prano heroines, Turandot, Puc cini gave the cruelest music, but when it is superbly sung it creates one of the most excit ing vocal effects in opera. Last night at the Metropolitan, Turandot was given its first performance of the season, and Birgit Nilsson was on hand to sing the title roleassurance that it would be superbly sung.

title: MAYOR GETS FUND FOR MORGENTHAU
description: Mayor Lindsay agreed yes terday to cut back funds for a major new office to be headed by Deputy Mayordesignate Robert M. Morgenthau, and the Board of Estimate then ap proved the figure by a vote of 18 to 4.

title: 2 MORE U.S. COPTERS DOWNED IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Two more Amer icn helicopters have been shot down in Vietnam, injuring seven Americans and 16 South Viet namese, a United States spokes man said today.

title: N.Y.U. Business Students Organize to Aid Ghetto Area Businessmen
description: Steven Boyd, a Negro who with his wife runs the Chicken & Soul restaurant at 1325 Nevins Street in Brook lyn, met face to face yester day with two young white business school students who expressed an interest in help ing him make a go of it.

title: Accused Captain Linked to 20 Killings
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The attorney for Capt. Thomas K. Willingham, the ranking Army figure to be charged with crimes in the Vietnamese vil lage of Songmy, said today that his client was accused of kill ing 20 Vietnamese civilians.

title: Fire on Oil Platform in Gulf, Burning Out of Control, Poses Threat of Pollution
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13  An intense fire has been burn ing out of control for three days on an oil platform over the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Knicks Crush 76ers, 151106, With 80 Points in First Half
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13  The New York Knickerbockers showed no brotherly love for the Philadelphia 76ers in their National Basketball Association game at the Spectrum tonight, handing the 76ers the worst defeat in the history of the franchise; 151106.

title: Market Place
description: WOULD a broker churn the stocks of a little old lady? Never. Especially not those of a housekeeper who came to this country from England, earned $125 a month most of her life and was fortunate enough late in life to marry her employer and inherit half a million dollars as his widow.

title: Jeffrey C. Morse Will Marry Miss Rowan Belknap Howard
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 12Mr. and Mrs. John Ham ilton Howard have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rowan Belknap Howard, to Jeffrey Clement Morse, son of Dr. and Mrs. Willard Jackson Morse of East Braintree, Vt. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Quake Shakes Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 13 (UPI)A light earthquake orig inating at the bottom of the ocean between Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands shook this island today. No damage of casualties were reported, al though earth tremors regis tered for four minutes. The tremor was felt in Puerto Rico in the centers of Trujillo Alto, Humacao, Caguas and Cayey.

title: Mailmen in Two Boroughs Are Taking Strike Vote
description: Branch 36 of the National As sociation of Letter Carriers is taking a strike vote among its 8,400 members in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Whitmore Joins Inquest
description: James Whitmore will play the role of Block, the defense at torney, in the Donald Freed drama Inquest dealing with the Rosenberg conspiracy trial. The production is scheduled to open at the Music Box April 23.

title: On Prague Television: Pointers on Manners
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 13While the Communist party has been talking about discipline, the people have been interested in manners.

title: Removal of Quotas on Imports May Cut Martini Cost in Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 13It will be possible to mix an inexpensive martini in Japan starting to morrow. The Government de cided today to remove quanti tative restrictions from nine categories of imports including vermouth.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1970

title: Boston College Black Funds
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 13 (AP)  Boston College an nounced today an increase in funds allotted to recruitment of economically disadvantaged black students. The increase, from $100,000 over four years to $500,000 over four years, is a concession to demands by black students.

title: Dr. Frederick Bissell Jr., English Professor at Post
description: Dr. Frederick Olds Bissell Jr., professor of English litera ture at C. W. Post College, died of a heart attack yesterday en route to a hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 16 Park Avenue.

title: Books of The Times
description: I GUESS because I was not satisfied that I had tested myself enough, Matthew J. (Joe) Culligan writes in explanation of why he wanted to be presi dent of the Curtis Publishing Company. I had never been Number OneI wanted a try at it myself. Sometimes, as Avis and Spiro T. Agnew have demonstrated, being No. 2 has its satis factions. For when

title: Pact on Minority Workers Ends TieUp on Campus at Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 13Despite protests from minority groups, Governor Rockefeller today ended a construction morator ium that had halted work since last March on a new campus for the State University in sub urban Amherst.

title: French Tax Offices Bombed
description: LYONS, France, Feb. 13 (UPI) Six bombs exploded in and near tax offices here today. No one was injured and dam age was slight.

title: M'GRADY BETTERS INDOOR 600 MARK
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 Martin McGrady ran down Lee Evans in the stretch and won a thrilling race to the fin ish tonight en route to an in door record in the 600yard run at the 11th annual Los Angeles Times indoor games.

title: Napoles 41 to Beat Lopez And Keep Ring Title Tonight
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) Expressions of confidence emanated today from the camps of the champion, Jose (Mante quilla) Napoles, and Ernie (In dian Red) Lopez as they went through final preparations for their 15round fight for the world welterweight champion ship tomorrow night.

title: Auto Insurers Win Big Jersey Increase
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13The Ca hill administration announced tonight that it had granted rate increase of up to 33.3 per cent to automobile insurance companies, which had threat ened to abandon all their coy erage.

title: Mrs. King Greeted in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 13 (Reu ters)  Mrs. Coretta King, widow of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., had a private audience today with King Gus taf VI Adolf and lunched with Premier Olof Palme. Mrs. King is touring Europe in connection with the publication of her book, My Life With Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Cooks Told Not to Use Mexican Earthenware
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration warned house wives today to stop using Mexican pottery and earthen ware in cooking because of the possibility of lead poison ing.

title: Treasury to Sell $1.75Billion Of Bills That Mature Shortly
description: The Treasury Department, in an experiment designed improve its cash management, announced plans yesterday to sell $1.75billion of bills that will mature in an unusually snort time in addition, the Treasury disclosed that it would raise additional money by increasing the size of its regular weekly and monthly sales of bills.

title: Dr. Barnard Marries Barbara Zoellner, 19
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Saturday, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Prof. Christiaan N. Barnard, South Africa's heart transplant pioneer, married 19yearold Barbara Zoellner, a Johannesburg socialite, early today.

title: U.S. to Back $21 Million Loans To Develop New City in Midwest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The Nixon Administration to day took its first step, a small one, toward developing new cities.

title: 3 MORE ESCAPEES OF U.S. JAIL SEIZED
description: Two suspected bank robbers and an alleged truck hijacker who escaped with six other prisoners from the Federal House of Detention here on Feb. 6 were captured early yes terday in Brooklyn by agents of the Federal Bureau of In vestigation.

title: Patricia M. Reardon Fiancee Of Andrew Vorkink, Yale '69
description: HINGHAM, Mass., Feb., 13 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George. Daniel Reardon of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Marie Reardon, to Andrew Nancen Vorkink, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franois Vorkink of New Hope, Pa.

title: Art: Masters, Past and Present
description: A MONG the exhibitions in town just now worth go ing out of your way to see, let us choose a couple. Old Master Drawings From Chatsworth is at the Mor gan Library, at the corner of 36th Street and Madison Avenue, and Leonard Bas kin: The Graphic Work, 19501970 is at the FAR Gallery, 746 Madison Avenue at 64th Street.

title: 23 Arrested at Newark March Held to Back Teachers' Strike
description: NEWARK, Feb. 13Twenty three persons were arrested here today during a march and demonstration in downtown Newark and outside of City Hall in support of the two weekold strike by the Newark Teachers Union.

title: G.M. Redesigning Auto Engines For Operation on Unleaded Fuel
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13The Gen eral Motors Corporation is redesigning its car engines to operate on unleaded gasoline of lower octane, ratings than those of most present fuels.

title: 9th Straight Ivy Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (UPI) Dave Wohl scored 5 consecu tive points in the closing min utes tonight to send oncede feated Pennsylvania to a 7062 Ivy League basketball victory over Yale at the Palestra.

title: The Odyssey Move
description: The Lindsay administration's belated move to help the children who are being treated for drug addiction in the Bronx Odyssey House program ought to be but the first step in a long march forward. The old antago nism between officials of municipal and of private addiction treatment facilities has to be replaced by a new spirit of cooperation. The drug problem is large enough to require a concentrated attack from many sides by many people.

title: For He Is an Englishman
description: LONDON, Feb. 13  In Nai robi one recent evening a young lawyer spoke of his feelings toward England. In most re spects he was himself the char acteristic product of an elitist English education: a First at Oxford, a prestigious fellow ship, a brilliant passage through the bar examinations. But his parents were Indian, and he was born in Kenya.

title: GALLO SAW LACEY ON EYE OF DEATH
description: NEWARK, Feb. 13  Hours before he died in an automobile crash early Tuesday morning, a man under indictment in the Federal investigation of organ ized crime in New Jersey had submitted to an extensive in terview by United States At torney Frederick B. Lacey.

title: OPPONENTS DEMAND REPORT BY MARCOS
description: MANILA, Feb. 13The Op position Liberal party has de manded that President Ferdi nand E. Marcos explain to the public exactly what he agreed to during his meeting Wednes day evening with militant labor and student leaders.

title: GOLA QUITS AS COACH OF LA SALLE QUINTET
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Tom Gola announced his resignation as head basket ball coach at La Salle College today after completing a two year rebuilding program.

title: Strike Snarls Italian Roads; Talks Begin on Coalition
description: ROME, Feb. 13 (Reuters) The Premierdesignate, Mariano Rumor, began efforts today to form Italy's 31st government in 25 years against a back ground symptomatic of his country's woes90,000 public transportation workers staged a crippling oneday strike.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SOYBEANS OFF
description: Profit taking hit the pits at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Grain and soybean futures prices, with the excep tion of soybean oil, dropped after days of upward move ment.

title: BLACK NEWSMEN VOW RESISTANCE
description: A group of about 70 black journalists announced yester day that they would resist any attempt by the Government to force them to appear before any investigation or law en forcement agency with unpub lished or unbroadcast material they had gathered.

title: LAWRENCE M. FLETCHER
description: Lawrence Meyer Fletcher, a Broadway, movie and television actor, died Wednesday in Bridgeport Hospital, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 70 years old and lived at 31 Smedley Road, Fairfield, Conn.

title: Bridge
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 13The American tour ing team wound up its Aus tralian visit by winning its final match here tonight.

title: 2 KEY INDICATORS SHOW A LEVELING FOR U.S. ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13In dustrial production declined in January for the sixth consecu tive month, further confirming the slowdown in the economy, the Federal Reserve Board re ported today.

title: Joint Use of American Bases Proposed by Japanese Minister
description: TOKYO, Feb. 13  A politi cally attractive but legally thorny proposal for joint use of American bases in Japan is be ing studied by Defense and Foreign Ministry officials here.

title: Similar Methods Used in Missouri Bank Holdup
description: The modus operandi, arma ments and descriptions of two men who used explosives to di vert the police while robbing a Danbury, Conn., bank yester day were strikingly similar to those of two men who held up a bank in Union, Mo., exactly three months ago.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins 19th, 9561
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) Unbeaten and No. 1ranked University of California, Los Angeles, raced to its 19th vic tory of the season tonight, routing Washington State, 9561, in PacificEight Confer ence play. Sidney Wicks scored 21 points and the Bruins dom inated the backboards.

title: College Basketball
Roadblock or Open Road
description: Vice President Agnew added to the widespread public misunderstanding of the meaning and purpose of open admission in respect to higher education when he used the term in tandem with his rejection of racial quotas. The two concepts are not correla tives but exact opposites.

title: PRICES SLIP A BIT IN AMEX TRADING
description: Traders on the American Stock Exchange tried hard yes terday, but they did not quite achieve an advance. Declines outnumbered advances by a narrow margin in quiet trad ing.

title: Mets Give Seaver $80,000 Pact, Doubling His 1969 Salary
description: Tom Seaver's salary for pitching for the New York Mets in 1970 will be $80,000, more than double the amount he re ceived while winning 25 games and leading the Mets to their pennant in 1969.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rights Leader Undaunted by Violence
description: SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Feb. 10 A wisp of gray in his short black goatee is the only out ward sign that Richard Turner has lived with the threat of death.

title: STOCK EXCHANGE ASKS RISE IN FEES
description: The New York Stock Ex change asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yes terday to approve a substan tial increase in the commission rates paid by small investors to buy and sell stock:

title: Lions Triumph, 7258
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 13 Dartmouth's basketball team threw up a strong zone defense that presented Columbia with plenty of problems for 32 min utes tonight. Then the Lions solved the puzzle and rang up 16 straight points to regain the lead and carry Columbia to a 7258 victory before 1,450 in Alumni Gynasium.

title: U.S. Envoy to Guinea Named
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  President Nixon nominated Albert W. Sherer Jr., a career diplomat, today as United States Ambassador to the Republic of Guinea. Mr. Sherer, who joined the State Department in 1946, is now Ambassador to Togo. His new appointment is subject to ap proval by the Senate.

title: U.S. ENVOY WARNS COMMON MARKET
description: BONN, Feb. 13  A senior United States diplomat, J. Rob ert Schaetzel, has accused members of the Common Mar ket of ignoring vital American economic interests.

title: St. Lawrence Five Wins
description: CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 13 (AP) St. Lawrence University de feated Rensselaer Polytechnic Instiute of Troy, 8274, in an Independent College Athletic Conference basketball game to day.

title: Toward Freer Trade
description: The Nixon Administration is seeking to continue the long movement toward a freer trade policy that has been going on in this country since President Roosevelt's Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act of 1934. The last major accomplishment in this direction was the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, which led to the Kennedy Round of tariff cuts.

title: MARITIME GROUP SCORES IMPORTS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 13  The continuing increase in foreign imports was criti cized as dangerous to the United States economy and un fair to this nation's workers by a major labor group meeting here today.

title: News Unions Seek Big Raises Here
description: Newspaper unions here are stressing demands for sizable wage increases in negotiations that are currently under way with the city's four major, gen eralinterest newspapers.

title: A City Center Cinema Planned Using Cinematheque's Archives
description: Plans for a new film unit on its 55th Street premises have been announced by the City Center of Music and Drama. The project, expected to take shape in late fall as City Center Cinema, will transform a large basement hall directly beneath the Cen ter auditorium into one or several movie theaters next to a new film museum. Henri Languns, airector or the Cinemathque Frangaise in Paris, will serve as artistic supervisor of the develop ment, which is expected to draw on the archives of the Cinemathque, numbering more than 50,000 movies, and other resources.

title: Prices of Darts Sharply Cut by Dodge
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13  The Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation sharply cut prices today on all of its compact Dart models. The cuts range frdm $157 to $194, F.O.B. Detroit.

title: TEXAS GULF TO SEEK REVIEW ON TIMMINS
description: The Texas Gulf Sulphur Com pany plans to seek a review of a recent Federal court ruling that it failed to use due dill gence in connection with a 1964 news release concerning a rich mineral find in Timmins, Ontario.

title: Marian E. Glick Plans Nuptials
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Feb. 12 Miss Marian Elaine Glick's engagement to Andrew David Zeitlin has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Glick of Rockville.

title: Three Captured 40 Minutes After Jersey Bank Holdup
description: CLARK, N.J., Feb. 13  Three men were captured in nearby Cranford today 40 minutes after they allegedly held up a trailer office of the Franklin State Bank on Raritan Road here at 9:20 A.M. and escaped with $21,612.

title: TRIANGLE IN SALE TO CAPITAL CITIES
description: The Capital Cities Broadcast Sng Corporation reached an agreement yesterday to acquire radio and television stations in Philadelphia, New Haven and Fresno, Calif., from Triangle Publications, Inc., in addition to the syndication division of Triangle.

title: Austral Oil Strike Reported
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) The Austral Oil Company has found an oil field in the Smack over region of Lafayette Coun ty, Ark. The well, which is on property leased by Austral from the International Paper Company, flowed at a rate of 144 barrels of oil and 1,050 cubic feet of gas per barrel of oil daily from depths of 10,935 to 10,944 feet. Austral has 11,000 acres in the region. In ternational Paper, which retains a 50 per cent interest in min eral rights, said that the dis covery appeared to be limited.

title: F.C.C. Reports It Erred On KFBC Hearing Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had incorrectly reported the vote of its chairman, Dean Burch, on the decision that set hearings on the renewal of KFBCTV in Cheyenne, Wyo.

title: Groping for a Word
description: While phone subscribers grope with their dials and the telephone system's communications gap widens, A. T. & T. has come up with an advertising gimmick being hailed as the biggest thing since Alexander Graham Bell. What bath its agency wrought? Some thing called the Gropea footprint made of four feet and twelve toes going in four directions at once, about to be launched in a huge promotional campaign to symbolize the hapless citizen who doesn't use the Yellow Pages.

title: Wagner Five Wins, 7266
description: The Wagner College Sea hawks survived a late second half surge by Susquehanna and held on for a 7266 victory at Sutter Gymnasium, Staten Is land, last night.

title: SARA LELAND BOWS AS EARTHY DULCINEA
description: Being a vision of ideal beauty is one of those ephemeral jobs that have to be handled with scrupulous delicacy if it is not to be lost. Dulcinea, the heroine in various guises of George Balanchine's Don Quix ote, was danced last night for the first time with the City Bal let at the State Theater by Sara Leland. She danced with a shade too much crisp fervor for total credibility.

title: HardHitting Mayor
description: WHEN he is asked about himself, the burly Mayor of Jersey City is fond of quoting the motto of the Fighting 69th Regiment: Gentle when stroked, fierce when provoked.

title: JERSEY CITY SUES STATE ON SCHOOLS
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 13This city filed suit in Superior Court here today in an attempt to force the state to pay for the support and maintenance of a thorough and efficient system of public schools.

title: New G.E. Pact Settled
description: The Pattern Makers League of North America, representing 150 General Electric Company workers in plants across the nation, reached a tentative agreement with the concern on a national contract yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Details were withheld pending ratification votes set for today, but the agreement was under stood to be similar to those with 130,000 workers who struck G.E. plants Oct. 27.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Protective Shields

title: Stage: Comedie Francaise's Les Femmes Savantes
description: THE quality that above oth ers is irresistible in Molire is his common sense. More perhaps than any other great playwright's, his feet are always firmly on the ground. He is rational, he is urbane, he is gorgeously sen sible.

title: Europeans Approve Watered Wine
description: PARIS, Feb. 13After nearly three years of wrangling, the European Economic Community has incorporated into its rules the right to add foreign matter to wine under certain condi tions.

title: 5 Boys Are Arrested as Cat Burglars in Flushing
description: The police said yesterday that they had broken up a teen aged gang of selfstyled cat burglars that was responsible for burglarizing 100 stores in the last year in the Flushing section of Queens.

title: Queens Resents Lack of Storm Sewers
description: This is low tide, said the policeman as he glanced at the curbhigh pond at the intersec tion of 140th Avenue and 170th Street in the Springfield Gar dens section of Queens.

title: Agnew Called Confused on Admissions
description: The chairman and the former chairman of the state's Joint Legislative Committee on High er Education said yesterday that Vice President Agnew had mistakenly equated open ad missions with ethnic quotas in his criticism Thursday night of college and university ad missions practices.

title: Sports of The Times
description: SOMETIME next week, after most of the rest of the world has settled with Joe Frazier or Jimmy Ellis as its 24th heavyweight champion, the staff of The Ring, boxing's publishing house, will have to decide whether not finally to drop Cassius Clay of Houston from the top spot on its monthly world ratings. The Ring publishes an annual encyclopedia, a monthly magazine, and a number of technical, biographical and historical books and is re ferred to as the final arbiter of boxing questions except when its answers conflict with the immediate need of a promoter.

title: Where Have Herring Gone?
description: A WORLDWIDE shortage of herring has resulted in some shortages of processed herring products at the re tail level and a 10 to 20 per cent increase in prices during the past six months.

title: Excerpts From Big Board Statement on Stock Fees
description: Four of every 10 New York Stock Exchange mem ber firms doing a public business lost money on se eurity commission income (including net margin inter est income) in the first half of 1969. Their cumulative loss amounted to $58mil lion. Losses ranged up to $5.7million, with 13 firms losing over $1million and 51 losing over $250.000.

title: Sonics Sink Bullets
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 13 (AP) Barry Clemens's two free throws with eight seconds remaining and Bob Rule's 39 points helped the Seattle Super Sonics post 141138 victory over the Balti more Bullets tonight.

title: Mishap Kills Five in France
description: GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 13 (Reuters)  Five men were killed and two seriously hurt here today when a dome under construction at the site of a FrenchGerman nuclear reactor crashed to the ground. Four men were killed when they fell from scaffolding on top of the building, which is 100 feet high, officials said. The fifth was trapped under broken concrete and twisted metal.

title: HEUSSLER RESIGNS AT TRENTON STATE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13Dr. Robert Heussler resigned as president of Trenton. State Col lege today as striking students demonstrated outside his office.

title: Drug Raid Seen as Panicking Addicts
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell said yester day that a largescale seizure of heroin and cocaine on Thurs day night would cause a temp orary panic among city nar cotics addicts.

title: OLIVER W. POWERS, FATHER OF U2 PILOT
description: WISE, Va., Feb. 13 (UPI)  Oliver W. Powers, father of the former U2 pilot Francis Gary Powers, died at a hospital here yesterday of an unde termined cause. He was 65 years old.

title: Bar to Review Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Judge Carswell's nomination will be considered again, in a routine manner, by the Ameri can Bar Association committee that last month declared him qualified to sit on the high court.

title: U. of Rochester Physicist Quits Faculty Senate
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 13 (AP) Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the nu clear physicist, has resigned from the University of Roches ter Faculty Senate in a dispute with the administration, it was learned today.

title: GA. TECH UPSETS N.C. STATE
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 13 (AP)Georgia Tech took ad vantage of a cold spell by fifth ranked North Carolina State to night and handed the Wolfpack an 8977 basketball defeat.

title: Project in Bowery Is Approved Following 10Year Controversy
description: After more than 10 years of planning, changes and heated controversy, the Board of Esti mate yesterday unanimously voted final approval of the Cooper Square Development Plan to revitalize six large par cels near the Bowery south of Cooper Square.

title: MISSISSIPPI OFFICIAL OFFERS SCHOOL PLAN
description: JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 13 (AP)Lieut. Gov. Charles Sul livan proposed today legislation to provide that all public schools in Mississippi be oper ated under a unitary school system but to allow a freedom ofchoice system of attendance.

title: MRS. MAXWELL KARSHAN
description: Mrs. Edna Wolf Karshan, wife of Dr. Maxwell Karshan, profes sor emeritus of biochemistry of Columbia University, died yes terday at the Columbia Presby terian Medical Center. She was 68 years old and lived at 420 Riverside Drive.

title: Pacification, Amid Gains, Is Said to Face Hard Road
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The longterm success of the pacification program may be in doubt, the latest reports from South Vietnam indicate, be cause of an inability to destroy the underground Vietcong shadow government and of resurgence of terrorism against village officials.

title: THRONGS IN CAIRO ACCLAIM NASSER; CRY FOR REVENGE
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13  Hundreds of thousands of Egyptians cheered President Gamal Abdel Nasser wildly in the streets of Cairo today and cried for re venge against Israel for the air attack on an industrial plant that killed scores of civilian workers yesterday.

title: L. I. U. Set Back, 5148
description: Northeastern University's fullcourt zone press wiped out Long Island University's 12 point lead as the Huskies went on to edge L. I. U., 5148, last night on the loser's court.

title: JERSEY TENANTS FIGHT RENT RISES
description: FORT LEE, N. J.When one of the two telephones in their apartment here begins to ring, as it does about every three minutes all day and part of the night, Martin Aranow usually says to Sylvia, his wife: I'll take the baby and you answer it.

title: Detroit's Sporty Cars Are Due to Be Sportier
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14  The sleekest steel skins that Detroit plans to produce this fall will cover the long hooded sporty cars. As a bonus for those who have complained that all new cars look alike, the 1971 four seaters will be distinctly dif ferent from one another.

title: California Senate Control Won By a Coalition of Conservatives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 Conservatives of both parties successfully revolted this week against the moderate Republi can leadership of the California State Senate, with effects as yet unmeasured on the gover norship race.

title: CAROL MANN SHARES LEAD IN MIAMI GOLF
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14 (AP) De spite bogeys on the final two holes, Carol Mann shot a 70 today to tie Sandra Haynie at threeunderpar 141 in the sec and round of the $40,000 Bur dine women's golf invitation at Country Club of Miami.

title: Andersen Artist's Medal Is Won by Maurice Sendak
description: Maurice Sendak has won the 1970 Hans Christian Andersen Medal for illustrators.

title: WEST GERMAN SOCCER
description: FIRST DIVISION

title: Life Insurance Up in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (UPI)  California surpassed New York for 1969 in life in surance coverage.

title: Victor Caracappa Weds Paula Gailinas
description: NORTH SCITUATE, Mass., Feb 14Miss Paula Phillip pine Gailinas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul P. Gailinas, was married here today to Victor Leonard Caracappa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor A. Cara cappa of Massapequa Park, L. I. The Rev. William J. Hel mick performed the ceremony at St. Frances Xavier Cabrini Roman Catholic Church.

title: BOWIE DASH WON BY GAELIC DANCER
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 14 (AP) Gaelic Dancer led the field in near record time at Bowie Race Course today to capture the $28,450 Native Dancer Handi capa race named after his famous sire.

title: A Style Revival
description: POLLARDED trees so often seen in Europe can be used in American gardens for interesting effects. Pol larding is the practice of cutting off limbs of a young tree at a height five to 12 feet above the ground. This drastic cut ting back causes adventitious buds to sprout at the stubs. These grow quickly into straight polelike shoots. When these have grown to the size needed, the cycle can be started again by cutting back to within a bud or two of the base. This is usually done annually.

title: Leslie Miller, a '62 Debutante, Married to George Wiltshire
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Feb. 14 The South Con gregational Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Leslie de Benneville Miller to George Lawrence Wiltshire, owner of the Forefathers Inn and presi dent of the C.C.J. Construc tion Corporation here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Howes.

title: Hepburn's Hep but Coco Isn't
description: IF the period of the mu sical theater that began with Rodgers and Ham merstein and Okla homa! and hit its peak with Lerner and Loewe and My Fair Lady has actually run its course  and whatever blood remains in it has been getting thinner and thinner Coco provides it with a rea sonably graceful and approp riate terminal point.

title: From School Days to Sweet Days
description: TWO very pretty, ambitious girls from Hicktown, U.S.A., age 26, come to New York to make it in the theater. Thousands like them slink back home every year, licking the wounds of defeat. These two make it, after trying since 1961. The last three weekssince their rock musical, The Last Sweet Days of Isaac, opened Off Broadwayhave been the first sweet days of Gretchen Cryer (book and lyrics) and Nancy Ford (music), who look as improbable as authors as George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart might have looked in chorus line.

title: Always on Wednesdays: Hookey on Skis
description: A TEACHER who said she welcomed a release from the anxiety of teaching at a tough junior high school in Spanish Harlem... an engineer who wanted to get in train ing for a visit to the Austrian Alps... fireman on vacation ... a movie stunt man who said he was an expert at fall ing ... a willowy Dutch girl...

title: Newark Rutgers Wrestlers Defeat Fairleigh Dickinson
description: TEANECK, N. J., Feb. 14 Pins by Lou Barnett, Charlie Trundale and Bob Blunt led Newark Rutgers to a 3410 wrestling victory over Fairleigh Dickinson today.

title: New York Post Moves
description: The editorial and mechanical departments of The New York Post will be situated beginning tomorrow in the newspaper's new plant at 210 South Street in lower Manhattan, which nnce housed The New York JournalAmerican. The Post moved from 75 West Street.

title: U.S. Marshals Here Sent 30 Riot Guns They Didn't Request
description: The United States Marshal's office here has received 30 shotguns, which it did not re quest, from the Federal mar shals headquarters in Washing ton.

title: PLAN URGED TO AID OPEN ADMISSIONS
description: A Queens College study group made up of student, fac ulty and administration repre sentatives has proposed a series of academic and admin istrative changes to smooth the way for open admissions next fall.

title: U.A.W. Asks Reverse Seniority To Assist Newly Hired Negroes
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14  The United Automobile Workers asked Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz today to help the union achieve a bargaining goalreverse seniority.

title: Death and decay as sources of life
description: Miroslav Krleza (Kirlezha), the formidable Croat who has dominated Yugoslavia's literary landscape for nearly half a century, remains vir tually unknown in the West. His is not the only such case and again reflects at least in part the parochi alism of Western publishers and their public; but the ambiguities of Krleza's themes and politics have no doubt contributed to the neglect of a writer who, ironically, happens to be quintessentially Western  or more precisely Central Europeanin the scope and sources of his work.

title: Amedee Gets Coaching Job
description: MONROE, La., Feb. 14 (AP) Lynn Amedee, a former Ca nadian Football League star and the 1963 Cotton Bowl's outstanding back, was hired today as an assistant football coach by Northeast Louisiana.

title: Lieut. R. G. Reider Weds Alison Jarmak
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 14 Miss Alison Rose Jarmak, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Jarmak, was married here today to Second Lieut. Richard George Reider, U. S. A. F. The Unitarian ceremony was performed at the Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Peter Samsom.

title: Exhibitions
description: ARTHUR TRESS  Photographs, Open Space In the Inner City. Tomorrow through March 31 at the Sierra Club, 250 West 57th Street. Monday through Friday, 9 to 5.

title: Flight Safety Group Asks For Nominees on Heroism
description: The Flight Safety Foundation said yesterday it would begin accepting nominations for its annual Heroism Award for valorous acts, associated, with civilian aircraft operations, that result in the saving of life or avoidance of hazards to people or property.

title: A Big Spender, Rail Buff Buys Old Private Cars
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  When the westbound Sunset Lim ited pulled out of here on a recent evening, the last car was a private one, the Anacapa. Waving good by from the car's platform was its owner, Allen J. Harris of Tucson, a 29yearold bachelor and railroad en thusiast.

title: Opera: FilleduRegiment
description: GIVEN a soprano who can sing the role of Marie and, even more, convince the audience that she is hav ing a good time singing it Donizetti's La Fille du Regi ment can be a lot of fun. And so it was Friday night in Carnegie Hall, when Beverly Sills took over the stage as star of the American Opera Society concert version.

title: 5 TIES MARK CARD IN ENGLISH SOCCER
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) All five English League First Division soccer games that es caped postponement because of bad weather or poor playing conditions ended in ties today.

title: Ski Classes Graduate the Lengths First
description: PERU, Vt., Feb. 14The Southern sol diers the Army inexplicably sent to Camp Hale, Colo., during World War II to be come ski troops called them torture boards, pronounced totcha bodes. One could sympathize.

title: Heinz Brandt, Prisoner of the Year, 1963
description: Modem heroes endure and keep true to their faith. Not to betraythis may be an act of supreme heroism; more he roic, perhaps, than the fabled deeds of warriors and saints and statesmen. Little known men like Heinz Brandt exempli fy the heroism of our be leaguered time. Locked for years in the deepest bowels of hella hell too satanic for Dante or Milton ever to have imagined  Brandt said no again and again to his jailers.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: muttered about who had popu lated Eastern Europe. These publicschool teachers were sexless saints to most of us, and we fully believed they were unencumbered by the usual physical apparatus that slowed everyone else down. We considered these teachers the most wonderful people in the world, and it is surprising to remember the awe in which the Jewish community held them. (How frightened our par ents were when a teacher summoned them to school. To day it is the teacher, ironically, who is frightened of the parents).

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: SURGICAL FABRICS HELD FLAMMABLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Several types of disposable surgical, nursing and utility caps, face masks and infant shirts used in hospitals have been designated as danger ously flammable by the Fed eral Trade Commission.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: ONE of the country's largest producers of housing is making its entry into the New York region this weekend with the opening of a development in the rolling New Jersey coun tryside that will eventually contain 133 homes.

title: Police (Cops?) Have Slanguage of Own
description: Did you collar the skell?

title: Donald J. Burris Marries Miss Taylor
description: Miss JoanMarie Elizabeth Taylor and Donald Joseph Burris were married here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Thomas P. McGloin.

title: LAOS SAYS ATTACKS HAVE BEEN REPULSED
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 14 (AP)The Laotian Government said today that North Vietna mese attacks on the Plaine des Jarres had been repulsed and that it did not believe that the enemy had begun an offensive.

title: MIAMI CONFUSED BY BUSING RULINGS
description: MIAMI,  The cold, wet weather of recent weeks has not helped anything in this imageconscious winter resort except the crimson hibiscus and butteryellow alamanda blooms that adorn the subtropi cal villas in expensive suburbs like Coral Gables and Key Bis cayne.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: Track Is Show Biz

title: BOLIVIA ATTEMPTS TO CURB DRUG USE
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 9  Among the tens of thousands of clowns, dancers, musicians and waterthrowing revelers parading through La Paz for the opening of carnival this week was a group masquerad ing as American hippies.

title: 200 Boats, Walking Catfish on View at L. I. Show
description: How man has unwittingly upset nature's balance is the theme of the live marine ex hibit at the Long Island Marine Recreation Boat Show, which began yesterday and will run through next Sunday at the Island Garden in West Hemp stead.

title: 14 BANKS IN INDIA RENATIONALIZED
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 14The Indian Government renational ized the country's 14 biggest private banks today through an ordinance designed to over come Tuesday's Supreme Court decision voiding the original takeover of last July.

title: EASTLAND ISSUES AMERASIA REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Controversy over a magazine called Amerasia, buried and nearly forgotten since the days of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, has been revived in an effort to cast doubt on the wisdom of the Nixon Administration's attempts at a dialogue with Communist China.

title: Columbia Tops Harvard, 7372, as McMillian Breaks Lions' Scoring Record
description: Columbia Tops Harvard, 7372, as McMillian Breaks Lions' Scoring Record

title: U.C.L.A. TRIUMPHS FOR 24TH IN ROW
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (UPI) Henry Bibby, a sophomore guard, scored 21 points today as topranked University of California, Los Angeles, coasted to a 10185 Pacific Eight vic tory over Washington.

title: Science
description: Although they occur under very different circumstances, three phenomena involving volcanic eruptions, submarine landslides and devastating avalanches are strikingly similar. In all three cases solid material suddenly be gins to act like a fluid tor rent.

title: Nasser, in Interview, Says He Is Seeking Soviet Weapons to Thwart Israeli Raids
description: CAIRO, Feb. 14President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic is press ing the Soviet Union for MIG 23 fighter planes and techno logical aid to intercept the Israeli bombers that have been flying almost at will over this country, but he is hesitating about asking for Soviet pilots to loin the Middle East war.

title: CAHILL SEEKS CURB ON SLUDGE TOWING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14 Gov. William T. Cahill announced to day that he would ask the Army Corps of Enginders to re quire immediately that all sewage sludge from New Jersey sources be carried at least 100 miles out into the Atlantic be fore it is dumped into the sea.

title: Princeton Crushes Yale
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 14 Princeton's cocaptains, Jeff Pe trie and John Hummer, com bined for 48 points tonight to pace the Tigers to a 8168 tri umph over Yale.

title: Sally L. Banks of Peace Corps Is Married to Peter S. Craig
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Feb. 14Miss Sally Love Banks, an official with the Peace Corps in Washington, was married here this afternoon to Peter Stebbins Craig, the general attorney for the Southern Railway Company in Washington.

title: Amex and Counter Stocks Decline Slightly in Moderate Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market eased slightly last week in mod erate trading.

description: AT MILWAUKEE

title: CONTROLLERS POSE SLOWDOWN THREAT
description: CENTEREACH, L. I. Feb. 14 (UPI)The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organiza tion threatened today to stage a slowdown at major air ports across the nation tomorrow after the United. States Trans portation Department failed to agree to met the controllers' deadline for a meting to discuss grievances such as alleged over work and substandard equip ment.

title: Doubell Finds There's No Time To Ponder Strategy in the 600
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 Outside The Forum, on a night when the air seemed un commonly cool and clean, Ralph Doubell carried a fiberglass pole to his car like a javelin thrower looking for a target, Like maybe Martin McGrady.

title: Excerpts From Interview With President Pompidou on French Forign Policy
description: PARIS, Feb. 14Following are excerpts from an inter view with President Pompi dou conducted Tuesday by C. L. Sulzberger, foreignaf fairs columnist of The New York Times. The translation from the French was pre pared by The Times and ap proved by Mr. Pompidou.

title: State Democratic Reform Caucus Endorses Nickerson and O'Dwyer
description: The Democratic State Com mittee's Reform Caucus, a group of committee members dedicated to promoting liberal candidates and causes, en dorsed Nassau County Execu tive Eugene H. Nickerson yesterday for the party's nomi nation for Governor and Paul O'Dwyer for the nomination for United States Senator.

title: Draft Dodger
description: When President Nixon, after a long search, picked Charles Di Bona last month to head the Selective Service System in place of its retiring director, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, it looked like a happy choice. Mr. DiBona, 37, is a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, a former Rhodes scholar and Pentagon Whiz Kid, the head of a re search firm with contracts with the Navy, and a supporter of Mr. Nixon's proposals for a volun teer army to replace the draft.

title: Jersey Coffeehouse Used by War Foes Is Target of Bomb
description: WRIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Feb. 14A bomb that slightly in jured at least three persons exploded shortly before 9 P.M. tonight inside a coffeehouse here that has been a center of antiwar activity involving sol diers at nearby Fort Dix.

title: YOUTHS RALLYING TO DODD OPPONENT
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 14It was 9 P.M. and girls in miniskirts and slacks moved along the corridors with campaign charts and notes. Typewriters clacked and a duplicating machine churned out handbills.

title: Jefferson the President
description: As we enter the decade of the seventies, which will celebrate the bi centennial of the American Revolution, nothing could be more welcome than this pioneer and masterly study of Jefferson the President. In the grand design of Mr. Malone's comprehensive biography Jefferson and His Time, the present volume (the fourth in the series) maintains the magnificent quality of the preceding ones and in one important sense outstrips them by filling an urgent need in American scholarship. For strange as it may seem, there has been no serious study of Jefferson's Presidency since Henry Adams.

title: Anne E. Freyss Will Be Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Anne Elizabeth Freyss to An drew Russell Humes 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Rus sell Humes of Upper Ny ack, N. Y., has been announced by the pros pective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. JeanPaul Freyss of New York.

title: Pompidou, in Interview, Explains Policy
description: PARIS, Feb. 14President Georges Pompidou considers the Mediterranean region to be Eu rope's vulnerable underbelly and is directing France's current foreign policy to an effort to bolster the Continent's south ern flank.

title: Pop
description: THE most exciting jazz site in this city at the present time is none of the traditional hang outs. It is the dismal back room of an almost repellent midtown bar called Danny's Restaurant. There, in Brecht ian gloom and a sinister atmosphere out of some yel lowed flick about bad old transvestite Berlin, the gen ius of the jazz drum, Elvin Jones, is appearing Saturday and Sunday afternoons with his trioJoe Farrell on saxes and flute and Wilbur Little on bass.

title: Art
description: FANGOR, an artist whose preference for being known by his surname alone will be respected here, is having his third one man show at the Galerie Chalette, 9 East 88th Street, and it is something to see. By the most nearly appropriate classification, Fangor is an op artist, although illusionist and environmentalist have been suggested as additional tags. Within recent years his basic patterns have been the circle, with color in concentric rings, and undulating bands. To these he has now added forms like those in the illus tration on this page.

title: A Snowmobile Record Of 114.5 M.P.H. Is Set
description: MALLETS BAY, Vt., Feb. 14 (AP)  Ky Michaelson broke the snowmobile speed record today reaching 114.5 miles an hour in five seconds over a quartermile stretch of Lake Champlain.

title: Coins
description: THE Boston Museum of Fine Arts is celebrating its centennial this year and among the 130 birthday acquistions now being exhibited are many coins of ancient and medieval times. Founded in 1870, the popular cultural center at 465 Huntington Avenue has titled its exhibition Art Treasures of Tomorrow. Along with its art and sculp ture from archaeological dis coveries of the past, the mu seum is displaying art rep resentative of the most mod works.

title: Area Gateway Unions Studied On Minority Group Membership
description: A survey of local unions that refer workers to jobs in the metropolitan area showed 15.8 per cent to be black and 13.5 per cent to be persons with Spanish surnames.

title: A Controversy Over Foils Is Resolved as a New World Restriction Is Accepted
description: THE flap over foils has been resolved. The Sports Car Club of America has accepted, with respect to the Group sportsracing cars that run in the club's CanAm series, the new international rule restricting the use of those rearmounted airfoils that resemble wings. The club's an nouncement speaks of complying with great reluctance, though resentment may be more precise. The rule was imposed last May 23, after an accident in the Spanish Grand Prix, by the Federation Internationale de ('Automobile (F.I.A.). At the start of the CanAm sea son last June, the S.C.C.A. and its counterpart, the Canadian Automobile Sports Clubs, refused to go along with the new rule on the ground that airfoils on Group 7 cars had never posed a safety problem.

title: WARREN BLOSSOM
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14Warren Blossom, who re tired as a manufacturing mana ger of the Bridgeport Brass Company three years ago, died Thursday at the Veterans Ad ministration Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived on Dog wood Lane in New Canaan.

title: SCHENK IS LEADER IN TITLE SKATING
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 14 (AP) Ard Schenk of the Nether lands took third place in the 500meter sprint and the 5,000 meters today and captured a slim lead in the world speed skating championships.

title: Boston Port Chief Opposes City Plan For More Revenue
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14The Mas sachusetts Port Authority, an autonomous agency created by the state legislature, has taken issue with recent legislative proposals by Mayor Kevin H. White of Boston, seeking more, revenue for the city from the authority's activities.

title: Surveyors Using Radar, Lasers, etc.
description: THE ancient art of sur veying, practiced by the Egyptians building their pyramids, is as useful today to the city dweller turned weekend squire when he tries to determine whether his tomato patch is on Farm er Jones's property.

title: CITY OPERA DEBUT FOR 16 IN SPRING
description: Sixteen artists will make their debuts with the New York City Opera in its spring season, which will open Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Andrea Green To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Green have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Andrea Green, to Lawrence Iason 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Girard Iason of Hewlett, L.I., and New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Patricia Jones And W. S. Lear Wed in Suburbs
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 14  The marriage of Mrs. Patricia Merritt Jones to William Schureman Lear took place in St. Mark's Epis copal Church here this after noon. The ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill Jr., the rector, who was assisted by the Rev. Benedict Williams.

title: Law
description: CHICAGOAn incredible trial reached an incredible end yester day. Minutes after the jury left the courtroom to begin its de liberations, Judge Julius J. Hoff man began sentencing the seven defendants and their two lawyers in the fourandahalfmonthlong Chicago conspiracy trial to jail for contempt of court.

title: Music
description: I HAVE been thinking about Harrison Birtwistle's little opera, Punch and Judy, which had its American pre mire last Jan. 30 in Minneapolis. It bothers me. Some of it was very successful and some of it limply col lapsed. Some of it was singable, and a great deal more incomprehensible. Some of Stephen Pruslin's libretto hit the audience like a massive dose of LSD, and some like a shower of cold cabbage soup.

title: Columbia Fencers Handed First Loss by Navy, 1413
description: Navy's fencing team cap tured eight of nine bouts in the second round and went on to upset previously unbeaten Co lumbia, 1413, at the Lions' Uni versity Gym yesterday.

title: MURPHY, TREVINO SHARE LEAD AT 206
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 14 (AP) Bob Murphy and Lee Trevino the winner here last year, tied for first place with 10underpa?? 206's after the third round of the $100,000 Tucson open to day when the halfway leader John Lotz, took a triple bogey 7 on the 18th hole. Murphy and Trevino had rounds of 66, 68, 72 while Lotz was one stroke back with 69, 64, 74.

title: Son to Mrs. E. L. Wolf
description: A son was born last Sun day in Lenox Hill Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel L. Wolf of New York. The child has been named Alexander. Mr. Wolf is president and board chairman of Allied Artists Pictures Corp. The child is the grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Wolf of Brooklyn, and of Mrs. Alex ander Levine of Tamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Mr. Levine.

title: Lawrence of New Zealand Wins Pole for Sydney Race
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 14 (UPI)Eight drivers exceeded the existing lap record of minute 26.9 seconds today dur ing practice for a 100mile auto race at Warwick Farm tomorrow.

title: Spain's Pilots Score General's Handling Of Plane Hijacking
description: MADRID, Feb. 14Spain's airline pilots have accused the authorities of treating a recent attempt to hijack an airliner more like a military operation than an effort to assure passen gers' safety.

title: A. H. Bradford And Mrs. Potter Wed in Weston
description: WESTON, Conn., Feb. 14 Mrs. Penelope Sack Potter of Weston, New York and Ama gansett, L. I., was married here this afternoon to Amory Howe Bradford, a lawyer and consultant on urban and management problems. The Rev. Robert Greene per formed the ceremony in the Norfield Congregational Church.

title: A pretty pickle
description: Slices of fruitstuffed citrus are a delectable and handsome garnish for poultry, game, ham and roast meats. They offer a welcome change of texture, flavor and appearance from the usual fresh or canned fruits. A jar would make a special gift for a friend who appreciates the unusual. Oranges and lemons processed now, while at their best, can be kept to garnish an Easter ham.

title: Scott Announces Candidacy After Party Endorsement
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 14 (AP)  The Senate minority leader, Hugh Scott, announced today he was a candidate for reelection after the state Re publicans unanimously en dorsed him for a third sixyear term.

title: A. E. Merriam And Dena Finn Engaged to Wed
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 14Mr. and Mrs. David Finn have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Dena Finn, to Arnold E. Merriam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Merriam of New Haven.

title: Vast Effect Seen From Dallas Airport
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 14The DallasFort Worth regional airportthe world's largest commercial airport now under constructionwill dominate air traffic in the southwestern United States even though Houston opened a large new airport last year.

title: SOVIET FIGHTERS BEAT U.S. TEAM, 83
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UPI)A powerful Soviet national box ing team soundly defeated an American amateur squad to night for the second time this week. 83.

title: HAWAII IMPLORED TO RETAIN ISLAND
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 14 (AP) Too much of what is really native Hawaiian has already been irretrievably lost, Gov. John A. Burns said this week in proposing that the state pur chase Niihan, Hawaii's seventh largest island, as a natural pre serve.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: FRIDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Bates Appointed by Reuters As Executive News Editor
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) Julian Bates, 47 years old, has been appointed executive editor of Reuters general news division. In this opst, effective March I, he will be deputy to the editor in chief, Brian Horton.

title: Virginia College Dean
description: STAUNTON, Va., Feb. 14 (AP) Dr. Eike Frank, now teaching political science in the Ameri can University's School of In ternational Service, has been appointed dean of Mary Bald win College, the president, Wil liam W. Kelly announced yes terday.

title: BOY WITH TOY GUN KILLED IN ROBBERY
description: A 16year old youth was shot in the head and killed yesterday afternoon after he pointed plastic toy revolver at a Transit Authority patrolman during changebooth holdup in Harlem.

title: Median Age of Americans 27.7 Years, Census Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) The median age of Americans is 27.7 years, down from 29.5 years at the time of the 1960 census, the Census Bureau re ports.

title: FRIDAY NIGHT FIGHTS
description: HAMBURG. GermanyMan uel Ibar Urtain, Spain, knocked out Leslie Borden, Canada; 1 round; heavyweights.

title: Mideast
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of thou sands of Egyptians took to the streets of Cairo last Friday screaming support for President Nasser and demanding retalia tion against Israel. It was the most emotional demonstration this capital has seen since the 1967 war. The cause: an Israeli air raid Thursday on an indus trial plant in a Cairo suburb that killed at least 70 civilian workers and injured many others.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: THINKING of whitebait yesterday afternoon and of how good a plate of them would be, I plunged into the newly published facsimile edition of Isabella Beeton's classic and monumental Book of Household Manage ment (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1,112 pp., illustrated, $12.95) to see what she had to say about them.

title: Coming Attractions
description: MARCH

title: We Lay Waste The World
description: The world is too much with us, wrote William Wordsworth a century and a half ago, late and soon, getting and spending, we lay waste our lives. Today he could well have written: we lay waste the world.

title: Price Decline Near Bottom?
description: When this market finally turns, brokeragehouse partner observed last week, nobody is going to fire a cannon down Wall Street.

title: HOUSTON RUNNERS SET RELAY RECORD
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) With Leonard Hilton anchoring with a 3:59.7 mile, the Univer sity of Houston bettered the world distance medley relay record with a time of 9 min utes 34 seconds tonight in the AstrodomeFederation national indoor track and field cham pionships.

title: LABOR CHIEFS SCORE MOVES ON INFLATION
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP)George Meany and other labor federation leaders blamed President Nixon's antiinflation policies today for the layoffs of thousands of construction work ers and for hurting efforts to hire more Negroes. The construction boys are the whipping boys, said Mr. Meany, president of the Amer ican Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organ izations:

title: TWINS ARE CHOICE IN WESTERN RACE
description: Asmost observers view it, only, an excess of compla cency, or wholesale injuries could divert the Orioles from their charted course to a second straight American League pennant. Baltimore won the Eastern Division title big last season, rolling up 109 victories. It's possible they may even top that out put in 1970. Manager Earl Weaver's team shapes up even stronger this year.

title: French Conservationists Are Fighting Excessive Boar Hunting on Leased Rural Lands
description: STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 14French conservationists are complaining that a system of leasing hunting rights on rural land is leading to untoward killing of wild boar and other wildlife in Alsace.

title: RADIOTODAY'S LEADING EVENTS
description: Talk, Sports, Special Events

title: Foreign Affairs: Upsetting No Applecarts
description: PARIS  The salient fact emerging from a long conversa tion with Georges Pompidou is that France's President has no intention of upsetting anybody's applecart. He is fully aware of the furore caused by the need lessly awkward revelations con cerning French sale of Mirage jets to Libya and it is obvious he is approaching his American visit next week with hopes but also with deliberate caution.

title: Favored Tudor Scott Wins Fair Grounds Handicap
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 (AP) Tudor Scott, the favorite, re sponded to Dave Whited's urging at the top of the stretch and romped to a twolength victory in the $23,950 Pelleteri Handicap today at the Fair Grounds.

title: OldTime Drummer a Vanishing Breed
description: What do you do on the road about your constant de pression and loneliness? You engulf yourself in your work and run up a big telephone bill calling home, says Daniel Kahn, a young New York salesman who travels the 100mile stretch of Long Island.

title: Time Inc. Asks Dismissal Of Libel Suit Over Songmy
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Time Inc. has asked the Fed eral District Court here to dis miss a $110million libel suit filed by Capt. Ernest Medina, of the Army. Time contended it had a right to publish an article about the alleged massacre at Songmy in South Vietnam.

title: Point of View
description: THE crisis in New York City's housing, if left unchecked, will lead to the hopeless decay many neighborhoods, giving them the bombed out, Vietnamlike appearance already observable BrownsvilleEast New York. To reverse this trend will take major effortsan initial $100million an nually in higher rents from rentcontrolled families who can afford the payments; about $200million from the city's capital budget for rehabilitation loan expenditures and, finally, about $100million in city expense budget outlays for rent assistance to fam ilies unable to pay higher rents and for major expan sion of staff and facilities to administer the program.

title: Galapagos: A Return To Life's Earliest Beginnings
description: BALTRA, Galapagos IslandsThis is about as exotic a dateline a tourist can find on today's con tracting globe, a destination more remote in time than in actual distance. The mileage from Manhattan is insignif icant  3,500 miles, the same as the Great Circle Route between Kennedy Airport and Londonbut the step back ward in time is all the way to Septem ber, 1835, when Charles Darwin, the young naturalist aboard H. M. S. Beagle on her world voyage of discovery, first saw the Galapagos Islands.

title: Harlem Census Office Will Open Tomorrow
description: The 1970 census will begin here tomorrow with the open ing of a district office in Harlem at 268 West 125th Street.

title: Paperback Books
description: With a new decade beginning, the Book Review recently asked editors and sales managers in the paperback field to take a long look and offer some predictions for the coming 10 years. Among the hardy souls willing to risk a bet in a risky business were Peter Mayer of Avon Books; Ian Bal lantine of Ballantine; Marc Jaffe, Ban tam; Pyke Johnson Jr., Doubleday; Ralph Daigh, FawcettWorld Library; Nat Sobel, Grove Press; Hugh Van Dusen, Harper & Row; Edward T. Chase, New American Library, and Eugene J. Prakapas, Pocket Books. In spite of one or two generally ac knowledged headaches, their overall view of the 1970's is unanimously en thusiastic. Here, in summary, is their forecast.

title: Great Cohoes Also Scores
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14Arnold Wi nick always has been a two thirds champion among Florida trainers. He has been the leader at Tropical Park six straight years and has finished on top at Gulfstream in nine of the last 10 years. But he never has been the leader at Hialeah.

title: Recordings
description: MAHLER. Even the bare name has an endoftheroad, tra gic sound to us now, and why not? His was the last great and authentic voice of Romanticism in music; aft er him come the Respighis and Rachmaninoffs and Strausses, not to mention the lesser men for whom the Ro mantic idiom has served as a language but in whose mouths it sounds synthetic, like an Irishman speaking Gaelic.

title: POLICE CITE ARSON IN MUNICH DEATHS
description: BONN Feb. 14The police today cited arson as the cause of a fire in Munich last night in which seven elderly persons, all Jewish, died. Two of the victims had survived internment in Nazi concentration camps.

title: Hunter Sinks Kings, 7560
description: Reggie Speights scored 25 points last night to lead Hunter College to a 7560 vic tory over Kings College at the losers' gym.

title: Letters
description: DR. BETTELHEIM AND THE YOUNG

title: Jay Kaine to Wed Margaret Custer
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 14Mr. and Mrs. Mer ton Davis Custer of Old Westbury and Naples, Fla., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Margaret Susan Custer, to Cadet Jay Wallace Kaine, who expects to graduate in June from the United States Military Academy.

title: Challenge To the North on School Segregation
description: WASHINGTONFor the past several years, Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Missis sippi, has been trying, throbgh legislative proposals and per suasion, to have the national Government apply its school de segregation pressures uniformly in all regions of the country. His motive was believed to be the obvious one. He once told me, said a civil rights enforce ment official, that if we moved in the North with the same force as we were apply ing in the South, a lot of North ern members of Congress would join the Southern cause and the pressures everywhere would be eased.

title: DAVIDSON TRIUMPHS AND CLINCHES TITLE
description: DAVIDSON, N. C., Feb. 14 (AP)Davidson's frontline kept Richmond's offense at bay from the start today and the 13th ranked Wildcats, hitting on 56.51 per cent of their shots, routed the Spiders, 9760. The victory clinched the Southern Confer ence basketball title for David son.

title: Criminals At Large
description: One of the most disturbing elements in today's society is the trend toward noninvolve ment. The trend has countless manifestations. None is more ominous than the frequent news reports of instances in which people stand by while violence is perpetrated against a help less fellow human. The literary potential of this circumstance has yet to be fully realized: in mystery fiction, it has played almost no part. Now, however, I recommend to your attention a book that makes notable amends for this omission, IN CIDENT AT 125th STREET (Doubleday, $4.95) by J. E. Brown.

title: BRITON, 78, AND ILL, IS FREED BY PEKING
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 14Com munist China today released William McBain, a 78yearold British subject, who was arrest ed in Shanghai last October. He was wheeled across the border into Hong Kong on a baggage trolley and subsequently admit ted to a hospital where his con dition was described as fair.

title: Ronnie Haran Wed on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 Miss Ronnie Haran, a per sonnel manager in Hollywood sonal manager in Hollywood, was married at her home here today to Chase Mellen 3d, a program executive with the American Broadcasting Company television here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dennis Quby of the First Unitarian Church.

title: Railroad Forms A Waste Unit
description: The Southern Railway has announced the formation of what it calls an Office of Municipal Waste Disposal Activities to coordinate the operating and marketing of a new trashdisposal service that it has developed for use by larger communities along its lines.

title: CARLOS LOSES DASH AT MIDWEST MEET
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 14 (AP)Michigan State's sophomore sprinter, Herb Washington, beat a field includ ing John Carlos in the invita tion 60yard dash today at the Michigan State Relays.

title: Letters
description: Business And Economics Supplement

title: Miss Johnson To Be a Bride
description: Roy L. Johnson, vice presi dent in charge of worldwide management manpower de velopment for the General Electric Company, and Mrs. Johnson of New York and Tuftonboro, N. H., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne L. Johnson, to Robert Welch Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wood Carter of West field, Mass.

title: Vietnam's Korean Solution
description: By withdrawing 65,000 American troops in his first year in office and promising to remove another 50,000 by April 15, President Nixon has defused the Vietnam debate in the United States. Although neither the debate nor the war has ended, the shape of the argu ment has been considerably altered.

title: Reaching a Peak In Puerto Rico
description: MAYAGUEZ, P. R.  Newly widened and improved roads have made a littleknown mountain peak here in west ern Puerto Rico easily ac cessible to tourists and na tives alike. The roads form an easy circle routea virtu al skyline drive  to the summit of 2,900foothigh Las Tetas de Gordo in Mari cao State Forest. From there on a clear day, one has spec tacular views of three sides of the Puerto Rican coast.

title: CHESAPEAKE DEAL WILL BE PATTERN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 The Sports Car Club of Ameri ca, which sanctions three series of professional road races, in tends to negotiate more long term contracts similar to the Chesapeake agreement, E. L. Hall, chairman of the club's professional competition board, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Format for Canada's Expo '70 Panes
description: AN unusual format has been adopted for Can ada's block of four stamps due March 18 to commemorate its partici pation in Expo '70, the inter national fair opening at Osaka, Japan on March 15. These were illustrated here last week, and are repeated in miniature today. The block of four 25cent stamps recog nizes participation not only by the dominion government, but also by the provinces of British Columbia, Quebec and Ontario. These provinces, like the dominion, will have pavi lions at the exposition.

title: C. W. Post Loses, 7461
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Feb. 14 Northeastern University com pleted a successful twoday trip to New York tonight with a 7461 victory over C. W. Post College at Conley Gymnasium.

title: BudapestBangui Ties Set
description: BANGUI, Central African Re public, Feb. 14 (Agence France Presse)  The Central African Republic and Hungary have es tablished diplomatic relations, it was announced here.

title: South Vietnam, to Help Budget, Will Open Center for Gambling
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb, 15The South Vietnamese Government has decided to open an entertain ment center offering legalized gambling and dancing in an effort to close its perennial budget deficit.

title: To Freud, his mind was a primitive city
description: It is a mark of sociology's maturity as well as achieved status among the social sci ences that increasing attention is being given Ito its intellectual roots. Among these roots, none has been more viable than the remarkable work of Max Web er which began threequarters of a century ago in Germany and ended only with his death in 1920.

title: Quest for Gold Medal Begins at 6:30 in the Morn
description: Sometimes the girls get to talking, while waiting for the race to start, and they ask Cheryl Toussaint if she's tak ing a scholarship to Tennes see State, say, or one of the other colleges with women's track teams.

title: QUEENS REGAINS CITY TRACK TITLE
description: Keith Saunders won two events as Queens College re gained the City University in door track title yesterday at the victor's Fitzgerald Gym nasium.

title: To Spare or Not to Spare
description: THERE is an art to cutting trees not the knack of seeing that they do not land on top of the best rhodo dendron, but an art of selectivity.

title: Penn State Defeats Navy By 7971 as Daley Excels
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 14 (AP)Penn State blew an. 11 point lead but strung together 11 consecutive points after Navy forged a 60all tie and beat the middies, 7971, in a basketball game today.

title: Baltimore Feeling News Strike Impact
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 14  A newspaper blackout, now in its seventh week, is making an im pact on Baltimore's economic, social and political activities.

title: Bridal Planned By Joy A Letts
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 14Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Letts have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Joy Ann Letts, to Bruce Andrew Pederson of Scarsdale, son of Mrs. Ar thur Pederson of San Diego, Calif., and the late Mr. Pederson.

title: WORLD SKI JUMP WON BY RUSSIAN
description: STRBSKE PLESO, Czechos lovakia, Feb. 14 (UPI)  Gari Napalkov of the Soviet Union made two nearperfect jumps today to capture the smallhill ski jumping title and give his country the lead in the world Nordic championships.

title: U.S. Increased Its Exports Last Year, but Still Lagged as a Competitor
description: United States exports rose in 1969 more than had been expected earlier in the year. But as a competitor, the country lagged considerably despite a large expansion of world markets.

title: LAKE POLLUTION MINNESOTA ISSUE
description: DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 13 The Reserve Mining Company, the state of Minnesota and the Federal Government prepared this week for another round in a classic pollution case that illustrates the difficulties of cleaning up the nation's waters. the mining company was af fecting the pure water of Lake Superior or whether there was any harm to life in and around the lake.

title: Unrequired Reading: East and West
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.

title: Advantage, TieBreaker
description: UH, is this a 9pointer or a 12pointer?

title: Poets' meeting in the heyday of their youth
description: On a May morning in 1816, Byron and Shelley met for the first time, as Byron stepped ashore from rowing on the Lake of Geneva. Byron was 28, Shelley 23. Byron had eight years to live, Shelley six. The older poet had written and pub lished the first two cantos of Childe Harold's Pilgrimage and a number of exuberant verse talesThe Giaour, The Corsair, Lara. Though these, in conjunction with his social and amatory triumphs and dis asters, had made him famous, they now live only as parts of that great poem, his life. Sim ilarly, Shelley had composed the revolutionary Queen Mob and the Wordsworthian quest poem Alastor, but his lesser notoriety was still founded on his beliefs and actions as athe ist, anarchist and apostle of free love. With Shelley were his mistress, Mary Wollstone craft Godwin and her step sister, Claire Clairmont, once briefly Byron's mistress, and Soon briefly to be the reluctant Byron's mistress again. With Byron was John Polidori, his personal physician, an im probable and volatile wouldbe man of letters.

title: MARAVICH SINKS 38 AS L.S.U. WINS, 9989
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 14 (AP)Pete Maravich of Louisi ana State scored 38 points and Danny Hester and Bill Newton combined for 45 today as the Tigers posted a 9989 victory over Vanderbilt in a regionally televised Southeastern Confer ence basketball game.

title: Yacht Trials to Decide Challenger for the Canada's Cup
description: The Canada's Cup will be defended by the Royal Cana dian Yacht Club of Toronto in 1972 against one of five United States clubs that have filed challenges. The prize is com parable to the America's Cup, in being for international match race competition, but is limited to clubs on the Great Lakes. When restored to competition last September, it was sailed for in small cruising yachts.

title: Lamey's 2Man Sled Takes A.A.U. Crown
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP)Paul Lamey, the leading United States bob sled driver, won the national Amateur Athletic Union two man bobsled championship today on nearby Mount Van Hoevenbere.

title: Playing the angles
description: The old, shingled houses that gave Watch Hill, R. I., its grandly Victorian seaside character inspired Charles Moore, dean of the College of Architecture at Yale, in his design for this large cypress house in Westerly, with its view of Block Island, Fishers Island and Montauk Point. Moore thinks houses that clients can know in a week or two are boring, and so he crammed this one with such playful spa tial variations as bay windows, decks, terraces and porches. Adults and chil dren enjoy separate living zones in the rambling house. And the kitchen is large enough to double as a family room.

title: MRS. SAM HOLLANDER
description: Mrs. Gertrude Felixbrod Hol lander, wife of Sam Hollander, president of Hollander Paper Products, died Thursday at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx. She was 49 years old and lived at 419 Rose Lane, Rockville Centre, L. I.

title: The Name Is S*U*T*H*E*R*L*A*N*D
description: WILL the real Donald Sutherland please speak up? Is he the grunting, dribbling idiot of Die! Die! My Dar ling!? Or the daffy soldier of The Dirty Dozen who, fresh from the stockade, poses as a general and blithe ly conducts a review of the troops? Or the coldblooded murdererformoney of The Split? Or the gently lisping, discreetly dying aristocrat of Joanna?
