Or could he be the triumphantly unmilitary military surgeon of M*A*S*H who nonchalant ly arranges assignations with nurses while amputating legs  a grimly funny heretic who makes a bloody mockery of the Korean War and all other wars?

title: Revolutionaries: European vs. American
description: I REMEMBER a charming column, published not too long ago, in Poland, called Thinking during a shave. In a Communist country, such a headline suggests laziness and pro crastination, a sort of independence. In an industrialized and democratic society, shaving has never attained such significanceit's something to be done in a few hasty gestures, to avoid wasting time. Nevertheless, the morning shave has remained for me the most intellectually prolific part of the day. Musing on revolution while shaving seems to be exceptionally rewarding; after all, a razor is ideal for conveying certain ideas.

title: M'GRADY LOWERS WORLD 600 MARK
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 14 Martin McGrady, who broke his world indoor record for the 600yard run last night in Los Angeles, broke it again tonight. His time was 1 minute 8.5 seconds, twotenths of a second faster than his time at Los An geles and fivetenths of a sec ond faster than the record he set here in 1966.

title: ST. PETER'S ROLLS TO 10365 VICTORY
description: St. Peter's, enjoying a height advantage and with superior shooting, almost ran St. Francis off the 69th Regiment Armory court last night in a 10365 basketball rout.

title: Frederick G. Geissler Weds Anne DuBosque
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Feb, 14Miss Anne Matheson DuBasque and Frederick Greeley Geissler were married here this after noon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carle ton Lee, the rector.

title: Penn Routs Brown For 10th Victory In Ivy League, 9075
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) Penn scored 12 points mid way through the second half to break open a close game against Brown tonight and cap tured its 10th straight Ivy League basketball game, 9075.

title: Molina Leads Wall by Shot With 205 in Venezuela Golf
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Feb. 14 (UPI)Florentine Molina of Argentina shot a twounderpar 70 today to maintain a one stroke lead over Art Wall of the United States after the third round of the 11th Mara caibo open golf championship.

title: All but 3 States Fail to Comply With Clean Meat Deadline Established in 1967
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Fortyseven of the 50 states have failed to meet a deadline set by Congress two years ago in tough legislation intended to assure consumers of clean meat by the end of the 1969.

title: An almost handy guide to the world of paperbacks
description: This is a familiar reference work to anybody who has ever tried to buy one of the 81,000 paperbacks the authoritative guide says are in print. The way it works is quite simple.

title: Concerns And Doubts Over the Nixon Program
description: WASHINGTON  Following President Nixon's message to Congress on environment last Tuesday, Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said: The President's proposals for protecting the environment represent the clearest recogni tion of the problems and the greatest influx of new initiative presented by any President since the administration of Theodore Roosevelt. But they are still not enough.

title: Sheila E. McConville Is Affianced
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 14  Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Mc Conville have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sheila Emma Mc Conville, to Robert Bellarmine Fane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard J. Fane of North Sa lem, N.Y. Fane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard J. Fane of North Sa lem, N.Y.

title: New and Outstanding
description: Nearly 25,000 paperback titles were published during the past 14 months. Here authorities in 10 fields name titles that they consider espe cially commendable and give their reasons why. Selected by Samuel Hynes, North western University.

title: DARTMOUTH WINS CARNIVAL CROWN
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 In a powerful display in which they dominated both of the program's eyents, Dartmouth's skiers breezed to an easy vic tory in their 60th annual Win ter Carnival concluded today in subfreezing temperatures.

title: Commuters On the Couch
description: There is an old gag about man hurrying along the street who, on encountering a friend, says: I can't stop. I'm late for my appointment with my ana lyst, and if I'm not there on time, he starts without me.

title: A Modest Proposal for Weekend Skiing
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. A midweek Jaunt to the snowcovered peaks of the Berkshires (see story left) may soothe the itch of those New York area ski buffs with spare time and hightor skills, but it does little for the beginners and novices who can't afford to lose a day's pay and the family groups who hate being shadowed by schooltruancy officers.

title: Excerpts From Interview With President Gamal Abfiel Nasser of the U. A. R.
description: CAIRO, Feb. 14Following are excerpts front an inter view with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic conducted in English Friday evening by James Reston, a vice presi dent of The New York Times, in the presence of Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, chief edi tor of Al Ahram, at the Presi dent's residence here:

title: California Defense Work
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) California companies got the biggest share of the nation's defense contracts in the last half of 1969, according to the Pentagon. About $3billion in awards, amounting to 19.3 per cent of all prime contracts, were given to California com panies in this period. New York was second with $1.8billion.

title: G.I. Gets HardLabor Term
description: FORT LEWIS, Wash., Feb. 14 (AP)Pvt. Wade Carson of Warner Robins, Ga., was con victed at a courtmartial yes terday of attempting to distrib ute unauthorized literature on this Army base. Private Carson, a Vietnam veteran, was sentenced to five months at hard labor, and his $109 a month pay during that period was ordered forfeited.

title: Rev. Francis E. Lucey, Led Georgetown U. Law Center
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) The Rev. Francis E. Lucey, head of the Georgetown Uni versity Law Center from 1931 to 1961, died yesterday at the Georgetown University Hos pital. He was 78 years old.

title: More Eyes on Football
description: THE last Super Bowl game on Jan. 11 attracted the largest television audience ever to watch a single sports event. According to the rat ings recently released the game was seen on 23,050,000 sets by about 60 million fans. Its share of the TV audience that Sunday afternoon was 69 per cent and the Nielsen rat ing was 39.4. The first Super Bowl game, Jan. 15, 1967, held the pre vious record of 22,500 sets. It was televised by two major networks simultaneously, Co lumbia and National, while Columbia alone had the 1970 game.

title: Averages Listed for Last Year's Reading Comprehension Tests in City's Schools
The Last of the HotShot BigMouths?
description: NOW that he has a television show, mornings on Channel 9, Barry Gray gets a lot of mail from radio listeners who are sur prised to find him so younglooking. It's true that, except for the pouches un der his small, slanted eyes, he doesn't look like someone who's been staying up late talking every night for half his 53 years.

title: Kerr Sees Little Glory in Gloria
description: JULIE BOVASSO has got to stop cheating. She cheats in two ways. One of them has to do with her (somewhat art ful) use of a blaring sound track. She used it in her recent, swiftly departed Moondreamers And she used it again a week ago when she brought her La Mama production of Gloria and Esperanza to the ANTA as part of its invitational series. It closed last night.

title: 1,642 POINT TOTAL CLIPS FORTE MARK
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 Jim McMillian set a Columbia career scoring record of 1,642 points when he made 40 points against Harvard tonight, though the Lions just managed to hold on and beat the Cantabs, 7372.

title: Moliere and Les Femmes Savantes' Farce Is Presented by Comedie Francaise
description: THE quality that above oth ers is irresistible in Moliere is his common sense. More perhaps than any other great playwright's, his feet are always firmly on the ground. He is rational, he is urbane, he is gorgeously sen sible.

title: How to Defend the Dunes
description: OCEANFRONT property owners along the Mid Atlantic coast are keeping a weather eye on the sea. In recent years, seashore erosion has been an increasing source of alarm. Those who own shoreline property and have been think ing about reinforcing their dunes with plantings of beachgrass had better get started. Winter or very early spring is the time to do it. In summer, the dunes are too dry. Plantings made during hot weather usually fail, un less they are watered regu lary.

title: DETROIT ACE GETS 28TH, 29TH GOALS
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 14 (UPI) Gary Unger scored his 28th and 29th goals of the season tonight to pace the Detroit Red Wings to a 52 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Showing Bulldogs a Family Adventure
description: CHARLES A. WESTFIELD Jr. of Huntington, L. I., was convinced that there was nothing like showing dogs as a family activity and said so during the concen trated period of canine com petition that ended with Westminster on Tuesday. He should know. His family three children and a wife all are busy with bull dogs and so is he. The rewards in clude keeping the family as a cohesive group with a common hobby, West field said. We travel together and meet many other people. Last year our team went to 15 cities that we normally would not visit and went to museums and zoos that I, traveling alone on business, might not have time for. We learned a lot.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Dear Reader, Worry No More..
description: DEAR Readerare you tired of stripes, squares, and dots? Have you grown just the tiniest bit bored with all this palaver about the shape of the support? Have all your most earnest efforts to overcome a distaste for fluorescent light tubes come to naught? Do you secretly bear a grudge against works of art that make a noise? Do you still yearn, secretly or otherwise, for painters to  as, the saying goes  return to nature?

title: Albert Weighing Keys to Speakership
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Be cause of a Presidential veto of the health and education ap propriations bill, Representa tive Carl Albert, the majority leader of the House, is facing a series of political decisions that could influence his pros pects of becoming Speaker.

title: Harvard Six 81 Victor
description: HANOVER. N. H., Feb. 19 (AP)Ron Mark scored three goals for Harvard and Jack Turco had two goals and four assists to lead Harvard to an 81 victory over Dartmouth.

title: Olivares to Defend Title
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 (UPI)Ruben Olivares of Mexico will defend his world bantamweight crown here against the Mexican bantam weight champion, Chucho Cas tillo, on April 17.

title: Expressway Construction Lags As Officials Heed Urban Outcry
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14In terstate 95 was designed a dec ade and a half ago as a 1,866, milelong Main Street of the East Coast from Maine to Flor ida. But on a map today it looks like a mortally wounded snake, severed in such places as Boston, Philadelphia, Balti more and Washington.

title: North Korea Releases 39 in Hijacking
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 14 North Korea returned 39 pas sengers from a South Korean airliner hijacked to the North two months ago, but kept eight passengers, the four crew mem bers and the aircraft.

title: The nonstory of Witold from Warsaw
description: Witold Gombrowicz (19041969), the Polish novelist and playwright, was that melancholy phenomenon in literature, the minor writer on to major vision. Gombrowicz conceived of an interhuman sphere, which he also called Form, that repre sented the collective shape he saw mankind assuming. Being united, he wrote, people impose on one another such or such a mode of be ing, talking, acting.... Every person deforms other persons while being simultaneously deformed by them.

title: B. S. Sultans Have Child
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 14A daughter was born Feb. 3 to Dr. and Mrs. Burton S. Sultan at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. She has been named Marla Beth. Dr. Sultan is an ophthalmologist in Hempstead. Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ringel of Jamaica Es tates, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sultan of Beth page are the child's grand parents.

title: Winter Bonuses in Bella Roma
description: ROMEWhere but in Italy in the off season would a taxi driver get lyrical about his home town? We recently spent two weeks on a winter holiday here and in Florence, and the tone was set when our Roman driver greeted us with, Che bet giorno, the bella Roma.

title: A Bologna School For World Studies Faces a Fund Crisis
description: ROME, Feb. 14The 14year old Johns Hopkins University Center of Advanced Interna tional Studies in Bologna, which has sent a quarter of its gradu ates into Western foreign min istries and international agen cies, may have to close for lack of financial support.

title: MORE WIVES HEAR AIRMEN ARE ALIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (Reuters)A young housewife in an Alabama city hurriedly tore open a flimsy airletter a few weeks ago, getting confir mation for the first time that her husband, an airman shot down in 1965, was a prisoner in North Vietnam.

title: Hilarity and Low Comedy In Austria's Bauemtheater
description: HIRSCHEGG, Austria  Mrs. Lisbeth Gwiasda, whose everyday chores include running a vacation home for 40 youngsters and tending to her own two children, remains a stalwart of the Bauerntheater (Peasants Theater) cast in this Walser Valley village because 1 can be somebody else for two and one half hours.

title: Britain's European Doubts
description: Britain's entry into the Common Market could double the price of bread and cheese for the British housewife, raise by half again the cost of steak, lift overall food prices as much as 25 per cent and add substantial burdens to the country's balance of pay ments. But these estimatescontained in a new white paperare unlikely now to discourage Britain's third bid for membership in a uniting Europe.

title: Professor at Harvard Finds Morality on Rise for the First Time
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Soc rates was put to death for try ing to teach youth the princi ples of morality.

title: FLORIDA OIL SLICK WASHES TO SHORE
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 14 (UPI)A blanket of tar like crude oil washed in from Tampa Bay today, blackening seawalls, boats and beaches, crippling birds and threaten ing oyster beds.

title: 2 Key Conference Games For Lehigh Five This Week
description: Two important Middle Atlan tic Conference basketball games are in the Lehigh Uni versity's team's program this week.

title: Tourism Plan Approved
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 14 (AP) The Travel Advisory Board of the United States Depart ment of Commerce, holding its bimonthly meeting in Cleve land, has approved joint Gov ernmentindustry programs de signed to increase earnings from foreign tourism to the United States by $400million this year.

title: SQUIRES DUO GAINS IN PLATFORM TENNIS
description: RYE., N.Y., Feb. 14Dick Squires and Tom Holmes of the Manursing Island Club here led the way into the semifinals of the fifth annual Rye plat form tennis championship to day. They defeated Ed Prince and Ted Rogers of Chevy Chase, Md., 63, 46, 63 at the Manursing Island Club courts, where the quarterfinals were played through snow and under lights.

title: PROBLEMS FEARED IN RIBICOFF STAND
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 Southern liberals generally agreed with Senator Abraham A. Rihicoff's attack on North ern hypocrisy this week, but some feared that it would add to their problems.

title: Canada and Red China Start 2d Year of Talks on Relations
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 14Canada end Communist China have begun the second year of their talks to establish diplomatic relations with no sign of an end to the deadlock over the paramount issue of Taiwan.

title: Palm Beach Floats NoVacancy Sign
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.The Brazilian Dock here has just been renovated, from concrete pilings to a new dock house, but Alton Poole, the dock master, says the No Vacancy sign is out. The same words come from Chuck Case, dockmaster of West Palm Beach's 146slip municipal marina and from the operators of Palm Beach County's 38 other major marinas.

title: Baseball Faces 1970 Season With Many OffField Problems
description: Baseball's 1970 season faces offfield problems that could become dramatic.

title: ST. JOSEPH's WINS TEAM TRACK TITLE
description: Byron Dyce summed it up accurately: These kids today practice so hard; they're in fantastic shape. They work lot more than we did in high school.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nixon Requests $200,000 For Lung Disease Study
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) President Nixon has request ed $200,000 in his budget for a comprehensive study of byssinosis, a little understood lung disease that apparently afflicts thousands of Southern textile workers. The money would be for use in the year beginning July 1.

title: Storm From South Brings Snow to Metropolitan Area
description: A snowstorm from the South swept over the metropolitan area last night. Freezing tem peratures in the city were ex pected to rise into the mid thirties late this morning, changing the snow to rain.

title: The Sampan Jam At Super Market In Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand Bangkok's Floating Market pays a price for its fame: Between 9 and 11 o'clock each morn ing, the Wat Sai Klong (ca nal) becomes almost impass able when the market women, trying to paddle their canoes and barges laden with ba nanas, rice, green mangoes, guavas, peppers and other produce, run headon into flo tillas of determined tourist launches.

title: Aides to Lindsay Back Relaxation Of Curbs on Rent
description: THE Lindsay administration's top housing officials have made it known that they will support a relaxation of rent controls under a plan that would tie rent increases to capital improvements and improved maintenance.

title: Religion
description: ROME  The dispute between conservative and progressive wings of the Roman Catholic church over the question of clerical celibacy escalated last week in a way that made it dif ficult to foresee a solution that would leave both the church and the authority of Pope Paul in tact.

title: Tracy E. Daroff Engaged to Wed Mark D. Rogers
description: Miss Tracy Ellen Daroff, a student at Dade Junior Col lege in Miami, and Mark Dud ley Rogers, a student at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla., plan to by mar ried June 28 at El Morocco here.

title: Small Doses of Strychnine Found in Confiscated LSD
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Feb. 14 (UPI) Small but often dangerous doses of strychnine and other household poisons were added to sizable quan tities of LSD that were con fiscated by police here and in other suburban Detroit commu nities in the last year.

title: Sandra Sloan Affianced To James W. Hunted Jr.
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Sloan have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sandra Eleanor Sloan, to James W. Husted Jr., a financial consultant in Washington.

title: O'Keeffe and Mumford Win '70 Arts Awards
description: Georgia O'Keeffe, the painter, and Lewis Mumford, the writer, will receive the Gold Medal Awards of the National Institute of Arts and Letters for 1970.

title: European Notebook
description: What is the outlook for European literature in 1970? The Milan daily Corriere della Sera addressed this question to critics and editors of leading periodicals in various countries and got the following replies. Most of them limited them selves to listing important forthcoming books.

title: CANADA IS PLANNING TO CUT TV FROM U.S.
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 14  The Canadian Radio Television Commission served notice this week that broadcasters must give viewers more and better Canadian programs and rely less on productions from the United States.

title: Monsanto Growing
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (UPI)  The Monsanto group has an nounced a multimillion pound program to expand its Blue C nylon plant at Dun donald in Scotland in readi ness for the introduction of new, highly advanced nylon products during the nineteen seventies. The expansion pro gram, which is scheduled for completion by the spring of 1971, will increase the ca pacity of the plant from its present annual rate of 30 million pounds weight to about 40 million pounds weight a year. The Dun donald expansion program is a further stage in the growth of Monsanto's textile inter ests in Europe.

title: FITZ GIBBON TRIMS ROSS, 62, 61, 62
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 14 Herb Fitz Gibbon and Pete Fishbach, the top  seeded players, scored onesided vic tories today and reached the final of the Eastern men's in door tennis championship.

title: Army Spurts in 2d Half To Beat Rochester, 7546
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 14 Army hit on only nine of shots in the first half, but pulled away early in the second to register a 7546 victory over Rochester tonight, its 16th, against five defeats.

title: Wagner Routs Lycoming
description: A 47point performance by Ray Hodge led Wagner College to a 10585 victory over Ly coming last night on the vic tor's Staten Island court in Sutter Gymnasium.

title: COUNCILMEN PUSH METHADONE PLAN
description: More than five months after passage of a law requiring the city to combat drug abuse with a program using methadone, the Lindsay administration has yet to produce a plan for ac tion.

title: Bridge
description: SOME Biblical maxims can help a fully be translated into bridge terms. A living dog is better than a dead lion, for example, becomes A doomed king is better than a dead one. Consider this simple situation in the heart suit when playing in a spade contract:

title: Lesli Ross Affianced
description: Miss Lesli Milch Ross plans to be married in May to Ran dall M. Rosenthal. He is a graduate of Carnegie Mellon University where she is a stu dent. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Ross, parents of the future bride, whose fi anc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Rosenthal of Hewlett Harbor, L. I.

title: Half Over
description: By midFebruary winter is half over, even in cal endar terms. And the better half is ahead. The year now moves toward spring, out of winter instead of into it. Each day is a little longer now, sunset a few minutes later. The twilight glow of dusk persists till almost six o'clock.

title: Jacksonville Soaring With Dynamic Duo
description: Holy jump shots, Gotham CityBatman and Robin have turned up in Florida.

title: Tell Is 4th on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 14 Snow Sporting, Clement L. Hirsch's Argentine import, won the $129,500 Charles H. Strub Stakes today at Santa Anita Park as Tell, the oddson favor ite, finished fourth.

title: >Vietnam: This Visit The Topic Is: How to Get Out?
description: SAIGONThe factfinding visits of American Defense Sec retaries to Vietnam have taken on such a ritualistic sameness over the years that one tends to be indistinguishable from another.

title: KNICKS BEAT 76ERS AT GARDEN, 116114
description: Almost as Coach Red Holz man of the New York Knicker bockers had predicted the night before, his National Basketball Assocation Eastern leaders had a prime battle before finally subduing the Philadelphia 76ers last night before a capacity crowd of 19,500 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mrs. Gabay Has Child
description: A daughter was born Jan. 28 at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Gabay of New York and Cheshire, Mass. Mrs. Gabay is the for mer Miss Vicky Geula.

title: Anniversaries
description: GRAYSONMr. and Mrs. Cyrus Grayson. Congratulations and best wishes to our parents on the celebration of their 25th wedding anniversary. February Sth, 1910. Roger, Maryboth and Eric.

title: New York
description: For nearly a year city housing inspectors had known about a gas leak in the chimney of a two family house in Brooklyn. Last week, four children and their 31 yearold mother were found in the house, dead of carbon monoxide poisoning.

title: Observer: The Man Behind the Poll
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The man behind President Nixon's triumph in the Gallup Poll is the littleknown B. D. Zeitel mann, White House Special Assistant in charge of Dullness. This week Zeitelmann called up and asked to be interviewed.

title: Dinner to Aid Urban League
description: Representative Shirley Chis holm, Democrat of Brooklyn, and Rawson. Wood, vice presi dent of the New York Urban Coalition, will be cochairmen of the fifth annual Frederick Douglass Awards Dinner on May 7. Proceeds of the $100 a plate dinner will be used for the New York Urban League's capital building fund The din ner will be held in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel at 7 P.M. Tickets may be purchased in advance from the Urban League, 204 West 136th Street.

title: Miss McLean, Gibbs Alumna, Becomes Bride
description: CENTERVILLE, Del., Feb. 14Miss Katherine Mather McLean was married here this afternoon to William Lawson Chamberlin Jr. in the Lower Brandywine Presby terian Church by the Rev. Robert Scott.

title: In Europe, Carry a Profile Of Drivers As Well As Maps
description: LONDONWhen the Italians at last brought out a Highway Code a few years ago, I pointed out to Tom Wisdom, the British road racing driver who won a 1,000mile sportscar race in Italy, a paragraph that said: Motor vehicles will give way to trains at level crossing.

title: Job Changes:
description: H. Edgar Lore, executive vice president, has been named to the additional as signment of chief operating officer of the Dravo Corpora thin. He will be responsible for all divisions and subsid iaries of the diversified en gineering, construction and manufacturing concern.

title: Syracuse Five Is Beaten But Doe'n't Lack Punch
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va. Feb. 14 (UPI)West Vir ginia downed Syracuse, 94 84, tonight in a game that was called with 61 seconds remaining after Syracuse's center, Bill Smith, threw a punch at Referee Herb, Young.

title: Neilson Out, Rangers Play Today
description: After Friday night's star tling upset by the Oakland Seals, during which the Ran gers' allstar defenseman, Jim Neilson, suffered an injury to his knee, the New Yorkers will costar with the Montreal Canadiens today in the Na tional Hockey League's TV game of the week.

title: Soviet Releases 2 Italians Sentenced in Store Protest
description: VIENNA, Feb. 14 (AP)Two young Italians who were sen tenced Wednesday to one year in a Soviet labor camp were freed today and expelled from the Soviet Union. They arrived in Vienna and boarded a plane for Rome. We think we have made it sufficiently clear what we wanted to achieve, said Valen tino Tacchi, 23, one of the two students sentenced for a protest in Moscow. The other student, Teresa Marinuzzi, 22, did not comment.

title: Education
description: For 75 years the Blaine Amendment of the New York State Constitution has banned the use of tax funds to support churchgoverned institutions. Last week the state Senate voted 41 to 15, to repeal the amend ment and replace it with the language of the First Amendment of the Federal Constitution which says Congress shall make no law respecting an establistimeit of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.

title: 14 Are Arrested in Protest At Struck Coast Paper
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Feb. 14 (Reuters) Fourteen persons were arrested and six hurt to day when about 600 members of the International Typograph ical Union marched in protest outside a strikehit newspaper here.

title: Pregnancies Follow Birth Pill Publicity
description: Doctors across the country say they are beginning to see the first round of unwanted pregnancies among women who stopped using birth control pills after adverse publicity in the last few months.

title: Shenandoah Card Canceled
description: CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Feb. 14 (AP)The racing pro gram at Shenandoah Downs tonight was called off because of snow, track officials said.

title: U.N. Women Elect
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 14Mrs. Pietr Maddens, wife of the Counselcr of the Bel gian Mission, has been elected president of the United Nations Delegates' Womens Club. The group has 200 members from 180 countries and was estab lished in 7963 to assist new comers to the UN community.

title: Something to Sell
description: LATE in the reign of Joe Louis as heavy weight champion, the boxing estab lishment was tossed into a state of confusion by the death of the knowledge able Mike Jacobs, a master at the art of arranging matches that made big money. His duties were suddenly thrust into the unwilling hands of his lawyer, Sol Strauss, and poor Sol was totally out of his element.

title: Turner Takes His 2d Race, Ties for 5.5Meter Cup Lead
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 14 (UPI)Nemesis, sailed by Ted Turner of the United States, gained a tie in the Scandinavian Gold Cup series for 5.5meter yachts today by winning the fifth race off Palm Beach, about 25 miles north of Sydney.

title: School Marm Is Boat Mechanic and Aviator, Too
description: When the Marine Recreation Boat Show opened its annual eightday run yesterday at the Island Garden in West Hemp stead, L. I., Eleanor Witchel knew what to wear because she was manning the Acme Marine booth.

title: COALITION OF 1968 PONDERS ITS ROLE
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14The in surgents of 1968 have returned to Chicago, still looking for ways to make their voices heard in national politics.

title: 100 Poets Tell Of Sorrow, Fear, Anger, Death
description: LISTENING to the three album Spoken Arts Treasury of Modern American Poets, in which 100 poets read from their own works, a mental quirk made me recall the Duke in Twelfth Night who asks to hear That strain again! The request may not be inspired by the pleasure he takes in the music played but by the difficulty of im mediately sensing its full im port. Very few of the poems in this miscellany may be fully enjoyed on first hearing.

title: Miss Seigel Is Wed To Barry Shanoff
description: The marriage of Miss Carolyn Seigel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kalman Seigel of Brooklyn, to Barry Sha noff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Shanoff of River Forest, Ill., took place last night in the Kings Highway Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Norman Seigel performed the ceremony.

title: Nixon Is Pressing His Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The White House is stepping up its campaign to push President Nixon's radical revision of Federal welfare laws, or some thing like it, through Congress this year.

title: Firehouse for Sale
description: ST. MATTHEWS, Ky., Feb. 14 (AP)The Louisville sub urb is trying to sell its fire station. There are no takers. John Monohan, chief of the volunteer fire department, said, we'll turn it over to a real estate agent when we find out the completion date of our new building. We've had several calls, but no buyers yet.

title: TOURNEY FISHING WILL START TODAY
description: Atlantic City's fishing tour nament season is under way for 1970 with the mailing of 1,000 letters to past contest ants announcing the start today of the Fishing Sweepstakes contest.

title: 2 Arabs Killed in Gaza
description: GAZA, Feb. 14 (Reuters) Two Arabs were killed and two children hurt when Israeli troops opened fire on a guer rilla suepect in a street in this. Israelioccupied city on the northern edge of the Negev today.

title: Wisconsin Triumphs, 8474
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 14 (UPI)Wisconsin moved ahead in a close game midway in the second half today and defeated Michigan, 8474.

title: No, But I've Read the Book
description: Motion pictures create a second life for paperbacks. People suddenly become aware of the titleIf they made a movie, it must have been a book. They see the film and don't understand it; or they do understand it and hope it will help them figure out the book. They might buy the reprint to discover what the movie left out; or, if they haven't seen it, to arm themselves with a protective conversation pieceNo, but I read the book. Sometimes people want to read what they have just seen film gives another dimension to a book, an added reality reflecting the multimedia proneness of our age. For whatever reason, movies and books are like popcorn: they go to gether. to arm themselves with a protective conversation pieceNo, but I read the book. Sometimes people want to read what they have just seen film gives another dimension to a book, an added reality reflecting the multimedia proneness of our age. For whatever reason, movies and books are like popcorn: they go to gether.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 126 book stores in 64 communities of the United States. The figures in the right hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Dartmouth Tops Cornell
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 Joe Cook, a junior guard, con verted four foul attempts in the final minute of play to lift Dartmouth to a 7269 Ivy League basketball victory over Cornell tonight in Alumni Gym.

title: Nixon Named Reds' Aide
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 14 (AP) Russ Nixon, a former Ameri can League receiver, joined the Cincinnati Reds organiza tion today as a minor league catching instructor. In June, he will manage the Reds' Sioux Falls farm team in the North ern League.

title: Scented Geraniums
description: ONE of the fondest mem ories of my childhood summers is the faint odor of peppermint from scented geraniums growing in the corner of a screenedin porch.

title: Sato Foresees Major Role for Japan in 1970's
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14  Premier Eisaku Sato said here today that the nineteenseventies would be an era where Japan's national power will carry un precedented weight in world affairs and called on his countrymen to build such nation as will have the whole world agreeing that the human race is richer for Japan's ex istence.

title: Purebreds From U.S. Help South Vietnamese Pigs
description: THOITHUAN, South Viet nam, Feb. 10  This is a tale of two pigsa Vietnamese pig and an American pig.

title: Photography
description: THE VALUE of antique miscellany in the field of photographics has been raised appreciably as a result of the recent ParkeBernet auction of the Sidney Strober collection (and others'). Held at the PB84 division of the galleries at 171 East 84th Street, the sale fetched a total of $61,870 for 570 lots of pictures, books, equipment and acces sory items.

title: Stamps
description: THE American Museum of Natural History will be host at first day ceremonies here on May 6 when a block of four socalled jumbo commem orative stampsa Natural History Serieswill have their firstday sale. The mu seum, at Central Park West and 79th Street, will service official firstday covers for the block of four.

title: ROSEWALL DEFEATS GIMENO IN FIVE SETS
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP)Ken Rosewall escaped two match points in the fourth set and went on to beat Andres Gimeno in the $25,000 Mont gomery Ward Cup tennis final, 36. 62. 35. 76. 63 today.

title: CRAFT OF APOLLO 11 TO TOUR THE STATES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Apollo 11, the first space craft to deliver men to the moon and bring lunar material back to earth, starts a year long tour of state capitals in midApril.

title: A Famous Prosecutor Talks About Crime
Antiques Show for Suburb
description: LITTLE FALLS. N. J., Feb. 14The Little Falls Junior Women's Club will hold its sixth annual antiques show and sale at the United Meth odist Church on Main Street here next Friday and Satur day. The show, which ex pects to draw dealers from New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey. will run from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Friday. and from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Saturday.

title: Card of Thanks
description: BESDINEThe family of the late Dr. Mat thew Besdine wishes to thank all of his friends, colleagues, and family for their warm letters, beautiful flowers and kind condolences expressed upon his passing. All dental journals please copy.

title: 8 G.I.'s Reported Dead in a Clash Near Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 15 (AP)North Vietnamese troops ambushed an American armored patrol near the Cambodian border yesterday, killing eight soldiers and destroying two tanks, the United States command said today. Thirty Americans were reported to have been wounded.

title: ROGERS, IN KENYA, MEETS KENYATTA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 14 (UPISecretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers met with Presi dent Jomo Kenyatta of Kenya today and gave him a letter from President Nixon on Wash ingtonNairobi relations that praised Mr. Kenyatta's leader ship and the direction of his country's foreign policy.

title: Ohio University Downs Miami On LastMinute Rally, 5857
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Feb. 14 (AP) Greg McDivitt scored on driving layup with 15 seconds left to play today giving Ohio University a 5857 victory over Miami of Ohio.

title: Unbeaten Dartmouth Tops Harvard in Swim, 72 to 41
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 14 A battle between two previous ly undefeated Ivy League swim ming contenders saw Dart mouth defeat Harvard, 7241, before a capacity crowd of 1.500.

title: Group Is Organized to Teach Handicapped Children to Ride
description: AS headmaster of the Graf ton School of Berryville, Va., an institution that spe cializes in teaching young sters with learning disabili ties, Howard D. Haynes is aware of the value of ther apeutic measures.

title: Bulls Top Lakers, 116113
description: Rick Roberson, the Los Angeles center, inadvertently tipped in a rebound in the final 15 sec onds tonight and Bobby Weiss added two free throws to give the Chicago Bulls a 116113 victory over the Lakers in a National Basketball Association game.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1GEORGEEN COMERFORD

title: Son Of Help!
description: THE Beatles are back, or soon will be. Although the lyrical lads from Liverpool were seen briefly in Yellow Subma rine, they have not appeared together in a nonanimated feature since Help! in 1965. Now comes the news that we will soon be treated to two new Beatles flicks, Let It Be and The Long and Winding Road.

title: Syracuse Hands St. John's Third Swim Loss in Row
description: St. John's swimming team suffered the worst defeat in its sevenyear history yesterday, as Syracuse trounced the Red men, 7438, at the Alumni Hall pool in Jamaica. The loss was the third in a row for the Redmen.

title: 200 Wed in City Chapel On St. Valentine's Day
description: New York City's Marriage License Bureau marked St. Valentine's Day by perform ing 100 marriages yesterday in its chapel in the Munici pal Building.

title: Susan E. Walsh Wed to Officer
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 14Miss Susan Elizabeth Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Leo Walsh, was married in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here today to Lieut. Loren R. Miller 3d, who is a communications officer with the 2d Marine Air Wing at Cherry Point, N.C.

title: Canisius Edges Manhattan In Closing Seconds, 5654
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 14Clyde Alexander's tip in with one sec ond remaining gave Canisius College a 5654 victory tonight over Manhattan College before 4,045 fans at the Buffalo Me morial Auditorium.

title: Maria Ewing Huffman Plans Wedding to Douglas E. Jones
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 14  Mrs. Grace Ewing Huffman has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Maria Ewing Huffman, to Douglas Evans Jones, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jones of Geneva. Ill.

title: Williams Names Dean
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 14 (AP)Prof. Neil Grabois has been named dean of Williams College. Professor Grabois, whose appointment is effective July 1, succeeds John Hyde, who plans to return to teach ing. Professor Grabois, 34 years old, is an associate pro fessor of mathematics at the college.

title: Edwin T. McKeithen, Executive Of American Can Co., 57 Dead
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 14Edwin Thornwell Mc Keithen Jr., director of the cor porate adminstrative facilities of the American Can Company, died of a heart attack outside his office in New York Thurs day evening. He was 57 years old and lived at 401 Sound Beach Avenue.

title: Miss Mariana Griswold And Lewis Geer Engaged
description: The engagement of Miss Mariana Van Rensselaer Gris wold to Lewis Frazer Geer has been announced by her par ents, Mr. and Mrs. George Griswold Jr. of New York and Litchfield, Conn. Mr. Geer is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis G. Geer of New York and Rumson, N. J. The wedding will take place in June in Litchfield.

title: Sheila McCarthy Fiancee of T. A. Saint Jr.
description: YONKERS, Feb. 14The engagement of Miss Sheila Ann McCarthy to Thomas A. Saint Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William T. McCarthy of Yon kers and Phoenicia, N. Y. Mr. Saint is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Saint of Wellesley, Mass.

title: ST. BONAVENTURE WINS 17TH, 6852
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Feb. 14 (UPI) Bob Lanier scored 10 straight points early in the second half today and sparked St. Bonaven cure to a 6852 triumph over providence in basketball. It was the 17th vitcory for the Sonnies, who have last once.

title: No Life in Antonioni's Death Valley
description: I HAVE a great feeling for things, Michelangelo Antonioni is reported to have once said, perhaps more than for people, although the latter interest me more.

title: Symptoms of Asthma Linked in Study of Parasites
description: A Canadian physician has re ported findings that suggest wider correlation than was pre viously suspected between symptoms of bronchial asthma and the presence of intestinal parasites.

title: Son for John P. Lesches
description: CALAIS, Vt., Feb. 14A son was born on Jan. 14 in Brightlook Hospital, St. Johnsbury, to Mr. and Mrs. John Paterson Lesch, for merly of Greenwich, Conn. Mrs. Lesch, the former Miss Jane Anne Ward, is the daughter of Woodrow Wilson Ward of Omak, Wash., and the late Mrs. Ward. The child, named Shawn Ward, is the grandson of Samuel C. Lesch of Greenwich.

title: TB TESTING READY FOR CAPITOL HILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 More than 17,500 Federal em ployes who work on or near Capitol Hill will begin taking tuberculosis tests Monday, fol lowing the recent deaths of two Senate restaurant workers from the disease.

title: Millican of U.S. Is Leader In Sunfish Class Regatta
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 14 (AP)Chuck Millican, a youthful favorite from Plym outh, Mass., held his lead today in the first Sailfish class world championship, but b faced a strong challenge from Jorge Bruder of Brazil and Gary Hoyt of Puerto Rico.

title: Shows and Activities
description: MORE than 300 camellia plants, growing un der glass at Plant ing Fields Arboretum, Oyster Bay, are expected to reach full bloom at the end of this week. Open house is held during the week from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Starting Saturday and continuing for the next three weekends, the green houses will also be open from 1 to 4 P.M. on both Saturday and Sunday.

title: Personality:
description: When Wall Street heard recently that Prime F. Os born 3d, the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad's vice presi dent for law, was going to become president, the first characterization that leaped to many securities analysts' minds was front man.

title: War Was Hell Then, Too
description: IMAGES of destruction have become such a nor mal part of our lives almost, in fact, a com moditythat it is difficult to think of a time when such images were unique and ex emplary, intended to convey some moral message or, at least, to indicate a horrible rupture in the routine of life. Not that scenes of violence city streets in flames, bloody riots, looted stores, the antic debris of the latest airplane disasterhave entirely lost their emotional impact when we now see them daily on the television screen. But we tend to fall back upon a com forting businessasusual psy chology while the momentary and vivid images are being washed away by cheery com mercials advertising allpur pose detergents and economy Florida.

title: Nancy Ann Dragonette, Student, Fiancee of Ens. David Michaels
description: CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, Feb. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Dragonette, formerly of Stam ford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Nancy Ann Dragon ette, to Ens. David Hughson Michaels, U.S.N.R. He is the son of David D. Michaels, publisher of The New Yorker magazine, and Mrs. Michaels of Greenwich, Conn. The fu ture bride's father is execu tive vice president and general manager of the FabriForm Company, producer of fabri cated plastics products, in Byesville.

title: Pupil Reading Ability Drops Here
description: The reading ability of public school pupils in the city fell back two months during the 196869 school year, apparently as a result of the two months of teachers' strikes in the fall of 1968.

title: NIXON WIDENS BAN ON GERM WARFARE TO INCLUDE TOXINS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 14President Nixon today ex tended his ban on the produc tion and use of biological weap ons to cover military toxins poisons that are biologically produced but are used as chem ical warfare agents.

title: Business Index Rose in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activ ity rose to 359.8 last week from.357.9 a week earlier. A year ago it was 345.3.

title: Machine Tested to Detect Lead In Wall Paint Poisoning Infants
description: A new detecting device was placed against the wall of an Upper West Side apartment yes terday and traced within a minute the presence of 36 per cent lead within a single layer of paintenough to seriously affect an infant who might un knowingly eat it.

title: SOVIET INTRODUCES ITS SPY IN IZVESTIA
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19George Blake, the convicted Soviet spy who escaped from a British prison in 1966, was presented to the Soviet public today in an article in Izvestia, the Govern ment newspaper.

title: Are Concert Halls Bad for Music?
description: ON Feb. 24, National Educational Television is releasing an hour long program called The WellTempered Listen er, conceived and de veloped by Glenn Gould. (New Yorkers can see it on Feb. 25 on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.) The program is partly a discussion between Gould and Curtis Davis, NET's di rector of cultural affairs pro graming, of Bach's The Well Tempered Clavier, partly a performance by Gould of ex cerpts from that work.

title: Nassau Seeking Drunken Driving Study
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 14  Nassau County expects to be a major study area for the De partment of Transportation's National Highway Safety Bu reau in its investigation of drunken driving.

title: Dr. Edward White, Headed Hudson County Dental Unit
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 14Dr. Edward R. White, director of dental services in Hudson county, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Trenton. He was 68 years old and lived at 33 Duncan Avenue.

title: Brydges Calls for State Unit to Raise Money for HomeBuilding
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14The crea tion of a State Mortgage Au thority to free more than half a billion dollars annually for New York's withering home building industry was proposed today by Senate Majority Lead er Earl W. Brydges.

title: Marion Coffin Bells Planning Marriage to Peter A. Schade
description: ROCK HILL, S. C., Feb. 14 Miss Marion Coffin Eells and Peter Arthur Schade plan to be married on June 13 in the Presbyterian Church on the Green in Bloomfield, N. J.

title: Kentucky Wallops Florida
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 14 (AP)  Kentucky overpowered Florida midway through the first half and went on to a 11066 Southeastern Confer ence victory tonight.

title: An Indian Expatriate Rediscovers India
description: NEW DELHI.

title: Alarm at The U.N.
description: Coming on top of the gradual rise in the level of fighting in the Middle East, the El Khanka bombing incident last week in tensified alarm at the United Nations. The fear was that both ides might be drifting into another fullscale war.

title: Bruins Win and Tie for Lead
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (AP) Bobby Orr tied his own goal scoring record and Boston moved into a tie with the idle New York Rangers for first place in the East Division of the National Hockey League as the Bruins defeated the Pitts burgh Penguins, 30, tonight be fore 12,202, the season's largest crowd here.

title: Brown Six Beats Penn, 60, As McGinnis Has 22 Saves
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 14 Rich McLaughlin and Connie Schmidt scored one goal and two assists apiece in leading crown University to a 60 vic tory over Penn in any Ivy League hockey game tonight. Don McGinnis had 22 saves to register his first shut out of the season.

title: Television
description: WHEN Richard S. Sal ant was named president of CBS News in 1966, sue ceeding Fred W. Friendly, there were some raised eye brows inside and outside of the network about putting a lawyer, a man charged with defending corporate legal in terests, in such a key posi tion in journalism. If a tick lish. story came up, it was suggested, might he not worry first about the Gov ernment barking at the net work rather than going ahead with the news?

title: Diana Armour Cochrane Is a Bride
description: Miss Diana Armour Coch rane, daughter of Mrs. Charles W. Thayer of Philadelphia and Ruhpulding, West Ger many, was married here yes terday afternoon to Frederick Henry, Prince 4th, son of Mrs. Peirce Prince of New York and the late Mr. Prince of Lausanne, Switzerland. The ceremony was performed at St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. John B. Coburn.

title: Deformed Boy Paid $28,000 In London Thalidomide Case
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters) A 9yearold boy born with stunted arms has become the fourth child in Britain to be paid damages by a company that marketed the sedative drug thalidomide.

title: Article 3  No Title
Dance
Leafs Top Flyers, 4 to 3
description: TORONTO, Feb. 14 (UPI) Brit Selby's goal at 2 minutes 29 seconds of the third period proved decisive tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 43.

title: Young Sociologist Wins Fortune on Men's Eyes
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 (AP)Two people in love spend more time gazing into each other's eyes than two people not in love, says a young Harvard sociologist who won $1,000 for the dis covery.

title: Princeton Swimmers Win
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14 The Princeton swimming team captured II first places today to down Navy, 7934, Bob Sin sheimer, a Princeton junior, won the 50yard freestyle, the 100yard freestyle and the 400 yard medley relay to pace Princeton to its sixth triumph in nine meets.

title: Spotlight:
description: The new procedure that commercial banks must fol low in reporting their earn ings has caused widespread confusionand even bitter ness  among analysts of bank stocks, aggravating a situation that changes were designed to correct.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To Outlaw Starvation

title: Aid to Biafrans Improves
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 14 One month after the defeat of Biafra, there are signs that substantial relief is finally reaching its bardpressed people.

title: Soviet Plans 2 More Atomic Icebreakers
description: After long hesitation the Soviet Union has announced plans for the construction of two more atomic icebreakers to clear sea lanes off the north coast of Siberia. The first is to be completed by 1975.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Headliners
description: Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy Onas sis was hack in the news last week, this time in an episode that might have been called The Gilpatric Letters. It all started when four highly personal letters written by Mrs. Onassis to 64 yearold, thricemarried Roswell L. Gilpatric, who was Deputy Defense Secretary in her late husband's Administration, turned up at a Manhattan autograph dealer's gallery. How the letters got there from Mr. Gilpatric's law office files remained unclear, but when word of them leaked out, the Jackiewatchers as usual hung on every syllable.

title: Seton Hall Wins, 8371
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 14 (AP)Ken House, Mel Knight and Frank Cortes combined for 62 points today as Seton Hall shook off a secondhalf chal lenge and pulled away to an 8371 basketball victory over Boston College.

title: CITY MAKING STUDY OF TRANSIT RECORDS
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that city audi tors were studying the financial records of the Transit Author ity.

title: MOSES ISAACS, 70, DEAN AT YESHIVA
description: Dr. Moses L. Isaacs, profes sor emeritus of chemistry at Yeshiva University and the dean of Yeshiva College for 11 years, died here Thursday, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived at 51 Woodycrest Drive, North port, L. I.

title: U.S. JET AIDS G.O.P. BUT NOT DEMOCRAT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The White House says per haps it was an oversight that a military jet sent to the Carib bean to return two Republican House members for a key vote did not bring back a Democrat, too.

title: You forgot to mention how angry I am, said the black man
description: In the angry shuffle of black in surrection and militancy has our be lief in the social scientist been lost? Moderate and even liberal Ameri cans had come to rely increasingly over the past two decades on the objective methods of quantification and analysis of social science to avoid confronting their basic lack of social consciousness.

title: Bishop Kenneth Evans, 66, Of Ontario Anglican Diocese
description: KINGSTON, Ont., Feb. 14 (Canadian Press) The Right Rev. Kenneth C. Evans, bishop of the Anglican Diocese of Ontario for the last 17 years, died yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: Nixon Library Planned On Plot at Alma Mater
description: WHITTIER, Calif., Feb. 14 (UPI) City officials of this southern California town where Richard M. Nixon was reared have acquired a plot of land and have pledged to build a library on it as a tribute to the President.

title: Rockefeller Drafts a Plan To Treat Youthful Addicts
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  Gover nor Rockefeller today proposed a series of measures to deal with youthful drug addicts, in cluding a $1million plan for inpatient and outpatient treat ment of addicts 16 years old and younger.

title: Quotes
description: DAVID DURK, a sergeant in the New York Police Depart ment, to a group of Harvard students: If you really care about cities, if you really care about individual people, don't loin the Peace Corps or VISTA. Become a policeman.

title: Kiki Cutter, 20, Retires As International Skier
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb., 14 (UPI)Kiki Cutter of Bend, Ore., a member of the United States national ski team, announced her retire ment from international com petition today.

title: 3D AYE. PROPOSAL IS BEING REVIVED
description: Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the City Planning Commis sion, is reviving a rezoning proposal for lower Third Ave nue that led a year ago to public protests from some of his staff that the commission had yielded to powerful real estate speculators,

title: U. of Vermont Post Offered
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 14 (AP)The trustees of the Uni versity of Vermont offered the school's presidency today to Dr. Edward C. Andrews Jr., dean of the university's Divi sion of Health Sciences and Medical School. Dr. Andrews was expected to disclose early next week whether he would accept the position, a uni versity spokesman said.

title: Brookdale Hospital Elects
description: Dr. David M. Spain has been appointed to the newly created post of Director of Medical affairs at Brookdale Hospital Center. Dr. Spain, who has been director of the depart ment of pathology at the Hos pital since 1953, will continue in that position. He is clinical professor of pathology at Co lumbia University and a mem ber of the New York State Board of Medical Examiners.

title: Benvenuti Settles for Immortality
description: TRIESTE, Italy, Feb. 14 (UPI)They swirl around Nino Benvenuti all day and half the night, not sure what they seek but convinced he's got it.

title: London's Albert Hall Getting a FaceLifting for Its Centennial
description: LONDON, Feb. 14The Royal Albert Hall, London's Victorian town hall for any function from a Verdi requiem to the Euro pean karate championships, is undergoing extensive restora tion inside and outside for its centennial next year.

title: Old English Sheepdog Best in Show
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 14The Selection of an Old English sheepdog as best in the show, Mr. and Mrs. Hendrik Van Rensselaer's Fezziwig Artful Dodger, from Basking Ridge, N. J., was the main thing that happened tonight at the 41st dog show of the First Company Governor's Foot Guard Athletic Association.

title: Lowdown from Paris
description: Though Paris couturiers dropped hemlines in their springsummer collections, they did not agree on how far they should go. Some daytime dresses came to just below the knee; others reached midcalf. And coats to cover them ranged from midilength to the ankle. All in all, it's a loose, languid look. To go with the low hems, low heels.

title: Robert W.A. Opel Marries Joanne Drew
description: WILTON, Conn., Feb. 14 The marriage of Miss Joanne Drew to Robert W. A. Opel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Selmar T. Opel of Yonkers, took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Chester Miller of the Wilton Congregational Church performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Drew, parents of the bride.

title: Concert by Film Musicians
description: Musica Elettronica Viva (MEV), the ensemble that made the electronic sound track for the motion picture Zabriskie Point, will make its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday and Saturday.

title: Warrior with the gift of gab
description: If in your childhood you were treated to the simplified versions of Greek history and legend that captivated most of us, you have carried through the years a picture of Alcibi ades (c. 450404 B.C.) as the Judas of Athens. It was an all dark picture. Granted, he scored some military and dip lomatic victoriesbut the em phasis was on his blasphemous behavior, his corruption of youth and his betrayal of his country.

title: Fairleigh Routs Horstra, 7855
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. 14 Fairleigh Dickinson defeated Hofstra, 7855, tonight as Lee Shulman scored 20 points and Ron Branch added 19.

title: Jersey Addicts Are Put at 7,000 With $30 Daily Needed for Habit
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14New Jer sey has perhaps 7,000 narcotics addicts, who may need at least $30 a daywhich could run to nearly $78million a yearto buy heroin, according to the State Law Enforcement Pro gram Assistance Agency.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: AT THE MIDPOINT of the first quarter, the economy is still being chilled by the wintry blasts of unfavor able economic news and some discouraging corporate developments, but the financial markets are withstanding the adversity very well.

title: Rush Order: LeadFree Gas
description: Lead must go.

title: U.S. AGENTS SEIZE HASHISH SHIPMENT
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 14 (UPI)Customs agents seized 600 pounds of hashish worth $1.2million today. The agents said it was the largest haul ever taken in the United States. Three men were arrested.

title: Is everything nothing but itself?; An Antique Drum
description: In the era of persuasion by press release and proof by public relations, warsintellec tual ones as well as shooting onesare sometimes won more by announcement than by dose fighting. Unless someone is able to make an onthespot inspec tion of the scene of battle, vic tory goes to the side firstest with the mostest in the way of selfserving declarations.

title: U.S. INCREASES AID TO MIDEAST REFUGEES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 14The United States has made an extra donation of mil lion dollars for the relief of Arab refugees in the Middle East, it was announced today.

title: Dennis Murray Fiance Of Maureen Fitzgerald
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Fitzgerald of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mau reen Jane Fitzgerald, to Den nis James Murray. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Murray of Evergreen Park, Ill. An August wedding is planned.

title: The cruel dilemma of men forced to play God
description: On Jan. 23, 1968, a convert ed cargo ship with 83 virtually unarmed Americans, hundreds of pounds of secret papers and millions of dollars worth of electronic equipment was at tacked by North Korean gun boats in waters off Wonsan. The seizure of this ship, the U.S.S. Pueblo, without a fight  without Commander Lloyd M. Bucher even attempting to uncover the ship's two machine guns  stirred a maze of ques tions about the ship's mission, the crew's training, the Navy's code of don't give up the ship, the moral versus mili tary ethic, the cruel dilemma of men forced to play God and decide, in seconds, the fate of other men.

title: Movies
description: THEY don't call her Mrs. Cary Grant so much any more. She's mostly Dyan Cannon now, and it's be cause of her outstanding perform ance in Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice. The New York Film Critics honored her recently as the best supporting actress of 1969, and the name Cary Grant wasn't even mentioned. And there she was, at the microphone in Sardi's, giv ing an emotional acceptance speech in which she said things like: I feel ... love. I feel ... gratitude. I dig Mike Frankovich's smells. And afterward, at a phototaking session with the other winners, Dyan wrapped her arms around the neck of Larry Tucker, the bearded, bigasabear coauthor and producer of Bob & Carol, looked him deeply in the eyes, and said: Oh, baby, I feel so out now.

title: Industry Backs G.M. on Unleaded Gas
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14The Ford Motor Company and the Chry sler Corporation are expected to follow the lead of the Gen eral Motors Corporation in modifying future car engines to run on lower octane, nonlead ed gasoline.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS FORDHAM BY 8053
description: A Valentine's Day Saturday night date crowd of 5,161 turned up at St. John's last night to see the Redmen defeat Fordham, 8053, and to watch Billy Paultz do all the things he loves to do.

title: PRINCETON IS VICTOR IN POLAR BEAR MEET

title: The Theater: Shakespeare in Chicago
description: CHICAGO It is amazing how we in America can get along very nicely without a theater. Of course it can be suggested that, unlike Europe, the theater is not an Ameri can tradition, but this is not strictly true. At one time there was plenty of theater in the United States, and ethnically the bulk of our population is only a few gen erations removed from Eu rope, while our language is the language of Shakespeare and O'Neill.

title: Africa

Rogers at Addis Ababa last week, Mr. Yifru noted that Mr. Rogers was the first United States Secretary of State to tour Africa and added I hope you will not be the last. Mr. Rogers smiled and said I think I get your point, Mr. Minister.

title: Art in Italy
description: IN 1313, Bernardo Tolomei of the banking family whose avocation was maintaining murderous feuds with its neighbor bank ers, the Slimbenis (you will notice the dangerous proxim ityalso a way to keep a close eye on each otherof their palaces in Siena) decid ed to remove himself from the giving and taking of death and, selecting a cracked piece of the creta (chalk) country, founded a Benedictine monastery, a short distance from Siena. Monte Oliveto Maggiore is an impressive set of tall, broad red buildings screened, scored and framed by lines of cypresses. The moated en trance, restored, is about the only vestige left of the early abbey; the rest is largely of the 15th century, when the abbey was a Renaissance center of culture.

title: NAPOLES SCORES KNOCKOUT IN 15TH
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 (UPI)The world welterweight champion, Jose Napoles of Mex ico, punching with machine like precision, scored a 15th round knockout tonight over his challenger, Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez, who was dropped three times before the referee halted the bout.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Although total retail sales are showing signs of slipping, the department store segment is giving evidence of consid erable stability. Even inclem ent weather in many parts of the country has not seriously affected dollar volume in the big stores selling the major portion of nondurable goods. In the week ended last Saturday, department store sales rose 12 per cent over the same week in 1969 al though reports from cities like New York, Philadelphia, Washington, Pittsburgh and Chicago indicated that stores were affected by unfavorable weather conditions. Total re tail sales during the week, according to the Department of Commerce, showed a 2 per cent decrease compared to the year before.

title: Superhighway Plan for London Runs Afoul of Cost Accounting
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (Canadian Press)Accountants have put the brakes on a traffic plan ners' dream of encircling the city with concrete loops of superhighways.New cost estimates have reached nearly $3.5billion, about 40 per cent more than was foreseen three years ago. Originally scheduled for completion in the mid1980's, the project now will probably be delayed until the end of the century.

title: A big cat with nine lives
description: The early settlers called America's big, tawny cat the panther or the painter, some times the catamount. Later, in the West, this same cat was called puma or cougar, from Spanish and Indian names, or mountain lion. Once native al most all over this country, this largest of North American cats now can be found only in wilder ness areas of the West and in the Everglades of Florida. Roger Caras has written his book about an Everglades panther.

title: Arms Related Jobs Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)  Employment generated by military expenditures, including military servicemen, declined 3.8 per cent in 1969 to 7.9 mil lion people, the Labor Depart ment says. A Government study, announced Tuesday, shows that military expenditures gave jobs in and out of the services to 5.8 million people in the fiscal year 1965. This rose to 8.2 mil lion in 1968, but dropped to 7.9 million last year, the depart ment said.

title: The News Between Covers
description: Early in December Esquire maga zine, in the last stages of assembling a special section on California, dis patched Gay Talese to report on the environs from which Charles Manson and his coterie of sycophants allegedly embarked to murder actress Sharon Tate. About the same time, editors at New American Library read a syndicated newspaper confessional by one of the accused murderers, Susan Atkins. The editors decided to turn the confessional into a book. The 136page paperback The Kill ing of Sharon Tate ($1) appeared late in January, well in advance of Esquire's March issue.

title: Odyssey Of a Friend
description: The American right is no less com plex than was Whittaker Chambers, whom we find by his second sen tence in this book embarked on a considered discounting of Senator Joe McCarthy's mind and tactics. It was, roughly speaking, their dis agreement over the Senator that first brought Chambers and William Buckley together (imagine a lasting friendship between two liberals be ing founded on disagreement over Drew Pearson).

title: To Reduce Car Pollution
description: Tougher exhaust standards for automobiles, to he applied on 1973 and 1975 cars, were a major part of the antipollu tion program announced last week by President Nixon. Some of the auto industry's antipollution devices are illustrated above. A: PCV valve, or positive crankcase ventilation sys tem, designed to remove unburned gasoline from the crank case. B: CCS, or Controlled Combustion System, involves controls for mixing air and fuel and modifying ignition tim ing. C: EEC or Evaporative Emission Controls, involves a series of pipes between the carburetor and fuel tank and a carbon canister to store fumes. It is on 1970 cars sold in California and will be on all 1971 cars. D: TCS, or transmis sion controlled speed. It retards spark timing to control nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons. E: Reactors, or some form of afterburner to consume exhaust gases. F: Catalyst muffler, a device that will oxidize unburned fumes. The first four systems are estimated to cut 80 per cent of hydro carbon and 66 per cent of carbon monoxide emissions. E and F devices will probably be introduced to comply with the President's 1975 deadline.

title: Dozens in Danbury Questioned For Leads on Robbery of Bank
description: DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 14 More than two dozen persons were questioned today by the local and state police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in efforts to find the men who robbed a bank here of $40,000 yesterday and exploded three diversionary bombs.

title: Winter Hikers on the Increase

On a pleasant summer day, the generally uphill trip through heavy secondgrowth hardwoods, past occasional stone foun dations of longabandoned farmhouses and over ancient stone fences is less than two hours. It took us more than four.

title: How many surprises are hidden here? It's still a question

That dream continues to come true: the Dead Sea Scrolls and the Vinland Map are two examples in recent decades. If there are to be further discoveries of this sort, it does not take a dowsing rod to identify the Secret Archives of the Vatican as one of the best places to dig.
