title: How to Avoid Being in Vogue?
description: LAST fall, during the Metropolitan Opera strike, Rudolf Bing deliv ered a series of lectures on opera. At the end of one such hour at Juilliard, a man in the audience asked the subject of the next lecture. This one, he said, was very disappointing, nothing but gossip and anecdotes. You treated the subject Ince a party joke. Startled at the insult, Bing demanded to know who the man was. I'm a composer, the man said. A student in the back of the room rose and proud ly proclaimed: That's Luciano Berio!

title: Mary Fry Edmunds Is Affianced
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 14  Mr. and Mrs. Robert Holt Edmunds have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Fry Edmunds, to John Davis Haywood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert Lynch Haywood of Durham.

title: Waterside's Fate Now in Hands Of a City Board
description: THE Waterside housing develop ment, with four towers and 1,470 apartments  an uncon summated dream for many New York housing idealistsmay at last be come a reality.

title: CAR RACING RESULTS BY COMPUTER URGED
description: An experienced timerscorer of motor races said last week that race promoters generally did not realize the value of scor ing and therefore were reluc tant to spend money on that operation.

title: Detroit's Motor Society Puts a Tranquil Family Life in the Driver's Seat
description: DETROITWhen they were married 20 years ago, Mary McCleary was a receptionist at the Ford Motor Com pany's assembly and parts distribution plant in Chester, Pa., and Lee Iacocco was its supersalesman.Last September Mr. Iacocco became president of Ford's domestic operations at a salary, plus bonus and stock ar rangement, that is expected to add up to about $500,000 a year. But his blond wife, fixing a hem on one of her size10 dresses, insisted, Nothing will change me. I cook. I sew. I do the dishes and the housework, and I take care of my two little girls.

title: Tiny TV Part Set to Meet U.S. Ruling
description: WILMINGTON, Mass., Feb. 14  The KEV Electronics Corporation announced last week that it can now offer mass production of voltage variable capacitors (VVC's) that will permit television set makers to meet new Gov ernmental standards for tuners. VVC's measure about the size of a grain of rice and can be produced to sell in large quantities at about 30 cents apiece.

title: Birch Bayh Isn't a Household WordYet
description: WASHINGTON. WITH its bestknown politicians driving off bridges or becom ing more absorbed in poetry than politics or disappearing into the obscurity of Midwest professorships, the Democratic party needs recruits at the top. It is a predicament that makes every aggressive Democrat in Washington look like a potential can didate for the national ticket in 1972. Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana has now entered that category.

title: Montclair State Defeats Glassboro State, 76 to 60
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 15Montclair State Col lege assured itself of at least a tie for its third straight New Jersey State College Conference Championship tonight by de feating Glasboro State, 7660.

title: MASSACRE CHARGE IS AIRED IN LAGOS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 14An international team of military observers today reported alle gations that 106 men, women and children were killed when a village near the Biafran en clave was wiped out last Christ mas, less than three weeks be fore the end of the Nigerian civil war.

title: Allen Bids School Aides Around Country Back Job Quotas for Minorities
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 14 Dr. James E. Allen Jr., United States Commissioner of Educa tion, called on local school ad ministrators today to support actively a guarantee of job quo tas for minority group members in all contracted educational expenditures.

title: What Day Care Means to
description: THE 4's are in their midmorn ing work period. Abife Saw yer, the chunky, middleaged, black teacher, sits on a scaleddown child's chair in a corner of the big, bright room and keeps an eye on a fortbuilding project: We don't kick blocks, George, because one might fly and hurt someone. Vincent, how can the trucks go through the gate when the trucks are larger than the gate?

title: Nuptials for Nan Maury McIlwaine
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 Miss Nan Maury Mcllwaine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Baird Mcllwaine 3d, was married here this after noon to Kurt von Kaltenborn. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Kaltenborn of Hill, N. H., and grandson of the late H. V. Kaltenborn, the news commentator. The ceremony in Trinity Memorial Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. H. H. Heistand. The Rev. Charles F. Penniman and the Rev. B. J. Rudderow assisted.

title: UNIONS SCORE USE OF LIE DETECTOR
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 14 Federal legislation to outlaw the use of polygraph machines and similar liedetection de vices, even in national security cases, was demanded today by a group of 41 unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of In dustrial Organizations.

title: Architecture
description: ISUPPOSE only a super scrooge could take ex ception to the superproj ect that the United Na tions Development Corpora tion has come up with to solve the UN's space and se curity problems in New York. You would have to be against the pursuit of peace, the brotherhood of nations and man, and the importance of the UN internationally and to New York  6,000 income producing visitors a day and $6million in increased taxes to the city.

title: Irish Win in Overtime
description: DETROIT, Feb 14 (UPI) Notre Dame came from 15 points down in the second half today tied the score 8383, at the buzzer, then beat the Uni versity of Detroit in overtime, 9593.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS CONTEMPT TERMS IN CHICAGO TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14  Judge Julius J. Hoffman sentenced four of the defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial today to lengthy prison terms for con temnt of court.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: WELL, the critical word is in regarding our production of Hed da Gabler at the Actors Playhouse and we are all amateurs, fools or worse. And we of the Op posites Company are forced to ponder whether, despite 30 or more actors and tech nical staff members, the critics are essentially good.

title: Article 4  No Title
PITCHING IS FORTE OF HODGES'S TEAM
description: Miracles aren't supposed to happen twice in a row. But, after much overthe winter reflection, baseball pundits are tending more and more to the belief that the Mets' 1969 sweep of honors was less of a miracle than labeled. The thinking now is that rather it represented an abrupt comingofage by a developing young team and, this having occurred, a repe tition of the Mets' success, in part if not in whole, not only is not impossible but quite likely.

title: Andrew Stern to Wed Sandra A. Gardner
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 14Mrs. Theresa Gardner has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sandra Ann Gardner, to Andrew E. Stern. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Theodore Stern of New York and Sands Point L. I.

title: BUSSEIN EXPLAINS GUERRILLA ACCORD
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 14 King Hussein strove at a news conference today to smooth over what he described as a misunderstanding between his Government and the Palestinian commando groups. The conflict is estimated to have cost 30 lives in the last four days.

title: Mass, Pike Close to Mark In Victory at Narragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R. L, Feb. 14 (AP)Mass. Pike, the favorite, came within twofifths of a second of a track record today in sprinting to a 2length victory in the $7,500 Valen tine's Day Purse at Narragan sett Park.

title: Advertising:
description: There was a particularly interested party in the audi ence in Washington a couple of weeks ago when Bryce N. Harlow, a counselor to Presi dent Nixon, said that the public had lost interest and confidence in the Better Busi ness Bureaus and called for efforts to upgrade their images.

title: Homosexuals in Los Angeles, Like Many Elsewhere, Want Religion and Establish Their Own Church
description: LOS ANGELES  The Rev. Troy D. Perry burst forward from his seat to a makeshift pulpit shouting, If you love the Lord this morning, say Amen. With one voice, the congregation of more than 400 persons roared back its response.

title: For Young Readers
description: Jonah and The Lord

title: Weather Scientists Warned of Environmental Damage From Poor Planning
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Two weather scientists told their colleagues today that man was changing his environment without proper planning and ran a high risk of destroying the basic relationships between living organisms and their sur roundings.

title: SCHOOL VOTE SUIT SEEKS EXTENSION
description: The mother of a 10yearold pupil in a private school has gone to court in an attempt to win the right to vote in the pending election of a local pub lic school board in her Bronx district.

title: Rutgers Matmen Score
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 14  Rutgers University built an early lead and handed New York University its sec ond straight wrestling defeat tonight, 2117.

title: F. RAPE TOOMBS
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 14 F. Raye Toombs, retired pres ident of the Fleet Patent Box Company of New York, who held several patents in packag ing, died yesterday at the age of 73.

title: TWO TO FORMALIZE RACES FOR SENATE
description: Two more Democrats an nounced yesterday that they would formally enter the race for their party's nomination for Senator within the next eight days.

title: Lowenstein, in Peace Move, Offers to Quit and Run Again if Governor Calls April Election
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15Repre sentative Allard K. Lowenstein of Nassau County, L. I., will offer tomorrow to resign his seat if Governor Rockefeller agrees to call a special election in 60 days.

title: David Cuenod Ernst Will Wed Miss Laura Vanderbilt in June
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 15Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Bed ford Vanderbilt of Green wich and Devil Lake, Ontario, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Laura Elizabeth Vanderbilt, to David Cuenod Ernst of Lake Bluff, Ill. He is the son Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Ernst of Lake Bluff, formerly of Greenwich.

title: Lindsay Backs Bill to Let U.S. Break Deadlock on Jetport Site
description: Mayor Lindsay is supporting a plan under which the Federal Secretary of Transportation would pick a fourth jetport site for the metropolitan area if New York State and New Jer sey remain unable to do so for the next three years.

title: MRS. JOHN F. O'CONNELL
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Feb. 15 Mrs. Marian Cox O'Connell, whose husband, John F. O'Con nell, was chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority from 1943 to 1955, died in Sub urban Hospital here today of a coronary attack.

title: Booming Homes for Aged Face Rising Discontent
description: One of the nation's fastest growing industries  nursing homes for the elderly  is fast becoming one of the most con troversial.

title: Israeli Jets Attack Twice At Suez Canal Alter Lull
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15  Is rael resumed her bombing of Egyptian positions along the Suez Canal today after a rela tively uneventful interlude of nearly three days.

title: FORMULA FORD RACE TAKEN BY CLARKE
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. (UPI)A former stock car driver who was permanently blinded in the left eye in racing accident last September. Won the first International Mo tor Sports Association 200mile Enrmitla Ford road race today at the Daytona International Sneedway.

title: Environment Board Urged
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent said today that he would file a bill in the legislature Tuesday calling for the creation of an Environmental Quality Control Council. The Governor, ad dressing student government leaders at Harvard University, said the council would receive complaints about damage done to the environment and do something about them, includ ing going to court if necessary.

title: Tax Savings Still Possible Despite Baffling New Forms
Fights Loom on Rights and Education as Congress Ends Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Congress returns from the grassroots politicking of a Lin coln's Birthday recess tomorrow with Senate Democrats seeking to outmaneuver the Administra tion on voting rights and House Democrats setting the stage for another confrontation on education funds.

title: Last G.E. Locals Settle
description: AUBURN, N. Y., Feb. 15 (UPI)The last of the striking locals at General Electric plants in New York, Ohio, and Indiana ratified new contracts today and will return to work tomor row. The Auburn local of the International Association of machinists ratified the new agreemetn, 331 to 60, on the 113th day of the strike, which at one time made 147,000 workers idle in 33 states.

title: HEAVY CALENDAR OF BONDS SLATED
description: The bond market's recovery is now two months old, and it isn't over yet.

title: Nader Cites Banks, Insurers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, indicated today that banks and insurance companies would be his next targets. He called banks leading candi dates for more scrutiny and said that insurance companies needed attention not only for abuses but also for failure to realize their potential.

title: Spain Begins Pledging Gold to Secure Loans
description: MADRID, Feb. 15A loss of foreign reserves has obliged Spain to make a cautious de parture from her traditional policy of keeping her sub stantial gold stocks intact.

title: New York Post Moves
description: The editorial and mechanical departments of The New York Post will be situated beginning today in the newspaper's new plant at 210 South Street in lower Manhattan, which once housed The New York JournalAmerican. The Post moved from 75 West Street.

title: Leader's Tire Blows Near End And Stott Wins Daytona Race
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Feb 15 (AP)  Ramo Stott of Keo kuk. Iowa. won a stirring duel from 54yearold Iggv Katona with only three laps to go to clay and took the Automobile Racing Club of America 300 mile stock car race at Daytona International Speedway.

title: Oil Cleanup Pushed in Tampa Bay After Spill by Greek Tanker
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 15City workmen toiled with hundreds of bales of straw, Polyurethane foam and suction equipped tank trucks today in an effort to control and clean up more than 10.000 gallons of heavy oil spilled into Tampa Bay by a Greek tanker that ran aground with a hole in her hull.

title: Correcting a Slipup
description: President Nixon's statesmanlike decision last Novem ber to have the United States renounce germ warfare was applauded here and abroad. This initial positive reaction was marred seriously, however, when it be came known that the ban did not include disease producing toxins. Some Pentagon spokesmen then at tempted to make a rather tortuous and unconvincing differentiation between microbiological organs ca pable of producing diseasewhich were bannedand the equally dangerous poisons or toxins they pro ducewhich were not banned.

title: A Modest Aristocratic Proposal
description: LONDON  An American who had his first look at the House of Lords when Prince Charles took his seat last week was surprised at the scarcity of blue blood. Hardly anyone pointed out to him was de scended from a Privy Councilor to Elizabeth the First. There were even two journalists on the floor: one a military cor respondent turned statesman, the other a practicing news paper political writer.

title: A.C.L.U. Deplores Contempt Terms In Chicago Trial
description: The American Civil Liberties Union deplored yesterday the contempt sentences against de fendants in the Chicago con spiracy trial and accused Judge Julius J. Hoffman of an ex traordinary and unconstitution al misuse of power.

title: Svelte Blonde Is a Commercial Pilot
description: A WOMAN is wearing the pants in another for merly allmale sanctuary: the cockpit of a commercial air liner.

title: Filipino Mayor Killed
description: MANILA, Feb. 15 (UPI) Mayor Julito Espino of Arayat in Pampanga Province was shot to death today at a cock fight. His assailant and a by stander were killed when the Mayor's bodyguards returned fire. Seven other spectators were wounded.

title: Roads Are Glazed As a Freezing Rain Follows Snowfall
description: Freezing rain and drizzle fol lowed snow yesterday and com bined belowfreezing tempera tures, left the New York met ropolitan area's roads slick and hazardous.

title: CPC TO PURCHASE A MUFFIN BAKERY
description: CPC International, Inc., yes terday announced plans to ac quire S. B. Thomas, Inc., bakers of English muffins and bakery products, through an exchange of stock worth about $20mil lion.

title: American Yacht Takes 4th In World Regatta at Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 15 (AP)The American yacht Travelodge International, skip pered by Roger Welsh of New port Beach. Calif., finished fourth over all today on points in the world 18footer cham pionship.

title: A.B.C.TV IS HONORED BY SICKLE CELL FUND
description: Plaques were presented yes terday by the Foundation for Research and Education in Sickle Cell Disease to Like It Is, the American Broadcasting Company's television series, and to Gordon Parks, the Negro author and photographer who adapted, produced and directed the movie version of his auto biographical novel, The Learn ing Tree.

title: Napoles Keeps Title as Aficionados Cheer
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 Last Tuesday, a novice fighter named Herbert Khou ry, also known as Tiny Tim, put on a pair of boxing gloves and tiptoed through a brief sparring sessions with Jose Npoles, the world welterweight champion.

title: Nestle Plans Samples Of Chocolate Aroma
description: The Nestle's gang is going to be giving out free samples.Hooray!

title: AIDE SAYS SOVIET WON'T RAID CHINA
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  Sergei L. Tikhvinsky, who has been a member of the Soviet delega tion at the talks in Peking with Communist China, vigor ously rejected today Western speculation that the Soviet Union was planning to attack China.

title: College Hockey
Susan E. Clarke Becomes Bride Of an Engineer
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Feb. 15Miss Susan Eliza beth Clarke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Clarke, was married here this after noon to Gerhard Botha, son of M. I. Botha, South African representative at the United Nations, and Mrs. Botha of New York and Koffiefontein, South Africa.

title: Italy's Repertory Politics
description: ROME, Feb. 15Italy's Pre mierdesignate, Mariano Rumor, will tuck up his sleeves tomor row and set about the task of picking up the Humpty Dumpty of the Italian party system, patching its multiple fractures and setting it back on the wall again in the guise of a new Government.

title: Ellis to Rely on His Sharp Left Jab in Bid for Undisputed World Title Tonight
description: In its essence, tonight's heavyweight title showdown at Madison Square Garden will match the swarming fury of Joe Frazier's twofisted bel ligerence against the disci plined skills of Jimmy Ellis's thwarting left jab and coiled right hand.

title: Books of The Times
description: AS if the decade hadn't already been swaddled in excelsior, crated and stowed in a time machine by an entire army of straining journalists, Esquire magazine now steps forward with its ver sion of the sixties. And to read Smiling Through the Apocalypse straight through one would think that the decade began with Norman Mailer discovering the luster of Jack Kennedy (Superman Comes to the Supermarket) and ended with Gore Vidal snapping at the ankles of William F. Buck ley Jr. (A Distasteful Encounter With ...), while Tom Wolfe, Terry Southern, Gay Talese, James Baldwin and sundry others cavorted in between.

title: ARVID E. TAUBE
description: Arvid Eaton Taube, president of the Westchester County His torical Society, died of em physema at Lenox Hill Hospital on Friday. He was 75 years old and lived on Bedford Center Road in Bedford. N. Y.

title: Memorial Services
description: WELCHMurray Dewitt Memorial service Thursday, February 19, 5:30 P.M. at St Thomas Church, 53 St. & Fifth Ave. Friends and associates are invited fo join the University Glee Club of New York in Its tribute to a devoted long time mem ber, whose loss on December 26, 1969 we mourn. By request of the family, a mem orial fund in lieu of flowers has been established in the U.G.C. to which con tributions may be made.

title: Bread or Pastry With a Hearty Walnut Flavor
description: RECIPES for a walnut brown bread to serve with ham and baked beans, a cinnamon walnut loaf for teatime or to accompany a light salad lunch and a rich nutty pie are given below.

title: SANTANA TRIUMPHS AT U.S. INDOOR NET
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 15 (AP)Snow, sleet and rain did not deter a record opening crowd of 2,500 at the $50,000 national indoor open tennis championships today, but the program had to be cut.

title: Protestants Plan 9Church Merger
description: Representatives of nine ma jor Protestant denominations yesterday released a compre hensive plan to unite a third of all American Protestants in a single church by 1980.

title: McCrady Sets Own Record Pace; Von Ruden Doesn't and Misses
description: Records, like races, are usually to the swiftest, but inspiration and wisdom help. Martin McGrady and Tom Von Ruden learned that Sat urday night in the Mason Dixon indoor track meet at Louisville.

title: 4 in Family Killed Upstate
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 15 (AP) Four members of a Kirksville family were killed today when their auto was struck by a Penn Central freight train at a grade crossing a few yards from their home. The dead were identified as Robert St. Hilaire, his wife, Kietha, and their two children, Susan, 13 years old and Robin, 11. A third daughter, Patricia, 15, was listed in serious condi tion at Memorial Hospital in Syracuse.

title: INSURING OF AUTOS ON NO FAULT BASIS IS URGED BY STATE
description: A complete overhaul of auto mobile insurance coverage in New York State has been pro posed by the State Insurance Department, which says that the new plan could reduce in surance costs by 56 per cent.

title: Sports of The Times
description: THE correlation between basketball and Jesus Christ is this, said Cazzie Russell, pleased at the turn in the conversation. I am able to live the same way all the time. Matthew, 26, talks about not living two lives. You have people doing the same thing Monday through Thursday,, then coming to church. You can't serve the devil and Jesus Christ.

title: Coming Primary for Surrogate Expected to Be Continuation of '66 Battle
description: Remember June 28, 1986? A lot of liberal Democrats do that was the day that Samuel J. Silverman won the Demo cratic primary election for Manhattan surrogateand they are quietly laying the ground Work for another surrogate pri mary this June.

title: Los Angeles Ruling Highlights Integration Issues
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 The recent court decision that Los Angeles must integrate its public schools illuminates number of problems that could soon face school districts across the country. In California alone, the State Department of Edu cation recently estimated that 198 districts, or 18 per cent of the state total, maintain schools that are racially imbalanced. If courts or Congress force Northern school districts to implement integration plans, one of the first problems the districts will encounter is money. In Los Angeles, school officials con tend that they will have to bus about 240,000 children, at a cost of $20million a year, to satisfy the court ruling.

title: Buck, New Olympic Group Head, Hopes to End Amateurs' Feud
description: In a lively, but apparently amicable battle, Clifford H. Buck of Denver was elected president yesterday of the United States Olympic Com mittee.

title: BENNETT IS HONORED BY COMPOSERS' UNIT
description: Robert Russell Bennett, the composer and arranger of Broadway shows, was awarded the Henry Hadley Medal of the National Association for Ameri can Composers and Conductors at the group's Tully Hall con cert yesterday afternoon.

title: WILEY'S RAGS GAINS HORSE SHOW CROWN
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 15 Rags, owned and handled by Ed Wiley of Stamford, Conn., captured all three blue ribbons in the division to win the regu lar working hunter champion ship today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show.

title: Easy Ride on a Philadelphia Transit Line
description: PHILADELPHIAThere's mass transit system here that is disproving one of the most cherished axioms of modern American lifethat man can't be divorced from his automo bile.

title: SOVIET TO SEEK BAN ON GERM WARFARE
description: GENEVA, Feb. 15  Aleksei A. Roshchin, the Soviet dele gate to the Geneva disarma ment conference, said today that the Soviet Union was giv ing top priority at the confer ence to an agreement to ban chemical and germ weapons.

title: Minnesota v. the A.E.C.
description: The state of Minnesota is engaged in a dispute with the Atomic Energy Commission over safety standards for a nuclear power planta dispute that has far reaching implications for other states seeking to pro tect their environment. In New York and Colorado, for example, local groups recently have raised search ing questions about the adequacy of A.E.C. precau tions for nuclear installations, existing and planned.

title: An AllinOne Playground for Toddlers
description: THE LATEST piece of equipment off the draw ing hoard for preschoolers an estimated market of some 1:5 million youngsters is a unit of tubular steel called Gymee that is de signed for indoor or outdoor play. Scaled specifically for youngsters under 5, the corn pact unit stands just over 6 feet high and occupies a 7hy9font area in which up to eight youngsters can play simultaneously. Painted in cheerful tones of orange, blue, yellow and white, Gymee includes slide, swing, climbing ladders, swinging bars and a totsized picnic table and bench. Manufactured by GymDan dy, Inc., a division of Gabriel Industries, Gymee is about $50 and is in Bloomingdale's eighthfloor toy department.

title: Volkswagen Places Glass Order in U.S.
description: The glass division of Com bustion Engineering, Inc., in a sort of international reverse trend, announced over the weekend that it would supply windows for 20,000 Volks wagens a month over the next two years. The contract calls for Combustion to furnish wind shields, side, vent and rear win dows.

title: 2 SOVIET SKIERS WIN NORDIC TITLES
description: STRBSKE PLESO, Czechoslo vakia, Feb. 15 (AP)  Juri Kozulin of the Soviet Union mastered fog and wind today and won the jumping event while another Soviet athlete, Viacheslav Vedenin, captured the 30kilometer crosscountry race in the world Nordic ski ing championships.

title: UPSET LOSS FAILS TO UPSET NIAGARA
description: Resigning coaches sometimes work unexplainable magic for basketball teams.

title: Case Histories of Progress in Latin America
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaThis is a good time and place to recall what the Alliance for Progress was all about. In their Declara tion to the Peoples of America, introducing the Charter of Punta del Este in 1961, twenty governments concurred:

title: U.S. Health Aide Named
description: Dr. V. Terrell Davis, director of the New Jersey Division of Mental Health since 1956, has been appointed mental health consultant in psychiatry for the Health Services and Mental Health Administration of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The appointment was announced yesterday by Mrs. Bernice L. Bernstein, the regional director of the department here.

title: TeenAge Use of Heroin Rising but Data Are Few
description: BALTIMORE  Gary is a handsome, cleancut looking 18yearold, the son of a pros perous businessman who lives, along with two cars, in the pleasant Northwest section of Baltimore. A future lawyer or doctor, perhaps.

title: DualPurpose Funds
Duquesne Routs Fairfield
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 (AP) Jarrett Durham scored 25 points today, 20 of them in the first half, as Duquesne defeated Fairfield University, 10162. It was the Dukes' seventh straight victory.

title: Muffin Man Signs Cast
description: Gil Rogers, Doris Relack, Richard Russ, Lucy Martin and Kevin Conway have signed to appear in Do You Know the Muffin Man, the Milton Ward play opening March 12 at the MercerHansberry Theater,

title: KENNEY CAPTURES FISK CUP SLALOM
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., Feb. 15 One of America's oldest ski ing fixtures was won by one of the East's newest collegiate stars today as John (Bill) Ken ney, a Middlebury freshman, scored an upset in the Fisk Cup competition by a surpris ingly large margin.

title: PROJECTION IS ALLY OF FIFTH DIMENSION
description: Hearing the Fifth Dimension at the first of two concerts at Philharmonic Hall on Saturday night, it became evident that there are some songs that bene fit from very loud projection. The quintet's medley of Aquar ius and Let the Sunshine In was strikingly effective largely because of the massed power that the quintet and its four in strumental accompanists put in to it.

title: Ford Fund Gives 8 Grants For Studies and Education
description: The Ford Foundation an nounced yesterday that it had made eight grants totaling more than $4.8million for re search and educational pro grams in the fields of law, poli tics, government affairs and civil rights.

title: ROGERS, IN ZAMIA, VOICES OPPOSITION TO RACIST REGIMES
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 15 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States deplored govern ments based on racial discrimi nation but that we do not be lieve that violence is the an swer.

title: Clark Terry Echoes The Ellington Days
description: It there is eventually to be an inheritor of Duke Elling ton's mantle as a band leader, it might be Clark Terry, once an Ellington sideman who is a brilliant performing personality on trumpet and flugelhorn. Mr. Terry led a big band at Car negie Hall last night that can, given a good arrangement, play it with the finesse and some of the individuality character istic of the Ellington band. To ice the cake, Mr. Terry has much of Mr. Ellington's suave aplomb in presenting his musi cians and his selections.

title: Seeing Through Albany
description: The fight to protect consumers against exploitation is tough enough, as New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson Grant knows so well. It is important that the State Legislature not take what she has correctly described as a totally unnecessary and backward step.

title: Transit Agency to Weed Out Subway Concessions
description: The days when a hungry man can buy a candy bar on a sub way platform, or a vain man a photograph of himself, or an inquisitive man a newspaper may be numbered.

title: New Books
description: A Change in the Wind, by Leslie Waller (Bernard Geis Associates, $5.95). The life and times of a Prohibitionera rumrunner.

title: HAWKS DEAL CELTICS A 146125 TROUNCING
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 15 (UPI)  Lou Hudson and Joe Caldwell triggered a 151 Atlanta burst to open the second half today and led the Hawks to a 146 125 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: Kidd, in Last Race as an Amateur, raptures Alpine Combined World Title
description: VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 15 (AP)Billy Kidd, in his last race as an amateur, gave the United States its first Alpine combined gold medal today by finishing tied for fifth place in the downhill. Bernhard Russi of Switzerland was the surprise winner In the final event of the world ski championships.

title: Refugees Pose Urban Crisis in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15We never meant to stay here permanently, Nguyen Huu Khoa said, smiling a little at the memory. We planned to go back to the village as soon as the fighting stopped. But that was eight years ago and the war is still on and we are still here.

title: FITZ GIBBON TAKES EASTERN NET CROWN
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 15 Herb Fitz Gibbon, the 27year old New York stockbroker who ranks 14th in the country, wore down Pete Fishbach today and won the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship, 1311, 75, 60.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Wheeling Steel Looks For Deals
description: PITTSBURGH  Robert E. Lauterbach, the new presi dent of the WheelingPitts burgh Steel Corporation, was telling a visitor about the outlook the other day, when he remarked casually, almost as an aside, that the com pany had taken a look at about 75 acquisition possibil ities in the last six months or so.

title: ROUGH COLLIE GETS SPECIALTY AWARD
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 15Beau's Dark Legacy, a rough collie owned by Her bert and Elsie Beaumont of North Scituate. R.I., came out of the classes today and won best of breed in the second an nual specialty show of the Col lie Club of Connecticut.

title: Facts on Title Fight
description: PrinciplesJoe Frazier, Philadel phia, recognized as champion in six states and some foreign na tions, and Jimmy Ellis, Louisville, Ky., World Boxing Association champion.

title: Car Makers Cut Prices Various Ways
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15  Price cutting isn't popular during in flation, but when car sales slump Detroit cuts anyway  but not the way one might ex pect.

title: MRS. STELLA UNGER, LYRICIST, DIES AT 65
description: Mrs. Stella Garfield Unger, a lyricist, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 25 West 81st Street. She was the wife of Dr. Louis A. Unger, a dentist.

title: Bridge:
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea land, Feb. 15The Ameri can touring team of William Root, Dorothy Hayden, Rob ert Jordan, Arthur Robinson and this writer began a week of play in New Zealand with two convincing victories in short matches here today. They beat Canterbury by 39 international match points and Southland by 56 points.

title: Rangers Beat Canadiens,20, Scoring in Record 118th Game in Row
description: Brutalizing the Canadiens in a game that symbolized per fectly how far the Rangers have come, the New Yorkers set a National Hockey League record while scoring a 20 vic tory yesterday over Montreal.

title: BIG BOARD BACKS SMALL INVESTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  The New York Stock Exchange has promised the Securities and Exchange Commission that it will take steps to keep its member firms from turning away small investors simply because they are smallpro vided the S.E.C. approves the new and generally higher sales commissions that the exchange wants.

title: Robert Lawrence, Tenor, Presents Songs, Ballads
description: When he does not exceed his limited vocal and expressive powers, Robert Lawrence sings with considerable charm.

title: Choreographers Put Dancers to a Trial Of Time and Space
description: A duration of time and an allotment of space are the basic limitations within which the choreographer works. Deborah Hay, Majorie Strider, John Per reault and Hannah Weiner gath ered last night in the Emanuel Midtown Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Asso ciation to use the gymnasium for 20 minutes each.

title: BAYONNE TEACHERS AGREE ON CONTRACT
description: BAYONNE, N. J., Feb. 15A strike by public school teachers was averted here today as teachers in Newark and Jersey City continued their strikes.

title: Astronaut to Be Honored
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 15 (AP) Neil A. Armstrong, the first man to set foot on the moon, and Eugene F. Kranz, flight director during the critical Apollo 11 lunar surface landing maneuvers, Thursday will re ceive an award given annually by the Downtnwn Jaycees of Washington for outstanding service to the Federal Govern ment.

title: Lord Dowding, Head of Fighters In Battle of Britain, Dies at 87
description: LONDON, Feb. 15Air Chief Marshal Lord Dowding, who headed the victorious Fighter Command during the Battle of Britain, died today at his home in Tunbridge Wells, Kent. He was 87 years old.

title: Radical Priests in Colombia, Heirs to Slain Guerrilla, Have Forged an Open MarxistsCatholic Alliance
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 15 Four years ago today, A Colombian priest named Camilo Torres died in a skirmish be tween his guerrilla band and an army patrol.

title: Miss Judith Mae Dunkelberger Is Married to Jonathan A. Wouk
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 Miss Judith Mae Dunkelberg er, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Tobias H. Dunkelberger, was married here this afternoon to Jonathan A. Wouk, son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Wouk of New York and Ossining, N. Y. Rabbi Jack Schecter per formed the ceremony in Temple B'nai Israel.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Sanford H. England and W. Hunter Platt have been named vice presidents of the First Na tional City Bank. Mr. England is the corporate banking group's consumer goods and services division, while Mr. Platt is in charge of loan operations with in the operating group.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: NETS WIN, 108100, FROM MIAMI FIVE
Mother of Defendant Admitted to Hospital
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15The mother of one of the de fendants in the Chicago con spiracy trial was admitted to a hospital here tonight after taking an apparent overdose of tranquilizers.

title: GREECE SAID TO SEEK ARMS FROM FRANCE
description: ATHENS, Feb. 15Qualified foreign diplomatic sources here confirmed tonight that Greece was negotiating the purchase of French  built heavy arms denied to it under a selective United States embargo.

title: Squash Racquets Title Won By Beth Anders of Ursinus
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 Beth Anders of Ursinus College, won the United States women's intercollegiate squash racquets championship today, defeating Sandy Krieger of Wellesley College, 1511, 1718, 1512, 154, on the University of Penn sylvania courts.

title: Uri Mayer in Viola Solo With Youth Symphony
description: Carnegie Hall was crowded with youngsters yesterday af ternoon for a concert by the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York.

title: First Marschallin Is Sung at the Met By Marion Lippert
description: It is a pleasure to report that the Metropolitan Opera has acquired a Marschallin for Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier who should provide many gra tifying performances here if her presence can he assured. She is Marion Lippert, the German soprano, who made her Metro politan debut last spring in the title role of Puccini's Turan dot.

title: While the Ring Is Prepared for the Big Fight, One of the Contenders Takes a Quiet Stroll
FREED PASSENGERS ACCUSE PYONGYANG
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 15 Some of the 39 passengers of a hijacked South Korean airliner who were returned from North Korea yesterday, after 65 days of captivity said today that most of the 12 pas sengers and crew members re maining in the North were be ing held there against their will. North Korea said yester day that some passengers had chosen to stay.

title: SAM SIEMEL, 80, JUNGLE EXPLORER
description: SUMNEYTOWN, Pa., Feb. 15 Sasha Siemel, hunter, ex plorer, author and lecturer, who was known as the tigre man of the Mato Grosso jungle of Brazil, died yesterday in Sellers ville. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: Theater: A Musical Gantry Arrives
LAKERS TOP BUCKS ON SHOT BY WEST
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 15 (AP) Jerry West connected on 20foot jumper with six sec onds left, then blocked a last second shot by Jon McGlocklin to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 9896 victory over the Mil waukee Bucks today.

title: Nixon Ship Program: Promise and Warning
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Nixon Administration is proposing to Congress the big gest burst of private shipbuild ing since World War II. At the same time, it is warning the shipyards that if they don't cut the high cost of American vessels, the Government's con struction subsidies may be phased out altogether. At the first round of public hearings on the new maritime program, the Administration has been eating its cake and having it, too.

title: WATERFRONT PANEL SUMMONS SCOT TO
description: Anthony M. Scotto, an Inter national Longshoremen's Asso ciation vice president who re cently refused to tell a state panel conducting an inquiry whether he belonged to the Ma fia, has been called as a wit ness before the bistate Water front Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Trade Bloc Is Cheerful On Outlook
description: BRUSSELS, Monday, Feb. 16 The Executive Commission of the European Common Market has noted in its report for 1969, published today, that the com munity moved into its final stage in an atmosphere far more cheerful than at the start of last year, a period that was marked by open talk of crisis, paralysis and even disintegra tion.

title: Plane Collision Kills 6
description: PLACERVILLE, Calif., Feb. 15 (UPI))The bodies of six persons, including three chil dren, were found today in the wreckage of two light planes that collided in flight and fell in flames in the Sierra Nevada foothills. The names of the vic tims were withheld until rela tives could be notified. One plane, a singleengine Bonanza, was on the way from Mam moth Lake to Cameron Park. The other was a singleengine Piper with two persons and flying from South Lake Tahoe Palo Alto.

title: Radicals in France Adopt Bold Platform
description: PARIS, Feb. 15  France's Radical Socialist party, full of years and past glory, made a new start in political life today with the adoption of a plat form of audacious economic and educational reform.

title: Missing Plane Carrying Five Found Off Connecticut Shore
description: GROTON, Conn., Feb. 15 (AP)  A twoengine Pilgrim Airlines airplane missing since Tuesday with five persons aboard was found Friday about a mile off Connecticut.

title: CANADA AND U.S. PRESS OIL TALKS
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 15Canada and the United States are deep ly immersed in negotiations over oil and natural gas and Canada hopes to announce results within weeks, the Minis ter of Energy, Mines and Re sources has disclosed.

title: Nonprofit Horne Builders Fear Curbs by F.H.A Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Sponsors of nonprofit housing, who have been heavily involv ed in the production of federal ly subsidized low and moderate income units in recent years, are alarmed by reports that the new head of the Federal Hous ing Administration plans to cur tail their activities.

title: Java's Gift to Seventh AvenueFabrics With a TieDyed Look
description: THREE thousand years ago in places like Java and Peru, people began decorating their fabrics by tying knots in them before dipping them in dye. Students in Europe and the United States revived the process a couple of years ago as they sought to give their blue jeans and T shirts a personal flavor.

title: A.J.C. CITES STAND OF BLACK PANTHERS
description: The American Jewish Com mittee charged yesterday that the Black Panthers were con sistently antiZionist and anti Israel and that this has made it almost impossible to make the distinction between that attitude and antiSemitism.

title: YONKERS SUSPENDS CHIEF FISCAL AIDE
description: YONKERS, Feb. 15Cline B. Stephens Jr., the City control ler, has been suspended for what City Manager Seymour Scher said could be an at attempted misuse of [city] funds.

title: Japan Orbits a Satellite
description: Japan became the world's fourth space power the other day when it orbited its first satellite, a 51pound package of scientific instruments. The calm with which the world received the feat contrasts with the enormous excitement generated by the first Soviet and American sputniks a dozen years ago. That excitement, though diminished, had not died by the time the first French satellite orbited in 1965. Nowa days a world blas about manned lunar landings and pictures or scientific data from rockets to Mars and Venus can hardly be expected to flip over the mere launching of a small satellite.

title: DELEYER IS WINNER WITH TWO HORSES
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., Feb. 15  Harry DeLeyer, riding master at Hollandia Farm in St. James, L. I., piloted the winners of both the regular working hunter and inter mediate jumper championships today at the Middle Island Horse Show. The event was held at the Middle Island Arena.

title: STEEL SHIPMENTS AHEAD OF '69 PACE
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15Steel shipments are running well ahead of the 1969 pace.

title: State Senator Calls For Bill of Rights For the Nonsmoker
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15A pack age of bills, dubbed the non smokers bill of rights by its sponsor, was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Edward J. Speno, Republican of Nassau County.

title: MRS. BENJAMIN ANTIN
description: Mrs. Dora Polsky Antin, widow of Benjamin Antin, for mer State Senator, died Satur day at the Wickersham Hospi tal. She was 73 years old, and lived at 601 East 20th Street.

title: MISS HAYNIE FAILS AFTER GAINING TIE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15 (AP)Carol Mann won a suddendeath playoff from Sandra Haynie and took the $40,000 Burdine's women's invitation golf tourna ment today at the Country Club of Miami.

title: Nasser Evades the Issues...
description: President Nasser's comments on recent United States peace proposals in his interview with James Reston of this newspaper can only heighten tensions in the Middle East. They diminish hope for the early settlement Egypt needs to regain her lost territory and to free Egyptian resources for the domestic re construction that was once the hallmark of Nas serism.

title: Emerson Conquers Gonzales in 3 Sets In $200,000 Series
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP)Roy Emerson of Austra lia took the third leg of the $200,000 professional tennis World Classic by defeating Pancho Gonzales, 63, 62, 60, today.

title: ANTIWAR PROTEST VOTED FOR APRIL
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 15 The Student Mobilization Commit tee called today for massive antiwar demonstrations across the country during the week of April 13 to 18.

title: Chess
description: PHIL NEWMAN of St. Peter's Prep, Jersey City, and Jon Jacobs of Stuyve sant High in New York, each with 5, topped 148 stu dents from seven states who participated in the recent Eastern High Schools Chess Championship at Harrisburg, Pa.

title: COLUMBIA ADDING MINORITY PH.D.'S
description: Columbia University reported yesterday that it had started a vigorous program to increase the number of minoritygroup students in its Doctor of Phil osophy and other graduate pro grams.

title: DOMINICAN PLANE, WITH 102, CRASHES
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Feb. 15A Do minican DC9 jetliner with 97 passengers and a crew of five crashed in the Caribbean to night after one of its two engines failed.

title: SCHENK TRIUMPHS IN SPEED SKATING
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 15 (UPI) Ard Schenk of the Nether lands won the 1970 world speed skating championships at Bislet Stadium today in his seventh try at the coveted title, and with a record score.

title: Von Thadden ReElected German Rightists' Chief
description: WERTHEIM, West Ger many, Feb. 15 (Reuters) The rightwing National Democratic party ended a twoday convention here quietly today after reelect ing Adolf von Thadden as its chairman.

title: New Repertory Dance Theater Makes Its Debut
description: The New Repertory Dance Theater, a group headed by Joel Benjamin, made its debut at Kaufmann Concert Hall last night. Those who expected Mr. Benjamin to follow through on the performance he gave last June and carry on in the mod ern dance idiom found them selves instead at that rarity, the chamber ballet concert.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
GIFTS TO CORNELL INCREASE BY 38%
description: Cornell University alumni, foundations, corporations and private individuals contributed more money from July 1, 1969, to Jan. 20, 1970, than for the corresponding period in the previous year despite last April's campus troubles.

title: Only American Known to Have Fought for Biafra Tells of War
description: The only American known to have fought as a mercenary on the losing side in me Nigerian civil war was a 37yearold black former paratrooper known by the Biafrans as Johnny Oche, or White Johnny.

title: Eban in Netherlands
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Feb. 15 (UPI)Israel's Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, arrived here today for a three day official visit to the Nether lands. At Schiphol International Airport, extensive security measures had been taken by the national police and the air port security police against possible antiIsraeli incidents.

title: Augustus Van Cortlandt, 76, Member of Prominent Family
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Feb. 15Augustus Van Cortlandt, a member of a family prominent in New York for 300 years, died today in Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 76 years old

title: Seine Overflows in Paris
description: PARIS, Feb. 15 (UPI)The Seine, swollen by flays of rain and snow, spilled over its banks in Paris today. Heavy snow still fell in northern and eastern France where a storm has raged for days.

title: Mary Biggers Is Affianced to Robert Fauteux
description: Reeve K. Biggers of Wes ton, Conn., and Mrs. White Hamilton of Warrenton, Va., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Mary Kelsey Biggers of Schenectady, N.Y., to Robert James Fauteux, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Fauteux of Yonkers.

title: TRACK TITLE WON BY FORDHAM PREP
description: Fordham Prep was the sur prise winner of the team title yesterday in the New York Archdiocese sectional indoor track championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association.

title: TV: Mr. Magoo and American History
description: MR. MAGOO, the near sighted cartoon figure with the great big voice sup plied by Jim Backus, has withstood the test of the years, so presumably a good many people must think him amusing. So be it.

title: Fire Damages Tufts Building
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 15 (AP)A threealarm fire early today caused extensive damage to Braker Hall, which housed the economics and history de partments at Tufts University here. A university official said the threestory building would he unusable for the rest of the school year.

title: Long Pollution in Nova Scotia From Tanker's Oil Is Expected
description: PORT HAWKESBURY, Nova Scotia, Feb. 15  The maxim that an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure illus trated with new meaning by the difficulties being exper ienced here in cleaning up the oil pollution that has resulted from the wreck of the tanker Arrow on Feb. 4.

title: Ronan Joins Research Unit
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15  Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of New York's Metropolitan Trans portation Authority, has been named a director of the Na tional Transportation Center, which has headquarters here. The appointment was an nounced by Frederick J. Close, board chairman of the center and board chairman of Alumi num Company of America. The center is a nonprofit corpora tion that does research in transporation.

title: KUNSTLER GIVEN FOURYEAR TERM BY CHICAGO JUDGE
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15The two defense attorneys and three of the defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial were sentenced to prison for contempt of court today.

title: RUSSIAN SOPRANO REASSERTS AGILITY
description: Bella Rudenko, the Soviet soprano, made her local debut two years ago, and it was a triumph. Heard at Philharmo nic Hall again last night, she has lost none of the deadcenter accuracy and dazzling agility that separates genuine color atura sopranos from imitation ones.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Conflict Among Pupils

title: Key Voters in Chile, the Women, Expected to Back a Conservative
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 14 It is the women of Chile who will decide next September's presidential election, in the opinion of this country's lead ing publicopinion analyst. And if he is correct, that means vic tory for the conservative candi date, Jorge Alessandri Rodri guez.

title: Memorial for Pee Wee Russell Draws His Jazz Fans to Jersey
description: MARTINSVILLE, N. J., Feb 15More than 1,000 fans of the late Pee Wee Russell, the jazz clarinetist, flooded into this snowcovered village in the Watchung Mountains this after noon to attend the First Annual Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp. Mr. Russell died on Feb. 15, 1969.

title: Cool in Mideast Crises
description: FOR seven years now, from his eyrie on the Hill of Evil Counsel above Jerusalem, Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull of Nor way has observed with bleak blue eyes and a minimum of passion the threshing cross currents of the Middle East the sniping and backbiting, attacks and counterattacks, the contradictory communiqus and shortlived ac commodations, the barrages of artil lery and the as saults of propaganda.

title: I.D.S. REASSURES STOCK EXCHANGE
description: CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 15 Admission of institutions to membership in the New York Stock Exchange would not significantly change the pattern of trading, Robert M. Loeffler, senior vice president of In vestors Diversified Services, Inc., declared here yesterday.

title: Hoyt's Sunfish Captures World Crown in Sailing
description: ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 15Gary Hoyt, an adver tising executive from San Juan, Puerto Rico, won the sixth and final race today and gained the Sunfish Class world sailing championship with a low score of 9 points.

title: Goodman Band in Rumania
description: BUCHAREST, Feb. 15 (UPI) Benny Goodman flew into Rumania today to a welcome reminiscent of his days as America's King of Swing more than 30 years ago. Mr. Goodman is leading a 17man hand of British musicians on a tour of 14 West European cities, including Bucharest, the only communist capital on the itinerary.

title: Osterman Joins Rothschilds
description: Lester Osterman has joined Hillard Elkins in the production of the musical version of Fred eric Morton's best seller, The Rnthschilds. The show, open ing in New York in October, has a honk by Sherman Yellen and score by Sheldon Harnick.

title: Mrs. Simon Guggenheim Dead; Philanthropist and Arts Patron
description: Mrs. Olga Hirsh Guggenheim, widow of Simon Guggenheim, the philantropist and industrial ist, died Saturday in her home at 1040 Fifth Avenue. She was 92 years old.

title: In Memoriam
description: KAPLANPhyllis Ann. Sept. 4, 1942 Feb. 16, 1963. Every one can master a grief but he that has it. Seven long, lonely today.

title: ALLIES SAY UNITS KILL 145 OF FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, Feb. 16 (AP)South Viet namese rangers and an armored brigade trapped an enemy dem olition battalion 18 miles south of Danang yesterday and all but wiped it out, allied spokes men said today.

title: City Concedes Many Tenants Have Had No Heat or Water for Most of Winter
description: Hundreds of apartment build ings in the city have had no heat or water for most of the winter, city housing officials conceded in interviews this week.

title: ARRAU GLITTERS IN CHOPIN WORKS
description: There are two Claudio Ar raus, and both of them played a piano recital yesterday after noon at Philharmonic Hall.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1970

title: REP. FORD SAYS U.S. WON'T PRESS ISRAEL
description: Representative Gerald R. Ford, Republican leader of the House, declared last night that the Nixon Administration, would not negotiate any peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: 2 City Teachers Arrested With Girl on Drug Charge
description: Two city teachers and a college coed were charged Saturday night with posses sing a marijuana cigarette.

title: Nixon Aides Finish Work on Message On Foreign Policy
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 15President Nixon's foreign policy experts put finishing touches on a 30,000word state of the world message here this morning. The last de cision they made was to en title the foreign policy message A New Strategy for Peace.

title: Leningrad Still Finds Housing Is Its Main Problem
description: LENINGRAD  Built on the marshy islands of the Neva, River 266 years ago by Peter the Great as a window on the West for the import of Euro pean civilization to Russia, Leningrad today is a growing metropolis struggling with most of the physical and social prob lems common to large cities everywhere.

title: Israel Says Oil Now Flows From Elath to Ashkelon
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 (UPI) Israel announced today the completion of a 42inch oil pipeline linking the Gulf of Aqaba and the Port of Elath with the Mediterranean port of Ashkelon 163 miles away.

title: DRIVERS WHO SKIP TOLLS ARE DUNNED
description: Motorists who thought they had beaten the automatic toll machines at facilities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority may be in for a shock. In many instances, someone was watching.

title: Four Dance Works And One Pure Idea At 14th St. Studio
description: An idea is the most insub stantial thing and yet the most persistent. On Saturday evening the 14th Street Studio pre sented a program of five dance works, one of which was a pure idea, no more no less. I took it away with me after the concert and have been thinking about it since. It's called A Work by Joel Mason.

title: Air Controllers and U.S. Agree to Mediate Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) The Government's highest ranking aviation officials and the air controllers who have threatened a nationwide slow down of aviation traffic agreed today to meet with a Federal mediator to resolve their dis pute.

title: Trevino and Miss Mann Win SuddenDeath Playoffs for Rich Golf Prizes
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 15 (UPI) Lee Trevino scored a birdie 3 on the first extra hole of a suddendeath playoff today to beat Bob Murphy for the $20, 000 first prize in the $100,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

title: KLEINDIENST SEEKS PORNOGRAPHY CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said to day that the Nixon Adminis tration hoped through new test cases to win Supreme Court de cisions curbing pornography.

title: Daddario to Run for Connecticut Governorship
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 15  More than 3,000 Democrats from throughout Connecticut crowd ed into the chandeliered ball room of the Hilton Hotel here today to hear Representative Emilio Q. (Mim) Daddario an nounce his candidacy for Gov ernor.

title: Rome: A Success That Couldn't List
description: ROMEWhat many con sider (and could very well be) the most successful Italian theatrical company of all time is going out of busi ness within three or four months, after 16 years of exemplary work, if nothing happens to solve some of its insoluble problems. To be sure, Parliament could still rush a new law, or an enlightened Min ister for Tourism and Entertain ment could step in at the last minute with a dramatic deci sion to prevent what could be considered a national ca lamity in a country in which the theater is in a coma. But, from the way things look, nothing of the kind will hap pen. Nature will have to take its course.

title: Soviet Official Visits Hanoi
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15 (AP)Dep uty Foreign Minister Nikolai P. Firyubin of the Soviet Union is in Hanoi, North Vietnam's official press agency repoted today. The agency said Mr. Firyubin and a delegation were welcomed upon their arrival Friday by Foreign Ministry of cials.

title: Soldier Set on Fire Jan. 13 Dies in San Antonio Center
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 15 (AP)Pvt. Ronnie D. Wil liamson of the Army, who told the military authorities that two men had set him afire, died today at the Brooke Army Med ical Center.

title: Wells College Clubs to Hold Theater Party
description: The Wells College Clubs of New York, Long Island, Westchester and Northern New Jersey will hold a joint theater party the evening of Feb. 28 at the first preview of Sam Shephard's rock mu sical, Operation Sidewin der, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: ... While the Palestinians Wait
description: Peace in the Middle East does not depend only on Israel and Egypt. President Nasser pointed to an ad ditional important element when he said, If the problem of the Palestinians, of the refugees, is not solved, there will be no peace. All the governments involved in the search for a settlement in the Middle EastArab governments includedhave for too long brushed aside the aspirations of the Palestinians them selves. Their emerging national consciousness is prob ably the most significant new development in the region since the 1967 war.

title: Gruening Scores War Aims At Rally Near White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Several hundred persons gath ered this afternoon in Lafayette Park, across the street from the White House, to hear former Senator Ernest Gruening of Alaska and others denounce the Nixon Administration's policy on the Vietnam war and other issues.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Australian Autos Finish 1, 2 In 6th Tasman Cup Race
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 15 (AP)Kevin Bartlett and Max Stewart of Australia, driving Mildrens, finished one, two today in the sixth round of the 1970 Tasman Cup auto racing Mike Campbell was 10th in a championship.

title: Heroin Epidemic Hits Schools
description: I wish she didn't have to go back to school, a woman said recently about her 15 yearold daughter. That's where she was hooked. That's where she started using dope, in school.

title: BLUES GAIN DRAW WITH STARS AT 33
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 15 (AP)  Minnesota's Danny Lawson and St. Louis's Terry Crisp exchanged unassisted goals in the final three min utes today as the North Stars and Blues fought to a 33 Na tional Hockey League tie.

title: WINFIELD ARONBERG
description: Winfield E. Aronberg, a law yer, who had offices at 299 Madison Avenue, died here yes terday. He was 68 years old and lived at 106 Lexington Avenue.

title: L.I.R.R. to Use Loan for Housecleaning
description: Walter L. Schlager Jr., presi dent of the Long Island Rail Road, said yesterday that the railroad's plans for spending the $5.5million it hopes to ob tain as a loan from the state would include a good deal of painting and a darn good over hauling for the commuter coaches.

title: Survivor of Nazi Camps Recalls Era in Paintings
description: Prague TerezinAuschwitz SchwarzheidePrague. Dec. 1, 1941, to May 10, 1945.

title: Jill Peabody Married Here To Leon Uris
description: Leon Uris, the novelist, and Miss Jill Peabody, a photog rapher, both of Aspen, Colo., were married here yes terday. Rabbi Herbert Fried man performed the ceremony at the Algonquin. Brian Wal lach sang a wedding march with music by Walt Smith and lyrics by Mr. Uris, which will be incorporated in Ari, their musical based on the bridegroom's bestselling nov el. Exodus. The show is slated for presentation on Broadway this year.

title: Advertising: Ketchum Chooses a President
description: Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove has promoted the general manager of its Pittsburgh headquarters office to presi dent. William H. Genge, who has been an executive vice president, takes that title from Edward T. Parrack, who moves up to chairman but re mains thief executive.

title: Prague to Pull In Reins On Slovakis's Autonomy
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 15Slovaks, who fought and Avon their long struggle a year ago to become an equal partner with the Czech majority, are about to lose some of their autonomy.

title: Nixon Tariff Decisions Awaited as Policy Clue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15With little public notice, Presi dent Nixon is moving rapidly toward a pair of trade policy decisions that are likely to be taken at home and abroad as a signal of his philosophy. Before the end of this month the President must decide on a major escape clause case, sheet glass, and a relatively minor one, pianos.

title: MRS. HOWARD RESNICK
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Feb. 16Mrs. Diana Resnick, direc tor of the JohnPlatt Realty Corporation, died today at the YaleNew Haven Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived on Fairgrounds Road. Mrs. Res Inick, a sculptor, was the wife of Howard B. Resnick, a law yer with Weissman & Weiss man in Waterbury.

title: Mrs. Marvel, Envoy's Widow, Is Remarried
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 Mrs. Gwladys Hopkins Mar vel, widow of Josiah Marvel, former Ambassador to Den mark, was married today to Dr. Frank Abercrombie Elliott. The bridegroom, a native of South Africa, is director of the neurological department at the Pennsyl vania Hospital and professor of neurology at the Univer sity of Pennsylvania. The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church here was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ernest A. Harding, the rector.

title: U.S. Oil Industry Not Panicking on Mideast
description: Middle East experts for the major oil companies are con vinced that the political sit uation in the Arab world is more critical than at any time since the 1967 war, but they are not panicking about the prospects for their indus try in the area.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: RocketLightning Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The Environmental Science Services Administration said today that its research labora tories in Boulder, Colo., were studying lightning hazards to rockets. The work is being done for the National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion.

title: Screen: Of Sin and Death:Yugoslav's 'An Event' Is Based on Chekhov
description: VATROSLAV MIMICA'S "An Event," which opened yesterday at the 34th Street East Theater, presents a curious case in that it goes from very good to very bad in relatively well-marked stages. Even at its best, it is a skillful and careful rather than an adventurous movie, and seeing "An Event" is a little like watching what appears to be the first-prize work of a film school valedictorian at the beginning, degenerate into the last act of a high school play by the end.Mimica, born in 1923, is one of the older of the Yugoslav directors, and one of the few to have had any exposure here. "Kaya, I'll Kill You," his sixth feature, played at the 1968 New York Film Festival and opened commercially last year. "An Event," which, like "Kaya," is a murder movie, is based on a Chekhov story, and the demands of the fiction ultimately do more to hinder than to help the director's generally interesting visual program.A boy and his grandfather set out for market to sell a horse. The way, which leads through a forest, is misty and menacing, and they arrive only after having just escaped a stray wolf. With money from selling the horse, they start back in plenty of time to reach home before nightfall. But soon they are overtaken by an evil gamekeeper and his friend, "Sin and Death," the local ferryman calls them, and the grandfather gives the boy the money, and he sends him on alone.Everything so far in "An Event" works  even down to the greenish color photography, which, probably unintentionally, casts an aura of unreality over the most familiar objects and actions. This part of the film is concerned with premonition, and, in the face of jet planes, cars, radios, and the standard modern paraphernalia, with presenting, quite without condescension, a community for which "premonition" is a viable state of mind. Mimica, therefore, plays around the edges of the supernatural, in which he succeeds admirably, so juxtaposing faces and landscapes, close-ups and long shots, as ever so slightly to animate his world beyond the requirements of specific events.But events take over, and the film begins living up to its name too energetically. Spectral quality is supplanted by violent action, which is not Mimica's forte. When the assailants confront the grandfather, supernature gives way to human nature. And for the closing coincidences, in the gamekeeper's cottage, with his wife and daughter and friend, and with the grandson hidden in his loft, "An Event" descends to horrendous melodrama. At the bloody climax, a handy transistor radio blares out a Beethoven symphony, but nothing can hide the natural affinity of this material for the lower reaches of grand opera.At the head of the fine cast, Pavle Vuisic as the grandfather and Sergio Mimica as the son perform with a generic truthfulness that looks second nature but must be achieved art, and that seems typical of recent Yugoslav movies. And for the time that she remains an enigma, Neda Spasojevio, the gamekeeper's young wifepretty, slatternly, kindly and suspiciousis the perfect image of what you might dream and fear to find in a little cottage in the deepest forest just as light is failing and, with it, all hope of safety.

title: Clay, in Vocal Form, Is Looking to Rock Frazier
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 Two shows brought down the house at the aged Arena to night, both put on by Phila delphians. Joe Frazier, the new undisputed heavyweight champion, scored first, but Cassius Clay, his predecessor, may have racked up as many points shortly afterward.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: IT is unlikely that the source of the oil slick that killed nearly 1,000 waterfowl off the south shore of Martha's Vineyard Island, Mass., re cently will ever be identi fied, according to a spokes man for the Federal Pollution Control Agency.

title: Graebner and Ashe Win but Riessen Bows in U.S. Tennis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 16 (AP)Roy Emerson of Australia and Clark Graebner of New York advanced with four other seeded players in the $50.000 national indoor open tennis championships today.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ADULT EDUCATION

title: Worldwide Interests
description: Epidemiologists  scientists who deal with epidemicsnec essarily think in broad terms, but Dr. Frank George Bou dreau's concerns were often global in scope.

title: P.S.C. TO CONSIDER 10.4% PHONE RISE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16The Pub lic Service Commission has de cided to consider granting the New York Telephone Com pany an interim rate increase of 10.4 per cent, pending final determination of how much more money the utility needs to make a reasonable return on its investment.

title: Hovhaness Composition Uses Songs of Whales
description: The songs of whales will be used in an orchestral work to be given its world premiere on June 11 during the New York Philharmonic's eighth season of Prome nades. The piece, by Alan Hovhaness, is called And God Created Great Whales.

title: LOUIS PAUL, AUTHOR OF 13 NOVELS, DEAD
description: Leroi Placet, an author known as Louis Paul, died last Friday after a long illness in his home at 8470 129th Street, Kew Gar dens, Queens. He was 68 years old.

title: SYMINGTON UPSET BY NUCLEAR DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Senator Stuart Symington told the Senate today that he had recently received extraordi narily disturbing Information on the deployment of United States nuclear weapons over seas that, he said, would affect relationships with the Soviet Union and other countries as well as the national security.

title: POWER TRACTORS OFFERED BY G.E.
description: The General Electric Com pany entered the outdoor pow er equipment business yester day with a new line of tractors and home garden attachments.

title: NICKEL FUTURES JOIN IN TRADING
description: Trading in nickel futures opened yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange with two contracts of 2,000 pounds of electrolytic cathodes each being traded at $2.50 a pound for the June month. During the session the December, 1970, contract was traded at $2.35 a pound and that of April, 1970, for $2.40 a pound. There were 45 trades in all.

title: Cerdan Wins in Second Round; Fans Mock Caliber of U. S. Foe
description: PARIS, Feb. 16 (AP)Mar cel Cerdan Jr. easily defeated Pablo Lopez of New York to night when the referee stopped the fight in the second round with the crowd protesting the onesided bout.

title: At Expo Site in Japan: Crowds, Traffic Jams and National Pride
description: OSAKA, Japan, Feb. 12 With characteristic energy, the Japanese are running well ahead of schedule on preparations for Expo '70 complete with characteristic traffic jams, crowds and other minor frustrations.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON ADVANCE BROADLY
Syracuse Suspends Star For Hitting Referee in Game
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Syracuse University suspended its leading scorer, William Smith, a junior, from its bas ketball squad today as a result of his conduct in Saturday's game against West Virginia.

title: Senate Backs Extension Of Disputed Hunger Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)  The Senate voted today to extend the life of its controver sial hunger committee for one year, allowing it to delve into medical and other nonfood aspects of malnutrition.

title: The Children's Penalty
description: Parents, teachers and politicians must all answer to the charge of having made children the pawns of adult controversies and power struggles. As each con flict erupts into strike, boycott or shutdown, the pro ponents of whatever cause appears of overriding im portance at the moment invariably claim that the resulting interruption of schooling is ultimately in the interest of better education.

title: Ecuador Frees Tuna Boat
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Feb. 16 (Reuters)The American tuna boat City of Panama, out of San Diego, Calif., was re leased today after paying $49,650 in fines and other charges after it was caught fishing within territorial fishing limits.

title: Arts in Harlem To Be Subject Of a City Study
description: A study on how best to promote the arts in Harlem has been authorized by the Parks, Recreation and Cultu ral Affairs Administration, ac cording to August Heckscher, the administrator.

title: NET FIVE TRIUMPHS OVER CAPS, 117114
description: CULLOWHEE. N. C., Feb. 16 (AP)  The New York Nets defeated the Washington Caps, 117114, tonight in an Ameri can Basketball Association game.

title: Article 1  No Title
U.S. and Egypt Manage to Get Around Their Breach in Diplomatic Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 For all their current dif ficulties, the United States and Egypt have developed a new form of diplomacy to circumvent their formal breach in diplomatic rela tions.

title: Kaiser Joins Price Rise In Aluminum Building Wire
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation followed other producers yesterday in raising the prices of aluminum building wire by 4 to 8 per cent.

title: State Lottery at New Low
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16 (UPI)  For the third straight month, the New York State Lottery re corded a new low. January sales totaled $3,682,764. Prizes totaling $1,004,800 will be shared by 5,080 January win ners. The group includes 42 Grand Tier priz winners who will win prizes ranging from $100,000 to $1,000. The draw ing will begin here at 8:15 A.M. tomorrow and will continue Wednesday.

title: ST. JOHN'S BEGINS $30MILLION DRIVE
description: St. John's University an nounced yesterday the begin ning of a $30million fund drive to finance 21 new academic chairs, two new buildings on its Jamaica campus, endowment funds for scholarship assistance to students and special com munity projects.

title: EASTERN JETLINER HIJACKED TO CUBA
description: MIAMI, Feb. 16 (AP)A hi jacker lit the fuse on a gasoline bomb to force an Eastern Air Lines jet to Cuba today, the crew members reported tonight when they landed here. The plane carried 104 persons.

title: McLain Misses Day in Court And Subpoena for a Hearing
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP)  Denny McLain the Detroit Tigers' pitching ace, failed to show up for a court appearance in Flint today and was unavail able for the serving of a sub poena involving a court appear ance Wednesday in suburban Southfield.

title: The Lingering Pesticide
description: Environmentalists who rejoiced over the Federal Government's ban on DDT in November reckoned with out the determination of manufacturers even more persistent than their product. Although the ban, which was to have been wholly effective by the end of this year, came after a thorough study by a Government appointed commission, six makers of DDT have launched an appeal process that can take two years to run its course.

title: 15 Seized and 10 Hurt Here Protesting Trial in Chicago
description: Fifteen persons were arrest ed and seven policemen and three demonstrators were re ported injured yesterday when a crowd estimated at 3,000 peo ple paraded in lower Manhat tan to protest the contempt citation in the Chicago conspir acy trial and other acts of political repression.

title: CUBA EXPANDING MARITIME FLEETS
description: MIAMI, Feb. 16The ac quisition of new ships for the Cuban merchant marine and fishing fleet has been an nounced by Havana.

description: COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES

title: Food Protest Slows the Panther Hearing
description: The pretrial hearing of mo tions brought by 13 Black Pan thers accused of plotting to bomb public places was halted for a half hour yesterday as the defendants refused to leavel their cells to return to the courtroom after the lunch re cess.

title: Thant to Meet Jarring
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 16  Secretary General Thant and Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring of Sweden, his special representa tive, will meet in Geneva, Wednesday to assess their roles in seeking to cope with the increasingly serious de terioration of the Middle East situation, a United Nations spokesman today said.

title: Contempt and Response
description: The worst thing about the extremely severe con tempt sentences imposed upon the Chicago Seven and their attorneys is that they serve just the purpose the defendants had in mind throughout of bringing into question the impartiality of the American judicial system.

title: Article 5  No Title
ExHead of F.N.M.A. Drops Dismissal Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Raymond H. Lapin, dismissed as president of the Federal National Mortgage Associa tion by the Nixon Adminis tration last month, withdrew today the lawsuit he had filed to regain the post.

title: CENSUS ESTIMATES ON HOUSE REVISED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Americans are not moving around the country as much as people thought they were.

title: Black Liberation Week Opens With Rally Charging Genocide
description: A series of programs and rat lies yesterday marked the be ginning of Black Liberation Week, a campaign sponsored by the Black Solidarity Day Committee.

title: Sylvan Benefit Game
description: The Queens CollegeSacred Heart University basketball game at the Queens gymnasium on Saturday night will serve as a benefit for Alan Sylvan, a member of the Queens track team. All receipts from the game will be given to Sylvan, who remains in critical condi tion following an airplane acci dent a month ago.

title: Editor Finds An Ugly Mood Against the News Media
description: EL PASO, Tex., Feb. (AP)  The head of the American Society of Newspaper Editors told Texas publishers today that an ugly mood against news media was sweeping the country. He predicted it would get worse.

title: GOVERNMENT SEES JOBLESS AVERAGE OF 4.3% THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  President's Nixon chief eco nomic adviser disclosed today that the Government expected an average unemployment rate in the zone of 4.3 per cent of the labor force this year, with some months higher than that and some lower.

title: Market Place
description: HERE'S a question: What kind of company can pay out more in dividends than it earns but neither flirt with bankruptcy nor alarm its shareholders?

title: South Africa Drops Trial of 22 Blacks and Rearrests Them Under Another
