description: A group of school officials and parents from West Harlem and Upper Manhattan, incensed over a drug case at Junior High School 52 on Monday in which a 14yearold boy died and three others were hospitalized, stormed down to. City Hall yes terday to demand a meeting with Mayor Lindsay.

title: Amerada Hess Profits Declined During 4th Quarter and for Year
description: The Amerada Hess Corpora. tion reported yesterday a de cline in earnings in 1969 to $84,655.776, or 52.38 a share, from the yearearlier 590,558, 213, or $2.40 a share. Fourth quarter earnings were also lower.

title: TV SLATE FOR N.B.A. RAISED TO 28 GAMES
description: The American Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had signed a threeyear con tract with the National Basket ball Association that would in crease the television network's annual coverage from a current minimum of 18 games to a minimum of 28.

title: Russianizing the Arab War
description: The Soviet promise of necessary help to the reel ing Arab states is at the very least a futile gesture that will escalate the arms race in the Middle East and work to the disadvantage of the Arabs. It will render more difficult progress toward the peaceful settle ment that the Russians say they prefer.

title: BROAD PRICE RISE SET ON CHEMICALS
description: The Shell Chemical Com pany announced yesterday it would raise prices by about 6.5 per cent on more than 50 organic chemicals sold by its industrial chemicals division.

title: Silver Futures Decline as U.S. Sells About 1.5 Million Ounces
description: Silver futures dropped yes terday on the New York Com modity Exchange in moderate trading.

title: Chief Justice Burger Scores Panel System for Rating Punishment Over Rehabilitation
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger last night urged American justice to change its emphasis from punishing wrongdoers to helping them.

title: R.P.I. Routs Army Six, 72
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 17 Rensselaer Polytechnic Insti tute scored three goals in 59 seconds tonight and went on to post a 72 hockey victory over Army.

title: Kennedy's Fever Lower
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP)Senator Edward M. Ken nedy, Democrat of Massachu setts was reported to he im proving today from a case of pneumonia with which he was stricken last weekend. Senator Kennedy's fever lingered but was lower, his doctor said.

title: Israel Protests as Greece Puts Off Trial of 2 Arabs
description: ATHENS, Feb. 17An Athens criminal court opened and ad journed indefinitely today the murder trial of two Arabs who attacked an Israeli airliner at Athens airport almost 14 months ago, and Israel quickly protested the postponement.

title: Voloshen and 2 Others Indicted; Defrauding of Company Alleged
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 17A Federal grand jury today in dicted Nathan M. Voloshen, a longtime friend of Speaker of the House John W. McCormack, and two other men on charges of defrauding a Baltimore con tractor of $10,000 in connec tion with a Navy contract.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW BROAD DROP
description: Prices declined on a broad front yesterday on the London Stock exchange. British Gov ernment bonds eased in the wake of a drop in the United States Treasury bill rate.

title: Article 4  No Title
Growth Is Pictured For Textile Sales
description: Textile sales in the next five years will grow from the pres ent $21billion a year at the mill level to $30billion, John P. Figh, the Chase Manhattan Bank's technical director for textiles, predicted yesterday.

title: Electronic Sensors Foil Unseen Enemy
description: TRACU, South Vietnam, Feb. 16Better Killing Through Electronics, said a sign some one had pasted up in the naval operations center of the small hase near the Vamcodong River, 20 miles west of Saigon.

title: BONN AIDE WARNS COMMON MARKET
description: BONN, Feb. 17  Karl Schil ler, West German Minister of the Economy, said today that the European Common Mar ket's proposed economic and monetary union should never be allowed to become an in strument for discrimination against outsiders.

title: TV: Anne Bancroft Show Tonight Is Tour de Force
description: THE viewer who misses to night's special, Annie, the Women in the Life of a Man, will be a sorry set owner. The performance by Anne Bancroft, who has been chiefly noted for her dramatic roles, is truly a tour de force of such a multiplicity of charms, humor and talent that it is almost hard to be lieve. Rightfully, she should be the toast of the country by tomorrow morning.

title: Steel Men Seek Curb on Scrap Exports
description: Officials from 40 American steel companies told the Com merce Department in Washing ton yesterday that the United States should restrict exports of iron and steel scrap because a shortage in this country has been driving prices to the high est levels in about 13 years.

title: Former Litton Officer Named President of Baker Industries
description: Baker Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday the election of Donald A. McMahon as president, chief operating offi cer and a director. Mr. McMa hon, who will be 39 years old this week, joined Baker from Litton Industries, where he was a vice president and president of the Monroe division. Baker is in the protection and security systems field.

title: SENATE DEBATES SEAWAY FUNDING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)Senator Walter F. Mon dale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that the St. Law rence Seaway has benefited the entire nation and should he paid for on that basis.

title: After Game Breaks Open, Knicks' Subs Get Chance to Display Skills
Ship 'n Shore, Shirt Maker, Appoints a New President
description: Richard L. Freundlich, 32 years old, has been elected president of Ship 'n Shore, Inc., the country's largest women's shirt producer, succeeding Wil liam Netzky, who remains director. Mr. Freundlich was previously marketing and ad ministrative director.

title: U.S. SITE SOUGHT BY NEW CHAMPION
description: Another attempt to organize a Cassius ClayJoe Frazier heavyweight title bout will be made soon.

title: Curtis to Seek Reelection As the Governor of Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 17 Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis said at a news conference here to day that he would seek re election.

title: 7 Are Acquitted of Murder In Guyana Revolt Attempt
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, F 17  Seven of ten defendants charged with murders commit ted during an abortive revolt in January of 1969 were ac quitted by a jury late last night. The three others will be retried.

title: Fire in Rush Hour Delays Penn Central Commuters
description: Thousands of homebound commuters using the Penn Cen tral's Harlem and New Haven division trains were delayed up to 45 minutes during the height of last evening's rush hour because of an engine fire at 154th Street in the Bronx.

title: Gannett Company
description: The Gannett Company, Inc., which publishes 34 newspapers and Operates eight broadcast ing stations, announced yester day it had agreed in principle to acquire Federated Publica tions, Inc., of Battle Creek, Mich., publisher of seven daily newspapers, for about $52mil lion in stock.

title: ALBANY BILL AIMS FOR STRICT CURBS ON ALL POLLUTION
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Citing the failure of state agencies to en force laws adequately to pro tect the environment, 41 mem bers of the Legislature introduced today what they called the most comprehensive environmental protection bill in the history of New York State.

title: U.T.W. Wins Phone Election
description: The independent Union of Telephone Workers has turned back a challenge by the Com munications Workers of Amer ica and will continue as col lective bargaining agent for 8,829 downstate commercial employes of the New York Tel ephone Company. The results, of a representation election an nounced yesterday showed the U.T.W. defeated the C.W.A. by 3.813 votes to 1.156.

title: 55 in State Senate Ask U.S. Aid To City Slums as Disaster Areas
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Fiftyfive of the Senate's 57 members introduced a resolution today calling on the President and Congress to recognize New York City's slums as disaster areas and to provide imme diate, emergency Federal fiscal ??id to alleviate inhuman condi tions.

title: Leni Goltz Engaged To G. L. Wilcox Jr.
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo., Feb. 17Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wil liam Goltz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leni Goltz, to George Latimer Wilcox Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilcox of Pittsburgh and Rector, Pa.

title: FOUL SMELL ON S.I. IRRITATES MANY
description: A foul ordersimilar to that of burning rubber  prompted hundreds of Staten Island and New Jersey residents yesterday to complain to air pollution agencies, and fire and police departments.

title: Anouilh a Hit at Brooklyn School
description: The goodlooking young actor walked to the foot of the stage to announce the start of Jean Anouilh's ver sion of Antigone. His ap proach was the signal for polite applause and a few ladylike whistles from the girls of Brooklyn's Prospect Heights High School.

title: GAMBLING SUSPECT GETS 2D INDICTMENT
description: Raymond Marquez, arrested Dec. 10 while on bail pending appeal of his fiveyear sentence for gambling conspiracy, was indicted again yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

title: U.S. Aide in Saigon Denies CounterTerror Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Administration formally told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that despite some illegal killing Opera tion Phoenix  a controversial program in South Vietnam ostensibly designed to weed out Vietcong agentscould not be regarded as a counterterror organization.

title: Rise of History of Science Is a Reply to Technology
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Feb. 17Until recently a man calling himself a historian of science would have had about as much success as an astrologist in getting a job teaching at a university.

title: On Bulletin Board, Pictures of Pupils' Babies
description: THEY climb slowly, laboriously, up four flights of stairs each school day, gossiping and giggling like the schoolgirls they are. They wear the usual uniforms youth: miniskirts, knitted sweater vests, pants and, occa sionally, dashikis.

title: News Summary and Index
description: As Israeli bombers struck again near Cairo yesterday, Premier Golda Meir told her nation's parliament that unless the Egyp tians agreed to abide by the ceasefire, the air raids would continue. They cannot carry on a war of attrition without our reacting, she said. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: 4 MAJOR AGENCIES PROPOSED IN CITY
description: The scrapping of the city's nine superagencies and the re shuffling of existing depart ments into four groups, each under the direction of a deputy mayor, has been recommended in a report to the Institute of Public Administration.

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY GETS M'LAIN DATA
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP)The whereabouts of Denny McLain remained a mystery today with speculation continuing on the role he might be playing in a Federal investigation of gam bling centered on Detroit.

title: Rangers' Kurtenbach Is Ready For Drive on Comeback Road
description: If there has been one posi tive factor surrounding Or land Kurtenbach's spinal fusion operation it is this: The big man has learned pa tience.

title: Colgate Lists Navy Eleven
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 17 (AP)Colgate University and the Naval Academy agreed to day to meet Sept. 12 at An napolis.

title: LOSS OF INFLUENCE ON YOUTHS FEARED
description: Officers of some of the coun trrys leading organizations, meeting to extol the virtues of public service and patriotism, discovered yesterday that many of them shared a fear that their influence over Amer ican youth might be in decline.

title: Pincay Gets Jockey Award
Disaster Funds Allocated
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) President Nixon allocated ad ditional disaster relief funds today to Alabama and Minne sota. Alabama was allotted $400,000 to help with relief from last summer's Hurricane Camille. The allocation to Min nesota, to repair public facili ties damaged by floods last spring, was $275,000.

title: Gibraltar Financial
description: Directors of the Gibraltar Financial Corporation of Cali fornia and the Wesco Financial Corporation have authorized merger discussions between the two companies whereby Gibral tar would acquire Wesco through an exchange of stock.

title: Wilson Names Pollution Aides
description: LONDON, Feb. 17  Prime Minister Wilson announced to day the formation of a nine member royal commission on environmental pollution. Its purpose will be to advise on any aspect of pollution that it is asked to study so that Gov ernment departments can take action.

title: S. Y. Agnon, Israeli Nobel Winner in Literature, Dies
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 17S. Y. Agnon, the Hebrew novelist; who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1966, died this lamming after a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: Leslie W. Scott has been named vice chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee of Fred Harvey, Inc. C.E.S. Burns was named pres ident and chief executive officer.

title: Alitalia Names Chairman
description: ROME, Feb. 17Alitalia Air lines announced today that Bruno Vclani had been named chairman of the board. The company also named Cesare Romiti, president and chief executive officer.

title: Japan to Aid Asian Bank
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Japan will contribute $30mil lion to the consolidated special fund of the Manilabased Asian Development Bank for the 1970 financial year, subject to Parliamentary approval, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Congress to Review CrimeControl Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, stringently criticized even be fore it has become fully op erative, undergoes its first Congressional review begin nine tomorrow.

title: 11,300 More Register in Schools Vote
description: A twoweek extension of the registration period for the schoolboard elections has pro duced 11,319 more potential voters, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.

title: New York Soldier Convicted
description: FORT LEWIS, Wash., Feb 17 (AP)A New York soldier ac cased of injuring himself to avoid duty and then refusing to board a Koreabound plane was convicted on three counts by a military judge late yes terday. Specialist 4 Steven W. Gilbert, 26 years old of Long Island City was sentenced to rive years at hard labor.

title: ST. JOHN'S TAKES MET TRACK LEAD
description: The way the St. John's coach, Steve Bartold, had it figured, only two things were standing in the way of his team and its third straight Metropolitan In tercollegiate track champion shipManhattan and Rutgers. Now there's only Manhattan.

title: HANOI TROOPS GAIN 20 POSITIONS IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 17 Korth Vietnamese troops, de spite what one diplomatic source here today called the most intensive United States bombing in the history of the Laotian war, are reported to have driven Government troops From more than 20 positions in and around the Plaine des Jarres.

title: 3 Killed in L. I. Car Crash
description: ISLIP, L. I., Feb. 17 (UPI) Three persons were killed today when their sedan collided with a fully loaded fuel oil truck on Commack Road and Weldon Lane here. The driver of the car was 73yearold Cesario Darrera of Central Islip.

title: Briton Gets $96,000 For Libel in a Book On '42 Navy Convoy
description: LONDON, Feb. 17The au thor and publishers of a book that alleged that the commander of a naval escort force aban doned a World War II convoy of freighters carrying supplies to the Soviet Union were or dered by the High Court today to pay him 596,000 in dam ages.

title: CHAPMAN MIFFED BY RECORD BOOK
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 17  The orderly keeping of harness racing records did not begin until 1939, when the then new ly organized United States Trotting Association started to function. Since then the sport has flourished, thanks to night racing (1940), the Phil lips mobile starting gate (1946) land the record books.

title: MARKET DECLINES AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stock market, after avoiding a decline on Blue Mon day, slipped lower yesterday. But some brokers on Wall Street were heartened by the lack of selling pressure during the decline.

title: The Controversial Operation Phoenix: How It Roots Out Vietcong Suspects
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17As a controversial opera tion known as Phoenix moves into its third year and to center stage today at Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings in Washington, American of ficals here privately continue to call it one of the most im portant and least successful programs in South Vietnam.

title: HARASSMENT LAID TO CONSUMERISM
description: The Better Business Bureau here, in a marked departure from previous practice, issued a harsh public rebuke to con sumer activists yesterday, ac cusing them of using harass ment, hunch, prejudice and emotion to push business into a deepening decline.

title: Heller Expects Expects Easing of Credit
description: Walter W. Heller charged yesterday that the Federal Reserve had overstayed its 14month policy of severe credit restraint and was on the verge of moving, prob ably within the next month, toward more relaxed con ditions.

title: 8 Dominican Crash Victims Buried in a Common Grave
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 17 (Reuters)The bodies of eight unidentifiable persons killed in a Dominican Airlines crash Sunday were buried in a common grave here today after a funeral service.

title: RATES STAY DOWN IN BOND MARKET
description: The drive toward lower in terest rates remained intact yesterday, both in the corpo rate bond market where a new Bell System issue was given a lowerthanexpected yield and in the money market where the Federal Reserve injected a sub stantial amount of credit.

title: Merchants With Attractive AidesTheir Wives
description: SOME men have all the luck. They're married to women pretty enough to make other men's heads turn but who aren't content to sit around and look appealing. They want to use their brains, too. That kind of wife is likely to be her husband's biggest business asset. Jay Greif and Jean Pierre Zuereb are quick to admit their good fortune. Both are married to blondes whose looks are certified: They are fashion mannequins with incomes figured on a $60 anhour basis. Both men, have recently started their own businesses, a move they say would not have been possible without their wives advice, support and hard work.

title: Board of Estimate Must Set New Vote On Morgenthau Job
description: The Board of Eistimate's vote last Friday to approve Mayor Lindsay's resquest for funds to staff Deputy Mayor Robert M. Morgenthau's office will have to be repeated because of a procedural illegality in the vote, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Big Board Seat Sold
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday the sale of a membership for $275, 000, down $25,000 from the previous sale Feb. 3. The cur rent price of a Big Board seat is $265,000 bid, $300,000 asked.

title: Brandt's Negotiator in Moscow
description: BONN, Feb. 17Last No vember, at the annual Bonn Press Ball, some jour nalist friends from Egon Bahr's newspaper days asked him how he was getting on as the State Secretary of the newly inaugurated Chancel lor, Willy Brandt. Mr. Bahr replied: The title carries the word secret in it. He added: I am quite willing to serve him, but I am always open and I speak my mind to him. Last month Chancellor Brandt appointed the 47yearold Mr. Bahr his special envoy to Moscow on a most delicateand se cretmission: to determine whether West Germany and the Soviet Union could over come 20 years of hostility and distrust to the point concluding an agreement renounce the threat and use of force in mutual relations.

title: Assembly Democrats Seek $330Million Tax Rise
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Minority Leader Stanley Steingut intro duced in the Assembly today a taxreform bill that would generate an estimated total of $330rnillion in additional state revenues by eliminating prefer ential treatment of capital gains, raising the corporate franchise tax and increasing the liability of topbracket wage earners.

title: Army Tops Seton Hall, 7769
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 17Army's basketball team had to go into overtime tonight to subdue Seton Hall, 7769. before 3,300 fans.

title: RULES PANEL VOTE POSES VETO PERIL FOR SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The House Rules Committee refused today to help insure for Presi dent Nixon the authority he sought to reduce education spending he regards as infla tionary.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

title: Air Slowdown Threat Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Negotiators ended the im mediate threat of a nationwide air traffic slowdown when they agreed today to set up a fact finding commission to hear air traffic controllers' complaints. Details of the agreement were not immediately disclosed.

title: JURY TO STUDY CASE OF YONKERS OFFICER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17 The Westchester County Grand Jury will begin an investiga tion Thursday of the financial affairs of the suspended Yon kers Controller, Cline B. Steph ens Jr., District Attorney Carl A. Vergari announced today.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had an early morning meet ing with Republican Congres sional leaders. Later in the morning the President re ceived a report from Defense Secretary Laird on his recent Vietnam trip and saw John J. McCloy, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Dis armament and Arms Control.

title: Moves Asked at Parley
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17  Swift er moves to develop economic ties with Communist China were stressed here today as part of a greatly changed role American business must play in the world trade of the nineteen seventies.

title: CAROLINA SCHOOLS INTEGRATE EASILY
description: Total school desegregation came with grace and style to a predominantly white school district in South Carolina yesterday, but whites aban doned classooms in two heavily black counties in Mississippi.

title: Time to Bury the Dead
description: The failure yesterday of another in a long series of efforts by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, to settle the fiveweekold strike of gravediggers in this city makes intervention by Mayor Lindsay a public necessity.

title: Executive Vice President Elected by Board of TRW
description: The election of Richard D. DeLauer as executive vice president of TRW, Inc., Cleve landbased diversified com pany, was announced yester day following a meeting of the board of directors in Los Ange les. He will continue as vice president and general manager of TRW's Systems Group.

title: Treasury Bonds Exchanged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (Reu ters)The Treasury Depart ment announced today that $5, 938,000,000 of the $6,662,000, 000 of bonds maturing Feb. 15 and March 15 have been ex changed for the three notes in its latest offering. The total figure is made up of $2,253, 000,000 of 8 per cent notes, $1,829,000,000 of 8 per cent notes, and $1,856,000,000 of 8 per cent notes.

title: 3 DEMONSTRATIONS ARE HELD IN MANILA
description: MANILA, Feb. 17Work on reforms was begun by the Government today, while stu dents and workers demon strated to protest what they charged was fascism and cor ruption in government.

title: JOHN F. ALLEN
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 17 John Findlay Allen, president of the National Railway Publi cation Company, which pub lishes The Official Guide of the Railways, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: SHELLING ACCIDENT KILLS 3 AT BIENHOA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 18 (AP) A South Vietnamese artillery bat tery accidentally fired 12 shells into the Bienhoa air base com plex last night and early today killing three Americans and wounding 20, allied spokesmen disclosed.

title: Judge Reserves Judgment In Pro Hockey Assault Case
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 17 (AP) Judge Edward Carter reserved judgment today on an assault charge against Wayne Maki of the St. Louis Blues of the Na tional Hockey League. The judge said in Provincial Court he would make his decision within 10 days.

title: Desegregation Under Fire
description: The resignation of Leon Panetta as chief civil rights officer in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare can only add to the gloom and uncertainty that have recently enveloped the future of school desegregation. The departure of this representative of the liberal view toward civil rights enforcement and the President's silence on his resignation lend added significance to increased segregationist activism.

title: Advertising: Wilkinson Shows The Blade
description: Wilkinson Sword, the Brit ish sword maker that intro duced the first stainless steelcoated razor blade in 1961, has just launched its advertising charge aimed at breaking into the ranks of the new generation of chromiumplatinum alloy blades.

title: $30.7Million Transit Aid Is Voted by State Senate
description: ALBANY, Feb. I7The Sen ate, in a vote that crossed party lines, approved and sent to the Assembly today a bill requested by Governor Rocke feller that would permit the state to lend $30.7million for transit aid, more than $24.7 million of it to improve main tenance on New York City's subway system and on com muter lines in the metropolitan area.

title: Metroliner Uncouples at 110 M.P.H. in Maryland
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A sixcar Metroliner, the fastest train in the nation, uncoupled at 110 miles an hour this morn ing and rolled for five miles before automatic brakes halted the two sections.

title: Peter F. Morse Becomes Fiance Of Miss Fingar
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 17Mr. and Mrs. Claudius DaSilva Fingar have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Batcheller Fingar, to Peter Farnsworth Morse, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Marston Morse of Princeton. N. J.

title: National Airlines Requests Delay in Service to London
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The strike  bound National Airlines asked the Civil Aero nautics Board today for per mission to postpone the start of MiamiLondon service until next June 30.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Visit Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will embark on a college tour March 2 to spotlight offcampus stu dent volunteer projects. In formed sources said the Presi dent's wife would make a four day journey to Michigan State University, the University of Kentucky, the College of the Ozarks and the University of Colorado.

title: British Steel Loss Grows
description: LONDON, Feb. 17The Gov ernmentowned British Steel Corporation, one of the world's largest steel producers, report ed today a loss of $54.7mil lion for its second fiscal year, ended Sept. 27, 1969, slightly wider than the loss of $53.5 million in the preceding 12 monhs.

title: 4 PLAYERS SCORE 18 OR MORE APIECE
description: The New York Knicketbockers gave their fans a treat last night at Madison Square Gar den. With balanced scoring, in which no player hit 20 points, but four got 18 or more, they romped to a 11493 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers before a capacity crowd of 19,500, the 21st of the season here.

title: Who Says New Haven Can't Run on Time?
description: Harried commuters on the New Haven division of the Penn Central railroad may be forgiven for putting two and two together: They had read in Monday's papers that a scotch distributor was of fering prizes yesterday for ontime arrivals at Grand Central Terminal, and the conductors of 26 out of 28 trains qualified for the tro phies.

title: Shelter Bay, 31, Takes Hialeah Dash
DROPPING OF CLAIMS MAY BENEFIT SHALE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) The Interior Department got some help today in trying to unsnarl the tangle of claims on shale lands which could one day become a huge source of oil.

title: Senate Delay on Carswell Likely Until After Vote Rights Action
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that Senate consideration of G. Harrold Carswell's Supreme Court nomination would prob ably be delayed until after the Senate acts on proposed voting rights legislation.

title: Miss Fitzgerald, 18, Is Leaving Fast Competition Behind in 400
description: For Gail Fitzgerald, run ning has provided equal doses of frustration and suc cess. Now she seems on the verge of such great success that she could become the world's fastest woman at 400 meters and 440 yards.

title: U.S. Judge Orders Integration Of All Schools in Pontiac, Mich.
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17A Fed eral judge today ordered schools in Pontiac, Mich., a nearby automotive industrial center, completely integrated by fall at all levelsstudent body, faculties and administra tors.

title: Ashe Leads in Earnings On Indoor Tennis Circuit
description: Arthur Ashe, the leading moneywinner among indepen dent professionals on the United States indoor tennis cir cuit, increased his earnings to $6,400 with victories in the singles and doubles finals at the Fidelity Bankers invitation tournament at Richmond last weekend.

title: MRS. RORERT M'KELVY
description: Mrs. Florence McKelvy, widow of Robert McKelvy, a former vice president of the Tidewater Oil Company, died yesterday in her home at 765 Park Avenue. She was 94 years old.

title: METS REPRESENT MODEL FOR YANKS
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Feb. 17 To the New York Yankees, who begin spring training to morrow with more than 30 pitchers and catchers in uni form, the New York Mets rep resent a model, an inspiration and a challenge.

title: Miss Babcock, William Prather To Be Married
description: KATONAH, N. Y., Feb. 17. Miss Brooke Somerville Babcock, whose grandfather, H. Howard Babcock of New York, is board chairman of the Madison Square Boys Club, plans to be married in May to William King Prather.

title: TEXAS CONTINUES OIL OUTPUT AT 68%
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17Evi dence of strong market demand by all except one major pur chaser led the Texas Railroad Commission today to continue Texas oil production for March at the 68 per cent which pre vails in February.

title: Mrs. Thomas Rudel Dies; Long Prominent in Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Feb. 17 Mrs. Doris Taylor Rudel, wife of Thomas R. Rudel, president of the Rudel Machinery Com pany in New York, died today in Moore Memorial Hospital after a long illness. She was in her midfifties.

title: Lowe Gains Quarterfinals In Squash Racquets Event
description: Art Lowe of the Downtown Athletic Club defeated Steve Rosenbloom of the Columbia Club yesterday, 1512, 1512, 1512, and advanced to the quarterfinal round of the Fow ler Memorial Class C squash racquets tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: BOARD OF TRADE VOTES RATE RISE
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade have approved an increase in commission rates, the commod ity exchange announced today. The increase averages 34 per cent for the board's traditional grain commodities.

title: Surplus or Deficit?
description: A very large enterprise reports a record operating defi cit for 1969. By another set of figures, however, it is able to show a modest surplus of receipts over expenditures. Is it time for the creditors to blov, the whistle and force the en terprise into bankruptcy?

title: Books of The Times
description: REVIEWERS notoriously bring to books their own conceptual carpetbag, as handymen and plumbers bring tools: yardsticks and saws to measure and re duce, drills to bore, pliers to wrench from context, as though the wordpack were either raw material to be fashioned into something agreeable, or a problem, like

title: In Memoriant
description: LEAVYLeonard, Feb. 18, 1966. Cherished memory of my dear husband. All my love. DOROTHY.

title: Black Hawks, Gains In Hockey Scoring Race
description: Stan Mikita of the Chicago Black Hawks, off to a slow start, after winning the Na tional Hockey League scoring title four of the last six sea sons, has moved into third place in the standing, with 67 points. He trails Bobby Orr's 85 and Phil Esposito's 73, according to the official statistics issued yes terday for games through last Sunday.

title: City Vows Speedier Trials To Ease Prison Crowding
description: A speedup in trial of crimi nal cases was promised yester day to combat an overcrowding crisis in the city's prisons.

title: Field Narrows in Race For McDonald's Account
description: The McDonald's Corpora tion, Chicago, sticking close to its schedule for picking a new agency for its $5million advertising account, yester day announced the three finalists that were chosen from the eight competitors. They are Foote, Cone & Beld ing; Needham, Harper & Steers, and Young & Rubi cam. According to Paul D. Schrage, vice presidentmar keting, the first two agencies were represented by their Chicago offices and Y. & R. by people from both Chicago and New York.

title: Music: Berio's This Means, That
Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: 100 PUERTO RICANS DISRUPT COLLEGE
description: Officials of Bronx Commu nity College, including the pres ident, were locked out of the administration building for al most eight hours yesterday when 100 militant young Puerto Ricans barricaded the building with chains and ropes. The demonstrators were demanding that the college grant what they called increased recogni tion for their human rights and dignities as Puerto Ricans.

title: Fate of Rent Control
description: The way city housing offi cials and politicians are talk ing at the moment, there is a good chance that New York City's 27yearold rentcontrol law will be relaxed in favor of the landlords this year. The 12w is up for its triannual re newal March 31, and although the politicians' resolve to change it may wither in the heat of the upcoming battle, some of the influential Demo crats in the City Council are now apparently impressed with two hard facts:

title: Japanese Takes On Quixote Challenge
description: TOKYO  Kabuki training and the Don Quixote spirit these are the elements youth ful Somegoro Ichikawa hopes to integrate on March 2, when he makes his Broadway debut in the title role of Man of La Mancha.

title: Robert Neville, Writer, Is Dead; A Former Time Correspondent
description: ROME, Feb. 17  Robert Neville, the American foreign correspondent and freelance writer, died here today of heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Wholesale
description: Unclassified

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change turned in its fourth consecutive loss yesterday as declines outpaced advances by a good margin in fairly light trading.

title: House Group Calls Auto Top Polluter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A group of house members from New York and New Jersey blamed the automobile today as the main polluter of the air in urban areas but disagreed on whether a person needs an automobile in New York City.

title: Narcotics Arrests Here Increase by 56% in Year
description: The city Police Department announced yesterday that nar cotics arrests for 1969 showed a 56.8 per cent increase over 1968 because of the total in volvement in narcotics law en forcement by all members of the force.

title: Savings Agency Is Held UP
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 17 (UPI) A bandit obtained about $2,000 in a holdup here shortly after 9 A.M. today in the Nas sau Savings and Loan Associa tion at 176 Mineola Boulevard. Employes told the Nassau County Police that the man pulled an automatic pistol and forced a teller to give him the money.

title: Catherine Haight of Boston U. Fiancee of Stephan Miller Petty
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 17 Miss Catherine Harper Haight, daughter of John Mc Vickar Haight Jr., professor of history at Lehigh Univer sity, and granddaughter of Hermon D. Smith of Lake Forest, Ill., board president of the Adlai Stevenson Insti tute for International Affairs in Chicago, plans to be mar ried here June 13 to Stephan Miller Petty.

title: City Safety Unit Keeps Eye on Road
description: Hundreds of thousands of little facts  the fruit of 1,502 investigations into automobile accidents last year  have been fed into a Police Department com puter and they sort them selves out into this profile of the most common kind of fatal accident here:

title: U.S. Urges Geneva Conference To Draft Biological Arms Ban
description: GENEVA, Feb. 17The Unit ed Stales called on the Geneva disarmament conference today, at the opening of its new ses sion, to negotiate a pact ban ning the use, production and possession of biological meth ods of warfare.

title: Card of Thanks
description: ALPERTAbraham. We wish to thank all our friends, lodge Brothers, and business asso ciates for extending their kindness and sympathy to us on the loss of our beloved Abe Alpert.

title: Court Tourney Sites Picked
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 17 (UPI) Fort Worth and Provo, Utah, were named today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association as sites for first round doubleheaders in the Midwest basketball tournament March 7.

title: Phones Out in White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17  Telephone service for 3,300 cus tomers here was interrupted today when a piledriver acci dentally cut through four major cables, a spokesman for the New York Telephone Company said.

title: CHICAGO 7 DEFENSE ASKS FOR MISTRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17Defense attorneys in the Chicago con spiracy trial filed a motion for a mistrial this afternoon on the presumption that the jury was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Mrs. Edmund Duffy Is Dead; Cartoonist's Widow Was 70
description: Mrs. Anne Duffy, an artist and widow of Edmund. Duffy, Pulitzer Prizewinning cartoon ist for The Baltimore Sun, died Sunday in San Juan, P. R. She was 70 years old.

title: Space Officials Favor End to Apollo Quarantine
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Space officials today rec ommended that the 21day quarantine for astronauts re turning from the moon be dropped for the Apollo 13 mission.

title: Uprising on Capitol Hill
description: Even rebellion, when it breaks out in the House of Representatives, must take a staid and highly impersonal form if it is to have half a chance of success. For that reason one of the two uprisings planned for today, Representative Jerome R. Waldie's attempt to unseat Speaker John McCormack, is expected to be overwhelmingly defeated. But the othera soft, almost bland, resolutionjust might herald the end of seniority, that most obstructive of all Congressional customs.

title: Appeal in Anastasia Case Rejected in West Germany
description: KARLSRUHE, West Ger many, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Anna Anderson will have to stay plain Mrs. John Manahan and not be known as Grand Duchess Anastasia, the West German Supreme Court ruled today in rejecting her 50year old claim to be the heir to Rus sian throne.

title: SINATRA TESTIFIES IN JERSEY INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17  Frank Sinatra testified for more than an hour here tonight before a hastily summoned, ex traordinary closed session of the State Commission of In vestigation, which asked him what he knew about organized crime and official corruption in New Jersey.

title: United Nuclear and A.E.C. Agree on Uranium Cutback
description: The United Nuclear Corpora tion announced yesterday an agreement with the Atomic Enegery Commission canceling deliveries of 1,792,000 pounds of uranium concentrate to the A.E.C. this year.

title: Theater: A Fitting Tribute to Moliere
Two Jima Rites Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The Marine Corps will mark the 25th anniversary of the battle of Iwo Jima with a cere mony Thursday at the Marine Corps War Memorial in nearby Arlington, Va.

title: Spread of Deadly Viral Fever Is Suspected in Nigeria
description: The American scientists who discovered the virus that causes Lassa fever suspect that there is now an outbreak of the lethal disease in Jos, a tin min ing town in northern Nigeria

title: Emerson Toppled by Curtis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 17 Peter Curtis of England en gineered the first major upset of the national indoor tennis open tournament tonight by de feating Roy Emerson of Aus tralia, 63, 64, in a second round match.

title: Article 5  No Title
GAS PIPELINE SAFETY CALLED INADEQUATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The National Transportation Safety Board today urged the Federal Government to upgrade natural gas pipeline safety standards to protect the nation's 40 million gas users.

title: NETS' LATE SURGE SUBDUES COUGARS
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 17 (UPI)The New York Nets, paced by Walt Simon's 22 points, defeated the Carolina Cougars, 108103, tonight after trailing most of the American Basketball Association game.

title: 5 CHARGES UPHELD AGAINST TRAINER
description: The New York State Racing Commission announced yester day the suspension of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson as an owner and trainer of thoroughbreds for 45 days, beginning on March 10. That date marks the opening of the 1970 racing sea son in New York State.

title: Theater: Robert Marasco's Child's Play Opens
description: WHEN a young playwright with his first Broadway play appends a quotation from Sophocles to it, you may feel that he is revealing a confidence fringing on the hubristic. Robert Marasco, whose Child's Play opened to a hero's welcome at the Royale Theater last night, may be no Sophocles but he has written a wonderfully powerful melodrama that will thrill audiences for a long time to come.

title: School Chiefs Decry Lack of Funds as Costs Rise
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17 Some 25,000 educators and school district officials meeting here seem agreed on one thing: Their school systems do not have enough money to meet rapidly expanding needs and costs.

title: Stage: Jules Feiffer's White House Murder Case
description: JULES FEIFFER is a very funny, very savage man. A comedian with a con science is always a danger ous fellow to have around. In The White House Murder Case, which opened last night at the Circle in the Square and which I saw at a preview, Mr. Feiffer takes a mansized swipe at our modern society.

title: Vietnamese Says G.I.'s Killed Children
description: A woman who said she survived a massacre in the area of Songmy in South Vietnam said yesterday that American troops had entered her hamlet and had begun shooting chil dren.

title: Erle Stanley Gardner Is Ill
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Feb. 18 Erle Stanley Gardner, the de tectivestory writer who has turned out more than 140 books, wns reported in just fair condition today at River side Community Hospital. Mr, Gardner, who is 80 years old, was brought here three weeks ago from his ??

title: MRS. CHARLES SPOFFORD
description: Mrs. Carolyn Storrs Spofford, wife of Charles M. Spofford, a partner in the law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell and vice chairman of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, died Tuesday at her home, 120 East 78th Street. Her age was 62.

title: State May Soon Gain Bluebird as Symbol
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18  New York has a number of symbols: There's a flower (the rose), a tree (the sugar maple), a gem (the garnet), and a motto (Excelsior or ever upward).

title: 8 PREMIERES HEARD IN MUSIC PROGRAM
description: Robert Russell and Ludmila Ulehla, the two composers whose works made up a pro gram at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, are alike in that both  as their music demonstrates  are experienced hands and aware of the subtleties of their craft.

title: Francis Boylon, 58, Is Dead; Headed Crown Zellerbach
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (AP)Francis O. Boylon, presi dent and chief executive officer of the Crown Zellerbach Cor poration, died yesterday, ap parently of a heart attack, at Boca Raton, Fla. He was 58 years old.

title: Girlfriend, Story Of Generation Gap, Offered in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 19David Percival's Girlfriend, at the Apollo Theater, is the latest of a long line of plays designed to keep the West End public pain lessly abreast with modern youth.

title: Nixon Says Soviet Missile BuildUp Raises Concern Over Moscow's Intentions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  The continuing buildup of So viet missiles is causing grave concern within the Nixon Ad ministration over the prospects for halting the arms race, the President said today in his for eign  policy message to Congress.

title: 3 FLORIDA SCHOOLS TO STAY ALL NEGRO
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP)  A Federal Court of Appeals has ordered a Florida county to implement a neighborhood pupil assignment plan that would leave intact three all Negro schools.

title: U.S. Backs GATT on Trade Liberalization
description: GENEVA, Feb. 18  The United States announced to day its support of proposals designed to start a major international attack on bar riers to world trade in 1971.

title: State Unit Puts Forth Proposal To Increase Racing Attendance
description: Suggestions calculated to in crease attendance at Aqueduct and. Belmont Park are con tained in the annual report of the New York State Racing Commission.

title: N.Y.U. QUINTET FACES CARR, IRISH TONIGHT
description: Austin Carr, one of the most discussed collegiate basketball stars, moves into Madison Square Garden tonight as a vital cog on the Notre Dame team that faces New York Uni versity in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: ADS BY GODFREY ADMIT POLLUTION
description: Arthur Godfrey has begun making television commercials for Axion that frankly admit the detergent is a water pol lutant, his office said last night.

title: Mayor of Flint Is. Indicted With 2 on Bribe Charg
description: FLINT, Mich., Feb. 18 (UPI) A oneman grand jury in vestigating alleged corruption among government officials in the handling of an urban, re newal project indicted today Mayor Donald it Cronin, a city commissioner and a business man on charges of attempting to solicit a bribe from a con struction company.

title: KING CONFIRMS PLOT BY MOROCCAN REBELS
description: RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 18 King Hassan II of Morocco vir tually confirmed today that new plot to overthrow the Moroccan Government had been discovered recently in Madrid.

title: Brandt Message Received
description: BERLIN, Feb. 18The East Germans tonight confirmed the receipt of Chancellor Brandt's offer of talks with Premier Stoph next month, but charged Bonn with seeking to avoid the basic question of securing peace.

title: Brooklyn Ballplayer Acquires Biggest Fan Club in San Diego
description: YUMA, Ariz., Feb. 18  Al Ferrara is probably the only 13yearold kid from Brook lyn who performed at Carne gie Hall and then went on to become a major league base ball player.

title: Chess:
description: THE chess buff banks gen erally on Mikhail Tal, middlegame virtuoso, to find a sacrificial coup for a win ning clincher. Two recent ex amples here are from the 1969 Soviet championship.

title: Miss Whitehorn, Penn Alumna, Is Married to Walter J. Minton
description: Walter J. Minton, President of G. P. Putnam's Sons, the publishers, and Miss Marion Whitehorn were married here last Sunday. State Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey performed the private cere mony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: BRANDT PROPOSES TALKS WITH STOPH IN MONTH ON TIES
description: BONN, Feb. 18Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany notified Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany today that he was prepared to meet him for talks in East Berlin any day between March 9 and March 22.

title: 4th Bomb Scare in Queens
description: The Queens County Criminal Courthouse, which contains the offices of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell, was evacu ated yesterday for the fourth time this month because of a bomb scare. A telephone caller said that a bomb had been placed in the building, and Mr. Markell, who had just returned from Albany, ordered a one hour evacuation at 2 P.M. How ever, the police found no bomb.

title: Coast Securities Concern Suspended for Nine Months
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended Kennedy, Cabot & Co. of Beverly Hills, Calif., and two individuals for violating anti fraud rules.

title: SUPPORTERS OF 7 FIGHT BACK TEARS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18Quiet, darkhaired Susan Schultz was on the edge of tears as she slipped through a group of young people and sat in front of the microphones Linder the bright television lights.

title: 3 Armed Arabs Seized at Munich Airport
description: BONN, Feb. 18Three armed Arabs suspected of trying to hijack an Israeli airliner were arrested last night at the Munich airport.

title: Wieczerak Paces Temple To 8055 Rout of L.I.U.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (UPI)  Temple, led by Tom Wieczerak's 19 points, defeated Long Island University, 8055, tonight in a college basketball game.

title: PANETTA'S OUSTER LINKED TO POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Two weeks ago Leon F. Panetta, director of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, was reasonably satisfied with the course that the Adminis tration was taking in school de segregation.

title: AllAmerica Dropout Hits Books Again
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 18 Until recently, James Street had never seen Chicago or Washington or those tall buildings that Texans iden tify with Times Square.

title: Personal Finance
description: Every shareholder, and es pecially the 780,000 share holders of Standard Oil Com pany of New Jersey, should find this formula a handy one to have. It's the easy way to figure the value of rights.

title: Highlights of the Message
description: VIETNAMThe President listed signs of progress: success in the pacification program, greater enemy diffi culties in recruitment and supply, a drop in Vietcong con trol over the rural population. But he also said Vietnamiza tion is still a developing process, and enemy intentions on the battlefield are unclear. He said that the key to peace lay in whether Hanoi wished to negotiate in good faith.

title: Rev. B. J. Ristuccia, 53, Dies; Taught at Niagara University
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 17The Rev. Bernard J. Ris tuccia, chairman of the depart ment of religious studies at Niagara University, died Sun day, apparently of a heart at tack at Mount St. Mary's Hos pital in nearby Lewiston. He was 53 years old.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Redmen Are Victors Over St. Joseph's by 47 to 46
description: Ralph Abraham has nothing against shooting a basketball. The only thing is, he usually has to grab a rebound before he can shoot.

title: ERVIN CRITICIZES RIGHTS DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Under the shadow of a March 1 deadline, a Senate Judici ary subcommittee began hear ings today on voting rights leg islation and immediately be came entangled in arguments over states' rights and tradi tional Senate rights.

title: City, Weary of Winter, Enjoys a Foretaste of Spring
description: Coatless workmen whis tled. Small children, unswad died from leggings and mit tens, babbled with joy. Over coat buttons were undone and mufflers pocketed. Hum mocks of begrimed snow dwindled into oily puddles. In Central Park, a young man and a young girl walked hand in hand across the deserted Mall.

title: Explorers Club To Hail Alaska At Feb. 27 Fete
description: The Explorers Club dinner on Feb. 27 at the Waldorf Astoria will salute Alaska.

title: Desegregation RollCalls
Dublin Gallery Fills a Cultural Gap
description: DUBLIN  Ten years ago the National Gallery of Ire land was a more or less mori band Victorian institution with just a trickle of visitors to view its rich art treas ures. Today this premier gal lery has become a hub of cultural life and is now visit ed by thousands including many parties of American and British tourists.

title: Duke Quintet Turns Back Davidson in Overtime, 7976
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 18 (UPI)  Randy Denton's 321 points and 13 rebounds led Duke to a 7976 overtime bas ketball victory over 10th ranked Davidson tonight.

title: Successful as Banker
description: Mr. Rovensky had a long and successful career as a banker before he became chairman of the executive committee of American Car and Foundry in 1943. He reorganized the man agement and diversified the products of the concern, and became its chairman in 1951.

title: Unheralded Play a Hit, While Gantry Departs
description: The hazards of fortune on Broadway are such that with in four days an unheralded and unsung play opens and proves to be a winner, while a musical in preparation for several years ends its run after four public perform annces and 28 previews with a loss of $400,000.

title: LingTemcoVought Registered Loss in '69 and in Final Quarter
description: LingTemcoVought, Inc., the giant conglomerate, is moving into red ink for the first time since it amassed a group of diversified companies over the last several years.

title: Jack and Jill Luncheon
description: The Nassau chapter of Jack and Jill, Inc., will hold its sixth annual luncheon and fashion show at Carl Hoppl's Restaurant in Baldwin on Saturday. The event, which will include a showing of clothes by black designers, will raise money for the Jack and Jill National Foun dation, a black women's or ganization, and the Associa tion for the Help of Retarded Children. The groups get equal shares of the proceeds.

title: Brooklyn Gypsy Cab Driver Is Shot in Holdup Attempt
description: The driver of a Brooklyn gypsy cab was shot yesterday morning as he struggled with a holdup man.

title: Panther and Chicago 7 Trials A re Denounced at Hunter Rally
description: Hunter College's assembly hall was filled to capacity last night to hear several speakers denounce the verdicts at the trial of the Chicago 7 and con demn the charges here against 13 Black Panthers.

title: Cosmos Landing Reported
description: BOCHUM, Germany, Feb. 18 (AP)The West German Space Research Center said that it had registered today the soft land ing in the Soviet Union of Cos mos 323. The Bochum Observa tory said that the unmanned satellite was launched in the Soviet Union Feb. 10.

title: A COMMUNITY HOLDS DAY OF NO SMOKING
description: BOSTON, Feb. 18Residents of Randolph, a community of Boston, were asked to stop smoking today and to donate the money they would have spent for cigarettes and tobacco to a scholarship fund.

title: U.S. Aides Say Manila Violence Hasn't Hurt Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  State Department officials said that tonight's attack on the United States Embassy in Ma nila was the work of a handful of militant students and had not damaged United States re lations with the Philippines.

title: Oil Slick Cornered Within Tampa Bay; Damage Assessed
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. Feb. 18 (UPI)The remnants of a vast oil slick that could not be brought under control as it slid across Tampa Bay ap peared trapped today, and ex perts began assessing the dam age to fish, birds, beaches and boats.

title: Soviet Quits European Writers' Group
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18The So viet Union disclosed today that it had withdrawn from the European Community of Writ ers, an organization promoting an exchange of EastWest ideas, because of the group's criti cism of the expulsion of Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn from the Soviet writers union.

title: Senate Leaders Praise Message to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  President Nixon's message on the state of the world was generally received favorably today by Senate leaders.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: VISITORS to Florida's Ever glades National Park who want something more than the usual water and land tours now have a fully charted and marked 99mile wilder ness waterway from Flamingo to Everglades City.

title: Main Author of Policy Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The quickest way to empty a crowd from the Orange Bowl, said a pudgy, bespectacled man seated there one day last fall, would be for the public address system to announce: Tele phone call for Mr. Kissin ger. The man who made the observation was Henry Alfred Kis singer, the 46 yearold Presiden tial Assistant for National Security Affairs. The remark may have overstated the extent to which the public identifies the Germanborn Harvard professor as a Dr. Strange love of the Nixon Adminis tration. But it was a fair expression of the time he spendson the telephone and in persontalking to Presi dent Nixon, and of Mr. Kis singer's own attempts to make light of his role.

title: Philadelphia Tax Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (UPI) Angelo Bruno, a reputed Mafia leader; his wife, Sue; a tax accountant, and a lawyer pleaded not guilty yesterday on charges of conspiracy to cheat the Government out of $46,000 on Mrs. Bruno's 1965 incometax return.

title: ExL. I. Bank Aide Indicted On Embezzlement Charges
description: A former assistant vice pres ident and manager of the Plain view branch of the Long Island National Bank was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brook lyn yesterday on charges of having embezzled in excess of $1,000.

title: Market Place:
description: EVERY once in a while a member of the Wall Street community wants to let his hair down but will do so only if he is assured that he can have his say without being identified.

title: GREYHOUND VOTES ARMOUR PURCHASE
description: Stockholders of the Grey hound Corporation approved yesterday a previously proposed plan to purchase substantially all of the common stock and 4 per cent convertible debentures of Armour & Co. owned by Gen eral Host Corporation.

title: FORD MOTOR REPORTS 1,600 MORE LAYOFFS
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it had laid off 1,600 workers at its auto parts manufacturing bringing total layoffs in the corpora tion to 7,000.

title: RURAL LIFE CHOSEN BY MOST IN A POLL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 18 Six of 10 adults living in the nation's metropolitan centers would move to less urbanized areas if they could live any where they wished, the Gallup Poll reported today. The four of 10 remaining like it where they are, according to the poll.

title: Egypt Opens Major AntiU.S. Drive
description: CAIRO, Feb. 18  The Unit ed Arab Republic has under taken a worldwide diplomatic campaign accusing the United States of responsibility for Is raeli air attacks against civilian targets in this country.

title: WELFARE PROPOSAL GAINING IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINTGON, Feb. 18 (UPI)  President Nixon's proposed welfare breakthroughs  mini mum annual incomes for work ing families  showed new strength in Congress today. Sources expected approval soon by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Alcindor Paces Bucks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (UPI)Lew Alcindor scored 12 of his 26 points in the second quarter tonight and led the Milwaukee Bucks to a 109102 National Basketball Association victory over the San Francisco Warriors.

title: School Will Remain Closed In Rahway Until Tuesday
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Feb. 18 (UPI)Racially troubled Rah way High School will remain closed until next Tuesday, to give parents, teachers and stu dents time to work out pro grams to ease the tense atmos phere.

title: Brown Beats Princeton Six
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 18 John Bennett scored three goals and his brother, Curt, had three assists as they led Brown to a 71 victory over Princeton in an Ivy League hockey game tonight.

title: Speedier Criminal Justice
description: The peculiar ways in which American communities arrive at desirable social reform are well illustrated by the factors underlying Mayor Lindsay's commend able pledge to speed up trial in criminal cases and to ease imprisonments for lack of bail. For many years public and private investigating groups at the Federal, state and local level have been warning that a principal element in the mounting crime rate is the deplorable overcrowding in many jails and the general atmosphere of degradation that surrounds prison life.

title: NIXON'S REPORT TO CONGRESS ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Following, as made public by the White House, is the text President Nixon's first annual foreignaffairs message to Congress, which was submitted today. under the title United States Foreign Policy for the 1970's: A New Strategy for Peace:

title: ThirdRanked Team Routs St. Francis for 18th, 8757
description: St. Bonaventure's third ranked basketball team breezed to its 18th victory of the sea son last night in the 69th Regi ment Armory, routing St. Fran cis, 8757.

title: ACCOUNTANTS ASK STIFF NEW RULES
description: The public accounting pro fession proposed yesterday that stiff new rules be adopted to prevent corporations from changing their accounting methods to improve their earn ings results.

title: Burns Says Money May Re Gradually Eased This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Arthur F. Burns, the new chair man of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that if the economy followed the path currently foreseen both by himself and by Administra tion economists, then monetary policy could be progressively loosened during the course of this year.

title: BARYARD NEIGHS POSTPUSEY YEARS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 As Harvard University moves into what its retiring president, Nathan M. Pusey, calls a fresh chapter in its history, the cam pus has begun to speculate on what kind of a man should be sought to lead it.

title: A Sense of Menace Lurks in Dramatist
description: If a mysterious atmosphere of evil broods over all the action in Robert Marasco's first drama, Child's Play, it is not mysterious to the author.

title: Kopechne Inquest Report And Transcript Are Filed
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 18 (UPI)  District Court Judge James A. Boyle filed today his inquest report and a transcript of the testimony in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne in Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy's car. The documents were not made public.

title: Cornell Six Wins No. 19
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. 18Cornell's hockey team re mained undefeated tonight by defeating Penn, 111, for its 19th victory. Richard Bertrand, with two goals and one assist, and Brian McCutcheon, with goal and three assists, led the Big Red attack.

title: Thant, in Geneva, Urges Halt in Tests Of Nuclear Arms
description: GENEVA, Feb. 18Secretary General Thant of the United Nations today urged the United States and the Soviet Union to declare a moratorium on the testing and deploying of stra tedic nuclear weapons.

title: ARTURO ALESSANDRI, CHILEAN LAW DEAN
description: Arturo Alessandri Rodriguez, former dean of faculty of law of the University of Chile, died here Friday of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: $15,000 Tapestry Stolen From Fordham Center
description: A tapestry by Sylvia Carewe was stolen last night from an exhibition at the Campus Center of Fordham University in the Bronx.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Long Cites Trend to Protectionism
description: GENEVADo the major powers want to carry on on the basis of worldwide free trade, or is the world going to be carved up into regional groupings based on discrim inatory preferential arrange ments?

title: Agency Course Set for Minorities
description: Although not many of its members would like to admit it, the New York advertising industry can learn something from the Chicago crowd. And one thing is how to train minoritygroup members for professional agency jobs.

title: SOVIET IS WARNED ON CONFRONTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon cautioned the Soviet Union today against any attempts to manipulate Middle Eastern tensions for its own greatpower interests.

title: ROBERT A. COOKE
description: VERONA, N. J., Feb. 18 Robert A. Cooke, who retired in 1966 after 30 years as traf fic manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Associa tion, died yesterday at Moun tainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 71 years old and lived at 20 Westover Road.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: The suggestion in your Jan. 31 editorialand in previous editorialsthat the Newspaper Preservation bill could provide a shield to established pub lishers against the entrance of new journalistic competitors ignores the realities.

title: No Motive Found in the Slaying of Army Family
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 18  Army investigators said this afternoon that they had been unable to establish a mo tive for the knifing deaths yes terday of an Army doctor's wife and their two small daugh ters on the base at Fort Bragg.

title: U.S. SETTLEMENT ON LTV SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Justice Department and Ling TemcoVought, Inc., one of the nation's largest conglomerate corporations, are attempting to negotiate a settlement of the Government's antitrust case against LTV's acquisition of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation.

title: Explorer Scout's Body Found in Great Smokies
description: GATLINBURG, Tenn., Feb. 18 Searchers today found the body of a 16yearold Explorer Scout, Geoff Hague of Morris town, Tenn., at the base of a cliff near the TennesseeNorth Carolina line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.

title: Where We Are, Where We Ought to Go
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)Fol lowing is a transcript of remarks made by President Nixon to news corre spondents on Monday during a brief ing on his foreignpolicy message. The briefing was conducted on the under standing that its contents would not be disclosed until today, when the message was sent to Congress.

title: Dr. George A. Manfredonia, Radioloaist in Brooklyn, 62
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 18 Dr. George A. Manfredonia, former director of radiology and president of the medical board at Wyckoff Heights Hos pital in Brooklyn, died Monday in Hempstead General Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 381 Stewart Avenue.

title: Australia, After Delay, Says She Will Sign Nuclear Pact
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 Prime Minister John Gorton announced in Canberra today that Australia would sign the treaty to ban the spread of nu clear weapons, but would not ratify it until her reservations were resolved.

title: On the War: Hopefulness And Caution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18In tensive studies conducted re cently by the Administration in South Vietnam and private re ports from the area have led President Nixon to see tangi ble progress in the Vietnami zation of the war and success to date in the pacification of the Vietnam countryside.

title: Black Studies Unit Voted
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Feb. 18 The Faculty Senate at the State University of New York at Binghamton today approved the creation of an AfroAmeri can studies department to be gin in September. The depart ment will offer both a major and a certificate to those who major in other departments but do extensive work in the field.

title: ROTZ REGISTERS STAKES VICTORY
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18Phil John son a trainer, made an error of judgment today and couldn't have been more delighted. While he expected Naskra to perform creditably in today's $33,350 Everglades Stakes at Hialeah, he warned that the colt was not at his best.

title: 1969 PROFIT DOWN AT FIRST BOSTON
description: The First Boston Corporation, the country's largest publicly owned investment house, an nounced yesterday that its earnings last year fell sharply  to $4,117,765, or $2.53 a share, from 1968's $7,714,255, or $4.72 a share.

title: Tito, in Nairobi, Criticizes Rich Nations on Loan Terms
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 18 President Tito of Yugoslavia criticized developed nations today for the terms on which they grant bilateral loans to developing countries under unfavorable conditions, high interest rates and short terms for repayment.

title: Judge Bars Original Seven As Title for Olympia Novel
description: The Olympia Press was en joined by State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer yesterday from selling a paper back novel called The Original Seven because its title and cover closely resembled Irving Wallace's best seller, The Seven Minutes.

title: Assembly Approves Transit Loan Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18The As sembly today approved a $30.7 million masstransit loan bill, all but $6million of which will go to improve maintenance on New York City's subway system and metropolitan area commuter, railroad lines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We are not involved in the world because we have commitments; we have commitments because we are involved. Our interests must shape our commitments, rather than the other way around."Predident Nixon, in his first annual report on foreign policy. [28:5.]

title: Chicago 7 Cleared of Plot; 5 Guilty on Second Count
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18All sev en defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial were acquitted today of plotting to incite a riot here during the 1968 Democratic National Conven tion, but five of them were convicted of seeking to pro mote a riot through individual acts.

title: State Urban Corporation to Plan The Development of Westchester
description: The State Urban Development Corporation, acting through a new subsidiary corporation, will undertake a countywide hous ing and development program in Westchester County.

title: New Yorker Sets Up Boycott Of Pompidou in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  A House of Representatives mem ber from New York who is organizing a Congressional boycott of the appearance of President Pompidou of France before Congress next Wednes day said today that more than onefourth of house members would stay away from the ses sion.

title: Public Housing Gets the Touch of a Decorator
description: WASHINGTONMrs. Erma Striner has a pleasant apartment with comfortable places to sit and pretty things to see. She thinks that people who live in public housing projects should have the same.

title: Short Interest in a Decline
Miss Olyunina, Soviet Skier, Wins CrossCountry Title
description: STRBSKE PLESBO, Czecho slovakia, Feb. 18 (AP)  The Soviet Union collected its fourth gold medal today when a 27yearold Moscow school teacher._won the women's 10 kilometer crosscountry ski race in the Nordic world skiing championships. Fortyfour wo men from 14 nations competed.

title: 2 Indicted on Drug Charge
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 18 A Linden couple, Rafael Garcia, 32 years old, and his wife, Urbana, 35, were indicted by a Union County grand jury today on charges that theyhad about 400 pounds of marijuana, worth between $200,000 and $250,000, in their possession Dec. 10, when it was discovered at a fire in their home.

title: DU PONT AND NALCO FOLLOW PRICE RISE
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., and the Nalco Chem ical Company announced yes terday they were matching the price increase for antiknock compounds initiated Tuesday by the Ethyl Corporation.

title: DROP CONTINUES FOR BOND YIELDS
description: The current decline in inter est rates gained force yester day.

title: ROGERS STRESSES AFRICAN FREEDOM
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 18Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today at a con ference of United States Am bassadors to African countries that the United States would identify itself with the un finished business of winning political freedom for black popu lations living under minority white rule in southern Africa.

title: $5 Ceiling Imposed On Bank Premiums
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The three Federal bank regulatory agencies ruled today that banks may not offer new savers pre miums worth more than $5 at wholesale. For deposits of more than $5,000, the value of the premium can rise to $10.

title: Washington: For the Record
HEARING ASSAILS THE SMUT 'FLOOD
description: Witnesses at a pornography hearing yesterday denounced the extensive distribution of im moral movies, the public dis play of obscene publications and the unsolicited mailing of offensive material.

title: M'LAIN TESTIFIES IN INVESTIGATION
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18 (AP) Denny McLain spent 45 min utes today testifying before a Federal grand jury investigat ing interstate gambling, Federal officials said.

title: Pro Skiing Gets Chance to Soar With U.S. Television in Picture
description: PROFESSIONAL ski racing, long a redink item in the snowsport's ledgers, may soon be writing in blue. The American Broadcasting Com pany said yesterday it would tape two profesional events this winter. The pictures sub sequently wil be televised across the United States over the net work's Wide World of Sports program. The first show is to be taped Monday and Tuesday at Verbier, Switzerland. The second is to be at Vail, Colo., on March 20 and 21. Both programs probably wil be shown within two weeks after they have ben taped.

title: Panthers' Lawyer Describes Verdict In Chicacio as Sad
description: The verdict in the Chicago conspiracy trial brought a range of contrasting reactions from individuals and organiza tions yesterday.

title: Concerns Act to Provide Protein for Hungry
description: A formidable contributor to the effort to provide protein for the world's hungry has emerged Its a result of an agreement between two large companies  one American and the other Swedish  to form a new corporation, the Nabisco Astra Nutrition Development Corporation, with headquar ters here.

title: State of Emergency Is Urged in Strike By Gravediggers
description: The New York Board of Rab bis yesterday called on Gover nor Rockefeller to declare an emergency in the gravediggers strike as mediation efforts con tinued in attempts to settle the 38dayold walkout.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
description: Blair (John)

title: Dr. Alan Solomon Dies at 49; ExDirector of Jewish Museum
description: Dr. Alan R. Solomon, chair man of the department of art at the University of California at Irvine, died yesterday ap parently of a heart attack in his home at 470 West End Avenue, where he had been confined for several months. He wag 49 years old.

title: SENATE, 5636, VOTES CURB ON DE FACTO SEGREGATION STENNIS HAILS LANDMARK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Senate voted today to cut off Federal aid to school dis tricts that fail to desegregate, even though their racial imbal ance is a product of residential patterns and not illegal.

title: Morgenthau Sworn as Deputy Mayor
description: Robert M. Morgenthau was sworn in yesterday as the city's third Deputy Mayor, and he took the occasion to twit the Nixon Administration for hav ing forced him to resign as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: Rangers and Flyers Play Their Fifth Straight Deadlock This Season, 33
description: The Rangers were so intent on preventing the Flyers from jumping out to their accus tomed early lead last night that they pressed too muchand the Philadelphians scored on the first two shots of the game.

title: 2 LEAFS' RALLIES DOWN CANADIENS
description: TORONTO, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Toronto Maple Leafs ral lied twice tonight to beat the Montreal Canadiens, 53, in a National Hockey League game.

title: 12 Firebombs in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 18 (AP)Twelve firebombs explod ed during the night in three major supermarkets and a drugstore in Puerto Rico, but they caused little damage in the fourth outbreak of bomb ings on the island so far this month. The police said that fast action by store employes had prevented serious damage.

title: Banks Cite Deposit Outflow
description: The 15 largest New York City savings banks had a net deposit outflow of $24.9million in the first 15 days of Febru ary, the Savings Banks Associ ation of New York State an nounced yesterday. This is in contrast to an inflow of $23.6 million in the corresponding 1969 period.

title: Jersey Bank Makes Offer
description: The Central Jersey Bank and Trust Company began yester day offering stockholders the right to buy $4.43million of 6 per cent 25year convertible capital notes on the basis of $100 of notes for each 50 shares held. The offer, to be underwritten by an Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co. group, expires March 9.

title: Head of Teachers' Union Is Arrested While Picketing in Newark School Strike
description: NEWARK, Feb. 18In what was apparently a show of strength and a test of a court order, David Selden, national president of the American Fed eration of Teachers, was ar rested and jailed here today.

title: PROCACCINO PLANS STATEWIDE TALKS
description: Former Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that he was beginning a statewide series of speeches to warn Democrats that the Limousine liberals ... the leftlefts, left overs and leftouts, were de stroying the party's chances to win this year's gubernatorial election.

title: State Senate Calls for Brooklyn Drug Hearings
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18  The State Senate unanimously adopted a resolution today calling for a legislative inquiry into possible dereliction of duty by the police in allegedly failing to thwart narcotics ped dlers in the BedfordStuyves ant section of Brooklyn.

title: NIXON GIVES DURABLE PEACE PLAN WITH GREATER RELIANCE ON ALLIES; CAUTIONS RUSSIANS ON MIDDLE EAST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon set forth to day the fundamentals of a for eign policy designed to achieve a durable peace in the seven ties. The policy commits the United States to a major role in world affairs, sharply quali fied, however, by the President's judgment that the United States should carry less of the burden and its allies more.

title: H. J. Freund to Wed Andrea E. Peterson
description: SAG HARBOR, L. I., Feb. 18Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Peterson have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Andrea Elizabeth Peterson, to Hugh James Freund, son of Mrs. Mortimer Berkowitz Jr. of New York and Remsenburg, and S. E. Freund of St. Louis.

title: METS OPEN CAMP ON TOP OF WORLD
description: St. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 18It was like Alice Through the Looking Glass. On the same field where Marvelous Mary Throneberry and Roadblock Jones had stumbled in dim years past, the affluent young Mets of 1970 opened their spring training season today in sunshine and jubilant com motion.

title: Music: Quartet for the End of Time
description: OLIVER MESSIAEN is a composer more talked about than played. This Frenchman is something of a legend: a mystic, a teacher who numbers among his pu pils Pierre Boulez and Karl heinz Stockhausen, an avant gardist who was experiment ing with postWebern music and totally organized music as early as 1948, an eccen tric, a composer who is eter nally animated by a sort of pantheism that encompasses Christianity, bird calls and the universe itself.

title: Hamilton Makes Right Pitch
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 18It was the first day of spring training today and a warm sun came out right on schedule, and the World Series was still 7 months away, but Steve Hamilton, the senior New York Yankee, al ready had one notable victory to his credit.

title: WELFARE STUDY DRAWS CRITICISE
description: Jack R. Goldberg, the city's Commissioner of Social Services, declared yesterday that most mothers on welfare, as well as his department, believe that employment where feasible should be encouraged.

title: If an Oboe Player Eats There, It's Probably a Fine Restaurant
description: IT IS one of those unexpected and A oblique references you hear over din ner when a certain topic is mentioned, and in this case it was Chinese cooking.

title: TURKS' UNREST HELD TASS'S CYPRUS AIM
