description: ATHENS, Feb. 18A state ment by Task the Soviet press agency, accusing the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of seeking to bring Cyprus under its control was seen by West ern diplomats in Athens today as an effort by Moscow to stir antiNATO feeling in Turkey.

title: McLaren Opposes New Merger Bars; Drop in Rate Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)  The Justice Depart ment's antitrust chief told Congress today that the rate of corporate mergers had slackened in the last year. He said any attempt to legis late tough new restrictions should be delayed until the trend and its causes became clearer.

title: BELGIANS GET PLAN ON ETHNIC REFORM
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18Premier Gaston Eyskens told Parliament today how he intended to re model the Belgian state, found ed in 1830 after the Belgians separated from the Netherlands.

title: Alfred Newman, Academy AwardWinning Composer, Is Dead
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 18 (AP) Alfred Newman, a piano prodigy who became one of Hollywood's most widely known composer  conductors and the winner of eight Acad emy Awards, died yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Advertising: Christmas Club Will Campaign
description: Christmas Club A Corpora tion, no longer content with Helping banks help you to be a Santa's helper, is going into the advertising business.

title: The Making of the President's Message: Many Minds and Hands
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  For three long days last week, six men and a woman sat in the sun outside or around a dining room table inside Villa 15 at the Key Bis cayne Hotel in Florida, a short drive from President Nixon's house, debating the structure of sentences and paragraphs.

title: Manila Rioters Storm U.S. Embassy and Battle Police Near Palace
description: MANILA, Thursday, Feb. 19  Rampaging youths shouting Down with imperialists! as saulted the United States Em bassy last night with stones and flaming objects and then spread out to the welltodo Ermita district, smashing win dows, burning cars and maul ing people who got in their way.

title: 4,800 Teachers in Britain Begin Birmingham Strike
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 18  About 4,800 teach ers began an indefinite strike at 460 city schools today in sup port of national wage demands by the National Union of Teach ers.

title: Peking Accuses Japanese of Developing War Rockets
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 18Com munist China accused Japan to day of developing missiles fort use with nuclear warheads.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Mary O'Brien, Richard J. Roth Planning Bridal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Miss Mary Patricia O'Brien, a master's degree candidate in cardiovascular nursing, and Richard J. Roth, the cofound er of the Edmund Burke School here, plan to be mar ried in April.

title: 13 Seized at U. of Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 18 Thirteen persons were arrest ed today at the University of Michigan while attempting to obstruct five recruiters from the General Electric Company.

title: JERSEY SCHOOLBOY TAKES MILE IN 4:11.3
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 18Joe Savage of Roselle (N.J.) Catholic High School sought national schoolboy mile record today on Lawrenceville School's 10lap board track but had to settle for the fastest indoor mile by an Eastern runner.

title: RAFTS ARE URGED FOR FISHING BOATS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The National Transportation Safety Board recommended to day that all ocean and coastal fishing vessels carry inflatable life rafts sufficient to accom modate all hands and that all life preservers be equipped with waterproof flashlights.

title: EDWARD O'MALLEY, BOOK DEALER, DIES
description: Edward J. O'Malley Jr., an Internationally known used book dealer, died of a heart attack list Friday at his home, 615 West 186th Street. He was 65 years old.

title: LONDON STOCKS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange retreated from the outset yesterday as buyers held back following the decline on Wall Street Tuesday.

title: U. S. Judge, Scoring Conditions, Bids Arkansas Reform Prisons
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 18 Judge J. Smith Henley ruled in Federal District Court today that the conditions in the Ar kansas Penitentiary were un constitutional and that the two state prison farms would have to be closed unless the condi tions improved.

title: Nixon Told Income Subsidy Experiment Supports His Welfare Reform Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  President Nixon was told by antipoverty researchers today that an experimental program of income subsidy among the working poor had provided evi dence that his controversial welfare reform plan would work.

title: Vote on McCormack Is Blocked As House Reform Drive Opens
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  With an inconclusive challenge to the House leadership, Demo cratic liberals opened today a longrange campaign to reform thy, institutions of the House, including the seniority system.

title: Manufacturing Accord Set
description: The Admiral Corporation and the National Union Electric Corporation said yesterday that they had signed a long term contract calling for Ad miral to manufacture all Emer son and Dumont homeenter tainment products for National Union's Emerson Television and Radio division.

title: 5 Nast Paintings Found in Jersey To Go on View
description: Old King Cotton sits on his throne, armed with a whip and fanned by female slaves. Watched by militant South ern leaders, both Napoleon and Britannia deposit their crowns at his feet. A tall figure crowned with horns sits on a shield, a symbol of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: L.I. PLANNER QUITS IN ETHICS INQUIRY
description: MINEOLA, L. Y., Feb. 18 Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Franklin National Bank, re signed today as a member of the NassauSuffolk Regional Planning Board in the face of conflictofinterest charges aris ing from land speculation in Suffolk County.

title: Neighborhoods: Riverside Park
description: It did not look like the setting for a murder. Not at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. In cheery sunshine, strollers and dogwalkers left footprints in the stillwhite snow. Children laughed and shrilled in the playgrounds while their moth ers chatted serenely. Sneak ered men clambered aboard their craft in the boat basin.

title: Screen: Sex and the Candid Camera
description: IN the lives of certain Ameri cans there comes a mo ment when the man who has been patiently conning them pulls off his dark glasses, his hat, his hairpiece, or whatever his impenetable dis guise of the day, and asks, Do you know who I am? And the answer, incredulous at first, and then in a torrent of amazed belief: Why ... you're ... ALLEN FUNT!

title: Memorial Services
description: RAV1DDr. Jacob M., late Chief of Pa thology and Director of Laboratories will be honored by a Third Pathological Con ference at St. Clares Hospital on Thursday, February 19 at 2:30 P.M. Family, asso ciates, and friends are invited to attend.

title: In Mermorial
description: EDELMANEvelyn, Feb. 19. A thing of beauty is a joy forever. Peace beloved comrade. HARRY, NORA, SARAH

title: Airline to Offer General and Mature Movies
description: On Trans World Airlines Flight 1 next Wednesday passengers aboard the Boeing 747 will be watching Robert Redford glide over the ski slopes in Downhill Racer.

title: State Court Rules Protest Must Not Dishonor Flag
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18The State Court of Appeals ruled today that the right of free speech did not permit the use of the American flag in dishonorable ways as a form of protest.

title: BUSINESS LAWYER NAMED TO N.L.R.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  President Nixon announced to day the choice of Edward B. Miller, a 47yearold manage ment lawyer from Chicago, for the post of chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Four Buildings at Amherst Held By Black Students for 14 Hours
description: AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 18 In a protest against five cen tral Massachusetts colleges, nearly 200 black students oc cupied four buildings at Am herst College for more than 14 hours today. They evacuated the building at 3:30 this after noon, saying they had changed their strategy.

title: ST. JOHN'S TAKES MET TRACK TITLE
description: After weeks of saying that St. John's would win its third straight Metropolitan Intercol legiate title, and two days of counting up real and imaginary points; Steve Bartold, the Red men's coach, had to sweat out the final event on the program last night at the 102d Engineers Armory before his prediction would come true.

title: In The Nation: The Death of Integration
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  The Senate of the United States has now cravenly abandoned the policy of racial integration sixteen years after it was born in a Supreme Court decision, ninetyfour years after the. Civil War Reconstruction ended in a similar sellout, and less than a week after President Nixon, on Lincoln's Birthday, gave the signal of surrender.

title: Bridge:
description: THE Omar Sharif Bridge Circus, which has been touring North America for the last month, has been strengthened by the arrival from Italy of Pietro Forquet of Naples, one of the world's greatest players. He has re sumed his celebrated partner ship with Benito Garozzo of Rome. Their teammates are Sharif, Lon Yallouze and Claude Delmouly of Paris, and Giorgio Belladonna of Rome.

title: GAIN IS ACHIEVED IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change posted its first advance in five sessions yesterday. Most issues closed higher in active trading.

title: Swedish Crystal With American Twist
description: MICHAEL LAX'S first encounter with glassmak ihg may have been by acci dent, but his present involve ment is definitely by design.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE ON A BROAD FRONT
description: Bluechip issues and the longdepressed oil group moved strongly in the forefront of a broad market advance yester day.

title: BULLETS TOP LAKERS FOR 3D TIME IN ROW
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (UPI)  Earl Monroe and Kevin Loughery combined for 47 points as the Baltimore Bullets defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 117103, for the third straight time tonight in a Na tional Basketball Association came.

title: The Age of Singing Joe
description: JOE FRAZIER makes a sound like Hripp when he's punching in close. His lips spread and flatten out against his teeth and his eyes grow bright and round. His body moves all over, alive with the sheer sensual joy of combat. His shoulders shrug continuously, he shuffles, snuffles, taps his forehead, jiggles his hips and cocks his elbows, stamps on his toes and stomps on his heels, bends his knees, shakes his waist, flexes his breast, waggles his jaw and turns his head from side to side.

title: ISRAEL CHARGES U.N. SUPPRESSED APPEAL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18The Israeli representative at the United Nations charged today that the Secretariat act ing for Secretary General Thant, had suppressed an appeal by Israel on behalf of Soviet Jews. He said that Mr. Thant's action resulted directly from strong pressure from Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet representative.

title: TeenAger Killed by Narcotics; 2d Youth Apparent Drug Victim
description: A 16yearold football player at James Monroe High School in the Bronx died Tuesday night of an overdose of heroin and yesterday another 16year old died in the Bronx, apparent ly also the victim of a narcotics overdose.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Police Investigating RentalCar Thefts Make 11 Arrests
description: The alleged sale of aircon ditioned 1969 and 1970 Chevro lets for $150 each resulted yes terday in a total of 11 arrests in connection with an investi gation of the theft of automo biles from a carrental con cern.

title: Providence Draws An Entry of 1,268 For Show Saturday
description: THE series of three New England shows that al ways follows Westminster will end with competition in Providence on Saturday and New Haven on Sunday. The Hartford event that began the series was held last Saturday. All three are in the 1,250 dog range.

title: Paris Court Rules Five Have Voice in Le Figaro
description: PARIS. Feb. 18 (Reuters) A Paris court ruled today that five members of the staff of Le Figaro had a right to share in the running of the morning newspaper.

title: East Hartford Marine Killed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Lance Cpl. John Marks, a Marine, of East Hartford, Conn., had been killed in action in Vietnam.

title: Fulbright Committee Is Told Pacification Is Gaining
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)Members of the Sen ate Foreign Relations Com mittee today reacted with hopeand a touch of skep ticismto testimony that pacification was succeeding in South Vietnam.

title: Miss von Stade, a Mezzo, Gives. Concert With George Reid, Bass
description: Two young singers associated in different ways with the Metropolitan Opera gave a joint concert at the New York Cul tural Center last night and showed enough talent to sug gest that the Met is doing something right. They were Frederica von Stade, a mezzo soprano, who is already singing small roles with the company, and George Allan Reid, who has worked with the Metro politan Opera Studio.

title: The Nixon Doctrine
description: President Nixon's 43,000word state of the world message is a unique and usefulif banal and wordy compendium of the Administration's foreign policies and procedures.

title: BELFAST COURTROOM IS ROCKED BY BLAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Irelands, Feb. 18An explosion shook a Belfast courtroom today while five Protestants were being tried on charges of conspiring to blow up a water pipeline in Northern Ireland last winter. Damage was slight and no one was injured.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES POST SOME HIGHS
description: With soybean futures again attracting the bulk of the in terest, trading was mixed and active in all major pits of the Chicago Board of Trade yes terday as prices rose. Several hit new highs for the season.

title: Striking Airline Employes Sue National for Damages
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18. (UPI) The Airline Employes Associa tion announced today it had filed a damage suit in excess of $1million in United States District Court in Miami, on be half of its members who have been on strike against National Airlines since. Jan. 31.

title: FOB E. ROYENSKY, INDUSTRIALIST, 90
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18John Edward Roven sky, who retired in 1954 as chairman of ACF Industires, Inc., formerly the American Car and Foundry Company, died yesterday at the Conval escent Center of the Palm Beaches. His age was 90.

title: PRIEST TO PRESS HUNTS POINT CASE
description: The Roman Catholic priest who was ejected from the City Council chamber two days ago for disrupting the meeting, said he would try today to present his demands at a closed execu tive session of the Council's Housing Committee.

title: Smith, Ashe, Graebner and Okker Beaten in $50,000 National Indoor Tennis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18 Only two Americans were able to advance to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 national indoor open tennis championships to day. They were Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and Jim Osborne of Honolulu, and they play each other tomorrow.

title: Grand Jury Summons 3 Top Mine Union Officials to Testify in Yablonski Murder Investigation
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 18The Federal grand jury investigat ing the murder of Joseph A. Yahlonski summoned three high officials of the United Mine Workers of America today, in cluding the first member of the union's headquarters in Wash ington to he called here in the threeweek investigation.

title: C.B.S. Is Dropping Red Skelton Alter. 16 Years as a TV Regular
description: Red Skelton, the comedian and pantomimist, who on Jan. 29 appeared at the White House to inaugurate a series of evenings of entertain ment at the Executive Mansion, is being dropped next season from the regular schedule of the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem.

title: Broncos Sign Three Players
description: DENVER, Feb. 18 (AP)Thel Denver Broncos of the Ameri can Conference of the National Football League signed three players as free agents today. The three are Randy Cayce, 215pound running back from Wichita State; Wallace Ricpard son, 215pound running back from South Carolina State, and Odell Sumter, a 220pound tight end from South Carolina State.

title: SINATRA HEARING: SHOW OF STRENTH
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18A high official of the State Commission of Investigation asserted today that Frank Sinatra was com pelled to testify here last night primarily because the commis sion was determined to show that it commanded the power to compel virtually anyone it wanted to appear before it. However, William F. Hyland, the commission's chairman, denied that publicity had any thing to do with its efforts to compel Mr. Sinatra to testify.

title: Cameroon to Elect President
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Feb. 18 (Agence FrancePresse) Presidential and Vice Presiden tial elections will be held in Cameroon on March 28. Presi dent Ahmadou Ahidjo, 46 years old, has not yet announced whether he will run again. He has held the post since 1961.

title: SALOMON ASSAILS STOCKFEE CHANGE
description: Salomon Brothers & Hutzler, one of Wall Street's leading institutional brokerage houses, charged yesterday that the new commission schedule proposed by, the New York Stock Ex change was grossly inequita ble.

title: NoFault Auto Insurance
description: It is the singular and fundamental finding of New York State's Insurance Department that present auto mobile insurance policies are, for those obligated to rely on them, unsafe at any speed. The department has just released a carefully prepared report that recommends scrapping the present method of compen sating traffic victims. This recommendation deserves sympathetic attention and action.

title: Jacksonville Tops Fla. State Before 10,050 Fans, 85.81
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Feb. 18 (UPI)  Sixthranked Jackson ville University shook off a full court press by 11thranked Florida State and posted an 85 81 victory tonight before the beggest college basketball crowd in Florida history.

title: HOUSING AGENCY JOINED BY CRITIC
description: After almost 10 years as an outspoken critic of the inade quate housing programs that have accompanied big cities on their road of decline, S. William Green was sworn in yesterday as administrator of the Northeastern region of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT is hard to convey such experiences, writes Robert Coles, such a world, to those who don't see it and feel it and smell it and hear it. It is even harder to describe that world as it is met and apprehended and suffered by hundreds of thousands of parents and children.

title: O.E.C.D. WILL SET POLLUTION LIMITS
description: PARIS, Feb. 17 Norwegians complain that their snow is fouled by air swirling up from the English Midlands. Swedes grumble that their acid rain has been polluted by winds from the Ruhr Valley in West Germany. The Dutch are up set by the wastes pumped into the lower readies of the Rhine from factories in Germany and Switzerland.

title: Leaders of Israel Attend State Funeral for Agnon
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 18 (Reu ters)  S. Y. Agnon, cowinner of the 1966 Nobel prize for Literature, was buried today in the old cemetery on the Mount of Olives.

title: A Policy for Transition
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18For a nation weary of war and other foreign burdens, in a world that seems less menacing if not yet safe, President Nixon has proclaimed a policy to pro tect what he deems vital at price that he deems bearable.

title: Smogless Car May fake Years
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 18Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, Presi dent Nixon's science adviser, said today that it would take 101 years to free the nation's high ways of pollutionproducing automobiles.

title: TV Producers Assail Dropping Of Show Examining U.S. Policy
description: The cancellation Monday night by six public television stations of an hourlong docu mentary critical of American foreign policy was assailed yes terday by an association of public television producers and by James Day, president of National Educational Television.

title: SAMUEL FRANK
description: Samuel Frank, a member of the American Stock Exchange and its predecessor, the Curb Exchange, since 1911, died Tuesday at the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived at 4 South Pinehurst Avenue.

title: NORFOLK RINK LEADS IN WOMEN'S CURLING
description: ARDSLEYONHUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 18The Norfolk, Conn., Curling Club rink, skipped by Mrs. Merwin Ellert, won its first two matches de cisively today for a plus15 score and a 1point lead in the Ardsley Curling Club women's invitation bonspiel at Ardsley Country Club.

title: Overseas Investors Cautioned by Mayo
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18  Hopes of American business for an early end of Government re strictions on direct foreign in vestments were dampened to day by Budget Director Robert P. Mayo.

title: Wilfred Burchett Barred From Australia Again
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 Wilfred Burchett, a leftist Australian newsman known for his reports from the Communist side in Korea and Vietnam, was prevented today from coming to Aus tralia to attend a memorial service for his brother.

title: Strike Threatened at Zoos, Museums and Libraries Here
description: Negotiations to avert a threatened strike at nine city museums, libraries and zoos will be held today at the office of Herbert H. Haber, City Labor Relations Director, 250 Broad way.

title: ROBERT BIRD, 65, NEWSMAN, DEAD
description: Robert S. Bird, who had been a prizewinning reporter on The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times, died last night at Bellevue Hospital after having suffered a heart attack on Sunday.

title: Stamford Girl, 17, Slain in Stairwell; Father a Policeman
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18 The 17yearold daughter of a Stamford policeman was found stabbed to death this morning in a stairwell near her family's apartment.

title: Dolphins Land Shula as Coach With a 5Year, $500,000 Pact
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19 (UPI)The Miami Dolphins dismissed their head coach, George Wilson, to day and named Don Shula of the Baltimore Colts to replace him.

title: Space Agency Seeking Designs Of Engines for an Orbital Ferry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The National Aeronautics and Space Administration took its first step into thirdgeneration space vehicles today by asking the aerospace industry to submit designs of engines for an or bital ferry.

title: Los Angeles Aide Resigns
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb 18 (AP) Louis J. Fuller, head of the Los Angeles County Air Pollu tion Control District since 1965, has resigned at the age of 63.

title: Australian Dockers Strike
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 (Reuters)  Longshoremen in the Sydney, Newcastel and Port Kembla today called a 24hour strike, tying up 60 ships. The strike, which is expected to spread to other major ports, is over demands for higher pay and longer holiday.

title: POLICE ASSAILED ON LEAFLET POLICY
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that policemen here are showing a wholesale disregard for regula tions in arresting persons or issuing summonses for dis tributing political leaflets on the sidewalk.

title: N.Y.U. FENCERS BEAT COLUMBIA, 15 TO 12
description: Paced by the Krause brothers, Walter and Wayne, New York University's undefeated fencing team beat Columbia, 1512, last night before a standingroom crowd of 200 at the Washing ton Square gym.

title: Israel Discloses Tentative Plans To Ease Plight of Arab Refugees
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 18 Israel disclosed tentative plans today to improve the lot of Arab refugees dislocated and caught within her jurisdiction by the 1967 war.

title: B52'S SUPPORTING LAOTIANS IN PLAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP)Informed sources re ported today that B52 bombing raids in South Vietnam had been halted for 36 hours while the planes, the biggest bombers the United States has, went into action for the first time against North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troops threatening the Plaine des Jarres in Laos.

title: HAWKS TURN BACK ROYALS BY 139125
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 18 (UPI)  Joe Caldwell pumped in 41 points tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 139125 overtime victory over the Cin cinnati Royals in national bas ketball association action.

title: 2 SLAIN AFTER FIGHT IN A MIDTOWN BAR
description: Two men were shot and killed and another was wounded in his left leg in a midtown building late last night by a fourth man with whom they had argued earier at a nearby bar. Their assailant escaped.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon in a document transmit ted yesterday to Congress, outlined the fundamentals of his Administration's foreign policy. The document, which is expected to become an annuel report on the state of the world, committed the United States to con tinuing its major role in world affairs, but with America's allies carrying more of the burden. [Page 1, Cols. 58; Text, Pp. 1929.]

title: Brydges Easing Opposition to New Abortion Law
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18  Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Bryd ges, for years one of the most powerful opponents of abortion reform, indicated today that his stand was easing and that he might support some form of liberalization.

title: A.T.&T. REGISTERS ISSUE WITH S.E.C.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company registered its record $1.57billion 30year debenture offering with the Se curities and Exchange Commis sion yesterday. In the process it also filled in most of the unanswered questions about the recordbreaking offering to the world's largest stockholder family, which now totals some 3.1 million persons.

title: Japanese to Reinforce Ships Like Ore Carrier That Sank
description: TOKYO, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Japanese shipbuilders today decided to reinforce 69 Japa nese vessels that are similar in structure to the 62,147ton ore carrier that sank off Japan Feb. 9.

title: Laotian Air Base Attacked
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 18 North Vietnamese supported by tanks mounted their fourth major attack against the air field in the Plaine des Janes last night.

title: Bill Asks Pornography Curb
description: Washington, Feb. 18 (AP) Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Dem ocrat of Connecticut, introduced today a hill to create a bureau of obscenity control in the Post Office Department in an effort to check the flow of pornogra phy through the mails before ?? reaches American homes.

title: Article 1  No Title
Cowboys Sign Safetyman
description: DALLAS, Feb. 18 (UPI)  The Dallas Cowboys announced toady the signing of Denton Fox, a 205pound safetyman from Texas Tech and a third round draft choice.

title: Nancy Barritt To Be a Bride
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18Mr. and Mrs. William James Bar ritt Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Jean Barritt, to James Dudley Clendinen, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Clendinen.

title: P.S.C. Rejects Con Ed Request For a 13% Rise in Steam Rates
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18The Pub lic Service Commission said to day that it had rejected a pro posed 13 per cent increase on the Consolidated Edison Com pany's steam rates and ordered an investigation to determine whether any of the $6.4mil lion in additional revenue the company asked for is justi fied.

title: President Reveals the Components of His Machinery for Making Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18A foreign policymaking apparatus that previously had been largely hidden from public view was revealed today by Presi dent Nixon in his message to Congress on the state of the world.

title: Ford Introduces Tractor to Aid the Poor
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18  A new tractor aimed at poor farmers was unveiled today by the Ford Motor Company.

title: . . . and Machinery to Execute It
description: One of President Nixon's objectives in his state of the world message was to persuade Americans that he has streamlined the machinery and tidied up the processes for the making and carrying out of United States foreign policy. This accounts for his claim to have reestablished and revitalized the National Security Council and his elaborate descrip tion of how, ideally, the N.S.C. system will function.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frederick A. Collins Jr., executive vice president and a director of the Sperry and Hutchinson Com pany, has been elected a trustee of the Harlem Savings Bank.

title: New Haven Riders' Group Opposes Rise in Fare
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 18 (UPI)A group of Connecticut commuters to New York City want to block a fare increase scheduled to take effect on March 1. They also want cleaner cars on the old New Haven Railroad, they said in a statement issued today.

title: Two Jersey Youths Held In Connection With Fire
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 18 Two youths were held in $2,500 bail each today in con nection with a twoalarm fire that extensively damaged the Masonic Temple at 311 Temple Place here yesterday.

title: Observer: Spiro, the Prince and Sophia Loren
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Is it advancing age, the habit of eat ing peanut butter on bananas just at bedtime, or perhaps only February? Whatever the cause, an entirely different class of people has been turning up lately there at the very foot of the day, in that disembodied moment between the last yawn and the first snore.

title: ALGIERS MOTEL JURY GETS DEFENSE DATA
description: FLINT, Mich., Feb. 19The jury hearing the Algiers Motel conspiracy trial will begin de liberating next week after a surprisingly brief offer of evi dence today by the defense.

title: Census Jobs Advocated
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) Martin G. Castillo, chairman of the Cabinet Committee on Opportunity for the Spanish speaking, urged today that MexicanAmericans and other Spanishspeaking people apply for jobs in taking the census in April.

title: Kunstler Attends Rally; Protest Due Saturday
description: CHICAGO: Feb. 18 (Reu ters)William M. Kunstler, one of the defense lawyers in the Chicago conspiracy trial, called for mass street demonstrations against the American legal system when he addressed a protest rally tonight.

title: 8 ExCollegians Enter Football Hall of Fame
description: Eight former college foot ball stars have been elected to the National Football Foundation's Hall of Fame. They will be formally induct ed, Dec. 8, at the awards dinner at the. WaldorfAs toria.

title: Celtics Topple Suns
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18 (AP)  The Boston Celtics defeated the Phoenix Suns, 116113, as Bailey Howell sank two free throws with 35 seconds left in a National Basketball Associa tion game tonight.

title: LABOR MAPS DRIVE TO ELECT BACKERS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18 Organized labor, stressing the importance of the 1970 offyear elections, is planning its most extensive and thorough drive to register members as voters and get them to the polls.

title: THOMAS J. BLAKE
description: Thomas J. Blake of 218 East 61st Street, a corporation law yer, died Monday. Mr. Blake served in the 148th Aero Squad ron in World War I. His clubs included the Cornell, Downtown Athletic, Metropolitan Opera and the Leash.

title: Jesse Gray's Son Charged With Possession of Cocaine
description: The 20yearold son of Jesse Gray, Harlem rent strike leader, and another man were charged in Criminal Court with posses sion of 22 ounces of cocaine.

title: MEXICO STUDY BACKS I.Q. LINK TO HUNGER
description: A group of Mexican children hospitalized at an early age with severe malnutrition has scored lower on intelligence tests in later life than did their siblings who had not suffered from the disorders.

title: Stennis Amendment Scored By Lindsay at Conference
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 19  In commenting here today on the Stennis amendment to the Sen ate's education bill, Mayor Lindsay said:

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: McCarthy Charges Administration Misleads the Nation on Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Sen ator Eugene J. McCarthy, who was a leading critic of the John son Administration's policy on Vietnam, turned his attention to the Nixon Administration today, accusing it of misleading the nation over the issues at stake in the war.

title: For InflationBeset Families on Coast, Affluence Is Still a Dream
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. Jim Schaap is a longdis tance truck driver with bad teeth. It will cost $1,200 to get them fixed, but the fi nance company wants 12 per cent interest to lend him the money and he cannot afford it.

title: EAST GERMANS SCORE BRANDT'S PROPOSAL
description: BERLIN, Feb. 19  The East Germans today renewed their criticism of Chancellor Willy Brandt's bid for openended talks, saying the Bonn leader failed to grant their demand for full recognition.

title: CARSWELL CRITICS ADD 10TH SENATOR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Critics of G. Harrold Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court said today that grass roots opposition to the nomi nation was rising and that they planned to mobilize it to bring pressure on uncommitted Sen ators to vote against confirma tion.

title: PHILLIP SHAW, 60, A READING EXPERT
description: Dr. Phillip Shaw, professor of English at Brooklyn College and a specialist in reading and learning skills, died yesterday in Adelphi Hospital, after an illness of several weeks. He was 60 years old and lived at 3824 Farragut Road, Brook lyn.

title: Staging of News To Be Scrutinized By Panel in House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Periodic charges that certain news reports have been staged by broadcasting net works and stations are under quiet and extended study by a Congressional subcommittee.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Japan's Reaction Is Pride and Disquiet
description: TOKYO, Feb. 19  Pride and disquiet in about equal proportion seemed to char acterize Japanese reaction to President Nixon's report on the state of the world, which called for creative partnership with all Asian nations and said Japan had a unique and essential role to play in the development of the new Asia.

title: Bridal Is Planned By Betsy Jamieson
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Feb. 19Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Jamieson have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Retsy Jamieson, to Thomas Watkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watkins of Montclair. A June wedding is planned.

title: Briton Bids Arms Parley Avoid Snarl on CS Gas
description: GENEVA, Feb. 19  Britain urged the disarmament con ference of 25 nations today to avoid getting embroiled in a discussion on whether a type of riot control gas known as CS should be outlawed as a chemical, weapon.

title: End Paper
description: The new decade hasn't even signed in at the history desk, and here is Geof Hew itt telling it how it is going to shape up in poetry, anyhow. These, he says, are the forms, the attitudes, the people and the general texture of the new poetry. The adjective is his. He has chosen those who, he feels, were among the best but unrec ognized poets in the last half of the sixties.

title: Dolphin Bait of Stock in Club Helped Lure Shula From Colts
description: IT is forbidden in pro foot ball for one owner to steal another's coach and that was what prevented Vince Lombardi's switch from Green Bay to the Giants in 1961. But there is a legal way to steal coachespro mote them to vice president or general manager and give them a piece of the franchise. Ed ward Bennett Wil liams did that last year, when Lombardi went to the Washington Redskins, and Joseph Robbie of the Miami Dolphins did it this week, when he hired Don Shula away from the Baltimore Colts.

title: Rip Torn Portrays Miller in "Tropic of Cancer" Adaptation
description: "THIS is not a movie," announces Rip Torn at the beginning and as the author-protagonist of "Tropic of Cancer." He's wrong. It is a highly interesting one, and definitely not for everybody. Produced, directed and co-adapted by Joseph Strick, the Paramount release opened yesterday ever so aptly, at the Paris Theater.Is the movie like Henry Miller's book? Yes, in essence, spirit and flavor. Remarkably so.Yes, good old "Tropic of Cancer," Miller's candid underground diary-novel of his rootless, libertine sojourn in France during the early 1930's, which was long banned in this country, has finally made it to the screen when anything now goes for sensation or elusive art. The picture is neither.With extraordinary alacrity, technical skill and plain common sense, Strick (and Betty Botley, his colleague) has lifted Miller's rambling, sizzling narrative off the printed page and shaped a vibrantly blunt and lifelike eyeful that either follows or suggests the original, retaining most of the key characters and situations. Add a brilliantly right personification of Miller by Rip Torn, whose labyrinthine wanderings about Paris are superbly evoked by the beautiful color photography of Alain de Robe.Add (straight from the book) the frankest and the filthiest flow of expletives, Anglo-Saxon and otherwise, ever to spew forth from a commercial, publicly shown movie feature, on these shores, at least. Wearying as the barrage becomes, the shock is acoustical, not visual. For all the blistering language, in a movie whose hero's primary concern is sex there is only a smattering or semi-clad, amorous intertwining and some casual, frontal female nudity.Another curiosity wrought by Strick is that the setting of the original, which was indelibly stamped with the nineteen-thirties of expatriate Americans, has been so subtly updated to the present as to be hardly noticeable. This becoming touch adds dimension, if not real stature, which is where Strick's towering transition of Joyce's "Ulysses" has it all over "Tropic of Cancer."Even with the splendid performances of the entire cast, with a freshness of comparatively unknown faces in the featured roles, the film succeeds best on the level of a comic, sexual adventure of a man obsessed and motivated by one thing.On this level of lust, for about two-thirds of the way, the picture is brazenly sly, boldly fatalistic and often hilarious, all of it mirrored in the face of the curly haired Torn, with his bland drawl and piercing eyes. In a mercurical rhythm of tight sparse images the camera lets Torn rip, as he wheedles cash and lodging from a group of friends, seducing and re-seducing, eyeing wives, mistresses and new quarries, and lending a friendly, lascivious ear to the sexual hang-ups of his pals.The acting, and acting it is, remains unflawed by a cast that includes Ellen Burstyn, David Bauer, Phil Brown, Ginette LeClerc, Dominique Delpierre, Giselle Grimm, Magali Noel and others. Miller himself appears for a second inside a crowded church. But the picture loses routing toward the end, when it casually but purposefully involves the hero in the plight of a homesick, neurotic pal, memorably played by James Callahan, and his fiery mistress, a comely brunette named Laurence Ligneres.This closing chapter also was in a summary philosophy, from Miller's mouthpiece, an exuberantly defiant stream-of-consciousness about a lone man against the world. Torn speaks it at the fade-out, standing in an open taxi, in a retreating camera shot that suggests a suspended head crossing the Seine on a straight level.Intended or not, this is the definitive image of Miller's high life that Strick has transplanted with such surprising, practical fidelity. It is all effect, not substance, a soulless business anchored to the groin, with no simple warmth or feeling and no real body, although Torn states his case clearly enough: "Above allthe ecstasy."When the movie runs out of steam, it leaves only a shiftless, conventionally cynical and foul-mouthed bucko who couldn't matter less, even with mouth closed.

title: NARCOTICS CALLED TOP SOCIAL ISSUE
description: Four candidates for the Dem ocratic nomination for the Unit ed States Senate agreed last night that the curbing of nar cotics traffic and addiction con stituted a toppriority national social problem.

title: MALIK SAID TO BAR CEASEFIRE PLEA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19Objections voiced by the Soviet delegate, Yakov A. Malik, are understood to have prevented an appeal by the Big Four today for restoration of a ceasefire in the Middle East.

title: Canada to Ban All Phosphates In Detergents Over 2Year Span
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 19The Gov ernment, confident that it has the full backing of the 10 prov inces, plans to ban phosphates in detergents in two years.

title: Vallin Has Plans to Halt Ski Thieves
description: SINCE ski thieves seem to have replaced leg frac tures and long lift lines as major topic of conversation around snow running cen ters, Harry Vallin, the own er of the Scandinavian Ski Shops, was sought out yes terday in the hope that he could offer some suggestions about coping with the problem.

title: Wyeth Show Opens at White House Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Andrew Wyeth, the Ameri can artist who represents un officially a vast silent major ity of his countrymen who know what they like, was a guest of the President and Mrs. Nixon at the White House today. Tomorrow an exhibition of 21 of his paint ings, the first oneman show in the history of the White House, will open to the pub lic in the East Room.

title: Arizona State NamesTanara
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Feb. 19 (AP) Al Tanara, a former University of Tennessee football star, was named offensive line coach to day at Arizona State Univer sity.

title: Seasonally Adjusted Price Index Up 0.6%, Continuing U .S .Trend
Piseator Group Plans Event
description: A lecturedemonstration on The Theater, and Human Rights will be presented by the Piscator Memorial Founda tion in the auditorium of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 111 Amster dam Avenue, on Thursday at 6 P.M. Dr. Maria Piscator; widow of Erwin Piscator, the, director, will conduct the program, which, will include Irma Sandrey, Ray mond Cole, Sarah Cunningham and Wendell Phillips.

title: Article 6  No Title
McLain Suspension Takes Mayo Smith by Surprise
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI)Detroit Tiger manager Mayo Smith, said today the suspension of Denny McLain came as a shock to him.

title: Jules Munshin, Comedy Actor In Film and On Stage, Dies at 54
description: Jules Munshin, the film, stage and television comedian, died of a heart attack yester day morning at his home, 1270 West End Avenue. He would have been 55 years old on Sunday.

title: Lea Hainan Takes Hialeah Dash as Brave Emperor, 45 Choice, Runs Fourth
description: MIAMI, (AP)  Wheatley Stable's Brave Emperor, the 45 favorite, ran into a bit of bad racing luck today and finished out of the money in the feature race at Hialeah.

title: Stamford Mayor Presses Search for Girl's Killer
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 19 Mayor Julius M. Wilenslw said today that he had told the police to pull out all the stops in their search for the killer of the 17yearold daugh ter of a local coliceman.

title: AGNEW ROLE IS SEEN IN FALL ELECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  Representative Rogers C. B. Morton of Maryland, chairman of the Republican National Committee, indicated today that Vice President Agnew rather than President Nixon might play a major role in this year's Congressional election campaigns.

title: U.S. DROPS BANGKOK AS G.I. LEAVE CENTER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (Reuters)American mili tary authorities today dropped Bangkok as a vacation center for United States troops after the Thai Government had de cided not to renew the needed airline landing rights.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ONE is persuaded by Presi dent Nixon's declaration of war on environmental deg radation and by an ever increasing public concern and understanding of the threat it poses to our survival that there is reasonable cause for optimism.

title: 6 War Protesters Fined
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI)Six men charged with disorderly conduct and obstructing traffic last September when they handed out antiwar literature of Students for a Democratic Society were fined $100 yester day in Chicago. Those fined in cluded Robert Roth, 19 years old, of New York; Joseph Kel ly, 24, of Mount Kisco, N. Y., and Russell Nevfeld, 22, of West Hempstead, L. I.

title: Tricia Nixon Back Home
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) Tricia Nixon returned to the White House today after a long stay in Florida. She went them Jan. 24 to recuperate from the flu, then came down with the measles on Jan. 30.

title: 41 DRUG SUSPECTS ARRAIGNED IN DAY
description: Fortyone young men and women were arraigned on nar cotics charges yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brook lyn. The figure set a record for the number of narcotics suspects arraigned there in one day.

title: J. ROBERT GUY
description: J. Robert Guy, a general agent of Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company from 1949 until his retirement in 1968, died here Wednesday. He was 65 years old and lived at Dawn Harbor Lane, River side. Old Greenwich. Conn.

title: C. B. Swope Jr. to Wed Gioia Pope
description: Mrs. Doris M. Brixey and Arthur Wallace Pope, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gioia M. Pope, to Carey Buckingham Swope Jr., son of Mr. and and Mrs. Swope of Baltimore and Juniper Point, West Booth bay Harbor, Me.

title: To Keep J. & L. Steel
description: DALLAS, Feb. 19 (AP)  LingTemcoVought, Inc., said today that it would sell its in terest in Braniff Airways, Inc., and the Okonite Company so it might retain control of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Company.

title: DANIEL C. C. GILBERT
description: Feb. 19Daniel C. C. Gilbert, an architect who practiced in New York and the Tarry towns for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: Greenberg and Lowe Reach. Squash Racquet Semifinals
description: Alan Greenberg of the Yale Club and Art Lowe of the Downtown Athletic Club seeded first and second, respectively, won their quarterfinal matches yesterday in the Fowler Me morial squash racquets tourna ment at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: Latins' Questions Unanswered by Nixon
description: GUATEMALA, Feb. 19  President Nixon's message on foreign policy gave no answers to the main questions Latin Americans are asking about the future of their economic rela tions with the United States.

title: I.C.C. Asked to Reconsider Change in New Haven Fares
description: The city asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yester day to reconsider a recent de cision approving a restructur ing of commuter fares on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central. The city con tended the the restructuring was unfair to riders and had been rejected by the Public Service Commission.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHTS GAME

title: Article 7  No Title
Mrs. Grant Honored
description: Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, the oity's Commissioner of Con sumer Affairs, has won the 1970 Freedom Cup of the Women's League for Israel. The presenta tion will be made at a luncheon of the league April 9 at the WaldorfAstoria. Mrs. Grant was cited for social commit ment, public service and lead ership in causes benefiting Israel.

title: Moscow Reacts With Scorn to Message
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19  The Soviet Union today greeted with scorn President Nixon's foreignpolicy message and lev eled particular criticism at his comments on Vietnam and the Middle East.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ATTACK IN MANILA PROTESTED BY U.S.
description: MANILA, Feb. 19The Unit ed States Ambassador in Mani la, in an unusually sharp di plomatic note today, protested over the mob assault on the American Embassy last night.

title: Whites Dominating Panther Hearings
description: What are you whiteys doing herethis is a trial for black people, shouted an angry black woman yesterday at a group of white students filing from the courtroom where pretrial hearings for 13 Black Panthers are being held.

title: Washington: For the Record
U.M.W. Aide Finds Inquiry on Wrong Track
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 19A Tennessee official of the United Mine Workers of America told newsmen today that the Fed eral grand jury investigating the murder of Joseph A. Yab lonski was trying to pin the staying on the union and is on the wrong track.

title: RUBY DEE AND DAVIS TO BE HONORED HERE
description: Ossie Davis and his wire, Ruby Dee, stars of the stage, screen and television, will re ceive the Frederick Douglass Awards at the fifth annual din ner sponsored by the New York Urban League.

title: Advertising: A Singular Creative Director
description: On the last Sunday in Jan uary, one of the creative di rectors at DancerFitzgerald Sample was quoted here as saying that a lone person with the title of creative di rector at a major agency could only be a figurehead.

title: 76ERS HAND PISTONS A 133114 TROUNCING
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 19 (AP) Archie Clark scored 28 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 133114 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a Na tional Basketball Association game.

title: Governor Seeking Control of U.S. Anticrime Aid
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 19 Governor Rockefeller urged Congress today to keep chan neling Federal anticrime funds through the states to local gov ernments.

title: CLARENCE A. BROWNE
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., Feb. 19Clarence A. Browne, wholesale manager of Cadillac cars on the East Coast for more than 30 years, died last night in his home at 10 The Loch, Roslyn Estates. He was 90 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
Marcello Conviction Upheld
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has upheld the conviction of Carlos Marcello, reputed Mafia chief of Louisiana, on charges of assaulting an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: MUSE JAZZ TRIO LED BY HARRY CONSTANT
description: Harry Constant, a jazz pi anist who usually plays at Mother Blues in the Bronx, brought a trio to Muse, at Bed ford Avenue and Lincoln Place in Brooklyn, last night for a concert performance. Assisted by Peter Pearson, bass, and Andrei Strobert, drums, Mr. Constant played a program that leaned heavily on his clean, deft technique but was a bit short on balance and imagina tion.

title: Cairo's Reaction Negative
description: CAIRO, Feb. 19Egyptians found nothing to praise and much to object to today in President Nixon's comments.

title: Reserve Action Deferred On Rochester Bank Plan
description: The Federal Reserve Board disclosed yesterday that be cause of objections from the Justice Department it had sus pended, at least temporarily, consideration of a complex plan that would allow the Charter New York Corporation and the Bankers Trust New York Cor poration to acquire banks in Rochester.

title: U.S. OPENS CLINIC FOR LEPROSY HERE
description: The United States Public Health Service opened a new outpatient clinic for leprosy here yesterday. The new facili ty, in a building at 245 Houston Street, is the fourth in the city to treat the estimated total of 100 New Yorkers who have the disease.

title: Notre Dame Defeats N.Y.U., 7765, Manhattan Downs Iona, 6557
description: Notre Dame and Manhattan, headed for postseason tourna ment bids, ran into a flock of big scares last night before they finally subdued their op ponents in a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Taylor Sets Back Tiriac in U.S. Indoor Tennis Quarterfinal Match
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 19 Ion Tiriac lost tonight and the National open indoor tennis championships lost half of its stellar attraction. Roger Taylor of England beat Tiriac, 119, 6 1, and advanced to the semi finals where he'll meet the other half of the Rumanian partner shin. Ilie Nastase.

title: Upstate Lab to Sell Results On Office Machines It Tests
description: International Evaluations, Inc., opened an independent laboratory yesterday to test and evaluate office equipment. The laboratory, in Hauppauge, L. I., will perform electrical, electronic and chemical tests on various types of office equipment to permit per spective buyers to discover whether the product lives up to manufacturers' promises.

title: A Siamese Twin Dies
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 (AP) One of a set of Siamese twins died today during an attempt to separate them, a Children's Hospital spokesman said. The second of the two girls was in guarded condition, it was said. They had been joined at the chest. The twins, whose parents are from Pittsburgh, were not further identified, at the fam ily's request.

title: 8 TRADE GROUPS ARE LEAVING CITY
description: At least eight business trade associations, representing a broad crosssection of Amer ican business, have setor re cently completedplans to leave New York for washing ton because of a desire to be closer to the Government and because of the high cost of operating here.

title: Cairo Decries Stand
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb.19A further intensification of Arab anger against the United States has been evoked by President Nixon's statement yesterday on the Middle East.

title: Israel Actress Loses Leg
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb., 19 (AP)  Surgeons am putated the left leg of the Israeli acrtess Hanna Maron, today. Miss Maron, 47 years old, who was wounded by grepade fragments in an Arab commando attack at the Munich airport last week.

title: U.S. B52'S CONTINUE RAIDS IN EAST LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (AP)  United States B52's continued attacks against suspected North Vietnamese supply depots in eastern Laos today, but some of the bombers were diverted for strikes against targets in South Vietnam.

title: 33 Fleeing Cuba Saved After 18 Days on Island
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19 (AP)  Exhausted but smiling, 33 Cuban refugees stepped ashore here today following 18 days of near starvation on a desert island where they lived off crayfish and crabs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1970

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS URGED TO CUT GRADE
description: A recommendation was made last night that all first grades in the Roman Catholic elemen tary schools of the Diocese of Brooklyn be dropped in Sep tember and that the second grades be abolished next year unless state aid is provided.

title: Article 4  No Title
Syracuse U. Students Stage R.O.T.C. SitIn
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 19Lead ers of the Student Government at Syracuse University directed a fourhour occupation of the Administration Building today. Forcing the chancellor to agree to an advisory referendum on the future of the Reserve Offi cers Training Corps on campus.

title: Biologist Doubts Man's Survival in a World Run by Idiots Too Old to Change
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass.  Any race that does pot adapt, will have to disappear, says Albert SzentGyorgyi, the biologist. The dinosaurs disappeared, and man may have to disappear too.

title: No Fat Cats Sunning in Mets' Camp
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19Tom Seaver combed his hair, put on a striped shirt, sat on a wooden stool in the locker room and tackled the question of the moment: What will keep the New York Mets from grow ing fat and complacent so soon after reaching the top?

title: Man Dies in Niagara Plunge
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP)A man; reportedly ill and jobless for a year, plunged 100 feet to his death in the Ni agara Gorge just beyond the American Falls today. He was identified as Robert J. Dono van, 50 years old, of Buffalo.

title: Kono of Japan Posts a 70 For Lead in Philippine Golf
description: MANILA, Feb. 19 (AP) Mitsutaka Kono of Japan posted a twounderpar 70 today for the firstround lead in the Philippine open golf champion ship.

title: Johnsons End Vacation
description: BOCA GRANDE, Fla.., Feb. 19 (AP)  Former President and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson left for Rochester, Minn., by private jet after a brief vacation here.

title: Court Dismisses Charges Against Cahill and Sherwin
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge Frank J. Kingfield today dismissed crim inal charges brought against Gov. William, T. Cahill and his secretary of state, Paul J. Sher win, for filing false reports on election expenditures.

title: Sayville Officer Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Pentagon today identi fied 23 servicemen as having been killed in Vietnam, includ ing Capt. John M. Gibbons, of the Army, of Sayville, L. I.

title: U.S. DROPS BANGKOK AS G.I. LEAVE CENTER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (Reuters)American mili tary authorities today dropped Bangkok as a vacation center for United States troops after the Thai Government had de cided not to renew the needed airline landing rights.

title: BIG BOARD RALLY FALTERS AT END
description: Stock prices continued to rally in early trading yester day, but the advance faltered later in the session. Closing prices were still on the upside but well below the highest levels of the day.

title: Actress Seeks Divorce
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 (AP) Tuesday Weld, the actress, filed suit for divorce today from her estranged husband, Claude Harz, giving irreconcil abl differences as the reason. The 26yearold actress and Mr. Harz, a writer, were sepa rated in 1968 after a three year marriage. They have one child, Natasha age 3.

title: SUSPENSION ASKED ON SCHOOL VOTING
description: A coalition of 40 organiza tions urged the Board of Edu cation yesterday to suspend the community, schoolboard elections scheduled to be held throughout the city on March 19.

title: Tito and Kenyatta Confer
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 19 (Agence FrancePress)  Pres dent Tito of Yugoslvaia and President Jomo Kenyatta of Kenya discussed bilateral rela tions and the international situation for two hours today. A joint communiqu will be issued tomorrow when Presi dent Tito leaves here for the Sudan.

title: Appetite for Books Is Found Growing in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  We are the People of the Book, and so help me we are going to live up to our name, Mayor Teddy Kollek said the other day.

title: Black Panther Pretrial Hearing Delayed After Student court Disturbance
description: Pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places were halted yesterday by a disturb ance caused largely by white college students.

title: SCIENTISTS URGE RESEARCH FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  A report that criticizes cuts in Federal research funds and warns that they are hampering the productivity of American scientists was released with out comment today by the White House.

title: For Chinese Fare It's the Real Thing
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vi cinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indi cated.

title: Leon Frechtel, Prosecutor at Nuremberg, Is Dead
description: Leon Frechtel, a prosecutor at the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials who left Government service to become an apparel manufacturer, died at his home yesterday after a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived at 1080 Fifth Avenue.

title: THE TIMES ACQUIRES 2D GOLF MAGAZINE
description: The New York Times Com pany has purchased Golf World, a British golf magazine with a circulation of almost 60,000, described as the largest in its field in Britain.

title: Baseball Suspends McLain for Ties to Gambling
description: Denny McLain, the pitcher who won 31 games for the De troit Tigers in 1968, was sus pended indefinitely yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, the commis sioner of baseball, because of 1967 bookmaking activities and his associations at that time.

title: Charles, in a Navy Family, to Sign On
description: LONDON, Feb. 19Prince Charles is going to join the navy.

title: North American Rockwell Elects Two
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 Directors of the North Amer ican Rockwell Corporation today elected Willard F. Rockwell Jr., chairman, as chief executive officer and Robert Anderson, executive vice president, as president and chief operating officer.

title: Rep. May Sues for Divorce
description: YAKIMA, Wash., Feb. 19 (AP)Representative Catherine May, Republican of Washing ton, filed suit yesterday for di vorce from her husband, James. They have been married 27 years. Mrs. May, who is 55 years old, asked for the divorce on the ground of separation of more than two years and per sonal indignities.

title: Top Labor Leaders Stress Need for Wage Gains
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19Organized labor's top lead ers emphasized today that workers must seek substantial wage gains this year to offset price increases and to achieve improvement in buying power.

title: Consent, Not Advice
description: In approving Judge G. Harrold Carswell by a vote of 13 to 4, the Senate Judiciary Committee has ex pressed an opinion so overtly political as to make a useless guide for Senate action on his nomination to the Supreme Court. Distinguished legal scholars who testified before the committee felt that their views fell on minds so determined to consent that they were closed to advice.

title: 1969 Sales and Net Set Highs at Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Com pany posted record sales and earnings in 1969, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: 2 Expelled by Boston U.; Played Role in TakeOver
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP)Two students who took part in a twoday occupation of Boston University's administration building last December Have been expelled, the university announced today.

title: Times Promotes 3 in Advertising
description: Max Falk, advertising di rector of The New York Times, announced yesterday that Joseph B. Wagner had been named advertising manager, Roger W. Atwood, assistant advertising mana ger and John W. Campbell, national advertising man ager.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Opera

title: $70,000 Gem Theft on L.I.
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Feb. 19 (AP)The owner of a jewelry store reported today that a tray of 45 diamond rings worth $70,000 was stolen while the store's clerks were busy talking to customers. Mrs. Gol die Blum Smolka said the theft at her shop, Goldie Bluin's Jew elry Store, at 12 South Park Avenue, occurred sometime between 6:30 and 8 P.M. yes terday.

title: Osaka's TeenAge Moles Use WayDown Hangout
description: OSAKA, Japan, Feb. 12The young man stood lounging against the window of the Miami Coffee Shop, three levels beneath the surface of the main street, his hands deep into his tight trousers, his heavily pomaded black hair fringing a face that would be pale and pasty for a Caucasian.

title: Smith Resigns at Davidson; Fagg Named Football Coach
description: DAVIDSON, N. C., Feb. 19 (AP)Homer Smith, who guided Davidson College to its first Southern Conference football championship and its first bowl game in 1969, resigned today as head coach.

title: Program for Voluntary Action To Organize in Capital Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  After 13 months of study and some confusion, a national program for voluntary action to which President Nixon gave fervent support in the 1968 cam paign formally gets under way tomorrow.

title: Wallace Schedules Parley To Reveal Campaign Plan
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 19 Former Gov. George C. Wal lace will hold a news confer ence here next Thursday to tell whether he will run for Gover nor of Alabama this year.

title: Two Groups Eorecast the Easing of Inflation by the End of 1970
description: Two groups of economists issued forecasts yesterday sug gesting that the Council of Eco nomic Advisers may have been too optimistic in predicting flat half. Both were optimistic, however, in forecasting a les sening of inflationary pres sures.

title: ADVANCES POSTED IN CITRUS FUTURES
description: Prices of frozen orangejuice concentrate futures rose yes terday in moderate trading after dropping for some weeks.

title: B'NAI B'RITH KEEPS ITS STATUS AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19A United Nations commit tee approved today consulta tive status for B'nai B'rith and its affiliates, allowing it to con tinue its work here. The Soviet Union and the Arab countries had sought to bar the influen tial Jewish organization from attending United Nations meet ings.

title: Rock Island Case Is Reopened; LTV Plans to Sell 2 Holdings
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for the second time reopened the case involving the planned acquisi tion of the Chicago, Rock Is land & Pacific Railroad.

title: Assurance Discerned
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 19Presi dent Nixon's report to Con gress on foreign policy has been read with deep satisfac tion in Israel.

title: VALLEY GIRL BEATS SPOILER BY A HEAD
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 19 Joe MacDonald, in his own, quiet way one of the more talented reinsmen on harness racing's big wheel, drove Val ley Girl, to victory in tonight's main event at Roosevelt Race way. It was the Nova Scotia born horseman's only driving assignment on the ninerace card and gave him 10 winners in 50 starts at the current win ter meeting.

title: RALPH E. FLANDERS OF VERMONT DEAD
description: SPRINGFIELD, Vt., Feb. 19 (AP)Former Senator Ralph E. Flanders, who retired from the Senate in 1958 after serv ing two terms, died tonight at Springfield Hospital. He was 89 years old.

title: Laotian Premier Stresses Peril Of Offensive by Hanoi in Plain
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 19 The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, today called the current enemy offensive in Laos the most important yet.

title: INSURER IS UPHELD ON CANCELLATIONS
description: The first attempt by the State Insurance Department to punish insurance companies for alleged racial discrimination in canceling fire insurance poli cies in slum areas was over turned yesterday by the Appel late Division.

title: Congress to Evaluate Manpower Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 For eight years. the Federal Government has been strug gling to develop effective pro grams for training the chronic unemployed, high school drop outs, welfare mothers and other unskilled persons for jobs in private industry.

title: 2d Nixon Veto Threatens $19Billion Fund Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The House approved tonight a $19.4 billion health and education bill for the current fiscal year in the face of a threat from the Republican leadership that President Nixon would veto the bill as inflationary for the second time.

title: Death Benefit Rise Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) Representative Fernand J. St. Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, introduced a bill today that would increase the amount of lumpsum death payments made under the Social Security Act.

title: Leary and 4 Senators Plan New Steps to Fight Drugs
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary submitted yes terday to more than an hour of tough questioning by four State Senators on his efforts to fight narcotics traffic here and then agreed that I can not say that there is no cor ruption in the Police Depart ment.

title: City Delays Regulation On Pricing Food Items
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it was defer ring enforcement of a regula tion that would require retail food merchants here to show the price per unit for some items.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BEFORE midnight next Wednesday a Little League baseball team in Van couver, O'Doul's Angels, will be properly financed for the coming season. Up to a couple of months ago, the free spending Lefty O'Doul had always staked the little cherubs himself. But when a heart attack ook away the popular Lefty at the age of 72, there suddenly was a heavenly scratch for money.

title: The Chicago Decision
description: Despite the chaotic and partisan proceedings in the flamboyant trial of the Chicago Seven, the jury man aged to return a verdict that at least points up the basic issues. It was given precious little help from judge who often acted as though in alliance with the prosecution and from defendants who, more interested in discrediting the courts than in looking to the legal process for vindication, richly deserved contempt sen tencesthough not of the severity they received.

title: Rail Negotiations Break Off
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 Efforts to resolve the rail road shopcraft dispute broke down tonight, raising new un certainties about the possibility of a strike or a lockout on the nation's railroads.

title: In a Bitter Debate About Patriotism on French TV, a Communist and a Gaullist Both Charge Betrayal
description: PARIS, Feb. 19A Commu nist and a Gaullist asserted their patriotism the other night before several million French men but neither would accept the other's claim to it.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED IN L.I. MURDER CASE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 19 A mistrial was declared in murder trial today following the arrest of a Queens man on a charge of offering to fix the jury for 56.000.

title: More Snow for Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 19 (AP) Two inches of snow fell in Buf falo overnight, the Weather Bureau reported today, raising to 100 inches the total snow fall this winter here. It was the first time Buffalo had been hit with 100 inches of snow since 196162. The greatest total snowall in the last 30 years was 125 inches in 195758.

title: Bomb Threat in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) A telephoned bomb threat brought about the clearing of maintenance personnel last night at the National Archives, Federal Trade Commission and Justice Department buildings. No bombs were found.

title: Mr. Nixon Acts on Genocide
description: President Nixon took a step toward removing an ugly blot from this country's international posture yesterday when he urged the Senate to ratify a United Nations genocide convention that has been pending for nearly 21 years.

title: BUSING CURBS ARE PASSED IN THE HOUSE AND SENATE; 2 SCHOOL AID BILLS VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Southerners in the House and Senate waged a successful as sault today on the Federal guidelines and busing plans that have been used to pro mote integration in Southern schools.

title: SOVIET WARNS CHINA ON ADVENTURIST LINE
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 19 (Reu ters)The Soviet Union warned China today against new ad venturist moves. On the eve of United StatesChinese talks in Warsaw, the Moscow radio said in a Chineselanguage broadcast that Peking's trade shift from Communist countries to the West had caused damage to China's economy.

title: Institutional Investor Elects
description: Myron Kandel, former finan cial editor of The New York Herald Tribune, has been ap pointed vice president in charge of editorial planning for Insti tutional Investor Systems, Inc. He will continue as editor of both The Wall Street Letter and Physicians' Portfolio, the latter, a plannedinvestment magazine for the medical profession.

title: Stock Firm Association Backs New Commission Rate Plans
description: The Association of Stock Exchange Firms, representing 513 of the member organizations of the New York Stock Exchange issued a qualified endorsement yesterday of the new commissionrate plan proposed by the exchange.

title: Romney Scores Rent Control Here
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  George W. Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, termed absolutely ri diculous today the concept that housing construction and improved maintenance could be achieved under New York City's rent control law.

title: Party on Thursday to Aid Citizens for Clean Air
description: Citizens for Clean Air, Inc. will benefit from a supper party at L'Etoile restaurant, 1 East 59th Street, next Thursday.

title: 46 MORE TEACHERS SEIZED IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19Tensions rose sharply in the city's school dispute today as 46 more strik ing teachers on picket lines were arrested and parent groups heatedly demanded an end to the walkout in an emo tional twohour meeting with Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.

title: School Prayer Proponent Convicted for Disturbance
description: BROCKTON; Mass., Feb. 19 (AP)Rita Warren of Brockton was convicted in District Court today on three charges in con nection with her fight to re store prayer in Brockton public schools.

title: COLLEGES SCORED ON DROPOUT RATE
description: A charge that twothirds of Puerto Rican college students are dropping out because of the insensitivity of colleges to their needs was made yester day by Louis Nieves, executive director of Aspira.

title: Enfeebled Sukarno Visits His Son and New Bride
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb 19 (AP)Former President Su karno, who is in failing health, was allowed out of house ar rest today to visit a newlywed son and his bride.

title: Continental Can Sets European Unit
description: The Continental Can Com pany said here yesterday that it planned to form a Euro pean subsidiary that initially would manufacture about $300million worth of pack aging a year.

title: A DIVER IS KILLED REPAIRING TANKER
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) A young diver died today while patching the hull of the tanker Delian Apollon, which has spilled 20,000 gallons of oil into Tampa Bay. The authorities said he had been found under the ship, apparently drowned.

title: LAYOFFS ARE SET IN VARIED FIELDS
description: Layoffs and possible plant closings were announced yes terday in a variety of major industries across the country.

title: NICKERSON CANCELS A COUNTY CONTRACT
description: Eugene H. Nickerson, Nassau County Executive, said yester day that he would investigate county contracts awarded over the last three years to a con cern headed by a man who re signed from the county govern ment five years ago.

title: NIXON WELFARE PLAN ADVANCES IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today the thrust of President Nixon's welfare reforms to pro vide a minimum annual income for working families.

title: Miss Sweeney, Peter C. Droste Planning Bridal
description: Miss Harriet Hauberg Swee ney, whose father, the late Edward Cleaveland Sweeney, was president of the Explor ers Club, plans to be married early in September to Pho tographer Technician 2d Cl. Peter Carl Droste, who is serving with Navy intelli gence in Japan.

title: AARON NEGOTIATES $250,000 PACKAGE
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 19 (AP)  Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves signed a twoyear con tract today for a reported $125,000 a year.

title: PENTAGON IS SILENT ON TEST CUTBACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The Pentagon is keeping secret its plans to cut back drastically, for economy rea sons, its readiness to resume atmospheric testing of nuclear weapons if the Russians vio late the test ban treaty.

title: Canadian Bill Rate Falls
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 19 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $140  million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 98.126 and average yield of 7.66 per cent, compared with last week's same amount at 98.108. and 7.74 per cent. Today's $35mil lion of 182day bills brought 96.328 and 7.64 per cent, against last week's $40million at 96.282 and 7.74 per cent.

title: $8Million Building to Rise At Albany Medical College
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Albany Medical College has announced the awarding of contracts to taling $8.1million for construc tion of a new building that will include a library, classrooms and other educational facilities.

title: Reports on Skiing Conditions
Greece Bows to the Arabs
description: On Dec. 26, 1968, two young Arab terrorists tried to blow up an El Al airliner preparing to take off from Athens Airport. Had the attackers succeeded fully, they would have killed 43 passengers and the crew of ten; actually, they murdered one passenger.

title: Rahway Seeks Racial Pact
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Feb. 19  A round of conferences involv ing high school teachers, stu dents and parents is seeking a formula to end racial conflict in this municipality's 1,600stu dent high school, so the school can reopen next Tuesday.

title: Penguins Rout Kings, 61, For 3d Straight Triumph
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI)The Pittsburgh Penguins scored three firstperiod goals, two of them by Bryan Hextall, and coasted to a 61 victory to night over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON DOWN NARROWLY
description: Prices moved narrowly yes terday on the London Stock Exchange. At the outset, stocks edged ahead hut, by the close, these early gains were cut back or reversed.

title: Chicago 7 Jurors Tell of Compromise
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19  The verdict in the Chicago con spiracy trial was described to day as a hardfought com promise, with three of the women jurors holding out for acquittal of all seven defend ants until a crucial conference in the Palmer House Hotel late Tuesday night.

title: Foreign Affairs: LowProfile Presidents
description: PARISLike Richard Nixon, his host in the United States, Georges Pompidou is a low profile President in France. There is an approximate con nection between the personal relationships of Nixon to Eisen hower and those of Pompidou to de Gaulle although, apart from his personal halo of mili tary glory, no one could ever accuse Eisenhower of having been charismatic. His Presi dential idea was more to reign, not to govern.

title: Germany: Twain May Meet
description: A meeting of the heads of Government of East and West Germany in Berlin next month now seems as sured. The mere fact of such a dramatic meeting first of its kind since the division of Germany in the aftermath of World War 11will be more significant than any probable early results. It will represent considerable success for the courageous new de parture in West German foreign policy under Chan cellor Willy Brandt.

title: POLICE BAR MARCH ON MITCHELL HOME
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 More than 150 demonstrators were arrested today as hundreds of policemen turned back a protest march on the Watergate Apartments, the home of Attor ney General John N. Mitchell and several other Cabinet members.

title: Nixon Message Seen in Britain as Warning of a Troop Cut Soon
description: LONDON, Feb. 19President Nixon's foreignpolicy state ment was seen in Britain today as an unmistakable sign that America will be reducing her forces in Europe before long.

title: Article 3  No Title
SelfMade Yankee
description: At one time or other in his serendipitous careers, Mr. Flan ders was the editor of a tech nical magazine, a pig farmer, a wartime production admin istrator, a lecturer, a banker, a machinists' apprentice, a draftsman, the trustee of two universities, and, at the age of 67 a freshman Senator.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: In thinking about your Jan. 15 editorial critical of the all volunteer army, I have arrived at different conclusions, and would like to take exception to a number of your points.

title: Article 2  No Title
Hire Minorities, School Builders Told
description: The Board of Education de cided yesterday that all future school construction and mod ernization contracts after May I would require onthejob train ing programs for blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: Amex Prices Mixed at Close; Selling Pressure Erases Gains
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yester day after selling pressure erased most of the gains achieved earlier in the day.

title: 6 MAYORS TO SEEK RISE IN STATE AID
