description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 19  Mayors of the state's six larg est cities will back legislation asking the state to give 10 per cent of its personal income tax collections next year to cities, towns and villages.

title: General Dynamics Loses Jet Pod Patent Suit
description: One of aviation's foremost inventors has won a Federal court decision enabling him to collect damages for patent infringement in manufacture of the General Dynamics Corporation's Convair 990 jet airliner.

title: Opening Bid Wins 5th in Row By Taking Santa Ynez Stakes
NICKERSON SEEKS THE GOVERNORSHIP
description: Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson formally entered the battle for the Dem Ocratic nomination for Gov ernor yesterday with a wide ranging attack on Governor Rockefeller and a declaration that he would seek a Negro running mate for Lieutenant Governor.

title: ATOM PROFIT SEEN BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: ONTARIO, N.Y. Feb. 19 The Westinghouse Electric Cor poration expects its nuclear power business to operate at a profit this year. John W. Simpson, president of Power Systems, told 110 utility an alysts here today

title: Friend Says Captain Discussed Tate Killing Before Family Died
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 19A Green. Beret team com mander said today that he and Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald of Pat chogue, L. I., discussed the rit ualistic murders of the actress Sharon Tate and three of her friends only a couple of days before the doctor's family was found dead at Fort Bragg.

title: Yolanda Chavez To Wed in June
description: Mr, and Mrs. Raul A. Chavez of Mexico City have announced here the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Yolanda Chavez, to William Harlough Knull 3d, son of Captain Knull Jr., U. S. N., and Mrs. Knull of Arlington, Va. A June wedding is planned.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0,170 HERE; EASING PREDICTED
description: The 10cent increase in city subway and bus fares and ris ing food prices pushed the Con sumer Price Index higher by 0.7 per cent last month in the New York area.

title: A Crusading State Senator
description: SPELLED backwards, Wal daba is a bad law. But when State Senator Waldaba Hamilton Stewart is asked if he spends his time being teased about the irony of a legislator having such a name, he smiles and says in his soft Panamanian accent.

title: Adolescents Today: Are They More Disturbed?
description: THE subjec is discussed as casually today as a visit to the dentist. Everyone either knows or has heard of an adolescent who is undergoing psy chiatric treatment.

title: FREIGHT TRAFFIC UP, AS IS TRUCK TONNAGE
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 19 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Feb. 14 were both above the volume in the correspond ing week of last year.

title: The Theater: Premiere of Norman, Is That You?
description: IT Is strange how taste and standards change. It seems only yesterday that we had plays such as The Green Bay Tree or even Tea and Sympathy, which handled the then vexed subject of homosexuality with silk gloves.

title: Hawks Top North Stars
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) Jim Pappin scored the winning goal for the Black Hawks with less than nine minutes to play tonight as Chicago scored a 32 victory over Minnesota, extend ing the North Stars nonwin ning streak to 17 games.

title: Opera: Return of Lucia
description: LEADING from strength, the New York City Opera opened its spring (spring?) season last night at the State Theater with its big hit of a few months ago. That was, of course, Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor With *Beverly Sills in the title role. This is the Lucia cleanly and log ically staged by Tito Capo bianco, with attractive sets by Marsha Louise Eck, and with several major cuts opened, including the Wolf scrag scene between Edgardo and Enrico.

title: No Major Declines in Rates of Interest Are Expected by Treasury Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy told Con gress today that the backlog of demand for credit was so large that he would not expect ma jor declines in interest rates, despite the softening of the economy.

title: Books of The Times
description: IF you're fashionably paranoiac and will ing to believe that the whole world is plugged into a tape recorder, you'll have a zippy time with Lawrence Sanders's first novel, The Anderson Tapes. For Mr. Sanders has given us a hero with the mak ings of charisma, an intriguing sex life, and an audacious plan. And to give his story the aura of documentary au thenticity, Mr. Sanders has told it all through tran scriptions of var ious tape record ings. Fresh from serving a sentence at Sing Sing for breaking and en tering, John (Duke) Anderson has found a woman and a home. The woman needs Duke  to beat her up everynow and then. Her home is a cooper in a New York City town house on East 730 Street. Duke doesn't intend merely to make himself at home at the woman's place; he plans to clean out the entire building, at an estimated profit of a quartermillion dollars or so.

title: MORE TALK ADDED TO YANK TRAINING
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 19  Slowly but in evitably, the development tech niques successful in other sport are making their way into base ball. For the New York Yan kees this spring, Manager Ralph Houk has installed a daily half hour skull session preceding field practice  a type of squad indoctrination common in foot ball and basketball but rare in baseball.

title: RESERVE KEEPING STRICT RESTRAINT
description: The Federal Reserve System gave no sign of easing its pol icy of strict monetary restraint during the last two weeks, bank ing data published yesterday showed.

title: Budzeyko Named Aide to Rao
description: John J. Budzeyko, a Queens businessman, was appointed yesterday a special assistant to Chief Judge Paul R. Rao of the United States Customs Court. Mr. Budzeyko, 54 years old, is former chairman of the New York State Council of Polish Democratic Clubs.

title: TWO CONVICTED HERE IN A PHONE SWINDLE
description: A jury found two business men guilty yesterday of swin dling the New York Telephone Company by making $146,000 worth of longdistance calls on a credit card and not paying the bills.

title: Soviet Union Skiers Win CrossCountry Relay Title
description: STRBSKE PLESO, Czechoslo vakia, Feb. 19 (AP)The So viet Union's crosscountry ski ers won the men's 40kilometer relay today before 10,000 spec tators in an exciting race that gave the Soviet its fith gold medal of the world Nordic ski ing championships. Only sec onds separated the first three teams.

title: 4,269 School Buses Recalled By G. M. in Safety Precaution
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 19 (AP)  General Motors an nounced today the recall of 4,269 school buses and 21,681 trucks because of a possible brake defect.

title: TV Fall Programing Puts Accent on Reality
description: In September, the networks assert, television's new enter tainments will pay more atten tion to reality and social awareness. Until then, for the rest of this winter, into the spring and through the sum mer, the country's 59 million television homes will watch, and rewatch, remainders and repeats of the current season's fantasies as well as some fresh ly turned out retreads and re placements.

title: White House Police Losing PalaceGuard Headgear
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)  Those Prussianstyle helmets that helped give White House policemen a new palace guard look have been scrapped.

title: French Reserves Grow
description: PARIS, Feb. 19 (UPI) France's gold and foreigncur rency reserves expanded by $4,332,629 in the week ended Feb. 12, the Bank of Frame said today. The new total was $3,696,000,000.

title: Guard Wants Fewer Untrained; DraftAge Men to Feel Impact
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The National Guard is about to embark upon a program aimed at attracting a greater num ber of experienced soldiers and cutting back the acceptance of untrained volunteers.

title: StreetOpening Ban Is Ordered for City; Potholes Are Factor
description: After jouncing and bouncing In his car on a trip through the city's pitted, potholed streets, Transportation Administrator Constantine SidamonEristoff ordered yesterday a ban on all streetopening permits.

title: RED SKELTON SHOW IS MOVING TO N.B.C.
description: Red Skelton, who on Wednesday was released by the Columbia Broadcasting System from his hourlong show next season, was signed yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company to do a halfhour show at 7:30 P.M. Mondays. He will precede N.B.C.'s Laugh In and its Monday night movie.

title: Missionaries Reach Rome
description: ROME, Feb. 19 (Reuters) Twenty  nine Roman Catholic missionaries expelled from Ni geria arrived here by air to night from Lagos for a week's stay before returning to their homes.

title: Martha Argerich Makes Piano Debut With Philharmonic
description: Martha Argerich chose the Third Piano Concerto of Pro kofiev for her New York Phil harmonic debut last night, and that virtuoso's vehicle proved precisely the score to introduce the young Argentinian. Miss Argerich, an attractive young woman with long black hair and all the temperament she needs to be a popular success, also owns a big technique, ex traordinary power and a sensi tive musical mind.

title: CITY TO HELP POOR COMPLY ON CENSUS
description: The Department of Social Services yesterday announced a massive program to assure that all of the city's poor will be counted in the 1970 Federal census.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Article 5  No Title
CITY'S RENT LAW FACING EXTENSION PENDING REPORTS
description: The city's rent control law will probably be temporarily extended to give the admin istration and the City Council time to study two pending housing reports, before taking final action on the law later this spring, it was disclosed yesterday. The law is scheduled to expire Marsh 31.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales for the latest week ended Feb. 14 were estimated $554million, an increase of 11 per cent above the $499million sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $6,105,000, 000, unchanged from the $6, 112,000,000 sales for the same period last year.

title: Rogers Seeks to Assure Lagos U.S. Respects Its Relief Plans
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 19 Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived in Lagos today anxious to smooth relations with Nigeria and to assure the Nigerian Government that the United States would respect its wishes in efforts to get relief to victims of the Nigerian civil war.

title: O.E.C.D. Aide Urges Wide Use Of Labor in Developing Lands
description: PARIS, Friday, Feb. 19An international aid official, saying that lack of jobs was the most severe problem facing the developing countries, asserted today that companies investing in those countries should forgo much of their laborsaving ma chinery and take advantage of cheap labor.

title: Pastor Urges Senate Panel to Strengthen Vote Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19A short, middle  aged minister with a thick Georgia accent ap pealed today to a Senate sub committee to strengthen, and not dilute or weaken the hard won right to vote, represented by the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Helpern Receives 2 Honors
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, has been awarded an honorary law degree by the University of Ghent in Belgium and has been selected by the magazine Mod ern Medicine to receive one of its 1970 awards. The magazine cited Dr. Helpern, a veteran of 38 years in the Medical Exam iners Office, for t dignity and scientific approach [he] brought to the profession of forensic medicine during a dis tinguished career as practition er and teacher.

title: Nixon Urges Senate to Ratify Genocide Pact, Stalled Since '50
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 President Nixon urged the Sen ate today to ratify the 1949 United Nations agreement out lawing genocide.

title: Brave to Aid Indian Colleges
description: The Robert F. Kennedy The ater for Children will present Brave, a program of music, dance and mime, on March 29 through April 5 at the ANTA Theater. Written by Joseph Golden and narrated by Frank Converse, Brave is described as epitomizing the forgotten people of Americathe Ameri can Indian whose future was a major concern of the late Sen ator Kennedy. The initial per formance will benefit the Amer ican Indian College Scholarship Fund.

title: Hanoi Says Message Shows Nixon Is Wedded to Force
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Feb. 20 (AP)The Hanoi radio said to day that President Nixon's foreignpolicy statement showed that his Administration wanted to win the war in Vietnam through force rather than ne gotiation.

title: Lindsay Brooke Davis Is Affianced
description: SMOKE RISE, N. J., Feb. 19The engagement of Miss Lindsay Brooke Davis to David Nelson Deinzer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Davis Jr., parents of the bridetobe. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon W. Deinzer.

title: HARRY L. HILY ARD, 75, TOBACCO EXECUTIVE
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Feb., 19  Harry L. Hilyard, a former vice president, treasurer and director of the American To bacco Company, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 25 Fernwood Road.

title: DEFENSEMAN RIPS TENDONS IN ANKLE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19  In a tempestuous game, the New York Rangers salvaged a 33 tie with the Detroit Red Wings to night on thirdperiod goals by Bob Nevin and Vic Hadfield after having lost their most tempestuous performer, Brad Park, with an ankle injury in the opening period.

title: MRS. TRYGVE HAMMER
description: TIED BANK, N.J., Feb. 19 Mrs. Emma Tronboll Hammer, a teacher of ceramics and the widow of Trygve Hammer, painter, sculptor and art teach er, died yesterday in Riverview Hospital. She was 93 yeats old and lied at 20 Cooper Boule yard.

title: AntiHippie Drive in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb, 19 (UPI)  The police statred an antihippie drive here today and arrested 20 persons on charges of loitering. A police spokesman said the hippies were becoming an inconvenience.

title: 4 Die in Salt Mine Blast
description: JEFFERSON ISLAND, La., Feb. 19 (AP)Four men were killed today in a blast at the Diamond Crystal Salt Company mine. The dead were identified as John O. Hollier, 34 years old; Joe Chranowski, 52; Len nis Landry, 30, and Obra Suire, 28.

title: RIGHTS AGENCY ASKS HOUSING GUIDELINES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The United States Civil Rights Commission recom mended today that Federal installations be withheldor even removed  from areas lacking lowcost nondiscrimina tory housing for their employes.

title: London: The Nixon Doctrine and Assumptions
description: LONDON, Feb. 19President Nixon's maxistatement on American foreign policy is a little like the brilliant maxi coats one sees swinging along the sidewalks of London these days: It is long, it covers a lot of territory, and it conceals the most interesting parts.

title: Fleet of 103 Yachts Starts In MiamitoLucaya Race
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19  The 33 foot Morgan sloop Surge, skip pered by Dr. Douglas G. Whit ney of Atlanta, swept into the early lead today in the 104 mile MiamitoLucaya yacht race.

title: U.S. AIRPORTS HELD LAX ON FIRE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  More than onefourth of the airports in the country used by the airlines have no firefight ing equipment, the Air Line Pilots Association reported to day.

title: U.S.BACKED ISSUES FOR HOUSING SOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The sale of the first Fed erally guaranteed securities is sued by private enterprise to provide funds for housing con struction was announced today by. Secretary of Housing Geurge Romney.

title: Reviving Fulbright Program
description: One of the most valuable of this country's postwar ventures in intellectual and cultural exchange has been cut back savagely in the last two years. It is the Fulbright scholarship program, named for the Chair man of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who conceived it in 1946.

title: Relief Teams Deluged
description: LAGOS, Feb. 19 (AP)Re lief teams report that they are being deluged by more than three million hungry refugees as they advance into the jungle area of the former state of Biafra.

title: Hunt Pressed for Dog Stranded on Isle in Bay
description: On a knoll overlooking a sandy strip or a tiny island in Jamaica Bay is a baited trap. It has been placed there by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Its purpose is to catch a dog that has been thriving without human help for many months, perhaps as lone as two years.

title: Penn Central Riders Get Written Apology
description: For the first time this year, riders on the Penn Central's New Haven and Harlem Divi sions have a written apology for a severe delay.

title: GEORGE MALDONADO GIVES SONG RECITAL
description: George Maldonado began his program in Carnegie Recital Hall last night with Schu mann's Dichterliebe cycle and ended it with Vaughan Williams's seven Songs of Travel. These proved to be the most congenial vehicles for the baritone, who gave his first recital here a little more than a year ago.

title: Museum Wrong on Trees
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art conceded yesterday that it had erred in not in forming the public before re moving 36 fullgrown trees last December. It also said it should have publicized its plans to plant more than three times that many in the spring and fall.

title: Ballet Theater Planning June 16July 12 Season
description: American Ballet Theater, which had lost its previously scheduled Manhattan season to the Met's opera festival at the Metropolitan Opera House in June, will now appear at the State Thea ter from June 16 through July 12.

title: G.E. Profit in All1969 Fell 22% On 4th Quarter's Strike Slump
description: Earnings of the General Electric Company plunged 85 per cent in 1969's fourth quarter, reflecting a 14week strike. As a result, the fullyear profit was down 122 per cent from the 1968 level.

title: Funseth Shoots a 3UnderPar 67 for 3Stroke Lead in San Antonio Open
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 19 (UPI)Rod Funseth endured cold weather and gusty winds today to card a threeunderpar 67 and take a threestroke lead after the first round of the $100,000 San Antonio open golf tournament.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS LOSS OF A JET IN SUEZ RAID
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 19Israel announced the loss of one plane to ground fire tonight as her air force attacked Egyptian po sitions in the Suez Canal zone for three hours. The attack fol lowed an unannounced 48 hour pause in Israeli bombing missions.

title: Willie Sutton to Get Welfare Assistance
description: Willie (The Actor) Sutton, who gained national notori ety, as a bank robber and escape artist, applied for wel fare assistance yesterday in Brooklyn.

title: Stuart Levy Fiance of Jan Berman
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 19Miss Jan Toni Ber man and Stuart Jay Levy plan to marry in August.

title: Bridge:
description: THE George Washington Birthday Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel with a full roster of events spread over four days in the following schedule:

title: Crafts Near and Far
description: THOSE who equate the crafts of Norway with the rest of contemporary Scandinavia may be in for one or two surprises at the exhibition of Norwegian handicrafts that opened yes terday at the American Federation of Arts gallery. There is a kind of whim sical sentimen tality, even a naivet about some of the work  an old fashioned look that one does not associate with the modern products that have come out of the North. This trait shows up primarily in the glass work  flowers and butterflies and fishermen and animals etched or acidpainted on lead crystal vases and blocks. And, in some of the ceramics too, one finds quaint heads and turreted clay castles.

title: S. E. C. SUSPENDS NEWBURGER & CO.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Newburger & Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, based in Philadel phia agreed today to a 10day suspension from doing most types of institutional business and business on the Philadel phia  Baltimore  Washington Stock Exchange.

title: F.C.C. Proposing Increase of 500% For License Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission proposed today that the fees broadcasters pay for licenses, applications and other services be increased 500 per cent in the next fiscal year.

title: West Germans Reserved
description: BONN, Feb. 19  Only three of a dozen major West German papers published edi torials today on President Nix on's foreignpolicy report and their comments  friendly but reservedreflected the general lack of excitement over his pronouncements here.

title: A CZECH AIDE AT U.N. WILL REMAIN IN U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Feb. 19  Czechoslovakia's third ranking diplomat at the United Nations, Jiri Mladek, was in hiding today with his family after having been granted asy lum by the United States.

title: Phone Company Seeks Rise
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19The New York Telephone Company to day filed with the State Public Service Commission a new sohedule of rate increases total ing $136.7million a year. The company acted because the commission last, Monday reject ed a $174.9million rate in crease request, but said it would consider a $136.7million request. The commission is ex pected to hold public hearings on the new request.

title: McLain Always on the Square, Former Tiger Teammate Says
description: YUMA, Ariz., Feb. 19 Dave Campbell says he doesn't know anything about the latest controversy swirl ing around Denny McLain, but he does know something about McLain.

title: Captain in Massacre Case Going Before Army Board
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (Reuters)Capt. Thomas Will ingham, accused in a second alleged massacre of Viet namese civilians two years ago, will testify before an Army board of inquiry tomorrow, the Defense Department disclosed today.

title: Weekend Recipes
description: IN the menus below, dishes I marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: CAHILL REBUFFED ON SLUDGE TOWING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19  The Army Corps of Engineers re buffed Gov. William T. Cahill today, declaring that it could not make any decision now to require immediately that all sewage sludge and industrial waste from New Jersey be dumped at least 100 miles out in the Atlantic.

title: A New Approach by U.S. Fails at Paris Peace Talks
description: PARIS, Feb. 19  The Unit ed States tried a new approach today to get the deadlocked Vietnam peace talks into the negotiating stage but said later that it had not worked.

title: Report in Kopechne Death Is Given to Boston Court
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 19 (UPI)A court clerk from Boston, traveling under state police escort, took custody to day of the judge's report and the secret transcript of the testimony on Mary Jo Ko pechne's death in Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy's car last July. ward M. Kennedy's car last July.

title: 3 Harlem Residents Killed in a Fire In 6Story Building
description: Three persons were killed and at least 11 injured in twoalarm fire that swept through a Harlem apartment building last night and early this morning.

title: SIEFERT INJURED, HALFORD UNHURT
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 49Talmadge (Tab) Prince of Dublin, Ga., a race driver who observed his 32d birthday on Monday, was killed in a three car crash this afternoon at Day tona International Speedway.

title: The Screen: 'Au Hasard, Balthazar':Bresson Feature Opens at the New Yorker
description: ROBERT BRESSON'S "Au Hasard, Balthazar" first played in New York at the 1966 Film Festival, at which time it received mostly unfavorable notices. That it is having a theatrical opening now results largely from the perseverance of Cinema Ventures' Tom Russell and the New Yorker Theater's Dan Talbotwho has done so much for movies in this city that he probably deserves a review of his own.Actually, Bresson, despite a general critical indifference and commercial failure that puts him in the company of the very greatest filmmakers (Carl Dreyer, for example) has never lacked for serious admirers. And the exceptional popularity of the recently completed Bresson retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art suggests that a much larger audience may be ready for him now than had ever heard of him only a few years ago.Along with the early "Les Dimes du Bois de Boulogne" (1944), "Au Hasard, Balthazar" (the title translates literally as "Balthazar at Random") is my favorite among Bresson's nine features. It is at once his most complex and most accessible movie, which should not seem so strange in light of the kinds of films he makes.His profoundly and unsentimentally religious vision and the severity and self-abnegation of his method set up certain expectations for any Bresson movie in relation to which "Au Hasard, Balthazar" looks like a sudden and gratifying relaxation in style. In fact, it is less austere (though possibly even more severe), than other Bresson films, and the multiplicity of things and themes (and things as theme), together with Bresson's most appealing hero, works for an unusual degree of audience empathy.That hero, Balthazar, is a donkey who, after a happy early life with Marie (Anne Wiazemsky), daughter of a scientific farmer, is sold into harsh toil and exploitation at the hands of a series of masters. Meanwhile, Marie's family suffers through her father's proud stubbornness, and she herself into humiliating liaison with Grard, leader of the genuinely vicious local young hoods. Periodically Marie and Balthazar are reunited, but at each reunion Grard reappears (in a sense, Balthazar prepares for Grard) to take the girl and to torture the donkey.By the time he has finished, Grardwhose evil is never explained but who adequately answers one set of his community's needs, just as Balthazar answers another set of needshas stripped Marie naked and abandoned her in an empty house, and he has loaded the donkey with contraband silks, gold, and perfume, which he means to smuggle across the border. The ensuing death of Balthazar, less a surprise than a summation, is in its pathos and depth of association the most richly evocative sequence in all of Bresson and surely one of the most affecting passages in the history of film.Where "Au Hasard, Balthazar" differs from Bresson's other films is in the degree to which it accepts and sustains a multiplicity of actions, objects, even, in an almost traditional sense, "character." Not that Bresson has lowered his vision (the film's range of associations in symbol and dogma should occupy any amateur of Christian theology for some time) but that he has expanded it to include a superbly precise and compassionate awareness of the physical universe.In this film we are given not only the movements of souls and bodies, but also the knowledge of hands and hearts and of the ground we walk on."Au Hasard, Balthazar" proceeds by contrariesbeginning with the sound track, which opens with a Schubert piano sonata rudely interrupted by a donkey's braying that lead to insights traditionally understandable only in terms of paradox. This is neither an easy film, nor, in the show biz sense, an entertaining one. It makes large demands upon its audience, and in return confers exceptional rewards. It is playing at the New Yorker Theater, and among recent openings it is the only absolutely essential moviegoing in New York.

title: ExGreen Berets Train Indonesians In CivicAid Work
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 19 (Reuters)A sixman United States military training team, including four men who have qualified as Green Berets, is in Indonesia giving instruction in civic mission work in vil lages, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Market Place:
description: IT is easy to understand that the little guy is upset over the New York Stock Exchange's plan to raise com ission rates substantially on smaller tradesthose of 300 shares or less.

title: United Fruit Skipper Seized For Dumping Oil Off Florida
description: PORT ST. JOE, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI)  The state authorities said today that the captain of a United Fruit Company freight er had been arrested for re leasing oil into St. Joseph's Bay.

title: YIELDS TRIMMED ON UTILITY ISSUE
description: This week's pronounced de cline in interest rates continued yesterday, and the yield on a new highgrade utility bond is sue was pushed down to 8.40 per cent, the lowest since last October.

title: Judicial Disaster
description: Federal Judge Julius Hoffman brought down the curtain on the dismal Chicago conspiracy trial with sentences which can only be explained as an act of personal vindictiveness. The imposition of maximum penalties of five years' imprisonment and $5,000 fines plus payment of the cost of prosecutioncombined with an order that the defendants remain in jail until all costs and fines have been paidis an assault on every civilized concept of justice.

title: Agnew Maintains Democrats Ignore Faults of Militants
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 20  Vice President Agnew accused the Democratic party tonight of condoning any aberration by the nation's young militants in an effort to win their favor.

title: 91Day Bill Rates Up to 6.812% At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Treasury bill rates advanced slightly at today's auction from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: PRICES ARE RAISED BY MORTON SALT CO.
description: The Morton Salt Company, a subsidiary of MortonNorwich Products, Inc., announced yes terday it would raise prices of salt and saltbased products by 5 to 7 per cent, effective April 1.

title: Appeals Court Rules City Owes M.T.A. $1.3Millior
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20 (UPI)The State Court of Appeals has unanimously backed a lower court decisdon, with some modi fications, finding New York City owes the Metropolitan Transportation Authority more than $1.3million in Long Island Rail Road station upkeep.

title: AETNA LIFE POSTS A SHARP DECLINE
description: Aetna Life and Casualty and the Travelers Corporationthe nation's two largest sharehold erowned insurance companies reported 1969 earnings yes terday, with Aetna showing sharp decline and Travelers showing a substantial gain.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: ALL HOURS GIVEN IN EASTERN STANDARD TIME

title: Beth Toni Applebaum Is Affianced
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 20  Dr. and Mrs. Irving Applebaum have announced that their daughter, Miss Beth Toni Applebaum, and Richard Greenwald Marcus will be married in June. The future bridegroom is the son of Robert G. Marcus, board chairman of the American Biltrite Rubber Company in Chelsea, Mass., and Mrs. Mar cus of Trenton. Dr. Apple baum, who is retired, was formerly president and chief of medicine at the Beth Is rael Hospital in Newark.

title: Now Accessories Can Come First
description: THESE days it's a moot point as to which comes first, the dress or the accessories. There is such an abun dance of goodlooking jewelry and belts that many women are reversing the traditional practice and buying dresses that set accessories off to the best advantages. The newest accessories are divided into three categoriesprimitive, casual and a kind of throw away chic. Each look has a lot going for it for, more than ever, design ers have allowed their imagina tions to run ram pant and have adapted old art and unlikely materials into modern looks.

title: STIRLING IS SPUR FOR NEW ISSUES
G.I. Racial Clashes Held on Increase Away From Front
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  More than three dozen Con gressmen, former military offi cers, professors and other war critics met today to discuss American involvement in Viet nam in a twoday conference on war and national responsibil ity.

title: C.B.S. SEVERS TIES WITH LEGAL FIRM
description: A 43year relationship has been severed between the Co lumbia Broadcasting System and its legal counsel, Rosenman, Colin, Kaye, Petschek, Freund & Emil. The firm, whose senior partner, Ralph F. Colin, had been associated with the net work since 1927, was dismissed last month, and Mr. Colin re signed from the C.B.S. board of directors on Feb. 9.

title: U.S. Apologizes to Cambodia For Air Strikes in November
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The United States has for mally apologized to the Cam bodian Government and has provided payments totaling $11,400 for 35 persons killed or wounded last Nov. 1617 in air strikes directed at Vietcong positions in Cambodia, the State Department reported to day.

title: Garment Makers Squeezed by Inflation
description: The pinch of general infla tion and the continually ris ing prices of clothing  as well as the confusion on mini, midi and maxi skirt lengthshave brought Sev enth Avenue to one of its most depressed states in years.

title: Maritime Vandals
description: For four years a small group in the House of Repre sentatives has been making it impossible to deal effec tively with oil pollution originating from ships at sea. Since the wreck of the Torrey Canyon first focused public attention on the menace, a series of such inci dents has afflicted the coastal areas of the world.

title: The Apartment Was a Mess But for $320 He Revamped It
description: IT was a disaster area, a garbage heap, Joseph Cucchiara recalled. I had seen the apartment a few weeks before it was vacated and well, it was dirty all right, but nothing like it was when they finally moved out.

title: NIXON POSTPONES A MAJOR CHANGE ON IMPORTED OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  President Nixon postponed in definitely today any major change in the controversial oil import control program pending discussions with foreign coun tries, including mainly talks with Canada on an integrated North American energy, market.

title: Japan Ships More Autos
description: TOKYO, Feb. 20 (Reuters) Japan's motorvehicle exports will top 1 million units for the first time in fiscal 1970, the Japan Automobile Manufactur ers Association predicted to day. It said overseas demand would rise 18.9 per cent to reach 1.07million units, while domestic needs would be 4.5 million units, up 12.4 per cent.

title: Conservative Lawyer to Head Desegregation Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) A Government lawyer who is considered a conservative on school desegregation will head the staff of a White House group designed to aid Southern school districts struggling with courtordered desegregation.

title: McNamara For More Aid; Treasury Chief Hacks Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Robert S. McNamara, the head of the World Bank, and David M. Kennedy, the Secretary of the Treasury, presented opposing views tonight over whether the United States is doing enough to help the de veloping countries.

title: WILLIAM G. FULLARD
description: William G. Fullard, who retired in 1963 as a vice presi dent of the Chemical Bank, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived at 554 Sherwood Parkway, Westfield N.J.

title: FIVE PROTESTANTS FREED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 20Five men accused of conspiring to blow up a water pipeline last year to embarrass the Government and as a pro test against the jailing of the Rev. Ian Paisley, a Protestant extremist leader, were acquit ted tonight.

title: CROWN GROUP BUYS DYNAMICS HOLDING
description: Henry Crown, Chicago indus trialist, and Nathan Cummings, chairman of the executive com mittee of Consolidated Foods Corporation, announced yester day they had entered into an agreement to purchase 526,400 shares of common stock of the General Dynamics Corporation from the Dreyfus Fund. Inc.

title: Pan Am to Add 747 Service
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that its Boeing 747's would start flying to San Francisco April 10 and to Hong Kong April 11. The big new jets will serve on the daily Los Angeles  San Francisco Tokyo run starting April 10. They are scheduled to appear in Hong Kong the next day when the Los AngelesHonoluluTokyo service, on which they are to make their debut March 10, is extended to the Chinacoast colony. The first daily 747 flight from Hong Kong to Los Angeles by way of Tokyo and San Francisco is scheduled for April 12.

title: Hampshire's Philosophy: Confusion Is Acceptable
description: PRINCETON, N. J.  Some philosophers search for clar ity of ideas and control over their languageto say no more and no less than they want to. Bertrand Russell was such a man: he believed that we can clearly express genuine knowledge of our own mental states.

title: For Her, Dressing Well Isn't Worrying About the BestDressed List
description: WHEN Mary Lee Fair banks tried to beg off going to Noel Coward's 70th birthday party recently be cause she was tired from a roundtheworld trip and felt she looked a mess, Mr. Coward comforted her with: Don't worry, they'll only be looking at me, anyway.

title: YONKERS OFFICIAL INDICTED IN THEFT
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20 Cline B. Stephens Jr., who re signed yesterday as City Con troller of Yonkers, was indict ed by a grand jury here today on charges of having appropri ated city funds for his own use.

title: INFERNO, 53FOOTER, WINS 104MILE SAIL
description: LUCAYA, Grand Bahama Is land, Feb. 20In a duel that rival yachtsmen found hard to believe, Windward Passage beat Ondine across the finish line in the 104mile Miamito Lucaya race today by 24 sec onds.

title: CAB FLEETS SEEK FARE RISE AT NIGHT
description: A 30 per cent average in crease in the cost of a taxicab ride on weekends, holidays and at night was requested yester day by the 78 taxi fleet own ers here.

title: MANY KEPT IN JAIL BY LACK OF AIDES
description: Scores, perhaps hundreds, of people convicted of minor crimes here and awaiting sen tencing have been kept in jail over the last few months despite a statute that specifi cally forbids such detention because there have not been enough probation officers to investigate their cases.

title: Arafat at Ends Soviet Visit Without Sign of Success
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20  Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guer rilla leader, ended a 10day visit to the Soviet Union today without apparently having met any important Soviet officials or having received any specific pledges of Soviet support for Al Fatah, the organization he heads.

title: Fumbling on Rent
description: No issue in municipal politics engenders mor emo tion than rent control. George W. Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, did little to de fuse the emotionality of the current argument over relaxation of New York City's creaky rent control law by his implied suggestion that the best thing to do was abolish it.

title: AntiDaley Black Militant Eyes House
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19Can a man who disdains Richard J. Daley and sides with the Black Panthers be elected to Con gress?

title: Mrs. Lindbergh Troubled by Dying Environment
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 20Anne Morrow Lindbergh, the author and conservationist, took an apprehensive look at the planet earth today, but found some hope for it if man kind can develop what she called earth values.

title: HAWKS OBTAIN WHITE IN TRADE WITH KINGS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20  The Chicago Black Hawks obtained Bill White, an experienced de fenseman, and Gerry Desjardin, a goaltender, today in a six player National Hockey League trade that dispatched Gilles Marotte, a defenseman, and Dennis DeJordy, a goaltender, to the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Cerrudo Cards a 65 for 136 to Take OneStroke Lead in San Antonio Golf
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 20 (AP)Ron Cerrudo, a young Californian, impervious to the inclement weather, carded a course recordequaling 65 to day and moved into the second round lead in the $100,000 San Antonio open golf tournament.

title: Penn Central Completes Oil Company Acquisitions
description: The Penn Central Company said yesterday it had com pleted the previously announced acquisition of the Southwest ern Oil and Refining Company and the Royal Petroleum Cor poration through the exchange of $40million of a new class of Penn Central preferred stock.

title: COBURN FORESEES FISCALYEAR LOSS
description: The Coburn Corporation of America, a diversified finance company based in Rockville Centre, L. I., announced yes terday that it expected to incur a loss in its fiscal year, which ends this month, that it had ousted its chairman and that the company was making vigor ous efforts to return to profit able operations.

title: Finch Calls on Courts to Define Idea of Unitary School System
description: AUBURN, Ala., Feb. 20Sec retary of Health, Education and Welfare Robert H. Finch said tonight that the desegregation of the nation's public schools could not progress on an order ly, uniform basis unless the courts settle on a definition of the nature of a unitary school system.

title: Robert Pinkerton, A Magazine Writer And Novelist, Dies
description: Robert E. Pinkerton, a nov elist and magazine writer, died Monday at the Florence Night ingale Nursing Home. He was 87 years old.

title: American Musicians From Rome Strive for Unusual Effect Here
description: Contemporary music reached some sort of desperate nadir last night as the Musica Elet tronica Viva displayed its wares at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Text of President's Statement on OilImport Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Following is a statement by President Nixon today on a report by his Cabinet task force on oilimport policy:

title: Wisconsin Capitol Cleared
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 20 (AP).  The Wisconsin Capital was evacuated shortly before noon today after a telephoned threat that a bomb was in the building. The building was searched and no bomb was found.

title: Businessmen Endorse Black Capitalism
description: Two businessmen, one white and one black, rejected today the contention by some that black capitalism holds little prospect for the economic advancement of the American Neero.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Quakers Keep Ivy Lead
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20Four players scored in double figures for Pennsylvania tonight as the Ivy League leaders defeated Yale. 8771.

title: Winner Rehired for a Year As Cardinal Football Coach
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 (AP)  The St. Louis football Cardinals rehired Coach Charlie Winner today for one year. His two previous contracts had been for twoyear terms.

title: Calley Meets With Wallace and Receives Sympathy
description: MONTGOMERY Ala., Feb. 20 First Lieut., William L. Calley Jr., who is awaiting courtmar tial on charges of murdering 102 South Vietnamese civilians, conferred for an hour today with former Gov. George C. Wallace and won a measure of sympathy.

title: Stennis Amendment Seems Sure to Haunt Liberals, Despite Doubts on Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The prominent new Senate pairing of John C. Stennis of Missis sippi and Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut has virtually guaranteed that racial segrega tion will be a more open issue in the 1970 elections than ever before.

title: Topics: Vietnam Options  One General's Viewpoint
description: As Commander of United Nations forces in Korea, I signed the Armistice on July 27, 1953, which terminated the fighting. After the signing cere mony I said:

title: ARIADNE AUF NAXOS SCHEDULED BY MET
description: Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera for the first time in six years in a performance to be given on March 12 (during the 11th week of its season. The title role will be taken by Leonie Rysanek, Reri Grist will be Zerbinetta, Evelyn Lear will be the Composer, and Walter Berry will be the Music Mas ter. Karl Bohm will conduct.

title: Bridal Planned In the Summer By Mary Freese
description: FRANKLIN, Ind., Feb. 20  Brig. Gen. James Freese, U.S.A.R., assistant command ing general of the Army Reserve's 70th Division in Detroit, and Mrs. Freese have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Mary Susan Freese of New York, to John William Holt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Holt of Pearl River, N. Y. The wedding is planned for July at the First Presbyterian Church in Edinburg.

title: FUTURES ADVANCE ON SOVIET REPORT
description: Commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade reacted sharply to several internation al and domestic events yester day.

title: Leary, Wife and Son Guilty Of Marijuana Possession
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP)Timothy Leary, his wife and son were convicted last night of possession of mari juana on Dec. 26, 1968.

title: Governor Urges Laws to Protect Dwindling Wildlife
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20  Gover nor Rockefeller has asked the Legislature to enact laws to protect endangered wildlife, in cluding the American alligator, by restricting possession or sale of their hides or parts.

title: KEY BASE IN LAOS REPORTED SEIZED
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Saturday, Feb. 21Tanks and about 6,000 North Vietnamese soldiers seized the Plaine des Jarres air strip early today and by mid day controlled nearly all of the strategic plain, official sources said.

title: 2 Women Die in L.I. Crash
description: ISLIP TERRACE, L. I., Feb. 20 (UPI)  Two women died and the 2yearold son of one of them was injured here this afternoon when their car col lided with a garbage truck. The police said that those killed were the driver of the car, Mrs. Carmella Lobello, 43 years old, of 249 Amityville Street, Islip Terrace and Mrs. Josephine Mignano, 69, of 66 Moffitt Bou levard, East Islip. Mrs. Lobello's son, Anthony Jr., was listed in fair condition at Southside Hospitl.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS REGISTERS ADVANCE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP) United States auto production surged upward as the auto in dustry scheduled 164,857 new cars for assembly this week, up from 95,433 last week.

title: Oil Industry Praises Directive by Nixon
description: The oil industry and its sup porters reacted favorably if not almost joyously to President Nixon's announcement that he would take no immediate action to implement majority recom mendations of his special Cab inet committee on oilimport policy.

title: Foot Doctors Keep in Step
description: Jim Turner, the New York Jets' placekicker, is to receive the Golden Foot Award of the American Association of Foot Specialists, a medical group, at a dinner at the Hotel Roose velt tonight.

title: MARION GREENWOOD, MURALIST. 60. DEAD
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Feb. 20 Marion Greenwood, a painter and muralist, died at the Ulster County Infirmary here this aft ernoon after a long illness. She was 60 years old and was a resident of Woodstock and New York City.

title: Fanny May to Sell $800Million Total In Two Offerings
description: A substantial volume of new security offerings was announced yesterday by Fed eral agencies, states and cor porations.

title: DR. FRANCES F. DOWNEY
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20 Dr. Frances F. Downey, assist ant medical director at the New Jersey NeuroPsychiatric Insti tute, died in an automobile col lision Wednesday night. She was 55 years old and lived at the institute, in Skillman, N. J.

title: Italy's Balance of Trade Showed Deficit in October
description: ROME, Feb. 20 (AP)Italy's balance of trade showed a def icit of $101.6million in Octo ber, reversing the yearearlier surplus of $80.2million, Gov ernment statistics showed to day.

title: A Correction
description: Some dates mentioned in the obituary of Mrs. Louise Clews Timpson in The New York Times of Feb. 11 were incor rect. Mrs. Timpson married her second husband, Capt. Ian Campbell, in 1935, and they were divorced in 1951. He be came the Duke of Argyll in 1949.

title: CHRYSLER PLANS 200MILLION ISSUE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20Moving to shore up its shrinking fi nances, the Chrysler Corpora tion revealed today plans to raise $200million through a public offering to be made dur ins the week of March 9.

title: Barge Hits Coast Jetty, Spills Fuel
description: EUREKA, Calif., Feb. 20 (UPI)A barge loaded with 2.5 millions gallons of gaso line and diesel fuel collided with a jetty in Humboldt Bay today and spilled 84,000 gal lons into a flammable, float ing slick 300 yards long.

title: Molniya Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP)The Soviet Union launched another in its series of Molniya satellites today, the official Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: Judge Delays Senate Inquiry Into New Left Units' Records
description: A Federal judge here yester day temporarily barred an ef fort by the Senate Internal Se curity Subcommittee to sub poena the bank records of the Liberation News Service and the regional office of the Stu dents for a Democratic Society.

title: Lions Score, 10774
description: Columbia, which has some of the fastest basketball play ers in the East, went into high gear last night and ran Dart mouth ragged to post a 10774 victory at University Hall.

title: Conservationists Ask Study of Environmental Unit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20The New York State Conservation Coun cil warned today against hasty action on Governor Rocke feller's plan to create a depart ment of environmental conser vation.

title: CARACAS WORRIED BY U.S. OIL TALKS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 20This country's oil, which has long heated millions of homes in the northeastern Unit ed States, is now causing a marked cooling in diplomatic relations between Washington and Caracas.

title: AN EPILEPTIC INFANT SAFE IN KIDNAPPING
description: Ozark, Ala., Feb. 20 (AP)A missing 4monthold girl, who needed medication for epilepsy three times a day to live, was found alive and aparently well tonight, more than a day after her mother reported her mis sing.

title: Newark School Talks Resume Despite Arrest of 20 Teachers
description: NEWARK, Feb. 20Despite the arrest today of 20 striking teachers on picket lines, formal negotiations to end the three weekold teachers' walkout re sumed this morning after a lapse of more than three days.

title: INDOOR 500 MARK CLIPPED BY EVANS
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20 (AP) Lee Evans streaked to a world record time of 54.5 seconds in the 500yard run tonight in the San Diego Indoor Games.

title: Dr. Joao Cafe Filho, 71, Dies; A Former President of Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20 Dr. Joao Caf Filhor, a former President of Brazil, died of a heart attack here today. He was 71 years old.

title: Mediators in Talks With L.I.R.R. Clerks
description: The National Mediation Board has entered contract negotiations between the Long Island Rail Road and the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, automatically defer ring a strike that had been scheduled for 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: Philippines Alerts Forces To Guard U.S. Embassy
description: MANILA. Feb. 20The Philip pines Foreign Secretary, Carlos P. Romulo, alerted police and military forces today to guard the United States Embassy to morrow against expected new demonstrations.

title: RALPH L. ROEDER, A BIOGRAPHER, 79
description: Ralph Lecierq Roeder, author of Benito Juarez and His Mex ico, died in Mexico City last Oct. 22, according to word re ceived here from the American Consulate by The Viking Press, his publisher. He was 79 years old.

title: Lunar Eclipse Called Poor by Viewers Here
description: A lunar eclipse, the first since April 12, 1968, occurred early this morning, but even before it began one expert classified it as poor.

title: Lindsay Is Refused California Degree
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 Mayor Lindsay of New York was turned down for an honorary degree today by the Board of Regents of the University of California.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON HIT LOW FOR 1970
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange again slipped to low levels for the year yesterday.

title: Market Place:
description: IS the brokerage community unwilling to speak out in favor of the new commission schedule?

title: U.C.L.A. Beats Ore. State
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Feb. 20 (UPI)  The nation's No. 1 ranked team, University of Cali fornia, Los Angeles, used a zone defense to screen out 7 foot Vic Bartolome and beat Oregon State, 7156, tonight. Bartolome wound up with only 10 points. The victory was the 21st in succession this season for the Bruin and their ninth in the PacificEight Conference.

title: Liguori Takes 1,500 in 3:44.8 at Olympic Meet
description: Marty Liguori, who prefers to sit back and let his rivals make the pace, went out early and quickly en route to his eighth straight indoor victory at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Miss Mitchell Plans Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 20David Windsor Mitchell, executive vice president of Avon Products, Inc., in New York, and Mrs. Mitchell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mar cia Anne Mitchell, to William Burlee Zeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Zeller of Darien.

title: Train Kills 2 on Snowcars
description: STRATFORD, N. H., Feb. 20 (AP)Two snowmobile opera tors were crushed to death when their machines were hit from behind by a Canadian Na tional freight train here today. The state Fish and Game De partment identified them as Willard McFarland, 53 years old, of Groveton, N. H., and Albert Hodgen, 46, of Granby, Vt.

title: Printing With Heat
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20A method of printing that Texas Instruments, Inc., has found highly satisfactory for computers applies heat in stead of pressure. A patent was granted this week to three company inven tors, one of whom Week was awarded medal last Mon day by President Nixon.

title: SYLVAN HOFFMAN, 78, PUBLISHER, IS DEAD
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20  Sylvan Hoffman, a publisher and editor, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 78 years old and had moved here in 1964 from New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: CITY ACTS TO EASE JAMMING OF JAILS
description: Two steps were taken yester day toward a program an nounced earlier by Mayor Lind say to ease overcrowding in the city's jails.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Peace in Mideast

title: Washington: For the Record
Dutch Fight Pollution of Their Canals
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 20Dutch officials have drawn up tough new legislation to fight pollu tion in their country's vast net work of inland waterways, but they have decided not to try to stop boatmen from dumping sewaae into the water.

title: China Raises Price of Tourist Goods for Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 20The owner of a small antique and curio store in a quiet back street in bustling Kowloon rubbed his bands in embarrass ment and smiled entreatingly at the complaining customer.

title: PAUL CHIHARA GIVES PIECES FROM TREES
description: The rock musician's way of dealing with the conflicts and confusion of presentday life is generally to turn up the ampli fiers and drown them out. Paul Chihara, the very modern, but nonrock, 32yearold Japanese American composer, who pre sented a program of his works at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, seems to prefer the op posite way.

title: COMPLAINT CASES OF THE POLICE RISE
description: The Police Department's Ci vilian Complaint Review Board has reported a sharp increase in the number of cases in which it has recommended the placing of charges against mem bers of the police force.

title: Airline Lays Off 1,100
description: MIAMI, Feb. 20 (UPI)Na tional Airlines furloughed 1,100 mechanics and other maintenance workers today and said the action was the result of a strike of Air Line Employes Association members that entered its fourth week. National has a total work force of 7,500 in 44 cities. The company said most of the lay offs, 750, would be at its main Miami installation. In New York, 150 maintenance em ployes were notified of suspen sion from their jobs.

title: U.S. and Chinese Envoys Confer in the American Embassy in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, Feb. 20 (AP) In a meeting described as useful and businesslike, the United States and Chinese Communist envoys in War saw conducted today the 136th session of their 15 yearold ambassadorial talks.

title: New Yorker's Gift Twits Lindsay
description: The New Yorker magazine, which observes its 45th birth day today without fanfare, had a little fun yesterday with Mayor Lindsay at City Hall.

title: REED SHOWS WAY IN GIANT SLALOM
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 20Last week at the Dart mouth Winter Carnival, Coach Ralph Townsend of Williams looked at the hard surfaces on the Big Green's Skiway slopes and said jokingly:

title: Japan's World Role
description: There is no disputing Premier Sato's prediction the other day that the 1970's will be an era where Japan's national power will carry unprecedented weight in world affairs. At the turn of the decade, the industrious Japanese have achieved a gross national product aproaching $200 billion, third highest in the world. At present growth rates, Japan confidently expects to reach a $600billion economy by 1980.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE names and problems that turn up in S. G. F. Brandon's essays on the religions of the ancient world are so familiar that his study might seem no more than a repeated, popular assessment of some of the major figures in the classical religious canon: Osiris, Zarathustra, Job, Akhenaten, Paul, Jesus. But the author's emphases are so much his own and his rea soning about the evidence so adroit that the conventional pictures may appear slightly askew and in some cases even disturbing.

title: Kathleen McGrath To Become Bride
description: Surrogate Christopher C. McGrath of the Bronx has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Kath leen Helen McGrath, to Paul Arthur Cunnion, sales man ager of the food importing concern of Calvert Vavas seur & Co.

title: U.S. Marshals Live With Lacey Family Because of Threats
description: NEWARK, Feb. 20United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey disclosed today that he and his family had been threat ened with violence during his investigation of organized crime in New Jersey.

title: Mrs. Margaret Scarrone Is Rewed Here
description: Mrs. Margaret Hitchcock Scarrone, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock, and the late Mr. Hitchcock, the polo player, was married in Tuc son. Ariz., on Dec. 31 to Walter H. Bowart, the artist who founded The East Village Other.

title: GUY ENDORE, 69, NOVELIST, IS DEAD
description: Guy Endore, novelist, biogra pher and screenwriter, died of a heart attack in a Los Angeles hospital on Feb. 12. He was 69 years old.

title: Cheese Dumplings Add Fillip to Meat
description: CHEESEFILLED dumplings are an Old World treat that can bring variety to con temporary meals. In the menu below they are teamed with a simple veal dish but would be equally good with roast veal, lamb or boiled beef.

title: Breeding Contempt for Law
description: LONDON, Feb. 20In this country, courts are treated as temples of order and tradition, detached from the noise of life. The notion of using them as a forum for social protest would be utterly unacceptable. Some Welsh students who tried a rather tepid demonstration in a courtroom the other day found themselves in jail before the day ended.

title: COMSAT'S NET IN '69 HIGHER BY $288,000
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  The Communications Satellite Corporation reported today a net income for 1969 of $7,129,000, or 71 cents a share. The 1968 net income was $6,841,000, or 68 cents share.

title: Goldwater Hails Young People, Agrees With Much of New Left
description: Senator Barry M. Goldwa ter told a college audience here yesterday that the current gen eration of young people was the best he had ever known.

title: Executive Changes
description: Nicholas E. Crane has been named vice president and manager of the option department of Hayden, Stone, Inc. He formerly held similar posts with Dean Witter & Co., Inc.

title: 5 IN CHICAGO TRIAL GET 5YEAR TERMS AND $5,000 FINES
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20The five men convicted Wednesday in the Chicago conspiracy trial were each sentenced today to five years in prison.

title: Rangel, Calling Powell a Failure, Says He Will Seek Congressional Post
description: Assemblyman Charles B. Ran gel charged yesterday that Rep resentative Adam Clayton Po well had failed the Harlem of today and said he would op pose the Congressman for the Democratic nomination in the 18th District.

title: Lowenstein Says F.A.A. Won't Curb Jets' Noise
description: Representative Allard K. Lowenstein charged yesterday that the Federal Aviation Ad ministration had not the slightest intention of doing anything to relieve the night mare of noise.

title: Tugboat Talks Still Stalled
description: An attempt by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to break the contract deadlock in the 20dayold tug boat strike failed yesterday.

title: Miss Madelyn Jamison Bride of L. M. Holmes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The marriage of Miss Madelyn Jamison to Lewis M. Holmes, a physicist with the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N. J., took place here today. Judge E. A. Beard of the General Sessions Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Kings Point Five Defeats Hunter in Upset, 74 to 67
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 20 Kings Point opened a 16 point halftime lead and went on to upset Hunter College, 7467, at O'Hara Hall tonight.

title: Labor Board Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 When George Meany announced that the Amer ican Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Or ganizations would oppose President Nixon's nominee to head the National Labor Relations Board, some union lawyers in Chicago were almost embar rassed. The soft spoken, dispas sionate nominee, Edward Boone Miller, is a pro fessional management lawyer who has mixed in labor dis putes there for 20 years, and among his opponents he has built up a reputation as fair minded, trustworthy and un derstanding of labor's posi tion.

title: Manhattan to Start Garner Against Fairfield Five Today
description: Rich Garner, the sophomore who came off the bench to fig ure prominently in four Man hattan College victories, will make his first start today when the Jaspers meet Fairfield in the first game of a basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: MEIER CONDUCTOR IN MAGIC FLUTE
description: One cannot get too much of The Magic Flute, so it makes perfect sense for the New York City Opera to present the Mo zart work just now, following the Metropolitan's staging of it this winter. The City Opera revived its production last night at the New York State Theater as the second performance of its spring season.

title: PORT HERE RETAINS ITS LEAD IN TRAFFIC
description: The Port of New York re tained first place last year among the 11 major United States ports in terms of the number of oceangoing ships that entered and left it, Its share of the total rose from 20.3 per cent in 1968 to nearly 21.2 per cent, according to fig ures compiled by the Maritime Association here.

title: Island Hunt: Wet, Cold, Dogless
description: Seagoing policemen and agents of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Ani mals went through rough water today and spent more than two hours on a cold beach, hoping to catch a dog that has been living on a tiny island in Jamaica Bay.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ABE RATTNER

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW FIRM TONE
description: For the second session in a row, the American Stock Ex change's index closed un changed yesterday. The steady ing point was 25.63. During the week the index moved as high as 25.89 and as low as 25.34.

title: Excerpts From Laird Report to Congress on Defense Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Following are excerpts from the introductory summary of the annual defense report to Congress by the Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird:

title: SCHOOL ELECTION IN MARCH BACKED
description: The New York Chapter of the American Jewish Commit tee disassociated itself yester day from a call by the Coali tion for an Effective Commu nity School System for the sus pension of the scheduled March 19 local school board elections throughout the city.

title: U.S. Judge Extends Rail Order; To Make Strike Ruling March 2
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) Judge Howard Corcoran ex tended a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court today, postponing until mid night March 2 a threatened shutdown of the United States railway system.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NUDES ALEX S

title: HOSPITAL IN CHICAGO LIMITS ADMISSIONS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20Cook County Hospital began restrict ing admissions to lifethreat ening emergency situations last night because of over crowding and shortage of per sonnel.

title: Hijackings Tighten Security at Latins' Airports
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 20  Boarding a commercial airliner in Latin America is becoming a complicated and timecon suming process.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
A ROCK GROUP ROCKS BUT WITH NO GUITAR
description: The Modern Rock Quartet, or MRQ as it prefers to be called, is providing a lesson in basic musical power. The group, from Ottawa, is playing through tomorrow at the Electric Cir cus, 23 St. Marks Place.

title: FOLK FIDDLE DUETS IN SWEDISH CONCERT
description: One of the high points of the Newport Folk Festival last sum mer was the fiddle duets of two Swedes, Ole Hjorth and Bjorn Stabi. Their performances so captivated Israel Young, the guru of Greenwich Village's Folklore Center at 321 Sixth Avenue that he closed up his shop in November and went off to Sweden for an extended va cation.

title: F.T.C. URGES A LAW ON CAR STANDARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Federal Government would prescribe and enforce minimum standards of quality, durability and performance for new auto mobiles under legislation rec ommended today by the Fed eral Trade Commission.

title: EXPORT OF FUNDS CURBED BY ITALY
description: ROME, Feb. 20  Reports from foreign money markets indicated today that two Italian measures designed to slow ex ports of capital, legal and il legal, already had begun to take some of the profit out of specu lation against the lira.

title: DR. E. J. DONOVAN, SURGERY DIRECTOR
description: Dr. Edward J. Donovan, for mer president of the New York Academy of Medicine and for mer director of surgery at St. Luke's Hospital Center, died Thursday here. He was 80 years old and lived at 510 East 23d Street.

title: Hylton Captures Citrus 250 at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20James Hylton of Inman, S. C., one of the few success ful independents in stock car racing, won the Florida Citrus 250 today at Daytona Interna tional Speedway. It was only the second time he had ever run this type of race, desig nated Grand American for smaller sedans like Camaro Cougar and Javelin.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Summer Bridal For Miss Turner
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20  Mr. and Mrs. Gordon B. Turner have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Michael Ann S. Turner, to Paul S. Walstad. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O. Walstad. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: STRATTON TO RUN IN A NEW DISTRICT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20  Repre sentative Samuel S. Stratton, an upstate Democrat whose dis trict was dismembered by the Republicancontrolled Legis lature, announced today that he would run against an in cumbent Republican, Represen tative Daniel E. Button of Al bany.

title: Reward Up in Police Attacks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 (AP)A reward fund rose above $25,000 today as city and law enforcement officials sought to halt bombing attacks on the Bay Area policemen. The police drafted plans to fence and floodlight precinct stations in the wake of two bombingsone fatal to a police sergeantand the discovery of a booby trap wired to a police man's car in nearby Vallejo.

title: Party in Prague Expels Two Leading Intellectuals
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 20 (Reuters) Prague's Communist party organization was reported to day to have approved the ex pulsion of some leading intel lectuals from the party.

title: Founder of Minutemen Gets 4 Years for a Bail Violation
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 20 (UPI)Robert Bolivar DePugh, founder of the militant Min utemen, was sentenced today to four years' imprisonment for failure to appear in Federal Court for trial on charges against which he posted a $5,000 bond.

title: Article 3  No Title
Rogers Apparently Mollifies Gowon on Relief Issue
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 20 Secretary of State William P. Rogers, who came to Nigeria on a mission of conciliation, apparently met with some suc cess today in a twohour meet ing with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian head of state.

title: LONE PATROLMAN KNIFED IN HARLEM
description: A policeman on a lone foot patrol on Lenox Avenue at 136th Street in Harlem was stabbed with a 10inch bowie knife at 12:45 A.M. yesterday by an assailant who stole up on him, plunged the knife into his back and fled.

title: CLASH NEAR DANANG KILLS 4 AMERICANS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Feb. 21 (AP)American troops clashed with North Viet namese forces for the second time in eight days in the Que son Valley area south of Da nang, the United States com mand said today. It reported that four Americans had been killed and 28 wounded.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A YEAR ago the high school basketball coaches of Queens were embroiled in a nasty controversy over the eligibility of a 6foot4inch sophomore center to play for Van Buren High. Decisions and counterdecisions by various school authorities confused the issue and a ruling in Queens Supreme Court led to the reinstatement of the boy but a disruption of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament. Most coaches felt the ruling was unfair and some revolted against the spirit of it, competing in a tourna ment of their own and forfeiting games rather than play Van Buren.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1970

title: COASTING KNICKS FACE HAWKS HERE
description: The New York Knickerbock ers enter tonight's game against the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden with an impres sive enough lead (seven games before last night's action) to allow them the luxury of a bit of a letdown in the final 17 games. With 52 victories in 65 games, the aim from now until the end of the schedule on March 22 will be to get ready for the playoffs.

title: Oslo to Aid Both Vietnams
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 20 (AP) Norway decided today to con tribute $140,000 for aid in North and South Vietnam. The Foreign Ministry announced that the money had been put at the disposal of the Inter national Red Cross Committee.

title: Attorney General Allowed To Review Kopechne Data
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)At torney General Robert H. Quinn was granted permission today by the Suffolk Superior Court to review the secret documents in the Mary Jo Kopechne in quest.

title: MARKET MANAGES NARROW ADVANCE
BEST OF FRIENDS STAGED IN LONDON
description: London, Feb. 20To com plete this week's set of basic West End horrors, James Elward comes forward with Best of Friends. The play at the Strand Theater, is an Amer ican family comedy with its heart firmly lodged in the Brooklyn Heights mansion where Nigel Patrick and Sio bhan McKenna are reunited after the storms of life to redis cover the virtues of marriage.

title: U.S SPUR PLANNED ON HOUSING FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The Administration is going to ask Congress to authorize the expenditure of up to $300mil lion to forestall what it fears could be a dramatic drop in the flow of money into mort gages.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Opera

title: AMATEUR CHORAL PICKS FROM BRAHMS
description: A full evening of Brahm's choral music is not often en countered these days, so at the very least, Martin Josman is to be congratulated for providing one yesterday at Philharmonic Hall.

title: Sellers Signs for Comedy
description: Peter Sellers has been signed to star opposite. Goldie Hawn in There's a Girl in My Soup, which M. J. Frankovich Produc tions will start filming in London next month for Columbia Pictures. John and Roy Boult ing will produce and Roy Boult ing will direct the comedy which was adapted by Jo Heims from the hit play by Terence Frisby.

title: KLEIN IS ACQUITTED IN L. I. KIDNAPPING
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20  Julius F. Klein Jr., a Long Island racketeer, and his father and a third defendant were, found not guilty today of hav ing kidnapped and extorted $175,000 from the president of a Suffolk County plastics com pany in 1967.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
Memorial for Dr. Solomon
description: A gathering for the friends of Dr. Alan R. Solomon, art his torian and critic who died Wednesday, will be held Mon day at 10 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In accordance with Dr. Solomon's wishes, there will be no funeral service.

title: Abram to Leave Brandeis; May Run for Goodell's Seat
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20Morns B. Abram, president of Brandeis University, will officially an nounce his resignation on Mon day, presumably to clear the way for his seeking the Demo cratic nomination for the United States Senate from New York.

title: Carswell Chartered White Club To Aid Florida State U. in 1953
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 20Judge G. Harrold Carswell, President Nixon's nominee to the Su preme Court, chartered an all white booster club for Florida State University in 1953.

title: SURVIVAL THEME OF FAIR ON COAST
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 20 As the sound of taps echoed through a sunfilled afternoon, the students of San Jose State College buried a car today, symbolizing their feeling that the automobile represents a grave danger to the survival of mankind.

title: Wife Visits Hess in Hospital
description: BERLIN, Feb. 20Rudolf Hess, the deputy fuehrer and last of the major Nazi war criminals still in prison, re ceived halfhour visits today from his wife and sister at the British military hospital in Ber lin. Hess, 75 years old, is serv ing a life sentence for war crimes. He has been under treatment for a stomach ulcer since November.

title: ANTIQUES SHOW OPENS 10DAY RUN
description: There are several oases for the hunter of antiques at the National Antiques Show, which opened yesterday for a 10day run at Madison Square Garden. The coin collector may find refuge and prizes in a special area devoted to his specialty, while the photography buff may be attracted by the prints and other relics of an earlier day of camera art.

title: Dike Heads Field of 10 for $133,800 Widener Handicap at Hialeah Today
description: MIAMI, Feb. 20The Widen er Handicap, one of the earliest of the big money races on the American thoroughbred calen dar, has attracted a field of 10 for its 33d running tomor row.

title: LAIRD CITES PERIL IF SOVIET PRESSES MISSILE BUILDUP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Soviet missile buildup, if it continued at its current pace, could place the United States in a second rate strategic position by the middle of this decade.

title: Marrero Picked to Direct Bronx Model City Program
description: Victor Marrero, a 28yearold assistant to Mayor Lindsay was appointed director of the Model Cities program for the South Bronx yesterday. He will be paid $25,000 a year.

title: A Forlorn McLain Asks for Benefit of Doubt: Don't Convict and Condemn Me
description: LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 20Denny Mc Lain, suspended from baseball at the age of 25 for bookmaking activities, sat in the living room of his home here today and asked the public not to convict and condemn him while his $200,000ayear world came apart at the seams.

title: HAROLD C. HOWE, 83, EXMAGAZINE EDITOR
description: Harold C. Howe, a magazine editor, news syndicate manager and movie publicity man in New York and Hollywood for more than half a century, died Wednesday night in Flushing Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old and lived at 4142 Parsons Boulevard in Flushing, Queens.

title: Bomb Suspect Calls Judge a Jackass
description: Samuel J. Melville, one of four defendants charged with a series of crimes involving the bombing of Government build ings and vehicles here last fall, faces possible contemptof court charges after calling a Federal judge a jackass yester day.

title: World Church Body Issues Plea to 4 Sides in Vietnam
description: GENEVA, Feb. 20  The World Council of Churches called on the United States today to refrain from methods of warfare in South Vietnam, which by longterm damage to the soil and vegetation further endanger the life of human beings!

title: Art: The Oeuvre of Avery and Moholy
description: TWO major retrospective exhibitions of modern art ists  the American painter Milton Avery (18931965) and the Hungarianborn painter, designer and theorist Laszlo Moholy  Nagy (18951946) came to New York this week.

title: Dr. Stanhope BayneJones Dies; Bacteriologist and Educator, 81
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  Dr. Stanhope BayneJones, a bacteriologist, medical educator and Army officer, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.

title: ED SEL FORD DIES; ARKANSAS POET, 41
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 20 (AP)Edsel Ford, the poet and winner of awards for his writ ings stet in the Ozark hill coun try, died yesterday. He had un dergone surgery recently. His age was 41.

title: R. H. Savage to Wed Lorna Dale
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20  Miss Lorna Alan Dale, an actress, and Robert Heath Savage will be married this May in New York.

title: Landlords Oppose Suggestions To Extend RentControl Law
description: Leaders of the city's major landlord groups yesterday as sailed suggestions by City Council members that the rent control law be extended until the lawmakers receive and study two pending reports on the housing situation here. The current law expires March 31.

title: Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: EL SHAFEI UPSETS LAYER BY 63, 108
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 20 Ismail El Shafei had to unpack his bags tonight. The 22year old Egyptian surprised himself, a crowd of 3,800 and the world champion by beating Rod La ver, 63, 108, and entered the semifinals of the National open indoor tennis championships.

title: ROOKIE MAY MISS PLAYOFF CONTESTS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20Xrays disclosed today that Brad Park, one of the most gifted mem bers of the New York Rangers, incurred a fractured right an kle during last night's 33 tie in Detroit but no immediate prognosis was made as to how long the 21yearold defense man would be unable to play.

title: CITY FINDS INTEREST ON LOANS HURTING
description: Higher interest rates for temporary loans have cost the city an unanticipated $20mil lion and have renewed pes simism that the current $6.6bil lion budget can be balanced by the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

title: G. W. HULDRUM JR., SHELL EXECUTIVE, 53
description: G. W. Huldruin Jr., an exec utive of the Shell Oil Company in New York, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 53 years old, and lived in New York.

title: SOVIET GIRLS WIN WORLD SKI CROWN
description: STRBSKE PLESO, Czecho slovakia, Feb. 20 (UPI)  The Soviet Union's women skiers won a gold medal today in the 15kilometer crosscountry relay race at the world Nordic ski championships.

title: Antiques: 1800's Cut Glass
