description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 (AP) Bob Netolicky scored 37 points to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 130110 victory over the Pittsburgh Pipers to night in an American Basket ball Association game. The 6foot9inch Netolicky also led both teams in rebounds with 22.

title: Edith Morrison, 69, Dies; ExSarah Lawrence Aide
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 21 Edith G. Morrison, who re tired in 1966 as controller of Sarah Lawrence College, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived here and in Provincetown, Mass.

title: 22 Injured on Bronx Bus Hitting Post After Pothole
description: Twentytwo persons were in jured, none seriously, yester day afternoon when a bus hit a pillar supporting IRT sub way tracks at Southern Boule vard and 167th Street in the Bronx.

title: Memorial Seroires
description: McEWENlan Howard Potter. Memorial serv ice Church of the Epiphany, York Ave. and 74th St., at 12 noon, Tuesday, Feb. 24. Please omit flowers.

title: Planned Community Is Rising
description: APLANNED community of mod est scope but wide interest among town and planning of ficials in New Jersey is begin ning to rise on the flat and rather barren land off Route 33 in East Windsor township, about 10 miles southeast of Princeton.

title: Choosing the Narrow Path
description: Dr. Arthur F. Burns has assured the Joint Economic Committee of Congress that the Federal Reserve Board will do everything in its power to prevent a reces sion. At the same time Dr. Burns has made it clear that he does not intend to ease money so much or so soon as to add to inflationary pressures. He warned that inflation may prove to be more stubborn than we realize. As though to underline his remarks, the new consumer price index showed another sixtenths of 1 per cent rise in Januarycontinuing the 7.2 per cent annual rate of rise of the preceding two months.

title: Security Steps Taken By Swiss Air Officials
description: GENEVA, Feb. 21Special precautions against possible Arab attacks on Swiss planes have been taken by the Swiss airline and the federal Air Of fice since the sentencing of three Palestinian commandos to 12 years in prison by a Swiss court last December.

title: REBEL CHIEF, HERE, ASSAILS PORTUGAL
description: The head of the liberation movement in Portuguese Guinea has charged that Portuguese forces have begun using Ameri canmade planes in napalm bombing and strafing attacks against guerrilla forces.

title: Article 11  No Title
Switzerland Paves Way For Tourists
description: GENEVAThe Swiss are literally mov ing mountains to keep visitors to this Alpine wonderland happy this year. To help make her soaring peaks and sparkling lakes more accessible, Switzerland is offering tourists new high mountain roads, new cable cars, new scenic highways and new lake steamers.

title: Arab Air Outrages
description: The death of 47 persons as the result of a bomb explosion aboard a Swiss airliner bound for Israel is the ultimate outrage in the murderous campaign Palestinian terrorists have been conducting against innocent air travelers. The response must come from the world, not from Israel alone.

title: AMBASSADOR IN BONN URGES VISITS TO U.S.
description: BONN, Feb. 21The United States Ambassador to Bonn, Kenneth Rush, has called for half a million West German tourists to visit the United States this year and for more West German capital invest ments in America.

title: CARDINAL DOI DEAD; TOKYO'S ARCHBISHOP
description: TOKYO, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Peter Cardinal Tatsuo Doi, the first Japanese to be named a Cardinal of the Roman Catholic church, died today of pneu monia in a hospital here. He was 77 years old.

title: Stop and Go: Italy Eyes Traffic Woes
description: ROME  Italy has been preoccupied with the automobile and its impact on tourism during the past year. On the one hand, it has been con structing new roads to speed vehicles; on the other, it has been creating new auto bans, or pedestrian islands, to provide a respite from escalating traffic.

title: In The Nation: Who Can Question the Government?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  Events in Judge Julius J. Hoff man's courtroom have spoken so loudly for themselves that there remain only a few things worth saying. On every side, there has been enough and to spare of near outrage and for that reason the end of this his toric political trial is at least merciful.

title: Amex Chief Has Doubts On Liquidity
description: The man who presides over the august board of governors of the American Stock Exchange usually is not outspoken on securities industry problems and unobtru sively goes about his business without landing in the public spotlight.

title: London: The Big Power Challenge
description: LONDONThe world is now passing through a time of in tense intellectual and political revision. Seldom have the con tinents, the nations, the races, or the generations of men been so dependent on one another in actual fact, or so determined to avoid nuclear war and world economic depression; yet un derneath their cooperation on these two supreme objectives, they have seldom seemed more divided and disconnected on secondary but important issues.

title: RISING MARKET 2D, FADES IN STRETCH
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 21 William Haggin Perry's Dewan outran Rising Market in the stretch today to win the $84,350 San Antonio Stakes at Santa Anita Park.

title: Announcements
description: Announcements

title: PENN FIVE SCORES OVER BROWN, 8456
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 211 (AP)  Penn rolled to its 16th straight victory and 23d in 24 games tonight by crushing Brown, 8456, in an Ivy League basketball game. The league leaders have won all 12 of their games.

title: VOTE ON SCHOOLS BEING ORGANIZED
description: A search will be made this week in several outofstate cities for persons who have had experience in oversee ing proportionalrepresentation elections. They will be invited to come to New York to help organize the community school, board elections on March 19.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.  All day, cold rain driven by a sharp northeast wind swept across Mack Ballard's 100 acre Squash Hill Shooting Preserve.

title: lona Conquers St. Francis As Wiggins Stars, 7860
description: Arthur Wiggins scored 22 points last night in facing Iona to 7860 victory over St. Francis at the 69th Regiment Armory. The winners held a 4319 half time lead.

title: Art
description: IN AN adulatory judgment of the Metropolitan Museum's splendid new exhibition, The Year 1200, which opened to museum members on the 11th and to the public the follow ing day, I reported one day last week that only the most assiduous nitpicker could find a flaw in this collection of some 300 sculptures, ivories, metal works, enamels, manuscripts, textiles, gems, and fragments of stained glass windows as selected and organized by Florens Deuchler, chairman of the Met ropolitan's department of medieval art and of its medieval branch, The Clois ters. I also found the installation by Stuart Silver, of the museum's exhibi tion design department, beyond reproach.

title: Education
description: In New York and in communi ties across the nation, fear is spreading over the apparent in crease in the use of narcotics among teenagersand even younger children. It is becoming an alarming problem in the schools.

title: Education
description: To those who remember the flood of industry and govern ment recruiters to college cam puses as recently as a year ago, often surrounded by stu dent pickets, the decline in job interviews these days would be surprising. The reason? The job market for fresh graduates, squeezed by economic pres sures, is drying up.

title: Hesburgh to Be Honored
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 21 (AP)The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the Uni versity of Notre Dame, will receive on April 14 this year's Bellarnmine Medal from Bellar mineUrsuline College. His se lection was announced Wednes day. The award, established in 1955, goes to an individual who has exemplified in a notable manner the virtues of charity, justice and temperate ness in dealing with difficult and controversial problems.

title: Jean C. Wylie To Be a Bride
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Feb. 21Mr. and Mrs. Alexander P. Wylie have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Jean Christie Wylie, to John Rolland Edmonds, son of John K. Edmonds of New York and Mrs. Jean Ed monds of Norwalk.

title: Dr. Wickersham Weds Virginia Marth, Nurse
description: OLD LYME, Conn., Feb 21 Miss Virginia Marth, nurse epidemiologist at Hartford Hospital, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Corne lius Wendell Wickersham 3d, a senior resident in internal medicine there and member of a noted New York fam ily. The Rev. Dixon Hoag per formed the ceremony at the Old Lyme Congregational Church.

title: A Panel in Arizona Denies Herbicide Caused III Effects
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21 (AP)A scientific committee has denied that a controversial herbicide spray program caused any significant ill effects in humans or animals.

title: Frederick II was an
description: Each year, for the past five, a new historical novel by Ce celia Holland has been her alded as one of the excite ments of midwinter publish ing. With her first, The Fire drake, Miss Holland (who was born as recently as New Year's Eve, 1943) burst upon the world like the comet for which her title was a synonym. In a re markably controlled style, with a plot built around a mythical knight, she made her reader understand what it might have been like to ac company William of Normandy on his invasion of England.

title: Musie

There were delays in the Gott schalk project, and the five volumes have just come off the press.

title: The Quality Of Military Justice
description: THE normal attitude of the Amer ican public toward military justice is compounded of equal parts of indifference and ignorance. In what used to be normal times, this was natural enough. Before World War II, the peacetime military establishment was small and com posed entirely of regularsa caste that tended to be distinct from the rest of the population. Its officers came from West Point or Annapolis, married the daughters of other regu lars and sent their sons to West Point or Annapolis. Enlisted men got drunk on payday and drunker at the expira tion of every hitch, after which they staggered back to the post and re enlisted. When they landed in the brig or guardhouse, which was fre quently, the civilian public cared about the fairness of the proceedings no more than it cared about the system of criminal justice applicable to other foreigners, such as Chinese coolies. Neither the Supreme Court nor anyone else ever supposed that the Bill of Rights applied to soldiers. Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase said in 1867 that the power of Congress in the government of the land and naval forces ... is not at all affected by the Fifth or any other amend ment, and the proposition was scarcely challenged until after World War II.

title: The Sculpture of Mary Frank: Poetical, Metaphorical, Interior...
description: IN THE current climate of art, esthetics, and criti cal opinion, the sculp ture of Mary Frank is difficult to place. It seems, by most of the prevailing standards, to exist outside of contemporary art history al together. It derives from no clearly defined intellectual position. It invokes no sweep ing historical imperatives. Theories of any sort seem alien to its purposes. Kant, Wittgenstein, Merleau  Ponty  none of the glittering names can usefully be quot ed on its behalf. Historically and intellectually, it is utter ly defenselessan orphan in the storm of theory and countertheory that now con sumes so vast a proportion of the attention, energy, and talent of the art world. It is a throwback to other times even its technique is an cient.

title: BERNSTEIN DENIES SHIFT ON PANTHERS

title: For Young Readers
description: With production costs for four color illustration soaring apace, the handmedown art book is getting to be an increasingly common phenom enon. Simply defined, the handme down, or retread, is a volume made up of previously published com ponents that have been altred slight ly, more or less to fit a readership for which they weren't originally tailored. These two volumes, 17TH & 18TH CENTURY ART and TWEN TIETH CENTURY ART (McGrawHill, $8.95 each; 191 pages), are typical examples and, although both carry prominent bylines, both turn out on close inspection not to have been written by their putative authors, but to have been adapted by them from materials earlier cobbled up in Eng land and Italy.

title: AUSTRALIA EASES RACIAL BARRIERS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 8 Ronne Arnold, a talented danc er from Philadelphia, came to Sydney eleven years ago in a touring production of West Side Story. He has re mained ever since, teaching and heading his own troupe, the Australian Contemporary Dance Company.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1970

title: Columbia Routs Harvard, 9469, As Dotson Scores 1,253d Point
description: Heyward Dotson and Jim McMillian received a 5minute standing ovation from a capac ity crowd of 1,924 persons at University Hall Iast night when they left the court 1 minutes before their Columbia team mates completed a 9469 vic tory over Harvard.

title: ANTONIONI DEFENDS ZABRISKIE POINT
description: MAMA mia! Michelangelo Antoni oni has a right to sing the blues. Until a few days ago, he was sit ting on top of the movie world: the establishment critics endorsed him, the auteur crowd adored him, the public stood in line and paid for the privilege of applauding him. Everybody dug his dissection of the bored Italian bour geoisie in L'Avventura and La Notte and Eclipse and Red Desert, and they grooved merrily along with the dissolute London swingers in BlowUp.

title: Mannequins Limn Mores
description: From Newark to Atlanta is a long way, but not so far as South Africa.

title: Utopia, unfortunately, was on the dull side
description: Ira Levin's brave new world is populated by 8 billion mem bers of The Family, who con sider hate and fighting dirty words, and live in cities known as EUR55131, or USA60607. Mars and Venus colonies take care of surplus people. Everyone eats totalcakes and worships Christ, Marx, Wood and Wei. Life is planned and programed from birth through death by UniComp, the super computer 5 kilometers down in side the earth under Mount Peace, in EUR00001. Not only does Uni select a person's ca reer, decide whether he can marry or have children, and tell him where to live. It also keeps him happy by carefully sched uled treatments at medicenters, where tranquilizers cancel all his latent tendency to worry, argue, complain  and also, unfortunately, to think.

title: Rent Unit Cuts Some Refunds, Changes LeaseExtension Rules
description: Refunds to many tenants un der the city's new Rent Sta bilization Law have been cut by the Conciliation and Appeals Board, the semiindependent panel appointed by Mayor Lindsay to adjudicate landlord tenant disputes under the stat ute.

title: Mrs. Romney Fails to Get Senate Nod
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 21 Mrs. George Romney was unable to muster sufficient support among Michigan Re publican leaders for endorse ment as a candidate for the Senate.

title: Sandra C. London Is Bride in Noroton
description: NOROTON, Conn., Feb. 21 Miss Sandra Conti London, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard John London of Wilton, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Francis McGratty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lee McGratty of Islip, L. I. The Rev. Michael F. Blanchard performed the ceremony in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: No one in film reviewing is so utterly unsentimental
description: In five years, Pauline Kael has published three volumes of her writ ings on film. After selling well in hard covers, the first two were rap idly reprinted, not, like most crit icism, in quality paperbacks but in the format of bestselling novels.

title: Pollution Fight: Profit Bonanza?
description: In Lawrence, Kan., the Kansas Power and Light Company is putting up a util ity station whose design in corporates an environmental control system that is geared to meet pollution control re quirements of the nineteen eigfities.

title: UDALL WEIGHING RACE FOR SENATE
description: PHOENIX, Ariz.  Stewart L. Udall, who served for eight years as Secretary of the In terior, is seriously considering a race for the Senate seat now held by Paul J. Fannin.

title: World Press Award Goes To Norwegian Newspaper
description: A daily Norwegian news paper, The Stavanger Aften blad, was the winner yesterday of the 1970 World Press Achieve merit, award. The award has been presented annually by the American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation for the last six years.

title: JIM BOSTWICK GAINS COURT TENNIS FINAL
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 21Jimmy Bostwick, the na tional open champion, won two matches today to reach the final of the 68th annual Gold Racquets court tennis tourna ment at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: Full Extent of Ford's Braking On Racing Outlay Is Not Clear
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21Motor racing is so expensive that nobody can hope to be successful at it without having big money be hind him. One of the more important sources of funds is factory support, which is a way of camouflaging, for purposes or public relations, a manufacturer's participation in racing. Instead of fielding a team that repre sents a Detroit company outright, the manu facturer may hire or subsidize an enterprise to race under its own name. The company gives the teams car parts and technical advice and pays expenses. Ford and Chrysler do it openly; General Motors does it ambiguously through the Chevrolet division, partic ularly in road racing.

title: The lifestyle, psyche and formal institutions of the Southtwo studies
description: Though these books cover much of the same ground and agree in many of their conclusions, they are different works, indeed. Numan Bait ley's The Rise of Massive Resist ance is valuable as a welldocu mented, carefullyfootnoted, chrono logical record of Southern turmoil brought on by a decade of special Dixie folly; his prose, however, is so bloodless as to conjure up visions of a plastic man writing from some distant detachment in an aircondi tioned and fumigated room.

title: Never Bow Decisively Takes Widener as Dike Finishes 9th
PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1BRIAN BRAKE FROM RAPHO GUILLUMETTE

title: Professor at Columbia Named to Oxford Chair
description: Dr. William E. Leuchten burg, professor of history at Columbia and an au thority on the New Deal of President Franklin D. Roose velt's administration, has been appointed to the Harold Vyvyan Harmsworth Chair of American History at Ox ford University for the 197172 academic year.

title: Ford Criticizes F.T.C. Plan For Auto Industry Controls
description: DETROIT, Feb. 21 (UPI) A proposal by the Federal Trade Commission to bring the auto industry under Govern ment controls similar to those of public utilities drew criticism today from the Ford Motor Company.

title: Knowles Tells Doctors to Change Or Face Government Control
description: Dr. John H. Knowles, direc tor of the Massachusetts Gen eral Hospital, warned the Amer ican medical profession yester day that, unless it makes a sharp turn away from what he called a 50year history of negativism and resistance to change, it is a virtual guaran tee that we will have govern mental controls slapped on us and that we will be handed lock, stock and barrel over to the central government.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Nichols
description: Miss Elizabeth Addale Nichols, a senior editor at BobbsMerrill & Co., and Joseph Francis Kelly Jr., a lawyer with Townley, Up dike, Carter & Rodeers here, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior. The Rev. Coleman Clohosey performed the ceremony.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: THERE was a somewhat surprising amount of buoyancy and enthusiasm in the financial markets last weekpartic ularly in the bond sectorthat once again derived more from hopes than realities.

title: Harvey to Aid Mission Society
description: Supporters of the New York Mission Society will gather for dinner in the Plaza's Terrace Room on March 3 before boarding buses for the ANTA Theater to see Harvey.

title: DR. MILTON R. MILLER
description: Dr. Milton R. Miller, a former professor of dentistry at Co lumbia University, died yester day in New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 650 Park Avenue.

title: Poetry as an expression of all that men knowandfeel
description: At the conclusion of his great es say on Poetry and Abstract Thought, the French poet Paul Valry summons the reader to con sider the extraordinary labor that must be invested in the making of a single poem: Think of everything that must go on inside a man who utters the smallest intelligible sen tence, Valry writes, and then cal culate all that is needed for a poem by Keats or Baudelaire to be formed on an empty page in front of the poet. There are many ways of arriving at such a calculation, of course, and the great edifices of es thetic theory, linguistic analysis, critical discourse, and literary history all testifyoften eloquentlyto the prodigious effort man has made to understand the nature of his own sublime utterances.

title: Columbia Turns Back Lehigh in Track, 5652
description: Columbia's track and field team won eight of 13 events to edge Lehigh, 5652, in a dual meet yesterday in the Baker Field airdome.

title: Those who lose can't risk
description: Horatio Alger would never have made it in Rio Verde. In Moritz Thomsen's recounting of the complexities of his rela tionship with the people of that small Ecuadorian town we learn why.

title: Troubled Ulster Seeks New Image
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  The troubles that have wounded North ern Ireland during the past year have not taken away its charm, its history and its opportunities for recreation, and tourist officials here have been under taking an intensive campaign to restore this country's battered image and to let the world know that it remains a place of hospitality and friendliness for visitors.

title: AN EXPLANATION ASKED OF M'RAIN
TREEPLANTING DRIVE REPORTED IN CHINA
description: PEKING, Feb, 21Millions of people are at work planting hundreds of millions of trees in a drive in southern, central and eastern China, according to Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency.

title: 30 TRIAL PROTESTERS SEIZED IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 21  About 30 youths were arrested today during a demonstration in support of the seven defend ants in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

title: African Marijuana Seized
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  South African police said today they have destroyed more than 224 tons of marijuana  worth more than $20million on the local market  since they began raids on the Umbumbula Afri can reserve near Durban on Feb. 12. Six Africans have been arrested, the police said.

title: Photography
description: COLOR for its own sake rather than as a vehicle for communication of realistic content alone is a growing practice, even among photojournalists. Color is often used today not mere ly to report on a factual level but to arouse emotional re sponse and to intensify mood. Its usefulness for abstract de sign is as obvious as it is be coming widespread, but the combining of realism with a strong, emphasis on color is less prevalent and calls for more than ordinary skill and imagination.

title: Messages to the World From President Nixon
Bargains Beside the Nile Luxury Vacations on Budget
description: CAIRO  Despite her hostilities with neighboring Israel, Egypt has adopted a warm and friendly attitude to ward tourists, and local hotels are offering special discounts to induce pros pective visitors to vacation here.

title: Nationalist China's Hsieh Leads Manila Golf by Shot
description: MANILA, Feb. 21 (AP) .. Hsieh YungYo of Nationalist China took a onestroke lead at 210 after three rounds of the Philippine open golf tour nament today.

title: Lloyd Varden's Contributions
description: LLOYD E. VARDEN, whose death in New York last month left the photo graphic industry be reaved of one of its most val ued mentors, had that rare combination of qualities that attracted people to him as well for his thorough techno logical gifts as for his funlov ing personality. His death at 58 was far, far too early for all that he had yet to con tribute.

title: INQUIRY ON PRICES DUE ON CEMETERIES
description: Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo said yesterday his office would investigate Brooklyn rabbi's charge that cemeteries involved in the six weekold gravediggers' strike were engaging in unscrupu lous price gouging.

title: Western White House To Be Used Regularly
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)  The Nixon Adminis tration has disclosed that the Western White House at San Clemente, Calif., will be used for federally sponsored meet ings on a yearround basis.

title: Layman's Peace of Mind
description: There is an old saying that when doctors disagree and the patient is caught in the middle the results can be not only confusing but also disastrous to the patient's peace of mind.

title: Mexico Facing European Competition
description: MEXICO CITY  The age of the jumbo jets is putting Mexico's lucrative tourist market under strong compe titive pressure from other areas that also interest wide ranging United States travel ers. More than 2 million for eign visitors came to Mexico last year. Of this record total, capping a decade of spectac ular tourist expansion, more than 90 per cent were from the United States.

title: He knew how to spell Abracadabra and Magick
description: Over the last hundred years or so Christianity has rapidly failed as a cohesive social and spiritual force, and the collapse of its credibility has led to much confusion and unhappi ness in Western religious life. These obvious facts have caused many peo ple to wonder what the world is coming to. Others have simply paid no attention. A smaller cannier group, however, has seen the situa tion as a call to positive action. A period of spiritual and moral relativ ism, while undoubtedly rough on the earnest seeker after truth, is a high old time for the religious conman, the crank, and even, I'm sorry to say, for the eager but stupid cleric.

title: U.S. Business:
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 21 The number of new plants and expansions in the over milliondollar category set a record in Virginia during 1969, according to J. Frank Alspaugh, director of the Vir ginia Division of Industrial Development.

title: HULL GETS 500TH AS RANGERS LOSE
The Beautiful People Go West
description: SUN VALLEY, IdahoAt celebritysated, starstudded Sun Valley, even the most jaded namedroppers remember the night at The Lodge when the cham pagne glasses were filled and refilled for the Shah of Iran until he raised his hand and quietly announced: And now, ladies and gentlemen, we shall ski in the moonlight.

title: Portgugal Declines Comment Special to The New York Timm
description: LISBON, Feb. 21Portuguese officials declined to comment when a summary of the Cabral interview was read to them. They said some comment might be forthcoming once the Gov ernment had a chance to read the complete article.

title: F.A.A. Gets Plan for Preventing Midair Crashes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Four recommendations for deal ing with the menace of midair collisions have been submitted to the Federal Aviation Admin istration by the National Trans portation Safety Board.

title: Martin and G.M. Head Elected to Mayo Board
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Feb. 21 (AP)William McChesney Martin, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Edward N. Cole, presi dent of General Motors, have been elected to the Mayo Foundation Board of Trustees.

title: Army Gymnasts Triumph But Cadet Riflemen Lose
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 21 Army's gymnastics team snapped a four  meet losing streak and evened its season's record at 44 today as the cadets coasted past Syracuse, 141.5 to 120.20.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: COLLEGE IN HAWAII

title: A WRITER KNOCKS ZABRISKIE POINT
description: PREVIEW night at a new Antonioni film feels a little like play ing bingo in Saint Peter's Basilica. You can sense the stakes in the air, the rustle of reputation over pile carpeting, the perspiration under corporate collars. After all, this isn't just somebody's movie they're unveil ing tonight. Zabriskie Point is MGM's entree into The New York Review of Books, and Antonioni's hid for a life time subscription to Rat. No wonder the lobby of the Coronet is brimming with dry expectation. One man's tenure arbiter of Now is the line.

title: Yale Conquers Dartmouth For Lead in Ivy Swimming
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 21 Dartmouth's slim hopes for an upset were dashed today as Yale's powerful swimming team scored a 6449 victory over the Indians in the Alumni Gym pool.

title: Letters
description: OPERA: THE HURRICANE AND THE MUSIC

title: Swedish Line Orders 2 Ships
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 21  The Grangesberg Company, a major Swedish shipping operator, has announced that it has placed $50million order for two com bination ore and oil car riers. The 265,000deadweight ton vessels will be built at the Uljanik Shipyard in Pula, Yugo slavia, and are scheduled for delivery in 1972 and 1973. The contract includes an option for a third vessel of similar size.

title: Phoenix: To Get Their Man Dead or Alive
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee may have been con fused by last week's testimony on Operation Phoenix. The com mittee had a report from the American military command in Saigon that seemed to give Phoenix the credit for hunting down and killing 6,187 Vietcong political cadres last year. Then it heard William E. Colby, the pacification chief in Vietnam, emphatically deny that Phoenix was an assassination program.

title: Renaissance Ensemble Fuses Classical and Rock at Fillmore
description: Renaissance is the latest Eng lish band to attempt a fusion of classical music and rock.

title: SOVIET RELEASES TWO MORE ALIENS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21The So viet Union, apparently relent ing under diplomatic pressure, today released the last two of four young foreigners who re cently received oneyear sen tentes for public protests in support of Soviet dissidents.

title: Ibos Who Fled to Biafra in Fear Begin to Reclaim Jobs in West
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 21 When a young man with a shy smile walked into a big busy hank here the other day, most work stopped for a moment, as the tellers whispered among themselves and then scurried over to see him.

title: Article 4  No Title
Cubans Here Are Ending Mafia's Monopoly on Numbers Racket, With 20% of City Play
description: The Mafia's nearmonopoly, of the numbers game, which is believed to collect $200million a year from New Yorkers and give back about half that amount  in prizes, is being broken by Cuban refugees with heavy bankrolls who have so far taken control of about 20 per cent of the operations here.

title: SHOD HONORS GO TO A PENNY MORE
description: READINGTON, N. J., Feb. 21 Capt. Gonzalo V. Fuentes, who served in the Mexican Army for 17 years before cor ing to the United States, rode A Penny More to the limit jumper championship today at the Four Seasons Farm horse show.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayHollandia Farms, Mo riches Road, St. James, L. I. Junior and green working hunt ers, intermediate jumpers, equi tation. 9 A.M.

title: Puerto Rican Group Is Quitting Role in Community Development
description: The Puerto Rican Community Development Project will be completely restructured from communityaction program to a technical assistance agency for the Puerto Rican com munity, according to Raul A. Reyes, the organization's new executive director.

title: MANY FROM CITY APPLY TO STATE U.
description: Applications to the State Uni versity of New York from high school seniors here have report edly jumped 50 per cent over last year, while applications for admission to the City University next fall have risen 15 per cent.

title: Bronx Fire Kills Mother And Injures Her 3 Children
description: A twoalarm fire in a six story Bronx tenement early yesterday killed a 40yearold mother and injured her three children, two of whom were hospitalized with burns.

title: Crime Panel Picks Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)  A former Assistant United States Attorney for the South ern District of New York, Paul L. Perito, has been named chief counsel of a House panel investigating organized crime. He succeeds Richard W. Kurrus, who returned to pri vate practice in Washington.

title: Start Them Indoors
description: START vegetables at home on a sunny window sill. I do!

title: A Correction
description: The report in last Sunday's Times describing the Old Eng lish sheepdog, Fezzwig Artful Dodger, the bestinshow win ner at Hartford, as being out of control most of the time under the amateur handler, Jim Mc Ternan, was erroneous. Frank Foster Davis, the judge, called the statement misleading. The dog is owned by Mr. and Mrs. Hendrik Van Rensselaer. The Old English sheepdog behaved in every way during the best inshow judging. Davis said, It was after this was complet ed that he became spooky. I would never have considered him had this display taken place during the judging.

title: SURVIVORS PLAN DEATH CAMP VISIT
description: For the 200 who will return to that site it will be a bitter memory, not to be forgotten in their lifetime, or for their chil dren, remarked Josef Rosen saft.

title: SERICA TAKES 2D IN $59,600 RACE
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 21Proc ess Shot, a 4yearold filly owned by Sonny Werblin, won the $59,600 Barbara Fritchie Handicap today, covering the 7 furlongs in 1:23 3/5. She won by four lengths.

title: H. EARLE DOW
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Feb. 21 H. Earle Dow, who retired in 1958 as vice president in charge of Brooklyn branches of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died today in his home at 43 Bingham Circle, Mtmsey Park. His age was 75.

title: Miss Carmichael Quits at 18 To Concentrate on Education
description: PAMELA CARMICHAEL of Gates Mills, Ohio, who ruled both the small and large junior working hunters divisions in recent years and then took to riding jumpers last season  has retired from competition at the age of 18.

title: Georgia Beats Ole Miss
description: ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 21 (AP) Georgia jumped to a 10point lead midway in the first half, then fought off several Missis sippi comeback attempts to win handily, 9479, today.

title: Dutch Scientists Blame Polluted, DredgedUp Mud for Widespread Deaths of Seabirds 100 Miles Away
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 21Dutch scientists have concluded that polluted, dredgedup mud that was dumped offshore from Rot terdam was apparently respon sible for the widespread deaths of a colony of seabirds a hun dred miles away.

title: Germany's Great Year To Star Oberammergau
description: BONNWest Germany is busy prepar ing for a great travel year, but only the farsighted tourist with wellmapped itinerary and advance reservations stands a chance of getting his money's worth of fun and variety.

title: Most Prices Mark Time On OTC List and Amex
description: Investors went through the motions again last week on the overthecounter mar ket and on the American Stock Exchange. Changes in the major indicators were slight.

title: Trinidad  When the Tourist's Not King
description: PORT OF SPAIN, TrinidadMo ments after Carnival ended here on Feb. 11, Ash Wednesday, the stillgroggy islanders began prep arations for next year's festival. For Carnival in this capital and throughout Trinidad is not just a weeklong baccha nal, but a carefully thoughtout event that involves everyone all year.

title: Soviet Scores Warsaw Talks
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  The Soviet press today stepped up attacks on the talks in Warsaw between American and Chinese Communist diplo mats, the day after the second round of the resumed talks fol lowing a twoyear break a twoyear break.

title: Policemen Catch Dog on Ruffle Bar
description: The dog that had roamed in freedom for many months on a little island in Jamaica Bay was in the hands of the police yesterday.

title: CatholicReformed Talks Set
description: ROME, Feb. 21 (UPI)  The Vatican Secretariat for Chris tian Unity announced today the Roman Catholic Church will begin talks on April 6 in Rome with the World Alliance of Re formed Churches. Theological questions arising between the two religious bodies under the principal theme of The Pre sence of Christ in the Church and in the World will be stu died.

title: Science
description: Last week one of the world's foremost authorities, Art Buch wald, explained why so many potholes have recently appeared on streets and highways. It is all the work of the National Pot hole Association whose members stealthily chew up the pave ments.

title: Going to the Fair?
description: ONE of the first conversations had after coming to Tokyo in February, 1946, was rather onesided. A man came up to me in the street, clutched my elbow, stared me in the eye for a few seconds, and declaimed: Idon'toknow!

title: Coins
description: EACH year, the birth day of George Wash ington, born in West moreland County, Va., on Feb. 22, 1732, is an oc casion for special celebra tions by many coin clubs throughout the nation. Groups meeting this week will no doubt carry on the tradition by making our first president the theme for exhibits at their February sessions and at regional shows.

title: Atlantic City's Conventions on Rise
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 14An addition being built to Convention Hall here symbolizes the growth of one of the leading industries in this resort  conventions.

title: Soviet Finds Continued Employment After Retirement Age Helps Prolong Life
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R., Feb. 16Dr. Zakary G. Frenkel, a Soviet hy gienist who turned 100 last year, was recently asked to what he credited his lone life.

title: CERRUDO POSTS 69 FOR 4SHOT LEAD
Cornell Beats Dartmouth
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 21  Ken Wiems of Cornell scored as time ran out tonight to give the Big Red a 7472 victory over Dartmouth in an Ivy League game tonight.

title: House Panel Hires Perito
description: Paul L. Perito, a chief as sistant to former United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau in New York, has been named chief counsel to the House Select Committee on Crime, Rep. Claude Pepper, chairman, announced yesterday. Mr. Peri to was a trial counsel against Roy M. Cohn when Mr. Cohn and two associates were ac quitted in a bribery case last December.

title: STAR SINKS 2 FOULS TO DECIDE BATTLE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 21Niagara edged St. John's, 7270, today before a crowd of 3,500 at the Niagara Student Center and an East Coast tele vision audience.

title: Greece Back In the Swim
description: ATHENSThe record 1.3 million vaca tionists in Greece last year almost caught the natives napping. Dis heartened by a twoyear slump in tourism, they had neglected to expand their facilities rapidly enough, and now they are trying to catch up with what may well be a tourist explosion this year of 1.6 million visitors.

title: Connecticut Democratic Party Is Called Shattered
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 21  As a major election approaches, Democrats are describing their party  which has ruled Con necticut for 16 yearsas shat tered, divided, split.

title: Norway Is Biathlon Victor
description: OESTERSUND, Sweden, Feb. 21 (AP)Norway won the jun ior relay event today in the world biathlon championships. Sweden was second and the Soviet Union third.

title: In Brief
description: In colonial times the nu merous Germans of Pennsyl vania (the socalled Pennsyl vania Dutch), of Maryland and the Valley of Virginia beyond the Blue Ridge were the only significant nonBritish seg ment of the American popula tion. A sturdy, homogenous group, they had fled the wars and persecutions of 17thand 18thcentury Europe to seek a better life in the New World. Their story and that of later German settlers in Virginia and of their contribution to the making of our nation are well told by Klaus Wust.

title: Stage: Simplicity and The Prince of Peasantmania
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 21 The Milwaukee Reper tory Theater Company has this season acquired a brand new and serviceably hand some theater, the Todd Wehr Theater, and last night it celebrated by producing a brandnew but rather less than serviceably handsome play, Frank Gagliano's The Prince of Peasantmania.

title: Eric Rivchun Fiance Of Miss Rosengarten
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Rosen garten of Belle Harbor, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Marla Rosengarten, to Eric Rivchun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Armand Rivchun of Cleveland.

title: Oklahoma Wins, 7573
description: AMES, Iowa, Feb. 21 (UPI) Garfield Heard hit 30 points to lead Oklahoma to a 7573 vic tory over Iowa State today.

title: Utah Wins by 11382
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Utah rekindled its Western Athletic Conference title hopes by routing Wy oming, 11382, today with a fastbreak at each.

title: Golden Ball Set in Jersey
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 21The North Bruns wick Woman's Club will mark its fifth anniversary with a Golden Ball Saturday at the Greenbrier here. Mrs. William Serensen Jr. and Mrs. Philip Pallone are gen eral chairmen of the event. Tickets at $35 a pair

title: Flutes of Gold, Golden Flutist
description: LOOKING for all the world like Ingres's famed portrait of Monsieur Ber tin, JeanPierre Rampal, the French flutist, exudes an enormous sense of bienetre and joviality. He is a big man  a man of energy and great good humor. Undoubtedly the leading flutist of his day, Rampal is currently making tour of the United States and Canada. During any concert he strides on stage with an air of supreme confidence; he smiles; he acknowledges applause like one accustomed to tribute, and he launches into the music with a passion altogether unheard of in the somewhat circumscribed world of the flute.

title: Patricia Johnson Engaged
description: CAMDEN, Tenn., Feb. 21 Robert Cobb Johnson, own er and publisher of The Camden Chronicle, and Mrs. Johnson have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Patricia Ann John son, to Stephen Andrew Lasher, son of Alfred William Lasher Jr. of Houston and of Palm Beach, Fla., an inde pendent oil producer, and Mrs. Robert Morrow Welch Jr. of Houston. Miss Johnson is a graduate of Vanderbilt University where her fianc is senior.

title: Ford Foundation Makes Asian Research Grants
description: The Ford Foundation has announced more than $2.5 million in grants for interna tional research, with special emphasis on Asia.

title: Bar Panel Reaffirms View That Carswell Is Qualified for Supreme Court
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 21The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary reaffirmed today its earlier unanimous finding that Judge G. Harrold Carswell was qualified to serve on the Su preme Court.

title: Post Tops Adelphi, 7862, To Snap Losses at 3 Games
description: BROOKVILLE, L. L, Feb. 21 C. W. Post College brokev a thegegame losing streak to night, defeating Adelphi Uni versity, 7862, M a NorthEast Collegiate Basketball League at Gymnasium.

title: Must man first go mad in order to be sane?
description: For a great many Americans, par ticularly young Americans, the 1960's were a time in which two of the deep est streams of consciousnessself consciousness and social conscious nessconverged. The radical vision and energy of the sixties aimed at a fusion of ideas and experiences which the fifties had found either unrelated or incompatible: political freedom and personal ecstasy, activism and mysti cism, voterregistration drives and mindexpanding drugs, sitins and loveins.

title: Melinda Hall Plans Nuptials
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 21 Mr. and Mrs. John Manning Hall have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Melinda Morgan Hall, to John Mc Curdy Eaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick McCurdy Eaton of New York.

title: Mrs. Robin Reeder McLagan Wed to C. Braxton Valentine Jr.
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 21In the chapel of Grace Cov enant Presbyterian Church here today Mrs. Robin Reed er McLagan was married to C. Braxton Valentine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine, by the Rev. William F. Sum mers.

title: Reader's Report
description: Here is a delicious sliver of whimsy hovering somewhere between A. A. Milne and Mack Sennett, if you can imagine such a phenomenon. Miss Tonks's characters are a covey of English (and one Ameri can) vacationing on an Italian island, who carry on about sex in the tone of Christopher Robin chatting up Winnie The Pooh. The effect is not in sipid, as one might fear, but disarming and joyful.

title: TB Strikes Capitol Hill
description: In an era of lunar exploration, it seems anachronistic that such an oldand curabledisease as tuberculosis could break out in the halls of Congress. But such was the case last week. Two per sons were dead of TB and four other cases were known among persons working on Capitol Hill. The outbreak was traced to a woman who had worked in the Senate restaurant.

title: U.S. Making Initial Move Against Thermal Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Federal officials will make their first major move next week against a new and largely un charted environmental problem thermal pollution.

title: Winter's Heat Bills Causing Shivers
description: THE winter is now heavy upon us, and its severity is giving many the nag ging feeling that money, as well as smoke, is going up the flue.

title: A Moroccan affair
description: One of the world's most unusual dishes is a Moroccan affair that combines chicken with pickled lemons and rich black olives such as the Alfonso olives of Spain (California olives don't make it). Here is one version of the dish with pickled lemons, which must be prepared at least two weeks in advance. These lemons may also be used with baked fish dishes, in salads and in marinades.

title: Who to Love Due April 8
description: Who to Love, the new mu sical based on William Alfred's play Hogan's Goat, will make its Broadway debut at the Broadhurst Theater on April 8. Previews will begin March 19. Play It Again, Sam, Woody Allen's comedy, will be moved from the Broadhurst to another theater after the March 14 per formance.

title: Gray and Sammis Retain Platform Tennis Laurels
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 22 Gordon Gray and Jesse Sam mis 3d of the home club suc cessfully defended their laurels in the Greenwich platform ten nis invitation tourney for the third straight year today. They won from Oliver Kimberly and Dick Squires, the team they defeated in last year's final. Gray and Sammis rallied from a 52 deficit in the fourth set to win, 61, 62, 16, 75.

title: LAOTIAN TROOPS REGROUP IN HILLS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 22 Laotian Government forces, ap parently having offered only light resistance to North Viet namese attacks on the Plaine des Jarres yesterday, are re ported to have regrouped in hill positions south and west of the plain.

title: Michael Rabin Shows Poise and Maturity
description: He still plays with exuber ance, but there is poise behind the excitement; one is never aware of an interpretation, only the music.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: The overwhelming causative factors which account for tru ancy among the city's teen agers [news story Feb. 2] can not be solved by the schools. An inadequate number of at tendance teachers, poverty which forces many students to stay home, overcrowded schools, the decline of adult authority, retarded readers, the irrelevance of the traditional curriculum for them, drug addiction, the inability of parents to make their youngsters go to school and the fear of parents about their children's safety in the streets as well as the lack of faith in schooling among black and Puerto Rican parents, are the real factors.

title: STEEL INVENTORY REMAINS STABLE
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb, 22  There is still no sign of a ma jor inventory correction in steel markets.

title: CAMBODIA SCANS DIPLOMATIC MAIL
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 22  Cambodia has taken the unusual measure of insisting on examining all incoming and out going diplomatic pouches, ap parently to forestall an attempt by three Communistcontrolled governments to introduce large quantities of illegally held or counterfeit Cambodian currency.

title: MISS VITA GAINS HUNTER TRIUMPH
description: SOMERS, Conn., Feb. 22A Little Wrecked won the regular working hunter championship at the Shallowbrook horse show today, but his days as a fox chaser are numbered.

title: AMMAN DISCLOSES GUERRILLA ACCORD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 Agreement was announced to day between the Jordanian Gov ernment and the Palestine commando organizations over commando activities in Jordan.

title: A Question of Responsibility
description: LONDONFor those in Brit ain and on the Continent who worry that American social problems may soon cross the Atlantic, nothing is more trou bling than the drug crisis in the United States. That crisis is not too strong a word was demonstrated by the recent re ports, read here in horror, of the widespread use of heroin in American schools.

title: Stage: Anthony Sloan Transports Oedipus to 30's
description: THE myth of Oedipus is as complex as the psychia trists would have led us to believe. The new version of Oedipus by Anthony Sloan now being given by the Roundabout Theater, 307 West 26th Street, is de scribed in the program as a free adaptation of the an cient myth. But in this freedom it allows itself wonder whether it has not lost some quality of myth in the retelling.

title: Pollution Fight Gains in Colleges Here
description: The sudden popularity on college campuses of the en vironmentalpollution issue has led to confusion, op portunism and uncertainty about goals, but has also led to demands for actions that go further than any con sidered seriously before.

title: DickinsonInspired Work Revived by Kostelanetz
description: Andre Kostelanetz revived the Archibald MacLeish/Ezra Laderman collaboration Magic Prison for a special nonsub scription New York Philhar monic concert Saturday night at Philharmonic Hall. The work was given its premiere by Mr. Kostelanetz at a Promenade concert in June of 1967.

title: CHARLES L. BOWMAN
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 22 Charles L. Bowman, head of Chas. Bowman & Co., suppliers to the nutrition and pharmaceu tical industries, died here Fri day. He was 71 years old and lived at 4 Sackett Circle.

title: Moderate Leaders Fall Silent in South
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 22 The people of Charlotte and Atlanta like to think of their cities as the most racially pro aressive in the South.

title: Belmonte Wins Again, Rides Emperor's Sword
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 22 Eddie Belmonte, who rode Never Bow to victory in the $133,800 Widener Handicap at Hialeah yesterday, won his second stakes race in two days today at El Comandante race track.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Francis J. Ludemann, chair man of the board of trustees of the Manhattan Savings Bank, has been elected a director of Savings Banks Trust Company.

title: FORD EXECUTIVE SEES NO UPTURN
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22  The depth of the present recession in the automobile industry is still unmeasured. Lee A Iacocco, president of the Ford Motor Company's automobile opera tions, said today in an inter view at the Chicago Auto Show.

title: Australian Yacht Wins 4th Race in 5.5Meter Saill
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feh. 22 (UPI)  Carabella, sailed by Dave Forbes of Australia, won the fourth race in the 5.5Meter Class world sailing champion ship off Palm Beach today.

title: FINN ENDS STREAK OF SOVIET SKIERS
description: STRBSKE PLESO, Czechoslo vakia, Feb. 22 (AP)Kalevi Oikarainen of Finland won the 50kilometer race (about 31 miles) as the Nordic world ski ing championships ended today.

title: Protester Held in Portugal
description: LISBON, Feb. 22 (AP)Mrs. Maria Eugenia Varela Gomes, wife of Joao Varela Gomes, prominent opposition leader, has been arrested for demon strating against Portuguese policy in Africa, sources said today.

title: Man Who Fired at Police In Radio Car Is Sought
description: The police searched yester day for an unidentified gunman who fired six shots late Satur day night on the Harlem River Expressway near 174th Street at a radio car containing two patrolmen.

title: Philippines Picks Peso Alternative: A Floating Rate
description: MANILA, Feb. 22  The Central Bank of the Philip pines has adopted a floating rate for the peso as part of a sweeping program to restore the country's ailing economy.

title: Rangers Down Leafs, 53, and Regain First Place as Bruins Lose to Hawks
description: With only two experienced defensemen, the Rangers moved back into first place last night, posting their 1,000th career triumph in a 53 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Swidler to Aid Nuclear Unit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the Pub lic Service Commission, has been appointed by the State Atomic and Space Develop ment Authority to the state's Nuclear Power Siting Commit tee. The committee, established last year, advises the authority on the selection of sites for nuclear power generators.

title: Bridge Accident Injures Eastern Shore's Economy
description: CAPE CHARLES, Va., Feb. 17  The loneliest road in America today is U.S. 13, which runs down the narrow peninsula of Virginia's East ern Shore. It is lined with ghostly motels, darkened res taurants and gas stations that lock up at sundown.

title: MARKERS TO LINE CITY'S HIGHWAYS
description: Installation of small green markers every tenth of a mile on major highways and park ways in the city will begin this year. The purpose is to help motorists specify where they are when calling for assistance in road emergencies. The markers will also aid in roar research.

title: President Pompidou's Visit
description: There are many Americans, including ourselves, who have the gravest misgivings about certain aspects of current French policy, especially France's recently announced sale of more than 100 jet warplanes to Libya. But it is grossly improper to use such policy differences as an excuse for failure to extend to President Georges Pompidou every official courtesy during his visit to this country which begins today.

title: Largest Containership Built in U.S. Sails for West Coast and a Cargo
description: The largest containership built in this country, the Ha waiian Enterprise, is headed for the West Coast to load her first cargo. The 34,700displace mentton vessel is designed to carry more than 1,000 24foot containers.

title: Versatile Knits Are Boon to Traveler
description: MANY women are wonder ing these days in what direction fashion is going. No one can give them a definitive answer on the ups and downs of skirt lengths, but as to other directions, the answer is simple. Fash ion is heading everywhere in the world, for travel is year round instead of seasonal. As the popularity of tray el grows, the days of meticu lous packing and stiff suitcases recede farther into the past. Clothes today can be stashed away in a duffle bag, to he carried on board aircraft with the case of a handbag. They are pack able, foldable and rollable, soft but not limp. Among the most satisfying are knits of different weights and fibers, designed to look and travel well.

title: 4,627 Fans See Club Hockey at Garden
description: Fairfield University, not at all nervous playing before 4,627 fans, scored a 64 vic tory over Iona College yester day in the first club hockey game played at the new Mad ison Square Garden.

title: 1970 DEMAND LAGS IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: Orders for machine tools, which suggest far before any other economic indicator how business men view the future in terms of production plan ning, got off to a faltering start with the New Year.

title: DEMOCRATS DECLARE BUDGET UNREALISTIC
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)I A Democratic party panel called today for substantial in creases in domestic programs and cuts in defense spending, asserting that the Nixon Ad ministration's budget can lead only to a dead end and national decay.

title: Nastase Gains U.S. Open Indoor Tennis Title
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 22 the Nastase of Rumania con tinued his ascendancy toward stardom today by surging from the brink of defeat to beat Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., for the United States open indoor tennis championship. The scores were 68. 36. 64. 97. 60.

title: Buddhists Rally in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 22 (UPI)Some 400 South Korean Buddhists demonstrated at rally at a temple in downtown Seoul today to demand the re lease of 11 South Koreans still detained in North Korea follow ing the hijacking of their plane Dec. 11.

title: Arbitration in Cemetery Strike Urged by Governor and Mayor
description: Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay called upon 1,700 union gravediggers yes terday to accept arbitration of their sixweekold strike.

title: Concern on Protests
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Nixon Administration plans to seek no specific agreements with France when President Pompidou arrives tomorrow. But it hopes to clarify a series of bothersome international problems. Above all, it hones to avoid public unpleasantness.

title: Saigon Troops Will Leave Secure Villages
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20  South Vietnam's de fense officials are planning a major shift of villagebased professional soldiers into con tested areas, leaving the de fense of villages considered rel atively secure to unpaid local militiamen and police.

title: Leslie Uggams Sparkles In Songs at Americana
description: Leslie uggams is back in the familiar, friendly safety of a supper club after two bad Fallsthe Fall of 1969 when her television series, The Leslie Uggams Show, was canceled, and the Fall of 1968 when Her First Roman, the musical in which she starred with Richard Kiley, appeared very briefly on Broadway.

title: Bacallao Wins Tourney
description: Dr. Pedro Bacallao of the host club, the United States open and amateur champion, Lyon the Princeton invitation squash tennis tournament yes terday. He defeated Dave Staf ford of the Bronxville Field Club, 1510, 159, 158.

title: Pompidou Arrives Today on Visit With Modest Goals
description: PARIS, Feb. 22  Ten years after President Charles de Gaulle visited President Dwight D. Eisenhower in Washington and then spread excitement in a quick tour across the United States, his successor and polit ical heir, Georges Pompidou is to undertake the same journey starting tomorrow.

title: Largest Containership Built in U.S. Sails for West Coast and a Cargo
description: The largest containership built in this country, the Ha waiian Enterprise, is headed for the West Coast to load her first cargo. The 34,700displace mentton vessel is designed to carry more than 1,000 24foot containers.

title: James Bostwick, McLernon Take Gold Racquet Finals,
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 22James Bostwick, national open court tennis champion, defeated R. J. Bijur of Phila delphia, 62, 64, 61, to win the 68th annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis tourna ment today at the Tuxedo Rac quet and Tennis Club.

title: Recreation Plan Puts Administration in a Quandary
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Nixon Administration, is in a quandary over what to do about a nationwide outdoor recreation plan that Congress ordered almost seven years ago.

title: HOLIDAY SALUTE GIVEN BY SWEDES
description: The Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra opened its second American tour at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night with a salute to American music and the holiday weekend by performing Ives's Washington's Birthday as the first work of the evening.

title: UKRAINIANS ADVANCE TO CUP SOCCER FINAL
description: The New York Ukrainians, paced by Wilberforce Mfum, a former national soccer player for Ghana who scored three goals, defeated the German Hungarians, 32, yesterday and gained the New York final of the United States Challenge Cuo. The Ukes will meet the winner of the GottscheeGreek American contest, which is slated Sunday.

title: Mt. Snow's Ski Boom Is Not All Boon
description: WILMINGTON, Vt.There isnt a piece of land I own around here that hasn't dou bled in value in the past two years.

title: Socialists Register Gains In Austrian Provincial Vote
description: VIENNA, Feb. 22The So cialists advanced, conservatives held their own, and the Com munists and a small Pan Germanic party lost ground in administrative elections in Aus tria's southern province of Carinthia today.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Licia Albanese Marks A Graceful Met 30
description: Fortified with a telegram of congratulations from Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, the Italian Government's Order of Merit and her own very special vocal gifts, Licia Albanese, accom panied by an orchestra under the direction of Alfredo Anto nini, celebrated the 30th anni versary of her Metropolitan Opera debut last night in Car negie Hall.

title: BANGKOK TO ALLOW G.I. REST FLIGHTS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 22 The Thai Government an nounced today that rest and recreation flights for American troops from Saigon to Bangkok, suspended late last week after a Thai official notified Pan American Airways that landing rights would not be renewed, would be resumed within 10 days.

title: City Will Consider Suing New Jersey To Block Foul Air
description: Jerome Kretchmer, who will become the city's Environ mental Protection Administra tor this spring, said yesterday that the agency would consider suing New Jersey to get full enforcement of that state's antipollution laws.

title: Marathon to Loeschorn
description: BELTSVILLE, Md., Feb. 22 Lieut. John Loeschorn, a former New York University runner who is stationed at Seymour Air Force Base in Greensboro, NC., won the Amateur Union Eastern regional marathon to day in 2 hours 27 minutes 28 seconds.

title: Lord Stokes to Address World Auto Symposium
description: The second annual Interna tional Symposium on the Auto mobile has selected Lord Stokes, chairman of the board and managing director of Brit ish Leyland Motors Corpora tion, to be its banquet speaker, at the ParkSheraton Hotel, April 8.

title: Mrs. Curtis Advances To Semifinals in Tennis
description: AGAWAM, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP)Mary Ann Eisel Curtis of St. Louis and Esme Emman uel of South Africa, last year's finalists, moved closer to a re match for the singles title in the New England women's in door tennis championships to day by posting straightset quarterfinal victories.

title: Rise in Rents, to Be Used for Renovation, Urged by Civic Group
description: The Citizens Buget Commis sion proposed yesterday that the city authorize rent in creases that would be used spe cifically for significant main tenance and renovation of housing.

title: Extended Forecast
description: (Wednesday through Friday)

title: LEON HOFFMAN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 22 Leon Hoffman, president of the Pawnee Publishing Com pany, publishers of educational books, died yesterday in Lawr ence Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 1 Normandy Road.

title: ISRAEL APPEALS FOR WORLD HELP IN PLANE ATTACKS
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 22The Israeli Government today called upon governments, civil airlines and pilots' organizations to end the wave of terrorism that is resulting from the Middle East war and, it said, making civil airlines unsafe for travel.

title: Neighborhoods: Marsh at Stake
description: GREAT NECK ESTATES, L. I., Feb. 22Several hun dred Queens and Nassau resi dents gathered hope in their hearts and mud on their boots today at a colorful out door demonstration to protest the construction of a parking lot in the salt marsh in Udall's Cove.

title: A Balmy Sunday in Rome Might as Well Be Spring
description: ROME, Feb. 22According to the officials at the Aero nautics Ministry who take the temperature of this city, the midday high at Rome's airport was 66 degrees. The sky, they reported, was slightly cloudy.

title: AIR WEST SAYS SUM IN SALE IS REDUCED
description: Air West, which is in the process of being acquired by Howard Hughes, announced this weekend in San Francisco that the sum of money to be available to shareholders from the sale has been substantial ly reduced.

title: New England Thruway Cuts Speed for Trucks
description: The State Thruway Author ity has reduced the speed limit for trucks using the New England Thruway in Westchester County, effective today, to 50 miles an hour. The old limit which still ap plies for all other vehicles was 55 miles an hour from the New York City line to the New Rochelle toll barrier and then 60 to the Connecti cut line.

title: Empathy With Injured
description: After a particularly brutal hockey game, when a player would suffer more than the usual bruises, Dr. Yanagisawa, the only man allowed to smoke in the dressing room, would stroll in and talk to the injured player.

title: Hamilton Takes Daytona 500, Outspeeding Pearson on Final Laps
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22Peter Goodwill Hamil ton, the 1968 rookie of the year on the latemodel stock car circuit, won the Daytona 500 today in a bright blue wing tailed Plymouth. It was his first victory in the Grand National division and his biggest ever. His purse and prizes totaled $46,400. victory in the Grand National division and his biggest ever. His purse and prizes totaled $46,400.

title: Taiwan Golfer Triumphs
description: MANILA, Feb. 22 (AP) Hsieh YungHo of Taiwan shot a par 72 in the final round to day and won the Philippine open golf championship by one stroke over Hsieh MinNan of Taiwan and Ben Arda of the Philippines, who tied for second. The winner posted a fourround total of 282 for the first prize of $3,000.

title: Open Season in the State Primary
description: Morris B. Abram, the presi dent of Brandeis University, passed the word last week that he was under considerable and growing pressure to run for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, prompting one of the party's most important leaders to tell a friend:

title: To Stop Murder in the Sky
description: One of the most severe crises in the history of the world's civil aviation has been touched off by the Arab guerrilla sabotage that last weekend destroyed a Swiss airliner flying to Israel and almost destroyed an Austrian plane. At any given moment, this planet has innumerable national quarrels, miniwars and other conflicts of varying degrees of intensity. When and if partisans in such disputes have reason to believe that the sabotaging of airplanes is an effective means of pursuing their causes, then murder in the sky might become so common as to paralyze the air transport industry. This vulnerability of airplanes makes it par ticularly important that those who try to profit by such sabotage learn quickly and unequivocally that this tactic is selfdefeating.

title: Tremors Shake Greek Town
description: CANDIA, Greece, Feb. 22 (UPI)Two sharp earth trem ors shook this city on the Island of Crete tonight, caus ing minor damage to several buildings. The Athens Obser vatory said the tremors reg istered 4.5 on the Richter scale of nine.

title: YugoslavParaguayan Pact
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. Feb. 22 (Reuters)Yugoslavia and Paraguay have agreed to raise their diplomatic relations to the ?? level.

title: Informal, Chic First Lady of France
description: PARIS, Feb. 22  Claude Pompidou, whose hus band, Georges, is President of France, would like if she had her way to cross the United States in a bus and eat doughnuts, according to a recent interview published here.

title: Mets Have a Pitching Problem: Keeping 6 Starters in Top Shape
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22How many injuries would it take to cripple the best pitching staff in base ball?

title: LABOR UNIT ASKS HIGHER WELFARE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22  The executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called today for a federalized public wel fare program with payments at a rate no lower than the poverty level.

title: 3 AMERICANS KILLED IN VIETNAM FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 (AP)  The United States command reported today that three Americans had been killed and 22 wounded in four enemy attacks ranging from 35 miles northnorthwest of Saigon to 44 miles south of Danang.

title: DR. YANAGISAWA, SURGEON, 65, DIES
description: BERGENFIELD, N. J., Feb. 22 Dr. Kazuo Yanagisawa, a physician for many years at Madison Square Garden whose successful surgery on a score of Ranger hockey players and Knickerbocker basketball play ers gained him national fame, died today in his home at 94 Ralph Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The last time Michael Rabin appeared at Hunter College, in 1952, hg was a teenage violin ist with a fluid tone and a daz zling technique. When he re turned there Saturday evening, deputizing for the indisposed Christian Ferras, he displayed those same qualities, along with the musical understanding that only artistic maturity can bring.

title: THREE JERSEY BOYS VANDALIZE 37 BUSES
description: BRIO TOWNSHIP, N.J., Feb. 22Three hatchetswing ing boys7, 8 and 9 years old damaged 37 of 41 school buses parked yesterday in the rear of the Brick Township High School.

title: Holiday Today Halts Most Services Here
description: Washington's Birthday is being observed today. Fol lowing is a list of services that are affected:

title: Channel 13 to Rebroadcast Sesame Street Saturdays
description: Channel 13 plans to rebroad cast each week's programs of Sesame Street, the experi mental educational series for children between the ages of 3 and 5, on Saturdays from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. starting this week.

title: Miss Goldsmith Engaged to Wed G. S. Howard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Goldsmith of the Bronx have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Carole Jane Goldsmith, to Geoffrey Scott Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Howard of New York, Ches ter, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: TWO U.S. SLEDS LEAD IN LAKE PLACID MEET
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 22 (UPI)  The United States moved into the first and sec ond positions today at the half way mark of the Kennedy in ternational bobsled competi tion.

title: Minnesota Inmates Give Up
description: STILLWATER, Minn., Feb. 22 (UPI)Six inmates at the state prison here held authorities at hay with three hostages and a guard's revolver for more than eight hours before surrender ing at 3 A.M. today. The war den, Jack Young, said the in mates gave up on condition their grievances not enough food, poor parole board custo dial care, and unfair isolation be aired publicly.

title: STENNIS WOULD CURB THE RIGHT TO TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)  Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, sug gested today a constitutional amendment to eliminate the right of trial in some cases, such as the recent Chicago con spiracy trial.

title: JUDGE DAVID STAHL OF U.S. COURT IS DEAD
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22  Judge David Stahl of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, was found dead in the garage of his home here yesterday. He was 49, years old.

title: Bridge:
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 22  The United States touring team finished on a strong note here last night by defeating a powerful local team.

title: 2 WELFARE GROUPS SLATED TO MERGE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The two major urban public interest groups will merge a week from today.

title: Robes Takes Class A Laurels In Ski Jumping at Brattleboro
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 22 A trip from the Far West, just to compete in the annual Fred H. Harris Memorial Invitation Ski Jumping Tournament, paid off today for Peter Robes.

title: Goldberg Firm on Noncandidacy; Says He Backs No One for Now
description: Arthur J. Goldberg closed the door again yesterday on re newed efforts to draft him as a Democratic candidate for Governor.

title: BONDS EXPECTED TO KEEP CLIMBING
English Sheepdog Judged Best In Field of 1,267 at New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22An Old English sheepdog, who is a candidate for top honors as often as not and comes through now and then, became best in show in the 53d event of the Elm City Kennel Club tonight.

title: MOLLOY CAPTURES TRACK TITLE AGAIN
description: Archbishop Molloy won its 10th straight Catholic High Schools Athletic Association in door track and field title yes terday, but not before getting a real scare from St. Francis Prep.

title: U.S. Declines to Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The State Department declined comment today on the tempo rary restrictions on diplomatic mail imposed by the Cam bodian Government.

title: FLARE POT HURLED AT CORNELL HOUSE
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 22 Kerosene flare pots were thrown at a house occupied by 10 or 12 black women students of Cornell University and a car parked in front of it early to day.

title: Jet Wakes' Turbulence May Limit Air Growth
description: The mysterious effects of wake turbulence  invisible, turbulent air currents trailing behind big jetliners  could seriously limit the growth of the nation's air transport sys tem during the next decade, according to a new Federal Aviation Administration 10 year plan.

title: Insurance Concerns in U.S. And France Sign Accord
description: The Insurance Company of North America and Compagnie d'Assurances La Prservatrice, Paris, announced yesterday that they had signed an agree ment to augment each other's facilities.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN the summer of 1953, an Englishman named Geoffrey Bibby returned to small island in the Persian Gulf, off the coast of Saudi Arabia, to settle an old score. Bibby knew the island from a hitch he had served there after the war as an officer in an oil company. He had had an amateur's interest in archeology then, and he had seen the burial mounds one day tens of thousands of them, stretching away as far as the eye could see. Portuguese, he was told. He had even dug in one, amateur ishly, and had found nothing.

title: CHAMBER GROUP TURNS STATELY 5
description: A 5yearold string quartet often has developed quite enough individuality and tem perament to rule its entire life. But it is probably seldom that any young group speaks with the authority of the Guarneri Quartet, which gave a concert last night at the New School Auditorium to mark the anni versary of its own birth.

title: Handicapped Man Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) Danny Scholl, a decorated Marine and former actor, has been named Handicapped American of the Year by the President's Committee on Em ployment of the Handicapped. Mr. Scholl, 48, years old, is publicist for Ohio's state audi tor, Roger Cloud. He was an actor and singer before a stroke paralyzed his right arm and leg.

title: Artists Raise $11,000 for Charleston
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 22 A group of East Coast artists who want to preserve the char acter of Charleston contributed their works to a weekend art auction that raised more than $11.000.

title: France Planning Institute for Industry
description: PARIS, Feb. 22A cartoon in the Paris newspaper Le Figaro shows a cobbler daydreaming about transforming his estab lishment into a giant shoe factory.

title: I.R.S. CHIEF URGES JAIL FOR EVADERS
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 22The Commissioner of Internal Reve nue warned today that tax avoidance could become a game which is socially accept able because in some areas very few tax evaders are being sent to prison.

title: U.S. Pilot Is Killed
description: VIENTIANE, Feb. 22 (AP) A United States helicopter pilot has been killed by sniper fire while ferrying supplies to be leaguered Laotian Government forces on the Plaine des Jarres, the United States Embassy re ported today.

title: Eban, With Heavy Guard, Sees Munich and Dachau
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 22  Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minister, flew to Munich today under tight security precautions for the first official visit of an Israeli Cabinet member to West Ger many.

title: Article 2  No Title
Louis A. Lemaire Dies at 74; ExSenator in Connecticut
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 22 Louis A. Lemaire, former State Senator and realestate pro moter, died last night at the Courtland Gardens Convales cent Home in Stamford. He was 74 years old and lived on Old Lantern Road here.

title: MISS TITOVA SNAPS WORLD SKATE MARK
description: WEST ALLIS, Wis., Feb. 22 (Reuters)  Soviet skaters dominated the international sprint speedskating champion ships today by setting a world record of 44.58 seconds in the women's 500meter race and taking two world titles.

title: Votes of the Week In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Miss Barnett Wed To Dr. D. B. Vogel
description: DETROIT, Feb. 22Miss Judith Barnett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Barnett of Birmingham, was married here today to Dr. Donald Bruce Vogel, a psychiatric resident at the Payne Whit ney Clinic of New York Hos pital. Rabbi Israel Halpern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Abraham.

title: LAWRENCE FIRST IN TASMAN RACE
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 22 (AP)  Graeme Lawrence of New Zealand won the Tas man Cup auto race series to day with a secondplace finish to Niel Allen of Australia in the final race.

title: Alternatives to Seniority
description: The Democratic Study Group has postponed very briefly its attempt to do something about the seniori ty system, which has for so long made committees of the House of Representatives a collection of prin cipalities, each with its own maharajah. The group's resolution, calling for a special panel to recommend ways of making these committee chairmen responsible to their party, was sidetracked last week by a filibuster within the Democratic caucus. But the movement for reform is gathering momentum, and another effort will be made within a very few weeks.

title: Jane Penneys Is Married Here
description: Miss Jane Penneys, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Robert Penneys of Philadel phia and Miami Beach, was married here yesterday morn ing to Milton B. Melinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Melinger of Mount Vernon, N. Y. Rabbi Nathan A. Peril man performed the ceremony in his tudy at Temple Emanu El.

title: HEROIN OVERDOSES KILL 3 MORE HERE
description: Three more deaths from heroin overdoses, including that of an 18yearold West Side youth, were recorded in the city yesterday.

title: Libyan Chief Says Request By Nasser Could Halt Oil
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 22 (AP)Libya's premier, Col. Muammar elQuaddafi, said to day that he would be willing to cut off Libya's vast oil ship ments to the West if President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic asked him to do so for the sake of the Palestine cause.

title: PRESIDENCY RACE QUIET IN COLOMBIA
