title: Systems Analysis Concern Set Up by ExAide to Laird
description: The formation of a new busi ness and Government systems analysis concern was an nounced yesterday by Ivan Selin, former acting assistant Secretary of Defense for Sys tems Analysis, and Charles O. Rossotti, his former chief deputy.

title: Susan Landis To Be a Bride
description: Howard Landis of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Landis, to J. Gordon Arkin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Arkin of Yonkers.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frank E. Cole has been appointed president of the Electronic Instrument Division, Lear Siegler, Inc., Anaheim, Calif. He formerly was executive vice president.

title: Brandeis School Planning Dinner
description: LAWRENCE, L. I. Feb. 24 The Brandeis School will celebrate its 40th anniver sary at a dinner dance at the Capri, Atlantic Beach, to be held Saturday, March 7, for the benefit of its scholar ship fund.

title: Motor Racing Drivers Honor Safety Fuel Tank Developer
description: DEL CLINE, who is 59 years old, doesn't wear the vic tory wreath or kiss the beau ty queen. He gets no ap plause from the crowd, which doesn't know him. The recog nition he receives is usually in private, from a race driver thanking Cline for saving him from a fiery death after a collision or spill. One eve ning last weekend Cline finally got a round of ap plause, and it came from men whose praise counts for something. They were the nearly 1,000 drivers, car owners, mechanics and race officials who had come to honor him for saving lives how many, no one can tell.

title: Heroin Cited at Columbia
description: The Columbia Spectator, the undergraduate newspaper, re ported yesterday that about a dozen students had been forced to leave school since January because of serious invoive ment with heroin, Philip Ben son, director of student in terests, said that the situation was not as cut and dried as, the story indicates and that there had been no incidents of discharging students sum marily.

title: Contract Increase Ends Bus Strike in Jersey
description: EAST PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 25 (AP)A threeweek old strike against the Man hattan Transit Company and the affiliated Mohawk Coach Lines ended today.

title: Chess:
description: THE experienced expert Harry, Fajans won the Marshall Chess Club cham pionship preliminaries after a tiebreak preference with Howard Ant. The twin lead ers each scored 51, topping a 32man qualifying field in the sevenround Swiss system. The appended games are from the event.

title: Mark Rothko, Artist, A Suicide Here at 66
description: Mark Rothko, a pioneer of abstract expressionist painting who was widely regarded as one of the greatest artists of his generation, was found dead yesterday, his wrists slashed, in his studio at 157 East 69th Street. He was 66 years old. The Chief Medical Examiner's office listed the death as a suicide.

title: LUCIA DEBUT MADE BY MILENA DAL PIV A
description: Donizetti's Lucia di Lam mermoor was given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater last night, and it was not quite enough that the performance was easily above average.

title: Historic Sites Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The House Interior Commit tee approved today a bill to authorize $32million for the preservation of historic sites across the nation. The proposed appropriation, along with state funds, would be used in the next three years for preserva tion of historic properties.

title: JUSTICES EXTEND ONE MAN,ONE VOTE TO LOCAL BOARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  The Supreme Court declared today that the election of school board members and most if no all other local officials must adhere to the principle of one man, onevote.

title: Utility Plans a Berkshires Plant
description: SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 25  Northeast Utilities, which al ready has built the country' s largest pumpedstorage hydro electric plant, formally an nounced today that it was plan ning to build another one up to twice as large in the re atively untouched Lower Berkshires around the MassachusettsCon necticut border.

title: DEAN SAYS HE LAID BETS FOR A FRIEND
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 25 Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, named as a coconspirator in a Fed eral gambling indictment in De troit yesterday, declared at a news conference today he had never had anything to do with bigtime gambling. Then, with tears in his eyes, he left the room.

title: H. E. W. PROPOSES TO PLACE CEILINGS ON MEDICARE FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Nixon Administration pro posed today to set ceilings on permissible fees to doctors and hospitals under Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Panther Hearings Halted Over Defendants' Conduct
description: Supreme Court Justice. John M. Murtagh halted pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers yesterday and announced that they would not be resumed un til the defendants promised, in writing, to behave in accord ance with American courtroom procedure.

title: Brooke Opposes Carswell
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Senator Edward W. Brooke, a Republican, announced on the Senate floor today that he could not support confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court.

title: Conrad Nagel Rites Today
description: A funeral service for Conrad Nagel, the actor, will be held today at 1 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Mr. Nagel was found dead Tuesday in his home at 340 West 57th Street. He was 72 years old.

title: Lehigh Gains M.A.C. Playoff
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Feb. 25 Bob Fortune scored 31 points tonight while leading Lehigh to an 8683 victory over Lafayette. This was a special Middle At lantic Conference game to de cide which team would advance, along with Rider, into the M.A.C. playoffs Friday and Saturday at the Palestra.

title: Humphrey Says Nixon Uses A Forked Tongue on Race
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP)Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today at a news conference that the Nixon Administration spoke with a forked tongue on ra cial issues.

title: EARLY GAINS CUT ON LONDON BOARD
description: Prices on the London stock market closed easier yester day after a reversal of earlier gains.

title: China Is Reporting Prodigious Feats by Workers
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 25In the rugged Taihang mountains of Shansi Province members of two communes, using only hand tools, have just finished after 10 months a 15mile wa ter conduit by hacking 22 tun nels through mountains and constructing 13 piers of hand hewn stones to support the conduit across gullies and streams.

title: Occidental Petroleum Posts Record Figures for Sales and Earnings
FEWER NEGROES FOUND IN GUARD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25A survey by the National Guard Bureau shows that the low rate of Negro enlistment remains virtually unchanged despite two years of official efforts at im provement.

title: TREASURY PUTS MINIMUM ON BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  The Treasury announced today that it would no longer sell Treasury bills in denominations of less than $10,000.

title: Congress Hails Pompidou; He Urges Israeli Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Congress courteously wel comed President Pompidou today and applauded him as addressed a joint meeting. The French leader here with his wife on an eightday state visit, touched briefly but pointedly on the problems of Vietnam and the Middle East, the principal points of policy divergence between Paris and Washington.

title: Egypt Hints U.S. Oil Concerns Face No Danger of Expulsion
description: CAIRO, Feb. 25  The Egyptian Government spokes man indicated today that the two United States oil com panies operating in this coun try faced no risk of expulsion as part of threatened Arab economic retaliation against the United States for support of Israel.

title: 4 IN MOTEL TRIAL FREED IN MICHIGAN
description: FLINT, Mich., Feb. 25Three white Detroit policemen and a Negro private guard were found not guilty of conspiracy today in the Algiers Motel trial.

title: Class Dons Gas Masks To Dramatize Pollution
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25,A group of 25 college students and teachers wearing gas masks and carrying antipol lution placards distributed leaflets on an 8 A.M. Manhat tanbound commuter train to day.

title: Rhine Flood Is Cresting in the BonnCologne Area
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Feb. 25  The Rhine flood appeared to the approaching its crest  almost 27 feet above normalin the Bonn Cologne area today. Local newspapers called it the worst flood in 70 years.

title: LIRA EXCHANGE RATE HITS 634 TO DOLLAR
description: MILAN, Italy, Feb. 25 (AP) The dollar reached an alltime exchangerate high of 634 lire at the Milan foreign exchange today in the third straight in crease from the floor level.

title: Fontainebleau Plans Concert To Aid School
description: Students who spent sum mers in France at the Fon tainebleau Fine Arts and Music Schools during the last 49 years will gather in Carnegie Recital Hall March 8 for the 18th annual con cert in behalf of the schools.

title: Valdes, Former Fisherman, Is Making Larger Catches in Pro Boxing Ring
description: He once worked on the fish ing boats that roam for red snapper and pompano in the Caribbean off Cartagena, Co lombia, and he earned about $10 a week. But now he's the world's fourthranked welter weight boxer, and on Monday night at Madison Square Gar den, he might make as much as $7,500.

title: Union Aide Indicted in Yablonski Case
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 25The Federal grand jury seeking evi dence against the plotters be lieved to have ordered and paid for the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski indicted a mine union official today on charges of conspiracy in connection with the slaying of the insurgent leader of the United Mine Workers of America.

title: Far Rockaway Gains Final
description: Far Rockaway advanced to the Queens Public Schools Ath letic League basketball final yesterday by defeating Long Island City, 7553, at Spring field Gardens High School. It was the 14th victory in 16 games for the Sea Horses, who will meet Van Buren Saturday for the title at Queensborough Community College. Ron Hooks led the Rockaway scorers with 23 points.

title: Big U.S. Base Handed Over To South Vietnamese Forces
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25 (Reuters)A $3million base at Laikhe near Saigon was handed over today to the South Vietnamese by the First Infan try Division, scheduled to leave by April 15.

title: In the World of Dogs, a Fancier Is a Judge and Artist as Well
description: MRS. CYNTHIA GUZEVICH is a woman of many tal ents. In the dog show world, she is known for her great Italian greyhounds. In just eight years her kennel at Las Cruces, N. M., produced 35 champions of the breed. She also has bred champion mini ture noodles and Pekingese.

title: Floyd Gets 36 on Hole For Stroke of His Pen
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25 (AP)The Professional Golfers' Associa tion champion, Ray Floyd, suffered a slip of the pen today and was credited with a score of 110 in the pro amateur event preceding the $150,000 Doral open golf tournament.

title: Plan Is Announced To Admit Nonwhites To Lathers' Union
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr. an nounced yesterday an agree ment that he said cracks open a major union in the building and contracting field to mi noritygroup workers.

title: The Screen:'Long Ride From Hell' Stars Steve Reeves
description: "A LONG RIDE FROM HELL" is a minor revenge Western of the contemporary Italian school made notable by the lean, elegiac work of Sergio Leone. It stars Steve Reeves who, in his youth, went into muscles instead of mutual funds. The muscles looked great in "Hercules" and "Goliath and the Barbarians" but they give the actor a peculiar silhouette on the range. As a result of his enlarged latissimus dorsi, Reeves stands tall only as the most round-shouldered gun in the West.The film was directed by Alex Burks, who seems to have learned his craft in that Marlboro country, where the sun never sets but is always directly behind the man with the cigarette. Burks also photographs almost every scene from a fixed position with a camera equipped with a zoom lens. The effect is disorientating, like being perched on the slide of a giant trombone."A Long Ride From Hell," which opened yesterday at the DeMille Theater, is dubbed with basic English dialogue and quite badly synchronized sounds of fists hitting flesh, grunts, shots and hoofbeats.

title: President Is Appointed At Lincoln Savings Bank
description: The designation of Edmond G. Murphy to succeed Michael J. Burke as president and chief executive officer of the Lincoln Savings Bank upon the latter's retirement at the annual meeting March 11 was announced yesterday. Mr. Murphy joined the bank in 1949 as controller and was elected vice president in 1954 and executive vice president in 1963.

title: MATUSHEVSKI HEARD IN PIANO DEBUT HERE
description: Voytek Matushevski is a young Polish pianist, trained in Warsaw, who came to the United States in 1965 to study for three years with Leon Fleisher. Last year he won the Young Artist Competition of the National Federation of Music Clubs, and last might he made his New York debut in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Six Plants to Close
description: The Ford Motor Company an nounced yesterday that it would close six of its 17 assem bly plants in the United States in March for periods ranging from five to 11 days.

title: INSURER ASKS RISE IN FASTCAR RATES
description: Insurance will cost more starting next month for many owners of new high perform ance or muscle cars, so des ignated because of extra power for fast starts.

title: COLLEGE IN QUEENS PLANS EXPANSION
description: Dr. Kurt R. Schmeller, presi dent of Queensborough Com munity College, announced a $31million expansion plan yes terday.

title: 8 Indicted Here in Kickback Plot Stemming From Sales to PX's
description: A Federal grand jury hand ed up an indictment here yes terday, charging a salesman and seven present or former military, postexchange buyers with conspiracy to defraud the Government through a kick back scheme.

title: Brown Six Routs Yale
description: New Haven, Feb. 25Brown scored twice within a 16sec ond span in the first period to night and routed the Yale hockey team, 82, for its fifth straight victory.

title: Tito and Nasser End Talks; Accuse the U.S. and Israel
description: CAIRO, Feb. 25President Tito of Yugoslavia joined Presi dent Gamel Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic today in accusing Israel of expansion ism and the United States of encouraging the Israelis.

title: Taken Aback Wins $63,500 Black Helen as Stablemate, Harem Lady, Is 7th
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25The wrong one won the $63,500 Black Helen Handicap today, but that made little difference to those in the crowd of 19,274 who had backed the favored Hobeau Farm entry. Taken Aback was expected to be in front for some part of the 1mile test for older mares, but her stable mate, Harem Lady, was figured to be first at the end.

title: Article 1  No Title
Personal Finance
description: Because of the skyrocket ing costs of hospital and medical care and of just about everything associated with getting sick, it doesn't take long for a major medical crisis to run up bills almost beyond belief.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Soviet Officials, in Interview, Score Nixon on Middle East and Vietnam, but Look to Improved U.S. Ties
description: MOSCOW, Feb, 25Official Soviet sources said today that they shared President Nixon's hope for improved Soviet American relations but took strong exception to his criti cism of Moscow's policy in the Middle East and Vietnam.

title: British Football
description: INTERNATIONAL EXHIBITION

title: Parenthood Group Elects
description: Henry H. Villard, professon of economics at the City Col lege of New York, has been re elected chairman of the board of directors of Planned Parent hood of New York. The organi zation provides birthcontrol services for 25,000 women a year.

title: St. Francis 10781 Victor As Conforti Gets 39 Points
description: Capt. John Conforti, playing his last home game, scored 39 points to lead St. Francis Col lege to a 10781 victory over City College last night at Bishop Ford High School in Brooklyn.

title: ... and a Plea to Ban Ecocide
description: Taking his cue from the Convention on Genocide, a Yale biologist has proposed a new international agreement to ban Ecocidethe willful destruction of the environment.

title: Ford Foundation Aids MinorityStudent Programs
description: The Ford Foundation an nounced $2.7million in grants yesterday to strengthen curric ulums and counseling services for minority students at col leges and universities across the country.

title: Dance: Pineapple Poll
description: HAPPINESS for a dance loveris the return of City Center Joffrey Ballet to the New York City Center. Happiness happened last night yet even happiness has its offbeat chords.

title: Nurse Goes to Nigeria With Plasma to Fight Lassa Fever Virus
description: The American missionary nurse in whose blood Lassa fever virus was first detected was on her way last night to Jos, Nigeria, where there is an outbreak of the disease.

title: 20, Including 3 Pupils, Held In Drug Raids at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 25 (AP) Three high school pupils were among 20 persons arrested to day in predawn drug raids by the city and the state police. An Onendaga County grand jury indicted 12 of the 20 on charges of selling drugs.

title: The A.B.A. on Genocide...
description: The American Bar Association displayed faint faith in American principles of law and morality the other day when it refused to revoke its 20yearold opposi tion to the United Nations Convention on Genocide.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert A. Rosen has been appointed president and a director of Bell Television, Inc. He formerly was the vice president of corporate finance and director bf the company.

title: Cornell Six Clinches Title
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 25 Cornell scored six goals in the second period and routed the Harvard hockey team tonight, 93. The victory was the 21st for the undefeated Ithacans, who clinched the Ivy League title for the fifth year in a row.

title: Judge Henry W. Edgerton Dies; Former Appeals Court Head, 81
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Henry W. Edgerton, a retired Judge from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and long a defender of civil rights, died Monday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: British Military to Get Raises, But Will Pay for Bed and Board
description: LONDON, Feb. 25Britain's servicemen will soon pay for their own bed and board as this country shifts to a new and higher pay system for the armed forces, the Government announced today.

title: Miss Constance Martin To Marry in California
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 25Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Martin Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Martin, to Richard Goodyear, son of Mrs. John Goodyear of Washington and the late Mr. Goodyear. The wedding will take place here on June 6.

title: Congress to Act Soon on Pay Rise Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Congress appeared to move closer today to another con frontation with the President with the announcement that House and Senate conferees would soon take up a Federal pay bill that President Nixon had threatened to veto as in flationary.

title: Underground Nuclear Test
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 25 (AP)  An underground test detonated today by the Atomic Energy Commission was felt slightly in highrise buildings here. The Nevada test site is 90 miles to the north. The test was described as of low inter mediate range.

title: Namath to Make Debut With the Philharmonic
description: Joe Namath, quarterback of the New York Jets pro fessional football team, will make his concert debut with the New York Philharmonic Professional Symphony Or chestra in May, narrating a work based on his life, with music by Richard Hyman and words by Dick Schaap.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1970

title: Rebuilding of Key Bridge A Symbol for Nigerians
description: ASABA, Nigeria, Feb. 25 Like the warshattered villages around it, the bridge that spans the broad Niger River here is finally being rebuilt.

title: Elk Used in Space Test Is Dead of Pneumonia
description: JACKSON, Wyo., Feb. 25 (UPI)Monique the elk was found dead in the National Elk Refuge today, probably of pneumonia.

title: John Mulholland, Magician and Author, 71, Dies
description: John Mulholland, magician and author of books on magic, died yesterday in University Hospital, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 600 West 115th Street.

title: Building Lag Laid to City School Board
description: City school officials were rebuked yesterday for slug gishness in putting up needed new buildings.

title: Mishap on T.W.A. 747 Inaugural: Film Projector Fails
description: It was the pilot's birthday, and he got the key to New York City. A movie projector failed en route. The 258 passengers aboard applauded as the plane took off in Los Ange les and later as it landed in New York. And as they streamed off, : passengers wait ing for the return hop were having a champagne party. Otherwise, the inauguration of domestic jumbo jet sservice yes terday by Trans World Airlines was routine.

title: 6 City Officials Given Raises Amounting to $190,000 a Year
description: Mayor Lindsay announced pay increases yesterday for the city's top 60 officials. The in creases will cost about $190, 000 a year.

title: YALE'S PROBATION VOTED BY E.C.A.C.
description: Yale University was placed on a 16month probation by the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday for al lowing Jack Langer to play on its basketball team.

title: Origin of the Longuette or, as They Say in Paris, Le Long Look
description: DAMNED if you do and damned if you don't. That has been the anguished cry along Seventh and Fifth Avenues during recent months as maunfacturers and retailers confront the hemline dilemma and customer hos tility in an era of sluggish business.

title: BAIL IN CHICAGO CASE IS OPPOSED BY U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 25  The Government urged the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today not to grant bail to the defendants and the two attorneys in the Chi cago conspiracy trial.

title: Strike Labor Loss Tallied
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) The Labor Department said today that 3.7 million mandays of labor were lost last month because of strikesthe highest for any January since 1946. It said that 233,000 workers were off their jobs, fourfifths of them at General Electric and National Airlines.

title: $200,000 Golf Tourney Is in Jeopardy
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25  The $750,000 Florida pro golf tour, which opens here tomorrow, is preparing to withstand a $200,000 punch in its pocket book.

title: Israelis Striving to Get Air Traffic Back to Normal
description: LYDDA, Israel, Feb. 25 Tel Aviv's international airport here was fairly crowded to day, not only with traveling businessmen and tourists but with airline employes working after hours to move air traffic in and out of Israel as swiftly and safely as possible.

title: A Pure Abstractionist
description: Twentythree years ago, when the abstract expressionist movement in American paint ing was still a long way from winning the nearly universal esteem it now enjoys, Mark Rothkowrote: The unfriendli ness of society to his activity, is difficult for the artist to accept. Yet, like many em battled artists be fore him, Mr. Au Rothko derived from this public hostility certain spiritual solace. Both the sense of community and of security depend on the familiar; he observed. Free of them, transcendental experi ences become possible.

title: Albany Expands Defense Group And Makes Room in the Bunker
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25  In a colloquy marked by grim laugh ter, the Assembly passed a measure today that would add three members to the Civil De fense Commission and make room for them in the state's nuclear bomb bunker.

title: Theater: Daring Games
description: PHOENIXES, of course, arise from the ashes by definition. However, it might be thought gratifying to note that the Phoenix Theater ap pears to be wellnamed, and at present it is most cheerfully kicking around a most lovely lot of ashes.

title: Students on Coast Set a Bank Afire; Guard Call Likely
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP)Young demon strators set fire to a branch of the Bank of America and to a police sedan tonight in the second night of street distur bances near the University of California's Santa Barbara campus.

title: Copper setAside steady
description: The Commerce Department said yesterady in Washington that the quantity of copper to bet set aside for defenserated stockpiling in the second quar ter would be 18,000 tons a month.

title: JEFFREY E. FULLER, EXA.C.L.U.OFFICIAL
description: Jeffrey Eastman Fuller, for mer assistant director of the American Civil Liberties Union, died Tuesday of a heart attack here. He was 52 years old and lived at 14412 Village Road in Jamaica. Queens.

title: Text of Address by President Pompidou
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Fol lowing is the text of President Pompidou's address delivered today before a joint meeting of Congress. The translation was read by his official inter preter, Constantin Andronikof.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: C. & N, W. OFFERS TO SELL ASSETS
description: Ben W. Heineman, chairman of the Chicago & North West ern Railway and chief execu tive of its parent, Northwest Industries, Inc., has given up his dream of creating a bal anced Midwestern railroad sys tem, which he would head.

title: Crown to Get Seat at Dynamics
description: Henry Crown, the Chicago financier and industrialist, is returning to a key role in the affairs of the General Dy namics Corporation, a giant defense contractor.

title: For Dining in Europe, Try Early Reservations Very Early, by Air Mail
description: IT could be called The Intelligent Man's Guide for Dining in Europe, and if anyone doubts the efficacy of the plan, they might ask Charles and Gloria Mandelstam.

title: N.Y.U. Fencers Win Again
description: New York University's var sity fencing team stretched its season wonlost record to 90 last night by coasting to a 216 victory over City College at Wingate Gymnasium. Gus Nicholson and Ed Ballinger won three bouts apiece in foil

title: Prices Rise Sharply After Bank Cuts Prime Rate
description: The American Stock Ex change turned in its best per formance in more than a month yesterday when a late rally sent prices sharply higher in steppedup trading. The up trend started in the final hour on news that the Lincoln Na tional Bank in Philadelphia had reduced its prime lending rate to 8 per cent from 8 per cent.

title: Carabella, Australian Yacht, Wins 5.5Meter Title Sail
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 25 (UPI)The Australian yacht Carabella, sailed by Dave For bes, won the 5.5meter world championship today off Palm Beach.

title: NEW YORK LIFE SET RECORD GAINS IN '69
description: The New York Life Insurance Company, the fourthlargest life insurer in the nation after the Prudential, Metropolitan and the Equitable, reported yester dway new highs in sales premi um income, insurance in force and assets for 1969.

title: Heavy Traffic Is No Drawback To Laurentian Ski Weekends
description: ST. DONAT, Quebec, Feb. 25Last fall Don Dairy, ski school director at La Rserve, made the rounds of all the major ski shows in the United States trying to sell his resort as the Laurentians' in place.

title: Vaccine Found for Southwest Fungus
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 An experimental vaccine has been developed against an im portant type of human fungus disease common in the South western United States.

title: Japanese Investing Move Is Hailed Here by Trusts
description: Japan's decision to permit the country's investment trusts to buy foreign securities was hailed yesterday by New York representatives of the trusts as a historic milestone in the internationalization of Japan's securities industry.

title: Thant Plans Talks With Big 4
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25  Secretary General Thant is scheduling private meetings with the Big Four to discuss certain positive ele ments he feels are emerging from their Middle East con sultations, a spokesman said tonight. Mr Thant cut short a visit to his family in Burma and returned here last night.

title: Observer: The Way of the Working stiff
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Instructions to workmen:

title: Kidd Wins Alpine Ski Meet In First Attempt as a Pro
description: VERBIER, Switzerland, Feb. 25 (AP)Billy Kidd of Stowe, Vt., won the giant slalom and the $4,000 first prize today in pro Alpine ski meet, billed as a world championship.

title: Rangers Top Blues, 21, on Contested Goal by Marshall Before He Is Injured
description: Bad luck overtook the Rang ers again last night, although they scored a 21 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a scorch ing contest and took a 4point lead in the National Hockey League's East Division.

title: RATES AGAIN SLIP ON TAXEXEMPTS
description: Interest rates on taxexempt bonds again moved lower yes terday, pushing yields on secu rities maturing in a year or two to the lowest levels since late last May.

title: Lisbon Holds Oppositionist In an Inquiry Into Protests
description: LISBON, Feb. 25Francisco Salgado Zenha, an opposition ist who ran as a Socialist can didate in the October election, is being held by the security police for investigation into incitement of demonstrations against Portugal's colonial wars in Africa.

title: Harold Proskey, 80, Is Dead; ExMerchandising Official
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 25  Harold Van Houten Proskey, a retired advertising and merchandising executive, died yesterday in his home at 5 Terrace Drive. His age was 80.

title: Paul W. Higgins Will Marry Miss Sara C T. Slats in April
description: Miss Sara Christina Thom son Slats, a bacteriologist doing research at the Rocke feller University, plans to be married to Paul Worthen Higgins. The wedding will take place April 11 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church with a reception at the New York Junior League.

title: Safeguard May Help to Defend a Senate Seat as Well as Country's Missile Sites
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Domestic as well as for eign threats determined the final shape of the Adminis tration's proposals for expan sion of the Safeguard anti missile system. In fact, the political danger faced by a stalwart friend of the ABM, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, was finally deemed more imminent than the danger posed by Com munist China's missile program.

title: 8 in Che ! Are Found Guilty of Obscenity
description: All five members of the original cast of the play Che!as well as the pro ducer, the playwright and the light manwere con victed of obscenity yesterday for presenting what a three judge panel called a nadir of smut on the stage.

title: U.S. Pilot Killed in Britain
description: LONDON (AP)Lieut. Col. Richard F. Murray, 44 years old, of Buffalo, was killed yesterday when his Phantom jet crashed into a field north of London.

title: Abram's Senate Hopes Clouded By His Lateness in Registering
description: An examination of election records disclosed yesterday that Morris B. Abram had failed to maintain his Demo cratic enrollment and so placed in jeopardy his chance to enter the June 23 primary for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

title: Thai Foreign Minister, Here, Urges Asians to Develop Regional Security
description: Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand said yes terday that Asian countries should develop their regional security without relying on United States troops. He said that collectively the Asian na tions might be successful in dealing with Communist China and ultimately winning its co operation.

title: Denounces Strikes
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 Wildcat strikes and the Government's credit squeeze have wiped out profits at the British Leyland Motor Corporation for the last four months, Lord Stokes, chair man, said at the annual meet ng today.

title: In The Nation : A Luxury for Nathan Clark
description: DENVER, Feb. 25Nathan Clark is a softspoken young black man, a high school grad uate with no jail or juvenile offense record, who is respon sible enough to head a security detail of five officers at a large discount store. Yet, nearly three years ago, Nathan Clark was badly beaten by at least four Denver policemen, who subse quently failed to charge him with an offense or to provide him medical assistance; and to this date no restitution of any kindnot even an apology has been made to him.

title: RESIGNATION ENDS TRASH SLOWDOWN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25A threeweek slowdown in trash collection ended today after the garbage collectors' union forced the resignation of Chief Police Inspector Joseph P. Halferty as Streets Commissioner.

title: Colombian University Shut
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 25 (UPI)Army troops occupied the National University today in compliance with a Govern ment order closing it until June because of a strike by its 11,000 students.

title: Resolution Offered In House to Declare Maddox Unwelcome
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)A Negro Representative introduced today a resolution declaring Gov. Lester G. Mad dox unwelcome in the House restaurant, where the Gover nor distributed pick and ax handles yesterday as symbols of his resistance to desegrega tion.

title: U.S.SOVIET NOTES DISCLOSED IN FULL
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP)The texts of letters on the Middle East exchanged recently be tween President Nixon and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union became avail able today. They confirmed that Moscow favored interven tion by the major powers that would compel Israel to with draw from Arab territory con quered in 1967.

title: 2 COAST MILERS PLANNING A COUP
description: West Coast track and field clubs, which have settled their financial dispute with the Ama teur Athletic Union, will at tempt to solve the mystique of Madison Square Garden tomor row night.

title: Columbia Men Stage SleepIn at Barnard
description: More than 150 Columbia College students slept in Barnard College dormitories Tuesday night openly and militantly to dramatize their demands for coeducational dormitories.

title: Quintuplets Born Here Are Called in Good to Excellent Condition
description: Five children born Tuesday night to a 27yearold New Jersey woman who had been treated with fertility drugs were reported to be in good to excellent health yester day in Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Med ical Center.

title: DOMINICAN CHIEF WINS NOMINATION
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Feb. 25The governing Reformist party pro claimed today in a national convention the candidacy of President Joaquin Balaguer for a second fouryear term.

title: Acting School Superintendent Named to Succeed Dr. Brown
description: The Board of Education by passed the school system's two ranking deputies yesterday in naming an assistant superin tendent, Irving Anker, to be the new Acting Superintendent of Schools.

title: Bridge:
description: THE greatest marathon match ever played draws to a close this week in Phila delphia, and an exciting fin ish is in prospect.

title: WILSON ASSAILED ON MARKET ISSUE
description: LONDON, Feb. 25A par tisan rift that has been building up over British entry into the Common Market erupted today on the floor of the House of Commons.

title: Nixon Budget Is Depicted As Tight Economic Rein
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon's budget is probably a good deal more re strictive in its economic im pact than appears on the sur face, a new analysis disclosed today.

title: Ann Louise Moses Plans June Nuptials
description: Dr. Campbell Moses, medi cal director of the American Heart Association, and Mrs. Moses of New York have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Louise Moses, to John Eu gene Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Everson Brown of Penn Hills, Pa.

title: French Papers Note Boycott
description: PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  French newspapers noted today that some Con gressmen had boycotted Pres ident Pompidou's speech in Washington yesterday, but stressed that the warmth of his welcome there canceled out the bad impression.

title: Expert Decries Alarm on BirthCurb Pill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  A specialist in population control testified today that sus pected complications from birth control pills are second ary to the medical and social dangers of pregnancy.

title: Marie Dunne To Be Bride
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 25  Mr. and Mrs. Leo T. Dunne have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Marie Elisabeth Dunne of Cambridge, Mass., to Enrique Jorge Tejera, son of Dr. Enrique Tejera, former Venezuelan Ambassador to the United States and now a member of the Venezuelan Congress.

title: MISS VOIKOS SCORES U.S. TENNIS UPSET
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP)Andrea Voikos of Paw tucket, R. I., a 16yearold local favorite, spiced otherwise rou tine firstround action in the national women's indoor tennis championships tonight by up setting Peggy Michel of Pacific Palisades. Calif., 64, 75.

title: SENATORS ASSAIL POLICY OF NIXON ON WAR IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Criticism of the Administra tion's Laotian policy broke out in the Senate today as Sena tor Charles McC. Mathias Jr., a freshman Republican from Maryland, charged that the Executive branch was subvert ing the will of Congress by the American military, involve ment in Laos.

title: CANADIENS BEAT PENGUINS BY 32
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 25 (UPI) Powerplay goals by Jacques Lemaire and Serge Savard to night led the Montreal Cana diens to a 32 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Army Six Blanks Dartmouth
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 25 Army's hockey team ex ploded for four goals in the final period tonight to upset Dartmouth College, 50.

title: Auto Exhaust Penalty
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 25 (UPI)  Drivers in Jackson ville will be subject to fines up to $100 if their automobile ex hausts produce visible smoke. Councilman Lynwood Roberts, in successfully urging the City Council last night to ban such discharges, said the action was needed to protect the lungs of residents 20 years from now.

title: NASSAU POOR REJECT FOOD STAMP PLAN
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 25  An overwhelming preference for Nassau County's program of free surplus food over the use of food stamps has been expressed by lowincome and welfare families in a poll con ducted by the county.

title: PRAGUE AIDE SCORES ANTISOVIET HAWKS
description: VIENNA, Feb. 25The Czech oslovak Education Minister, Jaromir Hrbek, warned in Prague today that the most aggressive antisocialist, party and antiSoviet elements were still active among stu dents.

title: NIXON ASKS HELP FOR ASIAN LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon asked the Con gress today to pledge a United States contribution of $100mil lion to the Asian Development Bank to finance expansion in Asia in the next three years.

title: Irate Californian, 75, Returns His Diploma
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 25 Marshall Maslin, a 75year old graduate of the Univer sity of California, has, re turned his diploma to protest what he calls the vulgar flimflammery behind the ac tions of the Board of Re gents.

title: VOTE BACKS SALE OF ARMOUR STAKE
description: Despite a charge that its shareholders would lose $50 million, the General Host Cor poration obtained overwhelm ing shareholder approval yes terday for the sale of its 55 per cent interest in Armour & Co., for $211million to the Greyhound Corporation.

title: Pamela Taylor, R. G. Schumann Planning Bridal
description: The engagement of Miss Pamela Taylor to Ronald Gary Schumann has been an nounced by Miss Taylor's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Gurney Taylor of New York and Center Sandwich, N. H. Dr. Schumann, a San Francisco resident, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benno Richard Schumann of Fayetteville, N. Y.

title: Credit Fraud Sentence
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP)  Federal Judge Bernard M. Decker sentenced Edward Deks nis to five years in prilson to day for his part in what the prosecution said was a $15 million credit card fraud scheme. Deksnis was among 32 persons indicted in an alleged plot to misuse credit cards. Of the others, 19 have pleaded guilty, 1 was acquitted and 11 are awaiting trial.

title: TEACHERS RATIFY PACT IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Feb. 25The 23 day Newark school strike ended tonight when teachers voted to ratify a oneyear contract agreement reached earlier in the day between the Board of Education and the Newark Teachers Union.

title: Music: Tippett Premiere
description: IT is expected that British conductors do something about British music, and Colin Davis did not disap point, last night in Philhar monic Hall. He conducted the Boston Symphony in the New York premiere of Michael Tippett's Symphony No. 2, a halfhourlong work in four movements that was composed in 1947.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE NIXON PRIORITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Senator George S. McGovern said today that Democrats must develop a coalition of con science and responsibility to offset the public relations of President Nixon.

title: Farhad Hormozi Keeps His Secret
description: Just who is Farhad Hormozi? What is this secret mes sage he promises to disclose in the Sunday editions of The New York Times and The Daily News?

title: Buding Eliminates Tiriac At Start of Macon Tennis
description: MACON, Ga., Feb. 25 (AP) Ingo Buding of France pulled an upset today in the opening round of the $15,000 Macon indoor tennis tournament by downing Ion Tiriac of Rumania, 46, 119, 75. Tiriac was the tournament's thirdseeded for eign player.

title: British Fathom May Go Overboard
description: LONDON, Feb. 25The fathom, ancient nautical measure for six feet, may soon suffer a sea change in Britain.

title: Greenawalt to Seek Nomination To Run for Attorney General
description: William S. Greenawalt, Manhattan lawyer and former Northeast regional director of legal services in the Office of Economic Opportunity, formally announced his candidacy yes terday for the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General.

title: U.S. Raids Continue in Laos After Loss of Key Airfield
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 25 United States bombers con tinued heavy attacks today in northeast Laos, especially around Muong Soui, where a LaotianAmerican air base was evacuated yesterday. The raids were designed to destroy ammunition and other supplies before they could be used by the Communistled Pathet Lao rebels and their North Viet namese allies.

title: ARMY SONGMY PANEL LISTENS TO GENERAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr., the Army's second in command in Vietnam at the time of the alleged Songmy massacre, tes tified for 40 minutes today be fore a special Army board investigating the incident.

title: GEORGETOWN PLAYS MANHATTAN TONIGHT
description: A National Invitation Tour nament bid may be the prize as Manhattan plays George town tonight in the first game of a college basketball double header at Madison Square Gar den. They are among the top independent teams in the East.

title: U.S. to Maintain 3Mile Limit Pending International Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The State Department said today it supported the 12mile limit on territorial seas but was adhering to the traditional threemile limit until interna tional agreement could, be reached.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Mets Turn Out 40 Strong for First Full Workout in Quest of Another Title
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25The New York Mets took the field today for the first time since they won the World Series last Oct. 16, and so many people turned out to watch that they created traffic jams in northwest St. Peters burg.

title: BUCKS TURN BACK BULLETS, 115113
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 25 (AP) Len Chappell, Greg Smith and Lew Alcindor starred to night as the Milwaukee Bucks rallied to beat the Baltimore Bullets, 115113, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Paterson Bids Democrats Unite Behind a Gubernatorial Choice
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25Senator Basil A. Paterson, a Harlem Democrat who is a candidate for Lieutenant Governor, said today that the liberal wing of the party should forsake its lemming syndrome and unite behind a single gubernatorial andidate.

title: Marine Concern Tied to Alleged Union Deals
description: The bistate Waterfront Corn mission of New York Harbo? has openeda new effort to strip a license from what may be the harbor's largest mar?? carpentry company. In part this stemsfrom alleged dealings with Anthony M. Scotto Brooklyn longshore union chief.

title: 2 DEMOCRATS AGREE TO FACE COALITION
description: Howard J. Samuels and Wil liam vanden Heuvel, two Demo cratic candidates for governor who have been complaining about the nominating proce dures of the New Democratic Coalition, assured N.D.C. offi cials yesterday that they would participate in the coalition's convention.

title: Miss Alliluyeva Cites Distortion In French Version of Her Book
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, has demanded the withdrawal of the French translation of her book Only One Year, an account of her flight from the Soviet Union, charging that it has been dis torted, apparently for politi cal reasons.

title: Conference in Capital
description: VIENTIANE, Feb. 25 (Reu ters)The American Ambassa dor, George Godley, was called to a conference today to dis cuss the deteriorating war situ ation in the north.

title: Freer Trade Urged For Farm Products
description: GENEVA, Feb. 25  The United States warned the world's major commercial na tions today that without some freeing of international trade in farm products the agency supervising their relations could collapse.

title: Market Place
description: No doubt about it, the National Student Market ing Corporation had a sub stantial Wall Street following.

title: Arab Governments Cooperate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25 Arab Governments are taking concerted action to counter the efforts abroad to place respon sibility on Arabs for the Swiss air disaster, according to the Baghdad radio.

title: BUSINESS AND FINANCE
description: BUSINESS AND FINANCE

title: Kings Point Five Defeats C. W. Post in Finale, 6760
description: KINGS POINT, Feb. 25 Kings Point defeated C. W. Post College, 6760, here to night. The Mariners led all the way in their season final. Kings Point's wonlost record is 13.11. The Pioneers are 1113

title: Jacobson Hits Back at Racing Officials
description: Howard (Buddy) Jacobson accused New York racing authorities yesterday of a vengeful conspiracy to drive him out of the sport and destroy his career.

title: NETS' FIVE SUBDUES COLONELS BY 117114
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Feb. 25Ed Johnson scored 8 points in less than a minute early in the fourth quarter to break open a close game and lead the New York Nets to a 117114 victory over the Ken tucky Colonels In an Americar Basketball Association game tonight at the Island Garden.

title: SovietAmerican Friendship at Sewing Machines
description: THERE were eight sewing machines and 50 women in the Palm Garden of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yes terday. The sewing machines hummed and the women spoke Russian.

title: Kentucky Teachers Backed
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 25 UPI)  National and state union officials urged 10,000 public school teachers in Ken tucky today to continue their strike until their demands for increased salaries were met. The teachers vowed that they would. About 25,000 teachers went on strike three days ago, closing schools serving more than a halfmillion children.

title: Air Activity on Suez Front
description: CAIRO, Feb. 25Egyptian fighterbombers struck Israeli positions this afternoon in the northern sector of the Sinai Peninsula near the Suez Canal.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Phouma to Seek Conference
description: VIENTIANE,Laos, Thursday, Feb. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) Premier Souvanna Phouma an nounced today that he would soon ask Britain and the Soviet nion, the cochairmen of the 1962 Geneva conference, to call a meeting of the 14 countries that signed the agreements on Laos.

title: Day Came In Like Lamb, Left With Lion's Nip
description: The tantalizing taste of spring and the nasty nip of winter were both experienced by New Yorkers yesterday.

title: Union Authorizes Strike Against Jersey Bus Line
description: INZWARK, Feb. 25Drivers and mechanics for the Public Service Coordinated Transport Company, the largest bus line in New Jersey, voted today to give their union, the Amalga mated Transit Union of New Jersey, authorization to call a strike Saturday at midnight.

title: Gromyko in Berlin Talks
description: BERLIN, Feb. 25 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today continued po litical talks with Otto Winzer, East German Foreign Minister, on the second day, of an of ficial visit.

title: Muskie Exhorts U.S. to Widen Aid to Poor Countries
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Senator Edmund S. Muskie de clared here today that the sur vival of the democratic process and of man himself might de pend on this nation's willing ness to spend more for econom ic development of the poor countries of the world.

title: Diners Club Omits Payout
description: Diners' Club, Inc., said yes terday that it was omitting the 12cent quarterly dividend on its common and preferred stock to conserve cash in view of the need to finance record credit card volume and because of poor thirdquarter results. The latest payment was made in December.

title: 16 Still Missing as Swiss Search for Slide Victims
description: GENEVA, Feb. 25Hun dreds of searchers who worked from dawn to dusk today found the body of only one of the 17 remaining vic tims of the gigantic avalanche that struck an army camp at Reckingen in southwestern Switzerland yesterday.

title: Albany Split in Passing Age18 Vote Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25The Sen ate and Assembly passed differ ing versions today of measures designed to lower the voting age in the state from 21 to 18.

title: 2 VAN GOGHS NET $2.1MILLION HERE
description: A painting by Vincent Van Gogh of cypress trees rising from a cornfield into a sky of swirling clouds brought $1.3 million at auction here last nightthe highest price ever paid for a Van Gogh.

title: PERIL DETECTED IN LEADEN SKIES
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 25On winter's day in many an Amer ican city, when a blanket of highaltitude warm air chokes off normal atmospheric circu lation, the description of leaden skies is more than a figure of speech. It suggests appropri ately a chemical analysis of a pollution problem already fast approaching the crisis point in cities such as San Diego.

title: 2 Israeli Leaders to Meet British Officials
description: LONDON, Feb. 25  The Deputy Premier and the For eign Minister of Israel will dis cuss air safety and the Middle East crisis generally with Brit ish leaders in the next few days.

title: Vorth America Insurance Elects 3 High Executives
description: The Insurance Company of North America announced yes terday that it had elected Edwin H. Marshall, John G. Paine and Frank E. Raab as executive vice presidents. All had been senior vice presidents and Mr. Raab had been president as well of Pacific Employers Insurance Company, a West Coast sub sidiary.

title: CONNECTICUT RACE DRAYS 5 IN G.O.P.
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 25 Lowell P. Weicher Jr., the fresh man Republican Representative from affluent Fairfield County entered the Senate race today.

title: Police Spy At Meeting Arouses Ire
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 25 Disclosures that policemen testified secretly before United States Senate subcom of people who attended a lec ture here by Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader, have stirred resent ment and anger in many quarters.

title: Indonesian Ends Soviet Visit
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia left here by air for Nepal today after talks on resumed Soviet economic aid.

title: DISCLOSURE LAW IS ISSUE ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 A personal holdings public dis closure law for public officials that passed the state legislature easily last year has turned out to have builtin political prob lems that may make the new law an issue in this year's Gov ernorship campaign.

title: BONNIES SET BACK CANISIUS BY 9168
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Feb. 25 (UPI) Bob Lanier scored 23 points despite playing only half the game tonight because of foul trouble to lead fourthranked St Bonaventure to a 9168 vic tory over Canisius.

title: Austria Curbs Arab Visas
description: VIENNA, Feb. 25Foreign Minister Kurt Waldheim an nounced today that Austrian consulates abroad had been in structed to request individual authorization in Vienna before issuing visas to citizens of Arab countries.

title: Advertising:Toy Buyers View Commercials
description: The outoftown buyers who are currently being given the royal treatment by toy manufacturers appear to be as interested in the advertis ing plans as in the toys them selves.

title: 5THGRADERS GET NARCOTICS LESSON
description: A 40yearold black man with 15 years of drug addiction behind him  and five drug free years sincetold 14 fifth grade boys and girls yesterday:

title: CITY TOLD TO FREE RAND SOUSING STUDY
description: The city was ordered yester day to release no later than Monday a controversial Rand Corporation housing study that reportedly includes an attack on the city's rent control policy.

title: Future of Virginia Islands Is Debated
description: CAPE CHARLES, Va., Feb. 20The future of Virginia's barrier islands, the last wild undeveloped seacoast be tween Maine and Norfolk, is again the subject of bitter debate between conserva tionists and land developers.

title: APOLLO 13 CREWMEN TO ROAM AMID HILLS
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 25 (UPI)  Fred W. Haise, a civilian astronaui assigned to the Apollo 13 moon flight, said today that he and Capt. James E. Lovell of the Navy planned to explore a hilly region of the moon, collect valuable subsur face samples, and possibly climb a mound 250 to 400 feet high

title: Lawless Sheriff
description: In denying bail to the defendants in Chicago pending appeal, Judge Julius Hoffman has continued to act in character as a man engaged in a personal vendetta. Fortunately, the case can now be expected to move speedily into more objectively judicious hands so that the defendants' rights will be assured full protection.

title: POTATO FUTURES REACH NEW HIGHS
description: Maine potato futures prices occupied the spotlight in com modities trading again yester day, as the three most active months hit new highs in heavy trading. Sales totaled 3,398 con tracts and prices closed 13 to 15 cents higher on the active months.

title: Stern Portrait of Elizabeth Includes Blemishes
description: LONDON, Feb. 25A con troversial new portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, showing her unsmiling and with marks under her mouth and on her left ear was unveiled here today.

title: Britons Offered a Week In New York for $213
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP)  British tourists can fly to New York and stay for a week for $213.60, hotel included, under a new charter plan announced today.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Fund and Church Score F.C.C.'Inertia on Hiring
description: The Federal Communications Commission was characterized as an indifferent agency ridden with inertia yester day as an effort to improve minorityoriented programing and fair employment within the broadcasting industry was an nounced jointly by the office of Communication of the United Church of Christ and the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: Woman, 70, Dies in Fire
description: A 70yearold woman was found dead after a fire in her fifthfloor apartment at 600 West 113d Street sherbly after midnight yesterday. Officials, who identified the woman as Agnes Healy, said she had been smoking in bed. The fire was confined to her apartment, where she lived alone.

title: Birth Drug Is Difficult To Control
description: After 10 years of treating women with drugs to induce fertility, doctors are better able to control the dosage, but they still cannot guaran tee that patients will have only one baby at a time.

title: U.S. ROUTS BULGARIA IN HOCKEY, 19 TO
description: BUCHAREST, Feb. 25 (AP) The favored United States team overwhelmed Bulgaria, 191, to day for its second straight vic tory in the Group B tournament of the world ice hockey cham pionships.

title: GUNN APPOINTED PUBLIC TV CHIEF
description: Hartford N. Gunn Jr., a Bos ton educational broadcaster, has been named the first president of the Public Broadcasting Serv ice, the newly created national network for public television. The 43yearold executive will assume his new post March 9 in Washington.

title: CoAuthor of 2001 Is Given a Computer
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  The Ceylonese Government today granted a special license to enable Ar thur C. Clarke, sciencefiction writer and coauthor of the movie 2001: A Space Odys sey, to import an electronic computer given to him by an American company.

title: Sports of The Time
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25The manager, Gil Hodges, was leaning against a batting cage, his cool, precise eyes snapping pictures of the Mets, when someone asked: How do they look this year? Hodges looked at the sky, glowering with the threat of rain today at 11 A.M., adjusted his mental light meter, snapped two more pictures and said: Too early to tell. Then he smiled, a private gesture that intimidates or warms people, accord ing to their moods, and added: I'll know by 2 o'clock.

title: Washington: For the Record
TwoLevel Government
description: In an era when progress in urban affairs almost by axiom implies decentralization, it is both surprising and stimulating to read the Committee on Economic Development's report on Reshaping Government in Metropolitan Areas.

title: INTEGRATION BILL GAINS IN ALABAMA
description: The Alabama Legislature gave initial approval yesterday to a school desegregation law pat terned after New York State's statute curbing busing. Four other Southern states have adopted similar measures.

title: In Memoriam
description: GREENBERGHerman. Forever In our hearts. Mother, Rita, Charles, Richard & Joan. GRUENBERGJennle. My cherished memories of you are longer than always. MARGIE KLETTERErnest, Feb. 26, 1967. Three years eternally in our hearts and thoughts.

title: Two Indicted for Homicide In Girl's Death by Heroin
description: A Bronx grand jury indicted two men yesterday for seconddegree manslaughter and criminally negligent homi cide in having given a 17yearold Barnard freshman heroin from which she died. District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said it was the first time to his knowledge that these charges had been brought in connection with deatlity nar dotics, even though the vic tim had sniffed the heroin willingly.

title: In an Exclusive Club
description: THE last time Dr. Raphael Jewelewicz allowed him self an evening's relaxation was a couple of weeks ago, when he and his wife went to the operabut he left his name at the box office, just in case, and as he said yes terday: In the back of my mind, I always had this...

title: GOVERNORS AVOID THE BUSING ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The nation's Governors moved today to keep the controversial issue of school desegregation off the agenda of their national conference, despite Southern pressure to bring it up.

title: DOCTOR IS GUILTY IN ABORTION CASE
description: NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 25 A jury of seven women and five men today convicted a 60 yearold physician of violating Connecticut's 100yearold abor tion law after the judge said that the danger of [the wom an's] possible suicide should not be considered.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: FRANK GRAHAM JR.'S Since Silent Spring (Houghton Mifflin Company, 333 Pages, $6.95) emerges with exquisite timing only a short while after the Nixon Administration's promise to wage war against pollution.

title: Shrives Says He Has Submitted His Resignation as Ambassador
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Sargent Shriver said today that he had submitted his resignation as Ambassador to France to President Nixon.

title: Library of Congress Names Stafford Poetry Consultant
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The appointment of William E. Stafford as consultant in poetry to the Library of Con gress for the 197071 term was announced today.

title: Held Up 9 Times, He Kills 2 Brothers
description: A Bronx pharmacist who had practised his marksmanship for about a year after having been the victim of nine holdups in six months shot and killed two brothers trying to rob him last night.

title: Errors and Omissions
description: The Department of Commerce reports that the United States sustained a $7billion deficit in its balance of payments in 1969the biggest liquidity deficit on record. There is one huge and innocent looking item in those figureserrors and omissions. During the first threequarters of last year these errors and omissions totaled $3.2 billion of funds leaving the United States.

title: Maravich and L. S. U. in N.I.T.; St. John's, Marquette Selected
description: Pete Maravich of Louisiana State, the greatest majorcol lege scorer in basketball his tory, is coming to the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Times Declares Dividends
description: The directors of The New York Times Company, Inc., de clared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on the Class A and Class B com mon stock, payable March 27 to stockholders of record on March 17. The board also de clared a quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 per cent cumulative prior prefer ence stock, payable April 1 to holders of record on March 17.

title: 3 POLICEMEN FREED OF BRIBERY CHARGES
description: Three city policemen were acquitted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn last night of charges that they had received bribes from gamblers in t he borough's Negro slums.

title: Books of The Times
description: PORTRAIT of the Young American as an UpperMiddleClass Idealist: Paul Cowan went to Dalton, where his grades were poor. He went to Choate, where they improved. He went to Harvard, where he was an editor of The Crimson. He dropped out, served some time at the London School of Economics, then drifted to the Middle East where he worked on an Israeli kib butz and taught English in Beer sheba. He came back to the U.S. in 1962, tutored black children one sum mer in Chester town, Md., re turned to Harvard to get his degree and enrolled in graduate school at the University of Chicago. In 1964 he was a white volunteer in the Mississippi Sum mer Project. In 1965 he married, and became a reporter for The Village Voice. In 1966 he and his wife, Rachel, joined the Peace Corps and spent two years in Ecuador. Surely the rsum of a Boy Scout on the New Fron tier, a can of sincerity as indigenous to America as our cans of frozen orange juice.

title: EXECUTIVES NAMED FOR PENN CENTRAL
description: In a realignment of top management the Penn Central Transportation Company has appointed three executive vice presidents and two senior vice presidents, Stuart T. Saunders, chairman, announced yester day.

title: Drop in Loan Cost Seen at N.I.C.B. Meeting
description: The Lincoln National Bank, a small bank in Philadelphia with some $50million in assets announced yesterday a reduc tion in its prime, or minimum interest rate on business loans to 8 per cent from 8 per cent effective next week.

title: Stock Prices Surge As Bank Cuts Rate
description: An explosive rally in the final half hour, touched off by a reduction in the prime rate by a small Philadelphia bank, sent stock prices soaring yesterday in their best performance of 1970. The DowJones industrial average ran up 13.86 points to close at 768.28 with the stock tape running three minutes late at the final bell. At 2:30 P.M., with the market apparently ready to finish an other routine day, the blue chip barometer was ahead by only 1.32 points.

title: Saul Cites Threat to Small Investor; Prime Rate Cut by Philadelphia Bank
description: Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, warned yesterday that institu tional membership on the ex change, if it became possible, might force small investors out of the stock market.

title: Slain U.S. Tourist Buried
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25 (Reu ters)Mrs. Barbara Ertle, a 31 yearold American tourist who was killed in an Arab guerrilla attack on a tourist bus Monday was buried in the American Christian cemetery here today.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Parochial School Aid

title: Academy in Rome Sees a Renascence
description: ROME, Feb. 25Members of the diverse, diverting and divided American art com munity here are slowly find ing a focus, or at least com mon ground, in the tradi tionally remote cloisters of the 76yearold American Academy in Rome.

title: Budget Aide Rebuts Pentagon Critics
description: The Nixon Administration presented its rebuttal yesterday to critics who contend that its proposals for new defense sys tems will mean a sharp increase in total Pentagon outlays.

title: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships
Dean Witter & Co. Elects Chairman
description: William M. Witter, 47 years old, was elected chair man and chief executive yes terday of Dean Witter & Co., one of the nation's largest securities houses. Mr. Witter is a son of Jean C. Witter, honorary chairman.

title: When Ethel Scull Redecorates, It Is Art News
description: ETHEL SCULL by Andy Warhol is on the road. In Plexiglas cases to protect the multiple enlarged snap shots from deterioration dur ing museum exhibitions. Ethel Scull by George Segal is at home. Sitting plaster cast immobile on the love seat in the marble hallway. Not far from two of Jasper Johns's American flags and Claes Oldenberg's stove with the papiermch sausages end rare roast beef.

title: STUDENTS ASSAIL BOARD'S POLICES
description: At a public hearing in the Klitgord Auditorium, 285 Jay Street, Brooklyn, Donald Reeves, head of the City Gen eral Organization Council, the officially recognized student government, called the meeting a sham and declared:

title: Buying of Fund Shares Up In January but Below 1969
description: Investors purchased $522, 752,000 of mutual fund shares last month, up slightly from $522,155,000 in December, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In January, 1969, purchases amounted to $875,862,000.

title: Market Place:
description: IT IS PROBABLY, true that the average man who seeks investment counsel doesn't really want it. What he really wants is an expert he can second guess. As a result, many professional investment managers spend too much time holding hands with their clients and not enough time watching stocks.

title: ITALY IS GLOOMY ON CONSERVATION
description: ROME, Feb. 26Italian of ficials acknowledged today that they had little or no money to spend on conservation, but said that they would nevertheless strive to make 1970, proclaimed as European Nature Conserva tion Year, a starting point for a serious attack on the country's grave environmental, problems.

title: House Bars a Rise In Timber Cutting
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 By a rollcall vote of 228 to 150, the House of Representa tives refused today to consid er a controversial bill to per mit increased logging in the na tional forests.

title: EMILIO S. BAS DEAD; EXFERRY MASTER, 65
description: Emilio S. Bas, who retired two years ago as master in charge of the Government ferry from the Battery to Governors Island, died Wednesday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 555 West 160th Street.

title: ST. REGIS REPORTS INCREASE IN PRICES
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices of un bleached kraft grocery bag and sack paper by $6 to $8 a ton, depending on the grade and basis weight involved.

title: CHINA SENDING AIDE TO NEPAL WEDDING
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 26Pe king has designated Kuo Mojo, a comparatively unimportant figure in the Chinese Commu nist hierarchy to represent Communist China in Katmandu at the wedding of the son of the King of Nepal tomorrow.

title: C. W. Geier Will Wed Miss Wendy Wiegers
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 26Miss Wendy Sue Wie gers, granddaughter of the late Bernarr Macfadden, the publisher, plans to be mar ried here April 25 to Corne lius Wayne Geier, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Geier of Westbury, L. I.

title: Senate Votes an Airport Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Senate passed tonight a bill that provides $5billion over 10 years to expand and improve the domestic airport and air way system. The money would be supplemented by state con tributions of $25billion.

title: Mia Farrow Has Twin Boys
description: LONDON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Mia Farrow gave birth to twin boys in London's Avenue clinic tonight. Miss Farrow and Andre Previn, the composerconductor acknowledged publicly parent hood before the birth. They are not married. The twins will be named Matthew Phineas and Sacha Villiers. Mr. Previn re cently filed a suit for divorce from his wife in Los Angeles on grounds of irreconcilable differences.

title: Kidd Is Defeated in Final Of Pro Special Slalom
description: VERBIER, Switzerland, Feb. 26 (AP)Billy Kidd of Stowe, Vt., was beaten in the final of the special slalom of a world pro ski meet today. Kidd lost to Kurt Rechner of Austria.

title: Bridge:
description: THOSE women who worry about situations in which their sex is not afforded an even break may care to note that all 44 presidents of the American Contract Bridge League have been male. The American Bridge Association, a primarily Negro group, has been similarly masculine in its 38year history, but re cently set a presidential precedent by electing Pauline Taylor of Detroit to its high est office.

title: Richmond Parkway Plan Is Accepted by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay accepted with reluctance yesterday Governor Rockefeller's de cision to run the northern seg ment of the Richmond Parkway along a route that cuts slightly into the Staten Island green belt.

title: TV: Hollywood Seen by Its Friends
description: HOLLYWOOD, experienc ing its most agonizing economic difficulties in decades, was forced to suffer another indignity last night. The history of motion pic tures from the 1900's to the present was the subject of a grotesque satire by Don Adams, the star of Get Smart, who had the incred ible presumption to believe he could do amusing take offs on all the great figures of the world of the cinema. Hooray for Hollywood, seen on the Columbia Broad casting System network, will stand as one of the season's more tawdry outings.

title: Confident Wallace Enters Race; Says Nixon Men Seek His Defeat
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 26  George C. Wallace con fidently entered the Alabama governor's race today and promptly accused the Nixon Administration of trying to arrange for his defeat.

title: Abbatiello Sets Steady Course Toward 400 Victories in Year
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 26 Carmine Abbatiello, making the Post of his skills, has prospered from a $150aweek truck driv er to a $150,000ayear driver of trotters and pacers.

title: Panel in House Bars Cuts In Wheat Support Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) A House Agriculture sub committee approved today proposed new wheat support program that would guarantee farmers against any future cuts in price supports.

title: Blatchford, Miss Saxton Score in Speed Skating
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 26 (AP) Mary Saxton and Neil Blatchford, both of Illinois, swept the ladies' and men's 500meter events today in an international speed skating meet.

title: MAY HEARINGS SET ON WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Senate hearings on a 47year old proposed constitutional amendment to guarantee equal rights for women are scheduled for May, according to Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indi ana.

title: Business Failures Decrease
description: The number of business fail ures in the United States fell to 205 in the week ended Feb. 19 from 214 in the yearearlier week, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. In the week ended Feb. 12, failures were 226.

title: Pipers Quell Late Rally And Top Colonels, 113106
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 26 (AP)  The Pittsburgh Pipers held off a late Kentucky rally and defeated the slumping Colo nels, 113106, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: COURT REINSTATES SCHOOL DISTRICTS
description: The Appellate Division re versed a State Supreme Court ruling yesterday and rein stated the proposed decen tralized school districtlines for Manhattan.

title: LIST TURNS DOWN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Most prices on the American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday in quiet trading.

title: BLACK HAWKS WIN 4TH STRAIGHT, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (UPI)Bobby Hull scored two goals tonight to give the surg ing Chicago Black Hawks their fourth consecutive victory, 32, over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

title: Article 2  No Title
DR. HOWARD H. SHIRAS
description: Dr. Howard H. Shiras, a re tired ophthalmologist, who had practiced from 1919 to 1948 in Cleveland and had headed there the eye departments of St. Vincent Charity Hospital and the City Hospital, died Monday at his home, 230 East 50th, Street. He was 85 years old and also lived in Cleveland.

title: Reforming Welfare
description: The tentative decision of the House Ways and Means Committee to approve President Nixon's plan for a Federal floor under family income reflects credit on the committee's chairman, Representative Wilbur Mills of Arkansas. Recognizing that basic surgery is necessary to overcome the deficiencies of the present welfare system, Mr. Mills was willing to submerge his own reservations to the Administration's approach.

title: S.E.C. Backs Ownership By Public of Stock Firms
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a qualified endorsement yesterday of the concept of public ownership of member firms of the New York Stock Ex change, as well as the Midwest and Pacific Coast Stock Exchanges. In separate letters to the presidents of each ex change, Hamer H. Budge, the S.E.C. chairman, made known the commission's stand on Public ownership for the first time, formally opening the way for stock exchange firms to sell their own shares to the public.

title: Florida Power Plant Told to Cool Water
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26Federal and state officials ordered Florida's biggest power company, today to curb the discharge of hot water from a generating plant into Biscayne Bay.

title: TIDE OF INFLATION EXPECTED TO EBB
description: Inflation will diminish and in terest rates will come down substantially later this year.

title: Movies Made for TV Are Gaining in Importance at Networks
description: As Hollywood dismantles its huge production studios, movies made for television, like My Sweet Charlie, are becoming the talk of the industry, and it is already apparent that they will play an increasingly im portant role in TV's immediate future.

title: Boyle to Open Own Yablonski Inquiry
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, said today that his union was under a tragic cloud of ugly alle gations concerning the murder of Josenh A. Yablonski.

title: Senegal Premier Is Named After the Post Is Restored
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  President Leopold Senghor today named Abdou Diouf, Minister of Planning and Industry, as the new Premier.

title: U.S. Census 204.3 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 26The population of the United States reached 204,354,000 on Jan. 1, an increase of 174,000 over Dec. 1, the Census Bureau re ported today.

title: Olshansky Offers Admirable Recital In Works for Piano
description: Ludwig Olshansky's Carnegie Hall piano recital Wednesday night provided a good deal to admire, including what seeme? to be an excellent performance its first in New York, of Mi chael Brozen's Fantasy (1967)

title: Manhattan Downs Georgetown, 6649, and N.Y.U. Defeats Fordham, 7066
description: It's all over for Manhattan College but the waiting. The Jaspers had to defeat Georgetown for a National In vitation Tournament bid and they did it convincingly, 6649, in the first game of a college basketball doubleheader last night at Madison Square Gar den.

title: McCarthy at Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 26 (AP)  Senator Eugene Mc Carthy, Democrat of Minnesota, will return to New Hampshire March 12, the second anniver sary of his political victory in the nation's earliest Presiden tial primary, to speak at Dart mouth College at the premiere of a documentary film on his 1968 campaign, a college spokesman said today.

title: Michigan Skiing Draws Top Jumpers
description: IRONWOOD Mich., Feb. 26 This old iron mining community near the southern banks of Lake Superior has taken on a surprising inter national atmosphere. Skiers from all parts of Europe are awaiting the start of the most spectacular ski show ever staged in the United States.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD SEEN IN JEOPARDY
description: Lindsay administration offi cials said yesterday that the Supreme Court's extension of the oneman, onevote principle to all local governing boards was a mandate for a total re evaluation of the structure of city government.

title: No Parking on the Cove
description: One hundred acres of wetlands may look like a mere scratch on the map. But when they are located on the busy boundary between Queens and Nassau Counties they mean as much as thousands of acres of national seashore in a less densely inhabited part of the country. Once yielded to a bulldozer in the name of improvement, the wildlife, the land, the marsh will be sunk forever.

title: Hanoi Units in Laos Continuing Advance
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 26 A battalion of North Vietna, mese troops was reported to day to have been sighted about 12 miles northeast of the new operational headquarters of the Americanbacked clandestine army at Long Cheng.

title: Williamson Accepts Nixon Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Nicol Williamson has ac cepted President Nixon's invi tation to appear March 19 for the third in a series of Eve nings at the White House.

title: Guerrillas in 2 Arab Lands Apply Own Discipline
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 Palestinian guerrilla organ izations have begun to apply their own discipline in Lebanon and Jordan.

title: Japan Asks Aid for Ice breaker
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26 (Reuters), Japan today called on the Unit ed States and the. Soviet Union to help her icebreaker Fuji, with 223 persons aboard, to escape thick Antarctic ice that trapped the ship yesterday. The ice breaker became trapped about 40 miles from Japan's Showa base after the four blades on one of her right propellers broke off.

title: 3 Slain in Guatemala As Elections Approach
